DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMISES TO GIVE UP ALL BUT CONSTITUTIONAL POWER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

In response to opposition calls for Chen to step down to take responsibility for a series of scandals involving senior officials and his in-laws, the president promised the premier will have "a free hand" in making decisions for the Executive Yuan, while the Democratic Progressive Party chief will have full authority to set the ruling party's policy agenda.

Chen said in a written statement issued by his office that as head of state, he would neither interfere with the policy-making of the Executive Yuan nor meddle with DPP operations, and will refrain from involvement in any political campaigns.
The president also said he and his family members will conduct themselves from now on according to the highest ethical standards, and live up to the public's expectations.

Chen said his family members have realized that as members of the first family they are subject to public scrutiny, they will never lead normal lives and that they should never interfere in governmental affairs.
In order to improve the image of his office, the president promised to reorganize the power structure of his administration.
Chen said he is a man of his word and that he is determined to carry out these promises.
Calling himself a man fully capable of self-examination, the president expressed confidence in winning back the public's trust in his administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI MEDICAL TEAM ON THE WAY TO INDONESIA TO HELP QUAKE VICTIMS(repeat)

TEXT.P: A team consisting of 18 medical personnel from three hospitals operated by a Hualien-based charity, Tzu Chi Foundation, headed for Jakarta, Indonesia Wednesday to provide relief to refugees of the May 27 earthquake.
A Tzu Chi press release said the team's members are from the foundation's hospitals in Hualien, Talin in Chiayi County and Hsintien in Taipei County.
Eight Tzu Chi volunteers are accompanying the team, which will join with 19 medical personnel from the foundation's Indonesian and Malasian chapters to offer three days of free medical services.

According to the press release, a worker at the foundation's Indonesia chapter had contacted Indonesian officials in Jakarta after the May 27 earthquake and made a fact-finding trip to Bantul, which was almost leveled to the ground by the magnitude 6.3 temblor. He told the Taiwanese foundation that medical services and daily necessities are urgently needed.
The chapter's Indonesian volunteers have already set up a medical aid station in Bantul but more medical personnel are needed, according to the foundation.
In addition to medical aid, Tzu Chi has already rushed tons of rice, cooking oil, biscuits, instant noodles and blankets to the disaster area.
According to Jakarta authorities, the earthquake has claimed the lives of more than 5,000 people, and left an estimated 200,000 homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT TO MARK NATIONAL POLICE DAY BY DONATING BLOOD(repeat)

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency plans to donate more than 1 million cubic centimeters (2,113 pints) of blood to the country's blood bank to commemorate Police Day, which falls on June 15.

According to the agency's press release, the idea was put forward by the national police chief, Hou Yu-ih, who has donated blood regularly over the past 20 years and has been cited four times by the blood bank.

In light of the fact that June 14 is designated as World Blood Donation Day and Taiwan's blood bank usually experiences a tight supply every year between July and September, the agency decided to celebrate Police Day by providing over 1 million c.c. of blood.
In a ceremony Thursday, Ho will lead senior police officers in giving blood on a blood-collection bus at the entrance of the National Police Agency in Taipei, according to the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 1, or the sixth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
2001: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issues a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial." ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET, DPP CAUCUS, PARTY TO JOINTLY MAKE POLICY UNDER NEW MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Following President Chen Shui-bian's decision to "delegate power, " all major government decisions will be jointly made by the Executive Yuan, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the party's legislative caucus, caucus convener Ko Chien-ming said late Wednesday.

The new "triangular decision-making" mechanism shows that the DPP will be even more united and unselfish when party members share their historic responsibility at this critical juncture in time, Ko said.

He called for a truce among the DPP's factions, urging them to stop their "senseless infighting" because, he claimed, only by joining forces to cope with the adversaries can they weather the party's current difficulties.

Ko was among the participants in a Presidential Office meeting during which the president, dogged by a spate of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members, announced his decision to delegate power.

Other participants in the meeting included Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, all of whom, according to Ko, "understood the president's determination and respected his decision."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO BETTER INTERACT WITH LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang told the legislature Thursday that the "ruling team" which has just been given "greater responsibility" will communicate and interact with the legislature more frequently in order to improve government operations.

Su made the pledge at the Legislative Yuan after President Chen Shui-bian, dogged by a spate of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members, announced his decision to delegate governing power late Wednesday.

According to Ko Chien-ming, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus, Taiwan's government will be run from now on under a "triangular decision making" mechanism involving the Executive Yuan, the DPP's Central Committee and the DPP legislative caucus.
Su said that he understands the president's hard work and sincerity in pursuing reforms and that he will work toward that goal so that the people will not be disappointed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT RIGHT TO 'PULL TRIGGER': KMT HEAD ON RECALLING PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that "it is time to load the gun but not yet time to pull the trigger" because there is only one chance to recall a scandal-ridden president.

Ma made the remarks in reply to media questions as to why he is opposed to pushing for a recall of the president who has been dogged by a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.
He cited KMT polls as showing that only 27 percent of the people support the idea of recalling the president, while 58 percent are opposed to it. "This is the public voice," he stressed.

However, Ma noted that he is not opposed to pushing for a recall in the future under certain circumstances. For instance, he said, if the corruption scandals "develop and burn upward" to involve the presidential couple, "I believe that more people, including Democratic Progressive Party supporters, will stand up in support of recalling the president."
Ma said he has not discussed the issue with KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan, who reportedly criticized Ma for being too reticent over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ACCUSES PRESIDENT OF VIOLATING CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's recent promise to loosen his grip on power is tantamount to admitting that he violated the Constitution and abused his power in the past, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) officials said Thursday.

They were referring to Wednesday's announcement by Chen that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president, a move which came in the wake of a series of scandals implicating officials close to him as well as his son-in-law.

Chen promised that he will neither interfere with the policy-making of the Executive Yuan nor meddle in DPP operations and will refrain from involvement in any political campaigns. Also, he pledged that the first family will conduct themselves according to the highest ethical standards to live up to the public's expectations.
According to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, it is a matter of course that the president should not enjoy any power that is not granted by the Constitution.

To show that he is truly repentant, the president should clarify to the public whether his wife, Wu Shu-jen, has had any role in the scandals, Ma said, pointing out that there have been a number of reports alleging that the first family has interfered in the personnel appointments of financial holding companies.

Meanwhile, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said the president's announcement indicates that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lacks any constitutional knowledge and any ability to conduct self-examination.
Cheng said the president, plagued by the scandals surrounding the first family, should resign immediately because he is obviously incapable of exercising his constitutional functions.

On a proposal put forth by some KMT legislators to recall Chen, Cheng said the KMT is not opposed to such a proposal but thinks that the action should be taken at the right time when there is a high degree of public consensus on the issue.

Disagreeing with the opposition party, senior DPP legislators, including Chen Chin-jun and William Lai, said they believe the president's decision was made after comprehensive deliberation and that the DPP must unite to back him up.
They urged the public to give the president their encouragement.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Ho Min-hao, who also heads the party's policy committee, said Chen's announcement is commendable but that the timing is wrong.
Ho expressed his concern that the announcement will be taken advantage of by the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" to promote its campaign to recall the president.
Ho suggested that the president address the deficiencies of the Constitution by constitutional amendments or the drafting of a new constitution for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEN ISLAND TO HAVE 100% RENEWABLE ENERGY BY 2035

TEXT.P: The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) is planning to renovate power-generating systems on Green Island by using renewable energy sources rather than non-renewable fuels, in hopes of making the outlying island truly "green" by the year 2035, an AEC official said Thursday.
The official said that currently, there are only coal-power units on Green Islands, which are not only costly but also environmentally unfriendly.

He noted the AEC will carry out the plan in two stages. Up until the year 2015, the power supply will be using 60 percent renewable energy at an estimated cost of NT$4 billion (US$1.25 million), while by the year 2035, Green Island will enjoy a 100 percent "green" power supply at an additional cost of NT$10 billion.
According to the AEC, in the first stage, the power supply will rely on wind and solar energies, and in the second, power systems using geothermal and ocean thermal energies will be established.

He explained that although Green Island's geographical conditions are highly suitable for the generation of geothermal and ocean thermal power, the technology for using these energies is still primitive.
As a result, he said, the AEC decided to delay establishing facilities that require these energies, and to wait for the necessary technologies to mature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TRAMPLING ON CONSTITUTION BY DELEGATING POWER TO DPP: MA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 1 (CNA) (By Timothy J. Hwang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Claiming that President Chen Shui-bian's decision to delegate power to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweights amounts to "trampling on the Constitution, " opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday he totally disagrees with Chen's power-sharing plan.
The president declared during a senior officials meeting Wednesday that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.
In order to improve the image of his office, the president promised to reorganize the power structure of his administration.
In reply to media inquiries, Ma said the president has not clarified everything about the first family's suspected roles in some of the scandals.
"It is absurd to delegate the power of presidency, " Ma said, since a president will be charged with dereliction of duty if he gives up his constitutional power which simply cannot be delegated.

As for the power that a president has not been given constitutionally, there is nothing for him to give up or to delegate, Ma said, citing the example of the first family's alleged interference in the merger of financial holding companies.

The only thing for the president to do now is to tell the truth about the whole story of every scandal in which his family members are suspected of involvement, Ma said, adding "this is the only way for him to possibly win back any remaining respect of the people."
Otherwise, he warned, the situation will continue to worsen for the president and his family.
He urged the president to "make the best choice for himself" at a time when his credibility has been severely damaged.

Ma asked, for example, "if Chen visits a foreign country now, will he have the respect of the foreign head of state? And if he receives an ambassador from a foreign country, can he win the ambassador's respect?
"And if he presents medals for outstanding achievement or contribution, will the winners accept the medals as an honor? " Ma further asked.
"Even if Chen cites a great hero or heroine who has passed on, will the bereaved family accept the citation?" Ma continued.
"These are all presidential duties, which Chen can hardly execute with dignity, " Ma said, calling for the president to "know what is the best choice to make."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ADOPTING 'BLUE OCEANS STRATEGY': VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that President Chen Shui-bian was adopting "the blue oceans strategy" when he announced his decision to delegate power during a senior officials meeting the day before.

The book "Blue Oceans" is a best seller in Taiwan. The main theme of the book is winning not by competing but by creating "blue oceans" to explore undeveloped markets in which competitors cannot hope to catch up.
Lu said the important thing for ruling party members now is to take up their share of responsibility.

Chen, who has been dogged by a spate of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members, declared Wednesday that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

Chen said in a written statement issued by his office that as the head of state, he will neither interfere with the policy-making of the Executive Yuan nor meddle with DPP operations, and will refrain from getting involved in any political campaigns.
In response to media inquiries, Lu stressed it is very clear from the president's statement that everyone within the party and the government should "shoulder his or her responsibility."
As for her future position, Lu noted that her duty will be to serve as vice president until her term ends May 19, 2008.
Lu denied a media report that the president was unhappy with a meeting of party and government officials called by her.
"I've reported everything to the president. He is not unhappy with me," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX RETURNS FILED ONLINE HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: A total of 2.06 million tax payers have filed their income tax returns online as of Thursday, the last day that filing is accepted for this year, Ministry of Finance officials said.
The figure exceeds the target of 2 million set by the ministry and is the highest since online tax filing was launched in the country, the officials said.

Of the 2.06 million cases, 762,861 have been received by the National Tax Administration of Northern Taiwan Province, 499,936 by the National Tax Administration of Central Taiwan Province, and 396,803 by the National Tax Administration of Southern Taiwan Province, they said.
The Taipei National Tax Administration and Kaohsiung National Tax Administration have received 267,942 cases and 133,171 cases, respectively, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 25.89 points to close at 6,872.84.
The bourse opened at 6,874.66 and fluctuated between 6,922.34 and 6.868.42 during trading. A total of 2.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.66 billion (US$2.86 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1 percent, construction issues at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.3 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down at 1.2 percent and plastics and chemicals shares dropping 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 399 to 380, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGISTRATE URGES BETTER COORDINATION AFTER PRESIDENT DELEGATES POWERS

TEXT.P: A better coordination mechanism must be fleshed out between the government and the ruling party now that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to delegate power in government and party affairs, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Thursday.
Su made the appeal afte Chen announced his decision a day earlier to delegate governing powers and party authority in the wake of a slew of scandals implicating his son-in-law and close aides.

Since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power six years ago, Su said government operations have been dogged by poor coordination among the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the party central.
"If this deficiency cannot be corrected, the president's delegation of power will not resolve the problems faced by the DPP administration," said Su, a DPP legislator-turned-magistrate.

In the past, Su claimed, the Presidential Office often played a key role in government personnel appointments which consequently hobbled the Executive Yuan's policy implementation with some Cabinet ministers subject to the Presidential Office's direct control. As a result, he lamented that the local governments often had difficulties conveying their opinions to policy-making authorities.
Poor coordination and insufficient policy integration have also hindered the formation of national consensus on major policy issues, Su said.

For instance, the DPP headquarters has so far failed to extensively discuss the much-talked-about issue regarding direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait, Su said, adding that the issue is too crucial to be decided by only a handful of party bigwigs.

Su suggested that President Chen be more magnanimous and focus on policy coordination and integration instead of personnel arrangements. It is also hoped that the president can keep the door open to opinions from all sectors of society and even constructive criticism and never again restrict his source of information to a few personal aides, he added.

To the best of his knowledge, Su said, President Chen faces pressure to quit the party. In his view, Su said it would not be a wise strategy to force Chen to leave the party at this moment for what some critics say saving the DPP's image. He stressed that the best way to weather the political crisis faced by the DPP is for the president and the premier to do more on policy coordination and integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEC WORKING TO BOOST RATIO OF TAIWAN'S 'SELF-PRODUCED' ENERGY SOURCES

TEXT.P: As Taiwan relies on imports to meet 98 percent of its energy needs, the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) is working on a "blueprint on future power supply" with the aim of boosting the ratio of Taiwan's "self-produced" energy supplies from the current 2 percent to 30 percent by 2050, an AEC official said Thursday.

According to an AEC report, currently, coal plants comprise 43. 15 percent of Taiwan's power supply, nuclear plants 20.9 percent, natural gas ones 19.14 percent, oil ones 6 percent, cogeneration plants 7.17 percent, while renewable energies comprise 3.61 percent.

According to the official, only 2 percent of Taiwan's energy sources are deemed as "self-produced" -- relying on local sources only, and 20 percent are "self-manageable" -- indicating sources that are either under long-term supply contracts or under mining cooperation agreements between Taiwan and the export countries.

The official added that aside from increasing the percentage of self-produced energy sources, the government is also planning to expand the share of self-manageable ones to 70 percent by 2050 to establish a more secure power supply system.

AEC research laboratories have been working on renewable energy technologies in areas such as wind power, solar power, geothermal utilization and ocean thermal conversion to achieve the 30 percent goal, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO FILE LAWSUITS FOR UNFOUNDED REPORTS ABOUT 'POSTS BUYING'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will file lawsuits against rumor mongers who spread rumors defaming military authorities, MND spokesman Wu Chi-fang said Thursday.

Wu made the remarks after news reports saying that former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan, who is currently being detained in a bribery and corruption investigation, had used his influence to secure the promotion of several high-ranking military officers in exchange for a handsome sum of money.
Wu stressed that the promotion of all military personnel has to pass a transparent, rigid and fair process and that there is no possibility of "buying posts" as some news reports claimed.
"Even Defense Minister Lee Jye cannot use his influence in the promotion of military personnel," Wu added.
Lee said recently that there was absolutely no pressure and influence peddling involved in the promotion of high-level military personnel.

According to Wu, since the publication of such news reports, the MND has asked judicial authorities to help investigate the issue and has held a press conference to explain the regulations governing personnel promotion in the three branches of the armed forces.
"The rumors have damaged the reputation of related people and the military," Wu said.
As the competition in obtaining high-level military posts is very fierce, Wu said, he can completely understand the depression experienced by those who don't secure promotions.

However, the MND will lodge a strong protest against the persons who publish such unfounded rumors that slander generals and damage the military's image, and will consider filing lawsuit against them, Wu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-VIOLET ALLIANCE CALLS FOR TAX REBATE AGAINST CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice, also known as the Pan-violet Alliance, called Thursday for public backing of a national tax rebate campaign against government corruption, saying that the wastefulness has cost taxpayers dearly nationwide.

Pan-violet Alliance convener Chien Hsi-chieh issued the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference. Some lawmakers from different parties, including main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Lai Hsin-yuan were also present to lend their support.

Chien demanded the government rebate NT$14,246 in taxes to each household due to what he claimed a misuse of budgets and several high-profile corruption scandals that have drained national coffers at least NT$70.8 billion (US$2.2 billion).

Taxpayers are entitled to a clean government and want to wipe out corruption by checking the facts, Chien said, urging the public to back the tax rebate campaign. Members of the "pan-violet alliance" will submit a petition to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) next Monday to state the cause of the initiative.
Lee accused the government of fostering special interest groups while turning a blind eye to many people living in poverty or even committing suicide.
Lai insisted the government must not waste the people's hard-earned money, saying members of the public must be fully aware of their rights and ask for a clean government.
In a related development, the MOF has received a record number of over 2.06 million income tax returns filed over the Internet as of June 1 -- the deadline for income tax filing.
The number has beat the ministry's target of 2 million cases, with the national tax administration in northern Taiwan receiving the largest number of electronic applications, MOF officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY CONFAB HINGES ON DIRECT LINKS BILL: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that the passage of a bill allowing direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links would be a decisive factor in the success of a planned conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth.

Quoting remarks made Wednesday by Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Central Policy Committee, Wang said if the draft amendments allowing direct transport links between Taiwan and China continue to be boycotted in the Legislature, the KMT would have no reason to take part in the economic sustainability conference being organized by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.

Lawmakers from the "pan-green camp" of the ruling DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union have continued to filibuster legislative sessions over the past two weeks to block the KMT-led opposition -- which controls a slight majority in the Legislature -- from putting the direct links bill to a vote.

Wang said he is pessimistic about the fate of the planned conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth since lawmakers from the two rival sides have failed to make any headway on negotiations on the direct links bill over the past two weeks, with both sides refusing to compromise and remaining deeply divided on the issue.
The opposition People First Party, which initiated the draft legislation, had insisted that the bill had to be passed before the end of the legislative session.

The legislative session concluded Wednesday without a vote. Opposition lawmakers have made "handling the direct links bill" a condition to the administration's call for convening an extraordinary legislative session to deal with initial budget bills.

The conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth has been postponed until July so the government will have more time to prepare the agenda and seek support from opposition parties for the meeting, Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Thursday.
A preparatory meeting of the conference was also postponed from June 3 to June 10, Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO BE RESHUFFLED SOON: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: Personnel in senior government posts will soon be adjusted, Secretary-General Tan Sun-chen of the Presidential Office said Thursday.

Former premier Frank Hsieh, who was absent from a senior officials meeting in which President Chen Shui-bian announced his decision to delegate executive power, said it would be nice if the president reallocated responsibility so the government can get back to normal operations.
President Chen said Wednesday that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

The president also promised the premier will have "a free hand" in making decisions for the Executive Yuan, while the Democratic Progressive Party chief will have full authority to set the ruling party's policy agenda.

Tan Sun Chen claimed that the president was very calm and determined at yesterday's meeting in which he did not mention reshuffling the government. The senior aide stressed that the president is not a lame duck.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said the president's announcement had nothing to do with the 2008 presidential election, as its main purpose was to respond to public expectations.
Bringing government operations back to normal is a good thing, as it would allow the Cabinet more authority in setting economic policy and improving social order, he added.

As for his absence from Wednesday's meeting at the Presidential Office, Hsieh asked the media not to exaggerate the incident, saying it was not very convenient for him to get car service during the Dragon Boat festival.

In order to solve a dilemma for the DDP, Central Standing Committee member Cheng Pao-ching asked the president not only to delegate power but also share power with opposition parties by forming a coalition Cabinet.
The DDP Legislator Kao Chih-peng said all party members should work together to tide over the current difficulties before the party can get back on its feet again.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO PRESS AHEAD WITH DRIVE TO RECALL PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) vowed Thursday to press ahead with its campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian, despite the president's recent promise to loosen his grip on executive power and uphold the highest ethical standards.
PFP Chairman James Soong said that as an opposition party, the PFP must not remain silent and must do something to rein in what he called a "corrupt ruling Democratic Progressive Party."

The PFP will organize a demonstration in front of the Presidential Office this Saturday to demand Chen step down, to renounce his presidential immunity and to facilitate judicial investigations into a series of scandals involving senior officials in Chen's administration and his son-in-law, Soong said.
Also, Soong urged the Kuomintang to fulfill its responsibility as an opposition party and join the PFP's campaign to recall Chen.
Soong said Chen's promise shows the DPP lacks any ability for self-examination and has severely damaged the country's constitutional system.
Soong pointed out that the power of the executive is clearly defined in the Constitution and not something that can be allotted, traded or decided arbitrarily by the ruling party.
On Wednesday, Chen announced he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

Chen promised that he will neither interfere with the policy-making of the Executive Yuan nor meddle in DPP operations and will refrain from involvement in any political campaigns. Also, he pledged that the first family will conduct themselves according to the highest ethical standards and live up to the public's expectations.

According to PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping, while Chen is reluctant to resign in order to take responsibility, he made the move in an attempt at damage control, as it seems likely the corruption scandals will snowball to implicate other members of the first family besides Chen's son-in-law.
Hsieh said it is against the principle of democracy to allow the premier, who is not elected by the people, to enjoy full administrative power.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING WINS NEW ORDER WORTH NT$30 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) has won an order worth approximately NT$30 billion (934.28 million) from a German shipping company, CSBC officials said Thursday.
The order, placed by Dole (IOM) Ltd. for 12 container vessels, is the largest the CSBC has ever received, the officials said.
Under the contract signed between both sides, the 12 vessels are set to be delivered between 2009 and 2010, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Probe Into Iraq Deaths Finds False Reports; Pentagon to Review Training After Alleged Massacre in Haditha.
The U.S. military investigation of how Marine commanders handled the reporting of events last November in the Iraqi town of Haditha, where troops allegedly killed 24 Iraqi civilians, will conclude that some officers gave false information to their superiors, who then failed to adequately scrutinize reports that should have caught their attention, an Army official said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SUES LAWMAKER OVER ALLEGED SLANDER

TEXT.P: An Army lieutenant general who was accused by an opposition lawmaker of gaining promotion to his current rank by bribing an aide of President Chen Shui-bian filed a slander suit Thursday against the accusing legislator.

After a news conference organized by the Ministry of National Defense, Lieut. Gen. Hsu Tai-sheng, director of the Joint Inspection Office under the Ministry of National Defense, went to the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office and filed suit with prosecutors in front of news media.

Hsu said at the news conference that as a career military officer he was shocked and angered by People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao's "groundless" claim that he gave NT$8 million (US$249,057) to then deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, Chen Cheh-nan, in return for a promotion in 2003.

"By airing baseless allegations, the lawmaker has not only tarnished my reputation but also damaged the credibility of the Ministry of the National Defense, and my personal silence on the charge would be considered tacit acknowledgement of it," Hsu said.
Hsu was one of several examples cited by Chang on May 30 to support his claim that President Chen Shui-bian's administration has been riddled with corruption.
Several other retired generals were quoted by Chang as complaining they quit the armed forces after having refused to "buy an advancement" in their careers.
Hsu said Chang has insulted all senior military officers by insinuating they have obtained their posts through bribery.

Hsu's decision to file suit has the backing of the Ministry of National Defense, which denied through its spokesman Wu Chi-fang at Hsu's news conference that there have been any cash-for-promotion cases in the armed forces.
He also denied the existence of what the lawmaker called "Bian's army" in the armed forces, consisting of a clique of officers who have close personal ties with President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROMISES WIDE OPENING UNDER 'ACTIVE MANAGEMENT' FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Thursday that the government will open Taiwan as much as it can in bilateral exchanges with China under the "active management, effective opening" policy.

Su made the remarks at a Dragon Boat Festival gathering with China-based Taiwanese businesspeople, which was also attended by officials from the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Straits Exchange Foundation and the Chinese National Federation of Industries.

Su's remarks came after President Chen Shui-bian's decision the previous night to delegate power to the Executive Yuan after a series of corruption scandals allegedly implicating his senior aides and family members drew attacks from opposition parties and even the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Based on the principles of "Taiwan sovereignty" and "policy flexibility, " the government hopes to proceed more effectively on many issues, such as opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists.
The government has been working on the issue since 2001, but China's lack of cooperation has led to limited progress, Su pointed out.

Although the government must take precautions against all possible senarios while opening Taiwan to China, he said that Taiwan must also have confidence in its dealings with China -- a confidence that has been a decisive factor in making Taiwan a hub of international trade over the past 400 years.

As a national economic conference on sustainable growth will be held next month, the government hopes to incorporate the views of Taiwan business operators and find ways to address their problems, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STARTING SALARY FOR MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS LEADS ALL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The average entry-level salary of NT$31,479 for medical and bio-chemical professionals has for the first time surpassed that of information technology workers, whose average starting monthly salary is NT$29,914, according to a survey by 104 Job Bank.

The online employment service released the results of its survey "2006 post-secondary graduates employment and starting salaries," which found the average starting salary in the finance and insurance industries is NT$28,651, while those in the export and import business and traditional manufacturing industries are NT$27,921 and NT$27,801, respectively.
All these industries offer a better entry-level salary to young graduates than other industries, whose average wages amounted to NT$27,446, according to the survey.
Compared by job, engineering research and development offers the best starting salary at an average NT$30,844 a month, the third year it has retained this position.

Engineering R&D was followed by system software engineering, which offers an average starting salary of NT$30,728, hardware communications (NT$29,521), marketing planning (NT$28,561) and sales (NT$28,501). The average for all engineering jobs was NT$28,307.

The young graduates include those from professional colleges, universities and graduate schools. These three levels of higher education receive average starting salaries of NT$25,849, NT$28,212, and NT$31,092, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.091 to close at NT$32.110.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.120 and fluctuated between NT$32.005 and NT$32.120.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 ILLEGAL WORKERS FROM VIETNAM AWAITING DEPORTATION

TEXT.P: Fourteen illegal Vietnamese workers detained in May by police in Puli township, Nantou County, will be sent back to their own country, a police spokesman said Thursday.
The spokesman said the Vietnamese nationals -- 11 women and three men -- are all runaway migrant workers who changed employers without permission.
Police arrested them after finding them working in six different locations, including motels, restaurants and construction sites.
According to the Employment Service Act, foreign workers who work for employers other than those prescribed on their work permits will be thrown out of Taiwan.
Under the revised regulations of the Council of Labor Affairs that became effective April 20, the six employers who hired the workers could face fines of between NT$150,000 and NT$750,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG ESTABLISHES TASK FORCE TO FIGHT RIVER POLLUTION

TEXT.P: The Keelung City Government plans to establish a cross-departmental task force aimed at fighting pollution in rivers running through the city, a municipal government spokesman said Thursday.
With the creation of the taskforce, Keelung City hopes to improve both the quality of river water as well as drinking water, the spokesman said.

A meeting on the task force's creation gathered a wide range of officials Thursday from the Keelung City Government at the Water Resource Agency, under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, to announce the city government's mid-term and long-term plans to improve Keelung's water quality.
The spokesman said the city government's previous efforts have already contributed to helping clean up Keelung's rivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREPARATORY MEETING OF ECONOMIC CONFAB TO BE HELD JUNE 10

TEXT.P: Minister-without-portfolio Hu Sheng-cheng said Thursday that a preparatory meeting for a national economic conference will be postponed until June 10, hoping the goodwill gesture will lure opposition parties to take part in the meeting.
Hu made the announcement while reporting on the economic sustainability conference slated for July 11-12.

Noting the bitter scuffling between ruling and opposition parties over the opposition-proposed amendments of a law allowing direct cross-strait transportation links on Tuesday, Hu said he hopes the postponement will help bring opposition parties to the conference.

After the melee Tuesday -- the last day of the current legislative session -- some opposition lawmakers have threatened to boycott the conference after the direct links amendment proposals again failed to pass in the legislature.

The July conference is scheduled to discuss five topics: enhancing the social security system, upgrading industrial competitiveness, financial reform, accessing global markets and cross-strait trade, and improving government efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WILL NOT TAKE PART IN PRESIDENTIAL RECALL RALLY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that the time is not ripe to recall President Chen Shui-bian and that he will not partake in a rally slated for Saturday to demand Chen's resignation.

At an interpellation session at the Taipei city council, Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, reiterated that "it is still not time to pull the trigger" in terms of pushing for a recall of Chen, who has been dogged by a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.

The opposition People First Party (PFP) vowed Thursday to press ahead with its campaign to recall Chen, despite his recent promise to loosen his grip on executive power and uphold the highest ethical standards.
The demonstration will be part of the presidential recall campaign launched by the PFP, which forms the opposition "pan blue alliance" with the KMT and the tiny New Party.

Discounting Ma's refusal to take part, New Party City Councilor Hou Kuan-chun likened Ma to legendary Buddhist monk Sanzang of the Tang Dynasty, who was unable to do anything but pray and call for mercy in the face of bugs and goblins. Hou claimed that Ma is "failing the public's expectation" by not supporting the campaign.

However, Ma defended himself by saying that as leader of the main opposition party he must be responsible and prudent in answering the public's expectations. He also quoted a recent public opinion poll as indicating that despite Hou's claims, only 30 percent of the respondents supported a recall of Chen but some 60 percent were against the idea.

Ma told all members of the opposition parties that timing is a crucial issue in terms of a recall of the head of state. "Once we do it, we must do it successfully. Otherwise, we'd better wait, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU ASKS FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION AND LEGISLATIVE REFORM

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislator Thursday reaffirmed the party's call for an extraordinary legislative session, while insisting major bills affecting people's livelihood be included for review.

Huang Shih-cho, convener of the TSU's legislative caucus, made the remarks after the Legislative Yuan failed to pass major bills related to the public's welfare, such as several budget plans for expanding infrastructure construction and flood-control projects, in the just-concluded legislative session, which ended tumultuously Tuesday.
Huang strongly criticized the lack of efficacy in the legislature, and blamed legislators for the chaotic situation in society.

Citing a report on international competitiveness conducted by the world's leading business school, Swiss-based IMD International, Huang said the legislature's inefficiency has seriously impacted Taiwan's development.

In view of the legislative impasse, Huang said, the TSU legislative caucus demanded the proposed extra session not handle the bill on direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links as well as an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian over a spate of corruption scandals allegedly involving members of the first family and his senior aides.

Describing the legislature as "the source of chaos in society, " Huang said the TSU will ask Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng -- who will hold a meeting with representatives of both ruling and opposition parties Friday to decide whether to convene an extraordinary legislative session -- to add "legislative reform" to the proposed session's agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA MINISTER VOWS TO PROMOTE TAIWANESE AGRICULTURE ABROAD

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Su Jia-chyuan reiterated Thursday the government's intention to promote Taiwan's agricultural goods on the foreign market.

Su made the statement at a meeting of farmers and fishermen association chairmen in the southern city of Kaohsiung. He added that it is the government's duty to provide assistance to farmers in order to produce good quality agricultural goods and help farmers to market their products.

Su said the COA will make sure within three years that every consumer will be able to trace the record of farm produce they buy -- whether it is sold in local supermarkets or shipped to other countries -- to the farmer who produced it.
He said that an agricultural product produced here will have all the procedures it went through listed, including the fertilizer used and its sale procedure, in order to assure its quality.
Su added that the government subsidizes local agricultural marketing expenditure abroad and hopes to see an annual 10 percent increase in exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DISRUPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT POLICY: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday that there will be no disruption of current cross-Taiwan Strait policy following President Chen Shui-bian's announcement the previous day that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

In response to opposition calls for Chen to step down to take responsibility for a series of scandals involving senior officials and members of his family, the president promised that the premier will have "a free hand" in making decisions for the Executive Yuan. As head of state, he will neither interfere with the policy-making of the Executive Yuan nor meddle with the operations of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, he said.

The media asked after Chen's announcement who will have the final say on cross-strait policy -- which used to be the president -- at a gathering of Taiwan businessmen who had returned from China for Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on May 31 this year.

Wu said the Constitution and the Organic Law of the National Security Council clearly define cross-strait policy and he added that the MAC will adhere to it and that there will be no disruption in the current cross-strait policy.

He also said that the "active management, effective opening" policy regarding cross-strait economy and trade that Chen announced earlier to replace the "active opening, effective management" policy will continue, saying that it was a result of long-term discussion.
"This major policy will remain unchanged, " Wu said, adding that it is important that the policy "will give people a sense of stability."
Asked whether Chen will still orchestrate cross-strait policy, Wu said only that the MAC will operate within the framework of the Constitution.
The MAC is not in a position to speak on how to share the power or who will take the lion's share of responsibility in policy-making, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$180,000 TO WTO FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECTS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 1 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated US$180,000 recently to the Doha Development Agenda Global Trust Fund (DDAGTF) of the World Trade Organization (WTO) for technical assistance and training projects for developing countries that are WTO members, a WTO official said Thursday.

Taiwan has donated a total of US$738,000 to the fund since its admission to the organization in 2002. The fund is aimed at extending technical assistance and helping developing countries to fully participate in the Doha Development Agenda.
WTO Director-General Pascal Lamy expressed gratitude for Taiwan's donation, saying that technical assistance is one of the benefits enjoyed by WTO developing or least-developed member countries.
In addition to reducing the weaknesses of such WTO member countries, the technical assistance will help establish a multilateral trade system that is more balanced and stable, Lamy said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CHENGKUNG UNIVERSITY RECRUITS STUDENTS FROM AFRICA

TEXT.P: National Chengkung University in southern Tainan City published Thursday a list of 279 qualified candidates for its Ph.D and masters courses in the coming academic year, with students from Africa listed for the first time.
According to a spokesman for the university, the first African students passing its examinations for advanced study are from South Africa and Gambia.

Most of the eligible students are from Southeast Asian countries such as Indonesia, Vietnam and Malaysia, while quite a few come from Japan, South Korea, the United States, Britain, Canada, Russia, Spain, Germany, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Kazakhstan, Paraguay, Honduras and Australia, the spokesman said.

In a bid to make it into a world-class university, National Chengkung University has been sharpening its competitiveness on various fronts, including recruiting foreign students, he said, noting that a record high of foreign students took part in the university's entrance examinations this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGULAR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS DUE IN FIVE MONTHS: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday that opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists and establishing regular passenger charter flights between Taiwan and China could be worked out in four or five months.

Wu made the remarks during a Dragon Boat Festival gathering with China-based Taiwan businessmen in which Premier Su Tseng-chang and officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Straits Exchange Foundation and the Chinese National Federation of Industries also took part.
Wu was given a round of enthusiastic applause when he said that "the two issues are proceeding smoothly" and that "related work should be completed in four or five months."

Commenting on a national economic conference on sustainable growth slated for next month, Wu said the government is keen to forge a broader consensus to craft policies of major national concern in the future. The MAC is willing to heed the opinions of Taiwan businessmen, he added.

"After a thorough review, the government will initiate more openings based on the principles of 'Taiwan sovereignty' and 'policy flexibility' following instructions by Su on cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, "he said.

"Cross-Taiwan Strait passenger charter flights are mutually beneficial and should not be limited only to the Lunar New Year holiday season, " he said, expressing his confidence that "there should be good news" by the time the next Lunar New Year arrives.

Wu also expressed the hope that he will be able to the take part in the June 8 inauguration of ferry links between Taiwan-held Kinmen island and Quanzhou in China's Fujian Province -- the third route of its kind in addition to the Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping lanes.

The MAC head urged China in April to wrap up tourist and regular passenger charter flight talks with Taiwan within six months. He claimed that Taiwan might unilaterally announce the two opening measures should relevant arrangements and preparations have been completed by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMANS SHOULD `RESUME CLOSE TIES WITH SUN': ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: Humans are nearing a dead end after relying on underground fossil fuel for two centuries since the Industrial Revolution while distancing themselves from the biological arena and the Sun, Taiwan's top academic said Thursday.

During a speech delivered at National Taiwan Normal University (NTNU), Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh called for mankind to resume close ties to the Sun, which he said beams energy to the Earth by an amount that each hour is tantamount to the amount of energy that the entire global population consumes for a whole year.

Lee called for Taiwan people, including the NTNU faculty and students, to be the "masters" of the nation who give the government the best advice on energy policy and seriously push for cuts in emissions of CO2 so as to do their duties as world citizens.
He said that globally, people should strive to raise energy efficiency and review their population policies.

For Taiwan, he said, at least three things should be done immediately. First, he said, as a member of the global village, Taiwan must reduce emissions of greenhouse gases and must improve waste water handling, a situation he described as the worst of its kind in the whole of Southeast Asia.
Second, there must be a clear and workable energy policy that will enable Taiwan to save energy in the coming three decades, he said.

Third, he said, Taiwan must speed up research on renewable energy and develop new energy resources, pointing out that technologies that transform solar power into electricity have been available around the world and that the world would not need fossil fuel any longer if just 1 percent of the world's land was used as a base to transform solar light and power into electricity. Taiwan could also develop other energy resources, including wind power, geothermal power and sea current power, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPROVES RESIGNATIONS OF TWO RIGHT-HAND MEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian approved the resignations of two of his right-hand men Thursday in an effort to reorganize his inner circle to facilitate political reform after a string of debilitating corruption scandals allegedly implicating his son-in-law and administration officials.

The Presidential Office said in a press release that Ma Yung-cheng, a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, and Lin Chin-chang, a National Security Council advisory member, tendered their resignations earlier in the day, both of which were approved by the president.

Their resignations came a day after Chen pledged to give full power to Premier Su Tseng-chang to control the Executive Yuan and to refrain from meddling with the affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The president also pledged in a written statement issued late Wednesday that he and his family members will "conduct themselves according to the highest ethical standards and live up to the public's expectations."
Chen's statement was issued amid rising calls in both the DPP and the opposition for the president to take responsibility for a series of scandals embroiling his family and administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAWMAKER ACCUSES FORMER CLA CHAIRWOMAN OF HIDING TRUTH

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) candidate for Kaohsiung mayor criticized his rival from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Thursday for harboring an ulterior motive by hiding the truth when she quit her post as chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) last year.

Legislator Lo Chih-ming, who will represent the TSU in the year-end mayoral race in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, told a press conference that former CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu, who resigned to take responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot by Thai workers last year, never explained who reversed the government policy that banned the hiring of foreign laborers for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit railway project.

Chen admitted to news media shortly after the riot that the policy of hiring only domestic workers was reversed after an "influential figure" had intervened. She did not reveal the identity of this "influential figure."

Lo claimed that Chen herself and National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Chiou I-jen were the "influential figures" who reversed the policy and contributed to the rioting by Thai workers to protest their poor treatment by their employers -- the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KTRC) -- and a labor brokerage firm.

He pointed out that in a notice dated May 10, 2001, the CLA rejected a KTRC application to import foreign laborers on the grounds that construction contracts awarded after May 16, 2001 were not allowed to use foreign labor.
The KTRC applied again in September 2001 to import Thai workers and the CLA approved its request in December and informed the Presidential Office of its decision, Lo said.

Lo claimed that the reason for the policy about-face was to please the Thai authorities in the hope that Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica and winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, would receive high-profile treatment at the 2003 summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Bangkok.

The TSU legislator also claimed that after Chen's remarks about the "influential figure, " most people took her to be referring to Chen Che-nan, who wielded considerable influence while serving as deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office in 2000-2004.

According to Lo, Chen Chu's remarks did far greater damage to then-acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, son of Chen Che-nan, than to herself because she ruined the political future of a would-be rival in the Kaohsiung mayoral race who enjoyed a higher approval rating than herself.
Lo's attacks on Chen Chu followed a first wave of criticism he leveled last week when he labeled her as "dishonest" and "unqualified" to be mayor.
In response, Chen Chu pointed out that Lo's claims were merely speculation. She told Lo that the candidates of the "pan-green camp," consisting of the DPP and the TSU, should not attack each other.
The NSC secretary-general also declined to comment on the "untrue claims."

Chen Chu appears set to become the DPP's nominee in the year-end election after winning a DPP primary, but Lo claims to have a better chance of winning the Kaohsiung mayoral election than her if he can represent the "pan-green camp."
Lo vowed to stay in the race and "fight to the end" even if Chen is unwilling to yield.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AWARD-WINNING BARTENDER TO TEACH IN SRI LANKA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's award-winning bartender Tsai Wen-hao has been invited to teach the art of cocktail-making in Sri Lanka, the Bartenders Association of Taiwan (BAT) said Thursday.

Tsai was the champion in the "flair tender" group of the ninth and the 10th Golden Cup Cocktail competitions. He also won championship in the 2004 Hong Kong contest and the 2005 Asian Cup championship competition.
He will represent Taiwan in this year's 55th World Cocktail Competition in Greece.
Taiwan is strong in the field of "flair tender" cocktail making and the southern port city of Kaohsiung will host the 2007 World Cocktail Competition.

The 2006 Golden Cup International Cocktail Competition took place in early May at the Kaohsiung Cultural Center with a three-day competition among more than 500 entrants competing in six groups, including eight finalists from Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN FOR CABINET RESHUFFLE: GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The performance of the Cabinet has improved after four months of adjustment and there is no plan for a reshuffle, a government spokesman said Thursday.

Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsan made the remarks amid calls for a speedy Cabinet reshuffle after President Chen Shui-bian's announcement the previous day that he will no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

The president, in response to opposition calls for him to step down to take responsibility for a series of scandals involving senior officials and members of his family, promised the premier will have "a free hand" in making decisions for the Executive Yuan, while the Democratic Progressive Party chief will have full authority to set the ruling party's policy agenda.
Cheng said that since Su assumed the premiership Jan. 25, he has shown himself as leading a "pragmatic" Cabinet.
The premier knows the high expectations of the public and has demanded that every Cabinet member follow the highest ethical standard, Cheng said.
The approval rating for the Cabinet performance has been rising, Cheng said. "Maybe there is still room for improvement, but there is no plan for a reshuffle," he added.

To live up to the public's expectations, Cheng said the administration is planning to speed up major construction projects, with plans to push for the completion of such projects as the 31-km Peiyi Expressway connecting Taipei and Suao in northeastern Yilan County, and the 345-km high speed railway connecting Taipei and Kaohsiung, according to schedule.
Meanwhile, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday that she has no particular thoughts about the lineup of the Cabinet.

She said that each Cabinet member will be appraised for their individual performance when she was asked whether there will be a change in the lineup after Chen's announcement that he will give Premier Su Tseng-chang a "free hand" in his administration.
She said that the president mainly wants the Cabinet to enhance its efficiency, which she said is "a greater responsibility for us, and we'll do our best."
Asked whether this means that a Su-Tsai ticket has been formed for the 2008 presidential election, Tsai said it was too early to say.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN GENERAL HOSPITAL HEAD RESIGNS AMID CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: The superintendent of the Taoyuan General Hospital, Ho Feng-ming, dogged by days of speculation that he bought his post through President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming, tendered his resignation to the Department of Health (DOH) Thursday.
DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mao said later that "in order not to affect the normal operations of the hospital, " he approved the resignation.
Prosecutors investigating the insider trading allegations surrounding Chao, an osteopath, inadvertently found that Chao could have been influence-peddling in securing the post for Ho.

Chao and Ho got acquainted while both were members of the table tennis team of National Taiwan University. knowing that Hou was one of Chao's teachers at the National Taiwan University Medical School, He asked Chao to recommend him for the post. More than NT$100,000 (US$3,175) was later remitted to a bank account of a member of Chao's family.
In a faxed resignation to the DOH, Ho said the days of reports have created trouble for him and that he decided to step down to avoid disrupting the operations of the hospital.
He, who has taken leaves over the past few days, did not deny or confirm the reports of his buying his way into the superintendent post.
Hou also said that if the judicial authorities find any irregularities, Ho will be given harsh treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FACTIONS HAIL RESIGNATIONS OF PRESIDENT'S RIGHT-HAND MEN

TEXT.P: Major factions in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hailed the resignations of two of President Chen Shui-bian's most trusted aides Thursday, saying the development signifies Chen's determination to honor his commitment to political accountability and integrity.
The Presidential Office said in a press release that Chen had approved the resignations of Ma Yung-cheng, his deputy chief of staff, and Lin Chin-chang, a National Security Council advisory member.

Their resignations came a day after Chen pledged to give full power to Premier Su Tseng-chang to control the Executive Yuan and to refrain from meddling with the affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The president also pledged in a written statement issued late Wednesday that he and his family will "conduct themselves according to the highest ethical standards and live up to the public's expectations."
Chen's statement was issued amid rising calls in both the DPP and the opposition for the president to take responsibility for a series of scandals embroiling his family and administration.

Ma, who has been dogged by allegations of political and financial irregularities, said he feels sorry for failing to do a better job even though "he has tried his utmost." Given the complexities of his official duties, Ma said he feels he is not capable and competent enough to handle them perfectly. "It's time for me to leave," Ma said in the letter. Ma has been one of Chen's most trusted right-hand men for 15 years.

Commenting on the resignations of Chen's close aides, Legislator Gao Chih-peng, who concurrently serves as secretary of the DPP's Justice Alliance, of which Chen is a member, said the departure of Ma and Lin will pave the way for Chen to infuse new blood into his inner circle and refresh the image of the DPP administration.

As to whether Cabinet members close to Chen could be replaced, Gao said the speculation is outrageous, adding that personnel reshuffles should be based on individual ministers credentials and performance rather than their "factional affiliations."

Meanwhile, Legislator Lai Ching-teh, also convener of the New Tide faction, which is widely believed to be the most influential subgroup within the DPP, said he respects and support Chen's approval of his two close aides' resignations to underscore his resolve to carry out political reform and establish clean politics.

Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the DPP's Welfare State Alliance headed by former Premier Frank Hsieh said the resignations of Ma and Lin do not necessarily mean that they have committed any wrongdoings or crime.
"But their images have been damaged in the pall of recent 'media politics and populist judgments,'" Kuan lamented, adding that their departure will help restore the Presidential Office's credibility.

The DPP's "pan-green" ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- also gave a thumbs-up to the resignations, saying their departure is Chen's response to public expectations of political integrity and accountability.
TSU Legislator Huang Shih-cho said he views Ma's departure as a move to symbolize his integrity.

"In the past, his detractors claimed that judicial authorities dare not investigate his suspected irregularities, Now that he has left the government, the judicial authorities can thoroughly probe all cases allegedly implicating him, " Huang said, adding that he admires Ma's courage in resigning at this critical moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUES' UNMOVED BY CHEN'S CLOSE AIDES' RESIGNATIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) were unmoved by the resignations of two of President Chen Shui-bian's most trusted aides, saying their departures could probably be Chen's "smoke screen" to weather his current political crisis.

KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, who is also chief executive of the main opposition parties's Policy Coordination Committee, said the most important thing at the moment is for judicial authorities to get to the bottom of a string of corruption allegations implicating Chen's inner circle, including his family member and close aides.

The PFP's legislative caucus convener, Lu Hsueh-chang, made a similar comment, saying that Chen himself should resign to take responsibility for the series of corruption scandals allegedly involving his son-in-law and proteges.

The pan-blues' remarks came after Chen approved the resignations of his two right-hand men -- Ma Yung-cheng, Chen's deputy chief of staff, and Lin Chin-chang, a National Security Council advisory member -- Thursday evening.

Their resignations came a day after Chen pledged to give full power to Premier Su Tseng-chang to control the Executive Yuan and to refrain from meddling with the affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The president also pledged in a written statement issued late Wednesday that he and his family will "conduct themselves according to the highest ethical standards and live up to the public's expectations."
Chen's statement was issued amid rising calls in both the DPP and the opposition for the president to take responsibility for a series of scandals embroiling his family and administration.

Ma, who has been dogged by allegations of political and financial irregularities, said he feels sorry for failing to do a better job even though "he has tried his utmost." Given the complexities of his official duties, Ma said he feels he is not capable and competent enough to handle them perfectly. "It's time for me to leave," Ma said in the letter. Ma has been one of Chen's most trusted right-hand men for 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FSC CHIEF TO BE ANNOUNCED SOON: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang will announce the new chief of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) at an appropriate time, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Thursday.

Cheng said the Cabinet will not undergo a reshuffle at the moment, but that the premier will announce a replacement to fill the top FSC post which has been left vacant since Kong Jaw-sheng was suspended his duties on suspicions of his implication in profiteering scandals during his tenure as Taiwan Sugar Corp. chairman.
As the tenure of three FSC commissioners will expire late this month, Cheng said the premier will make an overall evaluation before announcing the new FSC chief and new FSC commissioners.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: For Bush, Talks With Iran Were a Last Resort
After 27 years in which the United States has refused substantive talks with Iran, President Bush reversed course on Wednesday because it was made clear to him -- by his allies, by the Russians, by the Chinese, and eventually by some of his advisers -- that he no longer had a choice.
Wall Street Journal: Deep Trouble As Demand for Coal Rises, Risky Mines Play Bigger Role
Since May 20, seven miners have died, bringing the number of workers killed in coal-mine accidents in the U.S. this year to 33 -- compared with 22 for all of last year. Part of the problem, some say, is a rise in the number of small, undercapitalized mines that have become economical since coal prices have surged. Miners refer to them as "dogholes." Despite the recent rash of fatalities, coal mining has gotten safer overall, due to improved technology and mining methods. In the early part of the 20th century, when there were roughly seven times as many coal miners as today, the annual death toll from accidents often exceeded 2,000 miners. In 1950, there were 643 fatalities. By 1990, the number had dropped to 66.
