DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 2, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
2001: The Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Mongolian Olympic Committee sign a sports cooperation and exchange agreement in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES DELEGATION OF POWERS WON'T BE POLITICIZED

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that more power delegated to him and the Executive Yuan by President Chen Shui-bian means deeper trust and greater responsibility, and he urged the public not to politicize the matter.
Su called for the Taiwan public "to value the meaning of the empowerment as it is high time that the government strives harder to serve the people."
Su appealed to the country to give him and his administrative team some time and more "space" to carry out their tasks.
The premier made the remarks during an inspection tour of Hualien, eastern Taiwan Friday.

His remarks were in response to media members' inquiries about the overall situation following President Chen's announcement May 31 that he would no longer exercise any power beyond what is expressly defined by the Constitution as the role of the president.

The president, in response to opposition calls for him to step down to take responsibility for a series of scandals involving senior officials and members of his family, promised that the premier will have "a free hand" in making decisions for the Executive Yuan, while the Democratic Progressive Party chief will have full authority to set the ruling party's policy agenda.

Su urged Taiwan society to give members of the first family "more space" after President Chen's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming was taken into custody more than a week ago on suspicions of involvement in insider trading.
He also called for greater space for the judicial system to allow the judges and prosecutors to handle the Chao case objectively and free of outside pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF TAIWAN STUDENTS SHOW HEAVY RELIANCE ON MOBILE PHONES: POLL

TEXT.P: Approximately 70 percent of Taiwan students who own mobile phones demonstrate a heavy reliance on their phones, according to the results of a survey released recently.
The survey was conducted by the King Car Education Foundation on 2,242 primary, secondary and university students around Taiwan.

The survey indicates that 36.8 percent of students in higher grades at elementary schools own a mobile phone, while the ratio is 49.1 percent among junior high students, 85.3 percent among senior high students and 97.8 percent among college undergraduates.
Compared with the results of a similar survey carried out last year, the percentage of senior high students with mobile phones has increased 15 percent.

It was found that older students tend to demonstrate a greater reliance on mobile phones, with 80 percent of undergraduates with mobile phones relying heavily on the devices. Also, girls demonstrate a greater reliance on their phones than boys do, according to the survey.

Seventy percent of the students have their mobile phone bills paid for by their parents. While 50 percent of the students have average monthly mobile phone bills that exceed NT$500 (US$15.57), 19 percent have bills that exceed NT$1,000 per month.
Fifty-five percent of the respondents have been scolded by their parents for their high mobile phone bills, and 19.7 percent have to tighten their belts to pay their phone bills.

Many of the respondents said they will hide under their blankets to talk to friends on their mobile phones in order to evade the watchful eyes of their parents. These respondents tend to have higher mobile phone bills.

Approximately 60 percent of the students do not switch off their mobile phones at night, with 39.4 percent of students having had the experience of chatting with friends on their mobile phones after 11 p.m. and 10.2 percent doing so every night.

The survey shows that 45.1 percent of students feel uneasy or lonely when they do not have their mobile phone with them, 41.7 percent feel so when their cell phone batteries run out, 27.6 percent when their calls are not answered, and 19.4 percent when they don't receive a single call for a whole day.

On the drawbacks of and the troubles brought about by mobile phones, 71 percent of the students mentioned high phone bills, 60 percent expressed concerns about electromagnetic waves released by their phones, 42.5 percent said they worry about phone scams, 21 percent mentioned the large number of telemarketing calls they receive, and 17.4 percent mentioned concerns about pornographic text messages or calls.

DOC.HEADLINE: ST. VINCENT PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ralph Gonsalves, prime minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan June 5 for a five-day visit, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Friday.
Gonsalves will meet President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang during the visit, which will be his fourth in his present post, the officials said.

On June 7, Gonsalves and Su will jointly preside over the opening of a Taipei cultural and art exhibition marking the 25th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries, they said.
St. Vincent and the Grenadines forged diplomatic relations with Taiwan in 1981 and has since become one of Taiwan's loyal allies in the Caribbean, they noted.

For example, St. Vincent and the Grenadines offered its support for Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum against China's missile threat March 20, 2004, and it has voiced support for Taiwan's bids to join various international organizations, including the World Health Organization, the United Nations and the Organization of American States, the officials said.
The Caribbean nation also helped relay Taiwan's position on ceasing the function of the National Unification Guidelines to the United Nations, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO LAUNCH TAIPEI-OSAKA CARGO SERVICE

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) will launch a new cargo route between Taipei and Osaka July 4, with two flights available per week, company officials said Friday.
Currently, CAL operates cargo services to two Japanese destinations, namely Tokyo and Nagoya.
Osaka was added to the list following revisions of the Taiwan-Japan aviation pact in March.
Meanwhile, CAL is also set to launch a new passenger service between Taipei and Osaka July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO ADDRESS SEOUL CONFAB VIA TELECONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, June 2 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, founder and chairwoman of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , is scheduled to address the opening of the 2006 West Pacific Regional Convention of the DPU in the South Korean capital via teleconference Saturday, a diplomatic source in Seoul said Friday.

Lu had originally planned to travel to Seoul to attend the convention in person and deliver her keynote speech, but was denied entry by the South Korean government in the name of the "one China" principle, the source said.
She then decided to deliver her speech, titled "New Vision of the New West Pacific" via teleconference, the source said.

Officials, lawmakers and civic delegates from Russia, Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Solomon Islands, Palau, East Timor, Singapore, Tuvalu, South Korea and Taiwan are expected to attend the two-day regional convention, which carries the theme of "Prosperity and Progress in the West Pacific Region."

The Taiwan delegation will be led by former Vice Premier Wu Rong-i who is currently a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian. Other members of the delegation will include academics, think-tank specialists and legislators.
Prominent members of the South Korean delegation will include former Prime Minister Lee Han-dong and Cho Woong-Kyu, president of the Korean DPU, according to the source.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TAKES TWO-PRONGED APPROACH TO FORCE PRESIDENT TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) legislative caucus convener Lu Hsueh-chang said Friday that recalling President Chen Shui-bian and staging massive rallies to show the people's disgruntlement will be carried out at the same time.
In an attempt to improve the image of the Presidential Office, Chen promised to reorganize the power structure of his administration after a senior officials meeting two days ago.

He also approved the resignations of two of his right-hand men the previous day in an effort to reorganize his inner circle to facilitate political reform after a string of debilitating corruption scandals allegedly implicating his son-in-law and senior administration officials.
At a press meeting, Lu said the first rally to pressure Chen to step down will be held in front of the Presidential Office square Saturday, rain or shine.

He claimed that the main purpose of Chen's "delegate power" announcements was to keep himself in power instead of stepping down, adding that his announcement of returning to the normal operations of the Constitution is nothing but lip service, which is why the PFP caucus is demanding Chen's resignation.
PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng urged all those who support the double-pressure idea to join the rally Saturday.
Chin said the insider trading scandal involving the president's son-in-law is only one of many that involve people close to the president.

"We are going to stage a "soft revolution" in which almost half of the people in Taiwan want the president to step down, " PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said, adding that if the opposition parties are such cowards that they hide behind the people, they will have to apologize to the people.
Hsieh claimed that recalling the president is not a problem about how difficult it might be technically but simply something that should be done.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAS NO PLAN TO RESHUFFLE CABINET

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang has no plan to reshuffle the Cabinet, although improvements need to be made in some ministries, a Cabinet official said Friday.
According to Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan, Su's Cabinet has been working very hard since it was inaugurated four months ago, and the popularity of the Cabinet has also been rising.

Cheng said there will be some personnel adjustments in the Council for Economic Planning and Development later this month and he promised that the Cabinet will select candidates with professional backgrounds to fill the posts.

Cheng made the remarks in response to public concern as to whether the premier has any plans to revamp the Cabinet following President Chen Shui-bian's announcement Wednesday that he will not interfere with the policy-making of the Executive Yuan.
The president has traditionally played a major role in deciding the personnel appointments of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU BIOMEDICAL SCIENCE PARK TO BE PROFITABLE: NSC

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Biomedical Science Park is expected to expand the total production value of Taiwan's biomedical industry by NT$500 billion (US$15.5 billion) over a 20 year period, the National Science Council (NSC) said Friday.

According to an assessment carried out by the Nomura Research Institute under the commission of the NSC, the science park will generate an estimated NT$71.3 billion in tax revenue during the 20- year period, a council spokesman said.
In 20 years' time, the park will create over 10,000 job opportunities and generate NT$20 billion in annual revenue in the domestic biomedical industry, the spokesman said.
The park, with six major research and development centers, is scheduled to become fully operational by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-SENIOR PRESIDENTIAL AIDE DETAINED FOR TWO MORE MONTHS

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court granted a request by prosecutors Friday to detain a former senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian for two more months, on the grounds that releasing him could harm the investigation into his alleged wrongdoings.
Chen Che-nan was detained in April on suspicion of taking bribes from a businessman to help him settle his embezzlement charges. The original two-month detention is to expire June 6.
During the investigation, Chen admitted to having taken three checks and other fees amounting to NT$7.11 million from Liang Po-hsun, a wanted economic criminal.
As Liang has turned himself in to police to substantiate his charges that Chen did not help him get off the hook, the prosecutors said Chen was "highly suspected" of having defrauded Liang.

The prosecution requested an extended detention for Chen because other witnesses and suspects in this and related cases have not yet been summoned. Another reason for the request is that if freed on bail, Chen might collude with other people to destroy evidence.
The request takes effect June 7, meaning that Chen, who is also charged in connection with the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal, will be kept in custody until Aug. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIANANMEN SQUARE 'TANK MAN' REPORTEDLY LIVING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The "Unknown Rebel" who famously stood up to a column of tanks during the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989 is rumored to be living in Taiwan where he reportedly settled in 1993.

The "tank man" Wang Weilin has been an adviser on ceramic artifacts and antiques to Taiwan's National Palace Museum, the Epoch Times quoted a Hong Kong-based professor who spoke on condition of anonymity as saying.
The photograph of Wang standing alone in front of a column of tanks on June 5, 1989 is perhaps the most famous image from the Tiananmen Square protests.

The professor told the Epoch Times that Wang, born in Shaoyang in the southern province of Hunan, was the captain of the Mawangduei Archaeology Team of Changsha, Hunan in early June 1989 when he traveled with a union group to Beijing to take part in the pro-democracy demonstrations in the Chinese capital.

According to the unnamed professor, Wang, who was rumored by some to have been arrested and even executed after the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, went into hiding in China for three years and seven months after the bloody crackdown. He then reached Hong Kong in early 1993 from where he headed to Taiwan.
The professor told the newspaper that Wang later married a Taiwan woman and that they now have a six-year-old son.
He also claimed that Wang remains determined to see democracy and freedom ultimately prevail in China.
Time magazine included the "Unknown Rebel" in its list of 100 most influential people of the 20th century in an April 1998 issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BIDING TIME ON 'PULLING TRIGGER' ON RECALL PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is waiting for the most appropriate time to put forward at the Legislative Yuan a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

Noting that a draft proposal crafted by a KMT lawmaker has already gathered enough lawmakers' sponsorship needed for any motion, Ma said "the gun has been loaded" and the only question now is "when to pull the trigger."

Ma made the remarks after calling on Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to discuss a wide range of issues, including convening a provisional session of the legislature after the current session ended Tuesday, as well as proposals to recall the president or topple the Cabinet, and the resignation of two of President Chen's right-hand men Thursday.
The remarks came amid calls for the KMT to act quickly in proposing a recall of the president in the wake of a spate of corruption scandals implicating his close aides and family member.

Ma reiterated the KMT stance of waiting for the right time, saying that details related to the string of scandals have yet to come to light. "It might be more effective to pull the trigger when they snowball to the boiling point," he said.

According to the Constitution, at least a quarter of the members of the Legislative Yuan are needed to sponsor a motion to recall the president. The motion then has to be approved by two-thirds of the legislators before it can be put to a national referendum. In addition, for the referendum result to be valid, at least half of the nation's voters must vote and of those who vote, more than half of them must be in favor of the recalling the president.
If the voters reject the recall proposal, another recall motion cannot be put forward for at least three years.
Ma said that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has already moved to solidify its leadership, making the recall plan even more difficult.
"But the KMT has not ruled out any possibilities, and the party is engaging in related preparations," he said.

Asked about the possibility of toppling the Cabinet, Ma said that if the KMT initiates and wins the legislature's approval of a motion of no-confidence, the president might refuse to budge and dissolve the legislature, and the legislative elections would have to be carried out in accordance with amendments to the Constitution passed last June, including the halving of the number of legislative seats and implementing the "single constituency, two votes" electoral system.
However, as the re-districting in line with these changes has yet to be completed, the matter will require further study, he added.

On the resignations of Ma Yung-cheng, deputy chief of staff to President Chen, and Lin Chin-chang, a National Security Council advisory member, Ma said that this is only an attempt by President Chen to save himself, claiming that "the problem lies not with the two aides, but with the president himself."
The president should seriously consider whether to step down, Ma added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 86.8 points to close at 6,959.64.
The bourse opened at 6,951.42 and fluctuated between 6,967.09 and 6.885.39 during trading. A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.18 billion (US$2.97 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and construction issues both at 2 percent, textile stocks at 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with cement stocks moving down at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 386 to 366, with 118 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.92 MILLION HOUSEHOLDS FILE TAX RETURNS BY JUNE 1: MOI

TEXT.P: A total of 4.92 million Taiwan households had filed their income tax returns by June 1, the deadline for tax filing for this year, Ministry of Finance officials said Friday.

The tax returns filed online totalled 2.23 million, which represents a significant rise of 30 percent over the previous year and accounts for 45 percent of all tax returns accepted by taxation authorities this year, the officials said.
With approximately 5 million tax-paying households in Taiwan, they estimated that more than 70,000 households have not filed their tax returns.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HIGH SPEED RAIL WILL INCREASE TO 60 TRAINS WITHIN 6 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-speed railway, when inaugurated this October, will have safety and service quality as its primal considerations, so that the daily schedule will only increase to 60 trains within six months, Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi said Friday.
Kuo made the remarks when she presided over the inauguration of a 11.4-km new road connecting Taipao station in Chiayi County to downtown Chiayi City.
Kao said that in the initial stage, the daily train schedule will not be frequent.

According to a briefing given by Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp., the company in charge of its operation under a build-operate-transfer model, the first train will leave Taipei at 7 a.m. and the last will leave at about 9 p.m.

There are three types of train schedules, with the fastest one being the Taipei-Taichung-Kaohsiung, which will take 90 minutes. The second is Taipei-Panchiao-Taoyuan-Hsinchu-Taichung-Chiayi-Tainan-Kaoshiung, which will take 120 minutes, and there will also be a Taipei-Taichung schedule that will stop at every station along the way.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DIRECT LINKS BILL, NO EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Should the ruling party not promise to give a greenlight at the legislature to a law amendments package aimed at opening the door for direct transport links between Taiwan and China, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which along with the People First Party controls a slight legislative majority, will not agree to hold an extra legislative session, KMT Ma Ying-jeou warned Friday.

Under such a scenario, the current hostility between the ruling and opposition parties is expected to get worse, Ma said, adding that without the passage of the amendments package, it is unlikely the KMT will attend a national economic meeting on sustainable growth next month, while the current standoff between the ruling and opposition parties will not be resolved.

Calling on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus to accept the opposition-proposed law revision package, Ma said an agreement between the KMT and the DPP on the issue is the key to opening an extra session at the Legislative Yuan, which would allow a handful of other important bills to be screened.
Ma made the remarks after meeting with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who expressed hope that Premier Su Tseng-chang will try to dissuade DPP lawmakers from boycotting the package.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNTECH, AUSTRALIAN CNC COMPANY TO COOPERATE IN CNC R&D

TEXT.P: National Yunlin University of Science and Technology (Yuntech) in central Taiwan and ANCA, an Australian company specializing in CNC tool and cutter grinding, signed an agreement Friday to improve research and development in CNC, a spokesman for the university said.

The Yuntech spokesman said that ANCA will inject funds totaling US$30,000 in the coming three years to sponsor Yuntech's R&D in CNC, adding that ANCA has decided to cooperate with the university because it has found great potential in CNC applications in Taiwan.
The R&D results, obtained following research programs of the university, could be applied to optical testing equipment, laser machining and the making of other metallic and non-metallic products.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL CONTINUE NEGOTIATIONS OVER MAYORAL ELECTION: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Responding to the possibility that People First Party Chairman James Soong might run in the year-end Taipei mayoral election, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou admitted Friday that he has no answer and is open to negotiating over the matter.
Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, made the remarks in reply to a question from city councilman Chen Cheng-chung, who asked about the "pan-blue alliance's" candidate for the upcoming mayoral race.
Ma said it will take time to negotiate and that the two parties' secretaries-general are discussing the matter.
As for the best resolution to the candidate issue, Ma said that negotiations or polls will be the key.

He expressed his concern that both that PFP and KMT are opposition parties and that if the two cannot reach a consensus on fielding a joint candidate, it might have an adverse impact on the development of both parties.

Regarding the possibility of Soong insisting on running, Ma said he can understand Soong's thinking. However, he added that it would be difficult to ask the winner of the KMT primary to stand down in favor of Soong.
Former Environmental Protection Minister Hau Lung-bin was the winner of the KMT primary and public opinion poll to select the mayoral candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER LABOR OFFICIAL NAMED DPP CANDIDATE FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL RACE

TEXT.P: Former Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu was nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday as the DPP candidate to run in the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral race, according to DPP officials.

Chen won an approval rating of 77.76 percent in a recent public opinion poll in Kaohsiung City and captured nearly 80 percent of ballots cast by party members in a DPP primary, making her the one and only eligible DPP candidate for the mayoral election, DPP officials said in a written statement.
Also in a written statement, Chen said later in the day that she welcomes the outcome of the primary process, which she described as a "representation of the democratic values of the DPP."

Chen vowed to safeguard Kaohsiung's development should she be elected mayor of the port city. At the crucial juncture of the DPP, she said, she will listen to and follow the voices of the Kaohsiung residents and strive to improve quality of life for the entire city based on a solid foundation that has been consolidated by former mayor Frank Hsieh and incumbent acting mayor Yeh Chu-lan.

Noting that what the Kaohsiung residents need is not the tumult of political rhetoric but substantively good life, Chen said that if elected, she will carry out her ideals in the port city in all areas involving public order, transportation, education, employment, environmental protection, industrial development and culture.

Meanwhile, Chen said she will heed the advice of DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling in terms of city development efforts, including seeking to have Chinese Television System (CTS) move its headquarters from Taipei to the southern port city and for Kaohsiung to play host to a proposed national video and audio digital center.

Kuan, another DPP aspirant, won 20.76 percent of the total ballots cast by DPP party members in Kaohsiung City in the DPP primary. She suspended campaign three days before last Saturday's primary vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROHIBIT RESIGNED PRESIDENTIAL AIDE FROM LEAVING COUNTRY: KMT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) urged the prosecution Friday to prohibit Ma Yung-cheng, a senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian who has just resigned, from leaving the country.
The caucus claimed that Ma could have been involved in quite a number of corruption scandals now being investigated, given his role as the president's right-hand man.
Ma and Lin Chin-chang, another of Chen's trusted advisers, tendered their resignations one day after the president declared his decision to delegate power in pursuit of "thorough reforms" Wednesday.

Pan Wei-kang, KMT caucus secretary-general, told a press conference that if Ma and Lin had not been involved in any of the scandals, they need not have quit and that if they are involved, their quitting will not help them.
Lee Ching-hua, a caucus member, claimed that Ma is suspected of involvement in quite a number of scandals and should be prohibited from leaving Taiwan so that investigators can question him.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY SEEKS NEW PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University welcomes applicants from Taiwan and overseas to apply for the presidency of the university in southern Taiwan, a screening committee said Friday.
Those who apply need not be Republic of China nationals but cannot not come directly from China, the committee members said.

The 19 members of the screening committee, including convener and former Education Minister Wu Jin, National Cheng Kung University President Kao Chiang and former National Cheng Kung University President Ma Tze-ju, urged qualified applicants to come forward.
Wu said the university's president will be a leading academic and an intellectual.
Kao, who will step down after his term expires Jan. 31 next year, said that if the president has enough academic stature, a raise or adjustment of salary can be considered.

However, Ma expressed worry that the post has not been properly advertised as the university has been accepting applications since May 1 but has not received a single application or recommendation. The deadline for applications is June 30.

According to the regulations, those who are aged under 65, have served as a professor for five years and have more than three years of educational or administrative experience can be recommended by either academic individuals or institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER CLAIMS TO HAVE OF EVIDENCE OF ARMY GENERAL'S BRIBERY

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) claimed Friday that he is in possession of concrete evidence that Lt. Gen. Hsu Tai-sheng, director of the Joint Inspection Office under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), got promoted to his current rank through bribery.

At a press conference in the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's Policy Center, announced that he will ask Hsu and Minister of National Defense Lee Jye to come to the office of the PFP's legislative caucus Monday and examine the evidence face-to-face.

Chang said he will wait in his office all day Monday and that if they do not show up, he and his lawyer will present all the evidence to the Public Prosecutors' Office at the Taipei District Court Tuesday.
Chang made the announcement after Hsu filed a slander suit against him Thursday at the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office, with the support of the MND.

Before filing the suit, Hsu told a news conference that as a career military officer, he was shocked and angered by Chang's "groundless" claim that he gave NT$8 million (US$249,057) to then-deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, Chen Cheh-nan, in return for a promotion in 2003.
Hsu was one of several examples cited by Chang May 30 to support his claim that President Chen Shui-bian's administration is riddled with corruption.
Chang quoted several retired generals who complained that they quit the armed forces because they felt sick at being asked to pay millions in cash for promotion.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSIDER TRADING SUSPECT BAILED AFTER CONFESSING

TEXT.P: Tsai Ching-wen, former board member of Waterland Securities Co. and a suspect in a high-profile insider trading case, was released on bail from detention after confessing to prosecutors Friday.
Liu Shou-sung, a spokesman for the Taipei District Court, said the judge asked prosecutors' opinions before granting Tsai's request for release.
The prosecutors agreed, on the grounds that Tsai has admitted to his role in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) insider trading scandal. Tsai was then released on NT$500,000 bail.

Tsai was detained May 19 on charges of buying TDC shares on insider information along with businessman You Shih-yi and Chien Shui-mien, the mother of President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming.
Chien, her husband Chao Yu-chu, and second son Chao Chien-hsun and Chien-hsun's wife were all questioned and released.
You was detained May 21 and Chao May 25, when another suspect, Su Teh-chien, former board chairman of TDC, was also taken into detention. All three remain in custody.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING COSTA RICAN AMBASSADOR BIDS FAREWELL TO TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Costa Rican Ambassador to Taiwan Oscar Alvarez Araya, whose term ends June 17, visited Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Friday at City Hall to bid his farewell.

Ma, who is regarded as a hopeful for the next presidency in 2008, told the outgoing diplomat that he hopes for a boost on cultural and educational exchanges between Costa Rica and Taipei and that Costa Rican artists will come to Taipei to conduct exchanges with their Taiwanese counterparts.

Alvarez said he will take a post as a university lecturer after returning to Costa Rica and that he will continue to push his country to maintain friendly ties with Taiwan and the Taipei city government.
Ma presented a book, titled "Above Taipei" to Alvarez.
During his service in Taiwan from 1999, Alvarez has promoted visits of Costa Rica's president to Taiwan and two visits by the Taiwan president to his country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN A WORLD LEADER IN BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL PRESERVATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan tops the list of countries that are home to black-faced spoonbills, an endangered species of migrating bird, with 826 spotted at the seashore of the southern county of Tainan during January this year, environmental groups said Friday.
An eco-friendly group spokesman explained that black-faced spoonbills come to Tainan County's seaside each year because it provides the appropriate environment to shelter them in winter.

Eco-friendly groups quoted tallies compiled by the Hong Kong Bird Watching Society (HKBWS) , showing a total of 1,679 black-faced spoonbills were observed around the world in a census that took place Jan. 6-8 this year.
Besides the 826 birds spotted here, 397 were seen in Hong Kong, 206 in China, 74 in Vietnam, 155 in Japan and 21 in Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT LEGISLATURE WILL FOLLOW NEW ELECTORAL SYSTEM IF DISSOLVED EARLY

TEXT.P: If the current Legislative Yuan is dissolved, a new legislative election will have to be conducted under the new electoral system, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Friday.

The CEC made the announcement in the wake of reports that the opposition is considering seeking a recall of the president or the toppling of the Cabinet in the wake of a spate of corruption scandals implicating the close aides of President Chen Shui-bian and his son-in-law.

CEC officials said that if the opposition legislators initiate a motion of no-confidence and win support in the legislature, and the president refuses to budge and instead dissolves the legislature, then the CEC will have to conduct the new legislative election within 60 days.

The new legislative election will be carried out according to the amended Constitution, including the new electoral system of "single constituency, two votes" under a re-districting scheme and the halving of the number of legislative seats to 113, which was adopted last June.

According to the newly amended law governing the election and recall of public functionaries, the legislature should give its consent to the re-districting scheme 13 months before the current legislature expires.

CEC spokesman Deng Tien-you said that the draft re-districting scheme, which was mapped out by the commission after a lengthy consultation period with local election commissions and the views of academics and experts, has already been sent to the legislature.

If the legislature has not yet given its consent and a new legislative election is approaching, then the new constituency will follow the re-districting scheme mapped out by the CEC, because the status of the Constitution is higher than the law, he said.
The newly elected legislators will be sworn in for four-year terms instead of the current three years, according to the amended Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES END TO POLITICAL FIGHTING

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" to stop its political fighting Friday after President Chen Shui-bian vowed to hand over power to Premier Su Tseng-chang in a gesture to assume responsibility for a string of corruption scandals involving members of his family and close aides.
DPP legislative caucus whips Chen Chin-chun and Ker Chien-ming made the call at a Legislative Yuan news conference.

Saying that the "pan-blue alliance" must "stop creating chaos" now that Chen has become a lame duck president, Chen Chin-chun said the demands of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party that Chen step down from the presidency have gone too far. He called them an apparent intention to fuel political strife.

Chen Chin-chun asked the "pan-blue alliance" not to push the president to the corner as he has made it clear that he will play the role as head of state strictly in line with the Constitution, leaving full power to Su to lead the Cabinet and quitting all DPP activities.

While many key bills are still awaiting legislative approval after the Legislative Yuan went into recess May 30, Ker called on the "pan-blue alliance" to support the proposal of calling an extra session in summer instead of exchanging verbal attacks.

According to Ker, the resignations Thursday of Ma Yung-cheng, Presidential Office deputy chief of staff, and Lin Chin-chang, a National Security Council advisory member -- two close aides of Chen Shui-bian -- are an indication that the president has deeply reflected on himself in response to the public's expectations. He asked the "pan-blue alliance" not to further "complicate" the situation.

The resignations of Ma and Lin came as a surprise amid fierce demands that Chen should quit the presidency immediately to take responsibility for the many corruption scandals implicating his family members and close aids.
However, the "pan-blue alliance" views the resignations as a scheme designed by Chen to "drag out" the situation.

As Chen is mired in a serious crisis and his approval rating has sunk to a new low, leading opposition KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has come under fierce fire that he "lacks the teeth" to take action to boot out Chen.

Although Ma has called on Chen to quit presidency as he lacks the integrity to govern the country, he maintains that now is not the proper time to initiate a presidential recall proposal, as there is no hard evidence showing that the president himself is implicated in the corruption cases.

While KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po said that a presidential recall proposal should be decided by the party's legislative caucus, KMT lawmaker Ting Shou-chung, who is also a KMT Central Committee member, will put forward a presidential recall proposal in a committee plenary meeting Saturday to seek a resolution to do so despite Ma's ambiguous attitude.
According to KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen, Ma will give a speech in the meeting on his views regarding the presidential recall proposal and a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet.
Cheng, however, expressed reservations about a rally to be held by the PFP in front of the Presidential Office Saturday to demand Chen's resignation.

New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming also called a news conference at the Legislative Yuan Friday, in which he insisted that Chen must step down and face judicial investigation in line with constitutional requirements.
If he refuses to do so, the "pan-blue alliance, " which controls a slim majority in the legislature, should consider launching a no-confidence vote and forming a new Cabinet, Yok suggested.
Yok also visited the KMT legislative caucus earlier the same day to seek the KMT's endorsement to remove Chen.
New Party lawmaker Wu Cheng-dien asked Chen to honor his promises of delegating power to the premier and come up with concrete measures to show his determination to clear his name.

He must also publicize all suspected unlawful activities involving his family members, senior aides and high-level government officials, make public all the property of his family for public scrutiny, and pledge in public that he will wait for the results of an investigation, We demanded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, decreasing NT$0.030 to close at NT$32.080.
A total of US$691 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.110 and hit a low of NT$32.035.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 113 points to close at 6,967, with 44,918 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July increased 96 points to finish at 6,898, with 891 contracts traded, while September futures gained 92 points to end at 6,782, with 43 contract transactions. December futures increased 95 points to close at 6,790, with 16 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 55 points to finish at 6,780, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,854 for June, 6,802 for July, 6,690 for September, 6,695 for December and 6,725 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

June TE futures increased 4.1 points to close at 298.5, with 5,431 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 3.55 points to finish at 297, with 34 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 2.8 points to end at 291, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

June TF futures gained 26.6 points to close at 991, with 5,965 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures gained 24.2 points to close at 982, with 95 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 15.6 point to end at 968.6, with 15 contract transactions, December TF futures increased 21.6 points to close at 967.8, with one contract transaction, while March TF futures increased 31 points to end at 974.8, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFRICAN DANCES KICK OFF HSINCHU TOURISM FAIR

TEXT.P: African drums, fire-eaters and exotic dances marked the opening of a travel fair extolling the virtues of northern Hsinchu's tourism industry Friday.
The travel fair is taking place June 2-5 and features 15 kiosques sponsored by seven recreational theme parks and eight resorts to promote tourist spots in Hsinchu City and county.

According to organizers, the travel fair was held for the first time last year and attracted around 28,000 visitors. They hope to see more visitors this year as it is being held ahead of summer vacation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqi Accuses U.S. of 'Daily' Attacks Against Civilians
Iraqui Premier Kamal al-Maliki lashed out at the American military on Thursday, denouncing what he characterized as habitual attacks by troops against Iraqi civilians. In his comments, Maliki said violence against civilians had become a "daily phenomenon" by many troops in the American-led coalition who "do not respect the Iraqi people."
Wall Street Journal: Free and Uneasy, Tale of 5 Muslims: Out of Guantanamo And Into Limbo
After four years in Guantanamo Bay, Abu Bakker Qassim, former terror suspect cleared last year of having ties to al Qaeda, got word last month that they finally would be set free. However, the five Muslims from China were loaded onto a U.S. military transport plane in the middle of the night, shackled to the floor and flown for 12 hours to their new home: a converted military barracks in Tirana, the capital of Albania. They were afraid to go home for fear of facing jail or execution if returned to their homelands.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CALLS FOR PEACEFUL RESOLUTION TO IRAN NUCLEAR PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Taiwan wishes to see a peaceful resolution to the dispute over Iran's implementation of a nuclear program, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

Despite not being a member of the United Nations, Taiwan respects the UN's position on nuclear proliferation and hopes all members of the international community will keep their promise with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to develop and use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes only, the MOFA said in a news release.

The MOFA made the comment after U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Wednesday in Brussels that should Iran agree to halt its nuclear program, Washington would be willing to hold diplomatic talks with Iran -- along with Britain, France and Germany -- in order to seek ways to settle differences on the issue.

The news release said that Taiwan, a peace-loving nation, is delighted to see the United States willing to address the dispute through multilateral diplomatic channels, and that Taiwan supports the U.S. position on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISTS, CHARTER FLIGHTS AWAITING CHINA'S APPROVAL: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is ready to start talks with China at any time on opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists and setting up regular cross-Taiwan Strait charter passenger flights as soon as Chinese leaders give the nod, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Friday.

The Travel Agent Association of the Republic of China remains the government-designated body entitled to contact its Chinese equivalent, and all technical matters regarding the two issues are almost resolved, the MAC officials said.

But the officials were reserved about when representatives from the two sides could meet to wrap up negotiations, saying only that "the two measures could be put in place immediately once the Chinese side gives its approval."

"It would be a good idea to create the two openings in September and October when there is a long vacation period in China, " they opined, pointing out that Taiwan's current political situation may also affect when the two measures go into effect.

Premier Su Tseng-chang told a Dragon Boat Festival gathering with China-based Taiwanese businesspeople a day earlier that he would allow "a wide opening" of civilian exchanges with China under the framework of the "active management, effective opening" policy.
MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said on the same occasion that the two measures could be implemented in four or five months.

In a related development, tourism-related and construction shares in the Taiwan Stock Exchange surged robustly Friday on news that the government might allow Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan in the near future, directly rather than having to arrive from a third country.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FINANCE MINISTER QUESTIONED IN TDC INSIDER TRADING CASE

TEXT.P: Former Finance Minister Lin Chuan was questioned by prosecutors Friday in connection with an insider trading case in which President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law has been detained on suspicion of involvement.
Chao Chien-ming, the husband of Chen's daughter Chen Hsing-yu, was in detention on suspicion of using dummy accounts to buy and sell Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) shares on insider information.

The prosecutors wanted Lin to describe the process by which the Bank of Taiwan led a consortium of 19 banks to bail out TDC with syndicated loans, why the Bank of Taiwan recommended Su Teh-chien to be TDC chairman and how the Department of National Treasury decided to sell TDC shares. Su is also in custody.

The other focus of the prosecution's investigation is the sources of funding used by the Chao family to purchase TDC shares. For that purpose, investigators summoned several people for questioning, including National Taoyuan Hospital Director Ho Feng-ming, who was found to have remitted NT$500,000 to the bank account of Chao Chien-hsun, Chien-ming's younger brother. Ho resigned Thursday.

Also being questioned were Chen Hui-you, general affairs official at the president's residence; and Lin Che-min, a table tennis player in the national team. Chen and Lin told investigators they had asked other people to transfer money into the bank account of Chao Yu-chu, Chien-ming's father.
Hung Kuang-tsan, another table tennis player; and Chang Cheng-chung and Chang Cheng-an -- who are brothers and friends of Chao Chien-ming -- were found to have handled funds for Chien-ming.
Yu Shih-yi, a businessman detained since May 21, was also questioned to clarify details about the insider trading scandal, which has severely damaged support for the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WITHHOLDS COORDINATION WITH DPP ON KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) candidate for Kaohsiung mayor said Friday that it is too early yet to discuss whether the TSU and its "pan-green" alliance partner, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will field a single candidate in the Kaohsiung mayoral election.

Legislator Lo Chih-ming, TSU's candidate for Kaohsiung mayor, indicated through his office that he will not coordinate with DPP candidate Chen Chu until public prosecutors close the case on her role in a profiteering scandal involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.
Chen, former Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) chairwoman, was nominated by the DPP Friday as the party's candidate in the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral race.

Lo has questioned her integrity and urged her to withdraw from the race because he believes her chances of winning are slim. He has indicated that he will run in the election even if Chen is unwilling to yield.

Although some DPP officials favor using an opinion poll to select a single candidate to represent the pan-green camp, Lo's office said Lo will not coordinate with Chen until the dust has settled on the investigation of her role in the scandal.
Chen resigned from her post as CLA chairwoman in September last year to take political responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot in Kaohsiung County by hundreds of Thai laborers.

The scandal came to light after the Thai workers staged the riot to protest poor treatment by their employers and a labor brokerage firm. Subsequent investigations by public prosecutors indicated the possibility of a massive profiteering racket involving government officials, executives of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and construction companies contracted by the KRTC and two illegal brokerage firms.
Chen was questioned as a suspect by the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice last November and it is unclear whether she will eventually become a defendant in the case.

She has repeatedly faced questioning about the role she might have played in the DPP government's policy about-face that allowed the KRTC to hire Thai laborers instead of domestic workers for the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project.
Chen admitted before quitting her Cabinet post that the policy was reversed because of the intervention of an "influential figure," but she has never revealed the identity of that person.

The Washington Post: Six Powers Reach Accord On Iran Plan; U.S. Supports Combination Of Incentives, 'Disincentives'
The United States and five other major world powers agreed Thursday to offer Iran a broad new collection of rewards if it halts its drive to master nuclear technology, but they threatened "further steps in the Security Council" if Iran refuses.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqi Accuses U.S. of 'Daily' Attacks Against Civilians
Iraqui Premier Kamal al-Maliki lashed out at the American military on Thursday, denouncing what he characterized as habitual attacks by troops against Iraqi civilians. In his comments, Maliki said violence against civilians had become a "daily phenomenon" by many troops in the American-led coalition who "do not respect the Iraqi people."
Wall Street Journal: Free and Uneasy, Tale of 5 Muslims: Out of Guantanamo And Into Limbo
After four years in Guantanamo Bay, Abu Bakker Qassim, former terror suspect cleared last year of having ties to al Qaeda, got word last month that they finally would be set free. However, the five Muslims from China were loaded onto a U.S. military transport plane in the middle of the night, shackled to the floor and flown for 12 hours to their new home: a converted military barracks in Tirana, the capital of Albania. They were afraid to go home for fear of facing jail or execution if returned to their homelands.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MORE PRESIDENTIAL ADVISERS TO BE APPOINTED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decided Friday not to appoint any senior advisers or national policy advisers in the remaining two years of his second and final four-year term to signify his determination to promote political reform.
Chen was initially expected to name his new senior advisers and national policy advisers last week as the terms of his previous advisers expired May 20.
A Presidential Office news release said Chen, after comprehensive contemplation, has decided not to hire any advisers in response to public calls for political reform.

Chen was quoted as saying that he is very grateful to all his former advisers for their insightful and invaluable advice on handling national affairs, and expressed hope they would continue furnishing him with useful counsel and suggestions in the future.
Presidential Office sources said the "no more advisers" decision could save the government an estimated NT$130 million in annual expenditures.

According to Article 15 of the Presidential Office Organic Law, the president can hire up to 15 paid senior advisers and up to 15 unpaid senior advisers, plus a maximum 30 paid national policy advisers and up to 60 unpaid national policy advisers.

The "no more advisers" decision was seen as response to calls for Chen to abolish the presidential advisory system, as some of his senior advisers or policy advisers have been criticized as unqualified for the post or accused of involvement in scandals.

The decision followed Chen's announcement Wednesday that he will hand over policy-making and Cabinet-appointment authority to Premier Su Tseng-chang, a move that came amid increasing calls by both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and opposition for the president to take responsibility for a series of scandals embroiling his family and administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER ATTENDS APEC MEETING IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san has held bilateral talks with Taiwan's major trading partners on the sidelines of the 12th trade ministers meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which ended in Vietnam Friday.

According to MOFA officials, Hwang held talks with his counterparts from the United States, New Zealand, the Philippines, Japan, Mexico and host Vietnam on matters of mutual concern on the sideline of the APEC meeting.

As Vietnam will soon be admitted to the World Trade Organization, Hwang asked Vietnam to sign a free trade agreement and a temporary customs clearance agreement with Taiwan as well as offer visa-free privileges to Taiwanese citizens to boost bilateral economic cooperation and tourist exchanges, the officials said.

In his talks with the New Zealand representative, Hwang called for the opening of the New Zealand market to Taiwan-grown orchid, star fruit and lychee, the officials said, adding that Hwang also urged the Philippines to help its traders export gravel to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO REIN IN DRUG ABUSE, TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang directed the Ministry of Justice Friday to join forces with other government agencies and local governemns to crack down on drug trafficking and prevent drug abuse.
Su gave the instruction while presiding over an inter-department meeting on the campaign against drug abuse and trafficking.

The premier threw support behind a proposal to construct two more rehabilitation centers to help drug addicts quit their vice. At the moment, Taiwan has only two such facilities. He suggested that the justice ministry seek the assistance of the Ministry of National Defense to build new rehabilitation centers on unused military barracks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 3, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King" and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium in Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories include "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus" and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American sweetheart, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The U.S. Navy launches an attack against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treason. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution, with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for U.S. Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of the state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: An earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: A train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen visits the offshore islands of Tungyin and Matsu, his first visit to the frontline islands since he assumed the post on May 20.
2001: Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, says that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square is a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being forward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO PICK PREMIER FROM MAJORITY PARTY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng suggested Friday that President Chen Shui-bian pick a new premier from the political party that holds majority seats in the legislature in conformity with the basic spirit of the Constitution.
Wang aired his view while meeting with Huang Kwang-kuo, a representative of the Democracy Action Alliance who has been one of President Chen's most bitter critics.

Huang, a psychology professor at a National Taiwan University, said the nation's Constitution prescribes a dual-leadership governmental system which he claimed has been "distorted" into a presidential system with the president enjoying too much authority.

In the future, Huang said ruling and opposition parties should exercise self-discipline and jointly direct the governmental system toward a parliamentary system without any new round of constitutional amendments. He said the premier should be given the authority to endorse any major policy decision to be promulgated by the president and the Cabinet should respect the legislature's resolutions on major policy issues.

Wang echoed Huang's view, saying that the president should respect the legislature and let the majority party organize the Cabinet. "The president should pick a premier from the majority party which should also be authorized to form a Cabinet," he added.

The Wang-Huang meeting took place two days after President Chen said he will no longer exercise power beyond what the Constitution specifically conferred on him and will hand over policy-making and cabinet-appointment authority to Premier Su Tseng-chang amid rising calls in both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition camp to take responsibility for a recent rash of corruption allegations embroiling his family and administration.

Late Thursday, Chen accepted the resignation of his deputy chief of staff and perhaps his most trusted adviser, Ma Yung-cheng. In a Presidential Office news release, Ma said his decision to resign was a response to Chen's call for change.

Chen himself hasn't been implicated in any of the cases of alleged wrongdoing, but the allegations, particularly the detention of his son-in-law on suspicion of insider trading, have badly damaged him. Opposition lawmakers have urged him to resign and some of them have even initiated a motion to recall him.
