DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PROMOTES 'SOFT POWER' AT DPU MEETING

TEXT.P: The world, as a community sharing a common destiny, needs to promote and practise "soft power" because no-one will benefit from a zero-sum or negative-sum game, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.
Lu made the remarks while addressing via teleconference the opening of the 2006 West Pacific Regional Convention of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) held in Seoul, South Korea.
Lu pointed out that over the past century, the West Pacific region has experienced colonialism, ethnic confrontation and bloodshed originating from the endless pursuit of wealth and military power.

The formation of a global community sharing a common destiny has highlighted the importance of the values of democracy, peace and prosperity advocated by the DPU, Lu said, noting that of the five remaining countries practising communism in the world, four are in Asia.
Lu said she is convinced that the world will only enjoy stability and perpetual peace by sharing the values of democracy and that only through democracy and peace will prosperity be sustained.

Lu said that without democracy, the pursuit of economic prosperity will only expand the wealth disparity and that without peace, the pursuit of economic prosperity will only lead to arms races that sow the seeds of destructive military conflicts.

She said the DPU is different from the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) in that the DPU believes that democracy and peace should be given priority over the pursuit of economic prosperity.
She noted that the DPU has set up a Pacific disaster prevention center after its establishment last year and will soon form a Pacific parliamentary front and a Pacific university alliance.
The DPU is scheduled to hold a conference on bird flu control and prevention in Indonesia in July and will hold another conference on parliamentary reforms in Taipei in August, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Army Corps Admits Design Flaws in New Orleans Levees. The Army Corps of Engineers acknowledged Thursday that design defects in the levees protecting New Orleans caused the majority of flooding during Hurricane Katrina and that the disaster would almost certainly trigger reforms in how the federal government protected the American public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ANTI-DRUG EFFORTS `RECOGNIZED BY WORLD': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The fact that Taiwan has remained off a U.S. list of major drug-producing or drug-trading countries for six consecutive years shows that the nation's fight against narcotics has won international recognition, President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday.

Chen was referring to the 2006 International Narcotics Control Strategy Report released in March by the U.S. Department of State. He made the remarks in a written address to a national anti-drug conference held by the Executive Yuan.
Chen claimed that drug abuse and its accompanying crime seriously undermines the country's image, competitiveness and public order.

While a lot of new drugs have appeared in recent years, drug users and drug traffickers are starting at a younger age and the ratio of repeat and serial offenders is also rising in Taiwan, Chen pointed out.
Also, the sharing of needles among drug users has accelerated the spread of HIV, he said.

To promote a national campaign against narcotics, the Executive Yuan has made anti-drug operations a major part of its measures to improve the country's law and order, has worked out a program aimed at reducing the hazards of narcotics and AIDS and has declared 2005 to 2008 "years of national combat against narcotics," Chen said.

Meanwhile, the Executive Yuan has adopted four strategies, including drug prevention, drug rejection, drug withdrawal and drug crackdown, and holds regular briefings on drug control and prevention, he said.
The president urged the private sector to continue to work with the government to achieve the goal of making Taiwan a "drug-free country."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ECSTASY DRUG PMMA TO BE BANNED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has suggested placing paramethoxymethamphetamine (PMMA) on a list of banned ecstasy derivatives after the Criminal Investigation Bureau's (CIB's) forensic science researchers found three kinds of PMMA-containing street drugs among those confiscated by the police.

According to CIB experts in toxicant, PMMA is a ring-methoxlated phenethylamine derivative that affects the body in similar ways to ecstasy but because PMMA does not produce an immediate effect on the body, overdoses are common, the DOH claimed.
The drug caught world attention in 2001, when a young man in Belgium died of a PMMA overdose, according to the CIB.

With the fact that street drugs offered as ecstasy do not necessarily contain MDMA but frequently differ in composition, users therefore risk consuming pills with dangerous life-threatening ingredients.

The DOH asked judicial authorities to list the new amphetamine compounds as banned drugs while igniting its anti-drug abuse warning system to obtain the latest information on "dope evolution" and new ecstasy derivatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LAB RELEASES NEW III-V SOLAR POWER SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A laboratory under the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) released Saturday its newly invented "group III-V solar energy system, " which possesses a solar-to-electricity transfer ratio of more than 20 percent -- superior to traditional solar power systems that can only transform 10 percent to 14 percent of total light energy into electricity.

Group IV materials -- such as silicon and diamonds -- are widely used in making semiconductors. While searching for better substances, scientists found that group III-V compounds -- being better electricity conductors than group IV materials -- are more suitable for semiconductors. However, due to several technical difficulties, III-V semiconductors still have lower yields than silicon.

According to the AEC, the new solar energy system can generate a stable output of one kilowatt, as well as 0.5 degree accuracy in tracking the sun, which function will be improved to 0.2 degrees in the coming months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES END TO POLITICAL FIGHTING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday that political fighting does not live up to the expectations of the people.

The premier made the remarks amid reports that the opposition is mulling whether to recall President Chen Shui-bian or propose a no-confidence motion to topple the Cabinet in the wake of a string of corruption allegations implicating close aides of Chen and his son-in-law.

As the opposition People First Party (PFP) planned to stage a protest in front of the Presidential Office later in the day to call for the president to step down to take responsibility for the series of scandals, Su said that everyone has the freedom of assembly and expression in a democratic society.
But no acts should go beyond the legal boundary or affect social stability, Su said.

Su, generally considered to be one of the best bets for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run in the 2008 presidential election, said his administration hopes to serve the people, which he said is also the "greatest expectation of the public."

After Chen's announcement that he would delegate his power, the administration has been entrusted with a bigger task, Su said, adding that now is not the time to think about the 2008 presidential election or about who will succeed Chen, but "to get down to work."

In response to calls from the opposition for his resignation, Chen announced Wednesday that he would play his role as head of state strictly in line with the Constitution, giving Su "free rein" to lead the Cabinet. Chen also said that he would quit meddling in DPP affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 27 ICDF SCHOLARSHIP RECIPIENTS TO GRADUATE THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Twenty-seven recipients of graduate scholarship programs provided by the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) are set to graduate this summer, ICDF officials said Saturday.

The ICDF has since 1998 formed strategic alliances with local universities to provide full scholarships for students from the country's diplomatic allies to study in graduate programs in Taiwan, with 145 students having studied here under the scholarship.

Twenty-seven of the recipients will graduate this year from National Ping Tung University of Science and Technology, National Chengchi University, National Taiwan Ocean University, National Tsing Hua University, National Taiwan Normal University, National Yang-Ming University and National Central University, the officials said.
They are from 10 countries -- Burkina Faso, Senegal, Malawi, Gambia, Belize, Nicaragua, Honduras, Panama, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Solomon Islands, they said.

The officials said the foreign students can speak fluent Mandarin after spending several years in Taiwan and can contribute what they have learned in Taiwan to their countries after graduation, which is very helpful to enhancing substantial relations between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER MIGHT RUN IN TAIPEI MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh has begun to think about the possibility of throwing his hat into the ring for the year-end Taipei mayoral election, a lawmaker close to him said Saturday.
Legislator Wang Shih-chien of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) also said that he thinks the chances of Hsieh's running are high.

Although the DPP has targeted Hsieh from the beginning as the party's ideal candidate for the Taipei election, Hsieh has repeatedly said that he has no intention of running. The party has ended up in an embarrassing state with no candidate yet, as no one came forward to register in the party primary in late May.
Wang noted that when he called on Hsieh May 29, Hsieh asked him about his views on joining the Taipei mayoral election and he felt that Hsieh's insistence on not running had softened.
Wang said Hsieh has a great attachment to the DPP, noting that he took part in the drafting of its name and platform when it was founded in 1986.

However, in view of the slipping approval rating for the DPP because of a spate of corruption allegations revolving around President Chen Shui-bian's close aides and son-in-law, running in the Taipei mayoral election will not be favorable for Hsieh, Wang claimed.

But it will be positive for the DPP and the party will be able to keep its seats in the city councilor elections, according to Wang. Also, whether elected or not, Hsieh will probably be shut out of the 2008 presidential election, he added.
DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun echoed Wang's view, saying that Hsieh's participation will greatly boost the morale of the party, as Hsieh has a broad base of support among the grassroots supporters.
Saying that Hsieh has often taken on the most daunting tasks at the party's most difficult times, Yu expressed his admiration.
He also lauded Hsieh's "Kaohsiung experience, " which he claimed would contribute a great deal to Taipei's development.
Noting that Hsieh left a legacy of achievements during his six years as Kaohsiung mayor, including the dredging of the Love river, "neat and clean streets" and cleaning the city's drinking water.

He claimed that Taipei's development has been "very limited" over the past eight years since President Chen stepped down as Taipei mayor in 1998, adding that if Hsieh could serve as Taipei mayor, he would not only save the floundering party but would also make the city "on par with other metropolises."

DOC.HEADLINE: PART-TIME WORK EXPERIENCE ADVANTAGEOUS TO NEW GRADUATES: POLL

TEXT.P: Sixty-eight percent of new graduates in Taiwan have failed to get the positions they desire because of the lack of part-time work or internship experience, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

The survey conducted by 104 Job Bank, an online employment service provider, shows that the lack of work or part-time work experience was mentioned by 26.2 percent of new graduates as their weak point in job searches.
Also, 37.2 percent of the respondents named the lack of language ability as their weak point, while 34.3 percent mentioned the lack of professional skills.

Job bank officials suggested that students build up their competitive edge by seeking internships while they are still in school, noting that businesses usually offer higher pay to new graduates with internship experience.

They said the largest number of internship openings posted on the 104 Web site are for software design engineers, which account for 30 percent of all internship openings, followed by administrative assistants, which account for 22 percent.

Others include hotel staff, production management or testing personnel, financial or accounting assistants, marketing planning personnel, language school teachers, legal personnel, Internet program design engineers, computer system maintenance workers and restaurant waiters, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO REINFORCE RESTRICTIONS ON PESTICIDES MANAGEMENT

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is working to propose an amendment to the law regulating insecticides management to strengthen restrictions on sales of virulent pesticides as part of government efforts to prevent poisoning and suicide.
According to Department of Health statistics, suicide was listed as one of the top 10 causes of death among Taiwan people over the last eight years.
In 2004, liquefied or solid poisons, including pesticides, were the third most-used ways of committing suicide, the tallies show.

The COA began banning the production, processing, importing, sale and use of the virulent "90% methomyl" from June 1, while demanding that producers of methomyl in low-concentration include dyes, bitter or stink agents, or emetics to lower the risk of misuse, COA officials said Saturday.

The COA is also working to amend the pesticides management regulations to impose stricter restrictions on virulent insecticides buyers, who have to aged over 18. Upon purchasing agricultural poison, the shopper has to inform the seller of their personal data, and the purpose of the substance, the officials noted.

According to the drafted amendment, those who fail to follow the instructions will face punishment of fines ranging from NT$30,000 to NT$150,000 and will be deprived of their license to sell the poisons.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC CONFIRMS THIS YEAR'S FIRST JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS CASE

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control (CDC) confirmed Taiwan's first case of Japanese encephalitis (JE) Saturday and urged travelers to the southern part of the country to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes.

CDC Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi said there have been an average of around 30 JE cases annually during the past five years and he estimated that the number of JE patients this year will be similar to that of last year.
Shih said that the JE incubation period is roughly between five and 15 days, but that it is not contagious. The mosquitoes contract the virus by biting pigs and carry it until they die.

Recent tallies compiled by the CDC show that over half of the pigs they tested carried JE virus, and the subsequent confirmation of the first JE case indicates that the country has entered JE season, Shih said.
The confirmed case lives in the southern county of Tainan.
The patient, now hospitalized, was discovered May 20 with the symptoms of fever and difficulty speaking and his case was reported to the CDC May 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER DIES

TEXT.P: Former Legislative Yuan President Ni Wen-ya passed away at the Cathay General Hospital in Taipei Saturday at the age of 105.
A hospital spokesman said Ni showed no vital signs when he was rushed to the hospital that afternoon. Emergency resuscitation efforts failed and he was pronounced dead at 4:15 p.m.
The spokesman said that as Ni had no medical record at the hospital, it was up to his family if they wished to announce the cause of death.
Ni is best remembered for his gentle and refined manner and his superb political tact and acumen during his 16 years as the speaker of the Legislative Yuan between 1972 and 1988.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DPP PROTEST SPARKS VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: A protest organized by the opposition People First Party (PFP) to demand President Chen Shui-bian's resignation descended into chaos Saturday when a mob of PFP supporters, angry that the head of the party's "pan-blue alliance" ally the Kuomintang (KMT) refused to participate, set fire to a truck in front of the KMT headquarters.
The rally kicked off with "pan-blue" supporters throwing water balloons at Chen's portrait and shouting slogans on Ketagalan Boulevard, which runs in front of the Presidential Office.
In an unexpected twist, however, some of the protesters directed their discontent toward KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, accusing him of being "too soft" in his party's policymaking.
The breakaway protesters then started to throw eggs at the KMT headquarters building, but were broken up by police.

A man who claimed to be the owner of burned truck said later that he set fire to his vehicle to express his disapproval with a spate of scandals allegedly involving close aides and family members of the president.
The rally was led by PFP Chairman James Soong. Ma and Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng were both invited, but neither of them attended.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU, CHIAYI COUNTIES COMMEMORATE WORLD ENVIRONMENT DAY

TEXT.P: Various festive activities took place in Nantou, central Taiwan Saturday to mark World Environment Day, while Liuchiao township residents in Chiayi County commemorated the day by cleaning up their community.

A series of skits aimed at raising public awareness of environmental protection kicked off a ceremony in which Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-chin, along with 13 administrators of townships and villages in the county, vowed to spare no efforts to maintain a clean living environment.
Addressing the ceremony, Lee said he hopes the public will not be reluctant to clean up their homes and neighborhoods.

World Environment Day, commemorated each year on 5 June, is one of the principal vehicles through which the United Nations tries to stimulate worldwide awareness of the environment and enhance political attention and action.
According to Lee, every first Saturday of the month is marked as "cleaning day."
In support of the local initiative, a group of people living in Liuchiao township, headed by County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, set up a "street cleaning" movement.
Equipped with gloves, brooms and garbage bags, they picked up waste on the streets in the hope of awakening public awareness of the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEGISLATIVE CAUCUSES TO DECIDE TIME OF PRESIDENT'S STEPDOWN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the legislative caucuses of the KMT and its allies will decide the time and the method of President Chen Shui-bian's removal from office.
Ma made the remarks at a rally calling for Chen's resignation that was sponsored by the People First Party (PFP) , an ally of the KMT, in front of the Presidential Office.

Upon hearing his words, PFP Chairman James Soong urged an "immediate" proposal of a recall motion of Chen at the legislature in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations revolving around his close aides and son-in-law.

Ma, who earlier attended a plenary meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee, noted that Chen said Wednesday that he would restrain his family members, engage in reforms, and delegate power to Premier Su Tseng-chang.
The president is hoping that his "power sharing" will write off all the alleged wrongdoings by people around him, Ma said, questioning if Chen has any shred of remorse.
He also said the plenary session reached a consensus with its only goal to remove Chen.
It could be a recall of the president, a no-confidence motion to topple the Cabinet or any other form, because "the people can no longer put up with President Chen," Ma said.

To push for the goal, the legislative caucuses of the KMT will work closely with the caucuses of the PFP, New Party and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union to map out "the most effective and feasible approach."

Chen has lost the trust and respect of the people, Ma claimed, adding that if he tries to cling to power and get the DPP to solidify his floundering leadership, he will be making an even bigger mistake.
"President Chen, your days are numbered and your opportunities are fast slipping away," Ma said.

Ma said the party will first promote the recall and no-confidence motion in the legislature, saying that the party has collected more than a quarter of the signatures needed to establish a valid recall motion.
Meanwhile, in the earlier plenary session of the KMT, legislators proposed a recall of the president and the toppling of the Cabinet.
In addition, KMT Central Standing Committee member Lien Sheng-wen, son of honorary KMT Chairman Lien Chan, proposed a "Million people stand up" campaign.
Lien said that the drive will aim at gathering momentum to topple Chen, using such methods as a simulated referendum on the Internet, running ads and publicizing the message at specific locations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DON'T BLOW CASES BEING PROBED OUT OF PROPORTION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The opposition should refrain from "blowing out of proportion" criminal allegations that are still under investigation, a Presidential Office spokesman said Saturday.

Lee Nan-yang, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, made the call after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou threatened earlier in the day to initiate a vote of no-confidence in the legislature against President Chen Shui-bian's Cabinet over an insider trading allegation implicating his son-in-law.

Lee's call also coincided with a mass rally organized by the KMT's "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party -- in front of the Presidential Office pushing Chen to step down to take responsibility for a rash of corruption scandals allegedly involving his family and closest aides.

Noting that Taiwan is now a democratic society, Lee said the opposition should respect basic democratic principles. He said Chen has on many occasions reaffirmed his support for a proseuctorial inquiry into his son-in-law's alleged role in the Taiwan Development Corp. stock insider trading scandal and his willingness to respect a final judicial ruling on the case.

Moreover, Lee said, Chen has announced that he will no longer exercise power beyond what the Constitution specifically confers on him and will hand over policy-making and Cabinet-appointment authority to Premier Su Tseng-chang.

Stressing that Chen himself has not been implicated in any case of alleged wrongdoing, Lee said the opposition should show reason and rationality and refrain from "overblowing" suspected criminal allegations into a political crisis. "Doing so will only come at a heavy social cost and do no good for social stability, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S., Media Settle With Wen Ho Lee; News Organizations Pay To Keep Sources Secret.
Wen Ho Lee, the U.S. nuclear scientist once identified in news reports as the target of a spying investigation, will receive more than $1.6 million from the federal government and five media organizations, including The Washington Post, to settle allegations that government leaks violated his privacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES PARTIES TO END POLITICAL TURMOIL

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus whip urged parties across the political spectrum Saturday to end the turmoil over recent corruption allegations in which President Chen Shui-bian's close aides and family members are suspected of involvement.

DPP caucus whip Chen Chin-jun said that society will be chaotic if the opposition "pan-blue alliance" demands Chen's resignation simply for his son-in-law's alleged involvement in an insider trading scandal.

He said there are "many more important things to deal with" at the Legislative Yuan, such as more than NT$2 trillion worth of budget bills pending legislative approval, which could help boost the country's economy and upgrade its competitiveness if they could be passed by the legislature soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MEETING HOLDS KEY TO FORMER PREMIER'S RUNNING IN TAIPEI MAYORSHIP

TEXT.P: A meeting of a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) team on campaign strategy in the year-end elections next Wednesday will hold the key to whether former Premier Frank Hsieh will run in the Taipei mayoral election, DPP legislative whip Ker Chien-ming said Saturday.
Ker made the remarks after legislators sent out conflicting messages about Hsieh's joining the race.

Although the DPP has targeted Hsieh from the beginning as the party's ideal candidate for the Taipei election, Hsieh has repeatedly said that he has no intention of running. The party has ended up in an embarrassing state with no candidate yet, as no one came forward to register in the party primary in late May.
Meanwhile, DPP aspirants for Taipei city councilor elections said that Hsieh has lost the opportunity to "touch the heart of the people " by refusing to express his attitude clearly.

They also questioned if Hsieh, if he announces his bid, will only be reluctantly agreeing to throw his hat into the ring because he wants to jockey for a post in the runup to the 2008 presidential election in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's announcement Wednesday that he was "delegating his power" to Premier Su Tseng-chang, giving the latter a free rein in administrative work instead of being a mere executive director to the president as in the past.
The city councilor aspirants, including Wu Shih-yao, Lee Ching-feng and Lee Wei-ming, expressed their dissatisfaction over the lack of coordination ability of the party.

They said they were disappointed that DPP heavyweights, including Su, Hsien, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Vice President Annette Lu, have eyes only for the presidential election in 2008 and have no time or energy for the year-end mayoral and city councilor elections.

They said they will no longer wait for a decision from a DPP candidate and will decide themselves upon a "simulated mayor" that they can use to confront Hau Lung-bin, candidate of the opposition Kuomintang for the year-end mayoral election, on issues concerning city development.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN TAIWAN POLICY AFTER CHEN CEDES POWER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-you and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged in wake of President Chen Shui-bian's surprise announcement that he will cede some of his powers to Premier Su Tseng-chang to take responsibility for an insider trading allegation implicating his son-in-law, the U.S. State Department said Friday.

In response to Taiwan news media's inquiry about the U.S. government's view on Chen's latest move, the State Department said in a terse press statement that the investigations of corruption allegations involving Taiwan's first family are "internal matters of Taiwanese people."
"We have confidence that Taiwan's democratic society is strong and secure, " the State Department statement said, adding that the policy on U.S.-Taiwan relations remain unchanged.
The statement further said the United States has interest in stability across the Taiwan Strait and would like to see Taiwan's sustainable democratic development and prosperity.
The statement also said the U.S. government believes Taiwan's authorities will be able to get to the bottom of all corruption allegations through due processes enshrined in its Constitution and law.

Chen said in a statement issued by the Presidential Office Wednesday that he will hand over policy-making and cabinet-appointment authority to Premier Su, a move that came a week after the detention of his son-in-law following allegations of insider trading by an opposition lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DEFENDS CONSTITUTIONALITY OF PRESIDENT'S POWER DELEGATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's decision to hand over control of the Executive Yuan to Premier Su Tseng-chang is constitutional and doesn't violate any legal provisions, government spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Saturday.

Cheng was responding to questions about the constitutionality of Chen's recent delegation of policy-making and cabinet-appointment authority to Su in the wake of a rash of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
"Some critics claim that the president's move was in violation of the Constitution. Their criticism mainly results from their misunderstanding of our constitutional provisions," Cheng contended.

Quoting the Council of Grand Justices Interpretation No. 520, Cheng said the president is eligible to materialize his policy initiatives by naming a premier to carry out them. Against this backdrop, he said, the president can delegate more powers to the premier out of his trust in the latter.
"The power delegation doesn't involve any change to our existing constitutional framework and its constitutionality is beyond question," Cheng insisted.
While Su is appointed by the president, he is also held responsible to the legislature, Cheng said.
Quoting Premier Su, Cheng said the government must function continuously and effectively to maintain social stability and ensure economic prosperity and peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Cheng's issued the statement after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said his party will study either to launch a motion to recall Chen or a vote of no confidence against the Cabinet if Chen fails to resign to take responsibility for the string of corruption scandals allegedly involving his family and administration.

Ma made the remarks at a mass rally in front of the Presidential Office earlier in the day calling for Chen's resignation. The rally was organized by the KMT's "pan-blue" ally -- the People First Party.
In response, Cheng said either a presidential recall or a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet will cause social unrest and take toll on national development.

"Taiwan is now a mature democracy. Everybody has right to assembly and speech freedoms. All judicial cases should be handled in accordance with due process of law. Opposition parties should refrain from politicizing them. Any drastic move would let down the people and run against public expectations," Cheng said.

Since President Chen has on many occasions reaffirmed his support for a full proseuctorial inquiry into his son-in-law's alleged role in an insider trading scandal, Cheng said opposition parties should not "overblow" the case into a political crisis or abuse it as an excuse for political dogfight.

Touching on a U.S. State Department statement that the U.S. government has confidence that "Taiwan's democratic society is strong and secure" and that its policy on Taiwan-U.S. relations remains unchanged, Cheng said the government appreciates U.S. faith in Taiwan's democratic strength.

"It is hoped that all sectors of our society will cooperate to safeguard our hard-won young democracy and let politics be politics and judiciary be judiciary, " Cheng said, adding that he hopes opposition parties can refrain from blowing out of proportion criminal allegations that are still under probes.

The U.S. statement further said the United States has interest in stability across the Taiwan Strait and would like to see Taiwan's sustainable democratic development and prosperity. It added that the U.S. government believes Taiwan's authorities will be able to clarify all corruption allegations in accordance with the nation's Constitution and law.

President Chen said in a statement issued by the Presidential Office Wednesday that he will hand over policy-making and cabinet-appointment authority to Premier Su, a move that came a week after the detention of his son-in-law following allegations of insider trading by an opposition lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Initial Response to Marine Raid Draws Scrutiny
Marine commanders in Iraq learned within two days of the killings in Haditha last November that Iraqi civilians had died from gunfire, not a roadside bomb as initially reported, but the officers involved saw no reason to investigate further, according to a senior Marine officer. The handling of the matter by the senior Marine commanders in Haditha, and whether officers and enlisted personnel tried to cover up what happened or missed signs suggesting that the civilian killings were not accidental, has become a major element of the investigation by an Army general into the entire episode. Officials have said that the investigation, while not yet complete, is likely to conclude that a small group of marines carried out the unprovoked killings of two dozen civilians in the hours after a makeshift bomb killed a marine.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT NIXES 'HEIR-APPARENT' NOTION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that the notion of a national leader hand-picking a successor or an heir-apparent is outdated and not worth of talking about.

Lu made the remarks in response to a press inquiry while attending a National Central University commencement ceremony in Taoyuan about her views on the possibility of Premier Su Tseng-chang succeeding President Chen Shui-bian as the top leader of the country and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
In this democratic era, Lu said the nation has clear-cut rules governing the election of the head of state and the DPP has its own regulations governing party chairman election.

"The days are gone when a single person can determine the nation's or the party's succession issue, " Lu said, adding that the term "chiehpanjen" (heir-apparent) should be phased out in "our daily vocalbulary."

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 4 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday,June 4:
08:30, The Taipei Guest House will be open for public visits for the first time.
15:30, A global prayer day activity will be held at Ketagalan Bulevard near the Ministry of Foreign Affairs building.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA REQUESTS TAIWAN'S ASSISTANCE IN SCHOOL RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: An Indonesian municipal official has requested Taiwan to assist in rebuilding schools reduced into rubble in a devastating earthquake that hit his city in the central Indonesian island of Java May 27.

Yogyakarta City Mayor H. Herry Zudianto made the request Saturday when Taiwan Representative to Indonesia Lin Yung-lo and representatives from the Taipei-based Buddhist charity -- the Dharma Drum Mountain Culture and Eduction Foundation -- visited the Yogyakarta city government.

The mayor said nearly 200 elementary and high schools in his city were either completely destroyed or seriously damaged. It is hoped that Taiwan can assist in rebuilding some of those schools and constructing cultural and education centers to facilitate public education, he said.
The Dharma Drum Mountain representatives said they will decide how to help Yogyakarta rebuild its education facilities after making a careful evaluation.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's government authorities have purchased 25 tons of rice to be distributed to earthquake victims in the Yogyakarta area -- the ground zero of the 6.3 magnitude temblor that left more than 5,000 people dead and thousands of others homeless.
The Dharma Drum Mountain also donated 5 tons of rice to Indonesian authorities Saturday for distribution to residents in Bantul, the hardest-hit zone.

The Taiwan government sent a 26-member first-aid team, composed of well-trained rescuers and medical professionals, to help with post-disaster relief work last Sunday. The team was the first foreign rescue team to reach Bantul. The team took with it a large amount of relief goods and medical supplies. Taiwan authorities have also pledged to donate US$100,000 in quake relief fund to Indonesia.

Several other Taiwan charities, including World Vision Taiwan and Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, have also launched fund-raising campaign or sent volunteers to help with rehabilitation programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 4, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the French coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with U.S. Gen. Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1982: U.S. Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
2000: An ROC Navy goodwill flotilla reaches the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles.
2001: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- kicks off at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting a record high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad to take part in the five-day event.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Murakami quizzed on NBS
Prosecurtors and financial regulators have questioned well-known fund manager Yoshiaki Murakami on a voluntary basis over possible insider trading in connection with purchases of shares in Nippon Broadcasting System Inc. in 2005, investigative sources said Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush's India Plans at Risk.
A proposed nuclear deal with India that the White House considers one of the most important pillars of President Bush's foreign policy legacy is in jeopardy because of growing objections in Congress and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW METHANOL BATTERY INTRODUCED TO TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Portable Direct Methanol Fuel Cells (DMFC) that can continuously supply power to a Digital Video Disc (DVD) player for eight hours were introduced here by researchers at the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) Sunday.
The researcher said a new version half the size of the current DMFC and suitable for laptop computers will be unveiled by mid-June.

Using methanol as a power supply has become a new global trend. Generating power through reactions between methanol and air, the byproducts are pure water and half the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) produced by combustion engines with the same power output. DMFC technology is thus considered more environmentally friendly.

The official said the current 2kg version is capable of generating 15 watts of energy, while the new version for laptops scheduled for release on June 17 or 18 will be able to supply a power output of 25 watts for eight hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL RESEARCH TEAM INVENTS NEW SOLAR POWER SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A local research team in the central city of Taichung released Sunday its newly made solar power system "Chang Tien," which can utilize both light and heat emitted by the sun.

The head of the team, Wu I-lung, said that current solar power systems can only convert light to energy, while heat is left unused. He said, however, the new system is able to react both to heat and light, and therefore to generate more power than conventional systems.
Wu said the name "Chang Tien" in Chinese means "ever-lasting solar energy," a reference to the system's new feature.

Wu noted the new system not only applies to low-voltage everyday appliances such as radios, mobile phones and emergency lighting systems, but to systems that require greater amounts of energy such as ventilation, uninterruptible power supply and air conditioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DENIES RECOMMENDING KMT'S MA AS CABINET LEADER

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu categorically denied Sunday making the suggestion to President Chen Shui-bian that he consider inviting opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to form a new Cabinet.

According to a China Times report, Chen has never excluded the possibility of following Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's suggestion of allowing the majority party in the legislature to form a Cabinet. Chen has "started to seriously consider" Wang's proposal, according to the report.

The China Times went on to say that Lu has on private occasions recommended that Chen invite Ma to lead a new Cabinet. The Presidential Office's department of public affairs issued a brief statement Sunday denying that Lu has ever done so.
The "pan-blue alliance" of Kuomintang, the People First Party and independents enjoy a slight majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP AIDE SHRUGS OFF PRESIDENTIAL RECALL ATTEMPTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff said Sunday that the opposition's attempts to recall the president are not justified because the president has not been implicated in any wrongdoing.
Tan Sun Chen said the president was elected by the people of this country in accordance with the Constitution and that the president cannot be ousted if he is innocent of wrongdoing.
Tan Sun Chen called for opposition politicians not to destabilize Taiwan because of their own political agenda or electoral rancor.
"The public won't buy it," he asserted.

Meanwhile, the top presidential aide said he "didn't have the slightest idea" about Chen's intentions regarding media speculation that a coalition government may be formed by parliamentary majority after the president pledged last Wednesday to cede some of his executive power to Premier Su Tseng-chang in the wake of recent corruption scandals involving senior officials and members of the first family.

A local daily quoted an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) source as reporting Sunday that President Chen was not opposed to the formation of a coalition government as suggested by Legislature Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, and has "even started thinking about it seriously."
The daily also reported that some people have recommended to Chen that he consider inviting KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to lead a coalition government.

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus whip Chen Ching-chun said so far he "hasn't heard a single word" about President Chen "starting to think about a coalition government being formed by parliamentary majority."
Chen Ching-chun shrugged off the speculation, saying DPP legislators will not "dance to the tune" of the opposition or groundless media reports.

For his part, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday the public has reasons and the justification for either recalling the president or toppling the Cabinet, given that recent corruption scandals have aroused widespread public anger and the president has not shown any sign of remorse.
Ma said systematic and well-designed methods must be followed when the opposition launches either of these two approaches, which he said will be "unavoidably costly" in terms of social stability.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Palace urges wage consultations
Malacanang yesterday said Congress should hold more consultations with business groups on the wage increase measure approved by the House of Representatives on second reading to determine whether this would be feasible under the country's current business climate.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Probers eye 'jueteng'war
BATANGAS CITY -- Organized crime groups based in Batangas, including big-time"jueteng"operators, may have been behind the bomb attack on Gov. Armando Sanchez that killed two of his aides, officials said yesterday.
The Philippine Star: 'GMA insulting Congress by rejecting wage hike'
President Arroyo has insulted her foes -- and even her allies in the House of Representatives -- by rejecting the P125 legislated wage hike they had approved after more than six years of deliberating on the measure, detained Anakpawis Rep. Crispin Beltran said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Teachers up in arms
They are overworked, underpaid and angry. About 20,000 public-school teachers will express their indignation by marching in Manila on Monday in a show of protest timed with the opening of school.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY-FORMED CABINET NOT IN SPIRIT WITH ROC CONSTITUTION: J.T CHO

TEXT.P: Allowing the majority party in the legislature to form a Cabinet is not in accordance with the spirit of the Republic of China Constitution, a senior aide to President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday.

Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general to the president, was commenting on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's remarks that the Constitution allows the majority party to form the Cabinet although this has not been the case over the past six years.
President Chen Shui-bian's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has never been the majority party in the Legislative Yuan since Chen was first elected in 2000.

Ma made the remarks in response to a newspaper report that the president was "starting to seriously consider" Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's suggestion that he invite a majority party to form the Cabinet in order to overcome a political gridlock in the coming two years.

Cho said it was the former KMT administration which in previous amendments of the Constitution had stripped the legislature of its right of consent on the premier's appointment, thereby depriving the Constitution of "the spirit of allowing the majority party in the legislature to form the Cabinet."

It is unrealistic for opposition parties to now try to "discuss basic constitutional principles without seeking to explain why, when they led the campaign to amendment the Constitution, they had taken away the legislature's right of consent on the premier's appointment," Cho said.
He stressed that taking away the legislature's right to approve the appointment of the premier "was not an initiative of the DPP, " which came into power in 2000 and won re-election in 2004.

Cho continued that theoretically speaking, in a country that adopts the Cabinet system of government, a majority party in parliament forming the Cabinet is quite normal, but "it is very clear that it is simply not in the spirit of our Constitution to allow a majority party to form a Cabinet."
He added that he has never heard of President Chen Shui-bian talking about allowing a majority party to form a Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PROCUREMENT TO BUY PRODUCTS FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday that the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) of the Philippines will host a meeting to purchase processed food products and machinery equipment from Taiwan companies.

A DTI procurement group, led by the Philippine government and 17 companies, will visit Taiwan to attend the International Food Exhibition in Taipei from June 21 to 24 at TAITRA's Exhibition Hall at the World Trade Center, and is already set to meet with local manufacturers on June 19 to discuss purchasing.
The Philippine procurement group plans to buy agricultural products such as bananas, mangoes and durians, as well as equipment like squeezers for making juice and packing machinery.
TAITRA said it will arrange meetings between Taiwan suppliers who would like to sell to Philippine companies. The contact telephone number is 02-2725 5200 ext.1562.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VAGUE ON RUMORS OF NEW CABINET FORMULATION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou refused to be pinned down Sunday on whether he would serve as premier if President Chen Shui-bian agreed to allow the legislative majority to form the Cabinet in the event the current Cabinet is toppled by a no-confidence vote.

Ma gave no concrete answers on the subject when asked by reporters prior to a meeting of the KMT's Central Advisory Committee, after news reports alleged that Chen is "seriously" considering allowing the Cabinet to be formed by the majority in the Legislative Yuan should the current Cabinet led by Premier Su Tseng-chang be toppled by the "pan-blue alliance."
Stating that the Constitution allows the majority in the Legislative Yuan to form the Cabinet, Ma said that Chen had failed to adopt the practice over the past six years.
"For the time being, I am unable to respond to hypothetical cases," he said.

The KMT chairman also neglected to make it clear whether he would join a protest at the Presidential Office Saturday organized by the party's pan-blue alliance partner, the People First Party (PFP) -- the second of its kind after last weekend's -- to ask Chen to step down amid several high-profile corruption scandals involving his close aides and members of the first family.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, opined that it would help stabilize the political situation if the legislative majority could form the Cabinet in line with the spirit of the Constitution.
However, Wang did not say whether he supported either launching a motion to recall Chen or a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet -- an issue upon which the KMT and PFP remain divided.

Amid strong pressure to step down to assume responsibility for scandals embroiling his administration, Chen pledged earlier last week to cede any power to Su that is not expressly defined in the Constitution as the role of the executive.
Nevertheless, PPF legislative caucus whip Lee Hung-chun expressed fierce opposition to the idea of the pan-blue alliance forming a Cabinet at present.
"We want the corrupt and incompetent Chen to step down, not to 'split the loot' with the opposition," he stressed.

If the pan-blue alliance caves in and accepts the proposal to form a Cabinet, Chen would still remain in the presidency -- something which Lee said is against the public's expectations to remove Chen.

"Now is not a good time for the pan-blue alliance to set up a Cabinet, and the PFP will never bow to private partisan gains despite Chen's intention to lure opposition parties with political interests, " he said, pointing out that "the PFP will not stop its protests in the streets until Chen steps down."
"The present goal of the PFP is to boot out Chen from presidency, regardless of whether it's by resorting to a presidential recall motion or forcing him to resign," he said.
Meanwhile, KMT lawmakers accused Chen of plotting to slander the pan-blue alliance by saying that he is mulling the possibility of allowing Ma to form a Cabinet.

If Chen is sincere in his promise to serve the nation strictly in line with the Constitution, he should invite leaders of all parties to discuss the formation of a coalition government instead of making backroom deals, KMT Legislator Lai Shyi-bao said.

KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Jie and Tsai Ching-lung said that it is "unbelievable" that Chen would ask Ma to form a Cabinet at a time when the pan-blue alliance is trying to recall Chen or topple Su.
They described media reports about Ma forming a Cabinet as Chen's scheme to "drag out" the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD SAYS CHINA SHOULD NOT FEAR DEMOCRATIC REFORM

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged China Sunday not to be afraid of pursuing democratic reform, claiming Taiwan's experience shows it would not affect China's economic development.

Speaking at a seminar held at National Taiwan Normal University marking the 17th anniversary of the Tiananmen Massacre, Ma admitted that Beijing was "not very happy" with his participating in such functions every year.
In response to media queries as to whether he felt a little hesitant about joining such activities, he said he hadn't the slightest compunction.
"I am just trying to share my experience in handling the Feb. 28, 1946 tragedy, and not trying to use the opportunity to sabotage China," he added.

Ma stressed that in Taiwan, it took 40 years to rehabilitate and comfort victims and bereaved families of the Feb. 28 tragedy. As China is equipped with better information technology than the Taiwan of 1947, "I believe China's rehabilitation of the June 4 Incident will be faster than Taiwan's [of the Feb. 28 tragedy]," he said.

Citing the Taiwan experience, Ma said political reform will not affect China's economic development. On the contrary, it would help people vent their anger and frustration, "so China should not be afraid of pursuing democratic reform," he added.
On Taiwan's growing economic dependence on its neighbor, Ma said China's economy has grown at an unprecedented pace following the 1989 Tiananmen Square tragedy.
"For Taiwan, China is both an opportunity and a threat in that it is targeting missiles at Taiwan," he said.
Lin Cho-shui, a Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker, said corruption in China is more serious now than when the June 4 Massacre occurred.

"Though Taiwan's democracy is not very successful, it is after all a democracy, " Lin said, adding that as a fellow ethnic Chinese, he hopes China will develop into a democracy, a development which he said would be "a blessing" to people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SUBSTANDARD QUALITY FOODS' MOST URGENT HEALTH PROBLEM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The issue of "substandard qulity foods" is considered the most worrisome public health problem in Taiwan, the Taipei Medical University (TMU) found in its latest opinion poll, the results of which were publicized Sunday.
In the survey, 33 percent of respondents said "substandard qulity foods," originating mostly from China or elsewhere outside of Taiwan, pose the greatest threat to Taiwanese people's health.
A total of 32.4 percent of respondents said "how to lead a healthy life" is the most important issue for them, according to Prof. Han Po-cheng of the TMU's Department of Public Health.

The university conducted the survey by telephone in mid-May, obtaining 660 valid responses from adults randomly selected in major cities around the island. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points, Han said.
Only 12.3 percent of those surveyed identified "avian flu" as the most critical issue in Taiwan's public health, the poll found.
Meanwhile, 42.6 percent consider many news reports or TV talk shows to be commercial ploys by private companies to promote their products.
Another 45 percent disapprove of entertainers or celebrities appearing on television or in print media to promote health products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SENIOR NSC OFFICIALS TO BE REPLACED

TEXT.P: Two deputy secretary-generals of the National Security Council (NSC) will be replaced as part of President Chen Shui-bian's efforts at government reform amid growing pressure for him to step down over a string of corruption charges involving his senior aides and family members.

According to a press release issued by the Presidential Office's department of public affairs Sunday, Parris Chang and Tsai Ming-hsien, the NSC's deputy secretaries-general, will leave their posts. But according to Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to the president, NSC Secretary-General Chiou I-jen will remain in his post.

The adjustments in personnel are in line with President Chen's May 31 announcement to delegate power and reform the government, said the release, which noted that all political appointees in the NSC, including the secretary-general, deputy secretaries-general as well as advisers, will be strictly prohibited from stumping for party candidates.
These political appointees will also be banned from involvement in political party activities, said the release.
Chang and Tsai's removal follow the "voluntary resignations" of Lin Chin-chang, an NSC adviser, and Ma Yung-cheng, a deputy secretary-general to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE SHOULD STOP POLITICAL INFIGHTING: GIO HEAD

TEXT.P: Government Information Office chief Cheng Wen-tsan urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Sunday to stop political maneuvering aimed at recalling President Chen Shui-bian or toppling the Cabinet, and to instead work toward maintaining social stability.

Cheng also denied knowledge of a media report that Chen is gauging the possibility of allowing the majority in the Legislative Yuan to form a Cabinet at a time when the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) are poised to recall Chen or topple Premier Su Tseng-chang as head of the Cabinet, amid a string of high-profile corruption scandals embroiling Chen's family members and close aides.

Stressing that the corruption cases are judicial matters, Cheng said that "politicized maneuvering" will by no means help stabilize the situation and that "a paralyzed government will only fuel confrontation and instability in society."

Both ruling and opposition camps should respond to the public's demands, he said, adding the most pressing task at present is to hold an extraordinary legislative session and to pass as quickly as possible several key budgets pending in the legislature, Cheng said.

The Legislative Yuan session ended dramatically May 30 after a final session of scuffling and clashes erupted between pan-blue lawmakers and "pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

DPP lawmakers Cheng Yun-peng and Hsiao Bi-khim contended that conditions are "not yet ripe" for the pan-blue alliance to form a Cabinet, arguing the most critical objective is to maintain political, economic and social stability.

Meanwhile, the TSU described as "impossible" rumors that Chen is "starting to seriously consider" the possibility of allowing the pan-blue alliance -- which controls a slight majority in the Legislative Yuan -- to form a Cabinet.

According to two of the TSU's three legislative caucus whips, David Huang and Lo Chih-ming, a Cabinet formed by the pan-blue alliance would not only fail to safeguard Taiwan but instead "pave the way" toward Taiwan's unification with China.

Wrongdoing by the president's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, who was taken into custody by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office late last month for his suspected role in an insider trading, has nothing to do with Chen or Su, and the pan-blue camp must not use Chao as a political weapon to fight against Chen, Huang said.
Lo warned the DPP of fiercer political infighting should Chen replace Su, saying that the DPP's powerful New Tide faction, which maintains close ties with Su, would fight back.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARKING LOTS, SUITES, STORES MOST POPULAR INVESTMENT TARGETS

TEXT.P: With hot money pouring into the market, parking spaces, executive suites and stores have all become the most popular investment targets in Taiwan, while residences still remain high on the list, a real estate agent said Sunday.

Lin Chien, General Manager of H&B Realty, said the demand for real estate varies from region to region, with parking lots a welcome investment in the north, executive suites in the central region and stores in southern Taiwan.
The price of real estate and maintenance costs in metropolitan Taipei are higher, and there aren't too many residence units on the selling block, Lin said.
She said 6- to 8-percent returns are possible for those who invest in parking lots in a good location, since parking spaces require little maintenance.
For the central Taiwan area, Lin said executive suites are an excellent choice as long as they are in good condition and equipped with broadband Internet access.

H&B Realty pointed out that the neighborhoods of Tunghai University and Feng Chia University are the best areas for rented suites, adding the suites would have a 10-percent investment return if they are well managed.
Stores would be the best investment choice in the Kaohsiung area, where the population is only half of Taipei's and where lifestyles and investment habits are quite different from the capital city.

Given the general public's expectations about the post-2008 political climate and the long-held belief that real estate best maintains its investment value, more and more people in Taiwan would like to invest in it, Lin said.

However, Lin advised potential investors to carefully pick their investment targets and manage their finances, and avoid for example borrowing too much from banks to purchase property that carries high interest rates on the mortgage.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGLE SHOE BANK LAUNCHED IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Not everyone needs shoes in pairs, not least the person with deformed feet, so a bank of shoes for single foot was launched Sunday in Taichung, central Taiwan by a charity for physically-challenged people.

The Taipei-based Cheng Fung-hsi Foundation in partnership with a local shoe company set up the bank to help people who suffered foot disorders and therefore need only one shoe rather than a pair of shoes.

Wu Chi-chao who founded the foundation in 1977 in memory of her late handicapped husband said in a ceremony marking the inauguration of the bank that it is a waste and punishment for people who have only one foot, or have two feet of different length, shape or sizes to buy a pair of shoes at a time.
Thanks for a local shoe company which donated its unsold shoes, the Cheng Feng-hsi Foundation was capable of setting up the bank to offer shoes freely to people with deformed feets, Wu said.
About 1,000 people attended the opening ceremony of the bank and those of them with deformed feet, were given a free shoe of the size of their foot.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM BUS AND TRAIN PROMOTIONAL DISCOUNT ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau of Taiwan announced Sunday a new "Taiwan tourism bus" discount rate which is combined with existing western Taiwan tourism trains, offering a NT$999 day pass for Monday through Thursday journeys until June 30.

The Taiwan tourism bus will run on more than 40 sightseeing routes, while the western tourism trains, operated by ezTravel this year, will depart daily from Taipei at 7: 40 a.m. and from Fangliao, Pingtung County, at 2:12 p.m.

The first Taiwan tourism bus package tour, which will take you to history sites in central and southern Taiwan, costs only NT$999 per person for a round trip ticket of "President 1" train first class Monday through Thursday.
The rates will be a little more expensive on Friday and weekend including Saturday and Sunday, which cost NT$1,990 and NT$2,500 respectively, Tourism Bureau said.

As for the central Taiwan trip from Taipei to some tourism spots such as Changhua, Lukang little township, and Pa Kua Shan's Buddhist Statue, will also only cost NT$999 Monday to Thursday, NT$1,350 on Friday, and NT$1,500 on the weekend.

The third line for the tourism bus and train combo is from Taipei to Taichung, where the Sun Moon Lake is the destination of the journey. The cost is NT$1,190 per person Monday through Thursday, while Friday's rate is NT$1,490 and weekend price, NT$1,750.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS MIDDLE EAST COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang has gone to visit an unspecified middle eastern state since May 31 and will be back within a couple of days, a source at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Sunday. As that middle eastern country has not diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Huang flew to that country unannounced, the source said.
The ministry's spokesman Michel Lu confirmed Sunday that Huang has gone on an overseas trip but wouldn't reveal which country he is visiting.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SINGLE SHOE BANK' LAUNCHED IN TAICHUNG(repeat)

TEXT.P: Not everyone needs shoes in pairs, so a charity for physically-challenged people has decided to launch a "single shoe bank" to provide shoes to people with foot disorders.
The Taipei-based Cheng Fung-hsi Foundation, in partnership with a local shoe company, set up the bank in Taichung, central Taiwan Sunday.

Wu Chi-chao who founded the foundation in 1977 in memory of her late husband who was physically challenged, said in a ceremony marking the inauguration of the shoe bank that it is difficult for people with only one foot, or with feet of different length, shape or size to find suitable footwear.

"Thanks to the local shoe company which donated a batch of unsold shoes, the Cheng Feng-hsi Foundation has been able to set up the bank to offer shoes for free to people who face such problems," Wu said.
About 1,000 people attended the inauguration ceremony, with dozens of physically challenged people being presented with free shoes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER REPORTEDLY ON VISIT TO MIDDLE EAST COUNTRY(repeat)

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang departed Taiwan May 31 to visit an unspecified country in the Middle East, a ministry source said Sunday.
As the Middle Eastern country does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Huang's visit was not announced, the source said.
Ministry spokesman Michel Lu confirmed Sunday that Huang had departed on an overseas trip, but he wouldn't reveal which country the minister was visiting.
According to the source, Huang is scheduled to return to Taiwan in a few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 5, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, the Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1883: British economist John Maynard Keynes is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces in China.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective controls.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignia, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends a five-day visit to Taipei.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: U.S. President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.
2000: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew turns down an offer of a job as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says that in addition to financial aid, the Republic of China is to offer economic advice to its allies in the same way the United States helped the island some 50 years ago.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN ON VISIT IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China policy planner has departed for Japan Sunday for a three-day visit, mainly to exchange views with Japanese strategists and political heavyweights on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and interactions among Taiwan, Japan and China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Monday.

Terming MAC Chairman Joseph Wu's current visit to Japan as "routine, " MAC officials said Wu will mainly explain the Taiwan administration's position on cross-strait and Taiwan-Japan-China relations in order to prevent Beijing from misleading Japan, the United States and the European Union on relevant issues.

Wu is maintaining a low profile on his current Japan visit given Taiwan's difficult diplomatic situation and given that China maintains formal diplomatic relations with Japan and other important countries, the MAC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO MEET WITH PARTY LEADERS TO SOLIDIFY DPP ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang will have a working lunch with Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and DPP legislative caucus chief Ker Chien-ming on Monday in an effort to cement ties among his administration, the ruling party and the legislature.

Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsai said the meeting was initiated by the premier with the purpose of seeking backing for his administration from the ruling party and DPP lawmakers as well as closer cooperation among them.

In addition to exchanges of views on a wide range of issues, the Executive Yuan's request for an extra legislative session to debate budget bills urgently needed by the Executive Yuan will be broached in the meeting, Cheng said.
Instead of politically-charged bills, only bills closely related to the people's livelihood and the economy should be discussed in the extra session, Tseng quoted the premier as saying.
