DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAS NO INFORMATION ON TWO OUTGOING NSC SENIOR OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that it has no information on two outgoing deputy secretary-generals of the National Security Council (MSC) who reportedly will soon serve as directors of ROC representative offices overseas.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks after reports said that Parris Chang and Tsai Ming-hsien, the NSC's deputy secretary-generals, will soon be dispatched overseas after leaving their posts. According to the NSC press release, the adjustments in personnel are in line with President Chen's May 31 announcement to delegate power and reform the government.
Lu said that the assignment of the directors of ROC's overseas missions will follow set procedures, and he has "no information" on the two at present.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is expected to undergo personnel changes, with Michael Ying-mao Kau, originally vice foreign affairs minister, recently assuming the post of representative to the European Union, representative-designate to Malaysia Ouyang Jui-hsiung passing away after an illness, ROC Representative to Israel Deng Sheng-sheng recently retiring, and the recent promotion of Chang Siao-yue, originally representative to the Netherlands, to vice foreign affairs minister.

Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-feng recently said that the ministry has actively planned on major personnel changes and that most of the vacancies will be filled by personnel from the diplomatic system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE PHILATELISTS WIN AWARDS AT WASHINGTON 2006 STAMP EXPO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 4 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The "small dragons" stamp collection of Taiwanese philatelist Ho Mu-yuan recently won a Grand Prix Award at the Washington 2006 World Philatelic Exhibition, the highest honor in the world for stamp collectors.
The Washington World Stamp Expo, held every 10 years, attracted the participation of general post offices from more than 100 countries around the world in its 2006 show held from May 27 to June 3.

Thousands of professional stamp collectors, dealers and amateurs from around the globe visited this year's exhibition which was the largest ever of its kind due to the celebration of the Switzerland-based International Federation of Philately to mark its 80th founding anniversary.

Besides Ho, Chen An-you's collection of Chin Dynasty post cards took a gold medal, while Chen Ho-lin's collection of ocean-themed stamps won a vermeil during the world-class stamp competition, which also saw two other Taiwan collections of stamps and two documentary books awarded.

Hsiao Shi-sheng, former chairman of the Chinese Taipei Philatelic Federation, said Sunday that he is proud to see Taiwan decorated with the awards, which are regarded as the top honor in the hearts of stamp collectors. Hsiao is a member of a special committee in charge of the work to select fine Taiwanese philatelic collections for the contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU CALLS FOR MEETING OF LEADERS ACROSS POLITICAL SPECTRUM

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Monday called for a meeting of leaders from across Taiwan's political spectrum at this crucial juncture when Taiwan is facing an increasingly difficult situation in the international arena and turbulent politics at home.

Lu said that with President Chen Shui-bian's consent, she invited legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng Monday to collaborate with her to arrange an unprecedented meeting of President Chen, herself, Wang, the presidents of the Executive Yuan, Judicial Yuan and Examination Yuan, as well as leaders of the five major political parties to jointly tackle challenges and disputes facing Taiwan "with wisdom and in a rational and responsible manner."
Lu made the call after she delivered a keynote speech at the 2006 Taiwan-U.S. Technology and Industry Summit Forum, which opened in Taipei Monday.

In the face of partisan rancor and growing pressure from the opposition, which held a rally over the weekend to demand that Chen step down a week after the detention of his son-in-law following allegations of insider trading by an opposition legislator, Lu called for all parties concerned to demonstrate rationality and observe the Constitution.

Noting that President Chen has already met with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong and with Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in the past, Lu said there is no reason why such meetings cannot be expanded in scope to include other top leaders in order to "allow for a more resourceful meeting."

Lu appealed to all parties concerned to support the proposed meeting, noting that there are many major issues that urgently need to be tackled and that the whole country is eagerly expecting that the current volatile domestic situation will be stabilized soon.

The subject of Chen's son-in-law's alleged involvement in insider trading as well as a series of suspected corruption scandals involving top officials in the president's administration have aroused widespread public anger.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 244.37 points to close at 6,715.27.
The bourse opened at 6,956.77 and fluctuated between 6,967.38 and 6,700.47 during trading. A total of 3.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$100.35 billion (US$3.14 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 5.4 percent, followed by construction issues at 5.1 percent, textile stocks at 4.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 3.9 percent, cement stocks at 3.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.9 percent, and foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 781 to 46, with 36 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TO FILE DEFAMATION LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh is planning to file a defamation lawsuit against former Legislator Lin Ruey-tu, former Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao said Monday.

On behalf of Hsieh and accompanied by lawyer Chuang Ruey-hsiung, Yao held a press conference to clarify several accusations made by Lin against Hsieh, who expressed the hope that his filing of the lawsuit will help curb the growing tendency of people to slander others.

Lin claimed that Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) Chairman Su Teh-chien had given NT$3 million to then Premier Hsieh's relatives to try to solicit Hsieh's influence to help in Su's bid for the chairmanship of the company.
Noting that Hsieh and his relatives have no financial relations with Su, Chuang said Lin's accusations were unfounded.
Lin also accused Hsieh of illegally helping Yu Shih-yi, general manager of Kuan-Pin Co., make profits in some land acquisition projects when he was serving as Kaohsiung mayor.
However, Chuang noted that such land acquisition projects did not have to be passed through Hsieh, saying that Lin's accusations defamed Hsieh's reputation.

Yao urged the public not to use double standards in judging different politicians, noting that he didn't see anybody doubt Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's credibility after he attended several high-profile banquets held by Fubon Commercial Bank and decided afterward to sell Taipei Bank to Fubon.
As Ma also owned Fubon Commercial Bank stocks, Yao said Ma's case is more complicated than Hsieh's, expressing wonder as to why no one paid any attention to Ma's case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June dropped 289 points to close at 6,678, with 56,135 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July moved down 248 points to finish at 6,650, with 1,035 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 262 points to close at 6,520, with 137 contract transactions.
December futures lost 275 points to close at 6,515, with 109 contracts traded, while March futures dropped 279 points to finish at 6,506, with 12 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,967 for June, 6,898 for July, 6,782 for September, 6,790 for December and 6,785 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 15.95 points to close at 282.55, with 6,754 contracts traded, while July TE futures moved down 15.2 points to finish at 281.8, with 76 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 15.75 points to close at 276.25, with 10 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved down 37.8 points to finish at 953.2, with 4,701 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures lost 33.4 points to close at 948.6, with 76 contracts traded.
September TF futures lost 36.4 points to finish at 936, with eight contracts traded, while December TF futres moved down 3.4 points to close at 947, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PROPOSE EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will propose an extra legislative session in a planned meeting of ruling and opposition lawmakers Monday, according to a KMT legislative caucus whip.
Pan Wei-kang said the KMT caucus is planning to give priority to a special budget bill for flood-control at the proposed extra session.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will host the meeting Monday for party-to-party negotiations on the issue of whether or not to open an extra session after the first legislative session of this year closed May 30 without addressing several major budget bills, including some relating to state-owned enterprises and government operations.
There are other draft amendment packages, such as the one concerning the opening direct transport links with China, also awaiting legislative approval.

Demanding that all political parties promise not block discussions during the planned session, Pan said efforts should be made to prevent lawmakers from occupying the podium as a strategy to block bills they oppose. She was referring to clashes between ruling and opposition lawmakers over the direct links amendments package May 30.
Pan said the KMT will not insist on placing the direct links package as top priority in the extra session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACES 4TH CRISIS SINCE 1979: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu warned Monday that Taiwan is facing a major crisis as a result of long-time political confrontation and the exposure of a series of corruption scandals over the past six months, which she said has scared away foreign investors.

Lu described the crisis as "the fourth of its kind" since the severance of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the United States in 1979, the Kaohsiung Incident that occurring at the same time, and the weeks of political turmoil that erupted after the March 20, 2004 presidential election.
Lu made the remarks while addressing a Taiwan-U.S. technology industry summit.

Looking ahead, Lu said, the ruling and opposition parties need to cooperate to overcome three challenges -- building a clean government, upholding judicial justice and independence and the rule of law, and protecting the country's democratic system.

Lu claimed that compared with the past, when a lot of corrupt officials were not brought to justice, the country's judicial system is fairer now that officials allegedly involved in the scandals are under investigation and facing possible indictment.
She urged people who make allegations against others to back up their allegations with evidence and avoid jumping to conclusion before any conviction is handed down by the court.

Suggesting that the ruling and opposition parties seek to resolve their differences under the constitutional framework, Lu called on the leaders of the five major political parties to accept her invitation to a meeting with the heads of the five government branches to try to find solutions to the problems facing the country.

Lu expressed hope that the ruling and opposition parties will drop their struggle and put their heads together rationally and responsibly to hammer out what she described as "a blue ocean strategy" for the country's future development. SHe did not elaborate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, losing NT$0.031 to close at NT$32.049.
A total of US$833 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.080 and hit a low of NT$31.958.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP APEC MEMBER COUNTRIES DEVELOP SIGNATURE INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to collaborate with Thailand to help Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum member countries develop industries with "local features" based on the framework of an APEC digital opportunity center (ADOC) initiated by Taiwan, Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san said Monday.

Under the ADOC framework, Hwang said, an information and product exhibition platform will be established and summit meetings, market-oriented forums and Web site expositions, as well as training seminars, will be held to help create jobs in remote areas and narrow the digital gap and the gap between the rich and poor in APEC member countries.

Hwang made the announcement in an address delivered at the 2006 Taipei Summit -- a summit among high-technology research institutes and businesses from Taiwan and 10 Southeast Asian countries -- which opened in Taipei Monday with over 200 officials and industrial heavyweights from home and abroad participating.

Hwang welcomed the delegates to the summit, saying that the two-day meeting will serve as a platform where the participants can exchange opinions on the investment environment for the information, communications and technology (ICT) industries, probe new, innovative technologies and discuss new formulas for cross-border cooperation.

He said it is hoped that via the summit, Taiwan -- the world's No. 1 producer or provider of 10 high-technology products and technologies, including notebook PCs, LCD monitors, modems and semiconductor OEM production -- and the Southeast Asian countries that have strived to develop ICT industries in the recent decade, will cooperate further to create a mutually beneficial economic and trade environments for all.

According to Hwang, Taiwan, taking advantage of its strong ICT industries, proposed at a 2003 APEC meeting the establishment of the ADOC aimed at helping APEC member countries transform "digital gaps" into "digital opportunities."

Another advocacy of the "one village, one product" (OVOP) program, designed to help rural areas develop their own signature products with local features, was also promoted at the 2003 APEC meeting, and was highly valued by APEC delegates from Japan, Thailand, Indonesia and Taiwan, Hwang said.

Based on that concept, Hwang added, Taiwan is working to cooperate with Thailand to help APEC member countries develop their own industries with local features using Taiwan's development experience of the ICT industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'JUST WAIT AND SEE MY FEROCIOUS SIDE': KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou refused to be branded as "too soft" toward scandal-plagued President Chen Shui-bian Monday and challenged those who have such an impression of him to "just wait and see" his "ferocious side."
Ma, who also serves as Taipei mayor, made the remarks while fielding questions at the Taipei city council.

City Councilwoman Li-Keng Kui-fang asked Ma to explain his positions on two separate proposals to dismiss the Cabinet and recall the president, who is dogged by a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.

Li-Keng urged Ma to "harden up" and not "fall into the president's trap" by accepting his concession of allowing the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which enjoys a slight majority in the legislature, to form the Cabinet.

In reply, Ma said that although he did not know the origin of the reports that the president is considering letting the majority party in the legislature form the Cabinet, he was sure the proposal was apparently intended to shift attention from the crisis faced by the president.
"I'm not so stupid as to dance to their tune, " he said, adding that the most important thing at present is to get to the bottom of all the corruption scandals.

Ma said the proposal to allow the majority party in the legislature to form the Cabinet would cause a disturbance in the opposition parties and attract the nation's attention by creating a new political struggle.
Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party has never been the majority party in the Legislative Yuan since he was first elected in 2000.

News reports Sunday said the president was "starting to seriously consider" Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's suggestion that he invite a majority party to form the Cabinet in order to overcome a political gridlock in the remaining two years of his second term.

The KMT chairman was criticized by members of his own party for his reluctance to support a motion to recall the president, saying it was "not time yet to pull the trigger." Under mounting pressure, he suggested that a motion to dismiss the Cabinet would appear more feasible.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO MEET WITH TAIEX CHAIRMAN OVER PLANNED DEPARTURE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang confirmed Monday that Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Chairman Wu Nai-jen has told him that he plans to leave his post and said he will talk with Wu about the matter.
Su was responding to reports that Wu, a heavyweight of the powerful New Tide faction within the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will quit next month.
Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said Su will only consider if an individual is suitable for a post and will not take into account the individual's political or factional background.

Wu's planned departure came after President Chen Shui-bian announced last Wednesday that he would give Su free rein in setting the policy of his administration, inadvertently triggering misgivings among the various DPP factions.
Wu said that other DPP factions claim that the New Tide benefits most from its close association with Su and that members of the faction have too many key posts.

But Wu said that only two New Tide members -- himself and Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the National Security Council -- have taken the more conspicuous posts. "If Chiou asks my views, I'll advise him to leave too, which will be good for everyone." Chiou is also a New Tide heavyweight. Wu said he is also considering asking all New Tide members to leave their government posts.
DPP legislators had mixed reactions about Wu's planned departure.
New Tide Legislator William Lai had a positive reaction, saying that Wu is leaving because he wants to assuage the misgivings of the other party factions.
Another New Tide Legislator Lin Cho-shui said that since the DPP became the ruling party in 2000, members of the New Tide have never served as the heads of any of the five yuans, Lin said.

As calls mount for a recall of the president or a no-confidence motion to topple the Cabinet, the DPP should think about the problems the party will face in the 2007 legislative elections and 2008 presidential election, Lin said.

Lin dismissed reports that Su is forming a partnership with the New Tide, saying that several sitting ministers are associated with the Welfare State faction, of which former Premier Frank Hsieh is a heavyweight. "It is better to say that Su and Hsieh are forming a partnership," Lin added.
Legislator Gao Ji-peng of the Justice Alliance faction said that whether Wu's quitting will help promote party solidarity remains to be seen.

Gao said that the New Tide did not have many administrative posts, but added that "one has to consider the feelings of others." Furthermore, the rifts between the New Tide and other factions over the years will also not be easily sorted out, he added.
Legislator and convener of the Welfare State faction Lee Chun-yi said that Wu's quitting will mean a retreat of the powerful New Tide faction from President Chen's coterie.

The plight of Chen, mired in a series of corruption allegations involving his close aides and son-in-law, could be exacerbated, which is also the price the president has to pay for putting a premium on the New Tide members in the beginning, Lee claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW IMMIGRANT PROMOTES TAIWAN TEA

TEXT.P: A Chinese woman married to a Taiwan citizen captured the attention of visitors to a Taiwan tea trade fair Monday in the tea-growing Minchien township of central Taiwan's Nantou County.
Tang Wen-mei, whose family has lived in Cambodia since her grandparents' generation, brewed championship tea in the traditional manner, winning compliments for her skill and elegance.

Tang did not learn how to brew Chinese tea until she moved to Minchien township when she got married in 1997. Now, however, she is one of more than 90 members of a local association of tea experts, and the only new immigrant known for her skill in the Chinese tea ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MONGOLIA ECONOMIC CONFERENCE OPENS IN ULAANBAATAR

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Mongolia conference aimed at promoting bilateral economic ties opened in the Mongolian capital of Ulaanbaatar Monday, according to a press release issued by the conference's Taiwan co-sponsor, the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA).

The meeting, the fifth of its kind, is presided over by C.J. Hsu, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and Sambuul Demberel, chairman of the meeting's Mongolian sponsor, the Mongolian National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MNCCI) . It will last until June 8.

During the conference, Mongolian officials will introduce their country's business climate, while Taiwan financial leaders will give reports on incentives provided by Taiwan banking institutions to help Taiwan businessmen venture into the Mongolian market.
A 50-strong Taiwan delegation led by Hsu departed for Ulaanbaatar June 3, and will also attend the 2006 Mongolia International Spring Trade Fair which is slated for June 8-12 in Ulaanbaatar.

Begun in 2002, the conference has been held alternatively in Taipei and Ulaanbaatar, according to the CIECA, which is a private group founded in 2000 to help Taiwan businessmen to develop overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraqis Accuse Marines in April Killing Of Civilian; Disabled Man's Family Disputes Troops' Story.
BAGHDAD, June 4 -- All parties to the case of Hashim Ibrahim Awad al-Zobaie agree that he was shot dead by Marines of the 3rd Battalion, 5th Regiment on April 26 in the small central Iraqi village of Hamdaniyah. But there are differing accounts of his death, and they are at the heart of another investigation into the conduct of American forces in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER TO SERVE AS ENVOY TO SPAIN

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco Hwang said Monday that he hopes to strengthen relations with Spain when he assumes his new post as the nation's top representative in that country in August.

Hwang, who has been vice foreign affairs minister for the past three-and-a-half years, said Europe is very important to Taiwan and that there is room for development of relations between Taiwan and Spain.
Hwang, 65, has served in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for 38 years and has been posted to Costa Rica, Argentina, Chile and Guatemala.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said that Hwang was appointed May 29, replacing Lan Chih-min, the incumbent representative.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP HEADS HAVE NO INTEREST IN VP-PROPOSED SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) responded coolly Monday to a summit proposal made by Vice President Annette Lu earlier the same day aimed at redressing the current political situation.

Claiming that he had not received Lu's invitation relayed by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou expressed reservations about the proposed summit and predicted that the atmosphere would not be good should the summit be held now.

Ma made the remarks while fielding a question from a KMT city councilwoman during an interpellation session at the Taipei City Council at a time when the "pan-blue alliance" is poised to recall President Shui-bian or topple Premier Su Tseng-chang's Cabinet because of its strong dissatisfaction over a string of corruption scandals allegedly involving members of Chen's family and his close aides.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said that Ma would participate in the summit and work out ways with Lu to stabilize the political situation should Chen resign and if Lu would agree to publicly call on Chen to step down.
Amid rising public sentiment against corruption, Lu should make her stance clear to the people, whether or not she supports justice and fairness, by standing with the people, Cheng said.

PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang called a news conference later that day to refute a news report that Soong had given the nod to Annette Lu's invitation relayed by Wang. Lu Hsueh-chang said that Soong has not even the slightest interest in taking part in the summit proposed by the vice president.
According to the "pan-blue alliance," Chen's resignation would be the best way to stabilize the current political turmoil and save social costs.

Vice President Lu called Monday for a summit to tackle the current political situation, urging all political leaders to pool their wisdom to deal with the problems ahead amid the opposition's efforts to recall Chen or topple Su's Cabinet.

According to Lu, she and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will invite Chen, five political party leaders and the presidents of the four other yuans to take part in the summit in an attempt to find a means to stabilize the situation in the face of mounting political chaos.

According to Wang, Lu first mentioned the summit idea to him May 20 and he proposed that she first contact Chen to seek the president's agreement. Chen has showed willingness to attend the summit, Wang noted.
Wang said he also asked for opinions from Ma and Soong on the issue, claiming that Soong said he would consider attending and that Ma made no response.
Now that Lu has made the proposal for a second time, Wang said that he is willing to contact Soong and Ma again to explore their views on the issue.

Wang also expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan can hold an extra session this summer to deal with several key bills that remain outstanding after it ended the latest session May 30 in a dramatically chaotic situation amid confrontation between "pan-blue" lawmakers and their "pan-green" peers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union over a package of law amendment proposals on opening direct transport links between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CPI RISES 1.58% YEAR-ON-YEAR IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) increased 1.58 percent in May over the same month of last year, with the inflation rate for the first five months of 2006 standing at 1.37 percent, according to tallies released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS officials attributed the rise to price hikes for fruit, cigarettes, betel nuts, oil and medical expenses, as well as increased gift spending for Dragon Boat Festival.
In the five months to May, the prices of commercial goods climbed 1.91 percent, while services increased 0.76 percent, they said.

Meanwhile, owing to price increases for minerals, oil and basic metal products, the wholesale price index (WPI) rose 6.24 percent in May over the year-earlier level, marking the greatest single-month increase since December 2004, the officials said.

The WPI jumped 3 percent for the first five months of this year, with prices of locally produced products rising 5.42 percent, those of imports increasing 10.6 percent and those of exports up 2.44 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ESCAPES LUNCHTIME FIRE AT HOTEL

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang and two other heavyweights of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) escaped unharmed from a fire Monday at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel, where they were having a working lunch, trying to find a solution to the current political gridlock in Taiwan.

Su was playing host at the lunch to DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and DPP legislative caucus convener Ker Chien-ming when a fire alarm sounded at about 1 p.m., with black smoke billowing from the first floor of the hotel building.
The hotel management immediately made arrangements to evacuate all its customers.
The Taipei City Fire Department dispatched 20 fire engines, while reporters staking out the premier's working lunch rushed out of the hotel lobby to film the fire.
Firemen extinguished the flames in about 20 minutes. They were still trying to establish the cause of the fire.

When confronted by reporters on the streets, the premier said he was "not shocked" by the fire, adding that he and his guests had almost finished their lunch discussion by the time they were told to evacuate.
Su praised the hotel's efficient handling of the situation by swiftly making the emergency announcements in Chinese, English and Japanese to alert customers in its rooms and restaurants.
Su also said that Yu, Ker and himself had formed an "iron triangle" after having a good discussion, and that they had reached consensus on many issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DEMAND ACTION OVER HIGH-SPEED RAIL CAVE-IN PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Opposition legislators alleged Monday that a section of the Taiwan high-speed railway in northern Taiwan has serious cave-in problems and said the government should address the situation.

Legislator Lee Chi-chu of the Kuomintang, on the heels of an allegation she made a week earlier that a cave-in problem exists in the 30-odd km section between Hsinchu and Miaoli, held a news conference with Lee Hung-chun of the People First Party to claim that the Bureau of the High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp., (THSRC), the builder and operator of the railway, were lying when they said the railway "has no problems at all."
Neither legislator offered any evidence to back their allegations and it remained unclear as to where they got the information upon which they based their claims.

They asked for a full cave-in and drilling report to be presented to the legislators, saying that the MOTC should not use taxpayers money to endorse a private enterprise that has borrowed heavily from the government.

Lee said the THSRC has already completed more than 30 reinforcement jobs on the Hsinchu-Miaoli section and that it still detected three spots that were extremely soft in March. But the Bureau of High Speed Rail said they do not pose a problem.
Lee claimed that the bureau has lied to the public, warning that the railway could collapse in the event of an earthquake.
The construction work of the high speed rail must not rely on "luck, " Lee said, adding that the MOTC has to do its utmost to monitor the quality of construction.

He noted that the government's investment in THSRC has exceeded 36 percent of the total investment and that it can only manage seven seats on the board of directors, one less than the THSRC, which he said has invited most criticism.
Lee Chi-chu said that the THSRC has commissioned Sinotech Engineering Consultant, Ltd. to do the examination, but claimed that improvements have yet to be made.
The 345-km high speed rail connecting Taipei and Kaohsiung is expected to be inaugurated in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DENIES CONCESSION ON DIRECT LINKS DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) denied a media reports Monday that it will budge from its previous insistence on making prior government approval necessary for direct shipping and flight services across the Taiwan Strait.

According to the reports, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu met with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers over the weekend to mend their difference over the direct cross-strait transport link issues.

During the meeting, lawmakers from the two "pan-blue alliance" parties were quoted as having said they do not oppose the installation of a government licensing system after direct cross-strait transport links are in place, but they insisted that such a regulation should not be spelled out in the existing Statute Governing Relations Between the People in the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

In response, Wu reportedly said the MAC is not opposed to such a proposal. Nevertheless, he added that lawmakers of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) remain divided over the issue.
However, the MAC dismissed the reports, denying that Wu has made any concession or promise to opposition lawmakers on the issue.

Stressing that the licensing system is an important basis for effective government management of cross-strait shipping and air links, the MAC said the media reports of Wu agreeing to the "no inclusion of the licensing system in the statute" proposal were not true.

The ruling and opposition camps have been caught in a dogfight over the PFP-proposed package of amendments to the cross-strait statute paving the way for an opening of direct shipping and air links. The "pan-green camp" blocked the package from being put to a vote in the "pan-blue alliance"-controlled legislature three times before this year's first legislative session ended in chaos May 30.
The MAC said it is willing to further negotiate with parties across the political spectrum to seek a final solution to the direct links issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006 OPENS TUESDAY

TEXT.P: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006, the largest computer trade show in Asia -- and second in the world -- is set to take place June 6 to 10, with more than 1300 domestic and international participants showing off their latest products.

The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , the COMPUTEX TAIPEI organizer, will also arrange a live broadcast of the FIFA World Cup 2006 in its Exhibition Halls to better serve visitors who don't want to miss the event.

TAITRA estimates over 130,000 visitors and buyers will attend the five-day exhibition show, whose 2900 booths will occupy Exhibition Hall 1, Hall 2 and Hall 3, as well as the international conference center.
Major Taiwanese companies such as Acer, ASUSTek, Honhai, BenQ, TATUNG, VIA Technologies, MiTAC and CMC are among those on the show list to present their products.

Almost 200 major international players from 22 countries -- including NVIDIA, ATI, Intel, Fujitsu, AMD, Microsoft, Toshiba, Infineon, and SANYO DENKI -- will be showcasing their products. In addition, some Asian IT companies will be grouping themselves together in a special "Asian Image Pavilion."

Audio Visual System Integration, Intervideo Home Theatre and Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB) are among the main attractions of COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006, TAITRA said, noting they will be hot items for future buyers.

Besides the live broadcast of World Cup events, this year TAITRA is providing a bus shuttle service between the airport, exhibition halls and main hotels in order to make getting around town easier for international buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30-HOUR FAST ATTRACTS 500 PEOPLE IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Around 500 university students and teachers took part in a 30-hour fast in the southern city of Kaohsiung to raise funds for less privileged, homeless and starving children around the world, a spokesman for the National Kaohsiung Marine University said Monday.
Participants in the fast, organized by the charity group World Vision Taiwan, are only allowed to have liquid food such as milk and other drinks, from 1 p.m. Monday until 7 p.m. Tuesday.
Some of the funds will be used to help children injured during the recent earthquake in Indonesia's Yogyakarta.

According to a university official, the fast will help students enrich their lives and understand the meaning of life by letting them know that there are less privileged people in other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Air Masks at Issue in Claims of 9/11 Illnesses
With mounting evidence that exposure to the toxic smoke and ash at ground zero during the nine-month cleanup has made many people sick, attention is now focusing on the role of air- filtering masks, or respirators, that cost less than US$50 and could have shielded workers from some of the toxins. More than 150,000 such masks were distributed and only 40,000 people worked on the pile, but most workers either did not have the masks or did not use them. These respirators are now at the center of a federal lawsuit filed on behalf of more than 8,000 firefighters, police officers and private workers who say they were exposed to toxic substances at or near ground zero that have made them sick or may eventually do so. Lawyers representing the workers say that there was no central distribution point for the respirators, no single organization responsible for giving them out, and no one with the power to make sure the respirators that were distributed got used, and used properly.
Wall Street Journal: Without Borders, Global Exchanges Pose a Quandary For Securities Cops
As financial markets grow more electronic and international, a big question looms: Who should regulate them? More bluntly: Who's in charge if there's a market meltdown? That issue is now in the spotlight as the operator of the New York Stock Exchange sets plans to merge with Euronext NV, creating the first trans-Atlantic linkup of stock and derivatives markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONSENSUS ON ISSUES TO BE DISCUSSED IN EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that both the ruling and opposition parties have agreed to convene an extra legislative session but had not reached consensus on topics to be discussed in the proposed session.

The Legislative Yuan has been criticized for lack of efficiency for failing to pass major bills related to public welfare in the just-concluded legislative session, which ended in chaos a week earlier.

Ker Chien-ming, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus, presented a petition endorsed by 88 legislators to Wang asking for an extra legislative session to discuss eight bills including budgets for flood-prevention projects, several budget plans for expanding infrastructure construction, budget plans for state-owned enterprises, an additional NT$6.2 billion in the arms budget and unfreezing some of the central government's budget.

Although the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party also agreed to the convening of an extra legislative session, it has different opinions about the topics that should be discussed.

Because of the lack of consensus on the topics to be discussed, Wang said he will call an informal legislative session to set the agenda for the planned extra session. As to the timing for the informal session, Wang said, it will be decided at a caucus whips meeting to be held later.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST 'RIVERS DAY' FOCUSES ON RIVER CLEAN-UP

TEXT.P: The Water Resources Administration (WRA) announced Monday the designation of June 6 as Taiwan's "Rivers Day," while urging the public to help save the country's rivers from the threat of environmental degradation.

WRA Director-General Chen Kun-hsien and representatives of various eco-friendly groups signed a pledge vowing to take concrete action to protect the nation's rivers from pollution and to improve river water quality.
The WRA will also sponsor two large carnivals June 17 and June 18 in Taipei County, and is inviting the public to take part in a series of awareness-raising activities on river protection.

The WRA set June 6 as Taiwan's "Rivers Day" to mark the birthday of "Yu the Great" -- one of China's emperors and founder of the Hsia Dynasty, and a figure greatly admired for his remarkable ability to clean up rivers.
The last Sunday in September was designated as "World Rivers Day" by the United Nations last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS BEST PARTNER FOR DEVELOPING ICT INDUSTRIES: ITRI

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the best partner for Southeast Asian countries in the development of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) industries because Taiwan's government has listed that area as a top priority, Industial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) Chairman Lin Hsin-i said Monday.

Lin made the remarks at the opening ceremony for the two-day 2006 Taiwan-Southeast Asia ICT Forum. Lin said that Taiwan has close economic and trade ties with Southeast Asian countries, and that the forum is an excellent platform to allow participating countries to boost mutual exchanges.
Lin said that Taiwan has already developed a global marketing network and that each of those companies has built a strong reputation based on their product's brand name recognition.
Lin added that "win-win" situations can be seen in future regional cooperation, if Southeast Asian countries pool together their resources to develop ICT industries with Taiwan.
BenQ Chairman K.Y. Lee, who delivered a speech at the forum's opening ceremony, shared his company's experience in building a brand name known throughout the world.

Lee pointed out that the large number of consumers in Asia will be capable of sustaining an Asian brand name, adding that he is pleased to see other Southeast Asian countries developing their own brand names.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE PSYCHOLOGISTS TO HELP HEAL QUAKE SURVIVORS' MENTAL WOUNDS
DOC.DATELINE: Yogyakarta, Indonesia, June 5 (CNA) (By Charles Kang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA) reached an agreement with the Indonesian government Monday to provide the earthquake-devastated nation with a team of mental rehabilitation specialists.

At the invitation of the Indonesian government, a Taiwan IHA team attended the Indonesian government's internal meeting Sunday on post-quake mental rehabilitation. Indonesian authorities hope to draw upon Taiwan's experience of healing psychological trauma after the devastation of its own Sep. 21, 1999 earthquake.

Under the agreement, Taiwan will send a team of seasoned psychologists to the central Indonesian island of Java, which was hit by a magnitude-6.3 temblor May 27, taking the lives of more than 6,200 people and leaving hundreds of thousands homeless.
Taiwan will also help train Indonesian psychologists with skills and know-how to guide earthquake survivors through overcoming deep sorrow over losing family members.
The proposed program may begin operating in August, according to the IHA team.

Meanwhile, the Taipei-based Buddhist charity Dharma Drum Mountain Culture and Education Foundation (DDMCEF) decided Monday to work with a local cultural foundation in efforts to rebuild 10 elementary schools destroyed by the earthquake in Yogyakarta, ground zero of the devastating temblor, according to the DDMCEF's relief team in the area.
The foundation will map out a long-term reconstruction program to help elementary school students return to school as soon as possible in Bantul, the hardest-hit zone, the team said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'BLUE SEA SUMMIT' SET FOR THURSDAY: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday he has reached a consensus with Vice President Annette Lu on inviting political leaders to hold a summit meeting June 8 to discuss feasible measures to stabilize the volatile domestic political situation.

Wang said President Chen Shui-bian may attend the meeting, to be dubbed "blue sea summit" to signify its aim to seek innovative strategies to weather the current political upheaval over a string of corruption allegations implicating Chen's son-in-law and close aides.

Wang quoted Lu as having told him on phone earlier in the day that she will invite President Chen as well as heads of the four yuans -- Premier Su Tseng-chang, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng and Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen -- and top leaders of major political parties to the "blue sea summit" scheduled for Thursday.

Lu was also quoted as having told Wang that it seems to her that main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and James Soong, chairman of the second largest opposition People First Party, are not sure whether they would attend the summit.
Wang, a KMT heavyweight, said he will attend the meeting in his capacity as head of the legislature, adding that he will inform the KMT headquarters of his intention to attend the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO DONATE USED PRINTER CARTRIDGES TO CHARITY

TEXT.P: A local charity urged the public Monday to donate used laser printing cartridges to support a fundraising campaign promoting the welfare of the mentally challenged.
The drive was launched by the Syin-Lu Foundation in cooperation with CyberTek Corp., a company specializing in recycling printer cartridges.

Under the program, the foundation will receive a recycling incentive of up to NT$400 from the company for each cartridge collected, with the award varying according to the brand and model of the products.
According to officials at the Environmental Protection Administration, a total of 1.36 million printer cartridges were consumed in Taiwan in 2003, but only 210,000, or 15 percent, were recycled.
The ratio was much lower than the 29 percent of cartridges recycled in the United States, 30 percent in Europe and 21 percent in Asia or Australia, they said.

Officials of the Syin-Lu Foundation said companies and individuals intending to donate used cartridges can call the foundation at (02) 2592-9778 or (07) 3219911, or send the recyclables directly to places designated by the foundation.
Information related to the campaign is available on CyberTek Corp.'s Website at www.cybertek.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREX RESERVES HIT NEW HIGH IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to a record high of US$260.93 billion as of the end of May, up US$1.9 billion over the previous month, Central Bank of China (CBC) officials said Monday.

Despite remittances made out of Taiwan by foreign investors in May, the country's foreign exchange reserves continued to increase because of the appreciation of foreign currencies owned by Taiwan and interest generated from the reserves, the officials said.
According to statistics from the Securities and Futures Bureau, the net selling of Taiwan stocks by foreign investors amounted to NT$31.4 billion (US$981.25 million) in May.
While the euro rose 2.5 percent against the U.S. dollar in May, the Japanese yen gained 2.4 percent, and the pound jumped 6 percent, CBC officials pointed out.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves are third highest in the world after China and Japan, according to the CBC.
China's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$875.1 billion as of the end of March, and Japan's totalled US$839.2 billion as of the end of April, officials said.

Meanwhile, South Korea's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$224.3 billion as of the end of May, while those of Singapore and Japan registered US$126.6 billion and US$124.9 billion, respectively, as of the end of April, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD RESPONDS TO IDEA OF LEGISLATIVE MAJORITY FORMING THE CABINET

TEXT.P: Amid speculation that President Chen Shui-bian is considering forming a new Cabinet based on legislative majority, opposition Koumintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday the idea "met the spirit of the Constitution, " but in such a case the powers of the president and premier must be clearly defined.
After meeting with members of the Democratic Movement Alliance, Ma, who doubles as Taipei Mayor, made the remarks in response to media queries.
He said the nomination of premier in that case should not be decided by the president, but by the majority party or an alliance of majority parties in the Legislative Yuan.

Ma also stressed that calls for the president to step down or moves to topple the existing Cabinet are irrelevant, and that the point is to keep up the pressure and continue monitoring ongoing investigations into scandals involving government officials and the president's son-in-law.

Ma said the KMT is "watching over" the latest developments in the scandals, and is considering proposals in the event of a presidential recall motion or the Cabinet toppling, but cautioned that these moves are to be made by legislators at a time of their choice.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 TAIWAN AMATEUR GOLF CHAMPIONSHIP TO TEE OFF JUNE 6

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taiwan Amateur Golf Championship will tee off Tuesday morning at the Sunrise Golf and Country Club in Yangmei, northern Taiwan, with 121 golfers from eight countries competing.

The field of golfers comprises 91 men and 30 women. Ninety Taiwanese contestants -- including 24 who have been training for the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, Qatar, Nov. 27-Dec. 15 -- will vie for the titles with 31 foreign counterparts from the United States, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines and Hong Kong.

The annual championship -- now in its 16th year -- adopted a new system of competition three years ago, with the first two rounds devoted to a 36-hole stroke play to select the top three winners in both men's and women's groups.
Men players whose 18-hole total exceeds 95 in the first round and women players with first round scores of over 105 strokes will be disqualified from the second round.
The top 25 players in the men's group and top 16 in the women's group will then be pitted against one another, respectively, in a match play.
The five-day competition will end June 10.

According to organizers, all foreign contestants arrived in Taiwan by Sunday night. After an 18-hole practice round on the course Monday during the day, they were honored at a dinner hosted by Lo Fun-ming, president of the Golf Association of the Republic Of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY IS IN GOOD SHAPE: CEPD CHIEF

TEXT.P: Monday's significant dip in the stock market is unusual and likely attributable to recent political upheaval rather than anything related to Taiwan's economic fundamentals, the nation's top economic planner said Monday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks after the weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange fell 244.37 points -- or 3.5 percent -- to close at 6,715.27 Monday, the lowest closing level since April 4.

"The plunge of the stock index to a two-month low is unrelated to our economic fundamentals and mostly has to do with domestic political uncertainty," Hu said, adding that the local economy remains rosy and robust.

As of last Friday, Hu said Taiwan share prices had spiked 6.28 percent since the beginning of this year, compared to Hong Kong's 6.97 percent rise, Singapore's 3.07 percent increase and Nasdaq's 0.64 percent. During the same period, Japan's stock index posted 2 percent negative growth and the South Korean stock index also slid 5.1 percent.

Moreover, Hu said both Taiwan's exports and inbound investment posted higher-than-expected gains in the first quarter of this year, prompting the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics to adjust the economic growth target upward to 4.31 percent from the original 4.25 percent.
Hu lamented that the recent domestic political situation, however, has affected investor confidence, resulting in Monday's unusual stock market tumbling.
Hu was referring to threats from opposition parties to recall President Chen Shui-bian or topple the Cabinet over recent corruption allegations implicating Chen's son-in-law and close aides.
Hu said all those allegations have been under judicial investigation.
"We need not jump to arbitrary conclusions before judicial authorities complete investigations and mete out judgments," he added.

He also warned that if the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan fails to pass a large amount of critical budget bills in an extra session during this summer, the nation's economic growth for this year may fall below the original forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BIGWIGS REACH 4-POINT CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will exhaust its means to counter opposition moves to recall President Chen Shui-bian or to topple the Cabinet, a party bigwig said Monday.
Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, made the remarks after a lunch meeting with Premier Su Tseng-chang and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun.

During the meeting, Ker said, Yu proposed that the DPP do everything in its power to counter the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" attempts to remove Chen and topple Su's Cabinet as well as to oppose the opposition alliance's proposal for the majority party in the legislature to form a new Cabinet.

"We reach a consensus on Yu's suggestion, " Ker said, adding that they also agreed that if the oppostion "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which controls a slim majority in the legislature, really comes up with a no-confidence vote motion, the DPP legislative caucus will ask President Chen to dissolve the legislature to pave the way for a new election.

The trio also agreed that they will meet regularly to discuss major policy affairs now that the president has ceded policy-making and cabinet-appointment authority to Premier Su in the wake of corruption allegations involving his son-in-law and close aides, Ker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 6 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 6:
10:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will meet with members of a world real estate management industry association.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE MAY HOLD EXTRA SESSION NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: If all goes well, the legislature may convene an extraordinary session next week, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.

Wang made the remarks after presiding over a consultative meeting of legislative caucus whips across the party spectrum on the feasibility of holding an extra session during the legislature's summer recess to screen certain critical bills.
According to Wang, both ruling and opposition parties have a shared interest in convening an extra session, but remain divided over the topics to be put on the agenda.

Wang said he will call another round of cross-party consultative meeting Thursday to further gauge each side's stance and opinions. If a consensus can be reached, he said, the legislature will hold a "conversation" session next Monday to flesh out an agenda for the proposed extra session.
"If all goes smoothly, the extra session will start next Tuesday, " Wang said. "As to how long the session will continue, it remains uncertain."

Given the wide gap between the ruling and opposition camps' preferred lists of topics to be addressed at the extra session, Wang said a number of variables could affect the results of Thursday's meeting on whether an extra session will truly be convened.

On one hand, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , which controls a slim majority in the legislature most want the extra session to pass a PFP-initiated package of amendments to a statute on relations across the Taiwan Strait paving the way for opening direct cross-strait transport links and deal with a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian over corruption allegations against his son-in-law and aides.

On the other, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) strongly opposes those two topics and instead gives priority to four crucial budget bills that are related to people's livelihoods and sustainable economic development. The DPP's "pan-green" ally, the Taiwan solidarity Union, has vowed to exhaust its means to choke the direct cross-strait links bill on the ground that the passage of the bill would undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and put nation security at stake.
In view of the deep partisan rancor at play, Wang said he is not sure whether an extra session can really take place or whether any concrete results can be achieved even if the session is held.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 6, or the 11th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
2001: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County is quarantined after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis the previous day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOWNGRADED IN U.S. 'TRAFFICKING IN PERSONS REPORT'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 5 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been placed on a "Tier 2 Watch List" for not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking, according to the annual Trafficking in Persons Report released Monday by the U.S. State Department.
The latest listing marks a downgrading for Taiwan, which was listed as a "Tier 2" country in past years.

"Taiwan is placed on the Tier 2 Watch List for its failure to show evidence of increasing efforts over the past year to address trafficking, despite ample resources to do so, particularly to address the serious level of forced labor and sexual servitude among legally migrating Southeast Asian contract workers and brides, " the report says.

The report urges Taiwan authorities to demonstrate political will in tackling the human trafficking problem and develop a clear policy and action plan that adequately covers sex trafficking and involuntary servitude among foreign workers and brides.
The report describes Taiwan as a destination for men, women and children trafficked for forced labor and sexual exploitation.

While women from China and Southeast Asian countries are trafficked to Taiwan through fraudulent marriages, deceptive employment offers, and illegal smuggling, some foreign workers, primarily from Vietnam, Thailand, and the Philippines, are recruited legally for low-skilled jobs in Taiwan's construction, fishing or manufacturing industries or as domestic servants, and are subjected to forced labor or involuntary servitude by labor agencies or employers upon arrival in Taiwan, the report says.

It notes that Taiwan has a number of related laws that may be used to prosecute traffickers, including laws against slavery and exploiting children for prostitution, but it does not have comprehensive anti-trafficking legislation.

The Taiwan authorities provided inadequate protection for many victims of trafficking on the island over the last year, though they made efforts to improve levels of victim support in some areas, the report says.
Also Monday, Taiwan's representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee expressed regret over the result.

Lee said the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and the U.S. State Department had expressed their concern on the situation of human trafficking in Taiwan three months ago and that Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) had also provided the United States with a brochure for its reference.
Lee said the AIT's Taipei office has continued to communicate with the CLA and the Ministry of Justice for solutions to improve the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTORS TO ATTEND INVENTION EXPOSITION IN PITTSBURGH
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 5 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A group of 25 inventors from Taiwan has traveled from New York to Pittsburgh to attend the 2006 Invention and New Product Exposition (INPEX) slated for June 7-10.

With 27 original products, the group, headed by Taiwan Inventors Association Chairman Chen Chung-tai, is confident of winning several INPEX Awards, one of the world's major awards recognizing the achievement of inventors from around the globe, according to Chen.
At the INPEX 2005, Taiwan inventors won a total of 10 awards, including two gold medals, seven bronzes, and one special award.
INPEX, the largest invention trade show in the United States, showcases inventions and new products available to business and industry. The 2006 show is the 22nd of its kind.

A fruit and vegetable processor, one of the 27 Taiwan-invented products registered for the upcoming competition, won a gold medal at the Geneva International Exhibition of Invention in April, said Chen, who had also led Taiwan inventors to attend the European event.
Taiwan won 38 medals there, adding a glorious page to the island's history book of invention.

According to statistics compiled by Taiwan's Investment and Trade Office to the United States, nearly 5,000 items invented in Taiwan have received U.S. patents since 2000, ranking the country fourth in the world behind only the United States, Japan and Germany.
Taiwan only received its first U.S. patent in 1973.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt's visit to Taiwan later this week is a routine matter, and "there is no need for over interpretation, " a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Michel Lu was responding to reports that the AIT chief will pay his first visit to Taiwan since assuming his post in February and that during his visit, he will also learn about political developments in Taiwan and exchange views with leaders in every sector. Burghardt has also reportedly requested a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian.
The AIT serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Burghardt's visit will come in the wake of President Chen's announcement last Wednesday to hand over policy-making and personnel-appointment authorities to Premier Su Tseng-chang in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations against his close aides and son-in-law.
Lu said that since Burghardt assumed his post, he has planned the visit, adding that his itinerary will be arranged by the AIT.
"This is part of an international communication, and there is nothing special about it," Lu stressed.

Asked whether Burghardt will also meet with opposition leaders, Lu said that as a democratic society, Taiwan has many different political voices, which is normal, and there is a possibility that he will meet with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: RP, China now economic partners
The Philippines and the People's Republic of China yesterday signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) establishing a bilateral economic partnership that calls for a loan financing package of billion to fund various projects in the Philippines.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 2 leftists killed in wake
BORONGAN, Eastern Samar -- A week after men on a motorcycle gunned down former New People's Army leader Sotero Llamas in Albay province, a lone assassin wearing a bonnet over his head shot dead a Bayan Muna member and a leader of a farmers'group during a wake on Sunday night here.
The Philippine Star: 2007 polls for parliament?
Parliamentary elections, along with scheduled local polls, could be held next year if the campaign to amend the Constitution succeeds, Malacanang said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Buses and jeeps to issue receipts
THE Bureau of Internal Revenue will hold talks with the Land Transportation and Franchising Board to discuss the issuance of receipts by public utility buses and jeepneys, which will be the bureau's next tax-collection target after taxis, BIR Commissioner Jose Mario Bunag announced on Monday.

The Japan Times Murakami arrested over insider trading
