DOC.HEADLINE: ETHYLENE OVERSUPPLY MAY CAUSE DOWNTURN IN PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The global petrochemical industry is expected to experience a downturn this year as a result of an oversupply of ethylene, an important raw material for manufacturing plastics, a top executive of Formosa Plastic Corp. said Tuesday.

Lee Chih-tsuen, who took over as the new chairman of Formosa Plastic Monday, said global ethylene production capacity is estimated to increase 6 million tons this year, while the global demand will grow only 4.3 million tons, resulting in an oversupply of 1.7 million tons.

Lee said the predicted global demand for ethylene is based on an estimate by Global Insight Inc. -- an organization that provides economic information, analysis and solutions -- that the world economy will grow 3.8 percent this year, as the demand for ethylene is closely related to the world economy.
Lee noted that China and the Middle East are leading all other areas in the expansion of ethylene production capacity, accounting for 85 percent of the world's newly added productivity.

He pointed out that Iran alone plans to build 13 ethylene plants to cope with its petroleum surplus and that the completion of these projects in 2009 will definitely cause difficulties for the global petrochemical industry.

Ethylene, also known as ethene, is made by cracking hydrocarbons from petroleum. It is used as an intermediate in the manufacture of other chemicals, such as ethanal and ethanol, and can be polymerized to make polyethylene -- the world's most widely-used plastic.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC GARBAGE CANS HARD TO FIND IN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: Although most people in Taiwan have developed the habit of sorting their garbage, the insufficient number of public garbage cans has caused much inconvenience to the public, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by the Good Neighbor Foundation on 1,094 people around Taiwan.
The survey shows that 65 percent of the respondents are satisfied with the overall tidiness of the environment in their neighborhood, compared with 25 percent who are not.

As high as 94 percent of the respondents are in favor of the government's garbage separation policy. While 72 percent said the policy has not caused any trouble in their daily life, 88 percent said they sort their garbage even when they use public trash cans.
However, 50 percent of the respondents think that disposing of garbage in public places is a very inconvenient matter, and 62 percent said there are not enough public garbage cans in Taiwan.
Some respondents said that they sometimes leave their garbage in the baskets of parked scooters or discard it in the streets if there are no public trash cans in the vicinity.

As to the features public garbage cans should have, 95 percent of the respondents think the cans should come with clear signs indicating what kind of trash they are designated for. Other features mentioned were large openings for convenient disposal of garbage, large volume, and clean appearance, as well as convenient trash separation features.
Also Tuesday, the Good Neighbor Foundation announced the launch of a public garbage can design competition, with the top winner to be awarded a cash prize of NT$100,000.
Information related to the competition is available online at www.cleanuptheworld.org.tw, and people interested in the competition can also call the foundation at (02)8788-3278 ext. 106.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP TO ORGANIZE RALLIES CALLING FOR CHEN TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has decided to organize a rally in the southern city of Kaohsiung June 10 to push President Chen Shui-bian to step down amid growing public discontent with the first family and Chen's administration, while the KMT's ally -- the People First Party (PFP) -- is preparing to hold one in Taipei the same day as part of efforts to recall Chen.

Huang Yu-chen, deputy chief of the KMT cultural and communication committee, made the announcement Tuesday after a visit by PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-shen and PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping to the KMT headquarters.
Chin and Hsieh were greeted by KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuen-pao, KMT Organization and Development Committee Director Liao Feng-teh and Huang.

According to Chin, their visit was aimed at inviting the KMT to join with the PFP in the organization of its planned "People Rebuking Bian, A-bian Stepping Down" rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office. A-bian is Chen's nickname.

Chin said efforts have to be made by the opposition parties to push the corruption scandal-ridden administration to step down, noting that alleged bribery and profiteering reports involving the first family and high-ranking officials in Chen's administration have caused public outrage.
Talking about the strategy for pushing to have Chen step down, Chin said the best way is to promote a motion at the Legislative Yuan to recall Chen and then push for a public referendum on the issue.

Huang said because KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to visit Tainan, southern Taiwan on June 10, the KMT has decided to hold a similar activity to the one planned by the PFP for Taipei the same day. He added that the KMT encourages its members residing in the northern part of the island to attend the PFP-planned rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA LAUNCHES ACTIVITY TO SOLICIT ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION IDEAS

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has launched an activity to seek new ideas for conserving resources, recycling waste and reducing environmental pollution.
The EPA will give cash awards to those who come up with the best new creative ideas for environmental protection, with the top winner entitled to NT$10,000.
Any individuals or organizations interested in making a contribution may present their ideas in words and pictures and submit them to the EPA's Web site at http://.epa.e-info.org.tw by July 20.
EPA officials suggested that creative ideas could be developed by seeking inspiration from four major areas of people's daily life, namely food, clothing, dwelling and transportation.
All entries will undergo a screening process to determine the winners. The novel ideas will be published in the EPA's manuals to help educate the general public in promoting environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DISMISSES NSC VICE CHAIR SUSPECTED OF ROLE IN SCANDAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian issued a presidential decree Tuesday dismissing Vice Chairman Hsieh Ching-chih of the National Science Council who was detained last month on suspicions of using his influence in exchange for financial favors in the awarding of an engineering contract for a vibration-reduction project at the Southern Taiwan Science Park.
In addition to confirming Hsieh's resignation, the decree removed Hsieh from the NSC's vice chairmanship.
Hsieh tendered his resignation to Premier Su Tseng-chang on May 24, the day he was detained, and the resignation was accepted immediately.
At that time, Hsieh said he was quitting the job so he could devote his full energy to defending his name.
The presidential decree said Hsieh's resignation and dismissal took effect May 24.

The prosecution suspects that Hsieh used his influence in the awarding of a NT$8.05 billion (US$254 million) engineering project in exchange for financial favors. He was the first Democratic Progressive Party political appointee to have been detained.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 15 points to close at 6,730.27.
The bourse opened at 6,684.58 and fluctuated between 6,738.78 and 6.621.17 during trading. A total of 3.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.31 billion (US$2.94 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 466 to 290, with 100 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACHIEVING RESULTS IN LOBBYING FOR SUPPORT FOR FTA WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan has achieved results in its lobbying efforts to win support for the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Leo Lee, director general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, made the remarks while responding to questions about progress in the government's efforts to secure an FTA with the United States
Lee said the government has targeted the U.S. Congress, state assemblies and the industrial sector among others in its lobbying efforts.

He noted that a joint resolution in support of an FTA between Taiwan and the United States proposed by U.S. Reps. Jim Ramstad (R-Minn.) and William Jefferson (D-La.) has won the endorsement of 45 members of Congress to date. In the U.S. Senate, Sens. Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.) and Max Baucus (R-Mont.) have also proposed a joint resolution, which has won the endorsement of six other senators so far.
On lobbying efforts directed at state governments, Lee said that Taiwan has won the support of 15 states and 27 state senates and assemblies for the signing of a U.S.-Taiwan FTA.

On lobbying in the industrial sector, Lee said Taiwan's representative office in the United States has held five briefings on the proposed FTA so far this year. It is also actively soliciting noted think tanks to sponsor related seminars and stepping up lobbying efforts directed at U.S. enterprises.
Two noted organizations -- the International Intellectual Property Alliance and the American Council of Life Insurers -- have already expressed their support for a U.S.-Taiwan free trade accord.

In addition, the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei also recently issued a white paper report in which it said that if Taiwan's government shows strong will to promote the FTA, the chamber will also pitch in to help make the FTA a reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA TO MAKE 119TH ANNIVERSARY WITH SALE OF COMMEMORATIVE SOUVENIRS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) will sell 42 kinds of commemorative souvenirs at train stations in Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien from June 9-11 to mark its 119th anniversary which falls on June 9.
The souvenirs will include model trains, post cards and lunch boxes, with prices for the various items ranging from NT$90 to NT$28,000.
According to past experience, No. 14 locomotives sculptured in fine wood have been one of the most popular items among train fans.
The TRA will also present i-cash commemorative cards for use at 7-Eleven convenient stores island wide, which will accept reservations from June 6 to July 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 11 points to close at 6,689, with 52,334 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July dropped 25 points to finish at 6,625, with 1,319 contracts traded, while September futures remained unchanged at 6,520, with 107 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 10 points to close at 6,525, with 63 contracts traded, while March futures rose 20 points to finish at 6,526, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,678 for June, 6,650 for July, 6,520 for September, 6,515 for December and 6,506 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
June TE futures rose two points to close at 284.55, with 6,107 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 1.2 points to finish at 283, with 99 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved up 1.2 points to close at 277.45, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 9.6 points to finish at 962.8, with 3,620 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures gained 7.4 points to close at 956, with 56 contracts traded.
September TF futures gained 2.6 points to close at 943, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF VICE CHAIRMAN PROSECUTED ON CHARGES OF BREACH OF TRUST

TEXT.P: Vice Chairman Chang Chun-hung of the Straits Exchange Foundation was indicted Tuesday on charges of breach of trust, violating commercial accounting law and the stock exchange law while serving as chairman of an investment company.

Chang, once an influential figure in the Democratic Progressive Party, was suspected of embezzling money from Formosa Tele-communication Investment Co. Ltd., where he served as chairman and chief executive officer.
The prosecutors asked the court to sentence Chang and his girlfriend Lin Hui-chen to seven- and six-year jail terms, respectively.
A total of 14 people have been charged in this high-profile, white-collar criminal case.
Chang was DPP secretary-general from 1988 to 1991, and served as the party's acting chairman in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL RECALL PLAN CREATING SOCIAL CHAOS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang condemned Tuesday efforts by opposition parties to recall President Chen Shui-bian, arguing that the move would create chaos and affect national development.

Su made the remarks while fielding reporters' questions on reports that the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the "pan-blue alliance" want to make the presidential recall proposal a top priority in a proposed extra legislative session in summer.

Stressing that the public is fed up with political fighting that only hinders the country's development and competitiveness and causes social instability, Su said that several key bills have failed to pass the Legislative Yuan, whose latest session ended in turmoil May 30.

If an extra session is held in summer, Su called on lawmakers of all parties to first address bills affecting the public welfare, including a budget for a flood control project as typhoon season approaches. More than 30 bills are pending legislative approval, involving trillions of dollars and affecting over 10,000 job opportunities, he pointed out.
The premier also suspects the pan-blue alliance may have an axe to grind by planning to initiate a presidential recall motion, as it requires a high legal threshold.
Monday's 244-point plunge in the domestic stock market, he said, is in part due to ongoing political fighting at home, Su claimed.
Following a meeting of ranking KMT officials, including Ma, The KMT decided Monday night to launch a national campaign seeking to oust Chen.
The main opposition party also agreed to call for an extra legislative session to screen major bills regarding people's livelihoods and to put forth the presidential recall proposal, if possible.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokesman Tsai Huang-liang told a news conference that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's plan to promote a presidential recall plan is turning a deaf ear to the people's call for a better economy. He asked Ma to look to people's needs and KMT lawmakers to first screen major bills related to the public interest.
DPP lawmakers Hsu Kuo-yung and Lin Wen-lang claimed that Ma must be held accountable for the chaos that would likely ensue if the pan-blue alliance insists on calling a motion to recall Chen.

Ma is fully aware that it won't be easy to have the presidential recall motion clear the Legislative Yuan and that the public is unsupportive of such a move, they said, warning that doing so will only destabilize society and whip up a public confidence crisis.

Meanwhile, the pan-blue alliance is poised to take to the streets Saturday -- the second time in as many weeks -- to protest against Chen, whom it said must assume responsibility for a string of high-profile corruption scandals allegedly involving Chen's family members and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSURANCE PROGRAM AGAINST PIG DEATH TO BE EXPANDED

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will expand an insurance program against pig death this year in a bid to reduce the possibility of pig farmers selling pigs dying of illness for human consumption, officials said Tuesday.

The program, which was launched in Yunlin and Taichung Counties on a trial basis last year, will be expanded to seven others including Changhua, Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung Counties and Hsinchu, Taichung and Tainan Cities this year, with the goal of having 2 million swine covered by the provision, they said.

The premium for each pig is NT$21.6, with the government and pig farmers contributing 70 percent and 30 percent, respectively. The coverage is NT$1,200 per pig, while the compensation ceiling is 15 pigs for every 1,000 pigs insured, according to the COA.

A total of 619,803 pigs in Yunlin and Taichung Counties were covered by the policy last year, accounting for 77.5 percent of pigs raised in the two counties, and 8,940 deaths were compensated for, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDACIES OF HSIEH, CHEN WOULD BOOST BELEAGUERED DPP: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 6 (CAN) Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday that if former Premier Frank Hsieh joins another heavyweight of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run in the year-end mayoral elections, the party's prospects will be bright.

Su was referring to Hsieh throwing his hat into the ring for the Taipei mayoral election and former Chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), Chen Chu, who has already entered the Kaohsiung mayoral race as a DPP candidate.

Although the DPP's approval ratings have slipped to a new low following a string of corruption allegations surrounding close aides of President Chen Shui-bian and his son-in-law, Su said the campaigns of Chen and Hsieh, who has yet to announce his bid, would surely give the beleaguered party a boost.

Su recalled that both he and Hsieh were members of a defense team defending Yao Chia-wen, the current president of the Examination Yuan who was one of the eight people accused in a military court during the Formosa Incident, which took place in Kaohsiung on Dec. 10, 1979 when a pro-democracy demonstration to commemorate Human Rights Day turned violent and was suppressed by the then Kuomintang administration.
Su said he and President Chen Shui-bian -- also a member of the defense team at the time -- as well as Hsieh then went into politics.

Su said that although they have grown older they have kept their courage, responsibility and sense of mission, and that he is looking forward to seeing Hsieh take on the daunting task of running in the mayoral election at this critical juncture.

Su also said Hsieh's primary concern is not whether he can assure victory in the mayoral election, which promises to be an uphill battle, but to look after the party's best interest -- and the public's.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FSC OFFICIAL GETS 10-YEAR JAIL TERM IN 'STOCK VULTURES' CASE

TEXT.P: Taipei District Court sentenced Lee Chin-cheng, former director of the Examination Bureau of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , to 10 years behind bars Tuesday for his role in a high-profile corruption and insider-trading scandal known as the "stock vultures" case.

Lee was convicted of charges that he attempted to profit his stock-trading friends and that he had leaked information for that purpose. For the profiteering charges, he was sentenced to nine years in jail; for leaking charges, one year and four months. The court ruled that Lee must serve 10 years.

Other "stock vultures" were given sentences ranging from seven months to less than four years. For example, capital sponsor and trader Lin Ming-ta was sentenced to a two-year prison term plus a fine of NT$20 million. But Lin's jail term will be suspended if he is not convicted of any other charges within five years.

Chen Yung-cheng, chairman of a security trading company, was sentenced to seven months in jail with a two-year suspension, meaning he does not have to serve his time if he does not get convicted of any other charges in the coming two years.
Ku Chou-ming, a bank manager, was handed down a one-year-eight-month jail sentence with a three-year suspension.
Lin Yi-hung, a stock broker, was sentenced to one year and seven months in jail, plus a fine of NT$10 million.
Chang Hsi-kuan, an official at Taiwan Stock Exchange, was sentenced to one year and eight months in jail, with a four-year suspension.
Chen Chun-chi, a stock-trading club member, received a jail term of three years and 10 months, in addition to a fine of NT$15 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MANDARIN TEACHERS ARRIVE IN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 6 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Taijing Wu)

TEXT.P: A second batch of 10 language instructors from Taiwan arrived in Thailand Tuesday to teach Mandarin, ahead of the Thai government plan to make Chinese high school courses compulsory in 2008.
Eight of these teachers will serve as Chinese language instructors at a Thai normal university, while two others will be assigned to a Thai high school.

Wu Chien-kuo, deputy representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Thailand, said Thai universities already have an excellent impression based on the performance of the first batch of Chinese language teachers.
Wu said teaching Mandarin in Thailand is "doing the right thing in the right place" because the Thai government intends to make a Mandarin course compulsory in high schools by 2008.

One of the teachers, Peng Hsin-yun, said that learning Mandarin is currently very popular in Thailand. She hopes to accumulate more teaching experience in Thailand so she can be a better Mandarin instructor when she returns to Taiwan.
The group's 10 teachers were selected among 44 applicants.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006 ATTRACTS A FLOOD OF BUYERS

TEXT.P: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006, the largest computer trade show in Asia and second largest in the world, opened Tuesday for a five-day run with more than 1300 domestic and international companies showing off their latest products, attracting at least 30,000 foreign buyers.

Chao Yung-chuan, secretary-general of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , announced during the opening ceremony that the exhibition hall is being expanded to accommodate 2,000 more booths -- for a total of 5,000 stands -- starting in 2008, after TAITRA acquires 10-year administration rights for the Nankang exhibition hall.

COMPUTEX TAIPEI's co-organizers, TAITRA and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA) , estimated that over 130,000 visitors and buyers will attend the five-day show, whose 2,907 booths occupy Exhibition Hall 1, Hall 2 and Hall 3, as well as the international center.

Computex Taipei exhibition is not only presenting "the old 3C" concept of computers, consumers, communications," but also showcasing "new 3C" technologies that are "competitive, collective, and complete," Frank Huang, chairman of the TCA, said.

During the opening ceremony, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awarded prizes for "Best IT Export Products" to eleven domestic IT companies which produce and design notebooks, cellphones, CPUs, multi-media satellites and computer servers.
This year TAITRA has also arranged for a live broadcast of the FIFA World Cup 2006 throughout its Exhibition Halls to better serve visitors who don't want to miss the event.
Besides piping in World Cup events, TAITRA is providing a shuttle bus service between the airport, exhibition halls and main hotels to make it easier for international buyers to get around town.
In the exhibition halls, organizers set up six lounge areas to allow foreign buyers to discuss deals freely with vendors or take a rest during the show.
Major Taiwanese companies such as Acer, ASUSTek, Honhai, BenQ, TATUNG, VIA Technologies, MiTAC and CMC are among those presenting their products at the show.

Almost 200 major international players from 22 countries -- including NVIDIA, ATI, Intel, Fujitsu, AMD, Microsoft, Toshiba, Infineon, and SANYO DENKI -- will be showcasing their products. In addition, some Asian IT companies will be grouping themselves together in a special "Asian Image Pavilion."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.062.
A total of US$798 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.100 and fluctuated between NT$32.033 and NT$32.109.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS TO BENEFIT FROM MORE FLIGHTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tourists will enjoy cheaper and more convenient trips to Japan starting from July, as several local and foreign air carriers are increasing the number of flights to various Japanese cities, tourist industry sources said Tuesday.

Since Taiwan and Japan revised their aviation pact earlier this year, China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's major air carrier, will increase its stopovers to Osaka and Sapporo starting July 1, while EVA Airways will launch a Taipei-Nagoya route July 10 and increase the number of flights to Osaka.

Several local and foreign air carriers -- including CAL, EVA Airways, Cathay Pacific Airways, United Airlines and Northwest Airlines -- are offering regular flights to Japanese destinations such as Tokyo, Fukuoka, Hiroshima, Nagoya, Okinawa, Osaka, Sendai and Sapporo.

The sources opined that both Taiwan's and Japan's tourism markets will benefit from the Japanese government's plan to redouble the number of foreign tourists visiting the country, saying that plane tickets will be cheaper, especially after September.

However, since Japan is generally a high-expenditure tourist destination, cheaper airline tickets may offer tourists more options but not significantly cut the cost of their Japan tours, since hotel and restaurant expenses are still high.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISM TO CREATE BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES WORTH NT$30 BILLION

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists will create business opportunities in Taiwan worth an estimated NT$30 billion per year if travel restrictions on Chinese citizens are lifted, according to a report released Tuesday by a Japanese securities firm.

The estimate by Daiwa Securities SMBC-Cathay Co. includes spending on group tours and shopping, with the company predicting that Taiwan's travel agencies and hotels would benefit the most from easing restrictions.

Chen Kuan-jung, a senior analyst at the company, estimated that spending by each group of Chinese tourists could benefit the local economy between US$100 and US$120 per day, with each person spending between US$1,000 and US$1,200 each day of the 10-day tour.
If there are 540,000 Chinese tourist arrivals per year, spending on group tours will amount to US$540 million to US$650 million, or NT$17.3 billion to NT$20.8 billion, Chen said.
If each tourist spends NT$20,000 on shopping in Taiwan, the total amount will reach NT$10 billion per year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS CALL FOR HOUSE CLEANING TO RESTORE CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: Pro-Taiwan independence groups issued a joint statement Tuesday calling on the government to clean house and crack down on irregularities according to the law in order to restore the public's confidence and regain their trust.

In the statement, the "Hand-in-Hand League to Protect Taiwan, " the "Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association" and other pro-independence organizations also called on leaders of the major factions of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to renounce their "selfish ambitions" and work together to surmount what they described as the "gravest crisis" since the party's birth.

They were referring to the string of corruption scandals dogging President Chen Shui-bian's administration, including insider trading charges against his son-in-law and senior Presidential Office officials and the Financial Supervisory Commission, whose former Examination Bureau Director Lee Chin-cheng was sentenced to 10 years in jail Tuesday in the "stock vultures" case.

"We are deeply saddened by investigation into the irregularities involving members of the First Family. But Taiwanese do not have the right to be pessimists, " said the statement, urging the public to "give credit" to Chen's recent announcement that he will delegate power and pursue reform.

The president has decided to delegate power to the premier, an indication that he is sincere in listening to sound advice from all sides, it said. "Since the president has positively responded to society's expectations, people should give him encouragement, " it added.

But it accused the ruling DPP of not only failing to make good on its promise to create a "free, just and welfare" society in Taiwan, but also presiding over a string of corruption scandals to the disappointment of the people.

"The DPP should do some deep soul-searching as to why it has failed so miserably in its administration over the past six years. It should also realize that the recent eruption of serious corruption scandals has severely hurt the people's feelings," it said.

It urged DPP's faction leaders to tell the people they are honestly reviewing the party's records and are determined to reform the party and government so as to implement the party's previous blueprints for governing the country.

The pro-independence bodies also lambasted the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party for committing "all sorts of crimes" in Taiwan, including human rights violations and stealing huge amounts of public assets which have yet to be paid back.

On the opposition alliance's plan to recall the president, Huang Chao-tang, convener of the "Hand-in-Hand League, " said it has destabilized the political situation as well as the stock market for the ulterior purpose of seizing power.

Huang Kun-hu, president of the "Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association, " accused the opposition alliance of political maneuvering aimed at "scuttling Taiwan's localization campaign" and "making Taiwan part of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR CULTURAL TOURS CREATED IN CHANGHUA

TEXT.P: Four cultural tours have been organized in central Changhua County Tuesday by the county's Cultural Bureau to boost local tourism in the area.
Chen Yi-ling, a cultural official in charge of promoting tourism, said the four routes will allow tourists to experience the county's diversified culture and unique beauty.
The first route, with flora as the theme, winds through three rural townships of Hsichou, Tienwei and Peitou, all of which are known for flower farming.
The second route features natural beauty, and takes visitors to the country's Pakuashan ecosystemic farm to enjoy tranquil scenes and learn about various insects living on the farm.
The third route will cover the Chinshuiyan Temple and the Paofeng Goat Ranch in Shitou, while the fourth route includes the Tienhou Temple and ancient Wenkai Academy, both in Lukang town.
The Cultural Bureau will provide a free tour guide to 10 tour groups of 40 visitors each on the four routes beginning this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARDS SEIZE 1.8 TON OF SMUGGLED BETEL NUTS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (COA) officers seized 1.8 metric tons of smuggled betel nuts Monday near the estuary of the Choshui River in Yunlin County, a COA spokesman said Tuesday.
The spokesman said that COA officers were making a routine patrol when they spotted a suspiciously heavy-lade sampan.
While trying to escape, the two smugglers found their sampan became grounded on a sand dune.

The COA officers confiscated more than 100 packs of betel nuts smuggled from China, totalling 1.8 metric tons. They detained the two suspects -- Chang Chen-huan, 35, and Chen Shun-yi, 42 -- for questioning.
An initial inspection found that the betel nuts from China were sprayed with a freshness-keeping agent which may be harmful to human health.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER VOWS TO PROBE STOCK MARKET PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Rumors that Taiwan's stock market plunge Monday was due to four major institutional funds following the government's instructions on short selling must be clarified, an opposition legislator said Tuesday.

At a discussion session in the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Lai Shyi-bao of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vowed to find out the truth about whether the four public funds -- the Public Service Pension Fund, Postal Saving Fund, Labor Insurance Fund and Labor Pension Fund -- deliberately caused the stock market plunge in an attempt to keep scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian in power.

Retail investors suffered heavy losses Monday as the weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange shed 244.37 points to close at 6,715.27, causing NT$680 billion to evaporate in stock value. Losers outnumbered gainers 781 to 46, with only 36 stocks remaining unchanged.
There were rumors the plunge was caused by overselling by the four public funds.

Lai suspected the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government used the short-selling strategy to hurt retail investors and then blame the opposition parties for the current political turmoil and bad investment climate.
He said that if the rumors are proven true, the managers of the four funds, as well as those government officials who gave the instructions for short selling, must be held responsible.

DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang claimed Monday that the stock market plunge was in response to the plans of KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), to heighten confrontation with the DPP government, topple the Cabinet and recall the president.
The KMT and PFP, which are allies in the "pan-blue alliance," are pressing President Chen to step down over more than a dozen corruption scandals implicating Chen's family and senior aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO EXPAND EXHIBITION SPACE IN 2008

TEXT.P: To make up for the current shortage of exhibition space in Taiwan, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) announced Tuesday it has won administrative rights to Nankang exhibition hall -- twice entire floor space of the Taipei International Trade Center -- and will open the new space in 2008.
Speaking at the opening ceremony of COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said the computer exhibition will become the largest in the world after resolving the space-shortage problem.

After beating out a BOT competitor for rights to Nankang exhibition hall a day earlier at the review committee of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , TAITRA said it plans to ink an operational agreement soon with the MOEA.

COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006, the largest computer trade show in Asia and the second in the world, opened June 6 and lasts until June 10, with more than 1,300 domestic and international participants showing off their latest products.
TAITRA estimates over 130,000 visitors and buyers will attend the five-day exhibition, whose 2,907 booths will occupy Exhibition Hall 1, Hall 2 and Hall 3, as well as the international trade center.
According to TAITRA, the Nankang exhibition hall, with a size double that of the international trade center, has two-floor layouts which could accommodate 2,626 standard booths on the ground floor.
On the other hand, the second floor will be an ideal setting for indoor multi-purpose activities and performances, a TAITRA official said.

The International Trade Center and Nankang exhibition hall will be operating together in the future to make the best use of all available facilities, TAITRA said, adding it will also make efforts to invite foreign exhibitors to present their products at the new hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ASPIRANTS LAUNCH ANTI-PRESIDENT CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Two opposition Kuomintang (KMT) figures vying for the party's nomination to run for mayor of Kaohsiung have launched a signature campaign to demand that President Chen Shui-bian step down to take responsibility for a series of corruption scandals.
Huang Chun-ying and Huang Chao-shun, who are not related, are in the second round of the KMT's primary to see who will run on the party ticket in the year-end mayoral election.

In response to the KMT's campaign to bring down Chen Shui-bian and to "protect Taiwan with a government of integrity, " the two Huangs kicked off a petition campaign to show the KMT's determination to "end the corrupt regime."

Huang Chun-ying said his staff set up three stands in the city Tuesday, collecting hundreds of signature in just one day. The other Huang, who began the action a day earlier, claimed she has collected "tens of thousands" of names.
The party will conduct a public opinion poll June 22-24 and a vote June 25 to decide which of the two will represent the party in the mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY CHIEF CALLS FOR NUCLEAR WASTE REMOVAL

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei asked Tuesday that state-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) speed up the removal of nuclear waste from the first and second nuclear power plants in his county.

Cho made the remarks while presiding over a county meeting at which the pollution issue was raised following an oil leak the previous day at the fourth nuclear power plant -- still under construction in Kungliao, Taipei County -- which led to river and sea pollution.

Chou noted there are three nuclear power plants in Taipei County, and that high- and low-level radioactive nuclear waste is temporarily stored in the plant's complex, with the final disposal location as yet undecided.

Chou stressed that for the sake of the county's environmental protection, it adamantly opposes the storage of nuclear waste at the plant, saying the government must attach greater importance to the problem or the county government will have to resort to "extreme measures" to combat the situation.

If the central government fails to step up the waste's removal, Chou threatened that he might not allow any additional waste to be stored at the plant, and that he would block anyone other than security personnel from entering the plant.
"The operations of the nuclear power plant might be paralyzed, " he warned.
The county government will also send a team of experts to monitor the nuclear waste storage facilities in the first and second nuclear power plants, he said.

According to an Atomic Energy Council estimate, as of May this year 35,000 barrels of low-level radioactive nuclear waste are stored at the first nuclear power plant, while the second nuclear power plant has stored more than 44,000 barrels of low-level radioactive nuclear waste.

Taipower, the operator of the nuclear power plants, has a volume-reduction center near the second nuclear power plant which uses supercompactors and incinerators to compact or to burn inflammable waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN COUNTY PROMOTES 'HEALTHY FAMILY' CONCEPT

TEXT.P: The County Bureau of Education in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, launched a campaign called "1-6-8" Tuesday to promote its concept of a "healthy family."

Magistrate Chu Li-lun hosted a news conference at the county hall to explain the idea of "1-6-8," saying that in a healthy family, there are six ways to boost close ties between spouses and eight ways for people to enhance child-parent relations. This is the key to cultivating close family relationships, he said.

Encouraging the county's residents to say the word "love" from time to time, Chu said he hopes people can adopt the concept of "love" as featured in the 2000 Hollywood film "Pay It Forward, " and carry out that notion in their daily life.

Bureau Director of Education, Chang Ming-wen said that every day there are six ways to strengthen husband-wife ties: give your spouse a hug, doing one thing for him or her, share your experiences every day and listen to your partner carefully, conduct one activity together every week, respect that person's need to be alone and be willing to face all challenges together.

Outlining eight ways to enhance parent-child relationships, Chen stated that parents need to embrace their child every day, give them daily compliments, listen to them speak about their day at school, express gratitude daily for something together with the child, conduct one activity together every week, keep the child company during one activity he/she is interested in, encourage children to accomplish one mission and then compliment them on achieving the goal, and educate them together with your spouse in a manner that shows determination and kindness.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF SURPRISED BY VICE CHAIRMAN'S INDICTMENT

TEXT.P: Officials of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) expressed surprise Tuesday at the indictment of their vice chairman for allegedly embezzling money from a local company and said they will handle the matter properly after receiving more information about the case.

SEF Vice Chairman Chang Chun-hung was indicted Tuesday by the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office on charge of embezzling corporate funds from Formosa Tele-communication Investment Co. Ltd, where he also served as chairman and chief executive officer.
The prosecutors asked the court to sentence Chang to seven years in prison.

The SEF said in a statement that Chang's accused crime has nothing to do with SEF operations, adding that it will contact Chang as soon as possible to get a better understanding of the matter so that the SEF can decide on whether he will lose his post.
The statement said it will respect the results of the judicial investigation.
Chang, a once-influential figure in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, served as DPP secretary-general from 1988 to 1991 and as the party's acting chairman in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Fed Chief Raises Inflation Concern; Stocks Fall on Prospect of Higher Rates.
Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke expressed more concern about rising inflation than the cooling U.S. economy yesterday, sending his strongest signal yet that interest rates are probably headed higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAINT VINCENT CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS CAN BE REFERENCED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' constitutional reform process can be used as reference for Taiwan.

During a meeting with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Premier Ralph Gonslaves, Chen noted that the Caribbean country has set up a constitutional reform committee responsible for reporting its reform conclusions to its Congress and said the process can be considered as a reference for Taiwan.
"Taiwan's constitutional reforms will not be impossible as long as the social condition of Taiwan is mature and the reforms obtain the support from the legislature and the people, " Chen said.
He expressed thanks for the hospitality extended by the Saint Vincent government to him and his delegation when they visited last year.

Noting that both Taiwan and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have treasured their friendship since the establishment of diplomatic ties in 1981, Chen said Taiwan will try its best to help the Caribbean country develop several infrastructure projects such as the construction of bridges, highways, a national library and an international airport.
Taiwan is also planning to offer scholarships to students from the diplomatic ally and to strengthen bilateral agricultural and technological cooperation to boost ties, Chen added.

For his part, Gonslaves expressed gratitude to Taiwan for its various assistance programs to his country, stressing that it will continue extending its support to the nation's bid to join the world community.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S PART IN LARGEST TELESCOPE PROJECT INVALUABLE: ACADEMIA SINICA

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica's participation in establishing the "Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) " -- the largest ground-based array of radio telescopes in the world -- has opened a window allowing Taiwan into the world of advanced astronomical research, Academia Sinica said Tuesday in a press release.

The ALMA project, supported by Europe and the United States, employs 64 12-meter antennas located at an elevation of 5,000 meters in the foothills of the Andes in Chile. The array will be fully operational in 2011.
With the ALMA, astronomers will be able to detect and study the earliest and most distant galaxies, as well as look into the details of star and planet formation.

Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious research institute, has previously collaborated with the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in building the Submillimeter Array (SMA) in Hawaii. The SMA -- with eight six-meter antennas at 4,080 meters above sea level -- was the first of its kind in the world.

When comparing the SMA and the ALMA, a researcher at the Academia Sinica offered the analogy that with the SMA, observers can "see" a cockroach at Chiang Kai-shek Airport from Taipei 101, while with the ALMA, observers can tell what kind of cockroach it is in the same distance.

An Academia Sinica official said that Taiwan is participating in the ALMA project through joining an extensive project between Japan and the ALMA. The project can enhance the function of the ALMA by adding an additional four 12-meter and 12 seven-meter antennas to the existing ones, forming an "Atacama Compact Array" observing the universe with 80 radio telescopes.

The official noted that the Academia Sinica signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Japan last September in which the institute will provide US$16 million -- one 20th of Japan's total funding. He added that under the terms of the MOU, Taiwan's researchers share the same rights as their Japanese counterparts in utilizing the ALMA.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG DRAGON BOAT TEAM TO DEPART FOR PORTLAND

TEXT.P: A high school dragon boat team in the southern city of Kaohsiung will depart for Portland, Oregon Wednesday to take part in the Rose Festival activities.

It will be the 15th consecutive year the Shu-Te Home Economics and Commercial High School's dragon boat team has participated in the Portland festival. The 47-member delegation is scheduled to return June 20.

A ceremony presided over by Kaohsiung acting Mayor Yeh Chu-lan was held in honor of the dragon boat team's departure. She said dragon boat racing will be one of the official competitions in the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung, and that it is an honor for Shu-Te's dragon boat team to be part of the annual Rose Festival celebrations in Portland.
Kaohsiung and Portland are sister cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Is Offering Deals on Trade to Entice Iran
The European Union's foreign policy director Javier Solana arrived in Tehran on Monday night with incentives intended to resolve the nuclear crisis with Iran, including a proposal to allow Iran to upgrade its aging civilian air fleet through the purchase of aircraft parts from an American company, Boeing. The package agreed by the five permanent members of the Security Council --Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States -- plus Germany, waives trade sanctions against Iran. The offer includes a commitment from the six nations to support Iran's plan for a nuclear energy program for civilian use, including building light-water reactors through joint projects with other countries.
Wall Street Journal: Democrats Might Win at Least One House in Midterms; Senate Switch Less Likely, Northeast Is Key Battleground
As a bad year for Republicans keeps getting worse, expectations are growing that Democrats could capture at least one house of Congress, ending one-party dominance of the nation's capital and crippling President Bush for his final years. If the current mood holds, Democrats are in a position to win the 15 seats they need to take control of the House. They have a harder task, however, snagging the six seats needed in the Senate.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR FUND TRADING NORMAL: FSC

TEXT.P: The selling and buying of stocks by the four major institutional funds seemed "normal" Monday, Susan S. Chang, administrative vice chairwoman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) under the Executive Yuan, claimed Tuesday.
She made the remarks in reply to media inquiries about rumors that Taiwan's stock market plunged Monday due to the four government-managed funds following government instructions on short selling.

The four institutional funds -- the Public Service Pension Fund, the Postal Saving Fund, the Labor Insurance Fund and the Labor Pension Fund -- had a difference of over NT$130 million between selling and buying, with selling surpassing buying, she said.
The selling-buying difference was NT$300 million in the morning, while fund managers bought NT$160 million more stocks than they sold in the afternoon, Chang said.
She added that the four institutional funds were buying stocks during the stock market plunge at around noon and added that selling more than buying was "within the normal range."

The weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange shed 244.37 points to close at 6,715.27, causing NT$680 billion-worth of stock market value to be lost. Losers outnumbered gainers 781 to 46, with 36 stocks remaining unchanged.
There were rumors the plunge was caused by overselling by the four public funds and opposition lawmakers have demanded that the government investigate the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OFFICE CONFIRMS BURGHARDT'S TAIPEI VISIT PLAN

TEXT.P: The Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) confirmed Tuesday that AIT Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt will arrive in Taipei later this week for his first visit since assuming his post as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official ties between the two countries.

AIT Taipei Office acting spokesman David Miller said Burghardt plans to make extensive contacts with various sectors of local society during his stay. Nevertheless, details of his itinerary will not be made public, Miller added.

In addition to his stated purpose of inspecting AIT operations in Taiwan, local media reports said, Burghardt will take advantage of his visit to get first-hand information about Taiwan's latest political situation amid growing pressure on President Chen Shui-bian to resign over a string of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close associates. The reports said Burghardt has requested a meeting with Chen.

Burghardt, a retired career diplomat who served as the AIT Taipei Office head from 1999 through 2001, is versed in Taiwan affairs. Chen decorated him with a medal when he ended his Taipei stint in appreciation of his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

His diplomatic assignments also include ambassador to Vietnam, consul-general in Shanghai and deputy chief of the missions in Seoul and Manila. He now concurrently serves as director of the East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREVIEW OF OVERSEAS PHOTO EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A preview of a collection of 66 photographic images of Taiwan that is scheduled to be shown abroad opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Tuesday.

The preview, dubbed "Taiwan Revealed," gives a glimpse of an upcoming overseas show organized by Taiwan Panorama to display selected images from the monthly magazine that have been published by the Government Information Office (GIO) over the past five years.

Addressing the opening ceremony, GIO chief Cheng Wen-tsang said the periodical has been "telling stories" about how people live in Taiwan and providing overseas Chinese communities with literary descriptions and magnificent photos of the Pacific island over the past some 30 years.

Over the years, Taiwan Panorama has published numerous reports on a wide range of topics in Taiwan's society and its abundant cultural life. The bilingual journal is also a perfect gift for friends, Cheng said.

In his address, Cheng also called for public support of government efforts to promote cultural exchanges with countries around the globe, while reaffirming the Central News Agency's move to invite representatives of foreign news agencies to visit Taiwan in the near future.

The opening ceremony also saw the attendance of CNA President Liu Chih-tsung, Public Television Group Chairman Chen Shun-shang, Radio Taiwan International President Cheryl Lai, Yuan-Liou Publishing Group Chairman Wang Jung-wen, Photographic Society of Taiwan Chairman Tsai Wen-hsiang, as wall as many other cultural and communications representatives.

The Taipei exhibition is scheduled to run through July 9. There are six categories of photos on display -- beautiful islands, aboriginal people, village and city profiles, architecture, the lives of locals and traditional religious rites.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RESOLVED TO RECALLING PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is poised to attempt to oust President Chen Shui-bian by initiating a presidential recall motion "to prevent the country from becoming further crippled, " KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said Tuesday.

Pan made the remarks in a news conference at the Legislative Yuan in which she said that a KMT task force has decided to work to that end following a meeting with high-ranking party officials, including KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, the previous evening.

The KMT decided to first initiate a presidential recall motion to gauge Chen's reaction while weighing other possible means, such as toppling the Cabinet or taking people to the streets, to pressure him to resign, she said.
"The right time has come for the KMT do so, as the people want Chen to step down to take responsibility for the wrongdoings committed by members of his family," she claimed.

The KMT is poised to initiate the motion because it has been proved that Chen's wife, Wu Shu-jen, received political contributions from former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hao that can be dated back to the 1990s -- something that Chen and his wife have repeatedly denied, Pan claimed. Chen vowed to quit politics if the rumors were proved to be true.

Sheng Fu-hsiung, a former lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), recently confirmed that he accompanied Chen You-hao, now a wanted fugitive living in China after having committed a serious financial crime in Taiwan, to Chen's house in 1994 and made a political contribution to Wu at their residence when her husband was running for Taipei mayor.

In addition, Su Teh-chien, the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) chairman who has been held in custody since late last month for his suspected role in an insider trading scandal involving his company's shares, asked Chao Chien-ming, Chen's son-in-law, to use his influence to secure a syndicated loan for the TDC and thus secure his own post.

In exchange for Chao's favor, Su is suspected of telling Chao to buy large amounts of TDC shares on the grounds that the value of TDC stocks would surge if the syndicated loan for several land development projects could be secured.

In view of the many corruption allegations implicating members of Chen's family, the president should step down in response to "public demand" to bring an end to the present chaotic situation, Pan said, arguing that "Chen's stepping down would be the least he can do for the country to head off greater damage."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SENIOR PRESIDENTIAL AIDE QUESTIONED BY PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: Ma Yung-cheng, who resigned as deputy secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian last week, was questioned Tuesday by prosecutors investigating alleged meddling into appointments of board chairmen to state-owned enterprises.
Ma told investigators that his handling of such appointments was "completely legal," according to judicial sources.

Prosecutor Lin Pang-liang of the Taipei District Court said Ma was questioned for his alleged role in appointing Su Teh-chien, who is in detention, as chairman of the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC), a syndicate loan to bail out TDC, and an ownership fight over Waterland Securities Co.
Ma told the media that he "told the prosecutors everything they wanted to know."

According to judicial sources, Ma testified that Su was recommended by an Executive Yuan committee and the Presidential Office had reached a consensus with then-Finance Minister Lin Chuan before appointing him. He insisted that "the whole process was completely legal," according to the sources.

Ma told the investigators that he did not know Su personally and that Su might have used his name at a dinner party to boast of Su's own influence, a party that became damning evidence of his insider trading.

Ma further claimed that he had not interfered in the dispute over the ownership of Waterland Security Co., whose chairman, Tsai Ching-wen, was released on bail after admitting to his wrongdoings in connection with the TDC insider trading scandal.

Also questioned Tuesday was Chen Chung, former deputy finance minister and now chairman of Taiwan Cooperative Bank, for his alleged role in the fight for ownership of Waterland Securities and a government decision to approve a syndicate loan for TDC.

Judicial sources said Chen Chung testified that Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law now in detention, called him to express "concern" over the ownership fight but said he was not sure Chao was lobbying for any particular person.
He also explained why the Financial Supervisory Commission approved a NT$16.5 billion loan offered by a syndicate of 29 banks to TDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN'S POLITICAL SITUATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 5 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-you and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government is concerned about Taiwan's recent volatile political situation as the opposition parties are trying to oust President Chen Shui-bian over a string of debilitating scandals, a State Department source said Monday.

The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the U.S. authorities have maintained intensive contacts with Taiwanese political figures in recent days to keep abreast of the island's political developments.

Strictly abiding by diplomatic protocol, the source said, the U.S. government is unlikely to make any public comments on Taiwan's internal affairs. While the United States hopes Taiwan maintains stability, the source added that Washington looks forward to seeing Chen serve out the remaining two years of his second and final four-year term.
The official also denied a rumor circulating in Taiwan that Chen's intention of allowing the majority party in the Legislative Yuan to form a new Cabinet was the result of U.S. pressure.

Dismissing the rumor as outrageously misleading, the official said the U.S. government could not imagine the consequences of Chen handing over or ceding power to any "other individual." But he did not elaborate on what he meant by "other individual" -- another government official? a ruling Democratic Progressive Party bigwig? or an opposition heavyweight?

David Ta-wei Lee, Taiwan's top representative to the United States, confirmed Monday that the U.S. authorities have held constant dialogue with him over the past week, exchanging views on Taiwan's latest political developments. But Lee stressed that the U.S. officials were mainly getting information and refrained from making any comments.

Speaking with Taiwan journalists posted in the U.S. capital, Lee said U.S. officials asked him earlier in the day about the significanc of the recent announcement by Taiwan's National Security Council that its two deputy secretaries-general will leave their posts soon as part of personnel adjustments in line with President Chen's May 31 announcement to delegate administrative powers to Premier Su Tseng-chang and carry out political reforms.

Given Taiwan's special and close relations with the United States, Lee said his office must maintain intensive and extensive communications with U.S. authorities whenever there are major changes or developments.

According to Lee, the U.S. govenrment is concerned about the content of Chen's power delegation. Lee said he has assured U.S. authorities that Chen's move strictly follows Taiwan's constitution and existing law. Amid growing pressure on him to step down over corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and aides, Chen announced May 31 that he will delegate policy-making and personnel-appointment powers to Premier Su.
Lee said he has assured the U.S. authorities that the continuity of Taiwan's foreign policy will be maintained, no matter how the political situation develops.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOWS TO STEP UP CRACKDOWN ON HUMAN TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said Tuesday the government will step up crackdown on human trafficking and has outlawed cross-border marriage matchmaking to prevent human trafficking.

Lee made the remarks after the newly released U.S. annual report on trafficking in persons places Taiwan on a "Tier 2 Watch List" for not fully complying with the minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking.

The U.S. report said Taiwan has failed to show evidence of increasing efforts over the past year to address trafficking, despite ample resources to do so, particularly to address the serious level of forced labor and sexual servitude among legally migrating Southeast Asian contract workers and brides.

Lee said the government is determined to devote more energies and resources to clamp down on human trafficking. Under the newly revised immigration law, no more marriage brokerage companies can be set up and existing marriage matchmaking firms will be subject to stricter regulations and monitoring to prevent cross-border human trafficking in guise of marriage matchmaking.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 7 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, June 7:
10:00, The Taipei Society will hold a news conference at NTU Alumni Hall in Taipei.
10:00, Premier Su Tseng-chang will meet with visiting Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Premier Ralph Gonslaves at Grand Hotel in Taipei.
10:30, Premier Su will attend a reception marking the opening of a Saint Vincent and the Grenadines tourist, arts and cultural exhibition to be held at Grand Hotel.
16:00, The Ministry of Finance will unveil customs tallies on May exports and imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 7, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTED TO SIGN FTAS WITH HONDURAS, EL SALVADOR THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to sign free trade agreements (FTA) with Honduras and El Salvador later this year, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Wednesday.
Taiwan completed the first round of FTA negotiations with the two Central American countries late last month, in which the text of the agreements was hammered out, the officials said.
The three parties are scheduled to hold the second round of negotiations in mid July to add the finishing touches, they said.

After the implementation of the Central America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA) between the United States and Central American nations, Taiwan has been actively seeking to sign FTAs with its diplomatic allies in that region to help Taiwanese businesses tap the Latin American market.

While Taiwan has established FTAs with Panama and Guatemala, FTA talks are underway with Nicaragua, in addition to Honduras and El Salvador. FTA talks with Costa Rica and the Dominican Republic are set to start in the second half of this year.

According to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-rong, it is Taiwan's goal to build a Taiwan-Central America free trade region via the FTA framework and help Taiwanese businesses make further inroads in the U.S. market using the preferential tariff treatment enjoyed by Central American nations.
On Taiwan's industrial park project in El Salvador, Chen said some manufacturers in Taiwan's textile industry have expressed interest in setting up shops there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AMONG 7 FINALISTS FOR 'INTELLIGENT COMMUNITY' AWARD
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 6 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taipei City was selected as one of the best "intelligent communities" in the world in 2006 as it is considered to have commendable broadband infrastructure, knowledge workforce and digital democracy.

Taipei City, as well as South Korea's Gangnam, Japan's Ichikawa, Britain's Manchester, China's Tianjin and Canada's Waterloo were selected as the top seven finalists for the 2006 Intelligent Community of the Year Award to be presented by the Intelligent Community Forum (ICF) in New York City June 9.
More than 200 mayors, diplomats, high-tech corporate executives and internet technology experts from around the world are expected to take part in the annual ICF gathering slated for June 8-9.
Taipei Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung, on behalf of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, will attend the forum's discussion sessions as well as the award presentation ceremony.

Taipei City was also selected as one of the finalists for the Intelligent Community of the Year in 2004. During the award presentation ceremony that year, then Taipei Deputy Mayor Ou Chin-ter delivered a speech at the invitation of the ICF to introduce the development of wireless telecommunications and digital technology in Taiwan's capital.

In a study funded by the Province of Ontario, Canada, the ICF defined five critical factors for success in the creation of intelligent communities. The five "Intelligent Community Indicators" -- namely broadband infrastructure, knowledge workforce, innovation, digital democracy and marketing -- provided the first conceptual framework for understanding all of the factors that determine how competitive a community will be in the Digital Age.
During the upcoming award presentation ceremony, the ICF is also expected to name its Intelligent Building, Intelligent Community Technology and Intelligent Community Visionary of the Year.

William G. Hutchison, founding chairman of CANARIE and founding chairman of Canada's National Advisory Board for Science and Technology, is also expected to be presented with an ICF Lifetime Achievement Award during the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO CONVENE NEXT TUESDAY AT EARLIEST

TEXT.P: An extraordinary session of the legislature can be convened next Tuesday at the earliest, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday.

Wang noted that the legislature will have an informal meeting next Monday during which a decision on whether to convene an extraordinary session will be made. If an extraordinary session is held, the agenda will also have to be set, he added.

He stressed that both the ruling and the opposition parties have agreed that an extraordinary session is necessary and that "it is bound to be held," despite the early threat by the opposition that it will link the holding of an extraordinary session to discussions with law revision proposals that would allow direct cross-strait transportation links.

The previous session ended May 30 in chaos when the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party could not reach common ground on the law revision proposals regarding the cross-strait links.

Many important bills, such as a bill for a major arms procurement from the United States and one for a special budget for a national flood-fighting project, were left undealt with in the last session.

Wang also said that a proposal to recall the president, after collecting 72 signatures from "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers, is now valid and will set in motion a grueling process of recalling President Chen Shui-bian whose leadership has been cast in doubt following the detention of one of his former aides and his son-in-law for their alleged roles in corruption scandals.
On a reported plan by the opposition to adopt a no-confidence motion to topple the Cabinet in September, Wang also said that "all will have to be handled according to set procedures."

He said that the Executive Yuan has already sent its re-districting plan in line with a new electoral system to the legislature, adding that whether the legislature can give its consent by September "will also hinge on the decisions reached during the extraordinary session."

He was referring to the fact that President Chen might not accept the legislature's move to topple the Cabinet and instead dissolve the legislature, which would result in the holding of legislative elections which would have to be conducted under a new format following the passage of a package of constitutional amendments last June.

The amendments include the halving of the number of legislative seats to 113 and implementation of a "single constituency, two votes" electoral system, the latter of which has made the re-districting scheme necessary.

According to the newly amended law governing the election and recall of public functionaries, the legislature should give its consent to the re-districting plan 13 months before the current legislature expires.

If the legislature has not yet given its consent and a new legislative election is approaching, then the re-districting scheme mapped out by the Central Election Commission (CEC) will used, "because the status of the Constitution is higher than the law," according to the CEC.
The newly elected legislators will be sworn in for four-year terms instead of the current three years, according to the amended Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA INVESTMENT BY TAIWAN'S LISTED, OTC FIRMS TOPS NT$534 BILLION

TEXT.P: China-bound remittances by Taiwan's listed and over-the-counter (OTC) companies amounted to NT$534.6 billion as of the end of the first quarter of this year, up NT$2.9 billion compared with the level recorded at the end of 2005, according to the latest tallies from the Financial Supervisory Commission.
As of the first quarter of 2006, 485 listed companies and 331 OTC companies from Taiwan had made investment in China, FSC officials said.
These companies had remitted NT$41.6 billion of their profits back to Taiwan, with listed companies contributing NT$40.4 billion and OTC companies contributing NT$1.2 billion, the officials said.
The inward remittances represent an increase of NT$300 million compared with the end of 2005 and account for 7.78 percent of the amount that was remitted to China, they said.
Meanwhile, as of the first quarter of 2006, 527 listed companies and 383 OTC companies from Taiwan had made investment in foreign countries other than China, the officials said.

This overseas investment was valued at NT$1.63 trillion, up NT$30.8 billion from the level registered at the end of 2005, with NT$935.7 billion made by listed companies and NT$127.3 billion by OTC companies, they said.

The electronics industry contributed the largest share in terms of overseas investment, and the major investment destinations of Taiwan companies include the British Virgin Islands, the United States, Hong Kong, the Cayman Islands and Samoa, they said.
For the whole of 2005, Taiwan's listed companies made profits worth NT$112.5 billion from their overseas investment, while OTC companies made NT$5.8 billion, the officials said.
In the first quarter of 2006, listed companies made profits worth NT$30.9 billion and OTC companies made NT$4.5 billion, they said.

The Canadian terrorist cell that was busted over the weekend is believed to have connections in at least six other countries in Asia, the United States and Europe, officials said, as new revelations emerged yesterday that it planned devastating attacks on two targets here.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Japan's Emperor urges Japanese Government should remember the historical lessons.
Emperor Akihito on Tuesday said Japan should remember the damage and pain its militarist past caused its own people and Asian neighbors, and called for more effort to ensure it never happens again.
