In moves lauded by Malacanang, both chambers of Congress yesterday approved their respective measures to repeal the Death Penalty Law.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Death penalty is dead
IN A MOVE that would benefit about 1,000 people on death row, the Senate and the House of Representatives yesterday crossed party lines to approve the abolition of the death penalty, weeks before President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's visit to the Vatican for an audience with Pope Benedict XVI.
The Philippine Star: Congress OKs repeal of death penalty law
In two landmark votes yesterday, the Senate and the House of Representatives abolished the death penalty -- 12 years after it was reimposed by Congress as the maximum punishment for heinous crimes.
The Manila Times: President to veto trimmed budget
President Arroyo on Tuesday warned she would veto the 2006 national budget if the Senate insists on slashing it by P31.11 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED MILITARY OFFICER ARRESTED FOR SELLING MODIFIED GUNS ONLINE

TEXT.P: Police in Taichung in central Taiwan on Tuesday detained a retired military officer for selling modified guns over the Internet.
The police learned about Yen Hue-shu's activities after arresting two men earlier this year for illegally possessing firearms.

Taking advantage of the knowledge he acquired during his years in the military, Yen began selling modified firearms online. According to police, Yen modified the guns in the attic of his father's house in Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan.
After being arrested, Yen confessed to police that he had already sold more than 10 modified guns. Police are now working to track down the firearms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 117.53 points to close at 6,612.74.
The bourse opened at 6,691.50 and fluctuated between 6,699.54 and 6.612.74 during trading. A total of 2.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.22 billion (US$2.56 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by textile shares at 0.2 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by cement issues at 1.8 percent, financial shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, and paper and pulp shares at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 610 to 162, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June dropped 113 points to close at 6,576, with 46,653 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July moved down 103 points to finish at 6,522, with 745 contracts traded, while September futures lost 100 points to close at 6,420, with 74 contract transactions.
December futures dropped 104 points to close at 6,421, with 14 contracts traded, while March futures lost 75 points to finish at 6,419, with eight contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,689 for June, 6,625 for July, 6,520 for September, 6,525 for December and 6,494 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 6.25 points to close at 278.3, with 5,992 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 6.7 points to finish at 276.3, with 77 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 4.85 points to finish at 275.1, with three contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 0.9 points to finish at 275.7, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.
June TF futures moved down 15.8 points to finish at 947, with 3,045 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures lost 13.8 points to close at 942.2, with 53 contracts traded.
September TF futures lost five points to finish at 938, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Wednesday that American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt will meet with President Chen Shui-bian during a three-day visit to Taiwan.
Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison official with Taiwan in the absence of official ties between Taiwan and the United States, was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later in the day.
Huang said Burghardt was also expected to visit him to exchange views on various issues.
Huang said Burghardt's itinerary has been arranged by the Taipei Office of the AIT, which represents U.S. interest in Taiwan, according to protocol.
Reports said that in addition to inspecting AIT operations in Taiwan, Burghardt will have extensive contacts with representatives of various sectors to learn about the latest political developments.

Burghardt, who is making his first visit to Taiwan since assuming his new post in February, arrives amid growing pressure on President Chen Shui-bian to resign in the wake of a string of corruption allegations implicating his former close aides and son-in-law.

Burghardt, a retired career diplomat who served as the AIT Taipei Office head from 1999 through 2001, is versed in Taiwan affairs. Chen decorated him with a civic award when he ended his Taipei stint in appreciation of his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

His diplomatic assignments also include ambassador to Vietnam, consul-general in Shanghai and deputy chief of the missions in Seoul and Manila. He now concurrently serves as director of the East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.158 to close at NT$32.220.
A total of US$1.15 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.195 and fluctuated between NT$32.057 and NT$32.247.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK INKS COOPERATION MOU WITH THAILAND

TEXT.P: Hsinchu Science Park Administration (HSPA) Director James Lee signed a cooperation agreement with Deputy Director Chachanat Thebtaranonth of the National Science Technology Development Agency (NSTDA) of Thailand in the Finnish capital of Helsinki Wednesday to promote technological, information, trade and investment exchanges.
The signing ceremony took place during the annual meeting of the International Association of Science Parks (IASP) and was witnessed by IASP Chairman Luis Sanz.

An HSPA official said the cooperation agreement covers information and personnel exchanges such as advanced technologies and incubation centers, enhancement of exchanges between both science parks, possibilities of joint-ventures and extending industry cooperation plans.
Thailand's economic growth is one of the fastest in Asia, an official of the HSPA said, adding that Taiwan has a strong and close relationship with Thailand.

Moreover, Thailand has built many high-tech science parks to upgrade its industry and attract foreign investment, an official said, adding that the agreement will benefit both countries and advance future relationships.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD RESIGN IF FAMILY MEMBERS CONVICTED: ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should resign if any member of the first family is convicted of breaking the law, an academic with the public interest group Taipei Society claimed Wednesday.

Hung Yu-hung, a member of the Executive Committee of the Taipei Society -- a public interest body founded by a group of liberal academics who oppose nuclear power plants and social injustice -- claimed that Chen will have "no option" but to step down if any member of his family is convicted.

The opposition parties held a rally several days ago to demand that Chen step down 10 days after the detention of his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, following allegations of insider trading by an opposition legislator.

The subject of Chao's alleged involvement in insider trading, as well as a series of suspected corruption scandals involving senior officials in the administration, have aroused widespread public anger.

If Chen were to resign in the event that his son-in-law is convicted of wrongdoings, Premier Su Tseng-chang, who was appointed by the president, should also step down, said Hung, who is a professor in cranial nerves with National Yang Ming University.

After Chen and Su's resignation, Hung said, Vice President Annette Lu would constitutionally become the president. As to who would succeed Su will be a thorny issue facing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), he added.

Even if the president's son-in-law is found not guilty, Hung claimed, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party is unlikely to relent in its muckraking but will try to continue "dismembering" the first family until the DPP collapses.

At this critical juncture when the DPP is facing "life or death" challenges, Su should consider reshuffling the Cabinet without being held back by factional conflict, Hung said, adding that the DPP will see a silver lining in the 2008 presidential election only if the DPP administration improves its performance over the next two years.

On the 2008 presidential election, Hung said that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou -- widely viewed as the KMT's best bet in the next presidential race -- might not win the election if he indulges in muckraking over the first family and fails to put forth a campaign platform.

Meanwhile, Prof. Ku Chung-hua of National Chengchi University, who is also a Taipei Society Executive Committee member, said Taiwan is now being rattled by a political earthquake, where the "first family volcano" is ready to erupt at any minute.
Ku claimed that the greatest problem facing Chen is that he has not realized that his and the first family's power has undergone unlimited inflation, resulting in Chen's becoming distrusted.

Meanwhile, Hsu Yung-ming, another Taipei Society Executive Committee member who is an Academia Sinica assistant researcher, said that if Chen's son-in-law were to be convicted of wrongdoings, Chen's resignation might help defuse a political crisis.

But if Chao is not found guilty, the muckraking, mudslinging and rumor-mongering conducted by the "pan-blue alliance" would only be venomous campaign schemes targeting the 2008 presidential election, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY TO PROMOTE MANGO SALES IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-dji is scheduled to go to Japan later this month to promote the southern county's mango sales, a county spokesman said Wednesday.
According to the spokesman, Su's trip is slated for June 25-July 1 and will take him to Tokyo and Osaka.

The spokesman said Japanese consumers appreciate Taiwan-produced mangoes, but only those of the best quality are exported, with some premium-quality mangoes selling for over NT$90 (US$2.8125) per kilogram at the farms where they are harvested.

Besides selling mangoes to Japan, the county government also intends to cooperate with Hi-Life International Co., a Taiwanese convenience store chain, to provide consumers with mango-ordering services.
The spokesman noted that this year's mango harvest promises to be much better than last year's, as torrential rain had a devastating effect on last year's harvest.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUSTING PRESIDENT TO `KEEP TAIWAN CLEAN': KMT LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) demands that President Chen Shui-bian step down to take responsibility for a series of corruption scandals, regardless of whether the opposition resorts to a presidential recall motion or a motion to topple the Cabinet, KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said Friday.
Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Pan said that what the KMT wants to achieve is to "wipe out corruption" -- something that has nothing to do with political affiliation.

Although the legal threshold required to call a presidential recall motion is high, Pan expressed the hope that lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will join the KMT's lead to oust Chen and "build a clean Taiwan."

Even if the chances are slim for the presidential recall motion to pass the Legislative Yuan without the DPP's support, the KMT will try to make Chen the first president to face a recall motion in the legislature's record, she added.

Pan also accused Chen of trying to peddle influence among the investigation authorities probing the insider trading case allegedly involving Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, claiming that "it is hard for the people to believe that Chen has not attempted to meddle in the investigation on Chao's case." She asked Chen to give a clear explanation of the issue in public.
Local media reported that Chen met Investigation Bureau Director Yeh Sheng-mao in secret over Chao's case after having apologized to the public for any wrongdoings of his family members May 20.

Shortly after Chen met Yeh, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin also told local media that the investigation into Chao's part in the insider trading case could be closed quickly, Pan said, arguing that Shih's "inadequate remarks" suggest his intention to influence the ongoing investigation.

Turning to a media report that the main opposition KMT will propose a motion in the next legislative session in September to topple the Cabinet, Pan said that "all possible means will be studied" to pressure Chen to step down.
Should Chen dissolve the Legislative Yuan by that time, the KMT would prepare for a new general election, she said.
Meanwhile, Presidential Office spokesman Lee Nan-yang denied that Chen did not meet Yeh last month.

A spokeswoman for the Investigation Bureau also denied the report, saying that Chen never met Yeh in secret over Chao, who has been held in custody since May 25 for his alleged role in the insider trading scandal involving Taiwan Development Corp. shares.
Wu Lee-chen told a news conference Wednesday that Chen would only question the Investigation Bureau chief over national security affairs when necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY, CITY COOPERATE TO OPTIMIZE PUBLIC WELFARE

TEXT.P: Cooperation between Taipei city and county has borne fruit since a commission for this purpose was formed between them in February, an official from the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under Taipei City said Wednesday.

Citing a sea funeral held May 5 as an example, the official said Taipei City, which is landlocked, could not organize the environmentally friendly funeral without the help of Taipei County which covers part of the coastline of the Taiwan Strait.
Taipei City, most of which is densely populated, is encouraging its residents to resort to sea funerals to ease the heavy demand for graveyard space.
Also, the official said, the two districts' ambulance operation centers have harmonized their radio frequencies to communicate with each other in emergencies.
As a result, the official said, the ambulances of both districts can attend people in the other district during large scale disasters.
There are another 82 cooperation projects being studied that will further promote the welfare of residents of both districts, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN CHAIN STORE TO HOLD PROCUREMENT MEETING JUNE 21

TEXT.P: Officials of the European chain store OBI Merchandise Center GMBH, with annual business volume of 6.3 billion euros, will come to Taiwan June 21 for a procurement meeting with local companies, Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) officials said Wednesday.
OBI, a major DIY chain, is seeking to purchase items such as alarms, batteries, sockets, extension cables and battery chargers, the officials said.
TAITRA said OBI was established in 1970, with branch stores in 10 European countries and 450 sale points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR QUICK REVIEW OF MAJOR LEGISLATIVE BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang called on the Legislative Yuan Wednesday to hold a special session as soon as possible to review urgent bills concerning the people's well-being and the country's development, instead of engaging in "political struggle."
Speaking during a weekly Cabinet meeting, Su urged the legislators to work to sustain the country's stability to ensure the efficient operation of the government.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party put forth a proposal Tuesday to hold a special legislative session, during which the opposition plans to press ahead with a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Other bills that are likely to be raised for discussion include a proposed budget for a flood-prevention project, proposed amendments to the Statute Governing Relations Between Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area that would allow direct cross-Taiwan strait transport links and the nomination of the state public prosecutor-general.

According to Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan, the "pan-blue alliance's" campaign to recall the president and its plan to launch a no-confidence vote against the premier contradict the public's expectations for political stability.

Cheng said the Executive Yuan hopes that during the upcoming special legislative session, legislators will prioritize urgent bills related to improving the country's economy and the people's livelihoods and put off the controversial one concerning direct cross-strait transport links.
Su said that as typhoon season has begun in Taiwan, the passage of the budget for the flood-prevention project is critical to the government's efforts to protect people's safety.

Also important are the special budget proposal for the expansion of public construction investment projects, the budget proposal for the Executive Yuan's affiliated agencies and a draft law governing the establishment of a workers' retirement fund supervisory board, which the legislators should deal with immediately, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EXPORTS, IMPORTS HIT RECORD SINGLE-MONTH HIGHS IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports in May amounted to US$18.93 billion and US$18.21 billion, respectively, both representing the highest single-month levels on record, according to tallies released Wednesday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
This is the second consecutive month that the export value has hit a record high, MOF officials said.
They said the results show that Taiwan's foreign trade is expanding stably.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT DENIES BAIL FOR PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, detained since May 25 for his alleged role in insider trading, will not be released on bail, a spokesman for the Taipei District Court said Wednesday.

Spokesman Liu Shou-sung noted that Chao, an osteopath, had requested bail and to be allowed to communicate with others, but the judge rejected his request after reviewing the evidence against him and consulting with prosecutors over his role in trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) shares.
Chao said he wanted bail because his wife Chen Hsin-yu will give birth to their third child and his detention has also taken a toll on his mental and physical health.
The prosecutors also said that the case is still under investigation, adding that the flow of capital yet unclear and that more witnesses need to be summoned.
As the reasons for detaining Chao -- who it is feared would collude with other suspects and destroy evidence -- have not disappeared, the prosecutors noted, hence the need to keep him in detention.
While detaining Chao last month, the prosecutors said Chao played a key role in the trading of TDC shares that allegedly has generated huge profits for the Chao family.
Chao has denied any wrongdoing since his detention, claiming that the investment was done by his father, Chao Yu-chu, a retired school principal.

It has been found that Chang Hwa Commercial Bank (CHB) sold 12.45 million TDC shares it owned to three persons, including Chao Chien-ming's mother, Chien Shui-mien, July 25, 2005, four days after a dinner party attended by Chao Chien-ming and top CHB and TDC executives.

Chao allegedly obtained information that the financially troubled TDC would soon be granted a NT$16.5 billion syndicated loan by 29 financial institutions -- news that boosted the price of TDC stocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Court to Revisit Race in Schools. The Supreme Court agreed Monday to take up two cases that could mark a historic shift in the role of race in education and spell the end of official efforts to integrate the nation's public schools.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Republican Wins Calif. House Race
A former Republican congressman narrowly beat his Democratic rival early Wednesday to fill the House seat once held by jailed Randy ''Duke'' Cunningham, one of several contests in eight states closely watched as a possible early barometer of next fall's vote.
Wall Street Journal: Focus on Lower-Middle Class Helps Calderon Close Gap
The new middle-class residents in the urban sprawl outside Mexico City could prove to be the X-factor in next month's presidential election. Poll takers say the 15% of Mexico's voters who have yet to make up their minds -- some 11 million voters in all -- are massed among the lower-middle-class residents of the urban enclaves ringing Mexico City, Guadalajara, Monterrey and other large cities. These are the small businessmen, salesmen and housewives who have climbed a few rungs out of poverty in recent years -- but fear they will lose it all should Mexico stumble into crisis, as it has so often in the past.

The Washington Post: Terrorism Allegations Detailed In Canada; Parliament Among Group's Targets, Summary Indicates.
Suspects arrested last weekend in an alleged terrorism plot planned to storm the Canadian Parliament and hold politicians hostage, and at least one wanted to behead the prime minister if demands to withdraw Canada's troops from Afghanistan were not met, according to a summary of prosecutors' allegations read in court Tuesday.

The Japan Times China detente spells 74 billion yen in loans
Reflecting the recent detente between Japan and China, the government said Tuesday it will extend 74 billion yen to Beijing, lifting its freeze on low-interest yen loans for the fiscal year that ended March 31.

Moscow, June 7 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Millhouse Linked to Kommersant
Roman Abramovich appears to be on the verge of snapping up Kommersant, a deal that would put the daily newspaper, one of the last strongholds of independent media in Russia, in the hands of a perceived Kremlin loyalist. [ By ChangHung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN COUNTY POLICE VOW TO REINFORCE DRUNK DRIVING INTERCEPTION

TEXT.P: Hualien County's police bureau vowed to reinforce drunk driving interception because drunk driving caused the highest death rate in traffic accidents within the county from January to May this year, a spokesman for the county's police bureau said Wednesday.

According to tallies compiled by the traffic division of Hualien County police, 25 of the 44 reported traffic accidents during the first five months of this year in Hualien County were caused by drunk drivers -- 56 percent of the total number of accidents.
The spokesman said that checkpoints will reinforce the interception of drunk drivers in the county's Jian township, which is where drunk driving has caused the most number of deaths.

He urged people not to drink and drive, warning they will face fines of NT$10,000-NT$60,000 and have their driving licenses suspended for one year. Should they cause an accident, their driving licenses will be suspended for two years and if a drunk driver causes a death, his license will be revoked.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MIGHT RAM RECALL BID ONTO EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION AGENDA

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) passed unanimously Wednesday a resolution calling for the inclusion of a proposal pushing for a recall of President Chen Shui-bian on the agenda of a planned extraordinary session of the legislature.

All 59 KMT legislators present at a KMT legislative caucus meeting agreed that the proposal calling for Chen's recall should be put on the agenda and should be the first case discussed at the extraordinary legislative session. It has not yet been decided when or even if the extra session will be held.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, claimed that pushing for Chen's recall does not reflect the escalation of the opposition's contention with the Democratic Progressive Party administration.
To avoid Taiwan from being left in a "blank run" for another two years, the KMT must be instrumental in "allowing integrity to overcome corruption," according to Tseng.

Meanwhile, the KMT caucus was to send the signatures of 40 more KMT legislators to the Legislative Yuan department in charge of meetings later in the day, increasing the number of opposition "pan-blue alliance" legislators pushing for Chen's recall to 112, Tseng said.

Tseng claimed that after being in office for six years, Chen is presenting the people with a country where the leadership's integrity is in doubt, the first family abuses its power and the government continues refusing to open direct links with China, causing Taiwan's international competitiveness to continue to regress.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER, DPP CALL FOR OPPOSITION TO STOP POLITICAL FIGHTING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on main opposition Kuomintang Wednesday to stop political fighting immediately.

Su, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Ker Chien-ming, a DPP caucus whip in the legislature, made the plea at a news conference in an attempt to thwart a looming political storm before a meeting of the Central Standing Committee.

The KMT later passed a resolution in the meeting to set in motion the recall process for President Chen Shui-bian, whose leadership is in doubt in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations implicating his close aides and son-in-law.
The DPP trio asked Ma to "refrain from doing anything rash on the brink of the precipice" and lashed out at the KMT's promotion of the presidential recall and the toppling of the Cabinet.
As a former justice minister, Ma should not waver, not "undermine the rule of law" for the sake of his quest for power, they said.

According to Su, the "spirit of the rule of the law" is that the perpetrator will take responsibility. He noted that Ma said a few days ago that there is no direct evidence implicating Chen, even though his close aides are mired in corruption allegations.
"Despite his law training, he has changed because of his craving for power," Su claimed. Ma has a Ph.D in law from Harvard University.
Su noted that the political fighting has affected the stock market, sending share prices plunging despite sound economic fundamentals.

Su said he vowed to improve social order, but expressed worry about policing a public protest organized by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party to push for Chen's recall and toppling the Cabinet.

The Legislative Yuan should review government budgets in accordance with the Constitution, but major bills and key budgets were left idle when the last session ended in chaos May 30, Su added, blaming the opposition.
Yu said the convening of an extraordinary session should focus on the bills most related to the public, while the "pan-blue alliance" feels the recall or toppling the Cabinet is more important.
"Opposing President Chen should not do harm to Taiwan and the rule of law," Yu said.
Ker claimed the opposition's recall proposal is for the sake of winning the year-end mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, putting the nation's economy on the back burner.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA URGES DPP LAWMAKERS TO JOIN RECALL EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called on lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday to join his party's efforts to recall President Chen Shui-bian, saying "it is important to stand by the people at this historic juncture."

Ma made the remarks following a weekly meeting of the KMT's policy-making Central Standing Committee, in which the party decided to launch a motion to recall Chen in a planned extra legislative session in summer.
Ma urged DPP legislators to support the motion, which requires the endorsement of two-thirds of the legislature, so as to "give people the chance to have the final say" in a referendum.

"The KMT's bid to recall Chen is not aimed at private partisan gain or whipping up confrontation between pan-blue and pan-green camps," Ma claimed, calling on DPP lawmakers not to boycott the KMT's recall motion in the legislature.
"Only by doing so will people be allowed to make the final decision in a referendum, the way it should be in a democratic nation," he said.

Chen should resign to assume responsibility, if he still has a sense of duty and shame now that he has lost the people's respect and trust amid the numerous corruption allegations implicating his family members and aides, Ma argued.

The motion to recall Chen is by no means driven by political infighting and the public mustn't be misled into believing so, Ma said, stressing that Chen's stepping down to assume responsibility is "a must" that is in line with the core principles of a democratic society.
The KMT chairman also announced the kickstart of a national campaign to garner public support in calling for Chen's resignation.
Claiming that the KMT wants Chen to quit the presidency out of the nation's best interest, Ma warned there will be "no bright future for the country" should Chen remain in the post.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang told a news conference the same day at the Legislative Yuan that the party has decided to initiate a presidential recall motion in the legislature and to make it the priority in an extra session probably to begin June 13.
The presidential recall motion is the key reason the KMT has agreed to the extra legislative session, she pointed out.

KMT lawmaker Hung Hsiu-chu admitted it would not be easy to railroad the motion through the legislature, but insisted the pan-blue alliance must initiate the move "to leave a record in history" of Chen being Taiwan's first president to face a recall motion.

James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), said earlier the same day that he sincerely invited Ma to join his party's anti-corruption efforts to boot out Chen or topple the Cabinet, even if the PFP risks losing its seats in the Legislative Yuan when a new legislature is elected.
Soong said he supports the KMT's plan to hold a demonstration against Chen Saturday in Kaohsiung while the PFP will organize one in Taipei the same day -- the second time in as many weeks.

Recalling Chen is not just a task for the pan-blue alliance of the KMT and PFP; rather, it is a question of Taiwan's democratic values, Soong claimed, adding that the public must fully support prosecutors and judicial investigators who have been working on several cases.
Soong has vowed to take people to the streets until Chen has stepped down.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRCRAFT WITH TAIWAN FRUIT LOGO TO FLY TO JAPAN LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) aircraft will be sporting an image of Taiwan-made fruit on their fuselage to help promote the island's agricultural industry when they begin flying to Japan in late June, a CAL official said Wednesday.
It was the second time the Council of Agriculture (COA) has advertised in cooperation with the nation's leading air carrier to promote Taiwan's agricultural products.
Last year, several CAL aircraft carried the image of the butterfly orchid -- one of Taiwan's other key agricultural exports -- on its flights to Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and the Middle East.
After such a strategy, butterfly orchid exports doubled last year over the previous year, reaching US$8.2 million.
The COA expressed hope the new logo would increase the visibility of the nation's high-quality agricultural products around the world.
COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan said Taiwan-grown fruit is "tremendously delicious" and exports should reach out to the world amid an era of globalization and economic liberalization.
At the moment when agricultural products of other countries are flooding into Taiwan, Su expressed hope the new logos will significantly elevate the popularity of Taiwan-grown fruit around the world.

CAL Chairman Wei Hsing-hsiung noted their newly purchased A330-300 airplanes will carry images of nine of Taiwan's most popular fruits, such as pineapples, bell fruit, papayas, oranges, bananas and mangoes.
The planes are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan June 21, with the first group flying CAL's new Taipei-Osaka route, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY HELPERS TO BE SUBJECT TO LABOR STANDARDS LAW PROTECTION: CLA

TEXT.P: Officials of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday that they are considering including family helpers under the Labor Standards Law to further protect their interests.

The CLA officials made the remarks after the annual Trafficking in Persons Report released recently by the U.S. State Department downgraded Taiwan's labor situation to the "tier 2 watch list" along with underdeveloped or least developed countries.
In response to questions from reporters, U.S. State Department officials said Taiwan's labor situation being downgraded was due to too much forced labor meted out to foreign caregivers.

CLA officials said the agency has been working on including family helpers under the Labor Standards Law, but claimed that as the agency still has to work on many other details concerning the issue, such as fixing reasonable labor conditions for foreign caregivers, the CLA will hold several surveys among foreign caregivers and consult with experts to draw final conclusions.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP RESOLVES TO COUNTER KMT MOVE TO RECALL PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) decision to launch a nationwide campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian has angered the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, whose Central Executive Committee members threatened Wednesday to counter the move yet failed to reach a consensus on how best to achieve it.

Some DPP leaders at the Central Executive Committee meeting urged party members to air their views on TV to "rectify" the KMT reasons on why the president should be recalled, while others even proposed mobilizing street demonstrations to "check and balance" the opposition campaign.

But some feared the street-protest proposal might prod further confrontation between the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) supporters, as well as those of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party (PFP).
The meeting did not reach a consensus on how to counter the KMT campaign beyond forming an "ad hoc contingency" group to monitor the pan-blue alliance's next move.

Before the meeting, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Premier Su Tseng-chang and DPP legislative caucus convener Ko Chien-ming held a press conference urging KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to "stop political dogfighting."

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENPEACE MEMBERS PROTEST AT COMPUTEX TAIPEI SHOW

TEXT.P: Following on the heels of a protest at the CeBIT computer exhibition in Germany in March, a group of Greenpeace International members protested Wednesday against COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006 outside Taipei Exhibition Hall, claiming IT products contain toxic materials.

COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2006, the largest computer trade show in Asia and second largest in the world, opened Tuesday for a five-day run with more than 1300 domestic and international companies showing their latest products, attracting at least 30,000 foreign buyers.

Nine members of the international environmental group Greenpeace held a banner reading "No Toxic in High-tech" and showed pictures of electronic waste dumps in China, India, the Philippines and Niger, expressing anger at the use of toxic materials in IT products.

Chen Yu-hui, head of the Greenpeace group, noted the amount of electronic waste produced annually in the world is between 20 million and 50 million tons, or equal to the urban waste produced by Taiwan in two to six years.
He pointed out that because electronic products contain heavy metals and toxic compounds, their mass production -- and even the process of recycling -- creates enormous pollution problems.
These toxic materials not only influence blood circulation, the nervous system, and hormonal secretion of human beings, but also cause serious pollution to the environment, Chen said.

He said Greenpeace forced computer giant HP in 2003 to stop using toxic materials in computer manufacturing, and since then it has demanded Samsung, Sony, Nokia and Acer to follow suit. Acer committed to doing so eventually; it will publish a time schedule for achieving this goal in the third quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt arrived in Taipei Wednesday for his first visit since assuming the post in February this year as the top U.S. liaison official with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
Burghardt, a retired career diplomat, is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian Thursday.

The AIT Taipei Office, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan, said in a news release that Burghardt will inspect AIT operations and meet with a wide variety of personnel in various sectors of Taiwan's society during the several days of his stay.
According to AIT's press release, Burghardt will also meet with members of the Taiwanese and American business communities during his visit.

Burghardt's visit has drawn attention as it comes at a time when President Chen Shui-bian faces mounting pressure to resign in the wake of a string of corruption scandals implicating his former close aides and son-in-law.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said earlier in the day that Burghardt was expected to visit him to exchange views on various issues.
Huang said Burghardt's itinerary has been arranged according to protocol by the AIT's Taipei Office.

Burghardt, who served as AIT Taipei Office head from 1999 to 2001, is well-versed in Taiwan-related affairs. After finishing his Taipei stint, President Chen decorated him with a civic award in appreciation of his contribution toward promoting Taiwan-U.S. relations.

His past diplomatic assignments include ambassador to Vietnam, consul-general in Shanghai and deputy chief of mission in Seoul and Manila. He now concurrently serves as director of East-West Seminars at the East-West Center in Honolulu, Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENOWNED WRITER CHI CHUN DIES AT 90

TEXT.P: Chi Chun, a renowned writer who has published more than 40 works of lyrical prose, essays and fiction, died from pneumonia at a Taipei hospital Wednesday at the age of 90.

Chi Chun, born Pan Hsi-chen, was widely admired for her insightful analysis of human relationships and compassion for human weakness in her writing. Some of her best-known works include "Mother's Golden Wristwatch," "Teardrops and Pearls" and "Oranges are Mature."

In addition to being an established writer, Chi Chun taught Chinese literature at several local universities, including National Central University and Chinese Culture University. She was last seen in public at a ceremony honoring outstanding Chinese writers in Asia early this year.

Chi Chun was hospitalized May 13 at Koo's Foundation Hospital in suburban Taipei for pneumonia resulting from a cold. Her condition had worsened since May 20, hospital sources said. A funeral is scheduled for June 19 for her friends and fans to pay their last respects for her.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 8, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army when his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 U.S. troops from Vietnam.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the U.S. National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The ROC-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first Chinese-American astronaut.
1987: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Mainland China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
2000: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung carry out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation, giving Wu Feng-ying, 50, a section of liver donated by her son, Lin Yun-ju, 24.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: Such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard." "But men who live in retirement in order to study their aims and who practice righteousness in order to carry out their principles: The expression of such principles I have heard, but I have not seen such men."

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER REAFFIRMS CONTINUITY OF DIPLOMATIC POLICY

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang directed the nation's overseas mission chiefs Thursday to assure their host countries that the continuity of Taiwan's foreign policy will be maintained despite the country's recent volatile domestic political situation.

Huang gave the instruction as President Chen Shui-bian faces mounting pressure from opposition parties to step down over a string of debilitating corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and former aides.
Reaffirming the continuity of Taiwan's foreign policy, Huang said the nation's diplomatic operations will not be affected by any domestic political upheaval.
Despite the current political turmoil, Huang said Taiwan's resolve to fulfill its international obligations and promises under multilateral or unilateral frameworks remains intact.
He asked all embassies and representative offices abroad to continue their work in a "business as usual" manner.

If various sectors of their countries of residence inquire about Taiwan's political situation, Huang said staff of all diplomatic missions should give them detailed explanations in accordance with these principles.
He also directed diplomatic mission chiefs to be on guard against possible Chinese attempts to sway Taiwan's diplomatic allies into switching their diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER DENIES FORMING ALLIANCE WITH VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday the media have been "excessively imaginative" by reporting that he was forming an "informal alliance" with Vice President Annette Lu in the wake of an opposition alliance's campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

In response to media questions concerning a China Times report that Lu was preparing for a post-Chen Shui-bian era by trying to form an informal alliance with Wang, the speaker said that Lu had called him to discuss inviting political leaders for a "blue oceans" coffee and that they did not talk about recalling the president or toppling the Cabinet in the legislature.

Asked if the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has agreed to see Lu take over the presidency if Chen is unseated, Wang said that "this is not an issue of whether the KMT agrees or not. Rather, this is an issue that is clearly defined in the Constitution," he said.

Pan Wei-kang, secretary-general of the KMT legislative caucus, also dismissed the report as a product of "excessive imagination." She claimed that Wang is a loyal member of the KMT who will do everything for the benefit of the country and who has the wisdom to decide what is good for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MILITARY AIRCRAFT DELIVER RELIEF GOODS TO INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan military aircraft have flown 10 sorties over the past week to deliver relief goods to Indonesia to help with post-earthquake rehabilitation work, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Thursday.
The relief goods included tents, drinking water, foodstuffs and medical supplies, the officials said.
Taiwan sent a first-aid team to assist in search and rescue missions immediately after a magnitude 6.3 earthquake rattled the central Indonesian island of Java May 27.

Medical personnel organized by Taiwan's International Health Action (Taiwan IHA) -- an ad hoc inter-agency body aimed at pooling resources in the public and private sectors for international health and humanitarian aid projects -- have also traveled to Bantul, ground zero of the devastating earthquake, to help injured quake victims.

More than 6,000 people were killed in the powerful temblor and tens of thousands of others were left homeless. Many Taiwanese charities, including the World Vision Taiwan, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Dharma Drum Mountain Cultural and Education Foundation, have also joined the relief effort.
