DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO SUPPORT NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE IF WANG DESIGNATED NEXT PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will throw its support behind an opposition plan to initiate a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet if Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is designated as the next premier, a party official said Thursday.

According to TSU Secretary-General Lo Chih-ming, while the TSU was against such a plan, it has changed its mind after a recent meeting between TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang and former President Lee Teng-hui, who is the party's spiritual leader.

In light of the fact that the struggle between the ruling and opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan has stalled a number of legislative and budget bills, Su thinks that it will be unhelpful to the country's development if the situation continues, Lo said.
Lee believes that the majority party in the legislature should form the Cabinet and that Wang is the best candidate to be the next premier, Lo said.
Lee thinks that the appointment of Wang as premier will represent the majority opinion of the legislature and harmonize relations between the administrative and legislative branches, Lo said.
Lee is planning to meet with Wang to discuss the possibility of his idea, Lo said.
Also, Lo said, the TSU's legislative caucus will meet before Monday to make a final decision on the issue.

In addition to a plan to push through a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian during a special legislative session expected later this month, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party is also considering initiating a no-confidence vote against Premier Su Tseng-chang after the legislature reopens in September.

The "pan-blue alliance" claims that the president has lost the people's trust and should be stripped of office following a string of corruption scandals implicating his close aides and the first family.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, CHINESE SCHOLARS TO ATTEND TIBETAN STUDIES SYMPOSIUM

TEXT.P: The first Conference on Tibetan Studies, organized by Tamkang University's Center for Tibetan Studies, is set to take place June 9-10 at the university, with scholars from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait scheduled to present 17 academic papers during the two days' of discussions.

The symposium is being held in response to the expectations of Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, said Wu Kuan, director of Tamkang University's Center for Tibetan Studies, adding that she hopes more and more Taiwanese people will pursue advanced studies on Tibet.

Being different from previous discussions focusing on religion, this symposium will include 17 subjects concerning Tibet's music, religion, politics, social development and literature, Wu said, adding that several famous specialists will serve as panel discussion leaders.

During the symposium, four scholars from China will present three papers related to the Tibetan language, society and religion, while papers to be presented by Taiwanese professors will cover aspects of Tibetan literature, politics, society, law and language, according to Wu.
In addition to the panel discussions, a Buddhist cultural artifacts exhibition, including more than ten Buddhist statues and Tibetan books, will be held Friday morning,

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BELIEVES DARK CLOUD WILL PASS, BRIGHT DAY WILL COME

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, facing an opposition campaign to recall him, lambasted the opposition Thursday for waging a "Cultural Revolution"-style purge of him and his family and expressed optimism that the "overcast skies will eventually clear up."

He said that while he has been tolerating all sorts of embarrassment, jeers and insults, his optimism is based on his "confidence in Taiwan, in democracy, in the judicial system, and most importantly, in the people."

Responding for the first time to the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" decision to kick off a nation-wide campaign both in society and in the legislature to unseat him, Chen charged that this is a "naked attempt to use political force to interfere in the justice system and even to persecute the system."
He made his remarks in a "journal of mood" that he published in his electronic newspaper that is easily accessible on the Presidential Office Web site.

The president stressed that justice and fairness must not be a tool of the strong with which political parties simply use their numerical majority in the legislature to implicate people and to overthrow a government duly elected by the people.

"Otherwise, it will lead to a replay of the public trial of China's Cultural Revolution, which would be the greatest insult and humiliation of Taiwan's democracy and rule of law," Chen wrote in his "mood journal."

He accused "some persons" of twisting the meaning of "judicial justice" to become "brutal treatment" of the wife and children and even "all relatives" of a suspected criminal. He was referring to his son-in-law Chao Chien-ming, who has been detained on suspicions of insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) shares, a scandal that is still evolving daily.
The president said he is worried that things are developing in an "abnormal" way in which some people are using the scandal as "a basis of hatred" in an attempt "to kill" and to "take revenge."
In the face of the recent "turmoil, " Chen said he has been in pain and has felt guilty and apologetic, but most of all, has felt a deep sorrow.
"I am a man, an ordinary man, who makes mistakes but who corrects himself when a mistake is made, " he said, without elaborating on what kinds of mistake he has made.

However, he deplored that if after implementing his grand project of "building the nation with human rights, " he could only face a country in which all moral standards and codes of conduct and all of the basic ideas about democracy and the rule of law can be ignored so that the media can be manipulated and all sorts of smearing campaigns can be used to assassinate a person's character, value and dignity, just for the sake of scoring political points and achieving individual ambition, "then I must suspect that this is indeed an extremely serious matter."

The president said he has always believed in the principle that all men and women are equal in front of the law and that whoever has committed a crime must be sanctioned by the law, and not even he as president can defend a wrong-doing or cover up a crime or interfere in the judicial proceedings on meting out justice.
"I will not allow myself to do that. Nor will the media and public opinion allow a criminal act to go unpunished," Chen said.

He said the separation of justice and politics is "the most important indicator" of a democratic country. "We must not allow the erroneous criminal act of the previous authoritarian regime, in which justice served politics or was used as a pretext to purge political opponents, to continue to exist. And we must totally oppose the mean and heinous behavior of some political figures who are trying to take advantage of an on-going criminal case under judicial investigation as a tool of political struggle to realize their ambition of seizing power," he added.

The president said some people are claiming that only by recalling the president or toppling the Cabinet can the judicial authorities be provided with "a momentum" to boldly crack down on irregularities. "This is simply the most naked attempt to use political force to interfere with and even to persecute the judicial system," he claimed.

Over the past six years, he pointed out, some individuals and civic groups that have been hostile to him have used all sorts of smearing and attacking strategies to spread rumors among the people and to create social turmoil, expecting that they will regain power at an early date.

He said personally, he has no problem standing the jeers, ridicules and verbal insults, and out of his confidence in the people of Taiwan, he said he believes that the current dark cloud will pass and a bright day will eventually come.

DOC.HEADLINE: KING OF SWAZILAND TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: King Mswati III of Swaziland will visit Taiwan June 15 to promote economic and cultural exchanges between the two countries, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Thursday.

The king, leading an economic and trade delegation, will host an investment briefing during the trip to introduce Taiwan businesses to the investment environment and the preferential measures offered by his country, according to Lee Chen-hsiung, director-general of the ministry's Department of African Affairs.

Meanwhile, the embassies of African nations in Taiwan will hold a cocktail reception June 16 in Taipei to celebrate Africa Day, with President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu having been invited to attend the event, Lee said.
Africa Day is designed to commemorate the establishment in 1963 of the Organization of African Unity, which became the African Union in 2002, Lee noted.
The heads of state of 53 African Union member nations are scheduled to hold a summit in Gambia July 1-2, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORUM HELD IN TAIPEI ON PHOTOVOLTAIC TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The state-funded Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) held a forum on "Taiwan's Future in Photovoltaic Technology" Thursday, aiming to find a win-win solution for better development in the photovoltaic industry.

An ITRI spokesman said that during the year 2005, worldwide demand for photovoltaic-related products increased dramatically, therefore the ITRI wishes to shape an all-round strategy for local manufacturers by pooling resources in the public and private sector to increase Taiwan's global market share.
He added that due to sky-rocketing oil prices, the need for clean and renewable solar energy will only become stronger in the coming years.

Topics discussed at the forum included: "The Keys in Developing the Photovoltaic Industry," "Photovoltaics and its Applications," "Possible Niches for Local Makers," and "Trends and Core Technologies in Photovoltaic Products."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 280.93 points to close at 6,331.81.
The bourse opened at 6,562.1 and fluctuated between 6,564.1 and 6,331.81 during trading. A total of 3.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.25 billion (US$ 3.7 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 6.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 5.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 5.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 5.1 percent, textile stocks at 4.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 790 to 29, with 28 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE TO PRESIDENTIAL POWER AFTER DELEGATING: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his constitutional power has not been changed a bit even though he has announced a decision to "delegate power" to party and Cabinet leaders.
Chen made the remarks while receiving American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt at the Presidential Office.

In his first public explanation of what he meant in declaring his decision to "delegate power, " Chen said he was just meaning to "make some changes to the technical issues relating to the coordination of administrative and ruling party operations."
Chen said that in the past, when a personnel dispute or policy difference arose, the president's mediation was often required.

"But from now on, leaders in the party and the government must settle their differences and take the responsibility. This will not at all affect the president's rights and duties as stated in the Constitution," Chen said.
The president is responsible for the country's foreign and defense policy as well as cross-Taiwan Strait relations, according to the Constitution of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS REMIT US$77 MILLION NET OUTWARD IN MAY

TEXT.P: Foreign investors remitted a net amount of US$77 million in equity funds out of Taiwan in May, ending a six-month record of net inflows of remittances since November 2005, according to tallies released Thursday by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
Taiwan stocks lost 324.82 points in May, with net selling by foreign investors amounting to NT$30.11 billion.

From the start of this year until June 2, foreign investors bought listed shares worth NT$2.15 trillion and sold listed shares worth NT$1.91 trillion in Taiwan, with net buying valued at NT$241.9 billion, FSC officials said.

During the same period, foreign investors purchased over-the-counter shares worth NT$108.2 billion and sold over-the-counter shares worth NT$103.8 billion, with net buying registering NT$4.4 billion, the officials said.

Since the government began allowing foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market in December 1990, foreign institutional investors, foreign individuals and overseas Chinese had remitted a net amount of US$121.57 billion into Taiwan as of June 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN CONSIDERING RECOGNIZING TAIWAN'S INT'L DRIVER'S LICENSES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan are discussing details concerning Japan's plans to recognize Taiwan's international driver's license, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman said Thursday.

Michel Lu made the remarks after news reports saying that the Japanese government is studying methods to recognize international driver's licenses of Taiwanese tourists, one of the main sources of foreign tourists to Japan. Lu added that he hopes there will be concrete progress soon.

Speaking a regular press conference, Lu noted that although Taiwan is not a member country of the U.N. Convention on Road Traffic, many countries have recognized Taiwan's international driver's license, such as France, the Netherlands and Switzerland, as it is a practical consideration that has nothing to do with politics.

According to Lu, Taiwan and Japan have maintained frequent civil exchanges for a long period of time, with Japanese tourists making more than one million visits to Taiwan in 2005 and more than 1.2 million Taiwanese tourists visiting Japan the same year.
In addition to soliciting Japan's recognition of international driver's licenses of Taiwanese tourists, Taiwan hopes that Japan can also recognize Taiwan's drivers licenses, Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June dropped 360 points to close at 6,216, with 74,759 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July moved down 352 points to finish at 6,170, with 1,971 contracts traded, while September futures lost 369 points to close at 6,051, with 283 contract transactions.
December futures dropped 369 points to close at 6,052, with 284 contracts traded, while March futures lost 319 points to finish at 6,100, with 28 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,576 for June, 6,522 for July, 6,420 for September, 6,421 for December and 6,419 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 18.3 points to close at 260, with 9,185 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 18.2 points to finish at 258.1, with 142 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 19.3 points to close at 258.2, with 13 contracts traded, while December TE futures dropped 17.75 points to finish at 256.85, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.
June TF futures moved down 40 points to finish at 907, with 5,050 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures lost 52.2 points to close at 890, with 84 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 54.2 points to finish at 881.2, with 31 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 42.6 points to finish at 890.2, with four contracts traded.
March TF futures moved down 40 points to close at 893.4, with only one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL RECALL MOTION IS 'LAST RESORT': PFP

TEXT.P: Recalling President Chen Shui-bian is the last resort to prevent Taiwan from floundering, and the people should bravely support the cause at this critical time, opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmakers said Thursday.

PFP lawmakers made the remarks at a news conference refuting comments made by Chen in his latest electronic newsletter published by the Presidential Office earlier the same day, claiming that he is worried Taiwan's judicial system has been "twisted to serve political ends."

This is the first time Chen has responded to a plan announced early this week by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP to recall Chen at a time when Chen's spouse, son-in-law and close aids have been accused of involvement in several high-profile corruption scandals.

Claiming that "Chen must not make comments like this as head of state in a country ruled by law and order, " PFP legislative caucus whip Lee Hung-chun suspected Chen's motives for airing such rhetoric as being directed at prosecutors and investigators working on the various cases.

Lee blamed Chen's "feudal mindset" in making comments questioning the standing of prosecutors and investigators and asked the public to back pan-blue efforts to recall Chen, arguing that Chen lacks the ability to conduct self-examination and has no sense of duty to step down in response to public demand.
PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung opined that Chen's electronic newsletter revealed his intention to fight back at a time when public anger is mounting due to the series of scandals.
"People's power will be the key to deciding Taiwan's future path toward a degradation or further democratization," he said.
The KMT and the PFP have promised to join forces to launch a presidential recall motion or a motion to topple the Cabinet, so as to keep pressure on Chen and push him to resign.
The KMT is planning a large protest against Chen in Kaohsiung Saturday, while the PFP will organize a second rally in Taipei the same day to ask Chen to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO SET EXTRA SESSION'S AGENDA NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: After failing to decide on a date for an extra legislative session, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng on Thursday called for another round of inter-party negotiations June 12 to set the special session's date and agenda.

As the Taiwan Sustainable Economic Development Conference is to be held in July, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DDP) proposed postponing the session's date until August, but opposition Kuomintang party (KMT) opposed the proposal.
KMT accused the DDP of being "the party that proposed calling for an extra session but is now reneging on its word."
Wang has cancelled a parliamentary exchange trip to several Central American countries at the end of June owing to the extra session.
Besides lawmakers' differences on the date for holding the extra session, all parties also held their own ideas for topics to be discussed.
Wang said if political parties cannot reach a consensus on the date by June 12, he will call for a vote on the session's date and agenda. (B Timothy J. Hwang)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.293 to close at NT$32.513.
A total of US$2.012 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.270 and hit a high of NT$32.580.

DOC.HEADLINE: SKYPE CONSIDERS SETTING UP PRODUCT CERTIFICATION CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Skype, which has pioneered a revolution in global Internet communications, is considering establishing a product certification center in Taiwan to meet increasing market demand, senior officials of the Luxembourg-based company said in Taipei Thursday.

Speaking at the Computex Forum held at the Taipei World Trade Center, Skype Vice Chairman and co-founder Geoffrey Prentice said many Taiwan companies have made inquiries and sent their products to be certified at Skype's R&D and product certification center -- located in Tallinn, Estonia.
Prentice said in 2005, Skype received applications for 350 kinds of products from around the world requesting certification. Only half passed testing and received Skype certification.

Of about 60 companies that gained cooperative contracts with Skype through certified products last year, half were Taiwanese companies -- mostly makers of wireless electronic products -- prompting Skype to consider setting up a certification center in the country to meet the demand, Prentice said.

Today, more than 200 products in 33 categories have passed testing and are Skype-certified. These products include Bluetooth earphones, earphone mikes and webcams, said Manrique Brenes, a senior engineer with Skype's R&D center in Estonia who also spoke at the forum.
Skype, which was recently acquired by eBay Inc., is now the world's leader in Internet voice communications, offering people new ways to communicate in a global online era.

Since its launch in August 2003, Skype has been downloaded more than 163 million times in 225 countries and territories. Fifty-four million people are registered to use Skype's free services, with over 3 million simultaneous users on the network at any given time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: SC declares '1017' ruling final
The Supreme Court (SC) headed by Chief Justice Artemio V. Panganiban has declared final its May 3 decision that nullified as unconstitutional certain provisions of President Arroyo's Proclamation No. 1017 placing the entire country under a state of national emergency from Feb. 4 to March 3.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: PSG linked to torture of 5 Estrada supporters
TWO POLICE officers who took part in the warrantless arrest of five supporters of ousted President Joseph Estrada were identified at the Senate yesterday, but their companions from the Intelligence Service of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (ISAFP) remained unnamed.
The Philippine Star: Weekly oil price hikes feared
Weekly oil price hikes are expected to continue until July as oil firms try to recoup losses incurred due to the continued rise of world crude prices, a ranking industry official said yesterday.
The Manila Times: 1.6 million move up from poverty
Extreme poverty levels in the Philippines have declined slightly to about 30 percent of the population, with minority Muslims improving their lot significantly, the government said Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 50% OF TAIWANESE AGAINST RECALLING THE PRESIDENT: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: Fifty-three percent of people do not think President Chen Shui-bian should be recalled over a spate of recent corruption allegations, compared to 34.5 percent who are in favor of such a move, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Also, 66.2 percent of respondents oppose the idea of initiating a no-confidence vote against Premier Su Tseng-chang, while 17.1 percent are in favor of such a measure, the survey shows.
The survey was conducted by a private polling company for the DPP from June 5-6 on 1,091 people. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

Among DPP supporters, only 3.2 percent are in favor of recalling Chen, with as high as 93.6 percent opposing the proposal. Similarly, 93.1 percent of Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) supporters object to the plan.
Among supporters of the opposition People First Party (PFP), 73.4 percent think the president should be ousted from office, compared to 26.6 percent who do not agree.
Among opposition Kuomintang (KMT) supporters, 57.3 percent are for recalling the president, while 36.6 percent oppose the plan.

In the event a no-confidence vote passes against the premier, 47.4 percent of respondents think the Legislative Yuan should be dissolved, while 37 percent think the majority party in the legislature should form the next Cabinet.
By political affiliation, 65.1 percent of KMT supporters are against the plan to initiate a no-confidence vote, with only 25.9 percent backing the idea.
Meanwhile, 53.2 percent of PFP supporters are in favor of a no-confidence vote, compared to 40.8 percent who are against the move.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP is planning to push through a motion to recall Chen during a special legislative session expected later this month, and is also considering initiating a no-confidence vote against Su after the legislature reconvenes in September.
The opposition claims the president has lost the public's trust and should be forced to step down following a spate of corruption scandals implicating the first family and Chen's top aides.

Expressing disapproval over the opposition's plans, DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun said Thursday that the move to recall the president was "unjustifiable" because the insider trading allegations involving the president's son-in-law have nothing to do with the president himself.
The DPP legislator accused the KMT and PFP of attempting to usurp power by making the move, which he said would only lead to social and political instability.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORRUPTION SCANDALS A REFLECTION OF PRESIDENTIAL POWER: KMT

TEXT.P: Suspects in a recent spate of corruption scandals have profited from their proximity to presidential power, and President Chen Shui-bian has angered the public by not having conducted any self-examination, the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday.

As the public is increasingly frustrated by the president's failure to see the cause and effect of a recent chain of scandals and his plunging popularity, the caucus said it was the right time for the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party to kick off a nationwide campaign to recall the president.

In Chen's weekly online newsletter published by the Presidential Office, the president accused the opposition of launching the recall drive in a "naked attempt to use political force to interfere with the judicial system." Chen also suspected opposition leaders of using the campaign to "take back the power" they lost in 2000.

Pan Wei-kang, KMT caucus secretary-general, said the president's family members or top aides have been suspected of involvement or detained in a string of scandals related to a land lease of Taiwan Fertilizer Corp., Pacific Sogo Department Store vouchers, political donations by former Tuntex Group chairman Chen You-hao and insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. stocks.

The opposition is calling for public support nationwide for a presidential recall "to unseat a corrupt regime, not to provoke a confrontation" between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green camp," she said.

She added the president was merely trying to divert the public's attention when he accused the opposition of trying to "seize power" or waging a "Cultural Revolution"-style purging of himself and the first family.

Tsai Chin-lung, a deputy secretary-general of the caucus, said recalling a president is the constitutional right of the people, who alone decide whether a president should be recalled rather than any political party.
Tsai prayed the president would stand with the people to "protect Taiwan with a government of integrity" rather than shift the blame for corruption onto the opposition.
Lei Chien, another caucus deputy secretary-general, said the president's "mood journal" shows he was "trying hard to save his own skin" and that of his family members.

Lei said the exposed scandals show that a group of people taking advantage of their close proximity to executive power have formed a "non-institutional criminal structure" that has been plundering public resources.

She said that as more and more people are appalled by the greed and insatiable appetite of "a criminal gang operating outside the establishment and profiting from presidential power, " the opposition's recall campaign to end corruption is fully legitimate.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Gay Marriage Amendment Fails in Senate;
A constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage, backed by President Bush and conservative groups, was soundly defeated in the Senate yesterday after proponents failed to persuade a bare majority of all senators to support the measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL RECALL PLAN AIMED AT SEIZING POWER: DPP

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blasted the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Thursday for attempting to seize power by launching a recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian.

DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun made the remarks while fielding reporters' questions after a Presidential Office online newsletter published an article on President Chen's view on the opposition move earlier the same day, saying that the opposition's recall plan is "purely a power struggle" by attempting to hold Chen accountable for wrongdoing that is unrelated to him.

As no solid evidence exists to indicate that the president has been involved in various corruption scandals allegedly implicating his spouse, son-in-law and close aides, pan-blue recall efforts are actually intended to take power back, Chen Chin-jun argued.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan later the same day, Chen Chin-jun said that the pan-blue alliance must not list the presidential recall motion as the top priority on the agenda for a proposed extra legislative session, thereby turning the meeting into political struggle.

Chen Chin-jun claimed that President Chen has nothing to do with the wrongdoing committed by his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming -- who has been held in detention since late last month for his suspected role in an insider trading -- and insisted that lawmakers should instead redress several key budgetary bills regarding a flood-control project and the operation of various government agencies and state-run enterprises.

Chen Chin-jun urged the pan-blue alliance to separate politics from judicial matters, saying that efforts by KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong to remove Chen based on "groundless accusations" are part of a scheme to conceal their ulterior motives, and something that would only create social chaos.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS IN TAINAN EXTENDS SUPPORT TO EMBATTLED PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Ten members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) caucus in the Tainan County Council announced Thursday they will offer their utmost support to beleaguered President Chen Shui-bian.
They said they will invite the Tainan City Council caucus to issue a joint statement to urge President Chen to "stick to his guns" for the sake of the public's welfare and political stability.
President Chen is facing mounting pressure by the opposition to step down in the wake of a string of corruption scandals allegedly involving senior aides and his son-in-law Chao Chien-ming.

Chen Chao-lai, DPP caucus whip in the county council, said that if Chao -- who is currently under detention for his alleged role in an insider trading case -- is found to be involved in criminal dealings, he should be dealt with according to law, which he said is "the norm in a democratic society."

But there is no evidence to indicate that the president is involved in any shady practices, Chen Chao-lai said. The opposition's attempt to recall the president while the government is functioning normally is only aimed at disrupting the country's political stability, he added.

Chen Chao-lai said his office has been inundated with calls over the past several days protesting what they called the media's "siding with the opposition" in a bid to force the first family into a corner.
He said his caucus has asked the DPP to mobilize its supporters to counter forces against President Chen and to throw support behind the president, who is from Kuantien, Tainan county.
Meanwhile, Tainan City Councilor Wang Ding-yu invited 10,000 people to sign up before June 16 to express support for the president.
Wang made the remarks as several hundred DPP supporters gathered in front of his office, shouting slogans to cheer President Chen and condemn main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
The supporters said there is no evidence to implicate the president in any corruption allegations, and that Ma's recall motion was an "obvious attempt to humiliate President Chen."

DOC.HEADLINE: RESOLUTION TO REMOVE PRESIDENT CHEN'S PHOTO 'INVALID'

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Council's resolution to remove a picture of President Chen Shui-bian from its conference hall will be "invalidated, " Vice Interior Minister Yen Wan-chin said Thursday.

Yen made the remarks one day after the opposition-dominated Taipei City Council voted 27-0 on a resolution to remove President Chen's photo, claiming his leadership was in doubt in the wake of a series of corruption allegations implicating his close aides and son-in-law.

He said that to express respect for Taiwan's head of state, the ministry has mapped out regulations requiring government agencies, public schools and other assembly halls to display the president's pictures.
If city councils violate the regulations, the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of the Interior will require them to reverse their decision.
If local councils ask public functionaries to remove the picture of the head of state, the public functionaries will be in violation of the law, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUITABLE FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY: GERMAN ENVIRONMENTALIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan has a better environment than Europe for developing renewable energies, given its unlimited solar and wind resources, a German environmentalist said in Taipei Thursday.

In a speech delivered at the Taipei-based China Electric Manufacturing Corp., Franz Alt, a TV journalist and author who is also an environmentalist, said the energy question has become the key question of modern developed and developing countries. Environmental disasters are becoming ever more common, and 70 percent of all environmental problems are energy problems, he claimed.
The European Union authorities have estimated that all traditional energies, including fossil energy, will be in short supply globally by 2050, Alt said.

There is no future for the culture of mankind without ecology. And that means there is no future for the culture of mankind without renewable energy, Alt said, adding that environmental policy means peace policy in a double sense: Peace with nature and peace among peoples and societies.
Alt said the change to solar energy can and must take place within the next 50 years. "Only then have we an escape route from the greenhouse effect," he claimed.
The only path for Europe to a clean energy economy is to cut the consumption of crude oil by about 60 percent while developing and using renewable energy, he claimed.

Alt said not only Europe should strive to develop renewable energies, but so should Asian countries like China, Taiwan and India, where the peoples' desire for quality life like that enjoyed in industrially advanced countries is unavoidably demanding greater consumption of energy.

Alt recalled that during a visit with President Chen Shui-bian in Taipei in 2001, he told the president that Europe is expected to transform its economy to a renewable energy economy, using mainly solar energy, by 2050. Chen responded by saying that Taiwan can accomplish such transformation in 2030, thanks to the island's rich resources of hotsprings and geothermal heat.
Alt said he agreed with Chen's assertion, given Taiwan's rich resources of sunlight and wind power, which he claimed are much richer than those available in Europe.
The German environmentalist, however, said that Taiwan has lots to catch up in this regard, since an essential and much-talked-about renewable energy law has yet to be legislated.
Alt claimed that the amount of fossil energy that humans consume in one day took "500,000 days to nurture."
In addition, he said, the Sun provides the Earth with energy that is 15,000 times the daily energy required by the entire global population.

In Germany, he pointed out, nearly 1 million households are powered by solar energy, while some 700 churches use electricity generated by solar energy. Generating electricity with wind power, Germany has cut CO2 production by 18 million tons.
Renewable energy has also created over 1 million jobs across Germany, according to Alt.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAID CONFIDENT POLITICAL TURMOIL WILL NOT LAST LONG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said to the top U.S. liaison official with Taiwan Thursday that the political turmoil "will not last long, " Presidential Office sources said Thursday.

The sources said Chen displayed his confidence when Raymond F. Burghardt, new chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, expressed concern about Taiwan's political situation and economic performance during a meeting at the Presidential Office. Burghardt arrived a day earlier for his first visit to Taiwan since assuming his post in February.
Chen is in deep trouble as he faces mounting pressure from the opposition to oust him after a spate of corruption allegations implicating his close aides and son-in-law.

Addressing Burghardt's concerns, Chen said that whether the opposition puts forward a motion for a recall or a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet, it will have to follow Constitutional procedures and legal regulations, the sources said.

The president cited the example of the shooting of himself and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the March 20, 2004 presidential election, which the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party claims was staged to unfairly sway the outcome of the bitterly contested election. After Chen won by a razor-thin margin, the opposition filed two separate lawsuits, both of which failed.

Whether it is opposition's call for an independent investigation commission to probe the shooting or election-related lawsuits, they followed legal procedure and the judicial authorities ruled accordingly, Chen said.
He said he will respect the judicial authorities on this latest spate of controversy and claimed that the "current upheaval won't last long."

Burghardt later had lunch with Chen. Also present were Tan Sun Chen, the president's chief of staff, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, National Defense Minister Lee Jye, Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang, Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen M. Young and his deputy, David J. Keegan.
The AIT represents the U.S. interests in the absence of formal ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA ANNOUNCES TAIWAN'S LARGEST SEIZURE OF NARCOTICS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) announced Thursday the largest seizure of narcotics so far in Taiwan -- 202 kg of ketamine with a street value of about NT$150 million (US$4.68 million) -- at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Members of the drug smuggling ring had concealed the drugs in boxes with 12 containers each, under the guise of powdered health food. They intended to smuggle the contraband drugs from Europe to Taiwan, coast guard officials said.
A woman surnamed Huang was arrested while attempting to pick up the delivery of narcotics at the airport, and police are currently tracking down other suspects in the ring.

With the government's rigorous crackdown on drugs, the price of level 1 drugs (hard drugs such as opium, cocaine and heroin) and level 2 drugs (amphetamines, marijuana and MDMA) has soared, the officials said.

Ketamine, one of the level 3 drugs (also included FM2 or "raping pills"), is a nonbarbiturate narcotic. As it costs far less than heroin or amphetamine, it has become the favorite of drug traffickers.
Police estimated they have seized 298.26 kg of level 3 drugs in the first four months of this year, up 454 percent from the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN COAST GUARD NABS PROTECTED ANIMAL SMUGGLER

TEXT.P: Coast guard officers arrested a man in Hsincheng, Hualien County Thursday on charges of smuggling protected animals.

A spokesman for local coast guard authorities said they were tipped off that the man, identified by his family name of Kao, was illegally selling protected animals. Hualien coast guard officers broke into the man's house early Thursday, where they found 47 reptiles, including turtles, lizards, crocodiles and snakes.

The animals were sent to the Hualien County Animal and Plant Disease Control Center. Hualien coast guard officials urged people not to smuggle protected animals so that they can be saved from extinction.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MEDICAL RELIEF TEAM DEPARTS FOR INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A medical team organized by Taiwan International Health Action (Taiwan IHA) departed for Indonesia Thursday to offer relief to victims of a devastating earthquake that struck the island of Java May 27, killing more than 6,200 people.

The six-member team, composed of four orthopedic doctors, one psychiatrist and one nurse, were assigned to the island of Java in the earthquake-devastated country of Indonesia, which was hit by a magnitude 6.3 earthquake that left more than 6,000 dead and hundreds of thousands traumatized and homeless.
The team carried medical equipment for treating bone injuries. China Airlines, Taiwan's leading airline company, sponsored the team by flying the group and relief supplies to Indonesia.

Taiwan IHA reached an agreement Monday with the Indonesian government to provide them with mental rehabilitation specialists. Indonesian authorities hope to draw upon Taiwan's experience of healing psychological trauma after the devastation of its own Sep. 21, 1999 earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEANUT PRODUCTS FROM VIETNAM CONTAMINATED WITH AFLATOXIN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) warned consumers Thursday that brand names should be chosen carefully when buying peanut candies from Taiwan's food stores in order to avoid aflatoxin poisoning.

Health officials said the department had tested 108 samples of peanut products from stores around Taiwan and found 12 peanut candies -- all imported from Vietnam -- contained unacceptably high levels of aflatoxin.

The officials noted that the amount of aflatoxin in some of the candy reached 240.4 ppb (parts per billion), exceeding the 15 ppb maximum limit set by the European Commission for peanuts and peanut products.
They said the DOH had ordered the removal and destruction of all contaminated peanut candy from store shelves.

According to the officials, the three companies that had imported the contaminated peanut products will face a fine of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000. In addition, these companies will be put on a "black list", meaning that food products they import in future will undergo strict inspection procedures.
Aflatoxin is known to be a potent human carcinogen that can damage the liver and lead to other chronic disorders.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DENIES SPECULATION OF 'LU-WANG ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official on Thursday dismissed as sheer speculation that Vice President Annette Lu has forged an alliance with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng amid the political crisis facing President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen Chin-jun, a DPP legislative caucus whip, made the remarks after news reports alleged that Lu had solicited Wang's cooperation to form an alliance to "stabilize the political arena" as opposition parties are launching a campaign to oust President Chen over a string of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
Furious at the alleged crimes of the first family, the opposition is asking for the public's support and even support from DPP legislators to recall the president or topple the Cabinet.

The reports claimed Lu had recently begun maintaining frequent contacts with Wang, and had initiated a summit with Premier Su Tseng-chang, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng and Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, as well as top leaders of the major political parties.
The summit was originally scheduled for Thursday but was canceled because of cool response from opposition figures.

Denying the existence of the "Lu-Wang alliance, " Chen Chin-jun said Lu's recent communication with Wang was mainly to solicit Wang's help in establishing a parliamentary alliance among Pacific Rim countries under the framework of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , a non-governmental organization initiated by Lu and inaugurated in Taipei last August.

Chen Chin-jun stressed that media speculation on the matter would only add fuel to the flames, saying that Lu has conscientiously taken into account the country's constitutional, diplomatic and legal interest, and has acted not out of any personal gain.
In addition, such speculation would just cause further confrontation within the opposition Kuomintang, of which Wang is a member.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN VISITS KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt visited main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Thursday to exchange views on Taiwan-U.S. relations.
The 30-minute meeting took place at the Taipei City Government as Ma concurrently serves as Taipei mayor.

Burghardt arrived in Taipei Wednesday and met with President Chen Shui-bian Thursday morning. His visit came at a time when the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party are attempting to recall Chen over a string of corruption scandals allegedly involving his family members and close aides.

When asked whether he had visited Ma to relay the U.S. government's standing regarding the presidential recall motion, Burghardt said that it was not the purpose of his visit although Taiwan's politics are "interesting."
Ma was also asked the same question at the end of the meeting, repeating three times that "the United States has no position on the issue."

This is Burghardt's first visit to Taiwan since he assumed the AIT chairmanship in February this year. The AIT handles Taiwan-U.S. affairs in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN VISITS LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER, KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt paid a visit to Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng at the Legislative Yuan Thursday, where they exchanged views on Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Burghardt told the press after the 90-minute meeting that the two countries enjoy good relations.
Before meeting Wang at the Legislative Yuan, Burghardt met Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, as well as having talks with President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RELOCATES HEAD OFFICE AFTER SELLING BUILDING TO EVERGREEN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) began Thursday a four-day operation to move its head office in Taipei to a smaller office building than its present location opposite the Presidential Office to cut operational costs.
The KMT signed an agreement in March to sell its building on Chungshan South Road to the Evergreen Group, one of Taiwan's largest shipping companies, for NT$2.3 billion (US$70.7 million).

KMT officials admitted that financial difficulties and the maintenance cost for the building -- at NT$40 million a year -- were the main reasons that prompted the decision to sell the property and relocate the head office.
The new offices are in an eight-story building on Pateh Road belonging to the KMT, which has leased some floors to business firms and used other floors as campaign headquarters for elections.
KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po told reporters Thursday that office work will be back to normal June 12 and that a reception will be held June 14 to mark the relocation.

Chan said that although it was difficult to part with the old location that has housed the KMT headquarters for more than 50 years, the party must demonstrate its determination to rise again, starting with a cost-saving plan for its offices.
According to KMT officials, the maintenance of the Pateh Road building will cost NT$8 million a year, much less than the upkeep of the Chungshan South Road building.

The Evergreen group has agreed to let the KMT use a basement floor of the building to display the KMT's historical documents. It has also promised to use the building for charitable, cultural and educational purposes only for the next 10 years and will not sell the building to a third party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PARTICIPATES IN APEC EXERCISE AGAINST AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan participated in a just-concluded anti-avian flu exercise organized the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to test the information transmission capability of the member countries while facing the epidemic, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

According to the official, the exercise, presided over by Australia, began a day earlier and concluded Thursday afternoon, with Taiwan, Japan, China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Chile, South Korea and Vietnam playing the leading roles, while representatives from the World Health Organization, the World Organization for Animal Health and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization participated as observers.
Taiwan's team was composed of representatives of the DOH, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, and a disaster prevention committee.

Chou Chih-hau, deputy director of the DOH Center for Disease Control, noted that the exercise was conducted mainly by telephone, fax and e-mail to test the information communication and contingency management capability of the member countries.

During the exercise, Chou added, Taiwan received in four hours seven simulated emergency situations from the exercise collaboration center, such as the WHO raising the alert level to phase 5 (infection among humans) , factories producing anti-epidemic articles catching fire, Taiwan being asked to provide assistance to countries suffering from avian flu, and a help call from Canada to track down a suspect avian flu patient traveling alone.
According to Chou, the DOH was able to make proper responses to these situations within two hours.

Noting that Taiwan has seldom taken part in such cross-border exercises in the past, Chou said the country's participation in the anti-epidemic exercise has significant meaning, as it allows Taiwan to maintain a communication channel with other countries in fighting against various diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq Has Been Killed
Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, was killed in an American airstrike on an isolated safe house north of Baghdad at 6.15 p.m. local time on Wednesday, top U.S. and Iraqi officials said today. At a joint news conference with Iraq's prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, the top American military commander in Iraq, Gen. George W. Casey Jr., said Zarqawi's body had been positively identified by fingerprints, "facial recognition" and known scars. He said seven of Zarqawi's associates had also been killed in the strike.
Wall Street Journal: Justice Delayed For Global Court, Ugandan Rebels Prove Tough Test
In August 2004, the International Criminal Court sent investigators to Uganda to gather evidence against a shadowy insurgency known as the Lord's Resistance Army, which had terrorized Uganda's Acholiland region with murders, rapes and child abductions. Over two decades, the insurgents had kidnapped more than 20,000 children and driven nearly two million people from their homes, the United Nations estimates. But the ICC quickly discovered how difficult it can be to dispense justice in corners of the world where political, military and diplomatic forces have long failed to produce stability. Seven months after ICC investigators arrived in Uganda, a delegation of Acholi tribal leaders came to the court's headquarters here with an unexpected plea: Drop the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS URGED TO BE 'RATIONAL' UPON BOURSE NOSEDIVE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market investors were urged Thursday to stay cool and rational after the domestic bourse took a 4.2 percent nosedive that day as a result of the domestic political upheaval and a slide in regional markets.

Susan S. Chang, vice chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), called for Taiwan investors not to sell their stocks "irrationally" since most listed and OTC companies have healthy fundamentals with good performances.

Chang attributed the Taiwan stock market's abrupt nosedive Thursday -- down 280.93 points after the bourse plummeted 244 points Monday -- mainly to the slide in markets around the world and non-economic factors at home.
Chang said the FSC will not tamper with the market unless "incorrect or unfounded" information is disseminated to drive down the bourse. She said no such news was reported that day.

She quoted FSC tallies as indicating that turnover reported in all listed companies in Taiwan totaled NT$4.13 trillion as of April 30, representing a growth of 13.55 percent, or NT$493 billion, over the year-earlier level.

Meanwhile Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taipei Exporters and Importers Association, said he is confident in Taiwan's economy and considered Thursday's nosedive as only a temporary phenomenon that will be corrected in a couple of days.
Hsu called for the country to calm down in the face of political restlessness, saying that the current political chaos should be eased quickly before it undermines domestic consumption behavior.

Recent scandals allegedly involving the first family and President Chen Shui-bian's associates have driven Chen's approval rating to a record low and have prompted the opposition to demand his resignation. Members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party have also expressed concern that Chen's woes might hurt the party in upcoming elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO WORK WITH U.S. IN BARRING MACHINE TOOL SALES TO IRAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has promised to work closely with the United States to prevent precision machine tool shipments to Iran as part of their joint efforts to fight global terrorism, Presidential Office sources said Thursday.

According to the sources, visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt expressed concern during a lunch with Chen about reports that Taiwan-made precision machine tools have "unwittingly" been shipped to Iran.

Burghardt was quoted as saying that the reports caught U.S. attention more than a year ago. The U.S. government is concerned that Taiwan-made precision machine tools might be used by rogue countries to manufacture weapons.

The top U.S. liaison official told Chen that the American government is willing to provide Taiwan with state-of-the-art detection equipment to prevent sensitive precision machine tools from being exported to Iran or Iraq.

In response, Chen assured Burghardt that Taiwan is willing to strengthen cooperation with the United States in barring sophisticated machine tools from being "unknowingly" sold to volatile regions or countries.

Burghardt arrived in Taipei Wednesday on his first visit to Taiwan since assuming the AIT chairmanship in February this year. He held wide-ranging talks with Chen at the Presidential Office before the lunch.
During their talks, Chen was also quoted as having told Burghardt that Taiwan's current volatile political situation will not last long and that the pall over him will be cleared eventually.
Burghardt's visit comes at a time when Chen is beset by opposition pressure to resign over a string of debilitating corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and former aides.
The retired U.S. career diplomat has said the timing of his visit has nothing to do with the country's recent political developments.
"My visit is coincidental that it happens to be at the same time as all of this is going on," he said during his talks with Chen.
Chen told Burghardt that Taiwan's current political upheaval will not affect its relations with the United States.

Also present at the lunch were Tan Sun Chen, the president's chief of staff, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, National Defense Minister Lee Jye, Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang, Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen M. Young and his deputy, David J. Keegan.
The AIT represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal ties between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER RIGHT-HAND MAN OF PRESIDENT LOSES APPEAL FOR BAIL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court rejected Thursday an appeal by a former senior Presidential Office staffer for release on bail, saying that his continued detention is necessary for public prosecutors to complete their investigation into his roles in a number of corruption scandals.

Chen Che-nan, who served as deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office from 2000-2004 and was considered President Chen Shui-bian's right-hand man, was detained April 7 on suspicion of having accepted bribes from a businessman in 2002 to help him solve legal problems. He was accused by real estate developer Liang Po-hsun of accepting NT$7.11 million for helping solve some legal problems but failing to deliver on what he promised.

Liang, 50, a former vice chairman of the Bank of Overseas Chinese, was convicted in November 2002 for using his influence to borrow NT$5.3 billion illegally from several branches of the bank through dummy accounts in 1996-97. While applying for a deferred prison sentence in March 2003, he absconded abroad and remains at large, spending his time in China, Hong Kong, Japan and South Africa.
Liang was also sentenced to one year and two months in a separate case for committing forgery in real estate deals while he was chairman of the Hsinchiehchung Construction Co.

Public prosecutors have also been investigating Chen for alleged involvement in other corruption scandals, including a profiteering case involving the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit railway project, stock playing at the Presidential Office and an ownership fight over the Pacific Sogo Department Store, which has led to a controversy over whether the first family accepted Sogo gift vouchers worth more than NT$6 million.
The Taipei District Court ruled June 7 that because the investigation of these scandals was still incomplete, Chen should be detained for two more months.

Chen filed an appeal with the Taiwan High court for his release, but the high court ruled that it was necessary to detain Chen for two more months because there were still reasons to believe that his release would enable him to collude with other witnesses and destroy evidence.
The Taipei prosecutors had indicated earlier they were in no hurry to indict Chen, as they have until Aug. 8 to take that action.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL DOGFIGHTING HURTING STOCK MARKET: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang called Thursday for public confidence in Taiwan's stock market, saying that fundamentals of the domestic bourse are sound but that political infighting should be avoided to allow it to perform normally.

Su made the remarks while answering questions from reporters following an inspection of the Shuehshan Tunnel on the Peiyi Freeway, prior to its June 16 inauguration that will link Taipei and Ilan counties.

Asked whether the government will take measures to stabilize the stock market, Su did not reply but ascribed its recent plunge largely to the present political situation. "As long as there are no groundless rumors affecting the market, it will definitely rebound," he said.

The weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange tumbled by 280.93 points to end at 6331.8 points Thursday -- the latest in a string of falls in recent days that have sent prices of heavyweight shares, such as stocks of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., to new lows after foreign investors pulled out of the market.
Analysts said that a "correction period" in the domestic bourse might take longer should the climate in the domestic and overseas markets fail to improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SPACE FOR 'THIRD POLITICAL FORCE' AT MOMENT: DPP

TEXT.P: There is no chance of a "third force" gaining prominence in Taiwan's politics unless the current "native" regime experiences a collapse, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Chen Chin-jun made the comments after media reports quoted the DPP's New Tide faction as having estimated that Premier Su Tseng-chang is currently facing a dire situation as a "third force" indeed exists in local society and that Su's political career could be affected by the way President Chen Shui-bian maneuvers his power.

In response to media questions, Chen Chin-jun said the only chance of a "third force" gaining prominence lies in a collapse of the DPP administration which he describes as a "native" regime in contrast to the previous Kuomintang regime that originated in China.
Although the DPP administration now faces many challenges from the opposition parties, it is unlikely to flounder, he stressed.

In the face of opposition calls for President Chen to resign over corruption allegations involving his son-in-law and aides, Chen Chin-jun said all DPP members and factions should stand united to weather the current political storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU TOPS IN SOCIAL ORDER SATISFACTION: POLL

TEXT.P: A poll on social order satisfaction conducted by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) shows that 92.28 percent of respondents from Penghu are happy with the social order in their county, topping the list of all cities and counties of Taiwan, a Penghu police official said Thursday.

Penghu police chief Kuan Cheng-che said that county police succeeded in lowering the Penghu people's fear of crime with an efficient promotion of anti-crime knowledge based on cooperation with the central government.

The tallies compiled by the MOI show that Penghu County ranks top in satisfaction with general social order, low theft and the government's efforts to boost social order and general services provided by Penghu police to residents.
However, the county falls to second place in terms of satisfaction with police attitudes when filing people's complaints, with only 78.63 percent of the respondents expressing satisfaction.
The Penghu police authorities said they will try to improve their service attitudes.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, June 9:
09:45, Vice President Annette Lu will meet with foreign delegates to a summit meeting of Asia-Pacific island countries.
10:00, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang will deliver a speech at National Chengchi University.
10:40, Vice President Lu will attend a ceremony marking the launch of new book on Taiwan's feminist culture.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TIES GOOD, STABLE: AIT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's recent political developments will not affect its relations with the United States because the two countries have a solid foundation to shore up their bilateral ties, a visiting U.S. envoy said Thursday.
Raymond Burghardt, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , was quoted as having made the remarks during a closed-door meeting with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng.

Burghardt, who arrived in Taipei Wednesday for his first visit since assuming the post in Feburary this year as the top U.S. liaison official with Taiwan in the absence of formal ties, told reporters that his meeting with Wang focused on Taiwan-U.S. relations. Asked whether Taiwan-U.S. relations are good, Burghardt said: "Of course, good."

For his part, Wang said Burghardt's visit comes at a time when Taiwan's political situation is volatile and sensitive as opposition parties have put forward a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian over debilitating corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and associates.
Wang said he told Burghardt that the recall motion will be handled in accordance with legal procedures, but he added that he didn't make any forecast on the case's possible developments.

Burghardt also expressed concerns about certain key bills pending the approval of Taiwan's opposition-controlled legislature, including a long-stalled arms procurement package, Wang said, adding that he told the U.S. envoy that the arms bill may be addressed at a planned extra legislative session to be held later this month.
Earlier in the day, Burghardt met with President Chen Shui-bian for wide-ranging talks.
During the meeting, Chen said that an opposition campaign to recall him over allegations of corruption involving his relatives amounted to political interference with Taiwan's judicial system.
Burghardt's visit comes a day after the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Central Standing Committee voted to push for a referendum to oust Chen.
The KMT's move is "a blatant interference with the judiciary by a political force" and a humiliation to Taiwan's democracy, Chen told Burghardt.
Chen said he supported an investigation into the allegations, but stressed that the opposition should not turn a judicial process into a political campaign.
Burghardt told Chen that the timing of his visit has nothing to do with Taiwan's recent political developments.
"My visit is coincidental that it happens to be at the same time as all of this is going on, " the retired U.S. career diplomat said during his talks with Chen.
Chen told Burghardt that Taiwan's current political upheaval will not last long, nor will it affect relations with the United States.

He also assured Burghardt that so long as China has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will honor his "four noes" pledge during the remaining two years of his second and final four-year term just as he has done in the past six year.

As to his administration's constitutional re-engineering plan, Chen said all constitutional amendment proposals should be addressed in compliance with constitutional provisions. Given immature social conditions and the current political turmoil, Chen said he doesn't think that such sensitive issues as changes to national sovereignty and national title will be dealt with.

Under Taiwan's constitutional system, a presidential recall referendum would only be held if a two-thirds majority in Taiwan's 221-seat legislature agrees -- an outcome that would require about 35 lawmakers from Chen's Democratic Progressive Party to side with the opposition. That is considered extremely unlikely.

Still, the KMT legislative caucus opted to move ahead with the process, calculating that a prolonged public debate over corruption allegations could further weaken the president and even force him to resign, strengthening the hand of the opposition ahead of the 2008 presidential elections, political analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES PRESIDENT CHEN'S REAFFIRMATION OF 'FOUR NOES'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government is pleased with ROC President Chen Shui-bian's reaffirmation of his promises to the United States on cross-strait issues, a U.S. State Department official said Thursday.
"The United States attaches profound importance to these pledges, which are a cornerstone of cross-strait peace and stability, " State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said in a statement.

"We welcome President Chen's June 8 remarks as an important contribution to stability, and we urge Beijing to take parallel steps to fulfill its obligations for regional peace and stability, including by reaching out to Taiwan's duly elected leaders, " McCormack added.

During his meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt in Taipei Thursday, Chen said the promises made in his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses have remained unchanged, including the "four noes."

Chen was referring to his pledges that if China has no intention to use force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-strait relations in the Constitution and will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.
Chen told Burghardt that these promises will remain in place in the remaining two years of his term and that neither domestic nor foreign pressures will alter his guarantees to the U.S. government.
Also, Chen reiterated that sensitive issues concerning sovereignty and changes to territorial boundaries and the national title will be excluded from the process of constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 9, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," "Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned by the Nuremberg tribunal to hang for "crimes against humanity." In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Richard M. Hoban, vice-commander of the US Air Force Logistics Command, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the mainland Chinese communist regime.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Mainland China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew appoints Yang Chao-hsiang, former vice minister of education and current chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin Ching-chiang as education minister.
1999: The Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China is formally inaugurated in Taipei to facilitate bilateral exchanges.
2000: Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung confers a medal upon Oleg Lobov, head of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, in recognition of his contributions to Taipei-Moscow relations.
2001: The Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand and the Republic of China's Taipei Zoo signs a memorandum to promote the exchange of animals between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you do not study poetry, you cannot make yourself agreeable in conversation. If you do not study the arts, you will lack judgment and taste."

DOC.HEADLINE: DISPOSABLE TABLEWARE TO BE BANNED IN RESTAURANTS IN GOV'T AGENCIES

TEXT.P: Starting July 1, no disposal tableware will be provided to patrons when they eat at restaurants of government agencies, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Friday.
Restaurants in public and private schools will also be banned from providing disposable tableware to patrons starting Sept. 1, EPA officials said.
It is estimated that the ban will help cut 2,600 tons of disposable tableware annually, the officials said.

Chang Hsu-chang, a section chief of the EPA's Department of Waste Management, said that the EPA has always encouraged government agencies to use tableware that can be reused after being washed. The policy will extend to restaurants in public and private schools, he added.
The new regulations will not apply to those who order take-out food at the restaurants.
Chang said that currently around 80 percent of the restaurants of government agencies, colleges and universities provide tableware that can be reused.

EPA officials stressed that local environmental protection officials will from July 1 begin carrying out inspections of restaurants of government agencies to determine whether they are complying with the regulations. The officials will issue warnings to first-time offenders and request that the situation be improved. On second inspection, if there is still no improvement, the restaurants will be fined between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000 (US$36.92-US$194.6).
