DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM PUSHES FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Winnie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Officials of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) said in Washington, D.C. Thursday that setting up direct cross-Taiwan Strait links could fast-track a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) between the United States and Taiwan.

AmCham President Thomas Johnson said at a press conference that direct links would be a fast-track way for Taiwan to sign a free trade agreement with the United States. "Such a move would help shore up support in Washington, which has been lukewarm to Taiwan's request to negotiate an FTA deal," Johnson said.
"A U.S.-Taiwan FTA would make Taiwan a springboard for the United States heading to the huge Chinese market, creating a win-win-win situation for Taiwan, China and the United States," he added.
The AmCham president, however, said that he saw only a less than 50 percent chance that such an agreement can be signed within the next year given the current circumstances.

The Trade Promotion Authority, which authorizes the U.S. president to negotiate trade deals with other countries, expires in July next year. Any FTAs not completed by then would have to be re-negotiated, Johnson added.
"If Taiwan responds with sufficient political will, AmCham stands ready to offer its support and assistance to help make an FTA a reality," Johnson vowed.

He added, however, that before Taiwan begins any FTA negotiations with the United States, Taiwan should face and tackle several issues first, including the need for more political transparency, deeper IPR protection, improved health care policies and continued financial reform.

Johnson made the remarks at the press conference after he and an AmCham mission discussed AmCham's newly-published White Paper on Taiwan with U.S. government officials, members of Congress and think tanks in Washington, D.C. in a "door knocking" tour. The policy paper of the AmCham, which represents more than 500 companies, also urged Taiwan to push on for an FTA with the United States.

AmCham Executive Director Richard Vuylsteke said the U.S. companies not only maintain business and trade operations in Taiwan, they are also eyeing the even bigger market across the Taiwan Strait in China.
"Should there be cross-strait links, a lot of business interest will surge on the U.S. side for an FTA for Taiwan, " Vuylsteke said.

Quoting U.S. deputy trade representative Karan Bhatia as saying in May after visiting Taiwan that he saw little chance for an FTA between Taiwan and the U.S. within the next year, Vuylsteke said U.S.-Taiwan FTA talks would be a long process, but the AmCham would rather expect optimistically its happening.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAILWAY FANS LINE UP ALL NIGHT TO BUY COMMEMORATIVE SOUVENIRS

TEXT.P: Railway fans lined up all Thursday night in front of booths at the lobbies of main train stations around Taiwan in order to be among the first to buy commemorative items being offered by the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) from Friday to mark its 119th anniversary.
The TRA is offering more than 40 kinds of railway-related commemorative souvenirs, including wooden model trains worth NT$28,000 and less expensive train-shaped toy cars and flash drives.
The first railway fan, surnamed Chen, to purchase a commemorative item said lining up all night was worth it because the model train he bought is worth a lot more than the NT$8,000 he payed for it.
The commemorative souvenirs will be sold between 10 a.m. and 7 p.m. everyday until June 11 at train stations in Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APPRECIATES POSITIVE U.S. REACTION TO PRESIDENT CHEN'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: The government welcomes and appreciates the United States' positive reaction towards President Chen Shui-bian's latest reaffirmation of his promises on cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Friday.
Huang stressed that it remains Taiwan's position to maintain the cross-strait status quo and to prevent the status quo from being altered.
He urged China to take the United States' opinion seriously and engage in direct dialogue with the elected leaders of Taiwan.

During his meeting with American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt in Taipei Thursday, President Chen said the statements made in his 2000 and 2004 inaugural addresses, including the "four noes," have remained unchanged and will remain in place in the remaining two years of his term.
Also, Chen reiterated that sensitive issues concerning sovereignty and changes to territorial boundaries and the national title will be excluded from the process of constitutional reform.

Chen's remarks received positive reaction from Washington, with U.S. State Department spokesman Sean McCormack issuing a statement Thursday calling them "an important contribution to (cross-strait) stability" and urging Beijing "to take parallel steps to fulfill its obligations for regional peace and stability, including by reaching out to Taiwan's duly elected leaders."

According to Huang, the fact that the United States has reacted immediately to President Chen's remarks shows that communication between Taipei and Washington is smooth and sound, and the meeting between Chen and Burghardt has been the most direct and candid form of communication.

Huang denied a media report which claimed that Chen made the move because the U.S. State Department had recently relayed a "secret cable" to the president via ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee to urge Chen to reaffirm his promises on cross-strait issues.

Asked if it means a change in Taiwan's position since Chen has only reaffirmed his "four noes, " instead of "five noes, " Huang said the "principle and spirit" of the president's remarks have always remained the same, which he said are to maintain the cross-strait status quo and prevent the status quo from being changed.

The "four noes" refer to Chen's pledges that if China has no intention to use force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-strait relations in the Constitution and will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo.
The other "no" was that the abolition of the National Unification Council (NUC) or the National Unification Guidelines "will not be an issue."

Chen announced in late February this year that the NUC would "cease to function" and the guidelines would "cease to apply, " triggering a dispute on whether the move was equal to abolishing the NUC and the guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHASE-OUT MECHANISM FOR FOREIGN LABOR BROKERAGE FIRMS TO KICK OFF

TEXT.P: The government has studied the phase-out mechanism for foreign labor brokerage firms if they fail to reach a certain standard in a comprehensive assessment program, a Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Friday.

CLA Deputy Chairman Kuo Fong-yu made the remarks on the sidelines of an award presentation ceremony sponsored by the CLA. The ceremony honored excellent foreign labor brokerage firms, the first time the council has honored them since Taiwan first introduced foreign laborers in 1989.

Kuo noted that a revised regulation concerning the approval and management of private employment service operators will be completed in August. A phase-out mechanism for those sub-standard operators will be added in the revised regulation.

A comprehensive assessment of foreign labor brokerage firms will begin in the fourth quarter, the results of which will be used as a basis in determining whether to renew their operation licenses, Kuo said.

CLA officials said that in the future, there will be a three-tier assessment system, compared with the current five-tier assessment system. If the operators refuse to be assessed, or are given the lowest level for two consecutive years and don't make improvements during a given time, they will not be allowed to renew their licenses and will not be able to set up branches. Instead, they will have to bow out of the brokerage market, and the employers they serve will be transferred to other brokerage firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS ON DPP TO 'DRAW A LINE WITH PRESIDENT'

TEXT.P: Following a move to recall President Chen Shui-bian two days ago, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called Friday for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to draw a clear line in its relationship with Chen, saying it is the only way for the DDP to survive and possibly thrive.

In response to an advertisement in some newspapers placed by several pro-independence groups to shift the focus away from the campaign to recall the president, Ma reiterated that Chen should step down of his own accord as such "diversion tactics" will be useless.

Ma, who doubles as Taipei mayor, made the remarks in reply to media inquiries at Taipei City Hall, saying it's not moral or wise for Chen to mobilize pro-independence groups to fight back against the recall campaign by distorting the issue and representing it as a conflict between ethnic groups.

Ma said that the president's authority comes from the Constitution as does the right to recall the president, adding that since the president's power comes from the people, they have the right to take it back from him.
"Chen is fighting the public will since a majority of the people in Taiwan favor his recall, " Ma said, stressing that he does not think DDP members at this time should embrace Chen in their arms.

Pointing to the alleged scandals in which the president's son-in-law and senior aides are suspected of involvement, Ma said Chen's leadership can be summed up in two words: "incompetence and corruption."

Therefore, he emphasized, the campaign to recall the president has nothing to do with Taiwan's ethnic groups but has everything to do with "integrity versus corruption" and "competence versus incompetence".

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU DENIES SUPPORTING COALITION TO OUST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang denied Friday that the party's so-called "spiritual leader, " former President Lee Teng-hui, supports a coalition of Vice President Annette Lu and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in a bid to oust scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian.
"The TSU will never do anything that will hurt its allies and please its foes," Su said, quoting a Chinese proverb.

TSU Secretary-General Lo Chih-ming was quoted by newspapers a day earlier as saying that Lee and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou support the idea of forcing Chen to step down, to be replaced by Lu, with Wang as premier. Lee's office denied the report.
Su claimed that what Lee cares about is Taiwan's political stability, which is also the goal of his party.
Lo accused the media of "misquoting" him and thus hurting Lee, to whom Lo offered an apology.
He vowed to counter Ma's plan to whip up anti-Chen emotion in southern Taiwan, declaring that he will appeal to the southerners to oppose Ma's recall-the-president campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GRAD STUDENTS HEAD TO XIAMEN UNIVERSITY VIA 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: A group of graduate students from National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, departed Friday for Xiamen University in China's Fujian Province via the "mini three links" route to engage in three days of academic exchanges with students at the mainland university.

The "mini three links" refer to the postal, transportation and trade links between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and and the ports of Xiamen and Mawei in China's Fujian Province. The links were implemented Jan. 1, 2001.

Approximately 100 students and teachers from National Cheng Kung University's executive master of business administration (EMBA) program flew to Kinmen Friday from where they will head to Xiamen for academic exchanges with their Xiamen University counterparts.
National Cheng Kung University's EMBA program is designed to cultivate business leaders in all sectors in Taiwan.

While at Xiamen University, Wu Wuan-yi, dean of the College of Management of National Cheng Kung University, and Wong Junyi, dean of the College of Management of Xiamen University, will deliver speeches on corporate leadership patterns of the two sides of Taiwan Strait and other issues related to management.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12-YEAR-OLD LAUNCHES 'CANDY-RAISING' DRIVE FOR AFRICAN CHILDREN

TEXT.P: A 12-year-old launched a "candy-raising" drive in the central county of Changhua recently, aimed at collecting 200,000 pieces of candy that he wants sent to Africa, where he believes some children might have only heard about candy but have no chance of tasting it.

Lin Hung-chun, a sixth grader from the Hoping Elementary School in Changhua City, said he was inspired by a book written by Lien En-chia -- a Taiwan doctor who worked in Burkina Faso as a draftee on alternative military service -- and decided to raise funds to buy some candies for African kids.

After learning about Lin's wish, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yua instructed his office to initiate a "one student, one candy" campaign, anticipating that funds can be raised from elementary schools all over the County and the money used to procure some 100,000 pieces of candy.
Cho himself donated 10,000 candies to support Lin's drive.
Lin called for Changhua school children to save their "red envelope" money received during holiday seasons to enable the African children to have the "opportunity to taste candy."
He said if possible, he hopes that 200,000 pieces of candy can be procured before the end of the year so that he can take them to Africa during the winter break in early 2007.
Lin, a budding violin player, is a philanthropist despite his young age.

After learning that some students at Changhua Junior High School had no money to buy lunch, Lin mobilized other musicians of his age to give a free concert in front of the Changhua Railway Station last month, raising NT$22,000 for students who could not afford lunch.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 159 points to close at 6,375, with 70,824 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose 158 points to finish at 6,328, with 1,768 contracts traded, while September futures gained 165 points to close at 6,216, with 113 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 178 points to close at 6,230, with 25 contracts traded, while March futures gained 130 points to finish at 6,230, with 32 contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,216 for June, 6,170 for July, 6,051 for September, 6,052 for December and 6,100 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
June TE futures rose 9.6 points to close at 269.6, with 6,937 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 10.65 points to finish at 268.75, with 157 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved up 5.8 points to close at 264, with 19 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 13.05 points to finish at 269.9, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.
June TF futures moved up 17 points to finish at 924, with 3,497 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures gained 27 points to close at 917, with 67 contracts traded.
September TF futures rose 23.8 points to finish at 905, with 10 contracts traded, while December TF futures lost 5.2 points to close at 885, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED ALERT ISSUED FOR 233 RIVERS IN WAKE OF HEAVY RAIN

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has issued a red alert against mudslides for 233 rivers in six counties after several days of heavy rain.
Officials from the COA's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau said the rivers are located in 14 villages and townships in Miaoli, Taichung, Yunlin, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Nantou counties.
They urged residents of the villages and townships to be on alert against landslides and mudslides and that local governments should evacuate residents should the need arise.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT APPROVES FUNDING FOR LOCALLY-DEVELOPED CANCER DRUG

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) approved funding to a local biopharmaceutical company, sponsoring its research and development of a new "dual-effect" anti-cancer drug, an MOEA spokesman said Friday.

According to the application documents, the new drug "TLC-X88" -- developed by Taiwan Liposome Co. (TLC) -- for both chemotherapy and radiotherapy has been proven effective in killing metastatic cancer cells as well as improving the efficacy of radiation therapy.

The official said the company will file an Investigational New Drug application for TLC-X88 with Taiwan's health authority by the fourth quarter of 2006, adding that once sale of the drug is permitted, it can replace imported anti-cancer drugs to provide better treatment for cancer patients.

The official also noted that since the new drug is the only "duel-effect" anti-cancer drug in the global market, TLC estimates that the drug will be able to generate more than US$1 billion in annual revenue for the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 112.82 points to close at 6,444.63.
The bourse opened at 6,389.98 and fluctuated between 6,451.17 and 6,268.92 during trading. A total of 3.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$118.61 billion (US$3.65 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, textile stocks at 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with construction issues dropping 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 567 to 190, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSPECTS RAIN-DAMAGED WATERMELON FIELDS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang traveled to Houlung in Miaoli County in northern Taiwan Friday to see damage to watermelon fields wrought by days of heavy rain.
Damage to watermelon fields is serious, with nearly 80 percent inundation.
Miaoli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung, who accompanied Su, picked some of the watermelons to show how they had rotted after being soaked for several days.
The premier said cash subsides will have to be paid to farmers to subsidize them for their losses.

On an opposition move to recall President Chen Shui-bian and bring a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet, Su said the priority is to settle the problems of the public and he claimed to be unconcerned about the political infighting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD DAMAGE EXCEEDS NT$200 MILLION: COA

TEXT.P: Agricultural damage incurred by flooding brought by the monsoon season had exceeded NT$200 million islandwide as of Friday noon, according to Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) officials.
About 16 percent of the island's crop fields, or 4,785 hectares, have been affected by flooding, incurring damage worth some NT$237.52 million, the officials said.

Farmers of watermelons and cantaloupes in Miaoli County, who have sustained the greatest losses among the country's farmers, are entitled to cash subsidies for their losses, while growers of citrus, vegetables, rice and other fruit in Hsinchu County can apply for soft loans for their losses, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% OF RESPONDENTS WORRIED ABOUT RAILWAY SAFETY: POLL

TEXT.P: While only 10 percent of the respondents to a recent poll said they are satisfied with the quality of the country's rail services, more than 90 percent expressed worry about the safety of the system, according to the results of the survey released Friday.
The survey, published on the 119th anniversary of the launch of Taiwan's railway system, was conducted by the Consumers' Foundation from June 1-7 among just 203 consumers.

Of the respondents who expressed worry about safety, 50 percent said they fear the trains are prone to breakdown, 50 percent mentioned "constant" reports of track sabotage and 43 percent claimed that the railway services are "very dangerous" for the physically challenged owing to the lack of handicapped-friendly facilities.

A total of 62 percent of the respondents expressed dissatisfaction with the quality of the railway services because of frequent delays, with 93 percent of the respondents claiming that delays occur "very often."

While 58 percent of the respondents expressed dissatisfied with poor efficiency of the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) in informing passengers about train delays, 59 percent expressed dissatisfaction with the TRA's arrangements for passengers after delays. Another 63 percent said they are unhappy with the compensation offered by the TRA for passengers affected by delays.
Meanwhile, 40 percent of the consumers said they are unhappy with the TRA's telephone booking service, and another 40 percent are unhappy with its online booking service.

Commenting on the results of the survey, Chang Hsueh-kung, a professor of civil engineering at National Taiwan University, urged the TRA to seek to improve its services by prioritizing the needs of passengers to enhance its competitiveness.
He also suggested that the TRA should keep pace with international standards in terms of its operational procedures so as to increase the safety of the services.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Al-Zarqawi killed in Iraq.
Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq, Abu Musab Al-Zarqawi, was killed Thrusday in a U.S. air strike north of Baghdad. He was blamed for numerous suicide bombings and the beheading of kidnapped foreign nationals. His death is considered as a major victory for U.S. President George W. Bush and a heavy blow dealt against the terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES 'PAN-GREEN' UNITY TO COUNTER 'PAN-BLUE' PERSECUTION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on all "pan-green camp" supporters Friday to unite in the face of what it claimed is a "persecution campaign" launched by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).

Tsai Huang-lang, director of the DPP's department of information and communications, said unity is needed to protect what he described as "the Taiwan sovereigntist regime" when it is being challenged by the opposition alliance.

The "pan-blue alliance" has launched a nationwide campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian, whose senior aides and son-in-law have been detained or investigated on suspicion of involvement in a string of corruption scandals.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, a former justice minister, said that the recall campaign has nothing to do with Taiwan's ethnic division that is often whipped up by politicians seeking the ethnic vote during elections.

But an allegedly "misquoted" report Thursday about former President Lee Teng-hui supporting a bid to replace Chen with Vice President Annette Lu, with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng appointed premier, has shocked the DPP.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun called his "pan-green camp" ally, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang, to clarify what was happening. Su told Yu the report was wrong and that there is "absolutely" no such plan on the part of the TSU, whose so-called "spiritual leader" is Lee.

In spite of the denials by the TSU and by Lee's office, Tsai said it is regrettable that some media followed up on the "erroneous report" Friday. He accused the media of deliberately using the story to divide the DPP and the TSU and to deal a blow to Chen and his DPP government.
"When the 'pan-blue alliance' is doing all it can to persecute Taiwan's sovereigntist regime, 'pan-green' political parties should stand firmly together," Tsai said.
He called on the TSU to use caution "so as not to fall into the 'pan-blue alliance's' trap."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AGENCIES DIVIDED OVER LAND REQUISITION

TEXT.P: The government agencies in charge of indigenous affairs and land policy remain divided over the issue of land requisition by indigenous people around Taiwan, government sources said Friday.

Officials of the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) failed to reach consensus that day over the concern about aboriginal citizens' rights to acquire the land on which they traditionally live.

CIP Vice Chairman Cheng Tien-tsai said the aborigines should be accorded the right to claim ownership of the land on which they have been living for generations -- a proposal that runs counter to the version professed by MOI officials, who insist that the aborigines' land claims follow the Slope Land Protection Act, which stipulates that the potential land claimers must produce papers proving they have worked the land for at least five consecutive years before being eligible to make a claim.

CIP and MOI officials met Friday for another meeting to discuss details of an article to be included in one of the 11 complementary acts under the Basic Law of Indigenous Peoples, which was promulgated in February 2005.
So far, only one of the 11 complementary acts -- pertaining to protection of the indigenous peoples' intellectual property rights -- has been finalized, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI CITY ESTABLISHES FLOOD RESPONSE CENTER

TEXT.P: The southern city of Chiayi established a disaster response center Friday to prevent possible damage caused by flooding due to recent heavy rain.

A spokesman for the Chiayi city government said the rain has caused water levels in rivers to exceed warning levels, with the Bajhang river exceeding the 29-meter warning level by 0.8 meters, bringing it to less than six meters from the edge of the levee.

The water level under a bridge over the Bajhang river exceeded the 16-meter warning level by 2.66 meters, just 1.4 meters from the top of the dyke. The Water Resource Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has notified Chiayi residents living near the river to take precautions to prevent possible damage caused by flooding.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.063 to close at NT$32.450.
A total of US$964 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.513 and fluctuated between NT$32.429 and NT$32.560.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAIN WARNING ISSUED FOR ALL AREAS OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a heavy rain warning Friday for all areas of Taiwan, saying that the wet weather is expected to continue until June 12.
CWB forecasters said the heavy rain is caused by a stationary front that is lingering over Taiwan.
They warned holidaymakers to be prepared to spend a rain-soaked weekend.

The meteorologists said people in northern, northeastern, central and southern parts of Taiwan should take precautions against heavy or torrential rain, while those living in mountainous regions should guard against "exceptionally torrential" rain.
They added that heavy rain is also expected in the eastern and southeastern parts of Taiwan, as well as on the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.
People should also beware of the threat of landslides, falling rocks, mudslides and flooding, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY'S ALLEGED RESALE OF SOGO VOUCHERS UNDER INVESTIGATION

TEXT.P: In response to a legislator's accusation that the alleged ownership fight over Pacific Sogo Department Store is related to the resale by first lady Wu Shu-jen of the store's vouchers, Presidential Office spokesman Lee Nan-yang said Friday that judicial proceedings have already started on the case and will be handled according to the law.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Ying held a press conference in Kaohsiung, accusing Wu of receiving more than NT$5 million-worth of Sogo vouchers from the wife of former deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office Chen Che-nan and Huang Fang-yen, vice president of Hsin Kong Hospital.

Wu allegedly gave some of the vouchers to her son and daughter-in-law and sold the rest, worth some NT$4.9 million, to seven women, Chiu claimed. Moreover, he added, her son-in-law Chao Chen-ming is allegedly involved in a Wei Chuan Corp. land development scandal.

Lee said those allegedly involved in the voucher scandal have given public explanations and the prosecution authorities have summoned some legislators, as well as media people, to seek more facts about the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD EXHIBITION TO OPEN JUNE 21

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Food Exhibition 2006 will be held June 21-24 at the International Trade Center, giving food manufacturers from various countries the opportunity to conduct trade discussions with local companies, Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) officials said Friday.

Southeast Asian food companies, which come from the Philippines and Malaysia, hope to explore markets here by presenting their native processed foods, vegetables, fruit, confectionery and Halal foods, the officials added.
TAITRA said the trade talks will be held June 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP DISMISSES MEDIA RUMORS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu dismissed Friday a recent news report claiming that the "top authorities" have given a secret order to intelligence units, demanding reinforced work to collect information about Lu's public remarks and conduct.

The report claimed the move was taken as "the authorities" are engaging in "situation assessments" amid the domestic political turmoil resulting from a series of corruption allegations implicating close aides and the son-in-law of President Chen Shui-bian that are threatening Chen's administration.
Lu said that in a democratic country, no intelligence units would even try to "impose pressure" on their vice president.
She made the remarks during a book launch held by the state-funded National Cultural Association.

Lu is regarded as Chen's most likely successor if the opposition parties succeed in pushing their motion at the legislature to recall Chen or push for his resignation amid growing opposition outrage over his allegedly scandal-ridden administration.
The report claimed that the instruction issued to the National Security Bureau (NSB) to conduct surveillance on Lu was to "restrain Lu from actions" that would help her take over the presidency.

Lu said she believes "there's absolutely no such thing, " adding that she strongly believes in Chen's "respect for the law" and his determination to run Taiwan based on the principles of human rights.
She demanded a public explanation from the NSB head in order to prove her innocence amid rumors she has never stopped trying to replace Chen.
The NSB said that day that the bureau has never received instructions to collect information on Lu.

As an independent government agency, the NSB, founded to safeguard national security, will never collect information on a domestic political party or individual, nor will it become involved in the activities of any domestic political parties, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUC ROW OVER: AIT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: For the United States, the controversy over Taiwan's decision to cease the function of its National Unification Council is "case closed" as "Americans don't tend to dwell on old problems, " American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt said Friday.

During a meeting with Taiwan reporters, Burghardt said Washington is satisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's announcement Feb. 27 that he was ceasing the function of the NUC and the application of the National Unification Guidelines.
Burghardt noted that the subject did not come up in his meetings a day earlier with Chen, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
The U.S. did not care much about the ceasing of the function of the NUC because, unlike the "four noes" pledge made by Chen in his 2000 inaugural speech, "it doesn't touch on constitutional issues."
"The other four involve issues of sovereignty that are embedded in the Constitution, " and that's "a rather important inherent difference," he added.

The four things that Chen guaranteed he will not do during his term as president are: declare independence; change the national title; push for inclusion of a "two states" theory in the Constitution; and promote a referendum on the question of independence versus unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TO BUY 200 TONS OF TAIWAN BANANAS: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: China will buy 200 tons of Taiwan bananas to relieve an over-production problem, an official of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee as well as director of the KMT's Department of Chinese Affairs, said over production of Taiwan bananas has driven prices down, resulting in big losses for farmers.

He said that production of Taiwan bananas increased by 32 percent this year. The wholesale price of bananas averaged NT$25.6 per kilo in early May, but dropped sharply to NT$15.5 June 8, with wholesale prices in southern Pingtung County plunging to as low as NT$6, even lower than cost.
He said that a KMT team contacted "its counterpart" in China June 7 over the matter and received a reply the next day that it would buy 200 tons of bananas.

The KMT has asked the Taiwan Farmers' Association to supply the bananas at a purchase price of a little higher than the NT$10.25 per kilo the Taiwan Provincial Fruit Marketing Corp. is paying the farmers.

After honorary KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao met in China in April, China announced 15 new measures, including one promise to purchase Taiwan fruit and vegetables during periods of oversupply.
The KMT then formed a cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural trade and cooperation team to deal with the issue.
Contingent on the future situation, the party will also help farmers tap the Chinese market in other regards, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE FOREIGN MANPOWER RECRUITING AGENCIES AWARDED

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) awarded representatives of five manpower agencies specializing in introducing foreign workers into Taiwan Friday for their excellence in importing high-quality foreign laborers.
It was the first time that CLA had awarded foreign manpower recruiting agencies since Taiwan first started hiring foreign laborers in 1989.
The agencies are Yang Chieh International Co. Ltd., Man-Strong Manpower, I Shen Manpower International Co., Austin Manpower Agency and Shoushin Aliens Laborer Agency.
The five agencies, selected from among 695 foreign manpower recruiting companies participating in the evaluation, obtained extraordinary marks for each indicator.
CLA Vice Minister Kuo Fang-yu said the awards are also aimed at filtering out bad manpower companies.

According to Kuo, the CLA will also send citations to 29 other good similar manpower agencies, and will send the list of the companies to the representative offices in Taipei of the countries offering foreign laborers to Taiwan.

The CLA will also put the list of the foreign manpower recruiting agencies with scores of more than 80 marks on the Web site of CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration for the reference for local employers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NEEDS TO ENGAGE IN SERIOUS SOUL-SEARCHING: SEF CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: A spate of corruption allegations implicating President Chen Shui-bian's close aides and son-in-law have seriously undermined the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the party has to engage in serious soul-searching or risk losing the "heart" of the people, a DPP heavyweight said Friday.

Chang Chun-hsiung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and a former premier, made the remarks at an informal gathering with reporters. The SEF is a semi-official body set up to handle cross-Taiwan strait civilian exchanges in the absence of formal ties with China.
Chang said that one corruption allegation after another have literally destroyed the founding ideals of the party, which are integrity, reform and love of Taiwan.
The only resort now for the party is to publicly announce its respect for judicial authority and not cover up any wrongdoing.
To err is human, but one has to "review modestly so that the public can learn that the DPP has become a mature and responsible party," said Chang.
He urged the party to "reflect upon itself, reform and get straightened up, " to avoid losing the heart of the people and bringing about the demise of the party.

He described the DPP leadership as "void and erratic " since President Chen stepped down from his concurrent post of party chairman to take responsibility for the losses in the legislative election at the end of 2004.

He said he believes that if there is a misstep between the party and the administration, then the leadership would be void. Not only would there be aspirants jockeying for major positions, but there would be no possibility of forming accountable politics in times of crisis.

But he also said he has never been disappointed with the DPP "for a single day," saying that when the DPP was struggling to become a party in the 1980s, it "never thought about taking the reins of the country one day" and that it should not be timid when facing the year-end mayoral election and the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO EXTEND SERVICES TO CHINESE SPOUSES OF TAIWANESE

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the foundation will extend its services to Chinese spouses of Taiwanese starting next month, following its recent addition of services for China-based Taiwanese business people.
The semi-official SEF was set up in 1991 to handle cross-Taiwan Strait contacts in the absence of official ties between Taiwan and China.

Chang, who assumed the post last year, noted the SEF will also be making preparations for the possible opening of Taiwan's market to Chinese tourists, and urged Chinese authorities to allow SEF representatives to visit China to provide emergency assistance to Taiwanese business people or tourists based on humanitarian grounds.
Chang stressed the importance of the SEF's work, saying the organization handles more than 300,000 cases annually.

Asked about the opposition parties' plan to set up branches in China to better serve Taiwanese businesses operating there, Chang said he welcomed the assistance of any group to Taiwan's businessmen with investment in China.
However, decisions involving public authority should be made and commissioned by the government rather than by private groups including individual political parties, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' RALLIES SATURDAY TO DEMAND PRESIDENT STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) will stage rallies in northern and southern Taiwan Saturday to demand that President Chen Shui-bian step down to take responsibility over a series of corruption scandals involving his family and senior aides, a PFP legislative whip said Friday.

Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, told CNA in a telephone interview that a mass rally will take place in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei, while another will be held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to call on the president to apologize to the nation for his incompetence and step down from the post.
The mass rallies were being organized while the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP were preparing to recall the president and topple the Cabinet.

In a separate telephone interview, PFP Legislator Lee Hung-chun, general secretary of the PFP's legislative caucus, rebutted claims by legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that the two opposition parties were trying to grab power from the DPP.
Lee said such claims were untrue because if the president were recalled, another member of the DPP -- Vice President Annette Lu -- would be his successor.
According to the two PFP caucus whips, the rallies in Taipei and Kaohsiung will feature a number of well-known figures as speakers, including legislators and TV political commentators.

They disclosed that PFP Chairman James Soong will speak to the crowd as the Taipei rally draws to a close, while KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will also speak at the Kaohsiung rally, symbolizing a two-pronged attack on the scandal-ridden presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALL CAMPAIGN NEEDS NOT BE SUPPORTED BY CRIMINAL FACTS: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Launching a presidential recall campaign is a political action that does not require evidence of presidential misconduct as justification, the leader of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" said Friday.

Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT), made his remarks as his party and its pan-blue ally People First Party (PFP) were poised to stage mass rallies in Taipei and Kaohsiung to demand President Chen Shui-bian step down to take moral and political responsibility over a string of corruption scandals involving his son-in-law and senior aides.
He admitted that if the corruption investigations stop at the point they are now, the opposition's recall campaign would be seen as "falling short of legitimacy."
However, he questioned Chen's accusation that the opposition is trying to "extend the charges against one person [his son-in-law Chao Chien-ming] to all relatives of that person."
"I am not sure whether only one person has committed the crimes, because up to this moment judicial authorities are still investigating how many people might have violated the law," Ma said.

Was the president showing his respect for the justice system when he claimed only one person had committed the crimes? Ma asked, adding that the president seemed to be "setting a limit" as to how the judicial officials could probe alleged wrongdoing.

He said based on the progress made so far by the prosecution's investigations, it is "a reasonable assumption" that more people at higher levels will be summoned for questioning in connection with the corruption scandals.

As for whom might be investigated, he said he would not speculate due to lack of evidence, but added he was confident in the nation's prosecutors who should have no fear when deciding whom to question and where to search for evidence.

Ma said he had expected the party's decision to recall the president would be misread as a duel between the pan-blue alliance and the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union.
Since the decision was made by the KMT's Central Standing Committee with the support of the party's legislative caucus, "we will push it through," he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUDFLOW ALERT ISSUED FOR 299 RIVERS IN CENTRAL, SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) increased the number of rivers on a red alert list for mudflows from 233 to 299 Friday after heavy rain lashed central and southern regions of Taiwan for several days.
The COA sounded the alert shortly after the Central Weather Bureau warned that all of Taiwan is expected to experience heavy or torrential rain until June 12.
According to officials of the COA's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau, the 299 rivers are located in 18 villages and townships in Miaoli, Taichung, Yunlin, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Nantou counties.
They urged residents in these villages and townships to be on high alert against landslides and mudslides and to cooperate with local governments if evacuation to a safe area becomes necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Surveillance and Betrayal Ended Hunt
In recent weeks, American officials say, they had begun following a man who they believed could lead them directly to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi: his "spiritual adviser," Sheik Abd albu-Rahman. A member of Zarqawi's network, cauptusabured by the Americans, had told them the sheikalal was Zarqawi's most trusted adviser.In a news release on Thursday morning, American military commanders hinted strongly that a member of Zarqawi's inner circle had pointed the way, referring a meeting between Zarkawi and the sheikalal. "Tips and intelligence from Iraqi senior leaders from his network led forces to al-Zarqawi," the release said.
Wall Street Journal: Fateful Strike, Zarqawi's Death, Completion Of Cabinet Raise Hopes in Iraq Two dramatic turns in Iraq -- the killing of the country's leading insurgent and the formation of a full government -- mark a rare step forward in the effort to curb the cycle of violence that has beset the country and bogged down U.S. troops there. The airstrike against Zarqawi near the small town of Hibhib marked the successful culmination of more than two years of sustained pursuit by U.S. and Iraqi forces. It provides a psychological boost after months of seemingly endless bad news and also could produce intelligence to further disrupt the insurgent network. The more important accomplishment in quelling Iraq's strife and violence may well be the quieter one: the completion of the long-awaited new government. The government fell into place with the approval of the two final, and most important, cabinet members: the ministers of interior and defense. (Lillian Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: After Zarqawi, No Clear Path In Weary Iraq; Difficult Questions Surround Legacy of Insurgent Leader.
Analysts and military spokesmen said Thursday that the death of insurgent leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, killed Wednesday when two 500-pound bombs obliterated his hideout north of Baghdad, will not extinguish the sectarian conflict that he helped foment and that is now claiming many more lives in Iraq than his campaign of beheadings and bombings.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN CONFIDENT OF TAIWAN'S DEMOCRATIC RESILIENCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be able to deal with its current political issue in a way that leaves its democratic system intact and strong, visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Friday.

The top U.S.liaison official with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties was referring to an ongoing opposition campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian over a string of corruption allegations implicating his family members and aides.
During a meeting with local reporters, Burghardt was asked about his view on Taiwan's current political turmoil.

"As chairman of the AIT, I'm going to very strictly adhere to the principle that this is an internal matter and it's not something for us to offer opinions about. As you said, Taiwan is a young democracy.
Even in old democracies, there can be lots of political crises and political dramas," Burghardt said.
Burghardt said that not only he himself doesn't have a high sense of anxiety about the political situation here, he is sure that "people in Washington" don't have, either.

Praising Taiwan has actually shown a lot of resilience as a democracy, Burghardt said he remembers that there was a recall motion against Chen while he was the AIT Taipei Office director in the year 2000.

"That drama also came and went.So I have full confidence that Taiwan will be able to deal with the current domestic political issue in a peaceful way, in a way which somehow resolves the issue and then will go on to continue to function as an efficient government, " Burghardt said.

As to whether he shared President Chen's optimism that the current political turmoil will be short-lived, Burghardt said: "I'm not going to predict how long this current political drama will last or when it will fall into the next one. There will always be political drama in Taiwan. So we'll see."

Burghardt arrived in Taipei Wednesday for his first visit since assuming the AIT chairmanship in February this year. He met with President Chen, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for wide-ranging talks Thursday.
Since his arrival, Burghardt said he has heard a lot about Taiwan's current political situation.

"Of course I heard a lot about the domestic political situation. Of course I was interested in the subject and it's an important subject. But that was not the focus, not the reason of my visit, " Burghardt said, adding: "I came with no message about that issue. I came with no mandate to investigate anything. I came with no instructions to bring back any views about the subject to Washington. It was truly coincidental to the fact that I was here."
Asked what's the current mood in Washington about cross-Taiwan Strait issues and U.S.-Taiwan relations, Burghardt said relations are in a good shape.

"In general, the situation in the Taiwan Strait is quite stable. It's certainly a lot more stable today than it was when I last visited Taiwan in November 2004. And I think that most of us expect that stability will continue over the next couple of years.

But Brughadt cautioned that while the cross-strait situation is stable, one can never be complacent. "One can never assume that they don't need to be constantly tended, and constantly, carefully managed."
Burghardt further said he is particularly grateful to hear President Chen's public reaffirmation of the "four noes" pledge.
"That pledge to maintain the 'four noes' will continue to be very important in terms of maintaining a stable situation, " Burghardt stressed.

He also mentioned the importance of Taiwan taking seriously its self-defense. "Another issue is of course the maintenance of deterrance.The US has the commitments that are made in the TRA.This is a very serious commitment and we devote a lot of attention to it. There are a lot of people involved in making sure...so it's important to see that Taiwan also takes seriously its self-defense, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SOFT POWER' SHIELDS TAIWAN AGAINST CHINA'S AGGRESSION: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that "soft power, " which Taiwan has spared no efforts to cultivate and accumulate over the past half century, is Taiwan's best shield against China's military threat.
Lu cited some examples of this power -- democracy, human rights, peace, love and high technology.

Lu made the remarks during her meeting with over 30 foreign delegates to the third Asia-Pacific Island Nations Summit sponsored by the Universal Peace Federation (UPF), including former Japanese parliamentarian Taykashi Aoyama, former South Korean National Unification Board Minister Huh Moon Doh, and Maldives parliamentarian Mohamed Saleen.

Lu said that compared to China's great strength, Taiwan may appear weak and small. However, Taiwan's case has proven that the best way for a country to resist the military threat of a stronger power is to "sharpen its own edge."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES NATION TO PRIORITIZE FLOOD CONTROL OVER POLITICAL FIGHTING

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on the nation Friday to pool resources toward passing flood-control legislation instead of political infighting.

The party made the appeal on the eve of a "Super Saturday" when the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will hold mass rallies in Taipei and Kaoshiung to demand that President Chen Shui-bian step down to take political responsibility for a string of corruption scandals allegedly involving his son-in-law and senior aides.

The opposition alliance's presidential recall campaign and rhetoric have angered some "pan-green" supporters, who declared they will organize counter-rallies to "check and balance" the pan-blue gatherings.

Yu Shyi-kun, the DPP chairman, said he and senior party officials have been monitoring the situation and are planning to run newspaper ads urging supporters to express their views in a peaceful and civilized manner so as not to increase tensions.

Tsai Huang-lang, director of the DPP's department of information and communications, said recent heavy rainfall in central and southern Taiwan has caused a serious amount of damage affecting farmers and village dwellers.

Tsai urged the pan-blue alliance to cancel its planned rallies in northern and southern Taiwan and instead return to the Legislative Yuan for an extra session to pass budgets on flood-control projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG POLICE PREPARED FOR KMT, TSU RALLIES

TEXT.P: Police in the southern port city of Kaohsiung have set up barbed wire barricades in some streets in the city's Hsiaokang District Friday to prepare for possible skirmishes caused by events held by two opposing political parties this weekend.

On Saturday, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) of the "pan-blue" alliance will organize a signature collection drive inside the Kaohsiung Municipal Social Education Center to petition President Chen Shui-bian to step down, while the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will stage a sit-in outside the center as a counter move.

A spokesman for the Kaohsiung police said they were well-prepared to prevent clashes from occurring, adding that they have rehearsed responses to as many situations as possible in anticipation of clashes between the two parties' supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR END TO POLITICAL INFIGHTING AMID FLOODING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged party leaders across the political spectrum Friday to stop political infighting and instead give priority to disaster prevention efforts in response to flooding in some parts of the country.

Su made the appeal as the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties -- the Kuomintang and the People First Party -- plan to stage mass rallies this weekend in Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively, to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to step down over corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
During an inspection tour of the National Disaster Prevention and Relief Center, Su said some cities and counties have been inundated by heavey rains for 15 days.
Quoting the latest Central Weather Bureau forecast, Su said more heavy rainfall may drench most of the island, particularly mountainous regions, in the coming days.

"I'm worried that torrential rains will not only flood low-lying areas but may also trigger mudslides in mountainous regions. At this crucial moment, we should pool wisdom and energy to fight flooding and relevant disasters," Su said.

He urged the "pan-blue alliance"-controlled Legislative Yuan to hold an extra session as soon as possible to pass a long-stalled special budget bill for flood-control projects in low-lying areas around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 10 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, June 10:
09:15, Vice President Annette Lu will deliver a speech at the opening of a seminar on national identity and cultural discourse.
10:20, President Chen Shui-bian will inspect flooded areas in Chiayi County.
11:10, President Chen will inspect Yulin County.
19:00, GIO Minister Cheng Wen-tsan will attend the Golden Song Awards presentation to be held at Taipei Arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 10, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1922: American singer and actress Judy Garland is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet Me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," as well as "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: U.S. marines invade the Japanese Ryukyu islands, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins a decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors and expands its territory by 200 percent.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1972: Chang Feng-hsu assumes office as the new mayor of Taipei, succeeding Henry Kao.
1975: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, addressing the Kuomintang, pledges to carry out Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the late President Chiang Kai-shek's anti-communist policy.
1976: Lin Yang-kang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Reconstruction Department, is appointed mayor of Taipei City by the Executive Yuan.
1980: The Ninth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens at the International Hall of the Civic Aeronautic Administration in Taipei with 109 Chinese and American scholars and experts participating.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern mainland China, defects at the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for copyright infringements.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and reaffirms the ROC's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperation programs with Macedonia.
2000: The 2000 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race kicks off at Tachia Park, located alongside the Keelung River, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening ceremony.
2001: The Chinese version of "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," a new book by the Japanese historian and novelist Fuyuko Kamisaka, has been released in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."
