THE Supreme Court may have committed a "judicial error" when it ordered the execution of Leo Echegaray in 1999, Chief Justice Artemio Panganiban said on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times
World Cup party is ready to start Nearly 32 years after West Germany won the 10th World Cup in Munich, the world's greatest sporting event returned to the city Friday when Germany kicked off the 18th edition against Costa Rica.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN CONFIDENT OF TAIWAN'S DEMOCRATIC RESILIENCE(repeat)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be able to deal with its current political issue in a way that leaves its democratic system intact and strong, visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt said Friday.

The top U.S.liaison official with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties was referring to an ongoing opposition campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian over a string of corruption allegations implicating his family members and aides.
During a meeting with local reporters, Burghardt was asked about his view on Taiwan's current political turmoil.

"As chairman of the AIT, I'm going to very strictly adhere to the principle that this is an internal matter and it's not something for us to offer opinions about. As you said, Taiwan is a young democracy.
Even in old democracies, there can be lots of political crises and political dramas," Burghardt said.
Burghardt said that not only he himself doesn't have a high sense of anxiety about the political situation here, he is sure that "people in Washington" don't have, either.

Praising Taiwan has actually shown a lot of resilience as a democracy, Burghardt said he remembers that there was a recall motion against Chen while he was the AIT Taipei Office director in the year 2000.

"That drama also came and went.So I have full confidence that Taiwan will be able to deal with the current domestic political issue in a peaceful way, in a way which somehow resolves the issue and then will go on to continue to function as an efficient government, " Burghardt said.

As to whether he shared President Chen's optimism that the current political turmoil will be short-lived, Burghardt said: "I'm not going to predict how long this current political drama will last or when it will fall into the next one. There will always be political drama in Taiwan. So we'll see."

Burghardt arrived in Taipei Wednesday for his first visit since assuming the AIT chairmanship in February this year. He met with President Chen, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for wide-ranging talks Thursday.
Since his arrival, Burghardt said he has heard a lot about Taiwan's current political situation.

"Of course I heard a lot about the domestic political situation. Of course I was interested in the subject and it's an important subject. But that was not the focus, not the reason of my visit, " Burghardt said, adding: "I came with no message about that issue. I came with no mandate to investigate anything. I came with no instructions to bring back any views about the subject to Washington. It was truly coincidental to the fact that I was here."
Asked what's the current mood in Washington about cross-Taiwan Strait issues and U.S.-Taiwan relations, Burghardt said relations are in a good shape.

"In general, the situation in the Taiwan Strait is quite stable. It's certainly a lot more stable today than it was when I last visited Taiwan in November 2004. And I think that most of us expect that stability will continue over the next couple of years.

But Brughadt cautioned that while the cross-strait situation is stable, one can never be complacent. "One can never assume that they don't need to be constantly tended, and constantly, carefully managed."
Burghardt further said he is particularly grateful to hear President Chen's public reaffirmation of the "four noes" pledge.
"That pledge to maintain the 'four noes' will continue to be very important in terms of maintaining a stable situation, " Burghardt stressed.

He also mentioned the importance of Taiwan taking seriously its self-defense. "Another issue is of course the maintenance of deterrance.The US has the commitments that are made in the TRA.This is a very serious commitment and we devote a lot of attention to it. There are a lot of people involved in making sure...so it's important to see that Taiwan also takes seriously its self-defense, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SOFT POWER' SHIELDS TAIWAN AGAINST CHINA'S AGGRESSION: VP(repeat)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that "soft power, " which Taiwan has spared no efforts to cultivate and accumulate over the past half century, is Taiwan's best shield against China's military threat.
Lu cited some examples of this power -- democracy, human rights, peace, love and high technology.

Lu made the remarks during her meeting with over 30 foreign delegates to the third Asia-Pacific Island Nations Summit sponsored by the Universal Peace Federation (UPF), including former Japanese parliamentarian Taykashi Aoyama, former South Korean National Unification Board Minister Huh Moon Doh, and Maldives parliamentarian Mohamed Saleen.

Lu said that compared to China's great strength, Taiwan may appear weak and small. However, Taiwan's case has proven that the best way for a country to resist the military threat of a stronger power is to "sharpen its own edge."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES NATION TO PRIORITIZE FLOOD CONTROL OVER POLITICAL FIGHTING(repeat)

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on the nation Friday to pool resources toward passing flood-control legislation instead of political infighting.

The party made the appeal on the eve of a "Super Saturday" when the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will hold mass rallies in Taipei and Kaoshiung to demand that President Chen Shui-bian step down to take political responsibility for a string of corruption scandals allegedly involving his son-in-law and senior aides.

The opposition alliance's presidential recall campaign and rhetoric have angered some "pan-green" supporters, who declared they will organize counter-rallies to "check and balance" the pan-blue gatherings.

Yu Shyi-kun, the DPP chairman, said he and senior party officials have been monitoring the situation and are planning to run newspaper ads urging supporters to express their views in a peaceful and civilized manner so as not to increase tensions.

Tsai Huang-lang, director of the DPP's department of information and communications, said recent heavy rainfall in central and southern Taiwan has caused a serious amount of damage affecting farmers and village dwellers.

Tsai urged the pan-blue alliance to cancel its planned rallies in northern and southern Taiwan and instead return to the Legislative Yuan for an extra session to pass budgets on flood-control projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR END TO POLITICAL INFIGHTING AMID FLOODING(repeat)

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged party leaders across the political spectrum Friday to stop political infighting and instead give priority to disaster prevention efforts in response to flooding in some parts of the country.

Su made the appeal as the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties -- the Kuomintang and the People First Party -- plan to stage mass rallies this weekend in Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively, to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to step down over corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
During an inspection tour of the National Disaster Prevention and Relief Center, Su said some cities and counties have been inundated by heavey rains for 15 days.
Quoting the latest Central Weather Bureau forecast, Su said more heavy rainfall may drench most of the island, particularly mountainous regions, in the coming days.

"I'm worried that torrential rains will not only flood low-lying areas but may also trigger mudslides in mountainous regions. At this crucial moment, we should pool wisdom and energy to fight flooding and relevant disasters," Su said.

He urged the "pan-blue alliance"-controlled Legislative Yuan to hold an extra session as soon as possible to pass a long-stalled special budget bill for flood-control projects in low-lying areas around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Japan and S'pore reaffirm strong ties.
Japan and Singapore marked 40 years of diplomatic relations by reaffirming their strong ties of friendship and cooperation yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Japanese Emperor and S'pore's President agree Japan and S'pore have a strong ties.
Singapore and Japan have established the close cooperation relations in 40 years of diplomatic relations.
Japanese Emperor Michiko and Singapore's President S N Nathan both indicated that Singapore and Japan should keep the friendship at the state banquet last night.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI NAMED INTELLIGENT COMMUNITY OF THE YEAR

TEXT.P: Taipei City won the top prize of the Intelligent Community Awards presented by the New York-based Intelligent Community Forum (ICF) Friday.
Taipei Deputy Mayor Pu-tsung King received the award from forum chairman John Jung at a ceremony at the Marriott Brooklyn Bridge in New York.

The ICF announced the top seven Intelligent Communities list in January after a 10-month selection process, and the Intelligent Community of the Year was announced during the annual convention of the think tank focusing on job creation and economic development in the broadband economy.
The seven finalists this year were Cleveland, Ohio; Gangnam, South Korea; Ichikawa, Japan; Manchester, Great Britain; Tianjin, China; Waterloo, Canada; and Taipei, Taiwan.
Taipei was awarded for its continuous efforts in Wi-Fi development, according to ICF Chairman Jung, who lauded Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's leadership in pushing Taipei to develop into a cyber city.
The judges decided on the Intelligent Community of the Year based on the criteria of broadband infrastructure, knowledge workforce, innovation, digital democracy and marketing.
Taipei City was also among the seven finalists for the Intelligent Community of the Year award in 2004.

Receiving the award on behalf of Mayor Ma, Deputy Mayor King read a message from Ma, elaborating the city's IT policy of "digital city, mobile Taipei." He pointed out that currently, wireless access is available at major business areas and MRT stations throughout Taipei City. It is expected that in July, the city will achieve 90 percent wireless coverage, he said.

King also extended invitations to city functionaries, IT specialists and executives of IT industries to attend the Taipei City Government-sponsored Digital City Convention to be held in Taiwan's capital June 29-30.

Nearly 200 delegates from around the world, including mayors, ambassadors from nations with Internet communities and leading technology company executives, attended the ICF annual convention in New York June 8-9.

The Intelligent Community Awards were presented in four categories. In addition to Taipei being named Intelligent Community of the Year, the MARS Discovery District in Toronto, Canada was presented with the Intelligent Building of the Year award, the Cisco Systems IP Contact Center Technology received the Intelligent Community Technology of the Year award, and the Ministry of Communications of the Republic of Afghanistan was named Intelligent Community Visionary of the Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TREND IS UNIVERSITY RESEARCH LINKED TO INDUSTRIAL NEEDS: MOE

TEXT.P: The new trend in Taiwan universities' research is to respond directly to the practical needs in corresponding industries, a spokesman of the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Saturday.

Citing as an example a display Wednesday at the MOE, the official said the 14 exhibits of inventions -- made by research teams from 11 universities in Taiwan -- were closely connected to the demand side during the research and development process. Therefore, he said, once they were completed, they could be used directly in industrial applications.

The 14 inventions include an air-conditioned biochemical protective suit, a portable water purifier with an enhanced oxygen provider, a precise molding technique for cell phone cases, and production process refinements for optical lenses of digital cameras.

The official noted that the water purifier -- made by a research team at National Formosa University -- can increase a clam's growth rate by 80 percent to 100 percent and shorten the breeding period by three to four months, generating an estimated net profit of NT$2.1 billion (US$64 million) for the clam industry.
He added that besides the business profits, 2.4 billion tons of water can be conserved if all clam aquafarms adopt the purifiers in water treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAO TOME & PRINCIPE VICE PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Sao Tome and Principe Deputy Prime Minister Maria Torres, Foreign Minister Carlos Anjos and Ambassador to the United States Ovidio Pequeno are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan for a four-day visit at the invitation of the Republic of China government, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.

During their stay, the officials of the ROC ally in West Africa will visit Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang, Finance Minister Joseph J. C. Lyu, Minister of Economic Planning and Development Hu Sheng-cheng, and Government Information Office chief Cheng Wen-tseng.

They are also scheduled to visit the Tourism Bureau and state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp., as well as several cultural and economic establishments, including the Taipei World Trade Center, the National Palace Museum and the Taipei 101 building, according to the MOFA.

Sao Tome and Principe completed its fourth parliamentary election March 26, with the Force for Change Democratic Movement-Party for Democratic Convergence coalition backed by President Fradique De Menezes winning.
The MOFA praised Sao Tome and Principe's efforts in pushing for democratic politics as a model for other countries in West Africa to follow.

Deputy Prime Minister Torres, 48, is an expert in finance and economy. She had served as finance minister and a member of the National Assembly before assuming her current post, the MOFA said, noting that Torres maintains close relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES OPPOSITION TO MAKE FLOOD-RELIEF TOP PRIORITY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Saturday urged the opposition to stop all activities related to its decision to move to recall President Chen Shui-bian, and instead make flood relief the top priority.

Tsai Huang-liang, director of DPP's Department of Culture and Information, made the appeal as the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) canceled a plan to hold rallies to protest against President Chen in Tainan and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan due to torrential rains. Instead, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou took part in a protest rally held by the KMT's ally, the People First Party, in front of the Presidential Office to demand that President Chen step down.
The opposition has decided to push to recall President Chen, believing his leadership is in doubt in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
Noting that days of torrential rainfall has wreaked havoc in several places around central and southern Taiwan, Tsai said President Chen Shui-bian would head to Chiayi and Yunlin later the same day.
He said the president is concerned about the people and has chosen to side with the people, although related disaster-relief work will be the responsibility of the Executive Yuan.

Tsai urged the opposition to stop political infighting and join with the DPP in disaster-relief. It should also agree to convene an extraordinary session immediately to review budgets related to flood-fighting, he added.
Yeh Yi-jin, a DPP caucus whip in the legislature, echoed his views, calling for the opposition to put aside political infighting and address the people's woes.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will convene an informal meeting next Monday during which the time and agenda for an extraordinary session will be set, but Yeh said he regrets that the the opposition plans to make President Chen's recall the top priority on the extra session's agenda.
"The opposition's intention to make the extra session a political infighting arena is apparent," she said.
With the flooding in the wake of days of torrential rainfall, she said, the first-stage special budget for flood-fighting has become more urgent.

Major bills such as the budgets for state-owned enterprises, special budgets to expand infrastructure, as well as the confirmation of state public prosecutor-general, which remained unaddressed when the last session ended May 30, also urgently need to be dealt with, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD-INFLICTED AGRICULTURAL DAMAGE REACHES NT$413 MILLION: COA

TEXT.P: Flooding triggered by seasonal downpours over the past few days had caused an estimated NT$413 million in agricultural damage as of noon Saturday, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said.

The crops most devastated by the flooding include watermelons, pears, citrus, persimmons, grapes and leafy vegetables, COA officials said, adding that more than 14,700 hectares of farmland have been affected by the flooding.
Much fallow farmland in central and southern Taiwan has been washed away or inundated, and many poultry ranches have suffered major damage, leaving at least 18,000 chickens dead, the officials added.

Meanwhile, the officials said, watermelon and cantaloupe growers in Miaoli County, who have sustained the greatest losses among the country's farmers, are entitled to cash subsidies for their losses, while rice farmers and fruit growers in Hsinchu County can apply for soft loans for rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOUNDATION FOR DEMOCRACY TO CELEBRATE 3RD ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The state-funded Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) is slated to hold a series of seminars from Monday as part of celebrations marking its third founding anniversary.

The planned seminars will focus on four major topics, including the youth for democracy, non-governmental organizations, democracy in China and international democratic movements, with indigenous people, students, representatives of women's groups and democracy activists invited to attend the activities, according to the foundation.

Issues concerning the way to reinforce democracy in Taiwan and the island's participation in the global network in the promotion of democracy will be discussed during the upcoming seminars, the TFD said.

The TFD, now chaired by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, was founded June 19, 2003 with the aim of playing a positive role in consolidating Taiwan's democracy and fortifying the country's commitment to human rights, as well as promoting democracy around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAPID EXPANSION IN SOLAR CELL INDUSTRY EXPECTED IN COMING YEARS: ITRI

TEXT.P: The production capacity of the global solar cell industry has increased rapidly since 2000, and the total annual output is estimated to reach 2.82 gigawatts in 2010, with a value of US$4.23 billion, according to a report released by the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) Saturday.

An official of the ITRI said that as the demand for solar energy has continued to grow at a more rapid pace, the industry registered a compound annual growth rate of 37.5 percent during the 2000-2003 period, with the figure hitting 60.5 percent for the 2003-2004 period.
He added that global annual production of photovoltaic cells reached 1.727 gigawatts in 2005, marking growth of 45 percent....
The official noted that compared to the ITRI's relatively mild estimate, global solar cell manufacturers have a more optimistic forecast of 4.8-gigawatt production output by 2008.

Currently, the top 10 solar cell makers are: Sharp -- with 428 megawatts of output, Q-Cell with 160 megawatts, Kyocera (125 megawatts), Sanyo (125 megawatts), Mitsubishi (100 megawatts), Schott Solar (95 megawatts), BP Solar (90 megawatts), Suntech (80 megawatts), Motech (60 megawatts), and Shell Solar (59 megawatts).
Most of the top 10 are Japanese makers, while Motech is the only one based in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Napolitano: Peace mission by servicemen abroad is a duty.
Italian President Giorgio Napolitano said Friday that it is a duty assigned by the Constitution for Italian servicemen to conduct peace missions abroad. Napolitano made the remarks in a state funeral in honor of an Italian soldier killed in Iraq earlier this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO APPROPRIATE EMERGENCY FLOOD RELIEF FUND FOR YUNLIN

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday the Executive Yuan will appropriate NT$20 million in emergency flood relief funds for Yunlin County as floodwaters have wreaked havoc in the central-southern county.

Su gave the directive while accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on an inspection tour of a sewer system in the farming county's Shuilin Village which has been inundated by floodwaters triggered by seasonal downpours in recent days.

The premier said the emergency relief fund appropriation will be made at the suggestion of President Chen who has ceded day-to-day control of government operations to Su to assume responsibility for his son-in-law's alleged involvement in an insider trading.
Many residents of Yunlin, one of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's power bases, rushed to shake hands with Chen and offer him warm greetings to show their support for the embattled president.
Su again took the occasion to urge opposition parties to put aside political infighting and give priority to disaster relief in response to flooding in many parts of the country.

Su made the appeal as thousands of opposition supporters rallied in front of the Presidential Office in Taipei the same day to heap pressure on President Chen to resign over allegations of insider trading against his son-in-law.
Days of torrential rainfall caused flooding and landslides in central and southern Taiwan Saturday that washed away homes, cut off roads and derailed a train, stranding hundreds of people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACING 'FIFTH POLITICAL CRISIS': VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that Taiwan is facing its fifth political crisis in history, and the ruling and the opposition parties must put aside their differences and work together with wisdom and rationality.
Lu made the remarks when she delivered a speech at a "Cultural Discourse on National Identity" academic seminar sponsored by the Council for Cultural Affairs.

Amid the opposition's calls to recall President Chen Shui-bian, Lu said the current political crisis "is not the crisis of President Chen, the first family or the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. It is a crisis of overall constitutional rule and a national crisis."
"One has to look at it from this perspective in order to get a clear picture of current political developments, " she said, adding that this is "by no means the individual problem of President Chen."
The opposition has decided to push to recall President Chen, believing his leadership is in doubt in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.

However, Lu said that recalling the president will not do any good to any party and that this is why she had advocated a coffee meeting with opposition leaders, in the hopes of creating space for rational dialogue and communication to help Taiwan's political stability. Her offer was rejected later.

According to Lu, the first political crisis was in 1971 when Taiwan lost its U.N. seat to China, the second was in early 1979 when the United States switched diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing. The third crisis was the Kaohsiung Incident in which pro-democracy activists were arrested in late 1979. The fourth political crisis was the so-called "soft coup d'tat" in the wake of the shooting of President Chen and herself on the eve of the presidential election in March 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PASSAGE OF FLOOD-CONTROL BUDGET BILL

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged the legislature Saturday to pass a special flood-control budget bill as soon as possible and called for an end to political infighting as flooding caused by seasonal downpours has wreaked havoc in many areas in central and southern Taiwan.
Su made the call during a visit to the flood-affected southern county of Chiayi, along with President Chen Shui-bian.

Concerned for the people and relevant disaster-control work in the region, Chen had insisted on being driven to Minghsiung township in the county after it was determined that he could not fly there due to the bad weather, Su said.

There shouldn't be differences among the political parties over flood-control efforts, Su said, noting that there has been a public outcry against political infighting and that the people want politicians to focus on coming up with solutions to their livelihood problems. He expressed the hope for cooperation between the central and local governments on efforts to address flooding problems.

During his briefing to Chen and Su, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen said the Alishan mountainous area received 811.5 millimeters of rainfall Friday, which caused flooding in three major rivers in Chiayi, including the Peigang River, Puzih River and Pachang River.

Most low-lying areas in the region were inundated, and more than 60 pumpers having been activated there to deal with the flooding, Magistrate Chen reported, saying the county requires the central government's help as at least 20 more pumpers are needed.
The government has drafted a special flood-control budget totalling NT$110 billion (US$3.39 billion) over eight years.

Chiayi only needs NT$6.8 billion for its planned projects aimed at dealing with the annual flooding problem in the county, Magistrate Chen said, expressing the hope that the special budget bill can be passed as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS URGE PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: Leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) on Saturday lashed out at "the abuse, incompetence and corruption" of President Chen Shui-bian, saying that this is the reason why they want to push for his recall.

In a protest rally sponsored by the PFP, PPF Chairman James Soong said that the call for President Chen to step down has come from people of all political and ideological stripes and that it is by no means political infighting.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who earlier canceled similar rallies in Tainan and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan to join the PFP protest, said the decision to recall Chen is not because of "one individual incident, " adding that a spate of recent allegations of insider trading against Chao Chien-ming, son-in-law of President Chen, and Chao's family is "only the last straw."
"The discontent of the people has accumulated over six years, " Ma claimed.
With days of heavy rainfall in Taipei coming to an end, participants in the protest rallies were in high spirits, and there were only sporadic clashes with police.
Soong said that "those who are corrupt must step down. Otherwise, Taiwan will have no future."
He reaffirmed the necessity of a recall, saying that in a democratic society, the people are not the masters only on election day.

Faced with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's call for putting aside all activities related to the recall decision and for focusing on relief efforts for flood-affected areas in central and southern Taiwan, he said that the legislature has in the past approved large appropriations for flood-fighting but that the administration has not used the money well.
This shows that the legislature shouldn't pass another multi-billion dollar flood-fighting budget requested by the Cabinet, he added.
Ma said the KMT will put forward the recall motion in the extraordinary legislative session next week.
Faced with a president who abuses power and whose administration has been marked by several corruption scandals, the people have to retrieve the power given to him in the election, Ma said.
As long as the people think the president is incompetent, they can recall him through legal procedures, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 74 ROAD SECTIONS DAMAGED DUE TO FLOODING: NATIONAL FIRE AGENCY

TEXT.P: A total of 74 highway sections around Taiwan had been damaged as of 4: 00 p.m. Saturday due to flooding triggered by torrential rainfall over the past few days, according to tallies made public by the National Fire Agency.
A total of 21 of the highway sections have been repaired so far, the tallies showed.
The statistics also showed that 530 households in Hsinyi township, Nantou County have been deprived of water supply, while 450 households in Miaoli County have lost power due to flooding.
Meanwhile, several bridges in Taichung County and Kaohsiung County have been closed due to swelling waters.
A total of 5,500 hectares of land in Chiayi County have been inundated, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PREMIER TO FULFILL DISASTER PREVENTION AND RELIEF DUTIES

TEXT.P: A legislative caucus whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday that disaster prevention and relief is the responsibility of Premier Su Tseng-chang.

Legislator Pan Wei-kang made the remarks after Premier Su urged the opposition to stop political infighting and focus on relief works in areas of central and southern Taiwan hit by flooding after days of torrential rainfall.
The premier called for the opposition to stop all activities related to its decision to recall the president, urging the legislature to pass a multi-billion dollar budget for flood-fighting soon.

Pan said Taiwan has entered into flood-prone period since May, and disaster prevention and relief work is the responsibility of the premier, which she said has nothing to do with the eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.46 billion) flood-fighting special budget bill that was yet to be reviewed in the legislature when its last session ended May 30.
Pan said that the special budget laying idle in the legislature is mainly for the preliminary budget for county river dredging.
The legislature has already passed the annual flood-fighting budget of NT$24 billion for this year, and the Executive Yuan can also use the emergency fund for major natural disasters, she noted.
She said that "integrity versus corruption" is the theme of the opposition's push for the president's recall, which she claimed is the aspiration of the public.

She expressed the hope that Su will fulfill his duty stipulated in the Constitution and that he will also instruct the Ministry of Justice to get to the bottom of a series of corruption allegations against President Chen's son-in-law and close aides to live up to the expectations of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INVITES YOUTHS TO SAY NO TO DRUGS, GANGSTERS & DRAG RACING

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Bureau of Education hosted a dazzling garden party Saturday at the public squares surrounding the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall as part of its efforts to persuade teenagers to steer clear of drugs, gangsters and drag racing.
Dozens of food and game booths were set up, and the bureau also invited street dance performers and popular entertainers to speak for its "anti-drugs, gangsters and drag racing" campaign.
Drugs, bullying and violence have been the major factors jeopardizing the safety of students on campus, therefore drawing the most attention of the education sector, bureau officials said.

Furthermore, traffic accidents are also a problem that concerns the bureau, whose statistics indicate that during the 2002-2005 period, a total of 1,370 students around the country were killed in traffic accidents, accounting for 65 percent of the total number of student deaths by accident during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD BILL SHOULD BE PUT AT TOP OF LEGISLATIVE AGENDA: CABINET

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan looks forward to seeing the NT$116 billion special flood-control budget bill put at the top of the agenda for a planned extraordinary legislative session to be held later this month, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Saturday.

Cheng made the remarks after an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus whip said earlier the same day that the proposed extra legislative session should discuss before any other topic a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian which was put forward by opposition lawmakers on the final day of the last legislative session which ended May 30 in chaos.
"The KMT legislative caucus will agree to deal with the flood-control budget bill only after the presidential recall motion is addressed," KMT whip Pan Wei-kang said at a news conference.

If recall motion were to be discussed first, Cheng said, the ruling and opposition camps would definitely get into a deadlock, and political confrontation stoked by the motion could delay or hobble screening of the crucial flood-control bill.

Noting that days of torrential rainfall has caused flooding and landslides in many parts of the country, Cheng said the passage of the long-delayed flood-control bill has become ever more urgent and important.

If the extra legislative session fails to pass the budget bill, Cheng said, many flood-fighting projects that should be carried out or put for an open tender this year will get stuck and residents in flood-prone areas will have to endure the scourge of flooding for another year.

The legislature, where the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally the People First Party jointly hold a slim majority, is scheduled to hold a"conversation session" Monday to flesh out the agenda for a planned extra session.
While both ruling and opposition parties have a shared interest in holding an extra session, they remain far divided over the topics to be addressed.

Opposition parties have heaped pressure on President Chen to resign since his son-in-law was detained in May on suspicion of using insider information and dummy accounts to buy shares in a financially troubled real estate developer.

This week the KMT agreed to initiate a parliamentary vote to "recall" Chen, although it is almost certain to fail as the opposition lacks the two-thirds of seats in the legislature required to hold a referendum on the issue.

Still, the "pan-blue" alliance opted to move ahead with the process, calculating that a prolonged public debate over corruption allegations could further weaken the president and even force him to resign, strengthening the hand of the opposition ahead of the 2008 presidential election, political analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: Death "Great Loss" for Guerrilla Network. Loss of terrorist leader could lead to widening of existing factional splits among jihadist groups extending beyond Iraq, some analysts say.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK DENIES REPORT ABOUT OPPOSING TAIWAN'S GPA PARTAKING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 10 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong looks forward to a "satisfactory solution" to Taiwan's partaking in the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) and has never adopted a negative stance on relevant issues, a Hong Kong official stationed at the World Trade Organization (WTO) said Saturday.

The U.S.-based economic and trade news BNA reported earlier this month that Taiwan completed its GPA partaking negotiations in December 2002, but it has so far failed to join the system because China opposes the designation of Taiwan's government agencies to be subject to the GPA regulations, particularly its central government organs, such as the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of National Defense. In Beijing's view, the names of those agencies imply Taiwan's statehood.
The BNA report also said as China is not a GPA signatory, its opposition to Taiwan's participation in the WTO-affiliated GPA was conveyed by Hong Kong on its behalf.

The BNA quoted a Hong Kong delegate at the WTO as clarifying Saturday that the Hong Kong government has never opposed Taiwan's entry to the GPA and is hopeful that problems regarding Taiwan's entry can be resolved fairly and satisfactorily.
The Hong Kong official further said that Hong Kong authorities have never expressed opposition to any issues regarding Taiwan's GPA entry, including the designation issue.

The GPA commission passed last week a resolution initiated by the European Union and the United States on the "GPA partaking formula, " which is expected to help clear "political barriers" for Taiwan to join the GPA soon.

The resolution states that the names or terms used in protocols, documents and appendices regarding a customs territory's partaking in the GPA are mainly for defining its promises and bearing no "sovereignty" implications.
Taiwan joined the WTO under the name of "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" in January 2002. China is also a WTO member, but has not joined the GPA.

New York Times: Hamas Fires Rockets at Israel After Calling Off Truce
The ruling Hamas group fired a barrage of homemade rockets at Israel on Saturday, hours after calling off a truce with Israel in anger over an artillery attack that killed seven civilians at a beachside picnic in the Gaza Strip, according to Associated Press reports. The Islamic militant group claimed responsibility for at least 15 of the rockets fired after midnight, as well as a barrage of mortar bombs. DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD-INFLICTED AGRICULTURAL LOSSES SPIKE TO NT$467.16 MILLION: COA

TEXT.P: Flooding triggered by seasonal downpours over the past few days had caused an estimated NT$467.16 million in agricultural damage as of 4 p.m. Saturday, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said.

The crops most devastated by the flooding include watermelons, rice, pears, citrus, persimmons, grapes, green onions and leafy vegetables, COA officials said, adding that some 15,000 hectares of farmland have been affected by the flooding.
Much fallow farmland in central and southern Taiwan has been washed away or inundated, and many poultry ranches have suffered major damage, leaving at least 18,000 chickens dead, the officials added.

Meanwhile, the officials said, watermelon and cantaloupe growers in Miaoli County, who have sustained the greatest losses among the country's farmers, are entitled to cash subsidies for their losses, while rice farmers and fruit growers in Hsinchu County can apply for soft loans for rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAKES PROGRESS IN GRASSROOTS ELECTIONS: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) efforts to broaden its power base has borne fruit as it managed to capture more seats than ever before in the just-concluded elections for village/borough chiefs and township/village assemblies, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday.

According to initial election returns, the success rate of DPP candidates in the village/borough chiefs elections around the country except Taipei, stood at 47.71 percent, the highest record in the party's 19-year history. The DPP won a total 177 village/borough chief seats, up 51 seats compared with the electoral results four years ago.
The number of township/village assembly seats garnered by the DPP in the latest elections also increased from 183 to 205.

Particularly encouraging were that the number of borough chiefs won by the DPP in Kaohsiung City spiked to 66 from 51 in the 2002 elections and that the party also managed to register a nine-seat increase in the village chief elections in both Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.

The modest gain in the grassroots elections came as a morale boost for the DPP following a series of election setbacks in the past two years and amid the opposition campaign to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to resign over corruption allegations implicating his family and aides. Grassroots administrative and legislative seats have traditionally been controlled by the opposition Kuomintang. (By sofia Wu) ednitem

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASSROOTS ELECTIONS IN 48 VILLAGES POSTPONED TO JUNE 17

TEXT.P: The elections for village/borough chiefs and township/village councils in 48 villages and boroughs in several counties will be postponed to June 17 because of flooding triggered by seasonal downpours in recent days, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Saturday.

Voters around the country except those in Taipei went to polls Saturday to elect village/borough chiefs and township/village council members Saturday, but voting in 48 villages and boroughs was halted over torrential rainfall.
CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said the grassroots elections proceeded generally smoothly, with no reports of major controversies or disputes. All the winners will be sworn in Aug. 1.
The voter turnout in some regions, including Kaohsiung City, was very low due to heavy rains Saturday morning.

Most of the villages where the grassroots had to be postponed to next Saturday are in mountainous regions, including 12 villages in Chiayi County's Alishan area, 15 villages in Nantou County's Janai Hsiang and eight villages in Taichung County's Hoping Hsiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 11, or the 16th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a U.S. House of Representatives and was the only legislator to oppose American involvement in both world wars.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director-general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River" and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada with two gold and four bronze medals.
2000: Officials from 30 Asian-Pacific cities reach an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.
2000: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale hits the central Taiwan county of Nantou, injuring 16 people.
2004: The Legislative Yuan passes amendments to the Labor Standard Law to allow laborers to open portable pension account.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE VOLUNTEER RECRUIT PROGRAM SURPASSES MND EXPECTATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) 2006 volunteer recruit program, in which the military originally targeted to recruit 100 female volunteer soldiers, has been met enthusiastically by young women, MND officials said Sunday.
Inquiries about the female volunteer recruit program were so numerous that the MND decided to increase the number of openings from 100 to 604, MND officials said.

For the first time in Taiwan's history, the military began to recruit female volunteer soldiers this year in a program in which a total of 8,504 volunteers, including females, were originally expected to be recruited. The number has also been boosted to 13,500 by MND to meet the demand, the officials reported.
According to Armed Forces Reserve Command officials, more than 20 percent of those who have visited the MND's Web site to enquire about the volunteer recruit program have been women.
The officials said that more and more women are showing interest in joining the military, adding that this will make the armed forces' recruitment efforts easier.

The recruits will receive a minimum monthly salary of NT$27,775 (US$868). They will also be entitled to more pay for performing extra duties. They will also be allowed to attend various professional training programs that will help them find employment after they leave the military.
The MND launched the volunteer recruitment system in May 2005, when the first batch of 472 volunteer soldiers were recruited.
The Defense Ministry hopes that volunteer recruits will eventually form the bulk of the nation's armed forces, or represent at least a 60:40 ratio of volunteers to national service draftees.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA PROMOTES NEW CHICKEN FEED WITH PROBIOTICS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has released a new kind of chicken feed containing probiotics with the aim of replacing existing feed that is laced with antibiotics, a COA official said Sunday.

The official said that although imported chicken is cheap, local customers still prefer domestic fowl. He added, however, that the domestic chicken sometimes poses a health hazard because it is dosed so heavily with antibiotics.
He claimed that the solution to the problem is to invent a probiotic substitute with the same effect as antibiotics, increasing the incentive for chicken raisers to give up using antibiotics.

According to COA research, the new chicken feed -- containing bacillus natto and bacillus subtilis -- has proved effective against coccidiosis, decreasing infection possibility by 2 percent and reducing the death rate by 3 percent.
The research results also show that the probiotic feed can balance the bacterium groups in chicken intestines, as well as reducing body fat and blood lipids.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLED LIVE BIRDS DESTROYED: COAST GUARD

TEXT.P: A shipment of 173 live songbirds that were smuggled from China onto a beach on the outlying island of Kinmen early Sunday have been destroyed, the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported later that day.

The songbirds, including Japanese white-eyes, Siberian ruby throats and Siberian yellow robins, were found in 20 cages that were dumped on a beach on Little Kinmen Island, according to officers from the CGA Kinmen operation.

Officials from the Kinmen branch of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture and Kinmen County officials in charge of animal and plant quarantine were then notified about the smuggling.
The animal health officials took samples from 30 of the birds for quarantine examination before destroying them on the beach, CGA officials said.

Officers from the CGA Kinmen operation said their radar picked up a suspicious vessel moving toward the Hongshanan beach area of Little Kinmen, whereupon they immediately notified a nearby CGA patrol boat that saw a Chinese fishing boat fleeing from the beach after dumping the cages, the officers said.

CGA officials pointed out that China is listed as a bird flu-affected area and that those who violate Taiwan's regulations aimed at preventing animal contagious diseases face up to three years in prison or/and a maximum fine of NT$150,000 (US$4,690).

DOC.HEADLINE: LITTLE CHANCE OPPOSITION RECALL MOTION WILL PASS: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: There is little chance that an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian will pass the legislature, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng predicted Sunday.

Speaking at a graduation ceremony at Southern Taiwan University of Technology in Tainan, Wang said that if the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) follows that with a motion of no-confidence against the Cabinet, "political turmoil will be unavoidable."
He told the students, faculty and parents of graduating students that recalling the president, toppling the premier and impeaching top officials are the rights of the legislature.
He said he expected the KMT-initiated recall-the-president motion to be put on the legislative agenda Tuesday, when an extra session of the legislature will likely begin.
Later, in reply to media questions, Wang said the chances of the motion passing are "not great" because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" does not have enough votes.
The alliance of the KMT and People First Party enjoy a slim majority at the legislature, but fall short of a two-thirds majority that is needed to pass such a motion.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its Taiwan Solidarity Union ally, who together form the "pan-green camp, " are not likely to support a motion to unseat Chen, even though his senior aides and son-in-law Chao Chien-ming are being detained and investigated for suspected involvement in a string of corruption scandals.

As KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou has threatened to launch another campaign to bring down the Chen government if the recall action fails, Wang said it can be expected that Taiwan's political situation will remain unstable.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONDEMNS ASSASSINATION REMARKS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) condemned Sunday remarks promoting an assassination of KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou spread by some unlicensed radio stations in southern Taiwan, and demanded that Premier Su Tseng-chang and police authorities bring the facilities in question to account.
KMT legislative caucus members issued the demand at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang demanded that Su immediately order the National Police Agency (NPA) to conduct an investigation into the case and provide the public with a clear explanation of what it is doing to apprehend those guilty of fomenting the call to murder Ma.

She also accused some "pan-green camp" elements of trying to paralyze special telephone lines set up by the "pan-blue alliance" to collect public endorsement for a recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian, and asked the National Communications Commission and the Directorate General of Telecommunications to probe the situation at once.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao questioned Su's promise to improve Taiwan's social order in six months when he took over the premiership in late January this year, asking why Su has fallen short of taking concrete action to wipe out unlicensed radio stations that air such sensationalist remarks.

Echoing Lai's comments, KMT lawmaker Wu Yu-sheng blamed Su for failing to give the order and blasted the Ministry of Justice, the NPA and the Investigation Bureau for failing to initiate a probe into the case. "This is not a Cabinet that the people can count on should heads of relevant government agencies fail to give an explanation in public," he said.
KMT lawmaker Fei Hung-tai said he suspects that the Democratic Progressive Party government of using the unlawful radio stations to air rhetoric about assassinating Ma to cement its power base.

At a time when the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party have swung into full gear to boot President Chen Shui-bian from office, either by calling a motion to recall him or by toppling the Cabinet, due to a string of serious corruption scandals implicating his family members and close aides, some pro-DPP illegal radio stations in southern Taiwan began spreading fanatic remarks igniting backers to assassinate Ma to "protect" Chen and his so-called "Taiwanese regime."

Over 30,000 "pan-blue" supporters protested Saturday on Kategalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office demanding that Chen step down to take responsibility for the series of corruption scandals -- the second protest of its kind in as many weeks. Ma also gave a speech at the rally.

PFP Chairman James Soong vowed to return to the venue this Friday if a vote on the presidential recall motion is prevented from being passed by "pan-green" lawmakers at an extra legislative session that will begin this week.

The "pan-blue alliance" agreed to an extra legislative session only after the presidential recall motion was included on its agenda along with an eight-year NT$80 billion budget bill for a flood control project.

In response to KMT lawmakers' questions, ranking NPA officers stressed that the agency will not tolerate violence and will provide quick assistance to local police authorities when they need extra forces to protect political party leaders.
The NPA lacks the authority to raid illegal radio stations, but it is poised to punish those who resort to violence at any time, high-level NPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTORS WIN BIG AT INPEX 2006
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan inventors have again demonstrated their ingenuity by winning numerous prizes, including six gold medals, at the prestigious INPEX 2006 invention show held in Pittsburgh.

Displaying 27 new inventions at INPEX 2006, which took place June 7-10, Taiwan inventors took home six gold medals, four silvers and one bronze, as well as two special prizes, representing the highest honor of INPEX -- America's largest invention trade show -- said Chen Tsung-tai, chairman of the Taiwan Inventor's Association, which sponsored Taiwan's participation in INPEX 2006.

All of Taiwan's 27 entries except for one earned a prize, Chen said. The inventions, including a smoke-deterrent mask, switches made of fabric and a supersonic wine vibrator which it is claimed makes wine "tastier, " attracted American buyers who have offered money for the requisition of the technologies and patent rights of some of the inventions, according to Chen.

Some of the inventions were also prize-winners at the 34th Geneva Inventions Show that was held in early April. Taiwan inventors won a record-setting number of prizes then, including four special prizes, 15 gold medals, 13 silvers and six bronzes, marking the largest number of honors that Taiwan has ever garnered in the annual competition in Switzerland.
Taiwan won two gold medals, seven bronze medals and two special prizes in INPEX 2005.

According to tallies compiled by a Ministry of Economic Affairs office in charge of investment and trade affairs in the United States, Taiwan inventors won their first U.S. patent in 1973. Between January 2000 and May 2006, nearly 5,000 Taiwan products have obtained U.S. patent rights, the officials said.

La Repubblica: D'Alema: higher tax rate for idle capital yield.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALL MOTION JUST HORS D'OEUVRE OF LEGISLATURE BATTLEBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: The opposition's decision to launch a campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian, to be followed with a no-confidence motion against Premier Su Tseng-chang if that fails, has triggered a new war between the opposition "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green camp" at the Legislative Yuan, which is to decide Monday on a time schedule and agenda for an extra session.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng has predicted that there is little chance that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -initiated recall motion will pass the legislature because the opposition does not have enough votes to pass the two-thirds threshold. So why are the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), so adamant about what appears to be a doomed political scheme?

Analysts say the KMT wants to use the recall campaign to maintain momentum to unseat the president, whose son-in-law and senior aides are embroiled in a string of corruption scandals, using that momentum to add pressure on a government led by what they see as a tainted president.

KMT strategists say if the recall motion cannot pass the legislature during its summer extra session, the party in the fall session will put forth a more feasible proposal to topple the Cabinet led by Premier Su Tseng-chang, who was appointed without legislative approval by the scandal-ridden president.
These two legislative moves, plus street demonstrations, are aimed at the ultimate goal of unseating what they claim is a corrupt regime.
A no-confidence vote on the premier requires only half of the legislative votes, which is exactly what the "pan-blue alliance" has in the current legislature.

Liao Feng-teh, who is in charge of the KMT's organizational development, has said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is aware of the risks of the no-confidence motion, but the party has held "war games" for a possible re-election following the overthrow of the Su Cabinet.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun has declared that he will ask the president to dissolve the legislature if the opposition succeeds in bringing down the Cabinet, which he points out is led by a competent premier who has nothing to do with the corruption charges dogging the president.
With "dissolving the legislature" as a firewall, the DPP is confident that "pan-blue alliance" will not dare call a no-confidence vote on Su.

One reason for the DPP's confidence is that the KMT plan might not be supported by its PFP ally, a small party that will likely be "marginalized" in the envisioned legislative election, which will elect only 113 -- or half of the current number of seats -- in a "single constituency, two votes" system that is seen as unfavorable to small parties.

A DPP lawmaker points out that no-one in the current legislature would like to end their terms in office and go into battle for a new term so early. "Since there are so many conflicts of personal interest and contradictions, it will not be difficult for the DPP to abort the KMT plan," he added.

Another DPP insider even foresees the prospect of the PFP fighting the KMT for "pan-blue" nominations in the new election, whereas the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union will stand firmly together to create a battle line across which a "united pan-green camp" will overwhelm a "divided pan-blue alliance" to snatch the legislative majority.

The rules of the next election battle will be a problem as the zoning and other measures, including the design of the ballot, for carrying out the election for a new Legislative Yuan have not yet been completed by the Central Election Commission (CEC).

Under the law, such an election must be held within 60 days of the president disbanding the legislature. People will go to the polls to cast their "two-in-one" ballots -- one for an individual candidate and the other for a political party -- to elect 79 "regional" members and 34 "national and overseas" members of the nation's seventh legislature.

Wang has said that just rezoning the constituencies will be a point of contention, as disputes over this are still heard inside the political parties. "When the CEC submits its new zoning draft to the legislature, the parties will squabble endlessly over it, " he predicts.

Matching measures for implementing the "single constituency, two votes" system have also yet to be adopted. An Executive Yuan proposal for amending the election law for that purpose is still lying on the Legislative Yuan's back burner.

The Executive Yuan and the CEC could hurry up in presenting a proposal for the new rules, but controversy cannot be avoided in the legislature, whose members are good at little other than political bickering.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADER BLAMES GOVERNMENT FOR LAX FLOOD RELIEF OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou criticized the Executive Yuan Sunday for failing to use a reserve fund for relief operations in flood-affected areas in southern Taiwan following more than 10 days of torrential rain across Taiwan.

Ma made the comments after presiding over a ceremony at the Taipei city government in which Ma, who is also Taipei mayor, presented an official flag to a Taipei city task force that will head for southern regions to assist in relief work there after flooding caused by heavy rainfall wreaked havoc in local townships.

Ma blamed the Cabinet for mixing up flood prevention projects and flood relief operations at this critical time on the grounds that the government, instead of using a reserve fund -- an allocation of NT$7.5 billion in budget per year -- to better conduct the ongoing flood relief operations, it is asking for a special budget of NT$80 billion for an eight-year flood control program.

Responding to Ma's criticism, Government Information Office Director-General Cheng Wen-tsan claimed that Ma "lacks a full understanding of the matter, " arguing that the Executive Yuan hopes for the NT$80 billion budget to clear the Legislative Yuan in the coming extra session to allow construction of relevant flood control projects to be started earlier and therefore to help with flood relief more quickly.
The reserve fund is aimed at conducting relief operations, while the flood prevention program will help wipe out the cause of flooding, and the two are complementary, Cheng said.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan the same day, KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang urged President Chen Shui-bian not to try to pass the buck of the current flooding in southern Taiwan to the opposition "pan-blue alliance" by claiming that it is a result of the failed passage of the NT$80 billion budget bill at the "pan-blue"-controlled Legislative Yuan.

The flooding is proof of the DPP government's incompetence over the past six years, according to Pan, who questioned what the government has effectively done with so much resources and budgets every year. She made it clear that the "pan-blue" camp will no doubt seek to recall Chen because of his inability to lead, his abuse of power and corruption.
Pan said that Chen must never lie again to the public and pointed out that the passage of the NT$80 billion budget is no guarantee of no more flooding.

The "pan-blue" and the "pan-green" camps agreed to hold an extra legislative session that will begin this week, in which both the presidential recall motion and the NT$80 billion flood control project have been listed as top key issues for discussion.

Meanwhile, damage to the agriculture sector resulting from recent torrential rain has totaled NT$550 million (US$17.2 million) , according to the newest statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
COA officials said that prices of vegetables and fruit, which have surged by over 20 percent in recent days, will stabilize in two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC TV TO AIR 'LISTENING TO PEOPLE'S VOICES' SPECIAL PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A special program titled "The Way Out -- Listening to the People's Voices" will be aired from Monday at 11 p.m. for four consecutive nights on the public broadcasting system, the Public Television Service (PTS) Foundation said Sunday.
This will be the first joint production by PTS and Chinese Television System (CTS), which joined the public broadcasting system in April 2006, according to the PTS Foundation.

It said the special program was made as the political situation in Taiwan has made many uneasy and disappointed after a series of major events over the past seven years, such as the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake, the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on the United Sates, the peaceful transfer of government in Taiwan in 2000, the SARS outbreaks of 2002, the March 19, 2004 shooting of the president and vice president, the ruling-opposition standoff at the legislature and the worsening social order.

The program will invite civic groups, women, working people, faculty and students, and representatives from other sectors of society to talk about five subjects -- "The identity crisis and political confrontation, " "Bottlenecks in Taiwan's Economic Development and Ways of Breaking Through Them, " "Social Dilemma and Ethnic Conflicts, " "The Next Step for the Education System, " and "How to Break Taiwan's Diplomatic Deadlock?"
The program will be hosted by PTS anchor woman Huang Ming-ming and Professor Lo Chih-cheng of Soochow University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY HELPS EVACUATE FLOOD-TRAPPED PEOPLE FROM MOUNTAINS

TEXT.P: The army helped evacuate hundreds of people from mountainous areas in Kukuan, central Taiwan Sunday, freeing holiday makers who were stuck in flood-stricken tourism locations, officials from the Army Command said later that day.

The army dispatched CH-47SD helicopters to the flood-trapped Kukuan tourism attraction area, where a total of 244 tourists or backpackers were evacuated to safer places in six trips, army officers said.

Meanwhile, the 10th Army Group had activated its natural disaster rescue and relief mechanism by joining city and county governments around central and southern Taiwan since Saturday, offering real-time post-disaster help.

The Eighth Army Group also dispatched some 50 soldiers to help evacuate people in Ahlien and Liukuei rural townships in the southern county of Kaohsiung Saturday in the wake of week-long torrential rain that has triggered flooding and damaged roads. A total of 150 households there were helped, army officers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CRITICIZES CHINA FOR BAN ON COMMENTS ON SCANDALS

TEXT.P: A Chinese ban on its media from commenting on Taiwan's political turmoil was cited Sunday by the Taiwan authorities as an indication of the country's backwardness in terms of democratic development.

Johnnason Liu, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said China is worried that political comments in its media on Taiwan's political struggles could inspire its people to seek more freedom of the press and freedom of expression, both of which are hallmarks of democracy.

China might be able to silence its media but it has difficulty prohibiting its people from discussing Taiwan on the Internet and its limitations on freedom of speech could prompt a backlash among its people, according to Liu.

A mature democracy should give its media free scope to discuss political developments in other places, which would help its people understand the outside world, Liu said, adding that China should allow its media to freely cover Taiwan's events, warts and all.

China's Central Propaganda Department imposed the ban last month when Chinese media were scrambling to carry stories about the political scandals unfolding in Taiwan involving members of the first family and President Chen Shui-bian's close aides.

The Chinese media have monitored closely the development of the scandals that have snowballed into a political struggle with the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party seeking to oust the president and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party rallying behind the beset president.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM, INITIATIVE RESEARCH CENTER IN PIPELINE

TEXT.P: A preparatory conference for the establishment of an international center for the study of referendum and initiative will be held here on June 14 by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD), TFD President Michael Y.M. Kau said Sunday.

In order to be an regional center for the research of referendum, initiative and other rights exercised by people in direct democracy, Kau said the preparatory conference will bring together scholars across Asia to give them an chance to air their views on the proposed center.
It will be a part of the celebration of TFD's third anniversary which falls on June 17.
Founded in 2003, the TFD is a private group devoted to advancing democracy in the world.

An anonymous TFD official said the foundation had planned to invite the former heads of several foreign states to share their countries' experience in developing democracy on the occasion but gave up the idea because of the raging political struggle between the ruling and opposition parties over the alleged scandals involving the President Chen Shui-bian's family members and close aides.
However, the official said, the onging political struggle in Taiwan should be considered as the necessary evil of competition among political parties which is the cornerstone of democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA KEEPS LOW PROFILE AMIDST DOMESTIC POLITICAL TENSION

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang has postponed publicizing a "diplomatic strategy" report and assigning of key personnel to several overseas posts as the domestic politics turned tense over an opposition campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian, officials said Sunday.

They said that while the Ministry of Foreign Affairs looked like "a pool of stagnant water" now, cooperation projects and exchanges of visits were still going on, with major operations being conducted in a low profile.

Since he took over the post four months ago, Huang has weathered such diplomatic storms as the president's decisions to cease the function of the National Unification Council (UNC) and to cancel transit schedules in the United States, and Huang's own visit to the United Arab Emirates.

The UNC controversy, both at home and abroad, is one of the reasons for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of Kuomintang and People First Party to launch a campaign to recall the president, who the alliance charged with creating tension with Taiwan's key ally, -- the U.S. -- and across the Taiwan Strait.

The alliance's unseat-Chen Shui-bian campaign was triggered by the recent judicial investigation and detention of Chen's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming and senior aides, who are embroiled in a string of corruption scandals including insider trading and influence peddling.

The officials said another reason for Huang to delay his publication of the "diplomatic strategy" report is the National Security Council's national security report, which created a political row at home.
Besides putting off his "diplomatic strategy" report, Huang has also deferred appointments of two deputy ministers and top diplomats to the Netherlands, Malaysia and Israel, they added.
The minister has instructed his staff to explain to the international community that what is happening in Taiwan is a price that a country must pay if it insists on being a democracy.

Another priority work for the foreign service is to tell the world that Taiwan is standing firm on its position of maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait area, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGULATORS TO DISCUSS THREAT AGAINST OPPOSITION LEADER

TEXT.P: Members of the National Communications Commission (NCC) will meet Monday to discuss how to deal with unlicensed radio stations' threat against the life of Ma Ying-jeou, chairman fo the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , NCC Spokeswoman Liu You-li said Sunday.
Liu said NCC monitor in southern Taiwan has picked up broadcast of a radio station which encouraged its listeners to end the life of Ma to scuttle KMT's attempt to oust President Chen Shui-bian.
The spokeswoman said the monitor has been asked to sent a tape of the broadcast to the NCC for examination.
Liu said NCC is sure to crack down on unlicensed radio stations, especially those which incite the use of violence.

Unlicensed radio stations in southern Taiwan are mainly the supporters of President Chen Shui-bian and therefore take umbrage at KMT's attempt to recall Chen over scandals involving his in-laws and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:In CEP0015, headlined "TAIWAN INVENTORS WIN BIG AT INPEX 2006",Taiwan has won 13 gold medals, 11 silvers, nine bronzes and threespecial prizes instead of six gold medals, four silvers, one bronzeand two special prizes as sent.A corrected version follows:
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 11 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)
DOC.TEXT:
Taiwan inventors have again demonstrated their ingenuity by winning numerous prizes, including 13 gold medals, at the prestigious INPEX 2006 invention show held in Pittsburgh.
Displaying 27 new inventions at INPEX 2006, which took place June 7-10, Taiwan inventors took home 13 gold medals, 11 silvers and 9 bronzes, as well as three special prizes, representing the highest honor of INPEX -- America's largest invention trade show -- said Chen Tsung-tai, chairman of the Taiwan Inventor's Association, which sponsored Taiwan's participation in INPEX 2006.
All of Taiwan's 27 entries except for one earned at least a prize, Chen said. The inventions, including a smoke-deterrent mask, switches made of fabric and a supersonic wine vibrator which it is claimed makes wine "tastier, " attracted American buyers who have offered money for the requisition of the technologies and patent rights of some of the inventions, according to Chen.
Some of the inventions were also prize-winners at the 34th Geneva Inventions Show that was held in early April. Taiwan inventors won a record-setting number of prizes then, including four special prizes, 15 gold medals, 13 silvers and six bronzes, marking the largest number of honors that Taiwan has ever garnered in the annual competition in Switzerland.
Taiwan won two gold medals, seven bronze medals and two special prizes in INPEX 2005.
According to tallies compiled by a Ministry of Economic Affairs office in charge of investment and trade affairs in the United States, Taiwan inventors won their first U.S. patent in 1973. Between January 2000 and May 2006, nearly 5,000 Taiwan products have obtained U.S. patent rights, the officials said.

Three detainees being held at the United States military prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, committed suicide early on Saturday, the first deaths of detainees to be reported at the military prison since it opened in early 2002, United States military officials said. The deaths come at a time of mounting international criticism of the Bush administration's handling of terrorism suspects at Guantanamo and other prisons around the world. Military officials on Saturday suggested that the three suicides were a form of a coordinated protest.
