DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 12, or the 17th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before being taken to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1938: China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: A strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human-powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohammed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabic.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of British prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served in the post for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other British prime minister in the 20th century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti-Communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members from both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
2000: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology kicks off its three-day session in Taipei with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.
2001: The Republic of China opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan gives a speech at Oxford University in the United Kingdom in which he focuses on Taiwan's economic and political situations and the future of his party.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

Liu said the NCC will crack down on unlicensed radio stations, especially those which incite violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS MEET TO DECIDE WHETHER EXTRA SESSION NEEDED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan held an informal meeting Monday to discuss whether and when an extraordinary session will be convened as well as the session's agenda.

Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who convened negotiations among legislators across the political spectrum at 10 a.m. Monday over the much-talked-about extra legislative session, said that if a consensus cannot be reached on the schedule and agenda of the session in Monday's informal meeting, a vote will be held to decide matters.

Meanwhile, Ker Chien-ming, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , made an appeal to the opposition lawmakers to let pressing bills concerning the people's welfare, including a flood-prevention budget, top the agenda of the extra session.

Ker termed the opposition Kuomintang's and the People First Party's intention of putting a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian at the top of the extra session's agenda as "using the extra session as a tool of political dogfighting and mudslinging."

Ker called for the opposition legislators to forsake their "political persecution bid" and instead focus their energy on bills pertaining to the people's wellbeing. He said that if the opposition insists on putting the recall motion at the top of the extra session's agenda, a vote at the informal meeting will then be unavoidable.
Meanwhile, PFP Chairman James Soong planted himself at the PFP legislative caucus Monday to ensure that the recall motion is placed at the top of the agenda.
Soong said a day earlier that PFP-initiated street rallies will not cease until the day the president is unseated.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has also planned a series of new public rallies islandwide calling for the recall of Chen, including one in the central county of Changhua on June 17 and another in Taipei City on a day yet to be decided.
The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP enjoys a slim majority in the legislature but falls far short of the two-thirds majority that is needed to pass a recall motion.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its Taiwan Solidarity Union ally, who together form the "pan-green camp, " are not likely to support a motion to unseat Chen, even though his senior aides and son-in-law Chao Chien-ming are being detained and investigated for suspected involvement in a string of corruption scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MOVES TO NEW HOME

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) moved Monday to its new home on Pateh Road in downtown Taipei from Chungshan South Road where it had been headquartered since 1949 when it led the Republic of China government in relocating from China to Taiwan.
A formal opening ceremony will be held Wednesday at the KMT's new central headquarters in the Pateh Building, according to the party.

The KMT had ruled Taiwan until 2000 when it lost the presidential election. Since then, there has been a call from party members for the KMT to move out of the gallant Central Headquarters building on the Chungshan South Road as part of efforts to get rid of its stereotyped image as a wealthy political party.
The old building has been sold to the private Evergreen Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS HIGHEST INCIDENCE OF URENIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the highest incidence of urenia, a kidney disease, in the world, with 385 new cases for every 1 million people every year, a National Cheng Kung University Hospital doctor said Monday.

Nephrologist Sung Junne-ming also said the counties of Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan in southern Taiwan have the highest incidence of urenia in Taiwan, averaging 514 new cases per one million people annually.
Sung noted that a U.S. kidney research organization found that the number of patients in Taiwan that require dialysis is around 42,000, or the highest figure in the world.

Taiwan spends up to NT$25 billion (US$769.23 million) on dialysis every year. This, along with the NT$40 billion spent on dealing with related complications, accounts for the largest portion of national health insurance spending.
He said that the early symptoms of kidney disease are not apparent and that 50 percent of the patients have no symptoms in the initial stages and could easily miss early treatment.

He urged people in high-risk groups for kidney disease, such as seniors, smokers, those from families with a history of kidney disease, and those with high blood pressure, diabetes, or urine with abnormal levels, to be on guard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SET UP COMPUTER INFORMATION CENTERS TO HELP AFRICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate computer equipment and send information engineers to its diplomatic allies in Africa to establish "Taiwan Information Centers, " Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang said Monday.
Huang said that the information centers will provide computer hardware, Internet connection and engineers to teach locals how to connect to cyberspace and the wider world.

He said that the idea of establishing the information centers came to him when he visited several African countries in April. He said he found that young people in Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Africa are eager to learn about computers and gain access to information but that governmental institutions in these countries have trouble acquiring enough computer hardware.
Huang stressed that establishing the information centers won't cost much and will help many African people as well as win friendship from their governments.

He said that many countries admire Taiwan's achievements in high-tech and computer technology and hope that Taiwan can help them digitize their government administrative operations and make them more efficient. He added that Taiwan is going to make more efforts in this direction in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS SET SCHEDULE, AGENDA FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan decided Monday to convene an extraordinary legislative session June 13-30 to handle 14 bills, including an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian and a flood-control budget bill.

After two rounds of voting at an informal meeting, legislators from across the political spectrum finalized the time schedule and agenda of the extra session at a time when the opposition has been heaping pressure on Chen to step down while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party insists that an extra session should be convened only to review budgets related to flood-fighting and other issues pertaining to the people's welfare.
The voting on the legislative extra session's schedule and agenda proceeded in an unexpectedly calm atmosphere at the Legislative Yuan, except for some slight pushing and pulling during debates.

Other bills that the legislators decided to deal with in the upcoming extraordinary session include a budget bill for an overhaul of Shihmen Dam, budget bills for state-owned enterprises, special budgets to expand infrastructure, and revisions to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

Bills concerning the redistricting for legislative elections, an amendment to an act on treatment for retired presidents and vice presidents, as well as development projects in offshore areas -- all matters that remained unaddressed when the last session ended May 30 -- have also been included in the extra session's agenda.
Meanwhile, opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said that PFP-initiated street rallies will not cease until the day the president is unseated.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has also planned a series of new public rallies islandwide calling for the recall of Chen, including one in the central county of Changhua on June 17 and another in Taipei City on a day yet to be decided.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has decided to push to recall President Chen, believing his leadership is in doubt in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
The "pan-blue alliance" enjoys a slim majority in the legislature but falls far short of the two-thirds majority that is needed to pass a recall motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU ISLAND TO DEVELOP VACATION RESORT UNDER BOT MODEL

TEXT.P: The Penghu National Scenic Area Administration will sign a contract with a local development company June 15 for the construction of a multi-functional vacation resort under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

The signing ceremony will be presided over by Hsu Wen-sheng, director of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, with Chen A-ping, director of the Penghu National Scenic Area Administration, and Shih Lien-an, chairman of the Tingsheng Development Co., signing the contract.

The planned vacation resort will be located on Yuweng Island (Fisherman Island), one of the three main islets of Penghu, and near the Cross-Sea Bridge, the longest inter-island bridge in the Far East.
With more than four years of planning, the proposed tourist development project will be constructed under the BOT model, with an initial investment totalling NT$1.2 billion (US$37 million).

Under the BOT model, private investors receive a franchise from the government to finance, design, construct and operate a facility for a specific period of time before turning it over to the government.
The government plans to take over the operations of the vacation resort after 50 years under the contract.
The multi-funcional vacation resort will boast a natural sea water SPA area, a five-star hotel with 250 rooms, a SPA hotel with 100 rooms, and several large convention centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO SELECT CANDIDATE TO RUN IN TAIPEI MAYORAL ELECTION BY JULY 16

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will nominate a candidate to run in the year-end Taipei mayoral election before the party's national congress opens July 17, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

Yu declined to talk about who is likely to represent the DPP in the election, only indicating that Legislator Yu Chin, whose application to run in the DPP primary was withdrawn last month due to a lack of required documents, has not given up his efforts to win the nomination.

Because of Yu Chin's determination to run in the Taipei election, former Premier Frank Hsieh, regarded as the DPP's best bet for the Taipei mayoral race, has continued to decline calls for him to run, according to the party.
Hsieh has said that he will only consent to run if there are no others within the party seeking the nomination.

In order to persuade the influential and popular politician to represent the party in the election, efforts are being made to dissuade Yu Chin from continuing with his campaign, the DPP chairman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 1.73 points to close at 6,442.9.
The bourse opened at 6,384.32 and fluctuated between 6,443.21 and 6,339.24 during trading. A total of 2.22 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.61 billion (US$2.29 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues and construction issues both moving up at 2 percent and banking and financial shares gaining 0.4 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 439 to 305, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN GROUP TO START RENOVATION OF FORMER KMT HEAD OFFICE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's shipping giant, Evergreen Group, said Monday that it will apply to renovate the former head office of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) at the end of this month.
An Evergreen spokesman said that the group has invited architects to plan for renovation and that the work is expected to be completed in one year.
The KMT signed an agreement in March to sell its building on Chungshan South Road opposite the Presidential Office to the group for NT$2.3 billion (US$70.7 million).

The Evergreen Group has agreed to let the KMT use a basement floor of the building to display the party's historical documents. It has also promised to use the building for charitable, cultural and educational purposes only for the next 10 years and not to sell the building to a third party.

Chang Jung-fa, chairman of the Evergreen Group, said that it will renovate the building to turn it into the site of a foundation named after him. A planned marine museum will also be housed in the building, and the Evergreen Symphony Orchestra will use the basement as a practice venue.
The KMT has moved to a more modest, eight-story building on Pateh Road.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAINS CAUSE NEARLY NT$800 MILLION IN FARM PRODUCE LOSSES

TEXT.P: Days of torrential rain in central Taiwan have caused an estimated NT$798.5 million in damage to farm produce, including vegetables, fruit and poultry, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Monday.
Most severely damaged were watermelons, grapes and rice, the officials said while the COA announced an aid program for farmers in affected areas from Hsinchu in the north to Chiayi in the south.

The COA estimated agricultural losses at NT$668 million for 3,591 hectares of farmland, or 18 percent of the total, with lost crops including rice, watermelons, grapes, pears, oranges and green vegetables such as spring onions.
Stock losses, including hogs, chickens, ducks and geese, were estimated at NT$6.4 million and fishery losses were estimated at NT$1.8 million, mainly in Chiayi and Yunlin counties.
Farmland that has been inundated or washed away represented estimated losses of NT$33.8 million.
The COA said it is offering cash aid and low-interest loans to help affected farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for June gained four points to close at 6,379, with 50,729 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose four points to finish at 6,295, with 1,169 contract transactions, while September futures moved up 16 points to close at 6,232, with 75 contracts traded.
December futures dropped five points to finish at 6,225, with 36 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 20 points to close at 6,250, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,375 for June, 6,328 for July, 6,216 for September, 6,230 for December, and 6,230 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
June TE futures dropped 1.35 points to close at 268.25, with 5,235 contract transactions, while July TE futures moved down 1.75 points to finish at 267, with 118 contracts traded.
September TE futures lost 4.05 points to close at 260, with four contracts traded, while March TE futures moved down 9.8 points to finish at 262.15, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.
June TF futures moved up 4.8 points to close at 928.8, with 3,369 contract transactions, while July TF gained five points to finish at 922, with 55 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped two points to close at 903, with three contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH PRIEST DOUBLES AS RECYCLER TO SUPPORT HANDICAPPED

TEXT.P: French Catholic Father Yves Moal, who has been preaching in Taiwan for the past 40 years, is supporting a home for the handicapped in Hualien, eastern Taiwan with funds he earns by collecting recyclable garbage.

Moal, who is better known in Taiwan by his Chinese name, Father Liu Yi-feng, preaches at his church located in Yuli, Hualien every Sunday, manages the Andrew Handicapped Center located in the annex of the church and toils at a dump in a Yuli suburb as a recycler in between.
Moal earned NT$10 by selling a bundle of used newspapers eight years ago, which began his garbage collecting career. Today, Father Liu is a symbol of "turning dirt into fortune" in eastern Taiwan.

Currently, Moal's Andrew Handicapped Center accommodates 43 mentally and physically challenged people aged between eight and 40. Of them, four adults work at the church's dump, earning money for themselves and for the church as well.

The dump, where residents of nearby boroughs send their recyclable waste, has been a hen laying golden eggs for the church. An average of NT$500,000 is generated from the plant each year for Moal, enabling him to operate the handicapped center and support the residents' daily lives. The center also gets government subsidies.

Moal, who was assigned to Taiwan at the age of 25 as a missionary by the Paris Foreign Mission Society, is often mistaken for a garbage collector, but when asked if he ever gets tired of his "dirty work," the energetic father says: "There's gold in that garbage."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy's day in World Cup arrives.
The Itakian team will make its debut in the 2006 soccer World Cup Monday by playing against Ghana. Midfielder superstar Francesco Totti will be one of the starters. Manager Marcello Lippi assured Italian people that "We will make you satisfied."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD SHOW TO OPEN JUNE 21

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taipei International Food Show will begin later this month, providing a platform upon which foreign buyers and Taiwan food producers can forge business agreements, organizers said Monday.

According to a spokesman for the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), the exhibition will be held June 21-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 540 companies from around the world, including the United States, Canada, Spain, Chile, Japan, South Korea, Germany, Demark, France, Mexico and the Philippines, among others from Central America and Africa, showcasing their products at 1,570 booths.

Buyers from hypermarkets in 11 countries, including China, Japan, South Korea, Singapore and Britain, will seize the opportunity to purchase Taiwan-produced foodstuffs, the spokesman said, adding that some foreign buyers are from companies that have allocated a procurement budget of more than NT$10 billion (US$312.5 million) this year.
The Taipei International Food Show is the second-largest of its kind in Asia behind only the Tokyo International Food Show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS TO TAKE PART IN HONG KONG FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 12 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan legislators from across Taiwan's political spectrum have been invited to take part in a Hong Kong forum on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation slated for Thursday.

The lawmakers, including legislators Hung Chi-chang and Lin Cho-shui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, legislators John Chiang and Wu Yu-sheng of the opposition Kuomintang and opposition New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming, are expected to join 400 academics and political observers from Hong Kong and China at the "Hong Kong, Taiwan, China Peace Development Forum."

Topics expected to be up for discussion at the forum include the impact of the present Taiwan political climate on the development of cross-strait relations and the economic fusion among Taiwan, Hong Kong and China, as well as the marginalization of their economies, said Chiang Su-hui, chairwoman of the Hong Kong Cultural Exchange Foundation and vice chairwoman of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong, the two organizations that are sponsoring the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.093 to close at NT$32.543.
A total of US$829 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.531 and fluctuated between NT$32.410 and NT$32.583.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS TONE FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) set the tone Monday for the coming extra legislative session, deciding to focus attention on a flood-fighting budget bill while seeking to hold off discussion of some disputed bills.

The Legislative Yuan resolved earlier that same day that an extra session will be held June 13-30, and voted to list 14 bills on its agenda, including an opposition "pan-blue alliance"-initiated presidential recall motion and the flood prevention project bill.

DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said following a DPP legislative caucus meeting that the party is determined to push the flood control budget bill through the legislative session but will oppose the motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian until the end.

Amid the many corruption allegations implicating family members and close aides of Chen that have pushed the DPP's public approval rating to ever-descending record lows, Lin said the party will run advertisements in local media in an attempt to clear the many suspicious cases with what he claimed is "concrete evidence."
The next round of the DPP's publicity campaign will center on "democracy versus political infighting, " "truth versus blowing out scandals" and "law and order versus corruption," Lin said.
DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming demanded that main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou first heed bills related to public interest instead of engaging in political strife.

Ker urged Ma to firmly stand his ground and not to be blackmailed by its "pan-blue alliance" partner the People First Party (PFP) , which initiated the presidential recall motion that the ruling party claims would "hinder" national development.

DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin warned the "pan-blue alliance" of "serious consequences" if the two parties provoke confrontation. The Taiwan people are hoping for political stability and a normal life, she added.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen told a news conference that her party gave a thumbs-up to the Legislative Yuan's decision to hold an extra session and said the KMT will seek to promote the passage of the presidential recall motion, the flood control budget bill and other bills critical to people's livelihoods.

Insisting that the presidential recall motion and the flood prevention project bill are not contradictory and that both matters can be dealt with in the extra legislative session, Cheng said the DPP must not turn a deaf ear to what she claimed is "the people's call" for Chen to step down and must not try to divert public attention from the issue by releasing "misinformation."
Attempting to do so will just underscore the DPP's image of inability to govern the country over the past six years, she added.

Commenting on the DPP's plan to mobilize supporters to take to the streets to protect Chen and what his party has taken to calling his "Taiwanese regime, " Cheng told the DPP that as the governing party, it should not "boss people around on the streets."

In the face of mounting public pressure for Chen to step down, the DPP should realize that it is not right to shun the issue and should instead face up to the public anger by taking concrete measures, she said.

PFP Chairman James Soong has vowed to return to Kategalan Boulevard Friday to stage a protest if a vote on the presidential recall motion is again disrupted by the pan-green lawmakers of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DISAPPOINTED RECALL INCLUDED IN EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang expressed deep disappointment Monday after the Legislative Yuan decided to include a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian on the agenda of an extraordinary session of the legislature set to be held June 13-30.

The Procedure Committee passed the proposal of the main opposition Kuomintang to make the recall top of the 14-point agenda, and said the case will be reviewed June 21-23 and June 26 on the legislative floor before being put to a vote June 27.
The opposition initiated the recall motion, believing Chen's leadership is in doubt following a spate of corruption allegations against his son-in-law and close aides.

The premier expressed disappointment after a luncheon with ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and Ker Chien-ming, DPP caucus whip in the legislature. Ker later said that to integrate the administrative, legislative and party affairs, they plan to have a luncheon every Monday.

Cheng Wen-tsan, minister of the Government Information Office, said that over the past six years, the extraordinary session of the legislature has had simple missions and each time it has achieved fruitful results.
Cheng expressed the hope that this extraordinary session will be no exception and that it will focus on issues related to the public and the economy.

He lashed out at the opposition parties for "putting politics before public interest" and expressed hope that the opposition parties will focus on bills related to flood-control, budgets for state-owned enterprises and for 10 new construction projects, saying that national development should not stop because of the stalled bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN AIR RAID DRILL SCHEDULED FOR JUNE 15

TEXT.P: An air raid drill for central Taiwan will take place June 15 as part of the 2006 defense exercise codenamed Wanan No. 29, the Taichung City Reserve Command announced Monday.
A spokesman for the reserve command said the air-raid alarm will be sounded at 2 p.m. Thursday, with the all-clear signal given 30 minutes later.

During the 30-minute exercise, all pedestrians and drivers in the region should follow instructions from police and military police to go into basements of private buildings or move to designated underground shelters, the spokesman said.
The movements of trains and cars on freeways will not be affected, but passengers who disembark at a station and cars that exit a freeway must be evacuated to shelters, he said.
The spokesman added that the annual exercise is intended to increase the people's preparedness against possible air strikes and raise the effectiveness of the nation's security network.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT PAY PAYABLE DESPITE WORKING SHORT-TERM JOBS: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday that people can still claim unemployment pay if they take a short-term job.
CLA officials said that since jobless people need time to adjust when seeking new jobs, if they land a job but leave before two weeks, it will be regarded as a case of "uncertain employment."

However, those who are on fixed-term contracts, such as temporary staff or replacement teachers, will be deemed as involuntary departures if they leave when their contracts expire and will be eligible for unemployment pay one month after they leave their old jobs and have not landed a new job.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER AWARDS WINNERS AT 'DOORS TO DIPLOMACY' COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Chih-fang received Taiwan students Monday who won awards at the 2006 global Web competition "Doors to Diplomacy."

The "Doors to Diplomacy" award is funded by the U.S. Department of State, with the Global SchoolNet Foundation (GSF) organizing the competition, which is aimed at encouraging middle school and high school students around the world to produce Web projects that highlight the importance of international affairs and diplomacy.
Taiwan student teams won a silver award and two honorable mentions at the competition, the fourth of its kind.

Among the 305 projects competing, Ming-Dao High School won the silver award, with a project titled "Be a Good Global Citizen, Say No to Tobacco, " while teams from Wego Private Senior High School and Yu Da High School of Commerce and Home Economics garnered the honorable mentions, with projects titled "Out of the Darkness -- Chiang Ching-kuo and Taiwan" and "Nano from Mantmartre," respectively.

To increase Taiwan youngsters' concern over international and diplomatic affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Taiwan Information Technology Education Development Association also organized a similar competition last year.
Huang encouraged more Taiwan students to participate in such competitions in order to more closely connect with the world community.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FACTION PLEDGES FULL SUPPORT FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The New Tide faction of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) pledged Monday to support President Chen Shui-bian in his bid to "continue leading the Taiwan sovereigntist regime."

The New Tide faction, seen as the most disciplined and cohesive among the DPP's factions, threw its support behind a besieged Chen after the legislature decided to go ahead with an opposition-initiated motion to recall the president, whose senior aides and son-in-law are being detained or investigated for suspected involvement in a string of corruption scandals.

Legislator William Lai, convener of the New Tide faction, said his group opposes the recall motion and an expected no-confidence motion against Premier Su Tseng-chang, claiming that the campaigns are nothing but a tool of the opposition's "political struggle" against the DPP government.

Lai was referring to James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) , who called on "conscientious" members of the New Tide faction to rebel against the party hierarchy by demanding that the president step down to take moral, social and political responsibility for the suspected wrongdoings of his senior aides and family members.

Lai rebutted Soong by claiming that governing power is temporary while the country and its people last forever. "Now the people are suffering floods, but the 'pan-blue alliance' is waging a political struggle that will never be accepted by the people," Lai claimed.

Former New Tide convener Tuan Yi-kang also responded to Soong's attempt to drive a wedge between the New Tide and their DPP comrades, saying it is dangerous in Taiwan society, which is plagued by a tinder box of ethnic division, for a political leader to seek personal gains at the cost of igniting that tinder box.
Tuan went on to accuse KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who claims to be a "moderate" in politics, of having been forced by Soong into doing things that please radicals in the "pan-blue alliance."

Soong was trying to provoke DPP animosity toward the New Tide and to create a division in the DPP, Tuan said, adding that such a strategy might work for the short term but will only serve to aggravate political confrontations.

Lee Wen-chung, convener of the faction's legislative caucus, said the faction has been criticizing the DPP government's mistakes and mis-steps, but he pointed out that there are simply no legitimate reasons for recalling the president.

By calling itself the "Taiwan sovereigntist regime, " the DPP government and its "pan-green camp" ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union are suggesting that both Ma and Soong have their roots in China and are therefore unfit to lead a Taiwanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO NEED' TO SEARCH HOME OF PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW: PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: Law enforcers did not search the Taipei residence of Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law who has been detained over insider trading, because "there is no need to do so, " a prosecutor at the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office said Monday.

Lin Pang-liang, Assistant Director of the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office, said investigators have already gathered sufficient evidence from Chao's alleged accomplices in the case, and prosecutors in charge of the investigation believe after consulting with detectives from the Investigation Bureau it is unnecessary to search Chao's home.

He denied news reports that day that Yen Ta-he, chief of the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office ordered investigators in a meeting May 21 not to search Chao's house, which used to be President Chen Shui-bian's apartment before he was elected in 2000.

Lin said Yen did huddle with two leading investigators -- not a dozen investigators as reported -- over the case May 21, but he only exchanged views with them about how to subpoena Chao's father Chao Yu-chu, who is also involved in the case, and the issue of searching the workplaces and residences of people involved in the case was not broached.
The decision to search or not to search a place is taken jointly by the prosecutors and investigators through thorough discussion, Lin said.

Lin was responding to opposition lawmakers' criticism that prosecutors were pressed by their superior into making Chao's house off-limits to investigators, although he had been held in custody since May 25 pending the conclusion of the investigation.

Lin also explained that Dr. Huang Fang-yen, a close friend of the first family who was accused by an opposition lawmaker of relaying to first lady Wu Shu-jen a huge amount of gift vouchers given by a businessman, has been subpoenaed by the prosecutors but has asked for leave of absence until next month.
Lin said the prosecutors leading the investigation of that allegation will decide what to do next.
Huang, the deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Hospital in Taipei, is currently in the United States for treatment of prostate cancer.

Opposition lawmakers claim that he fled the country after being tipped off by friends in government that he was targeted for questioning by investigators looking into the alleged scandal surrounding the first lady.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO BREAK MYTH OF 'GIFTED EDUCATION CLASS': SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Academics and experts in education called on the government, the educational sector and parents Monday to work together in an effort to break the myth of the "gifted education class" -- a system criticized for having seriously distorted Taiwan's gifted education system.

They made the call during a forum held at the College of Education of National Taiwan Normal University by the private Education Reconstruction Front to review the education reforms that the government has carried out over the past 10 years.

"Why must the child be in a gifted class? " was the topic of the forum amid public concern over the issue after four county and city governments in central Taiwan held a joint examination May 13 to select "gifted" sixth-grade students in order to place them in so-called "excellent classes" in junior high school.

Lin Chin-yuan, a Tamkang University associate professor of economics, blamed the existence of such "special classes" on the demand of Taiwan people for a "university degree, " saying that most people regard university as the only way for them to find a good job or to have high social status.

However, the trend among youths to spend all their energy on seeking a "perfect" academic performance has only caused problems like "over education, " which sees many university graduates seek an advanced education merely because they want a higher social status or a better job, and the problem of "distorted gifted education," which sees a concentration of education resources on the "gifted class" students.

The May 13 gifted students selection examination drew protests from many teachers and parents who claim the test is a tactic by public junior high schools to "divide their future students into classes according to their academic performance."

Over 20,000 students from elementary schools in Taichung City and the counties of Taichung, Changhua and Nantou took part in the joint exam to strive for a place in one of the few privileged "gifted classes."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY TO STUDY SOCIAL WELFARE PROGRAMS FOR AGING SOCIETY

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Lee Yi-yang said Monday that the ministry is studying subsidies and other social welfare measures to deal with declining birth rates and an aging society.

Lee made the remarks at a meeting with academics, experts and leaders of social welfare groups in Kaoshiung, southern Taiwan, which is part of the ministry's preparation for one of the topics on the agenda of a planned national economic conference -- how to deal with the impact of an aging society and declining birth rates, as well as a national pension system.

Ministry of the Interior (MOI) officials said the birth rate was 9.06 percent in 2005, compared with 49.97 percent in 1951. The elderly aged over 65 were 9.74 percent in 2005, compared with 2.5 percent in 1949 and 7 percent in 1993.

To avoid younger generations having to shoulder the heavy responsibility of supporting the elderly at a rate of every 3.3 young person having to support one elderly person in 2026 from the current 7.4 youths, the ministry is studying whether to promote subsides for birth, nursing and the opening of a national pension system.
Lee said the national pension system will mainly target those who have yet to be covered by social security, estimated at around 2.7 million people.

He also said the ministry is studying whether to have the surplus of the public welfare lottery and a hike in business tax by 1 percent to finance the extra spending. If there is still a shortfall, then the central government will appropriate budgets, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU MAY STAGE RALLY JUNE 27 TO PROTEST PRESIDENTIAL RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a minor opposition party in league with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Monday it might stage a rally June 27 to "surround the legislature with 100,000 people, " at a time when the legislature will likely be voting on an opposition-initiated motion to recall the president.

Ho Min-hao, executive director of the TSU's Policy Committee, said the mass rally is aimed at protesting the "pan-blue alliance's unreasonable campaign" to recall President Chen Shui-bian and at protecting "Taiwan's sovereign regime" led by Chen.

The recall move by the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party alliance has triggered a sense of crisis in the TSU and its "pan-green camp" ally, the DPP, as they perceived Taiwan's sovereign government in danger of being toppled by the KMT and PFP, and led by Ma Ying-jeou and James Soong -- whose roots in China have led people like TSU's spiritual leader, former president Lee Teng-hui, to call the former KMT government "an alien regime."
According to the Constitution, Vice President Annette Lu will replace Chen if he is recalled.

Ho said the pan-blue alliance's motion to recall the president, which he claimed is "unlikely to pass the legislature, " is but a prelude to a future no-confidence motion against Premier Su Tseng-chang.

If the opposition succeeds in toppling Su's Cabinet -- which is possible given the alliance's slim majority in the legislature -- it will force the president to choose between sacking Su and dissolving the Legislative Yuan, Ho said.

If Chen dissolves the current legislature, the pan-blue alliance will try to win two-thirds of the 113 seats in the new legislature, he said, noting this will provide the pan-blues another chance to launch a second presidential recall motion.
He called on Chen to beware of the pan-blues' strategy and to "stand firm and never give in to opposition pressure."

For his part, he said the TSU would like to help Chen by holding a mass rally to surround the legislature on June 27 to protest the pan-blue alliance's attempt to overthrow "Taiwan's sovereign regime."

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO DONATE BLOOD

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese Blood Services Foundation (CBSF) urged the public to donate blood Monday in anticipation of an upcoming shortage in summer.

While expressing gratitude to more than six million blood donors in Taiwan who have donated blood over the past years, Tsung Ping, director of the CBSF's Department of Public Relations, urged the public to donate blood to the needy, especially AB blood type, which is always in short supply.

According to Tsung, blood donation centers in schools usually close over the summer vacation. However, summer is the season when people do more outdoor activities and get into more accidents, and therefore in need of more blood transfusions, Tsung added.
As the main theme of this year's World Blood Donor Day, which falls in June 14, is "commitment, " Tsung encouraged current and future blood donors to make a pledge to donate regularly.
To express its gratitude toward the non-remunerated volunteers, CBSF's blood collection centers will be giving out free T-shirts to blood donors on June 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESCENDENT OF TAIWAN'S LAST DUTCH GOVERNOR VISITS TAINAN

TEXT.P: The descendent of Fredrich Coyet, the last Dutch governor of Taiwan, visited Koxinga's Shrine in the southern city of Tainan Monday to pay homage to Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, who forced the Dutch out in 1662.
Michael Coyet, the 14th generation of Fredrich's offspring, paid the visit along with his wife and 22-year-old daughter Amelie Coyet.
Michael Coyet said the journey was the last wish of his ancestor, who hoped his offsping could return to set foot in Taiwan someday.
Accompanied by Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai, the Coyets toured historic relics of establishments constructed more than 300 years ago, during and after the Dutch colonization.
The Coyets are scheduled to leave Taiwan Tuesday, except Amelie, a student of Lund University in Sweden, who will continue to stay on the island for two more weeks.
Fredrich, a Swedish aristocrat, was named by the Dutch East India Company to serve as Taiwan's governor in 1657.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD SENDS PATROLS TO HELP TROUBLED TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: Two coast guard vessels are on their way to open seas near Japan's Iwo Jima island in the Pacific Ocean to intercept a Taiwanese fishing boat whose skipper was allegedly killed by Chinese crewmembers last weekend, officials said Monday.

The Paohsing and Hohsing patrol vessels, with SWAT team officers and criminal investigation agents aboard, have been assigned to help the Hsinglung fishing boat from the Suao fishing port in northeast Yilan County, the officials said, adding that the two patrols are expected to catch up with the Hsinglung in three or four days.

According to a report from Taiwan's representative office in Yokohama, the Japanese coast guard received a distress call from the Suao-based fishing boat June 10. In addition to relaying the message to Taiwan, Japan's coast guard dispatched a surveillance plane to search for the Taiwanese fishing boat.
Japanese coast guard officers discovered that the Taiwanese skipper, identified as Chen Mu-tsai, was killed Saturday afternoon.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu quoted the report by the Yokohama representative office as saying the boat is being "closely monitored" by Japanese coast guard authorities.

Lu said the Hsinglung, which had been operating in high seas near Iwo Jima since March this year, is sailing northwestward. As Japan is not in a position to deal with the case, Lu said Taiwan's coast guard authorities have decided to dispatch two patrol vessels to intercept the boat.
The latest reports said the boat's Taiwanese first mate, Huang Chin-hsing, has remained missing since Saturday.
Besides the Taiwanese skipper and first mate, the Hsinglung crew also included eight Chinese fishery workers.

It was the second time that the boat's two Taiwanese crew members have been overpowered by Chinese fishery workers onboard. In August 200, Chen and Huang were held hostage by nine Chinese crewmen who then steered the Hsinglung to Hawaii. The Chinese crewmen were arrested by U.S. immigration authorities upon arrival. At first, Chen and Huang were also taken into custody and the Hsinglung was impounded by U.S. authorities because the Chinese crewmen accused the duo of having helped them sneak into Hawaii.

The Yilan Prosecutor's Office sent personnel to the United States to look into the case. Chen and Huang were indicted on charges of helping smuggle Chinese fishery workers into the United States, but they were later acquitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TRADING CENTERS TO PROMOTE SALES OF QUALITY TAIWAN RICE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will set up four rice-trading centers -- in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan -- to promote sales of locally produced varieties of premium quality rice, a COA spokesman said Monday.
The spokesman said the trading center located in Tainan, southern Taiwan, will become operational June 22, whereas the center in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, opens July 6.
The northern Taiwan center in Taoyuan City and the central Taiwan center in Yuanlin township, Changhuan County, will begin to provide services in the second half of November.
The spokesman added that officials from the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency will provide free services at these centers to match buyers with suppliers.

He said all rice products offered at these centers must meet requirements of Grade 1 and Grade 2 of the Chinese National Standards, and come with complete information about the growers, places of origin, names of rice varieties and certification to prove they were harvested less than one year ago.
The spokesman added that there are no restrictions on buyers, except that each order must be no less than five metric tons.

In establishing these rice-trading centers, the COA aims to ensure that all rice transactions are well-protected, he explained, adding that the success of these centers could pave the way toward becoming export hubs for high-quality Taiwan rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS TO RALLY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A dozen pro-Taiwan independence groups announced Monday that they will rally on Kategalan Boulevard Saturday to show support for President Chen Shui-bian amid the opposition's efforts to recall him.

Representatives of the groups, including the Northern Taiwan Society and the World United Formosans for Independence (WUFI), made the announcement at a joint news conference in which they urged the public to take to the streets "to display their support for Taiwan."

According to Northern Taiwan Society Chairman Wu Shu-min, the current woes faced by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration are mainly the result of its failure to make a "clean sweep" when it took over the presidency from the Kuomintang (KMT) six years ago, claiming that many corruption scandals originated from the KMT era.

Commenting on the recent string of corruption scandals allegedly involving Chen's family members and close aides, Wu said he will send a letter to Premier Su Tseng-chang and Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin asking them to treat political figures and all people that have committed wrongdoings with the same standards.

WUFI Secretary-General Mao Ching-feng asked the opposition "pan-blue alliance" not to further rehash relevant cases and demand Chen's resignation, claiming that more political maneuvering will only lead to greater confrontation.

The June 17 rally was originally feared likely to bring to a boil the confrontation between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green camp," as the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) were to hold a demonstration a day earlier at the same venue and said that they would never leave if "pan-green" lawmakers disrupt a presidential recall motion at the Legislative Yuan Friday.

But a new development suggested that the confrontation might be headed off as PFP Chairman James Soong said late Monday that they might hold the demonstration at a later date, pending the agenda of the Legislative Yuan as to when to deal with the presidential recall motion.

According to Soong, he will visit the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to make sure PFP lawmakers vote to have the presidential recall motion included at the Procedure Committee to allow the motion to be handled Friday along with a bill relating to a budget for a flood control project.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCPES SIGNS AGREEMENTS WITH JAPANESE, U.S. UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: The National College of Physical Education and Sports (NCPES) signed cooperative agreements with two foreign universities Monday in hopes of boosting the competitiveness of teachers and students in physical education here.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng presided over the signing ceremony for cooperative agreements between the NCPES and the University of Northern Colorado in the United States and a sports university in Osaka, Japan.
Tu said he hopes that NCPES cooperation and exchanges with the two universities will help Taiwan boost its competitiveness in physical education and sports.

Meanwhile, a symposium on developing trends in physical education in Taiwan, Japan, the U.S. and South Korea will be held Tuesday. Scholars and specialists in physical education are scheduled to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS ADVISES PRESIDENT TO RESPOND TO RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: The leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus urged President Chen Shui-bian Monday to prepare a response to a legislative motion calling for his recall.

The opposition-initiated motion was put on the legislative agenda to be dealt with during an extra session of the Legislative Yuan that will last until June 30. Other pending legislation on the agenda includes a special budget for flood-control projects.
As the legislature is set to debate the recall motion, said caucus convener Ko Chien-ming, "there is no reason for the president not to make a response."
"If the president does not try to explain himself, wouldn't that be seen as tacitly admitting to the opposition's charges?" he added.

The motion has yet to pass the Procedural Committee before it is to be discussed during plenary sessions of the legislature, which is obligated to inform the subject of the recall motion to answer charges made against him seven days before the issue is debated on the legislative floor.
If the subject of the recall does not reply to the charges, the legislature's plenary meeting can still debate the issue before putting it to a vote.
If more than two-thirds of legislators vote "yes," the resolution still has to be approved by national referendum in order to become finally effective.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Prisoners' Ruse Is Inquiry Focus at Guantanamo
Three detainees at the United States military prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, tried to conceal themselves in their cells -- behind laundry and through other means -- to prevent guards from seeing them commit suicide, Military officials said one focus of an investigation into the suicides would be the need for procedural changes, like barring prisoners from doing laundry in their cells.
Wall Street Journal: Reality TV, Local Stations Struggle to Adapt As Web Grabs Viewers, Revenue
The 1,300 commercial television stations in the U.S., much like newspapers and magazines, are under attack as new technologies roil the industry. The Internet, in particular, is sucking away both viewers and advertisers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 TAIWAN FIRMS MAKE FINANCIAL TIMES TOP 500 LIST

TEXT.P: Four of Taiwan's companies were included in the Financial Times' newly released list of the world's 500 largest global corporations.
The leading financial daily listed Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) as the highest ranking Taiwanese company, ranking 136th with a market value of US$48.9 billion.

TSMC's new classification was a jump of three notches over last year, followed by Hong Hai Precision Industry, Co., which came in 277th, and Chunghwa Telecom and Nan Ya Plastics Corp., ranked 419th and 482nd, respectively.
Hong Hai ranked 426th last year, while Chunghwa Telecom and Nan Ya Plastics were classified 294th and 350th, respectively, the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: States' Changes Reshape Medicaid; New Restrictions Aim to Save Money.
After winning greater freedom from federal Medicaid rules, states are moving aggressively to transform the nation's largest public health insurance program, adding fees, restricting benefits and creating incentives for patients to take responsibility for their health.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM HEAVY RAIN SOAR TO NT$900 MILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses in central and southern Taiwan caused by five successive days of torrential rain increased to nearly NT$900 million by late Monday afternoon, according to statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

COA officials said Nantou, Taichung, Hsinchu, Changhua and Chiayi counties were the hardest-hit areas, and that the COA will offer financial assistance and low-interest loans to help affected farmers.
The most severely damaged crops were watermelons, grapes, persimmons and rice, while poultry farms also suffered considerable losses.
A total of 23,830 hectares of farmland were flooded, with nearly 20 percent of its crops destroyed.

The losses included the deaths of 410 swine, 205,000 chickens, 2,700 ducks and 6,525 geese. Flood wiped out 90 hectares of fish ponds in Chiayi and Yunlin counties, washed away the topsoil of 19.2 hectares of farmland and inundated 52.5 hectares of other farmland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CLOSER ENVIRONMENTAL COOPERATION WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday Taiwan and Japan should strengthen cooperation to develop technologies for energy conservation and environmental protection, since both are island countries with limited natural resources.
Chen made the call while meeting with 70-plus Japanese delegates to an international seminar on environmental protection and engineering technology development being held in Taipei.

Noting that Japan has been a front-runner in environmental protection and sustainable development technologies, Chen said Taiwan should increase exchanges and cooperation with Japan in these fields in its pursuit of becoming a "green silicon" island.

Given their geographical proximity, Chen said, Taiwan and Japan have traditionally maintained close substantive relations despite the absence of official ties. Chen said that in 2005, Japan was Taiwan's second largest trading partner while Taiwan ranked fourth on Japan's major trading partners list, with two-way trade reaching US$60 billion.

Bilateral tourism has also been cordial, with tourist visits between the two countries reaching 2.4 million last year. Taiwan was Japan's second largest source of tourists, while Japan ranked first among Taiwan's major tourist sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL NUISANCE COMPLAINTS ABOUT 'FOUL ODORS' INCREASE

TEXT.P: The third most frequent nuisance complaint lodged in Taiwan is related to offensive odors, after public dirtiness and noise pollution, a spokeswoman for the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Monday.

The spokeswoman said the number of air pollution complaints increased from about 33,000 in 2002 to 38,000 in 2005, with whiffy odors as the top cause of air pollution complaints. During the period, the number of foul odor-related complaints spiked from 24,000 to 28,000.

The spokeswoman added that most complaints come from Taipei County, followed by Taoyuan County and Taipei City. She said that changes in recent urban planning have caused residential zones to be located closer to polluted areas, therefore causing the number of complaints to climb.
She said that environmental protection authorities will emphasize placing controls on facilities producing the offensive smells and to modify regulations to improve people's living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 13 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 13:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 13, or the 18th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1994: The Foreign Ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit U.N. nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
2000: The United States Senate passes a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, for his distinguished service.
2000: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates praises Taiwan's companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING FRIGHTENED BY TAIWAN MEDIA EXPOSURE OF CORRUPTION: H.K. DAILY

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong newspaper questioned Tuesday why Chinese media cannot expose high-level corruption as media do in Taiwan, whose president is facing a recall motion in the legislature as a result of media reports about corruption scandals allegedly involving the president's family and close aides.

A columnist said in the Ming Pao daily that ever since the first family of President Chen Shui-bian came under fire for its suspected involvement in a string of corruption scandals, Beijing has reacted with unusual silence.
Some reports said Beijing has even ordered a blackout of reports about suspected irregularities involving members of Taiwan's first family, the Ming Pao article said.

It noted that Beijing is doing so apparently not to help Chen save face but instead out of fear that such reports could lead to an "association of thoughts" by the Chinese people who might ask why Chinese media cannot monitor the government like their Taiwan counterparts.

The article said when Beijing Deputy Mayor Liu Zhihhua was dismissed for leading a "corrupt and decadent life, " not a single national media outlet in China reported the facts about the dismissal and Chinese authorities went so far as to ban reports of the Liu incident.

Comparing Taiwan media's aggressive exposure of high-level wrong-doings and Chinese media's overwhelming silence over similar incidents in China, people would come to the conclusion that only a free press can put a stop to corruption, according to the article.

It asked how anyone could believe that the Chinese leadership's efforts to promote competency and integrity could be effective in stamping out corruption when the deputy mayor of the capital city cannot remain clean after years of such efforts by the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN CITY SETS 2007 AS YEAR OF CULTURE & TOURISM

TEXT.P: The government of Tainan City, a historic city in southern Taiwan, has decided that culture and tourism will be two themes of its administrative policy in 2007.

Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai has named Hsieh Shih-chie, secretary-general of the city government, to serve as the convener of a preparatory commission of the upcoming "year of culture and tourism" initiative.

With a unique cultural and historical heritage, Tainan City, known as "Fu Cheng" due to its ancient image of the capital of Taiwan, enjoys more resources than other cities around the island in the development of the business of tourism, Hsu said.
Tainan was established as the ancient capital of Taiwan in 1661 by Koxinga, a military leader at the end of the Chinese Ming Dynasty, after he drove the Dutch off the island in 1662.

In 1684, the Ching Dynasty conquered Taiwan and established "Taiwan Fu" (Taiwan Government) as the first official local government on the island, which was later renamed "Tainan Fu" in 1885 when Taiwan was established as a province.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE KICKSTARTS MOTION TO RECALL PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan Tuesday referred a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian to the Committee of the Whole for review, officially kickstarting a legal process to unseat the head of state.
The committee is scheduled to meet June 21-23 and June 26 to review the motion before it will be put to a vote during a plenary session June 27.
If more than two-thirds of the legislators vote in favor of it, the motion will then be put to a national referendum.

The motion was initiated by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party during an extra session of the legislature, in the wake of a spat of corruption scandals implicating the first family and the president's close aides.

To drum up support for their move, the "pan-blue alliance" is planning to hold public hearings on the sidelines of the scheduled committee meetings, with members of the first family to be invited to attend.

Ker Chien-ming, whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus, said the president will present a written statement to the legislature to defend himself before the review process starts.
According to the law governing the legislature's operations, such a written statement must be delivered to the legislature within seven days, which in this case means by June 19.
