DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OPPOSITION TO RECALL MOTION WILL BE RECORDED IN HISTORY: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) makes an all-out effort to block the legislature's motion to recall the president, depriving the people of their voice in the matter, it will "leave a poor record in history."
Ma reminded the DPP lawmakers that they came to power because they used to respect the people's will.
The recall motion must receive the support of two-thirds of the legislators in a vote before it can be put to a national referendum.

Ma explained why he had made an about-face in the recall campaign. He said he opposed the campaign at first because it would likely be interpreted as an attempt to wage a political battle to seize power, but now, nearly 70 percent of the people support the move to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

He said that although he knows it will be difficult to pass the motion at the Legislative Yuan, the motion will leave a mark in history and encourage the judicial authorities to shed any fear of political pressure in their investigation and prosecution of all those involved in corruption scandals.
Ma made the remarks in reply to media inquiries after a city government meeting. He reiterated his call for the president to step down on his own accord as this would be the least costly for society.
Ma said Chen's speech on the day of the Dragon Boat Festival showed that he had no remorse, an incident which the KMT chairman said made him change his attitude about moving to recall the president.

He also said that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party finally decided to propose a motion to recall the president at the upcoming extra session of the legislature rather than at the regular session in September because a delay would increase the anxiety of the whole society.
Citing the latest poll showing that almost 70 percent of the people now support the recall campaign, Ma said introducing the motion won't stir up too much trouble.
Ma stressed that the decision to move to recall Chen was made from the bottom up and was endorsed by a KMT plenary meeting and its legislative caucus, so it was a sound decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Australia storms past Japan 3-1
Super sub Tim Cahill scored two late goals as Australia inflicted a heartbreaking 3-1 defeat on Japan in their opening Group F game at Fritz Walter Stadion in Kaiserslautern on Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD URGES DPP TO DRAW A LINE WITH THE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong urged ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Tuesday to draw a line between themselves and President Chen Shui-bian, asking why the DPP should "tie its soul to Chen and trample on Taiwan's democratic values."

To express the PFP's determination to recall the president, Soong sat in the PFP legislative caucus office for the second consecutive day to monitor proceedings of a recall motion that was referred to Committee of the Whole of the legislature Tuesday.
The recall motion is a milestone in Taiwan's democratic establishment, Soong said, adding that Taiwan will become a third-rate country if it can't pass the examination.

Soong stressed that the reason why the PFP is pushing for a recall referendum is to promote the sense of right and wrong and the value of justice, which he said transcend the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" political divide.
He warned that the moral foundation of the country will be destroyed if it allows corruption scandals to be left undealt with.
Soong said saving Taiwan at all costs is the PFP's main purpose at this point in time, adding that he would like to salute the legislature for having launched the recall process.
PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng pointed to the recent example of "people power" forcing the prime minister to step down in Thailand.
"If the Thais can do it, we in the Republic of China can too," he added.

The legislature is set to debate the motion later this month in an extraordinary session, while the president will have a chance to answer opposition charges against him before the legislature votes on the motion on June 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE ASKS PRESIDENT TO REPLY TO RECALL MOTION BY JUNE 20

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan sent an official letter to President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday asking him to make a reply to an opposition-initiated motion to recall him, an unprecedented legislative move to recall a president in the history of the Republic of China.

The opposition claimed they were proposing the recall based on doubts of Chen's integrity and competency as his senior aides and son-in-law have been detained or investigated in connection with a string of corruption scandals.
The president has until June 20 to decide whether or not to answer the opposition charges.
Whether he responds or not, the Legislative Yuan will move ahead to debate the motion June 21-23 and June 26 before putting it to a vote June 27.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said some "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers had hoped to invite first lady Wu Shu-jen to a Committee of the Whole meeting dealing with the recall motion.
The opposition accused Wu of involvement in illicit business deals and accepting favors from some businesspeople, accusations that the Presidential Office has denied.

Wang said that if both the ruling and opposition parties agree to the proposal to invite Wu, "then I will agree." But, he added, this must be negotiated by both sides. If the negotiations break down, then nothing can be done about it, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOLD PRESENTATIONS TO BOOST SUPPORT FOR RECALL INITIATIVE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is planning to hold three large-scale public presentations in the northern, central and southern regions of the island to introduce and publicize the opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, KMT spokeswoman Chen Li-wen said Tuesday.

At a news conference at the KMT headquarters, Chen indicated that the party plans to hold the first public presentation in Changhua, central Taiwan on June 18, with the second one to be held in the southern city of Kaohsiung June 24.
Then, on June 25, the KMT will hold a large rally at the historic Sungshan Tobacco Factory in downtown Taipei, along with a planned presentation on the recall motion, Chen noted.

The KMT executive branch is taking over the operations of an initiative campaign launched by the largest opposition party's caucus at the legislature to collect signatures of voters supporting the motion, and it is preparing to hold a signature drive at all KMT chapters around the country in an effort to seek national support for the motion to recall Chen, whose family and government have been dogged by a spate of corruption allegations.
The Legislative Yuan began the operations to review the recall motion Tuesday, kicking off the legal process to unseat the president.

A vote in the legislature on the motion has been scheduled for June 27. If more than two-thirds of the legislators vote in favor of the motion, the resolution will then be put to a national referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-GREENS TO PUSH FOR REFERENDUM TO RECLAIM KMT'S 'ILL-GOTTEN' ASSETS

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from the "pan-green camp" unveiled Tuesday their plan to initiate a referendum on the reclamation of the "ill-gotten" assets owned by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The legislators went to the Central Election Commission to pick up a form for a public signature drive for the referendum, saying that they hope to collect at least one million signatures although only 80,000 are required.

The move, jointly promoted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , was retaliation against the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance's" campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Citing a media report estimating the value of the KMT's assets at NT$600 billion (US$18.4 billion) , the legislators argued that the assets should be returned to the nation and distributed to the people, with each person expected to get a share of NT$30,000.

According to DPP Legislator Lin Chung-mo, the "pan-green camp" decided to resort to a referendum because the "pan-blue alliance" has taken advantage of its majority in the Legislative Yuan to block a law on the handling of the KMT assets.

Trong Chai, another DPP legislator, urged KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to put forward a written statement to explain how his party is going to deal with its assets, just like President Chen has been required to present a written statement to the legislature to defend himself.

TSU Legislator Liao Pen-yen said while his party believes that authorities should get to the bottom of the insider trading allegations surrounding the president's son-in-law, it is "very fair" that an exhaustive investigation is launched on the KMT assets.
Ho Min-hao, head of the TSU's policy committee, claimed that using "people power" to resolve the issue of the KMT's ill-gotten assets is the most suitable method.
Ho accused the KMT and PFP of focusing only on political struggle and ignoring the people's welfare for promoting a motion to recall the president during an upcoming extra legislative session.
TSU Secretary-General Lo Cih-ming said the public will be able to sign their names in support of the referendum on the KMT assets during an anti-recall event set for June 17.
The TSU's candidates for the year-end elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung city councilors will also help collect signatures from the public, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO SET UP VILLAGE, BOROUGH SERVICE CENTERS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said Tuesday that the DPP will set up service centers in villages and boroughs islandwide to better solidify grass-roots support in view of a new electoral system.

At a hand-over ceremony for new head of DPP's Taichung city office, Lin stressed that the party should strengthen solidarity among villages and boroughs in preparation for future elections instead of waiting for the splitting of the opposition "pan-blue alliance."

Chen noted that according to a package of revisions to the ROC Constitution passed in 2005, which include the downsizing of the legislature and changes to the electoral system, the seventh legislature beginning from 2008 will see the number of seats reduced from the current 225 to 113, while the electoral system will be changed from the current "multiple seats for each constituency" to a "single seat, two ballots" system.
Under the new electoral system, each voter should cast two ballots -- one for a political party and the other for a candidate.

Noting that the presidential, legislative and city and county chief elections in the future will all be "one-on-one" fierce competitions in each constituency, Lin said the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party will have to collaborate in choosing the best candidates to vie for the posts.
For the DPP, the solidarity among the party members of all spectrums is extremely important, in addition to introducing the best candidates for the elections, Lin stressed.
He said that the DPP headquarters will strength its services in villages and boroughs in the future by offering more lectures and training courses to grass-roots supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June dropped 109 points to close at 6,270, with 52,290 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July moved down 107 points to finish at 6,225, with 1,502 contracts traded, while September futures lost 105 points to close at 6,127, with 72 contract transactions.
December futures dropped 119 points to close at 6,115, with 20 contracts traded, while March futures lost 159 points to finish at 6,110, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,379 for June, 6,332 for July, 6,232 for September, 6,234 for December and 6,269 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 5.05 points to close at 263.2, with 6,488 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost six points to finish at 261, with 222 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 1.45 points to close at 258.55 with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved down 18.8 points to finish at 910, with 3,048 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures lost 12.4 points to close at 909.6, with 80 contracts traded.
March TF futures moved down 27 points to close at 888.2, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BEING CAUTIOUS ON MOVE TO RECALL PRESIDENT: HONORARY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Any motion to recall the head of state is "not child's play" and has to be considered carefully, which explains why Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) seems to have been proceeding slowly in moving to recall President Chen Shui-bian, visiting KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday.

Lien said at a news conference attended by foreign correspondents based in Singapore that he hasn't discussed the issue with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, but the political ramifications of such a motion are sure to be far-reaching and should be considered carefully in advance.

Lien pointed out that the threshold to recall the president is very high and that the legislative procedures are also complicated, adding that it is only natural for the KMT to act cautiously rather than hastily.

Now that the KMT has decided to move to recall the president, Lien said, the party should spare no efforts to achieve its goal by drumming up support among not only its followers but also among supporters of other parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy beat Ghana 2:0 in World Cup.
Italy beat Ghana 2: 0 in its 2006 World Cup debut. It was a beautiful triumph for the Italian team led by Marcello Lippi. Midfielder superstar Francesco Totti had a nice game in the first half.

DOC.HEADLINE: 64% OF TAIWAN'S OFFICE WORKERS HAVE PROFESSIONAL LICENSES: POLL

TEXT.P: Sixty-four percent of office workers in Taiwan have at least one professional license, with each person owning three licenses on average, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank between May 30 and June 12 on 1,159 office workers, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.
Eighty-five percent of the survey's respondents agreed that owning professional licenses is important to enhance their competitiveness in Taiwan's future job market, the survey shows.
Among professional licenses held by respondents, 44.16 percent are in professional skills, 32.74 percent in computer skills and 19.43 percent in finance-related affairs.

In the survey, 74.24 percent of respondents said obtaining a license in computer skills would be helpful in their jobsearch and plans to change jobs, compared with 12.27 percent who disagreed and 13.48 percent who had no opinion.
A total of 63.35 percent of respondents think gaining a license in computer skills will help boost their work efficiency, while 23.34 percent disagreed and 13.31 percent expressed no opinion.

A total of 62.83 percent said getting a professional license in computer skills would help them get a promotion or salary increases, compared with 19.10 percent who disagreed and 18.06 percent who expressed no opinion.

Meanwhile, 60.41 percent of respondents are unsatisfied with their computer proficiency, with 74.64 percent saying they are considering taking on-the-job courses to obtain a license in computer skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 105.69 points to close at 6,337.21.
The bourse opened at 6,349.09 and fluctuated between 6,401.55 and 6,328.38 during trading. A total of 2.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.71 billion (US$2.38 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.6 percent.

The seven other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by cement stocks and banking and financial shares both at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, construction issues at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 539 to 210, with 90 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ CLARIFIES FIDH REPORT ON TAIWAN'S CAPITAL PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Tuesday that Taiwan has not violated any human rights principles in its handling of capital punishment cases or in its treatment of death-row inmates, but it promised to refer to other countries' measures to refine the existing system.
The ministry was responding to a report issued by FIDH -- the French acronym of the International Federation for Human Rights -- on Taiwan's use of capital punishment.

It marked the first time that an international organization has issued a "country report" on Taiwan's use of capital punishment. The FIDH groups 141 human rights organizations around the world with an aim to obtain effective improvements in the protection of victims, the prevention of human rights abuse and the prosecution of those responsible.

FIDH Vice Chairwoman Siobhan Ni Chulachain unveiled the report at a news conference in Taipei Monday, during which she also offered suggestions for Taiwan's government and its private sector on how to further improve the county's human rights records. Chulachain will present the report to President Chen Shui-bian on behalf of the FIDH.

The report is expected to catch the attention of major world human rights bodies, such as the Amnesty International and the U.N. Human Rights Council, and may affect Taiwan's international image, analysts said.
The FIDH report made a case for Taiwan to craft a timetable for phasing out capital punishment. Taiwan is one of 72 countries in the world that have not abolished the death penalty.
The report also claimed that Taiwan has violated the U.N.'s minimum requirements for treatment of death-row inmates by demanding that death-row inmates wear leg irons on a long-term basis.

In response, MOJ officials said the FIDH report was incorrect, stressing that local prisons and reformatory centers have been ordered not to use handcuffs, leg irons or legcuffs, shackles or other such restraining gear for punitive purposes.

Under prison management rules, the officials said, leg irons and handcuffs are used only for protective purposes, meaning that only death-row inmates who are emotionally unstable or likely to flee or commit suicide are restrained in accordance with regulations set forth in the Criminal Procedure Code.
"We have not been in violation of relevant U.N. rules, " an MOJ official said.
As to the FIDH's suspicions that local death-row inmates might have been forced to donate their organs before execution, the MOJ official said such speculation and concerns are unfounded.

Of the 12 death-rown inmates executed between 2003 and the present, seven donated their organs of their own free will. None of their organ donations ran against medical ethics principles, the official stressed.

On the FIDH's criticism that Taiwan fails to allow death-row inmates to meet with their families before their execution, the official said preparations for execution have indeed proceeded in secret with a view to ensuring security and avoiding causing anxiety or adding to the suffering of the family members. In fact, the officials said, death-row inmates invariably have enough time to meet their beloved ones. Prison authorities consistently inform their families immediately after the execution.

The official further said the MOJ will work with other government agencies to revise laws that prescribe "capital punishment" as the only penalty, in tandem with the principle of gradually phasing out the death penalty.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ DONATES OVER 60,000 BOOKS TO 312 PRIMARY SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice donated more than 60,000 books to 312 primary schools around Taiwan Tuesday.

Of these recipients, 300 are schools where the Ministry of Education is concurrently promoting a reading program, and 12 are schools that have reported a shortage of library resources, officials said.
The books will be delivered to these schools before summer vacation starts.

Addressing a ceremony to commemorate the occasion, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin recounted how he grew up in the rural area of Chiayi, and that getting a book to read was the thing he desired most.
Shih said he hopes the books donated by the ministry will help enrich children's reading experience over the coming summer vacation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE PRESIDENT CHIANG'S CHIHAI RESIDENCE LISTED AS HISTORICAL SITE

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government designated the Chihai residence of the late President Chiang Chin-kuo in suburban Taipei as a historical site Tuesday, enabling the preservation of the 1960s building, which is on military property.
The residence will be opened to the public after its restoration, officials of the City Department of Cultural Affairs (CDCA) said.

The Chihai Residence, located close to Navy headquarters in northern Taipei, was being used by the Navy to house foreign guests before Chiang moved in at the beginning of his term as minister of defense in 1969.
The son of late President Chiang Kai-shek lived there until his death in 1988. During that period, many key political decisions were made there.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou frequently set foot in the building during his service as Chiang's English secretary.

The simplicity of furnishings in the western-style residence reflects the modesty of its former inhabitants. On the first floor, there was space for meetings with foreign quests or family reunions, while the second floor had Chiang's office and several bedrooms, according to the CDCA.

In addition to the Chihai residence, the home of the late senior adviser to the president, Sun Yun-hsuan, on Chungchin South Road in downtown Taipei, and the old National Taiwan Science Education Center (built in 1956) located in Nanhai park were also designated as historical sites in the capital city.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: PEOPLE'S LIVELIHOOD MORE IMPORTANT THAN RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday he respected the legislature's right to set forth a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, but said the consideration of people's daily lives is more important.
In response to a ruling party lawmaker's question at the Legislative Yuan, Su expressed concern that the recall motion -- which is unlikely to pass -- would cause social unrest.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Kuo Jung-tsung asked for Su's comments on the legislature's decision to refer the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" proposal to a plenary session, setting in motion a grueling legislative bid to recall the president.

Su said it was the legislature's duty to review all proposals, some of which should have been passed in the previous session, including bills governing workers' retirement pension funds, a budget for flood-control projects and management regulations involving state-owned enterprises.

If these major proposals -- which directly affect people's livelihood -- fail to gain legislative approval during this extra session because too much time is spent on political bickering over the recall motion, the nation's economic development may be adversely affected and unemployment could rise, Su said.

Kuo furher asked Su's response in the event the "pan-blue alliance" of Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) propose a no-confidence motion against him in September after failing at an presidential recall attempt.
In response, Su said if his Cabinet failed to win the confidence of the legislature, he would respect whatever it decided to do according to the Constitution.
"Since the Constitution says the Legislative Yuan is the highest authority representing public opinion, I believe it will act prudently," he said.

People just want to see the government operating in an effective and responsible way, Su said, adding that the Executive Yuan has been working hard to meet the expectations of both the public and the legislature.
"And I think the legislature knows what the people's expectations are, and will act accordingly," he said. (By S.C. Chang) ENMDITEM/diG

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.117 to close at NT$32.660.
A total of US$1.129 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.595 and hit a high of NT$32.695.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VOWS TO FIGHT AGAINST NPSU-PROPOSED EXPANSION OF 'MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that it strongly objects to a draft bill on amending a statute on outlying islands development, claiming that it would leave Taiwan's offshore islands wide open to China and downgrade Taiwan to a Chinese province.

DPP legislative caucus whip Chen Chin-jun made the comments while answering reporters' questions following the party's legislative caucus meeting in which Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu reported on the issue.

According to Wu, the law amendment proposal initiated by opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmaker Feng Ting-kuo and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) aims to allow people from Taiwan proper to freely travel to and return from China via Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu while permitting Chinese people to enter the three islands without the Taiwan government's approval and document verification.

Under the opposition-proposed amendments, local governments on Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu would be entitled to sign agreements with China and the central government in Taipei would have the legal obligation to assist the three local authorities in executing the accords signed by them with China.

Arguing that such a revision to the law would compromise Taiwan's national dignity and turn the country into a province of China, Chen said that the DPP would resort to "violent means" against the amendment's passage in the Legislative Yuan, if the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP insist on handling the draft bill in the ongoing extra session.

DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-jin warned against "serious consequences" should the Legislative Yuan approve the amendment, which would permit people from Taiwan and China to freely travel between the two sides via the three Taiwan-held outlying islands without government approval.

The measure requiring the central government to help the three local governments implement their agreements with China would seriously damage the constitutional system and cripple the central government's power in these areas, she said.

The draft amendment bill, put forth by the NPSU, was returned to the legislature's Procedure Committee due to DPP opposition to dealing with it. It remains uncertain when the bill can be assigned to a standing committee for deliberation.
The amendment proposal to expand the exiting "mini three links" was one of 14 important draft bills included on the agenda of an extra legislative session which began June 13 and ends June 30.
The current "mini three links" ferry services allow residents on Kinmen and Matsu islands to directly travel to and from Fujian ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTORNEY REQUESTS BAIL AGAIN FOR CHEN'S SON-IN-LAW

TEXT.P: The attorney of Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, requested that the Taipei District Court release Chao on bail Tuesday -- the second time since Chao was detained in late May due to his suspected involvement in an insider trading case.

Wellington Ku made the request by presenting to the Taipei District Court two newspaper reports which claimed that Chao would no longer be able to escape, collude with other suspects or destroy evidence after being released on bail.
The Taipei District Court said that it would make a ruling on Ku's bail request as soon as possible.

Ku first tried to convince the Taipei District Court to release Chao on bail June 6 on grounds that Chao's wife, Chen Hsin-yu, is expected to give birth in July, but the court turned down the request.
Chao has been held in custody since May 25 after information obtained by prosecutors suggested his alleged role in an insider trading involving shares of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC).

According to media reports, Chao has remained tight-lipped about his role in the affair, but recently admitted that he gained advance knowledge TDC stocks would surge while at a banquet with three other suspects in the case, and prior to his mother's substantial purchase of TDC shares from Chang Hwa Commercial Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LOCAL BRANCH SETS UP CLEAN POLITICS TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: The local branch of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in northern Taipei County set up an 11-member special task force Tuesday "to pursue clean politics, " a KMT spokesman said that day.

The 11 members were described by the spokesman as "respected social figures" who will be responsible for responding to complaints lodged by the public about irregularities and suspected wrongdoings by KMT members. The ad hoc group offers a special telephone hotline, (02) 29527417, and a P.O. box for the public to lodge their complaints.

The establishment of the task force was in response to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's call for clean politics to build a good image for the party, which is striving to gain greater grassroots support since it lost power in 2000, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF MIGHT BE ABSENT FROM PFP-ORGANIZED RALLY ON FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou might be unable to take part in a demonstration organized by the People First Party in Taipei Friday because of his tight schedule, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Tuesday.

Cheng said Ma, who attended two previous PFP-led demonstrations in Taipei, fully supports Friday's demonstration which is intended to show the public's disapproval of President Chen Shui-bian and gain support for a presidential recall motion.

Cheng said Ma is scheduled to call on several well-respected figures Friday, seeking their opinion on ways to calm the social upheaval caused by partisan bickering between ruling and opposition parties over the motion to recall the president, whose administration has been beset by a series of scandals allegedly involving his close aides and family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Violent Crime Rises In U.S.; District Reports 5 Percent Jump as Robberies Spike.
Violent crime in 2005 increased at the highest rate in 15 years, driven in large part by a surge of killings and other attacks in many Midwestern cities, the FBI reported yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI RELEASES `SUPER-QUIET' ROBOTIC VACUUM CLEANER

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute debuted Tuesday its newly invented "super-quiet" robotic vacuum cleaner, which operating at a sound level of 56 decibels -- 10 decibels lower than existing models.
An ITRI official said the compact cleaner, which weighs about 3.5kg, can automatically clean the house in various movement patterns -- spiral, zigzag, random and against-the-wall.

He added that if the cleaner detects low power conditions, it will switch to "charging mode" -- in which it will move along the walls only to find its charger. Once power is restored, it will restart the "cleaning mode."
The official said that due to what he described as a "strong demand" in the Taiwan market for automated household appliances, the institute has placed more and more resources into meeting demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES DREDGING OF SHIHMEN RESERVOIR

TEXT.P: Premier Sung Tseng-chang said Tuesday during an extra legislative session that the government urgently requires a special budget to dredge Shihmen reservoir in Taoyuan County to prevent water shortages.

Su noted that typhoons that have hit Taiwan over the past four years have brought a tremendous amount of silt into the reservoir, greatly increasing the water turbidity. The reservoir provides water to Taoyuan and other counties in northern Taiwan.

In 2004 alone, typhoon Aere brought 973 mm of rain in just four days, seriously increasing the reservoir's turbidity and rendering its filtration pumps unable to cope with the amount of silt. As a result, the reservoir was unable to supply water, causing a water shortage in Taoyuan that lasted for 18 consecutive days and creating serious consequences for residents and the investment climate in the area, Su added.

In addition, the daily amount of water used by residents and industry is 105 tons, but by 2021 the demand is expected to surge to 132 tons daily, Su said, adding that there must be dredging and an improvement project as soon as possible in order to resolve the water shortage problem and increase the reservoir's function and durability.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung noted that the first phrase of the Shihmen reservoir dredging and improvement project will include increasing the capability of water purification plants and the conservation of land near the reservoir, and estimated it will cost NT$14 billion (US$432 million) in the period from 2006-2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP INVITES ENTERTAINERS TO CAMPAIGN FOR BREASTFEEDING

TEXT.P: A breastfeeding association called on local entertainers Tuesday to join a campaign to "rectify the image of breastfeeding" after two female entertainers made fun of the practice last Saturday in a skit they performed at an award presentation ceremony.

The Breastfeeding Association of Taiwan said that on Monday, just a day after the Golden Melody Award presentation in honor of Taiwanese musical performers, a mother filed a complaint with the association after she was mocked by a male coworker who had jokingly asked her if she could "do the same as the women on TV."
The association said the issue was fiercely debated on its Web site by breastfeeding mothers who wrote that airing such a joke on TV was "vulgar" and reflected negatively on breastfeeding.
The association urged entertainers to think carefully before doing such performances, and welcomed them to help develop a campaign on behalf of breastfeeding.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG RANKED THIRD IN TUBERCULOSIS INCIDENCE

TEXT.P: Southern Pingtung County has the nation's third highest tuberculosis (TB) incidence rate after Hualien and Taitung, a county health bureau official said Tuesday.

The official made the statement during a question-and-answer session at the county council. According to tallies unveiled by the Pingtung County Health Bureau, more than 1,000 people have contracted tuberculosis in the county, which means 110 to 120 people contract tuberculosis among every 100,000 people.
The county councilor claimed that this high tuberculosis incidence is caused by X-Ray machines being left idle because of a lack of radiologists.

The health official replied that the lack of personnel is due to a national budget shortage, but since there are other X-Ray inspection trucks that make two trips per year to indigenous villages, tuberculosis screening is considered sufficient. Official tallies show that TB incidence is comparatively higher in aboriginal communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP SAO TOME FIGHT EPIDEMIC: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that Taiwan will help Sao Tome and Principe fight malaria and cholera, using its successful experiences in fighting the diseases.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Sao Tome and Principe Deputy Primer Minister and Minister of Planning and Finance Maria Torres, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation Carlos Gustavo, and its Ambassador to the United States Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno.

During the meeting, Chen extended his congratulations to the coalition backed by Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique de Menezes for winning a parliamentary election held March 26, and wished the African diplomatic ally successful local and presidential elections to be held July 9 and July 30, respectively.

Hailing Torres as an outstanding financial and economic expert as well as an influential Cabinet member, Chen said both he and De Menezes have paid much attention to the rights of women and hope that women can have better career opportunities, citing the example of Taiwan, where the vice president and deputy prime minister are women.
De Menezes made his fourth visit to Taiwan last November, when his country was hit by cholera.
After discussing the situation in his country with Chen, Taiwan offered to provide US$100,000 to Sao Tome and Principe in emergency relief funds, and sent a medical team to control the epidemic.
Chen said with its epidemic-fighting experience, Taiwan is glad to help Sao Tome and Principe eliminate malaria and cholera.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 100 SHIPS VIOLATE INDIRECT TRANSPORT RULES

TEXT.P: A total of 104 local and foreign cargo ships have been punished for violating indirect transport rules between Taiwan and China over the past 14 years, the Ministry of Communications and Transportation (MOTC) reported Tuesday.

Vessels breaking the regulations stipulated in the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area that took effect in 1992 are fined NT$3 million for their first violation and NT$6 million for a second offense, MOTC officials said, noting that repeat offenders could be fined up to NT$15 million (US$468,800).

The latest case involves the foreign-registered M/V Sylvette cargo vessel, which was found to have shipped to Shanghai from Taichung port in central Taiwan without detouring via Japan's Ishigaki Island and then returned to the port directly, according to the officials. The vessel's owner was punished by the MOTC with a fine of NT$3 million.

MOTC tallies show that to date, 64 ships loading and unloading at Keelung port in northern Taiwan were caught breaking the rules requiring transit through a third country or area for all cross-Taiwan Strait voyages. Meanwhile, 29 ships at Taichung port, 10 at southern Kaohsiung port and one in eastern Hualien port were also punished for unlawful direct travel across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEGETABLE WHOLESALE PRICES GETTING BACK TO NORMAL

TEXT.P: Wholesale prices of vegetables soared as a result of recent heavy rains, but returned to normal levels Tuesday after the Council of Agriculture (COA) released a large amount of frozen vegetables onto the market.
To stabilize the market's supply and demand, a COA official said it would keep moving some 250 metric tons of frozen vegetables onto the market daily.

According to Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Corp. (TPMC), the average wholesale price of vegetables in Taipei city had risen to NT$36.16 per kilogram June 11 and dropped to NT$31.75 Tuesday as the new supply went up to 1,455 metric tons -- up 470 metric tons from the previous trading session.
Meanwhile, TPMC noted, the price of vegetables and spring onions which had increased by a large margin, are also lower now.
COA pointed that to stabilize prices, it will continue coordinating with agricultural groups to improve marketing for fruit and vegetables in major markets around Taiwan.
On the other hand, agricultural groups and refrigerated warehouses have jointly released 1,153 metric tons so far, helping to stabilize retail market prices, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL VISITS CHINA FOR ANTI-DUMPING PROBES

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Finance (MOF) official traveled to China Tuesday to investigate whether two Chinese towel makers have sold their products to Taiwan at prices far lower than fair market value.

The visit follows Taiwan's levying from June 1 of a 237.7 percent provisional anti-dumping tax on all Chinese towel exports to Taiwan, with the exception of those from two Chinese companies that have been subject to lower anti-dumping taxes of 109.3 percent and 107.7 percent, respectively.

The two companies -- one in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province and the other in Zhejiang Province -- replied to an initial anti-dumping survey conducted by the MOF earlier this year, while the other seven Chinese companies surveyed did not respond. The nine companies account for 35 percent of the total Chinese towel exports to Taiwan.

The MOF official is accompanied by an accountant, MOF sources said, adding that the official will investigate whether the data provided by the two companies is correct. The investigative results will serve as reference in determining whether the temporary anti-dumping taxes imposed on them should be adjusted when the ministry announces a formal anti-dumping tax on Chinese towels in mid-September.
The official is scheduled to conclude his visit and return to Taipei June 22.

It marks the first time Taiwan has formally sent an official on an anti-dumping visit to China under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), MOF sources said, adding that the Chinese mission at the WTO formally informed Taiwan last week of its consent to the MOF official's visit. The two companies have also expressed welcome to the official's visit.

Unless the seven other major Chinese towel corporations respond to the MOF's questionnaires before the ministry completes its anti-dumping investigations, the 237.7 percent anti-dumping tax imposed on their products is not expected to be changed when the ministry decides upon the formal anti-dumping tax.
According to general international trade practices, a provisional anti-dumping measure usually does not last for more than four months. The MOF is scheduled to announce the formal tax rate Sept. 16.

The ministry began the anti-dumping procedures against Chinese towel imports after local towel makers filed complaints and staged many rounds of demonstrations to call for government attention to their plight due to the influx of extremely cheap imports from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 860,000 TAIWANESE SUFFERING FROM KIDNEY DISEASE

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) officials announced Tuesday that based on a 2005 health survey, an estimated 860,000 Taiwanese over the age of 15 suffer from kidney disease, despite the decrease in prevalence among the population to 3.8 percent from 4.1 percent in 2002.
The prevalence of kidney disease is rising to become an illness that is threatening the health of the country, warned officials of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH.

At present, some 50,000 kidney disease patients in Taiwan must undergo dialysis regularly, according to Taiwan Society of Nephrology Chairman Huang Chiu-chin, who also noted that the number of patients in the third to fifth stages of chronic kidney disease has surpassed that of the island's diabetes patients.

A nephrologist at National Cheng Kung University Hospital recently revealed that Taiwan has the world's highest incidence of uremia, a kidney disease, with 385 new cases per every 1 million people every year, and that Taiwan spends up to NT$25 billion (US$769 million) on dialysis -- the sole treatment for uremia -- every year.

Since the early symptoms of kidney disease are not apparent and 50 percent of patients have no symptoms in the initial stages and so are likely to miss early treatment, Huang said he believes regular health checkups are recommended to avoid disease, suggesting that people who experience a combination of symptoms such as edema, headache, fatigue or frothy urine should consult a doctor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SOCIAL SECURITY EXPENDITURE SPIKES TO 9.7% OF GDP: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's social security benefit expenditure reached 9.7 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) in 2004, according to a report released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The report made a critical point that Taiwan's social security expenditure as a percentage of GDP has been risen steadily and reached 9.7 percent of GDP in 2004. With Taiwan's population aging faster than many Western countries, the report said Taiwan faces great pressure in raising social security funding.

According to the report, the nation's social security expenditure amounted to NT$1.05 trillion in 2004, including NT$541.6 billion in cash payment, NT$471.5 billion worth of products and NT$32.2 billion administrative cost and overheads. Per capita social security benefit reached an average of NT$46,157.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Violence Erupts Between Fatah and Hamas
Hundreds of Palestinian security personnel loyal to the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, went on a rampage Monday night in the West Bank town of Ramallah, attacking the parliament and cabinet buildings controlled by his rivals in the Hamas-led government. The attack by forces from the Fatah faction loyal to Abbas, came after Hamas gunmen attacked the Gaza headquarters of the Fatah-dominated security forces with rockets and grenades.
Wall Street Journal: Bumpy Ride, As China's Auto Market Booms, Leaders Clash Over Heavy Toll
The rise of the automobile highlights the wrenching balancing act China faces as it tries to join the ranks of modern consumer societies: improving living standards and creating jobs for the country's 1.3 billion people while keeping pollution and oil demand under control. Officials from China's central government as well as local leaders are divided over how to proceed. China's car debate stands out because its population is the planet's largest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL VISITS CHINA FOR ANTI-DUMPING PROBES(repeat)

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Finance (MOF) official traveled to China Tuesday to investigate whether two Chinese towel makers have sold their products to Taiwan at prices far lower than fair market value.

The visit follows Taiwan's levying from June 1 of a 237.7 percent provisional anti-dumping tax on all Chinese towel exports to Taiwan, with the exception of those from two Chinese companies that have been subject to lower anti-dumping taxes of 109.3 percent and 107.7 percent, respectively.

The two companies -- one in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province and the other in Zhejiang Province -- replied to an initial anti-dumping survey conducted by the MOF earlier this year, while the other seven Chinese companies surveyed did not respond. The nine companies account for 35 percent of the total Chinese towel exports to Taiwan.

The MOF official is accompanied by an accountant, MOF sources said, adding that the official will investigate whether the data provided by the two companies is correct. The investigative results will serve as reference in determining whether the temporary anti-dumping taxes imposed on them should be adjusted when the ministry announces a formal anti-dumping tax on Chinese towels in mid-September.
The official is scheduled to conclude his visit and return to Taipei June 22.

It marks the first time Taiwan has formally sent an official on an anti-dumping visit to China under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), MOF sources said, adding that the Chinese mission at the WTO formally informed Taiwan last week of its consent to the MOF official's visit. The two companies have also expressed welcome to the official's visit.

Unless the seven other major Chinese towel corporations respond to the MOF's questionnaires before the ministry completes its anti-dumping investigations, the 237.7 percent anti-dumping tax imposed on their products is not expected to be changed when the ministry decides upon the formal anti-dumping tax.
According to general international trade practices, a provisional anti-dumping measure usually does not last for more than four months. The MOF is scheduled to announce the formal tax rate Sept. 16.

The ministry began the anti-dumping procedures against Chinese towel imports after local towel makers filed complaints and staged many rounds of demonstrations to call for government attention to their plight due to the influx of extremely cheap imports from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 860,000 TAIWANESE SUFFERING FROM KIDNEY DISEASE(repeat)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) officials announced Tuesday that based on a 2005 health survey, an estimated 860,000 Taiwanese over the age of 15 suffer from kidney disease, despite the decrease in prevalence among the population to 3.8 percent from 4.1 percent in 2002.
The prevalence of kidney disease is rising to become an illness that is threatening the health of the country, warned officials of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH.

At present, some 50,000 kidney disease patients in Taiwan must undergo dialysis regularly, according to Taiwan Society of Nephrology Chairman Huang Chiu-chin, who also noted that the number of patients in the third to fifth stages of chronic kidney disease has surpassed that of the island's diabetes patients.

A nephrologist at National Cheng Kung University Hospital recently revealed that Taiwan has the world's highest incidence of uremia, a kidney disease, with 385 new cases per every 1 million people every year, and that Taiwan spends up to NT$25 billion (US$769 million) on dialysis -- the sole treatment for uremia -- every year.

Since the early symptoms of kidney disease are not apparent and 50 percent of patients have no symptoms in the initial stages and so are likely to miss early treatment, Huang said he believes regular health checkups are recommended to avoid disease, suggesting that people who experience a combination of symptoms such as edema, headache, fatigue or frothy urine should consult a doctor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SOCIAL SECURITY EXPENDITURE SPIKES TO 9.7% OF GDP: DGBAS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's social security benefit expenditure reached 9.7 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) in 2004, according to a report released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The report made a critical point that Taiwan's social security expenditure as a percentage of GDP has been risen steadily and reached 9.7 percent of GDP in 2004. With Taiwan's population aging faster than many Western countries, the report said Taiwan faces great pressure in raising social security funding.

According to the report, the nation's social security expenditure amounted to NT$1.05 trillion in 2004, including NT$541.6 billion in cash payment, NT$471.5 billion worth of products and NT$32.2 billion administrative cost and overheads. Per capita social security benefit reached an average of NT$46,157.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 14, or the 19th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1838: Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894: After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Colombian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900: The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920: In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936: Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940: German troops march into Paris, and the flag of Nazi Germany, bearing the swastika, is hoisted up the Eiffel Tower.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943: The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949: Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952: The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is put on public display in the United States.
1955: The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964: In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: A 10-member Chinese national judo team headed by Mao Ming-chu leaves for Lausanne to take part in the 8th world championships.
1974: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung and Deputy Premier Cuthbert Edwy Talma of the Barbados sign a joint communique in Taipei announcing the extension of the Sino-Barbados agricultural technical cooperation agreement.
1975: More than 500 Chinese poets and Dr. Jeno Platthy, chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Third World Congress of Poets, gathered in Taipei to celebrate Chinese Poets Day and pay homage to poet Chu Yuan of the period of Spring and Autumn Annals.
1978: A technical cooperation agreement between Saudi Arabia and the Republic of China is signed.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Huang Shao-ku and Hung Shou-nan as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, respectively, following unanimous approval by the Control Yuan.
1982: Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo visits the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Taipei to extend his condolences over the passing of King Khalid ibn abdul Aziz.
1989: Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
1992: Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton sends his greetings to the participants in the 24th annual Joint Business Conference of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-U.S.A. Business Councils, which kicks off in Taipei.
2001: A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrives in Taipei to take part in an unprecedented cross-Taiwan Strait long-distance race as part of a campaign for mainland China's bid to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU SEABIRD WATCHING CRUISES TO START JULY 1

TEXT.P: The annual seabird watching cruises from the outlying island of Matsu are scheduled to be launched July 1, officials at the Matsu National Scenic Area Administration said Wednesday.
The cruises will set off from Peikan at 2 p.m. every Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday and will be available until the end of September, the officials said.
The cruises will take passengers to waters around Chungtao, Paimiao and Tiehchien, where they will be able to watch the large number of terns and the beautiful coastline of Matsu, the officials said.
Visitors interested in the activity can register with the four travel agencies in Matsu in advance or they can register on the spot, with the fare being NT$350 (US$10.73) per person, they said.
However, the cruises are subject to cancellation in the event of bad weather, they said.

The officials noted that terns are common in Matsu and that tern watching activities have become very popular among visitors, especially after the discovery of the Chinese crested tern -- an endangered species -- on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOT TO RESPOND TO OPPOSITION CHARGES: DPP CAUCUS WHIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will not present any official statement defending himself over an opposition motion in the Legislative Yuan to unseat him, a parliamentary whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday.

Claiming the recall initiative is basically a "derivative" of infighting within the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) over the year-end Taipei mayoral election, Ker Chien-ming, the DPP legislative caucus convener, said it's meaningless for Chen to give any reply to the opposition's charges against him.
According to Ker, DPP party bigwigs and lawmakers were initially divided over whether Chen should refer to the legislature a written statement defending himself.
"After a 'brainstorming' discussion, we have come to the conclusion that the president shouldn't dance to the tune of the 'pan-blue alliance,'" Ker said.
"Our 'no response' recommendation will be presented to the president for reference," Ker added.

The legislature officially kickstarted the legal process Tuesday to consider the recall motion against Chen on the opening day of an extra legislative session. The "pan-blue alliance" holds a slim majority in the legislature.
In addition to referring the motion to the Committee of the Whole for review, the legislature also filed a letter to Chen explaining why the opposition wants to oust him.

The opposition claimed they were proposing the recall based on doubts of Chen's integrity and competency as his senior aides and son-in-law have been detained or investigated on suspicions of involvement in corruption scandals.
Ker said the reasons enumerated by the opposition were nothing more than mudslinging and exaggerated personal attacks on Chen.

Claiming that the recall motion was initiated by the PFP in an attempt to muster the support of "pan-blue" loyalists for PFP Chairman James Soong's bid for the Taipei mayorship, Ker said main opposition KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at first disagreed with such a drastic move but later made an about-face for fear of drawing a backlash from "pan-blue" extremists leading to the defeat of KMT mayoral candidate Hau Lung-pin in the year-end race.

Ker further said the "pan-blue alliance" originally opposed the DPP's proposal to hold an extra legislative session to screen an urgent flood-control budget bill but later made an about-face simply because it intends to "turn the session into a theater for the 'recall drama.'"
Given the fact the opposition is using the recall motion for political gain, Ker said, it would be to no avail for Chen to make any response.

DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang echoed Ker's view, saying Chen should instead clarify to the public all the allegations against him and his family as well as address the public on his administration's achievements over the past six years and the true cause behind this round of political strife.

The president has until June 20 to decide whether or not to answer the opposition charges. Whether he responds or not, the legislature will move ahead to debate the motion June 21-23 and June 26 before putting it to a vote June 27. If more than two-thirds of the legislators vote in favor of it, the motion will then be put to a national referendum for ordinary citizens to decide whether to unseat Chen two years before his second and final four-year terms expire.
Meanwhile, both KMT legislative whip Pan Wei-kang and her PFP counterpart Lee Hung-chun claimed that Chen's silence could be seen as tacit recognition of the legitimacy of the recall motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS GIVE MIXED REACTIONS TO CHEN'S DECISION NOT TO RESPOND

TEXT.P: Legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gave mixed reactions Wednesday to President Chen Shui-bian's decision not to present any official statement defending himself against a recall motion initiated by the opposition in the Legislative Yuan.

The legislature had asked President Chen Tuesday to reply to the recall motion, which is unprecedented in the history of the Republic of China. The opposition initiated the recall motion based on doubts of the president's competency and integrity in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations against his son-in-law and close aides.
Regardless of whether President Chen responds or not, the Legislative Yuan will go ahead and debate the motion June 21-23 and June 26 before putting it to a vote June 27.

Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim of the DPP said she is in favor of ignoring the motion, noting that the president himself has not been implicated in any of the corruption allegations against his son-in-law and close aides.
"If the president replies, it will make him look like a defendant, " she said, adding that "it is senseless for him to be interrogated by the public."
"As long as the president comes forward to address all misgivings clearly prior to the legislative vote, the public will accept it, " she claimed.
DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung said the opposition-initiated recall motion is based on "political reasons, not legal ones, " and the president has no need to respond.

Ker Chien-ming, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the legislature, said that the recall initiative springs from the infighting within the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) over the year-end Taipei mayoral election.
"The DPP has no need to dance to the tune of the opposition," Ker said.

However, DPP Legislator Cheng Yun-peng said a reply from the president would provide a stage for the DPP and himself. If the "president defends himself well, it will strip the recall motion of any legitimacy and scuttle the momentum the opposition is trying to build up to topple the Cabinet," he said.
A legislative caucus whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the DPP, said that the president's ignoring of the recall motion is "the right direction."

TSU Legislator David Huang said that the opposition only wants to use the upcoming extraordinary session as a stage to humiliate the president, adding that there is no need to "play a duet with them."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD APOLOGIZES FOR IMPRUDENT REMARKS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou made a public apology Wednesday for his imprudent remarks recently while calling for the quit of President Chen Shui-bian.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Ma feels regret for making such reckless remarks as chen will end up in a "foul death" a few days ago while criticizing President Chen's "irresponsible" attitude in dealing with incessant corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides.

Ma was so angry with President Chen's lack of sincerity in addressing the alleged scandals which have caused social unrest that he could not stop himself from using rude language in talking about Chen, according to the spokeswoman.

After making such comments as "condemning him (President Chen) to die a foul death one day after he is overthrown by the people, " Ma feels terribly sorry for failing to exercise self-discipline and because he believes such imprudent remarks have a bad influence on society, the spokeswoman said.
Citing Ma's apology, the spokeswoman said that the KMT chairman has promised to be very cautious with the use of language.

The mass-circulation China Times on Tuesday published a letter to the editor critical of Ma's imprudent remarks. The letter said that Ma is regarded as an upright and honest politician who is seen as the most suitable person to serve as Taiwan's next president and that he should therefore not talk in such an indecent way.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA LEADS FARMERS' ASSOCIATIONS TO BEIJING FOR FRUIT EXPORT TALKS

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) official is leading a delegation of representatives of 18 farmers' associations around Taiwan to Beijing for negotiations on fruit exports to China.

TAITRA Secretary-General Chao Yung-chuan said that the aims of the delegation, being led by TAITRA's deputy secretary-general, are related to business and that the delegation will not be engaging in any official negotiations at the commission of the government.

Although the Chinese government announced last year that it would grant tariff-free treatment to several categories of Taiwan fruits, it continues to be reluctant to engage in talks directly with TAITRA, the sole organization designated by Taiwan's government to negotiate with Beijing on the issue.

In the past, TAITRA usually led Taiwan exporters to negotiate with importers of foreign countries for the export of Taiwan products. However, this time, it is leading representatives of farmers' associations to make direct contacts with Beijing importers.
Chao said the direct contacts between fruit producers and importers will help Taiwan farmers better understand the real market demand in China, which he said will be beneficial to future trade.

In addition to organizing trade shows in China, TAITRA will also invite Beijing buyers to attend the 2006 Taipei International Food Show slated for June 21-24 to better promote Taiwan products, according to Chao.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET SOAR

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 131.8 points to close at 6,469.01.
The bourse opened at 6,343.66 and fluctuated between 6,494.92 and 6,340.28 during trading. A total of 3.23 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.68 billion (US$2.91 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.7 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2.9 percent, textile stocks at 2.8 percent, cement stocks at 2.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.5 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 675 to 105, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.

TAIEX Index futures for July rose 189 points to finish at 6,414, with 2,507 contracts traded, while September futures gained 172 points to close at 6,299, with 128 contract transactions.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
