DOC.HEADLINE: FREQUENCY OF ASSASSINATION THREAT BROADCAST DETERMINED: NCC

TEXT.P: Members of the National Communications Commission (NCC) said Wednesday the commission has determined the frequency of an unlicensed radio station's recent broadcast in which the life of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was threatened.

Ke Chi-sen, director of the NCC Department of Broadcasting Affairs, said in a meeting called by the KMT legislative caucus that the commission had determined the frequency of the radio broadcast after an NCC monitor in southern Taiwan picked up the broadcast of the unlicensed radio station in which listeners were encouraged to end the life of Ma to scuttle the KMT's attempt to oust President Chen Shui-bian.

The broadcast could have originated from anywhere in the southern counties Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung, Ke said, adding that the contents of the broadcast were transcribed by the NCC which discovered that several people who called in to the radio show claimed to have made the threatening remarks.

KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said Taiwan's social order would be jeopardized and national security endangered if Ma were to be killed or wounded as a result of an underground radio's broadcast inciting of violence.

Kuo Su-chun, a deputy whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said that similar threats were made against former Premier Frank Hsieh and Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao last year and that police moved quickly to deal with both cases.
The police and prosecutors, however, have been slow in responding to the threats against Ma's life, Kuo claimed.

Tsai Ching-hsiang, director of the Department of Prosecutorial Affairs under the Ministry of Justice, said the law enforcement authorities formed an ad hoc committee Tuesday to deal exclusively with the assassination threat case, adding that any such threat inciting of violence will not be tolerated and will be dealt with according to the law.

Huang Jung-tiao, an official with the National Security Bureau, who was also present at the meeting, said that the Ma assassination threat rumors have been heard since the three-in-one elections last December and that the bureau has been moving to boost security for Ma on the one hand and to speed up the gathering of relevant information on the other.

Most of the unlicensed radio stations in southern Taiwan support President Chen and have therefore been broadcasting messages critical of the KMT's attempt to recall Chen over scandals involving his in-laws and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA AGREE ON CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: Taiwan has reached an agreement with China on measures with regard to four kinds of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, including the launch of special charter cargo flights, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman (MAC) Joseph Wu announced Wednesday.

The other measures are the regularization of cross-strait charter passenger flights for special holidays and the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs and humanitarian purposes, Wu said.
The agreement was established by the Taipei Airlines Association, which was authorized by the MAC to conduct talks with China on the issue, with the Beijing-based Civil Aviation Association.

Wu said the MAC will coordinate with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as soon as possible to work out rules related to the measures' implementation before accepting applications from airline companies interested in operating the services, Wu said.
While only airlines from Taiwan and China will be allowed to operate the charter services, their destinations must be those agreed upon by authorities of both sides, Wu said.

According to Wu, the special charter cargo flights are designated for Taiwan businesspeople with operations in China who need to ship machinery, facilities or related parts and components across the strait for their operations.
He said Taiwan will continue to negotiate with China to pave the way for the launch of regular charter cargo flights in the future.

Meanwhile, regular charter passenger flights will be available during the Chinese New Year, Tomb Sweeping Festival, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival holidays between Taoyuan and Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Xiamen in China, Wu said.

The duration of the holiday charter services will be 14 days before and after Chinese New Year Day and seven days before and after Tomb Sweeping Festival, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-Autumn Festival, he said.

Six airlines from each side will be allowed to join the services, with a total of 168 flights available per year, he said, adding that passengers eligible to take the flights are Taiwan residents with legal permits to enter and exit China and Taiwan as well as foreign and Chinese workers and dependents of Taiwan businesspeople.

While the emergency medical charter flights are intended for the delivery of personnel and medical facilities for emergency medical needs, the humanitarian charter flights are designed for relief and rescue efforts, the transportation of the physically challenged and other special circumstances agreed upon by both sides, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ PHOTO EXHIBITION TO MARK 40TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday that it would like to gather all kinds memorial photos and valued relics to celebrate its 40th anniversary.
"The 40th anniversary photo exhibition of the EPZ" is slated to be held from Dec. 1, 2006 to Feb. 28, 2007 at the National Science and Technology Museum in Kaohsiung.

The Kaohsiung export processing zone, which was the first of its kind in Taiwan, was established in December 1966 to help Taiwanese companies export their products. The Export Processing Zone (EPZ) has become a locomotive of Taiwan's economic development.
At the same time, an EPZ official said, Taiwan's EPZs have become a model for other countries to follow, attracting specialists from around the world to learn from the Taiwan experience.

To make the upcoming photo exhibition more meaningful and successful, the EPZ welcomes people to submit all kinds of photographs and items related to the history of the EPZ in Taiwan, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION TRIES TO COPY U.S. CONGRESSIONAL HEARING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" tried Wednesday to copy the congressional hearing system used in the United States as Taiwan's legislature was set to "review" a historic motion for recalling President Chen Shui-bian later in the month.

The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said that if the new measure is adopted, the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally the People First Party (PFP) will likely invite the president and his wife to answer charges against them at the Legislative Yuan.

KMT Legislator Kao Sze-po said the measure, being drafted by a lawyer, will offer a forum "like a court hearing" in which the defendants have ample time to explain themselves while helping to "find all the facts for the nation."

"The review process is a major incident that will set a precedent in the constitutional history of the Republic of China and must not be seen as a ploy of political struggle or partisan bickering, " Kao claimed.

Under the alliance's proposal, the intended recallee can attend the legislative "Committee of the Whole" review in person or by delegating a legislator to stand in for him, while the motion initiator and co-sponsors can also delegate a person to state the reasons for the recall bid.

Both sides can produce evidence to support their statements and invite witnesses to make statements as well as to be cross-examined. After the statements and cross-examinations, both sides will make concluding statements for the legislators and the people to make their own judgments.

Hung Hsiu-chu, convener of the KMT Ad Hoc Recall Group, said it is unfair for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which claims referendum as a universal right for all people, to "twist" the opposition's proposal "for the people to judge the president's integrity and competency" an attempt to wage political war and seize power.
If the motion is approved by two-thirds of the 221 legislators, it will then have to be endorsed by more than 50 percent of voters in a national referendum to become effective.

Pan Wei-kang, secretary-general of the KMT caucus, urged the DPP and its "pan-green camp" ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union to support the alliance's proposal for instituting a long-lasting measure for the review process.
The legislature is scheduled to hold plenary meetings to review the motion June 21-23 and June 26 to debate the recall motion before putting it to a vote June 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER RESPECTS PRESIDENT'S NO RESPONSE DECISION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that he respects President Chen Shui-bian's decision not to respond to a recall motion initiated by the opposition in the Legislative Yuan.
Wang said the legislature had already sent a letter to the Presidential Office, asking Chen to defend himself.
He said he respects the president's decision, although he claimed it would have been better for the president to respond to the request.
The opposition initiated the recall motion based on doubts over the president's competency and integrity in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations involving his son-in-law and close aides.
Regardless of whether Chen responds or not, the Legislative Yuan will go ahead and debate the motion June 21-23 and June 26 before putting it to a vote June 27.

Ker Chien-ming, a legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said the recall motion is the by-product of political infighting between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), which make up the "pan blue alliance."

Ker claimed that the recall motion was initiated by the PFP in an attempt to muster the support of "pan-blue" loyalists for PFP Chairman James Soong's bid for the Taipei mayorship. Main opposition KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at first disagreed with the move but later made an about-face for fear of drawing a backlash from "pan-blue" extremists that might lead to the defeat of KMT mayoral candidate Hau Lung-pin in the year-end election, Ker added.
Ker claimed that there is no evidence that Chen and first lady Wu Shu-jen are implicated in the corruption allegations, and said the DPP will back the president's decision not to respond.
But he also said the president needs to give a public explanation, adding that the Presidential Office has begun to prepare a report.
Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus asked if the president's decision is because he is "afraid to face the public."
Pan Wei-kang, a KMT caucus whip, claimed that "not defending himself is tantamount to acquiescence."

Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said Chen's performance over the past six years has grossly violated the pledges he made in his inauguration day, adding that the people entrusted him with power and can take away that power.
Legislator Lee Ching-hua claimed the president's decision is "because the statement can't be altered randomly and is subject to scrutiny under the sun."
The PFP legislative caucus said that "it regretted" the president's decision.
Lee Hung-chun, a PFP legislative whip, claimed it is because the president "cannot possibly explain all doubts about his integrity."

DOC.HEADLINE: FM TO ATTEND PRIVATE FORUM IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 13 (CNA) (By Lin Chiehyu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Huang Chih-fang will attend a private forum in Colorado from Thursday to Sunday, officials of the Taipei representative office in Washington, D.C. said Wednesday.
The American Enterprise Institute (AEI) World Forum, held annually since 1983 by the private think tank and the Vail Valley Foundation, will be presided over by former U.S. President Gerald Ford.

Former Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Tan Sun Chen have attended the forum several times during their terms as foreign minister, the officials said.
Other Taiwanese invited to this year's forum include Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, and Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group.
Huang will fly to New York for a brief stay after the forum, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR PUSHES FOR AUTONOMY BILL FOR INDIGENOUS PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Kung Wen-chi sponsored a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday calling for the legislation of an autonomy act allowing indigenous people living in the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan to own and run their own areas.

Kung, himself an aborigine legislator representing indigenous people around the country, said the Taroko people -- whom as a whole were acknowledged by the government as Taiwan's 12th aboriginal tribe only two years ago -- want an exclusive law to allow them access to autonomy, self-governance and self-determination to help free them from exploitation.

The Taroko National Park -- traditionally home to the Taroko people -- located in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County, has been exploited by two cement companies and a tourism hotel with complicity of the Taroko National Park Administration since 2004, triggering protests by the Taroko tribal men, who have said that only by enacting a new law can their rights and interests be protected, Kung said.

Kung said the Taroko people have reached a preliminary consensus on the autonomy need after the tribe convened 29 rounds of meetings since July 2004. The bottom-up legal proposal has also been endorsed by international indigenous organizations, including the Asian Indigenous Peoples Pact and the Peruvian Quechua Tribe, he added.

The proposed act, authored by Teyra Yudaw, chairman of the Taroko National Autonomy Promotion Committee, stipulates that the Taroko people can establish their own Taroko national parliament, a Taroko self-governance authority and an elders council as the group's legislative, administrative and judicial nerve centers to help the Taroko people rule themselves, uphold their rights and protect the homeland that their ancestors have handed down through the generations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP MEMBER INVITED TO RUN CHANGHUA'S PUBLIC TV CHANNEL

TEXT.P: An invitation from Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan for Chen Wuan-chen, a former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member who was an extreme pro-independence activist, to run the county's public television channel drew public attention Wednesday because Cho comes from the opposition Kuomintang, the DPP's political foe.
Chen said in response to media inquiries that since she is now an independent, her taking the job is based purely on the wish to do something for her hometown.

The non-profit Changhua County Public Channel Foundation passed a proposal Wednesday to hire Chen as chief executive of the foundation and to run the TV channel, which is mainly used for publicizing county policy.

Chen, a former newspaper journalist who founded a radio station to promote the independence movement, had been placed on a blacklist of political dissidents by the former KMT government. She served as a member of the National Assembly and as chief of social affairs of the Nantou county government before becoming a "cultural worker" in the central county.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT UNDECIDED AS TO ANSWER RECALL MOTION OR NOT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was considering whether or not to present an official statement defending himself against a recall motion initiated by the opposition in the Legislative Yuan, Presidential Office Secretary-general Tan Sun-chen said Wednesday.

The senior aide to the president claimed that the opposition's "10 great reasons" for recalling the president as "an insane irrational accusation, " and said Taiwan's people "will not be so easily duped."
Chen made the remarks in reply to media inquiries before a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) central executive committee meeting.

Citing the examples of the impeachments of former American presidents such as Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton, also brought by opposition parties, Chen said the reasons for those impeachments were very clear so the accused's replies were meaningful.

In contrast, Chen claimed that the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party just copied media stories to make up what they claim are "10 great reasons" to charge the president.
Regardless of whether the president responds or not, the Legislative Yuan will go ahead and debate the motion June 21-23 and June 26 before putting it to a vote June 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.04 to close at NT$32.620.
A total of US$9.37 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.710 and fluctuated between NT$32.522 and NT$32.749.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ANNOUNCES NEW MEASURES ON CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu announced Wednesday four kinds of special charter flight services between Taiwan and China, but said that relevant details cannot be made public due to a tacit agreement between the two sides.

Wu made the remarks at an Executive Yuan news conference in which he also announced that Taiwan and China have agreed to open special charter cargo flights, institutionalized holiday charter flights, and charter flights for emergency medical assistance and humanitarian purposes. Beijing officials also called a news conference to make the announcement simultaneously with the Taiwan side.

According to Wu, Taiwan and China agreed to first launch the four kinds of charter flights, although the two sides remain divided over setting up charter cargo and passenger flight services on a regular basis.

Asked when the cross-Taiwan Strait special charter cargo flights could be put in place, Wu said that Taiwan companies will be able to file applications within two weeks of the relevant measures being worked out.

Noting that applications for the special charter cargo flights will be screened on a case-by-case basis by the Civil Aeronautics Administration based on the model of this year's Lunar New Year holiday charter flights, he added that the planned holiday charter passenger flights could be institutionalized for the first time for this year's Mid-Autumn Festival.
In the meantime, the two sides will continue working on establishing cross-strait charter flights for both passenger and cargo traffic on a regular basis, the MAC head said.

Government Information Office Director-General Cheng Wen-tsan told reporters following the news conference that the development underlines the fact that government-to-government negotiations are necessary to forge direct transport links between Taiwan and China.

The development also makes it clear that the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" previous demand that a deadline be set for opening cross- strait direct transport links was "irrational," Cheng claimed, adding that bilateral legislation without two-way negotiations authorized by the governments through due process are useless.
Cheng promised that the government will handle cross-strait affairs cautiously and responsibly to best secure Taiwan's interests.

Meanwhile, Tsai Tui, vice minister of transportation and communications, commented that the cross-strait charter cargo flight services that the two sides have agreed upon is not comprehensive enough to meet Taiwan businessmen's needs.

He said that the scope of the service, limited to the transport of production equipment by China-based Taiwan businessmen between the two sides, should be expanded and he called for further two-way negotiations to push for overall normalization of cross-strait charter services.

In view of what the government claimed are "the breakthroughs" in cross-strait relations, sources in Taiwan's aviation industry expressed regret over the many restrictions remaining -- in particular the failure to open charter passenger flights on weekends.
It will be very difficult for carriers to attract enough passengers if passenger flights on weekends are not added to the charter services, they pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ARROGANCE' BEHIND PRESIDENT'S REFUSAL TO ANSWER RECALL MOTION: KMT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Wednesday that if President Chen Shui-bian refuses to defend himself at the Legislative Yuan, which will review a motion to recall him later in the month, it will lead the public to think that arrogance is behind the president's decision.
Ma made the remarks in reply to media questions during a tea party celebrating the moving of the KMT's head office to a new address in Taipei.
According to Ma, replying to a legislative invitation is "a privilege and an obligation." He added that "he can give up a privilege but cannot give up his obligation."
Ma said the recall motion has been put on the legislative agenda and the president should respect the legislature by explaining to it why he should not be recalled.
"Even if the president is very very unhappy, and very very unwilling to make a reply, he should make a reply," Ma claimed.
It will be a chance for him to defend his name and to show his respect for the Legislative Yuan, he added.
As a popularly elected president, Ma went on, Chen has a duty to respect "the highest institution representing public opinion."

Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to the president, said the president was still considering whether to accept a Legislative Yuan invitation to defend himself when it reviews the opposition-initiated recall motion June 21-23 and June 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10% OF TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES HAVE NOT BANNED SMOKING: POLL

TEXT.P: Approximately 10 percent of universities in Taiwan have not banned smoking, with toilets and dormitories being the most common indoor smoking areas, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by the Bureau of Health Promotion.
Bureau officials noted that the universities are violating the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act, which stipulates that smoking is forbidden on campus with the exception of designated smoking areas.
In approximately 60 percent of the 56 universities surveyed, less than 10 percent of male staff and faculty and less than 5 percent of female staff and faculty are smokers.

While 56 percent of the universities surveyed put the smoking rate among male students at between 11 percent and 20 percent, 74 percent of the universities surveyed put the rate among female students at below 5 percent.
A total of 11.1 percent of the universities surveyed have not set up any prominent "no smoking" signs.

In 39.9 percent of the universities surveyed, people have been seen smoking in indoor areas such as classrooms, libraries and stadiums, while stairways and corridors are where people are most commonly seen smoking on campus, the survey shows.

Cigarettes are sold in 5.5 percent of the universities, and 3.8 percent of the universities have not forbidden smoking in cafeterias, while 38.9 percent of the universities have not provided counseling on quitting smoking.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEIYI FREEWAY TO BE NAMED 'CHIANG WEI-SHUI FREEWAY'

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Wednesday that the Peiyi Freeway will be officially named the "Chiang Wei-shui Freeway" to commemorate Chiang, a pioneer of Taiwan's democratic movement who was born in northeastern Yilan County.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou thanked the Cabinet for the decision. Ma and the Yilan county government made the name proposal in January.

The 54.3-km freeway linking Taipei and Yilan counties, begins in Nankang in Taipei and ends in Suao in Yilan. The most difficult part of the road to construct was the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel, the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth-longest in the world.
Premier Su Tseng-chang noted that the Hsuehshan Tunnel, which was considered by some foreign experts to be "impossible to build, " will be opened to traffic June 16 after 15 years of construction.
According to Su, the freeway is "a combination of science, history and tourism."
Describing the Chinese name for the freeway as being "too long to remember, " Su said the new name is "appropriate" for the freeway as Chiang is a well-respected figure in Taiwan.

Chiang, who was born in 1891, was a physician and forerunner of the Taiwanese nationalist movement under Japan's rule. He formed the first political party in Taiwan and promoted many cultural activities and social movements during his lifetime.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER REJECTS CPC OIL-HIKE PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san stated categorically Wednesday that "it is not possible" for the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to increase fuel prices again following price hikes as recently as mid-April.

Maintaining stable consumer prices is a national economic policy, Hwang said, suggesting that the CPC make efforts to tap new resources and economize on expenses instead of taking more money out of consumers' pockets.
The state-managed company has to operate based on the interests of the country and its people, the minister said.
The CPC had submitted a proposal to the Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to seek permission to raise domestic fuel prices again.

The proposal points out that the CPC is faced with financial difficulties and is short of cash to buy crude oil, liquefied petroleum gas and liquefied natural gas since international crude oil prices have skyrocketed.

Hwang said it is understandable for the CPC to try to extricate itself from its financial problems. However, raising fuel prices is a "national business " and any changes have to be made based on the interests of the country and people, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL RESPECT CONSTITUTIONAL RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: In his first public response to a recall motion in an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he will respect it as long as the opposition adheres to the Constitution.

Speaking at an event marking the third anniversary of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, the embattled president said he will "give it respect" if the opposition leaders abide by the Constitution. The foundation is funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng serving as its chairman.
"Democracy has not come easy. Soliciting democracy is a right and defending democracy is a responsibility," he said.

The opposition-dominated legislature, which doubts the president's competency and integrity in the wake of a series of high-profile corruption allegations involving his son-in-law and close aides, began the recall motion proceedings Monday.

The legislature will debate the motion June 21-23 and June 26 before putting it to a vote June 27. If the motion gets a two-thirds endorsement of the legislature, which is considered very unlikely as the opposition only maintains a slim majority in the 221-seat legislature, it will be put to a national referendum.
The president also urged the opposition leaders "to put aside election feuds and calculations so that the judicial part can be left for the justice and the politics can be left to politics."
Let the judicial authorities probe and rule on all the allegations so that the nation can return to a normal and peaceful situation after the recent political turmoil, Chen urged.
On the detention of his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, since May 25 on suspicion of insider trading, he said he and his family have suffered tremendously in recent days.
He said he regrets that he has not set Chao, a half-son in traditional Chinese thinking, straight, but added that he will face justice and will support and rely on the justice system.
Everyone is equal before the law and everyone will have to face the law with no exception, he added.

He noted that times have changed and that during the previous authoritarian era, one had to challenge existing system in the pursuit of freedom, democracy, human rights and justice, but said "that era has passed."
He said democracy is the most important agenda in Taiwan, and that the Constitution and rule of law must be the norm.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE AIR RAID DRILLS TO KICK OFF THURSDAY

TEXT.P: A series of air raid drills is scheduled to take place around the country, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Wednesday.

MND officials announced that the "Wan-An" drill will be held in central Taiwan June 15, in southern Taiwan June 20, in eastern Taiwan June 22, on Penghu June 27, on Kinmen June 29, on Matsu July 4 and in northern Taiwan July 6.

The officials said that when the air raid siren sounds, pedestrians will have to clear the streets and vehicles will have to stop, although trains and vehicles on the country's freeways will not be affected.
Planes will take off and land normally, but arriving passengers will be led to evacuation points.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Prodi reiterates pro-European stance.
Italian Premier Romano Prodi confirmed again his pro-European stance Tuesday when he visited Vienna. In a joint news conference after meeting with his Austrian counterpart Wolfgang Schuessel. Prodi said that Europe and Italy's ties with other European countries will be of the priority. But he also affirmed Rome's strong ties with Washington, saying that Italy would avoid irritating the U.S. in its handling of troop withdrawal from Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SAVES 6-8 HOURS OF TRANSPORT

TEXT.P: The opening of four kinds of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, including special charter cargo flights, will significantly benefit humanitarian efforts between Taiwan and China, a consultant for International SOS said Wednesday.

Special cross-strait charter cargo flights will save six to eight hours of flying via third places and about half of the costs otherwise required for emergency medical or humanitarian transportation, said Tsai Hsing-han.
Currently, emergency medical or humanitarian flights across the Taiwan Strait must transit via a third place and change aircraft, causing money and time losses for passengers in need, Tsai said.

According to International SOS, about 500 to 600 Taiwan people are transported back to Taiwan from around the world via the International SOS mechanism each year. Most of the total are transported back to Taiwan from China, with the passengers' insurers paying the transport bills. The bill for a patient under intensive care averages about US$70,500 for a one-way trip.
Similar flights from Taiwan's offshore areas, including the islands of Kinmen and Matsu, to a hospital in Taiwan proper, cost about NT$400,000 (US$12,500) per trip, according to Tsai.

Tsai's remarks came in the wake of an announcement by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) earlier in the day that Taiwan has reached an agreement with China on measures with regard to four kinds of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, including the launch of special charter cargo flights.

The other measures are the regularization of cross-strait charter passenger flights for special holidays and the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs and humanitarian purposes, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said.
The agreement was established by the Taipei Airlines Association, which was authorized by the MAC to conduct talks with China on the issue with the Beijing-based Civil Aviation Association.

Six airlines from each side will be allowed to offer the services, with a total of 168 flights available per year, Wu said, adding that passengers eligible to take the flights are Taiwan residents with legal permits to enter and exit China and Taiwan as well as foreign and Chinese workers and dependents of Taiwan businessmen.

While the emergency medical charter flights are intended for the delivery of personnel and medical facilities for emergency medical needs, the humanitarian charter flights are designed for relief and rescue efforts, the transportation of the physically challenged and other special circumstances agreed upon by both sides, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM RAIN TOP NT$1 BILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses resulting from several days of torrential rain have climbed to NT$1.15 billion, according to the latest tallies released Wednesday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

The amount includes NT$922.97 million in crop damage, affecting 25,478 hectares of cropland, with the non-harvested areas totalling 5,023 hectares, COA officials said. Most severely damaged was rice, watermelons, grapes, peaches, pears, persimmons, tangerines, spring onions and peanuts.
Livestock damage amounted to NT$20.61 million, with 490 pigs, 283,000 chickens, 65,000 ducks and 15,808 geese dead, the officials said.

While fishery and forestry damages amounted to NT$4.85 million and NT$1.31 million, respectively, damage to agricultural and livestock facilities is valued at NT$65.48 million and NT$310,000, respectively, they said.
As relief measures for the agricultural sector, the government will provide farmers in Hsinchu and Taichung counties with relief funds and low-interest loans, they said.

While farmers in Taichung, Changhua, Nantou, Miaoli and Yunlin counties are entitled to low-interest loans, watermelon and cantaloupe farmers in Miaoli County, as well as turnip farmers in Nantou County, will be offered relief funds in addition to low-interest loans, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MEASURES ON CHARTER FLIGHTS DECEPTIVE: PFP

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) accused the government Wednesday of deceiving the public with an announcement on direct charter flight services between Taiwan and China.

PFP legislative caucus whip Lee Hung-chun made the accusation at a news conference after Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu announced earlier in the day that Taiwan and China have agreed to open four kinds of direct charter flight services -- special charter cargo flights for China-based Taiwan businessmen, holiday charter passenger flights, charter flights for emergency medical assistance and flights for humanitarian purposes.

Questioning why the government failed to set up charter passenger flights on weekends, which would be far more useful for Taiwan businessmen with operations in China, Lee said that charter passenger flight services that will be put in place for four major national holidays have little meaning.

The MAC was just trying to deal with the opposition's demand for establishing full direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait by making a "small compromise, " he claimed, adding that the PFP will continue pressuring the government to widen the scope of direct transport links to boost Taiwan's economy in the current extra legislative session ending on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: REQUEST DENIED TO FREE PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW ON BAIL

TEXT.P: Taipei District Court turned down a request Wednesday to release on bail Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law who is under detention for suspected involvement in an insider-trading scandal.
The court said Chao's reason for the request -- that his wife was expecting their third child in July -- had nothing to do with the prosecution's reasons for keeping him under custody.
The court noted that Chao's testimony was insufficient to be seen as a confession of crime and that there are witnesses who have yet to be questioned in connection to the case.
According to the court, there are still concerns that if he were freed he might seek to collude with others in an attempt to destroy evidence.

On June 6, according to the court's ruling against granting the request, Chao admitted that during a dinner party at a Japanese restaurant he heard Tsai Ching-wen, a board member of Waterland Securities Co., Su Teh-chien, chairman of the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) , and businessman Yu Shih-yi talking about selling TDC shares and about a plan to secure a syndicate loan to bail out TDC.

However, Chao denied passing on the information to his father Chao Yu-chu, claiming he had not contributed any money toward buying TDC shares. Rather, he told investigators, it was Tsai who approached his father to buy the shares.
Tsai has been freed after confessing wrongdoing. Yu and Su are still being detained.
The president has apologized for Chao's involvement in this much-reported scandal. On Wednesday, he again blamed himself for "failing to teach my son-in-law well."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: In Baghdad, Bush Pledges Support to Iraqi Leader; Visit Aimed at Buttressing Newly Formed Government.
President Bush told Iraq's prime minister and his cabinet Tuesday that "we'll keep our commitment" not to withdraw troops from the country until the new government is capable of defending itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: BETEL NUTS FROM CHINA SEIZED AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: An estimated 900 kilograms of betel nuts smuggled from China were seized at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Tuesday, a spokesman for the Taipei Customs Office said Wednesday.
The spokesman said the fresh betel nuts were packed in 44 bags, each weighing 20 kilograms.

The illegal shipment was expected to slip through custom checks early Tuesday morning, but was intercepted by customs agents. The nuts will be destroyed to prevent possible environmental damage by insects.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP RECOMMENDS PRESIDENT NOT RESPOND TO LEGISLATURE'S RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: The central executive committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian ignore a Legislative Yuan invitation to defend his position in response to a presidential recall motion.
Instead, the DPP said after a meeting of its central executive committee members, the president should speak directly to the people, to explain his stance and the achievements of his administration.

The "Report to the People" should also tell how difficult it has been over the past six years to govern Taiwan and the direction the DPP government is leading the country, according to a resolution adopted unanimously at the meeting.
Such a report would contrast with the "absurd and groundless" accusations made by the opposition in its recall motion and win back public trust and support, said the resolution.
Lin Chia-lung, DPP secretary-general, claimed the "pan-blue alliance" of Kuomintang and People First Party was using a judicial investigation to wage a political war in a bid to seize power.
"Members of the executive committee all agreed -- the DPP need not dance to the tune of the pan-blue alliance," he added.
Lin said the question of how to address the report directly to the people should be decided by the Presidential Office.

Faced with the legislative motion, the president must offer his version of the story to the public, although how to avoid presenting himself like an accused in a court trial is something the Presidential Office must consider too, former premier Frank Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND INDONESIA TO JOINTLY DEVELOP ENERGY RESOURCES

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san said Tuesday that Taiwan and Indonesia have reached an agreement on cooperation in energy resources development to ensure stable supply.
Hwang made the remarks after wrapping up a two-day visit to Indonesia, where he attended a ministerial-level economic conference. The last time the two countries held such a conference was in 2001.

Indonesia attaches great importance to trade with Taiwan, he said, and Indonesian Vice President Muhammad Yusuf Kalla's special aide warmly received Hwang's delegation when they arrived in the country Monday.
During the visit, Hwang met with Kalla and Indonesian ministers of energy, mineral resources and trade.

One of the main purposes of Hwang's Indonesia visit was to ensure a stable supply of fossil fuels for Taiwan, Hwang said, adding that Indonesia has reaffirmed its supply of liquid natural gas and coal to Taiwan under a contract signed earlier by the two countries.

Indonesia also expressed hope of cooperating with Taiwan in developing energy resources to ensure its stable supply, and welcomed Taiwanese enterprises to set up naphtha cracking plants in Indonesia, a prospect which Hwang said Taiwan needs to examine.

In addition, Indonesia plans to develop its information and communication industries, upgrade the development of its textile and footwear industries and its small- and medium-size enterprises, Hwang said, adding that Taiwan is glad to offer expertise to help with Indonesia's development in those fields.

According to Hwang, the Indonesian government will send a trade delegation to Taiwan in August in search of trade opportunities, and he has also invited Indonesia's Minister of Industry to visit Taiwan in the near future to strengthen bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 CLINICS TO HELP LOVELORN WOMEN LOSE WEIGHT AND FIND ROMANCE

TEXT.P: Fifteen clinics and hospitals throughout Taiwan have banded together to help lovelorn young women shed unwanted kilos and increase their chances of finding romance.

Dr. Hsiao Tun-jen, president of the Hsiao Tun-Jen Clinic in Chungli City, northern Taiwan, told reporters Wednesday that the 15 hospitals and clinics will provide free weight-loss services for three months to 150 young women who have found it difficult to have a romance because of body weight problems.

Hsiao pointed out that according to a recent online survey of 502 overweight young women, 66.5 percent of the respondents admitted their weight problems were a main factor in the break-up of their past relationships. Nearly 40 percent said they had tried to lose weight because of these experiences.

Of the 15 clinics and hospitals, seven are in northern Taiwan, with one in Taipei City, two in Taipei County, and one in Hsinchu County. Three others are in central Taiwan, and the other five are in southern Taiwan.
Registration for the free service is set for June 15-23, and qualified young women who are interested may contact the clinics and hospitals at http://www.heartbroken.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: In Iraq Visit, Bush Seizes on a Step Forward
In visiting Baghdad on Tuesday, U.S. President Bush was trying to deliver a carefully calibrated message to Americans: that Iraq and the administration's strategy there appear to be turning a corner, but troops will not be withdrawn anytime soon.
Wall Street Journal: Crude Calculations In Oil's New Era, Power Shifts To Countries With Reserves
Since World War II, the industrialized world has relied on stable and affordable supplies of crude to fuel economic growth. The U.S., Europe and Japan together needed more oil than they could produce. Industrialized countries tapped the cheap resources of poor ones. Now this mutual dependency is unraveling and a new order is taking shape, turning the tables on America, its allies and other big energy consumers. The world's top crude-producing countries are keeping a tighter grip on their spigots.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SIGN FREE TRADE PACT WITH NICARAGUA JUNE 16

TEXT.P: Taiwan will sign a free trade agreement with Nicaragua June 16 to further boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation, government officials said Wednesday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san and his Nicaraguan counterpart, Alejandro Jose Arguello Choiseul, will sign the agreement in Taipei on behalf of their governments. Arguello will travel to Taipei for the event.
The new agreement is set to take effect at the beginning of next year, the officials said.

The two countries completed free trade pact negotiations earlier this year. Nicaragua, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, will be the third country to sign a free trade accord with Taiwan, after Panama and Guatemala.
Two-way trade between the two countries totaled US$46.27 million in 2005, marking a 5.2 percent year-on-year growth and leaving a US$33.06 million trade surplus in Taiwan's favor.
Major Taiwan exports include textiles, kitchenware and plastic products, while imports from Nicaragua include frozen beef, coffee, timber and scrap metals.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAPITAL BALLET-TAIPEI TO PERFORM IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese ballet choreographers with extensive experience in performing abroad will be showcasing their art Friday evening in the northern county of Hsinchu with "Four Landscapes," a ballet in four acts.
The three dancers/choreographers worked with the Capital Ballet-Taipei in the troupe's early years, but they later traveled abroad to pursue their career goals.
They will join the troupe's leader, Hsu Chin-fong, in performing the "Four Landscapes" at the performance hall of Hsinchu County's Cultural Affairs Bureau.

The first act of "Four Landscapes, " "The Distance, " was choreographed by Lin I-fang, who has returned from performing in France. The second act, "Uncertainly Hovering, " was created by Wang Mei-hua, who has danced in the United States. "Man in Frame" was created by Hsu Chin-fong, the ballet company's leader, and "Angle" is by Lai Tsui-shuang, who has danced for the German Pina Bausch Tanztheater.
A Capital Ballet spokeswoman said this ballet is like four pictures of scenery in everyday life. The ballet company was founded in March 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT TAIWAN WILL WEATHER CURRENT POLITICAL STORM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he has full confidence in Taiwan's democracy and that he believes the people, in their utmost wisdom and ability, will definitely join him in weathering the current political storm so the country will soon return to normal.

The president, who is facing a presidential recall motion in the legislature, made the remarks while meeting with seven Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) county magistrates and city mayors from southern Taiwan who came to Taipei to voice support for Chen during the crisis.

Thanking the seven DPP local government chiefs, Chen said he hoped to have the chance to express his ideas and views to the public, outlining his administration's achievements as well as describing how difficult it has been over the past six years as head of Taiwan's government.

He said he faced a recall campaign in 2000 after his administration announced a suspension of construction on the fourth nuclear power plant in a move to realize his campaign promise of building a nuclear-free country.
"At that time, the opposition parties wanted to recall me simply because of a difference in views [on the nuclear power policy], " he said.
Earlier this year, Chen continued, his decision to cease the function of the National Unification Council also triggered calls for him to step down.

"I made that decision to consolidate Taiwan's democracy, hoping the people's right to decide on their own future would not be deprived. But the opposition claimed I should be recalled for doing just that," he said.

Commenting on the opposition's current recall campaign, the president said the opposition originally said the motion required some criminal evidence but then changed its own rationale by claiming a recall is a political action that requires no damning evidence.
He accused the opposition of using a judiciary investigation into his son-in-law's suspected involvement in insider trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) shares as a political tool to recall him.

Chen quoted a former Kuomintang (KMT) official as saying that while the KMT was the ruling party, "Courts are run by the KMT." After the DPP came to power, some people continued to say "Courts are run by the DPP," he added.

But six years after the DPP's rule, it has been proven that Taiwan's courts are not operated by the DPP, because whomever has committed a crime will be investigated and punished by the law without exception, not even the president's son-in-law and his son-in-law's father, Chen claimed.
He boasted this feature as a proud legacy in Taiwan that indicates the value and meaning of a transfer of power from one political party to another.
"This is absolutely not a liability," he claimed.
He assured his party comrades that as president of Taiwan, he will definitely carry on under the burden of the cross that is placed on him.
"I will never give up, discount or cede my duties as president, " he added.
So tomorrow, Thursday, he said he will visit outlying islets in Kinmen, near China, to demonstrate the execution of his duty as commander-in-chief of Taiwan's armed forces.
"While the opposition parties are waging a political struggle against me, I want to do my job with regard to maintaining national security."

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE FOOD-RELATED TRADE SHOWS SET FOR JUNE 21-24

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will hold an annual international food show -- Food Taipei 2006 -- June 21-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center, along with two other food-related shows: Foodtech Taipei 2006 and Taipei Pack 2006.
The three shows have signed up more than 800 exhibitors who have registered to use 2,371 booths in three exhibition halls at the trade center.

According to organizers, the three events will provide an excellent opportunity for global buyers whose shopping lists may run the gamut of food products, ingredients, tableware, containers, food processing machinery, and refrigerating and freezing equipment.
The exhibitions are expected to attract 45,000 domestic visitors and more than 3,000 buyers from abroad.
The first two days of Food Taipei 2006 will be reserved for companies only. The show will open to the public June 23-24, with admission set at NT$300 per head.

The food show will have 540 domestic and foreign exhibitors, who will occupy 1,570 booths. There will be 32 national pavilions for participating countries, including the United States, Canada, Spain, Chile, Japan, South Korea, Germany, Denmark, France, Mexico, the Philippines, and several Latin American countries.
The Taiwan Pavilion, the largest of all the national pavilions, will host 82 companies and use 172 booths.

To further promote Taiwan's cuisine, TAITRA will hold Taiwan Food Cerebration, which will feature delicacies by 48 recommended restaurants from around Taiwan and bring together the best chefs from Taiwan's top hotels to present their specialties.

Foodtech 2006, co-organized by TAITRA and Taiwan Food and Pharmacy Machinery Manufacturers Association, brings together 140 exhibitors who will use 509 booths. Buyers will be able to meet with Taiwan's leading suppliers of food processing equipment and peruse their products.

Taipei Pack 2006 is jointly held by TAITRA and the China (Taipei) Packaging Association. More than 100 exhibitors will display their products in 308 booths with product categories ranging from filling, packaging, weighing, printing, sealing machinery to multi-functional equipment, according to organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIMS TO PHASE OUT CAPITAL PUNISHMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday Taiwan is determined to phase out capital punishment in a gradual manner in tandem with the general world trend.
Chen made the reaffirmation while meeting with Siobhan Ni Chulachain, vice chairwoman of the Paris-based International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH), at the Presidential Office.

Chulachain presented a report on Taiwan's use of capital punishment authored by the FIDH in terms of the findings of its field surveys. The report made a case for Taiwan to craft a timetable for phasing out capital punishment. Taiwan is one of 72 countries in the world that have not yet abolished the death penalty.

Chen told Chulachain that abolishing capital punishment is Taiwan's ultimate goal. As local society has not yet shaped a consensus on the issue, he said, seeking the support of the public and the legislature is a critical part of the work to that end.

Despite the absence of a national consensus, Chen said his administration has continued laying groundwork for an eventual elimination of death penalty, including revising the Criminal Code to raise the ceilings of prison terms for multiple convictions and set new requirements for parole of life imprisonment convicts. These new regulations, which will take effect July 1 this year, are complementary measures in preparation for eventual abolishment of capital punishment.

Moreover, Chen said Taiwan has gradually reduced the number of death sentence and execution. In 1998, Chen said, Taiwan executed 32 death-row inmates, but the number plunged to three in 2005, and no execution has been made so far this year.
"These figures signify our efforts toward the 'no capital punishment' goal," Chen said.

To better protect local people's human rights, Chen said Taiwan will set up a national human rights commission in line with relevant U.N. conventions and will push for domestic legislation of international conventions regarding civil rights and political rights protection.

The FIDH groups 141 human rights organizations around the world with an aim to obtain effective improvements in the protection of victims, the prevention of human rights abuse and the prosecution of those responsible.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL SCIENCE PARK ESTABLISHES R&D AND INCUBATION CENTER

TEXT.P: National Chung Hsing University (NCHU) in Taichung began construction of an incubation center at the Central Taiwan Science Park Wednesday with an aim to bolster local manufacturers' technological innovation.
Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng and a number of prominent academic figures attended a ground-breaking ceremony for the new R&D center.

NCHU President Shaw Jei-fu said that cooperation between private manufacturers and talented individuals from his university will be "a great leap" for the development of industry in the country. The new facility is scheduled for completion in September 2007.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, June 15:
09:10, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will deliver a speech at a seminar on Taiwan's labor affairs to be organized by the Legal Aid Foundation.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference.
10:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang and Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang will attend a Police Day celebration gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER LEAVES FOR U.S. TO ATTEND WORLD FORUM

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang left for the United States Wednesday to attend a forum on international economic and strategic affairs.
Huang said prior to his departure that he will attend the World Forum, to be co-organized by the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), a noted private think tank, and the Vail Valley Foundation.

The forum, to be held at Beaver Creek, Colorado from June 15-18, will bring together U.S. politicians, academics and business executives as well as their counterparts from major European and Asian countries to exchange views on international economic and strategic issues.
Huang said he will stay in the United States for five to six days.
The AEI World Forum has been held annually since 1983. In 2005, U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney and then-Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan attended the forum.

In addition to a plenary session to be presided over by former U.S. President Gerald Ford, the forum will also include a series of panel sessions to be moderated by business executives, government officials and academics, respectively. U.S. Cabinet ministers and congressional leaders have traditionally given briefings on major U.S. policy initiatives at the closed-door panel sessions.
Taiwan's sitting foreign minister has invariably been invited to attend the annual event.
Other Taiwanese invited to this year's forum include Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., and Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 15, or the 20th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border west of the Great Lakes.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down in Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1944: U.S. forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the U.S. envoy to China notifies the Chinese government of the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the U.S., Great Britain and the USSR agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The People's Daily, a Chinese Communist Party newspaper, publishes its first issue.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastics raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1975: Chang Pao-shu, secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, and four other members leave for Tokyo to attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Eikaku Sato.
1976: Maj. Gen. Kin Sang Tao, chief of the South Korean Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1981: Sun I-suan, chairman of the Taipei Bankers Association, announces an increase in the highest deposit interest rate to 15 percent and in the top loan rate to 18 percent.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries -- Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest level ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
1999: South Korea sinks one North Korean gunboat and heavily damages others in the Yellow Sea.
2000: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Exhibition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with exhibitors from more than 10 countries participating.
2001: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says the information technology (IT) industry will remain be the top player among all industries in the next 10 years.
2004: The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union is inaugurated with former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya as its founding chairwoman.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To preach in the public streets the commonplaces which you have picked up on the way is to throw away all your finer feelings."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES PROGRESS ON CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 14 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States Wednesday applauded the latest agreement reached between Taiwan and China on the expansion of cross-strait charter flight services.
A U.S. State Department official in charge of East Asian affairs told Taiwan reporters that the agreement represents major progress in the promotion of cross-Taiwan Strait interaction.
This progress will help enhance the common interests of the people on both sides of the strait and achieve cross-strait peace, stability and prosperity, the official said.
The official suggested that Beijing and Taipei continue their dialogue and cooperation and urged Beijing to have direct contact with the elected leaders of Taiwan.
On Wednesday, Taipei and Beijing simultaneously announced that they had reached an agreement with regard to measures on expanding cross-strait charter flight services.

The measures included the launch of special charter cargo flights, the regularization of cross-strait charter passenger flights for special holidays as well as the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs and humanitarian purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOMPETENCY CAN BE REASON FOR RECALLING ELECTED OFFICIALS: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou called for President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to "get it right that recalling does not have to hinge on committing a crime and that incompetency and dereliction of duty can be reasons for recalling an elected official."

Replying to media questions after chairing a meeting of city government officials, whom he also leads as mayor, Ma said that for example, the governor of California was recalled three years ago because he did not handle well the power rationing issue.

Gray Davis was at the time also suspected of embezzling political donations, which contributed to his low popularity of a little over 20 percent, Ma said, noting that "the governor did not commit a crime but was still recalled."

In Taiwan, the Legislative Yuan is the first hurdle for passing a recall motion which sets a threshold of a two-thirds majority vote, which offers good protection to the intended recallee, Ma said. "And yet, the president does not want to answer the legislature's charges. It is unfair, " he added.
In many other countries, Ma said, a motion for recalling the president is initiated by the people and so it is not a problem for the president to make a reply directly to the people.
"If (President Chen) wants to report to the people, why can't he report to the legislature, the highest organ representing the people?" Ma asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L COMMUNITY POSITIVE ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The international community is positive about the agreement reached between Taiwan and China Wednesday on cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Michel Lu said that the United States, the European Union, and countries in the Asia Pacific region have responded positively to the agreement, adding that they believe that it will contribute to the maintaining of peace, stability and prosperity in the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan and China announced simultaneously Wednesday that they had reached an agreement on measures concerning four kinds of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, including the launch of special charter cargo flights.
The other measures are the regularization of cross-strait charter passenger flights for special holidays and the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs and humanitarian purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN ACCUSES OPPOSITION OF USING JUDICIAL CASES TO TRY TO USURP POWER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accused the opposition Thursday of taking advantage of judicial cases to try to usurp power by initiating a motion to recall him over the insider trading allegations against his son-in-law.

In the latest edition of his online newsletter, Chen wrote that over the past six years since the ruling Democratic Progressive Party came to power, a tug-of-war between pro-reform and anti-reform forces has been going on in Taiwan.

"The political storms, including presidential recall campaigns and no-confidence votes against the Cabinet, that I have faced repeatedly since my inauguration in 2000 are all the result of this political struggle, " Chen said.
According to Chen, the differences over the direction, objective and method of reforms should be resolved through discussion and should not be turned into a politicized debate.
"What is more unacceptable to us is for some political parties or individuals to take advantage of judicial cases to try to usurp political power," he said.

The president said he is sorry that he failed to make everyone happy about his performance, although he has tried very hard to do a good job to improve the freedom, democracy, prosperity and stability of Taiwan over the past six years.

Chen said that his being elected by the people to the presidency means "responsibility and obligations rather than fame or power" and that from the day he was sworn in, he accepted the responsibilities and obligations handed to him by the people.

"Everyday during my term, I must do the best job possible and honestly exercise the power granted by the Constitution. I will not cross the line or drag my feet, nor will I be influenced by the recent uproar," he said.

Expressing confidence in Taiwan's judiciary, democracy and people, Chen said it is unnecessary for him to "dance to the tune of others" and that he believes the people will give him their support as long as he persists in "doing the right thing and walking the right path."

The Legislative Yuan is set to review an opposition-initiated motion to recall Chen next week and has requested Chen to present a written statement to the legislature to respond to the charges made against him before the review process starts.

It is likely that Chen will ignore the request, with DPP officials dismissing the rationale of the recall campaign as "reckless" and "ridiculous" and suggesting that the president report directly to the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECISION TO SUMMON FIRST LADY TO BE MADE ACCORDING TO LAW: PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: The prosecution will decide whether or not to summon first lady Wu Shu-jen according to the law, based on the on-going investigation into the ownership fight over Pacific Sogo Department Store, a prosecutor said Thursday.

Prosecutor Lin Pang-liang of the Taipei District Court said that the prosecution has summoned most witnesses or suspects in connection with a financial bail-out and ownership fight for the store and that it is now probing the flow of vouchers.

It was the use and sale of Pacific Sogo gift vouchers that the first lady was allegedly involved in. "Depending on the needs of the investigation of the case, we will decide whether or not to summon Wu Shu-jen," Lin said.

As to media reports that the prosecutors may visit Wu's residence to conduct their questioning, Lin said it is too early to speculate how the prosecution will go about questioning Wu if it decides to do so.
"Every step will be followed according to the law, and what should be done will be done," he said.
Cheng Li-wen, spokeswoman for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , urged the judicial authorities not to "draw a red line" for investigators.

Taiwan is a democracy and all men and women are equal before the law, she said, urging the prosecution not to grant any special privileges to members of the first family when it comes to investigating alleged crimes.

While encouraging the working-level judicial officials to "just do your job in finding all the facts about alleged irregularities, " Cheng called on top officials of the judicial branch to "resist political pressure and support your staff's independent investigation."

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN NT$400 BILLION IN BUSINESS CONTRACTS SIGNED AT COMPUTEX

TEXT.P: The Computex Taipei 2006 has netted business contracts totaling over NT$400 billion (US$12.3 billion) for Taiwan- based manufacturers, according to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

A TAITRA spokesman said Thursday that the council has held the Computex -- the second largest show in the world for information technology products -- for 26 consecutive years and that this year's show is the largest to date in terms of number of booths and participants.
According to TAITRA statistics, 1,312 local companies set up 2,907 stands at this year's Computex, which attracted 130,000 foreign buyers, IT professionals and members of the general public.

The official said the new expo hall of the Taipei World Trade Center in Nankang will be fully operational by 2008, offering space for 2,000 booths. The current exhibition halls in Sungshan District have a 3,000-booth capacity.
He added that with space for more than 5,000 booths, the Computex Taipei should become the most important showcase for IT products in the Asian-Pacific region.
