The government and other parties involved in the dispute over the Ninoy Aquino International Airport Terminal 3 (NAIA-3) are close to reaching an agreement that could lead to a "surprise" opening of the facility soon, Trade Secretary Peter Favila disclosed yesterday.
The Manila Times: Sex syndicate lures Filipinas to Dubai
THE Philippine Overseas Employment Administration on Wednesday exposed a human-trafficking ring that recruits Filipino women as prostitutes in Dubai in the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BREAKFASTS CONTAIN EXCESSIVE CALORIES, LACK CALCIUM

TEXT.P: A survey found that the typical breakfast of elementary school children in Taiwan is excessive in calories and deficient in calcium.

Judging from the breakfast menus provided by more than 600 parents around the island, professor Chen Chun-jun from Taipei Medical University found that nearly 80 percent of children in the country ingest less than 300 milligrams of calcium for breakfast, or one-third of the daily amount suggested for children.
According to Chen, the main foods eaten for breakfast by Taiwan children are bread, rice porridge, hamburgers, sandwiches, and egg cakes, with milk tea and soybean milk being the main beverages.

In general, the average breakfast eaten by children in Taiwan is excessive in calories and deficient in calcium, Chen said, adding that some beverages containing caffeine even affect calcium absorption.
Chen stressed that insufficient calcium will affect children's growth and learning capability.
In addition, food deficient in calcium will make children prone to be nervous and irritable, which can be aggravated by lack of quality sleep, Chen said.

Chen suggested that parents prepare breakfasts that are higher in calcium for their children, saying that fresh milk, tofu, cheese, fried fish and green soybean are all good choices. He said this will help improve their children's concentration and calm their mood during the morning, which he pointed out is the best period of the day for learning.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Laws proposed to keep research data private.
New laws have been proposed to safeguard the privacy of individuals who agree to take part in medical research.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore's ties with Australia have never been stronger.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Ancient Hand Inspires Talk of Miracles
Thousands of people, many of them old women wearing long skirts and head scarves, shaded themselves with umbrellas as they waited for hours Wednesday to see and kiss a chest containing the purported right hand of John the Baptist. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Public finance continue worsening.
Finance and Economics Minister Tommaso Padoa Schioppa said at a joint meeting of Senate and House committees Wednesday that the public finance continues worsening with rising debt. He said that although the nation's economy is recovering. it has not yet been substantial.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUAM SOLICITING TAIWAN VISITORS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the third largest source of visitors to Guam, with around 30,000 visits from Taiwan people every year, a Guam Visitors Bureau official said Thursday.

Pilar Laguana, marketing manager of the Guam Visitors Bureau, and Miss Guam Tourism 2006 Risha Michelle Marque Aguon promoted Guam's tourism at a news conference in Taipei, hoping to solicit more Taiwanese visitors.
Laguana said that around 1.2 million people visit Guam every year, with Japanese being the largest group at around 900,000 visitors annually, followed by Koreans at 100,000 and Taiwanese at 30,000.
Most Taiwanese tourists are professionals, businesspeople or executives, and they usually stay for four or five days, Laguana said.

She said that Taiwan visitors can enter Guam without a visa and that Guam offers a wide variety of interesting activities, such as golfing and shopping. She especially recommended diving activities because of Guam's clean water.
Guam Visitors Bureau is taking part in a tourism exhibition which kicked off at the Taipei World Trade Center Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Bashir freed after sentence for Bali attacks
Radical Indonesian cleric Abu Bakar Bashir walked out of a Jakarta prison Wennesday after serving time for links to the 2002 bali bombings, calling on jubilant supporters to joi n forces for the spread of Islamic law.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Crackdown Underway in Baghdad.
American and Iraqi troops launched a large- scale security sweep in Baghdad this morning after a surprise 5 1/2-hour visit to the Iraqi capital by President Bush on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES HIT US$33.23 M. AFTER DAYS OF TORRENTIAL RAINS

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses in the wake of recent torrential rains have reached NT$1.08 billion (US$33.23 million) , according to the Council of Agriculture's (COA's) latest statistics released Thursday.

The tallies show that crop losses total NT$985.92 million to date, with 25,884 hectares of farmland having been affected, or 20 percent of the total farmland in Taiwan. Crops most seriously affected by the torrential rains and flooding include rice, watermelons, grapes, persimmons, peaches, pears and oranges.

In addition, livestock and poultry losses amount to NT$20.61 million to date, with a total of 490 pigs, 283,000 chickens, 65,000 ducks and 15,808 geese dying in the flooding triggered by the torrential rains.

Fishery losses have reached NT$4.85 million, forestry losses have hit NT$1.31 million, farmland and agricultural facility losses have topped NT$73.32 million, and livestock and poultry facility losses have hit NT$310,000.
COA officials announced that affected farmers in the counties of Taichung, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Nantou and Yunlin are eligible for subsidies or low-interest loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down 56 points to close at 6,409, with 51,995 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July dropped 44 points to finish at 6,370, with 3,475 contracts traded, while September futures lost 79 points to close at 6,220, with 65 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 54 points to close at 6,246, with 24 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,465 for June, 6,414 for July, 6,299 for September, 6,300 for December and 6,230 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 3.6 points to close at 266.6, with 5,954 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 4.3 points to finish at 264.5, with 389 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 4.65 points to close at 262.15, with two contracts traded, while December TE futures dropped 10.45 points to finish at 260.05, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.
June TF futures moved down 2.4 points to finish at 944.6, with 3,087 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures gained 0.2 points to close at 939.6, with 257 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KING OF SWAZILAND ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: King Mswati III of Swaziland and Queen I. LaDube, his 12th wife, arrived in Taipei with a 40-strong economic and cultural delegation Thursday for a six-day visit, according to a statement issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
A ceremony in honor of the king's arrival will be held on Friday at 10:30 a.m. at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
The statement said that Mswati's entourage includes the ministers of foreign affairs, economics, labor affairs and energy, as well as leaders of Swaziland's industry and business sectors.

The king of Swaziland and his entourage are scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian during their stay and to attend the annual "Africa Day" activities Friday, which will be presided over this year by Chadian Ambassador Hussein Brahim Taha. They are also scheduled to attend investment fairs in Taipei and Kaohsiung on June 17 and 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR BETS JOB IN SOGO VOUCHERS SAGA

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker pledged Thursday that he would quit his job if his claims about suspected irregularities surrounding the use and sale of Pacific Sogo Department Store vouchers turned out to be a sham.

Chiu Yi of the Kuomintang (KMT) made the vow at a Legislative Yuan public hearing on a Sogo gift voucher saga that was boycotted by all invitees, including first lady Wu Shu-jen and Bureau of Investigation Director Yeh Sheng-mao.

Evidence shows Wu has used some of the suspicious vouchers, Chiu told the public hearing sponsored by legislative caucuses of the KMT and People First Party (PFP) , which form the "pan-blue alliance" in Taiwan's politics.

He has previously claimed that a group of seven ladies -- wives of senior officials and rich businessmen -- had jointly bought the vouchers and that "old vouchers" issued by the store's former management had been exchanged for new ones in larger denominations.
"All these claims can be verified," he stated.

He challenged Formosa Television and the Liberty Times newspaper "to quit the market," as well, if the two media outlets' reports were proven untrue when they alleged his stories about the Sogo vouchers "had mistaken incident A for incident B" and were a "big sham."

In connection with the ownership fight over the department store, the prosecutors summoned Ma Yung-cheng, former deputy secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, for questioning Thursday. This was the second time Ma has been called in for questioning in relation to the suspected acceptance of favors.

Also under questioning was Chen Che-nan, another senior aide to the president, who is under detention on charges of fraud in an influence-peddling case and has been indicted in connection with the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal.
Judicial sources said Ma and Chen, both right-hand men of the president, would face each other in a cross-examination about their respective roles in the Sogo saga.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 42.62 points to close at 6,426.39.
The bourse opened at 6,531.81 and fluctuated between 6,535.13 and 6,418.77 during trading. A total of 3.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.83 billion (US$2.54 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock category gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up at 0.2 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 557 to 234, with 92 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER HSIEH ANNOUNCES BID FOR TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh announced Thursday that he will represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in December's election for Taipei mayor.
Hsieh made the announcement at a news conference, accompanied by DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming and DPP Taipei branch committee head Lee Cheng-yi.

Hsieh said that he finally decided to "share the party's burden" by agreeing to take part in the mayoral election in Taipei-- capital and the largest city in Taiwan -- because the DPP "cannot afford to be absent from the race."
Hsieh called for public support and vowed to campaign in a "clean and healthy way" by denouncing mudslinging, vote-buying, violence and rehashing ethnic issues.

The DPP has for some time courted Hsieh, one of the most popular figures in the ruling party, to run in the year-end election for Taipei mayor at a time when it has been dogged by a series of corruption allegations implicating family members of President Chen Shui-bian and his close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TFGH MARCHING BAND TO TAKE PART IN U.S. INDEPENDENCE PARADE

TEXT.P: The celebrated marching band of Taipei First Girls High (TFGH) School has been invited to take part beginning June 30 in an American parade marking the 230th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence of the United States, a TFGH source said Thursday.

Taipei Deputy Mayor Chin Pu-tsung presented the Republic of China national flag to the 160-member TFGH marching band at a ceremony held at the high school. He gave his blessing to band members, exhorting them to demonstrate all the talent and energy of Taiwanese girls, and to be "sunshine Mulans" -- a reference to an ancient Chinese heroine who posed as a man to join the army in place of her aged father and was later commended by the king for her service.

The TFGH marching band is scheduled to take part in an Independence Day parade in Annapolis, Maryland July 4 before performing at Longweed Gardens in the state of Pennsylvania July 2, and at Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium in Washington, D.C. July 3, the TFGH source said.

TFGH's marching band is considered a source of pride for Taiwan after it first performed overseas in 1996. The band won rapturous applause when it marched and played in the Pasadena Rose Parade in California in December that year.

The band has been invited to take part in parade events in the United States almost every year since 1996. It has also given performances in Japan, Singapore, South Africa, Great Britain and China over the past years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PUBLISHER DEBUTS TRAVEL GUIDE TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 14 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A leading travel publisher in Germany, Polyglott Tours & Travel AG, published a new guidebook this month that is considered the most useful and detailed German-language source of information for traveling in Taiwan.

The 106-page color travel guide contains comprehensive summaries of Taiwan's history, culture and politics, while recommending four key tours in the island's northern, central, southern, and eastern regions, and covering 12 major sightseeing attractions including the capital city of Taipei, the wood sculpture township of Sanyi and Kenting National Park.

The guide also provides detailed information about special folk traditions and cultural life in Taiwan, such as the night markets, hot springs, tea ceremony, local religion and traditional puppet shows.

The author, Guenter Whittome, also reminds his readers -- would-be travelers to Taiwan -- of the existence of many cultural differences, such as the custom of not leaving chopsticks upright in bowls or the acceptability of making lip-smacking noises while dining.
For instance, Whittome notes in his new book that most Taiwanese are not accustomed to paying the check separately while dining with friends because one of them will "fight to pay."

Whittome, who holds a degree in Sinology from Hamburg University, said in an interview with CNA Wednesday that to refresh the German media's outdated image of Taiwan, he spent more than half a year writing the guidebook hoping his compatriots would better understand modern Taiwan and how its culture differs from China's.
Whittome has resided in Taiwan for three years, and is currently working as a translator in Taipei.
Taiwan's Tourism Bureau in Frankfurt has ordered 10,000 copies of the book to send free copies to Europeans who are preparing to travel to Taiwan, office director Chan Wei-ting said.
The new Taiwan guidebook is expected to be on shelves of bookstores around Germany and German-speaking countries including Austria and Switzerland, according to Polyglott.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.079 to close at NT$32.541.
A total of US$840 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.630 and hit a low of NT$32.478.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC NOT TO POLITICIZE PEIYI FREEWAY PROJECT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the public Thursday not to politicize the upcoming official opening of the Peiyi Freeway, which he called "a major construction project that belongs to all of the people."

Responding to allegations that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has hastened construction work at the expense of safety considerations in an attempt to take credit for the project, Chen said "the credit and honor do not go to myself alone just because the project has been completed during my term."
The president said such "politicized defamation" is severely damaging to the morale of the thousands of workers who built the Peiyi Freeway.

Chen made the remarks in the latest edition of his online newsletter, in which he paid tribute to the 25 workers who died during the construction of the Hsuehshan Tunnel -- the centerpiece of the 55-km Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei to the northeastern county of Yilan. The 13-km tunnel -- the fifth longest of its kind in the world and Southeast Asia's longest -- is set to be inaugurated Friday.

According to Chen, the Hsuehshan Tunnel is one of the most difficult construction projects in the world owing to fragile geological conditions and bountiful underground water deposits, which have caused several accidents and seriously hindered the progress of construction.
However, the difficulties were finally overcome with the persistent efforts of the government and construction workers over the past 15 years, he said.

Chen pointed out that two presidents and eight premiers have witnessed the tunneling project since its inception on July 15, 1991, and that each of these leaders have contributed toward the Peiyi Freeway and Hsuehshan Tunnel projects.
"The Peiyi Freeway belongs to all of the people. The painting inside the Hsuehshan Tunnel is also colorful, definitely not completely blue or green," he said.

Chen noted that the inauguration of the Hsuehshan Tunnel will mark the Peiyi Freeway's official opening to traffic, which will significantly cut down travel time between Yilan and the Western part of Taiwan to 30 minutes.
"This is not only the third historic milestone in the development of Yilan's outbound transportation but it's also a sign that the development of Yilan is entering a new stage," Chen said.
"This is a major event for Yilan and Taiwan, and a cause for great celebration by the whole nation," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WELCOMES VISIT OF LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that a U.S.-based representative of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) has informed him the United States "welcomes him for a visit."

Wang made the remarks amid news reports that the long-stalled arms procurement package with the United States has affected Taiwan-U.S. relations. Taiwan's diplomatic corps has attempted to arrange Wang's meeting with U.S. officials, but the United States had declined the request on grounds that "the arms procurement project has yet to make headway," according to the reports.

The multi-billion-dollar arms deal -- including the purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries -- has been blocked for two years by the opposition-dominated legislature.

Wang said that Yuan Chien-sheng, the U.S.-based representative of the KMT and PFP, has conveyed the United States' welcome gesture and that the U.S. also wants to learn about the reasons behind such reports.
Wang has canceled his planned trip in late June to the United States because of an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan slated for June 13-30.

Wang received Stephen Yates, former deputy national security adviser to U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney, earlier in the day, and Yates expressed concern about the political turmoil in the wake of a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian initiated by the "pan-blue alliance" in the legislature.
The opposition argues the President's leadership has been cast in doubt in the wake of a series of corruption allegations against Chen's son-in-law and close associates.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGAZINE LAUNCHED FOR VIETNAMESE WOMEN IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A magazine catering to the needs and tastes of Vietnamese women married to Taiwanese men was launched in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Wednesday.

The quarterly magazine is published by a Christian family service association to help Vietnamese spouses obtain information about their new living environment and adapt to local customs and lifestyles.
An association spokeswoman said the magazine will mainly be in Vietnamese, with Chinese as a supplementary language, so that its readers can easily understand the content.

According to official tallies, Kaohsiung has 801 families with foreign spouses, 60 percent of whom hail from Vietnam. Because of language and cultural barriers, the spokeswoman said, many foreign spouses have had a hard time adapting to life here.
"We hope the new publication can be a useful guide and help enrich their lives through offering information and sharing experiences and feelings," the spokeswoman said.
The magazine will be distributed free to households with Vietnamese spouses and to relevant service organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOL DONATES CASH FOR EARTHQUAKE RELIEF IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: An international school in northern Taiwan has donated a cash award it won to provide relief for earthquake victims in Indonesia.

Teams from Hsinchu's Holland International School won the 1st, 3rd and 4th prizes in this year's Dragon Boat Race in the international team event. The teams that won 1st and 3rd decided to donate the NT$44,000 (US$1,350) prize money to the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- a local charity.
Hsinchu Mayor Lin Cheng-tze, who attended an annual party of the school Thursday, donated the money to Tzu Chi officials on behalf of the school.
The international school has 150 students from 20 countries and uses English as the major language for teaching.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSIDER TRADING CASE AFFECTS PHYSICIANS' DATING OPPORTUNITIES: AGENCY

TEXT.P: A dating agency that has doctors as its main clients claimed Thursday that fewer women want to date doctors due to the negative effect caused by Chao Chien-ming, President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law who has been detained for alleged insider trading.

An agency executive said doctors are usually popular in Taiwan's marriage market but that the trend has reversed since the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome a few years ago, in which doctors were prone to infection, and other factors such as drops in salary due to the change in the payment system for hospitals and physicians under the national health insurance program.
The situation was aggravated with Chao's alleged involvement in an insider trading scandal. Chao is an osteopath.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAN AN AIR-RAID DRILL TAKES PLACE IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The No. 29 Wan An air-raid drill for central Taiwan took place in Taichung City Thursday, with all pedestrians and drivers told to clear the streets.
The 30-minute drill began at 2 p.m. when the air-raid siren sounded. Cars were ordered to stop and stores and shops were told to close their doors.
The movements of trains and cars on the freeways were not affected by the drill, but passengers disembarking at the station and cars exiting the freeway were told to take shelter.

Deputy Commanding General Lee Tien-yi of the Air Force Headquarters, who was the deputy commander of the exercise, inspected drill operations at the Taichung Central Railway Station in the company of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.
A fire drill was performed at the station, along with an exercise simulating an incident in which a passenger had a heart attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S KINMEN TRIP CANCELED DUE TO BAD WEATHER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's scheduled trip to the outlying island of Kinmen Thursday was canceled because of deteriorating weather conditions that developed as he was due to land.
The troops that President Chen was slated to inspect were prepared for his arrival, but the president's plane was forced to turn back due to low clouds and increasingly strong winds.

Chen was expected to announce his determination to preserve security on Kinmen, the frontline of Taiwan's defenses against the threat from China, amidst ongoing political turmoil currently embroiling the country.
A military source said the president's visit requires high security standards and that it was the first time a presidential trip to Kinmen had been canceled.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST RICE TRADING CENTER TO OPEN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The country's first rice trading center will become operational June 22 in southern Tainan city, a spokesman for the center said Thursday.

According to the spokesman, the southern rice trading center will be the first of its kind to open in Taiwan and will be responsible for rice trading in the Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Pingtung and Penghu areas, where the first crop of the year has recently been harvested.

The trading center, run by the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, will open its market every two weeks, with retail vendors and distributors required to buy no more than five metric tons of rice and 30 metric tons, respectively, in each deal, the spokesman said, noting that the center has 303 metric tons of new rice for auction.

The rice trading centers to be opened in northern, central, southern and eastern regions will provide farmers' associations and dealers across the country with additional channels of sales and new clients, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNILATERAL DIRECT BILL NO ALTERNATIVE TO NEGOTIATIONS: CABINET

TEXT.P: "Pushy, " one-sided legislation of a law governing the opening of direct transport links between Taiwan and China can never supersede official negotiations between the two sides on the issue, a government spokesman said Thursday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the administration will promote cross-Taiwan Strait interaction, including the opening of direct transport links, only when Taiwan's identity is championed and the government's power of authority secured.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced a day earlier that Taiwan had reached agreement with China on measures with regard to four kinds of cross-strait charter flight services -- the launch of special charter cargo flights, the regularization of cross-strait charter passenger flights for special holidays, the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs and flights for humanitarian purposes.

The opening of the new measures is not only poised to provide better services for people traveling across the Taiwan Strait but has been met favorably by U.S. liaison officers stationed in Taiwan, Cheng claimed.

Nevertheless, Cheng said, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has continued to push for the passage of a cross-strait direct transport links bill and the bill will be screened during the June 13-30 extraordinary legislative session.

Cheng reiterated that cross-strait exchange programs can be implemented only after government-authorized negotiations are completed to ensure that such policies, including cross-strait transport links, are safe and that Taiwan's interests are not compromised.

Cheng ridiculed some politicians for what he described as "wishful thinking" that direct transport links can be opened as a result of "pushy, one-sided legislation" passed in an extra legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IT MANUFACTURER SHOWS MILITARY-PURPOSE LAPTOPS AT COMPUTEX

TEXT.P: The most unique and "confidential" exhibits at the Computex Taipei 2006 are four new models of "rugged" notebook computers made by a Taiwan-based information technology group that supplies the army, special forces, and police of the United States, according to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) which organized the show.

A TAITRA official said Thursday that the "rugged laptops" -- made by GETAC under MiTAC Co. -- feature great resistance against dust, water, extreme temperatures, shock and vibration, and are suitable for military operations under harsh conditions.

Comparing the notebooks to commercial purpose ones, Lin Hung -- a MiTAC spokesman -- said that rugged laptops emphasize high survival rates over high-speed calculations or high performance in graphics.

Citing an example from US operations in Iraq, Lin said several months ago a Humvee loaded with combatants ran over two landmines during routine surveillance. The explosion caused the vehicle to overturn and some injury to soldiers; however, the rugged notebook was later retrieved and found to be fully intact and operational -- with only a few scratches on its case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR `NUTRITIONAL' YEAST PRODUCTS RECALLED OVER HOG FEED SCARE

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) recalled all its nutritional yeast products Thursday after public prosecutors in Tainan, southern Taiwan, detained a former Taisugar executive and an importer for supplying hog feed to the company to produce health products for human consumption.

The prosecutors at the Tainan District Court arrested Lin Ying-hua, a manager in charge of food production at Taisugar's Hsinying plant, and Tseng Teh-fu, former owner of an import firm that supplied performance protein powder to Taisugar to manufacture nutritional yeast products, including vitamin yeast, flavored vitamin yeast and yeast candy.
The prosecutors searched six locations in Tainan City and Tainan County Wednesday and questioned eight people, including four Taisugar employees.

According to Yen Jung-sung, chief prosecutor at the Tainan Public Prosecutor's Office, Taisugar stopped producing material for its yeast products in 1993 when the production cost increased to NT$150-NT$200 per kilogram.
Instead, the company began to procure the material -- performance protein powder -- from abroad through an import firm, Hua Wei Trading Co., managing to lower the cost to NT$38-NT$50 per kilogram.

Yen said the performance protein powder imported by Hua Wei from Egypt and Belgium at about NT$10 per kilogram was meant to be used for hog feed only and that the customs import declaration forms stated clearly that the material was not for human consumption.

However, the import firm had the material repackaged and sold it to Taisugar for producing nutritional yeast products. For 13 years, consumers, including many children, have been using these nutritional supplements without knowing that they have actually been eating hog feed, Yen said angrily.
Taisugar admitted Thursday that there were "some problems" with the company's internal controls. A spokesman said the company will begin an investigation to find those responsible for the negligence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU LEADERS VISIT TAIPEI TO PUSH FOR CASINOS

TEXT.P: Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa and Penghu County Council Speaker Chen Chao-ling flew to Taipei Thursday to lobby for the passage of a legislative amendment allowing the establishment of tourist casinos on Penghu island, located off Taiwan's southwestern coast in the Taiwan Strait.
The delegation visited Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and leaders of various parties' legislative caucuses to promote the idea of casinos for Penghu.

Their appeal was given a mixed reception, with the opposition Kuomintang saying it will throw its full support behind Penghu, the opposition People First Party responding that it remains open on the issue, and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party saying that it will make a decision only after the DPP caucus convenes a meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraq Amnesty Plan May Cover Attacks On U.S. Military; Leader Also Backs Talks With Resistance.
Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki on Wednesday proposed a limited amnesty to help end the Sunni Arab insurgency as part of a national reconciliation plan that Maliki said would be released within days. The plan is likely to include pardons for those who had attacked only U.S. troops, a top adviser said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: After Iraq Visit, an Upbeat Bush Urges Patience
U.S. President Bush, speaking at a news conference in the Rose Garden just hours after from his surprise trip to Baghdad, warned Democrats that an early withdrawal of troops would set back counsterterrorism efforts and "endanger our country." He said, "The challenges that remain are serious," referring to Iraq, "and they will require more sacrifice and patience."
Wall Street Journal: Rapid Descent Bet on Huge Plane Trips Up Airbus
Airbus's high-stakes bet on a giant plane is running into serious trouble, creating a major crunch for one of Europe's industrial titans as it battles Boeing Co. for dominance of the passenger-jet market. Airbus announced Tuesday that deliveries of its double-decker A380, designed to be the world's largest passenger jet, would face a further six months of delays because of the unexpected complexity of wiring the aircraft. Shares in European Aeronautic Defence & Space Co., which owns 80% of Airbus, fell 26% yesterday as investors panicked about the A380 and other bad news. EADS said the delay would shave US$2.5 billion in operating profit between 2007 and 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BUSINESSMEN TO EVALUATE BEFORE INVESTING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen should evaluate prudently before investing in China amid its changing economic climate, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.

At a seminar on the impact of cross-Taiwan Strait relations on local laborers, Wu noted that Taiwan businessmen with operations in China are facing increasing social, legal, economic, personal security, tax, anti-dumping, and electricity deficiency problems due to China's rapidly changing economy.

According to statistics, the number of Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China surpassed 600,000 currently, and the number of cases involving Taiwanese businessmen's personal security increased from 67 in 2001 to 133 in 2005.

With the widening of the gap between the rich and the poor in China, the social order is deteriorating rapidly, making it almost impossible for the police to reach trouble spots in time, according to Wu.
In addition, conflicts between management and labor, the lack of rule of law, and the corrupt government have made investments by Taiwan businessmen more risky, Wu said.

Furthermore, Taiwan businessmen should also pay heed to several factors in their investments in China such as increasing operating costs there, the "saturated Chinese market" and the continued appreciation of China's currency, Wu added.

Wu said the government will present more incentives in an attempt to persuade overseas Taiwan businessmen to invest in Taiwan based on the "active management, effective liberalization" policy announced by President Chen Shui-bian in his New Year's Day speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS RAID ILLEGAL RADIO STATIONS, DETAIN THREE OPERATORS

TEXT.P: Public prosecutors in Kaohsiung, supported by local police, raided four illegal radio stations in southern Taiwan Thursday and took three operators into custody for questioning.
The prosecutors searched 11 locations belonging to the four unlicensed radio stations in mountainous regions of Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties and dismantled their transmitting antenna.

The pirate broadcasters used the frequencies FM92.3, FM92.8, FM99.4 and FM107.6. The three program hosts taken into custody were two women -- Lu Chia-chen, 43, and Shih Tou-tou, 50 -- and a 35-year-old man identified as Hung Chien-erh.

Prosecutor Huang Chia-chun, who led the police on the raid, told reporters that the Kaohsiung Public Prosecutor's Office raided the underground radio stations after obtaining evidence from the National Communications Commission about their operations.

He said the investigation will seek to find out whether the operators of these stations had tried to incite their audiences last weekend to assassinate main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOI CHIEF TO BE SUMMONED IN SLANDER SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 15 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Bureau of Investigation (BOI) Director Yeh Sheng-mao and so-called media pundit Chang You-hua will be summoned to appear in court July 20 to testify in a slander suit filed by opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong against President Chen Shui-bian.

Soong is suing the president for alleging that he met with a senior Chinese official in the United States in early 2005, an allegation that Soong claims is groundless but Chen claims is "based on something."

Lin Chih-hao, the president's legal counsel, said Chen based his allegations on "intelligence" gathered by national security authorities and the Bureau of Investigation, as well as statements made by Chang and reports carried in the United Daily News (UDN).

The Taipei District Court summoned a UDN reporter Thursday for questioning about the case regarding the alleged secret meeting between Soong and Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office.
The reporter said at the hearing that his source in national security circles told him that Soong met with Chen Yunlin, but he refused to identify his source.

Responding to the reporter's testimony, Soong's lawyer Lee Tien-fu said Soong stayed in Las Vegas Jan. 3-9, 2005, while Chen Yunlin made a transit stop in San Francisco Jan. 7, 2005 on his way back to China after a U.S. visit.

When Soong met with a senior U.S. official Jan. 14, Chen Yunlin had long since left the U.S., Lee said, adding that even if the U.S. official had indeed arranged for a Soong-Chen meeting as claimed by the UDN reporter, it could not have taken place as Chen had left for home by that time.
The presiding judge said a second hearing will be held July 20, when Yeh and Chang will be subpoenaed.

Soong filed the slander suit against the president last June on the grounds that the "unfounded claim" of his meeting affected voter confidence in his integrity. Since the president has never produced evidence proving that the meeting took place, Soong demanded the president run an apology in local newspapers for one day and pay a symbolic NT$1 in damages. Last October, Soong expanded his compensation demand, asking the president to run an apology in newspapers for three days and pay NT$50 million in damages.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC GROWTH SLATED FOR JULY 27-28

TEXT.P: A conference on policy options and initiatives for Taiwan's sustainable economic growth will be held July 27-28, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday.

The meeting will focus discussions on structural, chronic and controversial issues, Tsai said, adding that the conference's top goal is to mend differences and shape a consensus on those issues to pave the way for necessary legislation and solution.
Tsai said a preparatory meeting for the two-day conference will be held Friday.

She further said Premier Su Tseng-chang, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Vincent Siew, a former premier who is now chairman of the Chunhua Institution for Economic Research, will serve as co-conveners of the sustainable growth conference. The conference dates are a common decision of the three co-conveners, she added.

Meanwhile, Tsai said a 12-member advisory group has been formed to offer counseling on the agenda and policy options to be addressed during the two-day conference. Among the members are former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, former Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker P. K. Chiang and two former vice premiers -- Wu Rong-i and Lin Hsin-i -- as well as CommonWealth Magazine publisher Diane Ying.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC VICE MINISTER RETURNS FROM HONG KONG VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Ho Nuan-hsuan returned to Taipei Thursday after a low-profile visit to Hong Kong to attend the opening of an international travel fair.
Ho was the highest-ranking Taiwan official ever to attend the annual Hong Kong travel fair.

During his stay in Hong Kong, Ho had a courtesy handshake and chat with China's National Tourism Administration Director Shao Qiwei. But Ho said they didn't touch on any issues regarding the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists.

Ho left for Hong Kong Wednesday to attend a Taiwan tourism promotion activity sponsored by the Kwang Hwa Information and Culture Center, the representative office of Taiwan's Government Information Office in Hong Kong.
On Thursday morning, Ho attended the opening of the 20th International Travel Expo and returned to Taipei in the evening.

More than 150 Taiwan travel agencies operate exhibition booths at the Hong Kong travel fair to attract tourists to Taiwan. Taiwan is the second largest exhibitor at the Hong Kong travel expo, behind only China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT JAPAN IN JULY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will visit Japan July 10-15, Japanese news media reported Friday
The reports said that Ma will visit Tokyo, Yokohama, Osaka and Kyoto, marking his first visit to Japan since assuming the KMT chairmanship last August.

Kyoto News said that Ma, who concurrently serves as Taipei mayor, is scheduled to arrive in Tokyo July 10 where he is expected to meet with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara and political and financial figures from across the political spectrum.
He will also deliver speeches at the Foreign Correspondent Club of Japan and Yokohama City University.
Reports said that Ma is scheduled to travel to Kyoto July 13, where he will meet with the governors of Kyoto and Osaka and deliver a speech at Doshisha University before winding up his trip July 1 5.

Sankei Shimbun analyzed that in the wake of his visit to Europe and the United States early this year, Ma is hoping that this trip will help him score points in diplomatic affairs and shed his anti-Japanese image.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INAUGURATES HSUEHSHAN TUNNEL

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang, accompanied by three former premiers, rode a jeep through the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel in 20 minutes Friday, officially inaugurating the longest tunnel in Southeast Asia and the fifth longest in the world.

The Hsuehshan Tunnel, known as a "construction miracle, " is the centerpiece of the 55.3-km "Chiang Wei-shui Freeway" linking Nankang in the northern city of Taipei to Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan.

The opening of the freeway to traffic -- after 15 years of painstaking construction at a cost of more than NT$100 billion (US$3.11 billion) -- will significantly cut down travel time between Taipei and Yilan, as well as reduce travel time between Nankang and Suao to 45 minutes from nearly three hours.

Before taking the ride, Su and his predecessors, Frank Hsieh, Yu Shyi-kun and Chang Chun-hsiung, as well as officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications attended a ceremony held at the Shihting Service Stop to pay tribute to the 25 workers who died during the construction of the Hsuehshan Tunnel.

The Hsuehshan Tunnel was one of the most difficult construction projects in the world owing to the fragile geological conditions and bountiful underground water deposits, which caused several accidents and seriously hindered the progress of construction.
Two presidents and eight premiers have witnessed the tunneling project since its inception on July 15, 1991.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and the Yilan County government jointly proposed in January this year that the tunnel be named the "Chiang Wei-shui Freeway" to commemorate Chiang, a physician and a native of Yilan who was known as a historic trailblazer in Taiwan's democracy movement during the period of Japanese colonial rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY OPEN TO CHINESE TOURISTS IN FOUR TO FIVE MONTHS: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to complete negotiations with China on measures related to visits by Chinese tourists in four to five months, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said Friday.
Liu said the talks have so far proceeded smoothly according to schedule, adding that the MAC hopes the talks can be completed as soon as possible.
Liu said both sides will make public the results of their talks as soon as they come to an agreement.
Taiwan has since 2002 allowed Chinese citizens meeting certain criteria to make pleasure trips to Taiwan and is now planning to expand the policy to allow more Chinese citizens to visit the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: UKRAINE COMPLETES WTO TALKS WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 15 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Ukraine has completed bilateral talks with Taiwan to pave the way for the Eastern European country's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) , a Ukraine official said Thursday.
The announcement was made by Valeriy Pyatnytskiy, deputy minister of economy of Ukraine, while reporting to a WTO working group considering Ukraine's application on WTO entry.
A total of 50 WTO member nations have requested talks with Ukraine, and Taiwan is the 49th country that has completed talks with the Eastern European state.

Three rounds of bilateral talks have been held between Taiwan and Ukraine. In addition to economic and trade issues, Taiwan has expressed concern during the talks over the Ukrainian government's rejection of ROC passports printed with the word "Taiwan" on their cover. Ukraine has dealt with the problem at the request of Taiwan.

According to official statistics from Taiwan, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Ukraine was valued at US$257 million in 2005, down 41 percent from the year-earlier level, with Taiwan posting a trade deficit of US$12 million with the country.
Imports to Taiwan from Ukraine amounted to US$135 million, down 60 percent over the previous year, while exports to Ukraine amounted to US$123 million, up 28.41 percent over the previous year.
During the first three months of 2006, exports from Taiwan to Ukraine increased significantly from US$15.2 million to US$31.93 million, marking an increase of 108 percent.
Taiwan's exports to Ukraine are mainly machinery, textiles, consumer electronic products and consumer products. Major imports from Ukraine include aluminium, iron, steel, zinc and cotton.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE POLICY COULD BE EXPANDED: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Friday that domestic differences over cross-strait trade policy have narrowed and that there is room for expansion in this policy.
Tsai made the remarks while delivering a speech on Taiwan's current economic situation and its prospects at the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

She noted that cross-strait issues and globalization have been major issues for nearly half a century but that they have only become the focus of public debate over the last decade. In other words, she said, the problems accumulated over the past 50 years have surfaced during the past decade, and this is why Taiwan has gone through a period of confusion amid disagreement.

However, Tsai said that she personally feels that following this turbulent period, the differences on these issues have narrowed. As such, there is room for cross-strait policy to be expanded and adjusted, she added.
The level of cross-strait policy adjustment will be deliberated at a conference on policy options and initiatives for Taiwan's sustainable economic growth slated to be held July 27-28.

Addressing the discontent expressed by businesspeople that the government's newly announced cross-strait charter flight services still have too stringent restrictions, Tsai said that the government will continue to work hard to address the needs of the businesspeople.

Taiwan and China announced simultaneously Wednesday that they had reached an agreement on measures concerning four kinds of cross-strait charter flight services, including the launch of special charter cargo flights,
The other measures are the regularization of cross-strait charter passenger flights for special holidays and the operation of charter services for emergency medical needs and humanitarian purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES URGED TO CONSIDER PUBLIC INTEREST

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san urged state-owned enterprises Friday to consider the public interest after one of the enterprises recalled its sham products.

Hwang made the remarks when asked about state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp's recall of all its nutritional yeast products while on the sidelines of the inauguration of an office under the ministry to promote the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

He said that as everything the state-owned enterprises do "represents the government as well as the national interest, " the enterprises must therefore always exercise extra caution lest they negatively affect the public's interests or the nation's image.
A former Taisugar executive and an importer have been detained for supplying hog feed to the company to produce health products for human consumption.

Prosecutors at the Tainan District Court arrested Lin Ying-hua, a manager in charge of food production at Taisugar's Hsinying plant, and Tseng Teh-fu, former owner of an import firm that supplied performance protein powder to Taisugar to manufacture nutritional yeast products, including vitamin yeast, flavored vitamin yeast and yeast candy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHOTONICS FESTIVAL 2006 OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: This year's Photonics Festival is being held this week in Taipei, introducing Taiwan's best optoelectronic products to the world, a spokesman of the Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association (PIDA) said Friday.

According to the PIDA -- the main organizer of the show, the Photonics Festival 2006 features five programs, namely "Opto Taiwan," displaying optoelectronic components and devices; "OptoCom Taiwan, " for communications products related to optical technology; "LED Lighting Taiwan, " for light emitting diode (LED) appliances and applications; "Optics Taiwan, " for components made in precision optics; and "FPD Taiwan, " an exhibit for locally made flat panel display products.
The spokesman pointed out that a total of 527 companies have set up 1,314 booths at the exposition, which opened June 14 for a four-day run.

The total production value of Taiwan's optoelectronic industry is expected to expand from last year's NT$1 trillion (US$30.8 billion) to NT$1.03 trillion this year, or 17 percent of the global figure, the official said.

He noted that the expansion will largely be due to the strong performance of Taiwan's flat panel display industry, which is forecast to see total production hit NT$784.1 billion for 2006, or a 20-percent increase over the year-earlier figure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEIYI FREEWAY'S OPENING THIRD BIGGEST EVENT IN YILAN'S HISTORY: YU

TEXT.P: The opening of the Peiyi Freeway is the third biggest event in the history of Yilan after the development of the Lanyang Plain and the launch of the Yilan railway, former Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.
Yu, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, made the remarks while participating in a ceremony for the inauguration of the Hsuehshan Tunnel, the centerpiece of the freeway project.

The 55-km freeway linking Taipei to the northeastern county of Yilan officially opened to traffic following the inauguration of the tunnel, significantly cutting down the travel time between Taipei and Yilan to about 30 minutes.
Yu noted that the proposals to build a freeway and a university in Yilan were first put forth by some candidates during the 1978 legislative elections and that both projects have now been completed.

The former Yilan magistrate urged the Yilan County government to review its urban development plans to improve the county's transportation network and parking facilities, saying that these are problems that the county has to deal with after the opening of the Peiyi Freeway.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET SOAR

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 149.38 points to close at 6,575.77.
The bourse opened at 6,589.7 and fluctuated between 6,629.33 and 6,550.13 during trading. A total of 3.91 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$110.21 billion (US$3.39 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.8 percent, followed by textile stocks at 4.5 percent, cement stocks at 4.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.9 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 1.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 658 to 163, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY RECRUITS ENGLISH-SPEAKING VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government has recently put forward an urgent demand for people with English language skills to serve as volunteers during the 2009 World Games to be held in the southern Taiwan port city.

It hopes to recruit 10,000 volunteers for the city's World Game Volunteer Group by the end of 2008, according to the City Bureau of Social Affairs, which said that at present the group comprises only 2,500 volunteers, some of whom cannot speak English.

The group's services include reception, airport services, medical treatment in case of accidents, health care, traffic and environmental order maintenance, and work in the command center and the media center, as well as services in restaurants and hotels.

To ensure the success of the games, the city government will hold three international sports events -- the world dragon boat championship, the Asia skating games and a rock climbing championship, in September and October, as part of its preparations for the World Games.

It is expected that more than 2,000 athletes from over 20 countries will attend these preliminary games, city officials said Friday, noting that the World Game Volunteer Group will start work at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: KING OF SWAZILAND ACCORDED FULL MILITARY HONORS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Friday honored King Mswati III of Swaziland at a military ceremony held at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office, welcoming him to Taiwan for a six-day visit.
Leading an economic and cultural delegation of more than 40 members, Mswati arrived in Taipei Thursday.

After the welcoming ceremony completed with full military honors, both heads of state had a conversation at the Presidential Office, where President Chen hailed Mswati III for his extraordinary leadership in implementing the new constitution of Swaziland in February this year, an important step in Swaziland's democratization.

According to Chen, Mswati III held a job-promotion conference last year, in which he successfully raised US$200 million in funds for use in helping boost the economy and increasing employment in his country.

Noting that the memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cooperation between Taiwan and Swaziland will expire next year, Chen expressed the hope that the two countries can engage in talks on the details of a new MOU to better fit Swaziland's need.

Chen said it will be the first time that two heads of state attend the annual "Africa Day" activities to be held Friday night, adding that he hopes the activity will attract more Taiwan business people to invest in Swaziland.

Chen noted that there are currently 22 Taiwanese enterprises with operations in Swaziland. With a total investment exceeding US$60 million, these Taiwan companies have provided 14,000 jobs for the people of Swaziland over the years, he added.
However, Chen said he believes there is still much room to make progress in this field.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 171 points to close at 6,580, with 44,190 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose 160 points to finish at 6,530, with 5,259 contracts traded, while September futures gained 190 points to close at 6,410, with 110 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 110 points to close at 6,349, with 266 contracts traded, while March futures gained 228 points to finish at 6,402, with 10 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,650 for June, 6,528 for July, 6,348 for September, 6,350 for December and 6,300 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
June TE futures rose 6.5 points to close at 273.1, with 5,526 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 7.3 points to finish at 271.8, with 872 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved up 5.85 points to close at 268, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures moved up 34.2 points to finish at 978.8, with 3,663 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures gained 34.4 points to close at 974, with 952 contracts traded.
September TF futures gained 40.6 points to close at 959.6, with 14 contracts traded, while December TF futures moved up 34.8 points to finish at 960, with one contract traded.
March TF futures rose 37.2 points to close at 960, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, NICARAGUA SIGN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Nicaragua signed a free trade agreement (FTA) in Taipei Friday, a move that is expected to strengthen bilateral cooperation in trade and investment.

Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san and Nicaraguan Minister of Industry, Development & Commerce Alejandro Arguello signed the FTA at the ministry on behalf of the respective governments, ending nearly two years of negotiations.
Nicaragua is the third country to sign an FTA with Taiwan after Panama and Guatemala. The FTA will go into effect after it has been approved by the legislatures of both countries.
The ministry hopes that it will be put into practice early next year, Hwang said.
He said the signing of the FTA signals closer trade cooperation between the two countries and a giant step forward for Taiwan on the international trade stage.
Both sides can complement each other economically through the removal of trade barriers and can boost trade opportunities through increased trade, investment and technology cooperation relations.

Economic officials said that after the FTA goes into effect, Nicaragua will provide immediate tariff-free treatment for 3,374 products from Taiwan (accounting for 51.1 percent of its exports to Nicaragua). In turn, Taiwan will immediately remove tariffs on 5,797 products provided by Nicaragua.

Fifteen years after the FTA goes into effect, 97.3 percent of Nicaraguan products will go freely into the Taiwan market, while 95.1 percent of Taiwan products will be able to enter the Nicaraguan market freely, the officials said.

They noted that a Central America FTA signed between Nicaragua and the United States went into effect April 1 and said a Taiwan-U.S. FTA would provide opportunities for Taiwan businesses to tap the North American market.
If Taiwan and Nicaraguan enterprises can form strategic alliances, then Nicaraguan products will have more easy access to the Asia-Pacific market, and vice versa, the officials added.
