The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.541 and fluctuated between NT$32.400 and NT$32.593.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM RAIN RISE TO NT$1.12 BILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses resulting from several days of torrential rain have risen to NT$1.12 billion, according to the latest tallies released Friday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

The amount includes NT$1.02 billion in crop damage, affecting 26,510 hectares of cropland, with non-harvested areas totalling 5,515 hectares, COA officials said. Most severely damaged was rice, watermelons, grapes, peaches, pears, persimmons, tangerines, spring onions and peanuts.
Livestock damage amounted to NT$20.61 million, with 490 pigs, 283,000 chickens, 65,000 ducks and 15,808 geese dead, the officials said.

While fishery and forestry damages amounted to NT$4.85 million and NT$1.31 million, respectively, damage to agricultural and livestock facilities is valued at NT$73.48 million and NT$310,000, respectively, they said.
As relief measures for the agricultural sector, the government will provide farmers in Taichung County with relief funds and low-interest loans, they said.

While farmers in Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin and Chiayi counties are entitled to low-interest loans, watermelon and cantaloupe farmers in Hsinchu and Miaoli counties, turnip farmers in Nantou County, watermelon farmers in Tainan City and sorghum farmers in Chiayi County will be offered relief funds in addition to low-interest loans, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC TO RECRUIT 400 NEW EMPLOYEES

TEXT.P: Taiwan SemiconductorManufacturing Co. (TSMC) announced Friday that it will recruit around 400 new employees to work at its plants in southern Taiwan.
A TSMC spokesman said the recruitment drive is aimed at satisfying the demand for engineers at its new 12-inch wafer factories in the Southern Taiwan Science Park.
With the addition of the new recruits, the TSMC staff at the Southern Taiwan Science Park will exceed 5,000 people, representing nearly 30 percent of TSMC's entire staff.

The spokesman said it is more difficult for TSMC to hire people to work in southern Taiwan than in the north, probably because the Southern Taiwan Science Park is less well-known in the high tech industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVIST GROUPS DEMAND ENVIRONMENTAL RIGHTS INCLUDED IN CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Activists representing 75 civic groups from around the country met at a news conference Friday to demand that the people's environmental rights be included in the Constitution to better protect the environment.

Major propositions of a draft constitutional amendment stipulating the people's environmental rights -- authored by the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) -- include that the people should have the right to oppose to regulations or policies that undermine their environmental rights and that the people should have the right to determine or oversee public development projects carried out in their communities.

Other propositions of the draft also stipulate that the government should come up with policies and measures to enhance sustainable use of national resources; that "people should be allowed to live in harmony with nature;" and that Taiwan should be made nuclear-free.

TEPU Secretary-General Ho Tsung-hsun said that only when the people's environmental rights are written into the Constitution can environmental protection and soil and water conservation be secured under the law.

Ho expressed hope that such a constitutional amendment proposal -- a bottom-up initiative combining the strength of private groups and civic societies -- will let the Taiwan people perceive more deeply the importance of their environment and understand that environmental rights are their right.

National Taiwan University Professor Shih Hsin-min said people in the United States and Europe have become environmentally conscious since the 1970s and some U.S. states have even enacted laws governing matters concerning the relations between people and the environment.

Shih said it is right and crucial that Taiwan consider including environmental rights into the Constitution. By doing so, the Taiwan people would not only improve the Constitution, they would also be doing the right thing as members of the global village, Shih added.

Meanwhile, Huang Wei-chin, a man in his early 20s and a TEPU volunteer, staged a skit at the news conference in which he pasted paper notes indicating mudslides, nuclear waste and mercury-contaminated dirt on his naked body.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN TRADE OFFICE TO HOLD KISSING CONTEST

TEXT.P: The German Trade Office in Taipei will organize a kissing contest Sunday as part of a series of activities held in Taipei supposedly related to the soccer World Cup, a spokeswoman for the trade office said Friday.
The winner of the contest, which will take place at the Living Mall, will receive NT$10,000, the spokeswoman said.
Participants will first have their "degree of bad breath" measured after a meal of German beer, sausages and salad mixed with onions and blue cheese.
Before kissing their mate, the contestants will have to a take breath fresheners made by a German company.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHEEPDOG TO FEATURE IN GUIDE DOG CAMPAIGN ADS

TEXT.P: Officials from the Taiwan Guide Dog Association said Friday that it will use a sheepdog to serve as a "goodwill ambassador" to help promote the rights of guide dogs.

Association officials said there are around 50,000 visually impaired people in Taiwan, but only 11 guide dogs. Although the law clearly states that guide dogs or young guide dogs being trained can move freely around public transport and businesses, many places still deny access to guide dogs.

The association has therefore focused on a "no denial of access" concept in its campaign activities this year, the officials said, adding that Alpha, a lively seven-month-old sheepdog featured in a TV program, will appear in a series of campaign ads.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 TAIPEI BIOTECHNOLOGY AWARDS BEGINS TO ACCEPT APPLICATIONS

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taipei Biotechnology Awards will be open for applications from June 20 through Aug. 5, the Department for Economic Development under the Taipei city government announced Friday.

Department officials said a 28-member panel formed by experts from the biotech industry, government agencies, universities and research institutions will evaluate the applications from Aug. 5 to Sept. 25, with the award presentation ceremony scheduled for mid-October.
The awards cover four categories: commercialization of technology, innovation in research and development, technology transfer, and university-industry cooperation.
The winners of the gold, silver and bronze awards in each category will receive cash prizes totalling NT$5 million.
The awards were established by the Taipei city government in 2004, with the aim of helping to make the city an important biotechnology center.
Information about how to apply for the awards is accessible online at www.biodriven.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO RUN ADS TO COUNTERATTACK MOTION TO RECALL PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will run advertisements in the media from Saturday in attempt to counter an opposition legislative motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a DPP official said Friday.

DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang noted that the DPP has made several TV ads to highlight the party's goal of boosting the economy and increasing the welfare of the people amid the current political upheaval.

Tsai described Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, as the "source of political turmoil" in Taiwan after Ma revealed his plan to solicit support from the public for a campaign organized by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" to oust Chen over a string of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.

According to Tsai, the DPP will not exclude the possibility of posting frequent ads before June 27, when the recall motion will be put to a vote in the legislature, "to avoid Taiwan falling into chaos."

Asked whether DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will participate in a rally to be organized by some pro-DPP groups Saturday to counterattack the "pan-blue alliance" recall motion, Tsai said Yu's schedule had not been fixed.

Claiming that Saturday's rally will be aimed at seeking to stabilize the political situation and boost the economy, Huang said the DPP will try to render assistance to the participants, but expressed hope that the rally will be conducted "rationally and peacefully."
Organizers said they hope to attract some 50,000 people to the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU ENCOURAGES MORE RESIDENTS TO PARTICIPATE IN SPORTS

TEXT.P: A total of 60 government agencies and private organizations in the northern city of Hsinchu have planned nearly 100 sporting events this year in the hope of encouraging more residents to play sports or exercise, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Cheng-tze said Friday.
Lin revealed the city's plan to boost the sports participation rate at a news conference Friday, expressing his hope that the number of participants will surge to 100,000 people in 2006.

The plan is part of the Multiplied Sports Population Project that the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sport (NCPFS) launched in 2002 in an effort to encourage people to improve their fitness and in the hope that everyone in the country will develop the habit of participating in sport or exercise.

The project was proposed after a survey released in 2001 showed that at least 33 percent of Taiwan's population had not engaged in sports or exercise in the past three months. As the average weight of adults is climbing each year, losing weight and keeping fit have come to play an important role in the lives of the people, according to the NCPFS.
Under the project, a goal is set at increasing the number of participants in sports by 50,000 each year from 2002 to 2007 through teaching sports novices how to exercise.

As of December 2004, schools, sports organizations, and local governments throughout Taiwan had offered a total of 6,857 programs to Taiwan citizens, thereby increasing the number of people participating in sports by 1.6 million, the NCPES said.

The planned sports-promotion programs in Hsinchu cover swimming, dancing, mountain climbing, roller-skating and ball sports. Detailed information about the events is available at the city government Web site at http://www.hceb.edu.tw/index.aspx.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN COUNTY GOVERNMENT ISSUES WARNING ABOUT JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS

TEXT.P: Health authorities in the eastern county of Hualien cautioned the public Friday against Japanese encephalitis in the wake of one confirmed case of the disease in the county.
According to Shih Jen-hsing, head of Hualien's health bureau, six suspected cases of Japanese encephalitis have been reported in Hualien this year, with one case having been confirmed.
Shih urged the public to avoid pigsties, animal housing and places where mosquitoes multiply to reduce the risk of contracting the mosquito-borne virus.
In Taiwan, the Japanese encephalitis virus usually multiplies among pigs first before it is spread to human via mosquitoes, Shih noted.
The outbreak peaks two to three weeks after the Japanese encephalitis virus antibody-positive rate among pigs exceeds 50 percent, with the peak season running approximately one month, Shih said.
Tests conducted May 27 on pigs in Hualien indicated that the positive rate had reached 54 percent, he said.

He said that while Japanese encephalitis has become an endemic disease in Taiwan, the country reports only 10 to 20 confirmed cases of the disease per year owing to the government's efforts to control the disease over the past 20 years.
In Hualien County, eight confirmed cases were reported in 2004 and three confirmed cases were reported in 2005, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ENFORCE CONSENSUS REACHED IN CONFERENCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that the Cabinet will put into force any consensus reached at a conference on sustainable economic growth slated for July 27-28.

Speaking at a preparatory meeting of the conference, Su assured the public that consensus reached will be implemented by the Executive Yuan "with full vigor and urgency," while majority opinions will be referred to Cabinet agencies for future reference.

Su appealed to all prospective participants in the conference to contribute their foresight and wisdom on structural, chronic and controversial issues that Taiwan faces so as to help the government map out policy options and initiatives for the country's sustainable economic growth.
He reiterated that the conference's top goal is to mend differences and shape consensus on those issues to pave the way for necessary legislation and solutions.

It is undeniable that Taiwan is facing various major challenges, ranging from an increasingly graying society and declining birth rate to a lack of a social security system and imbalanced manpower resources.

Finding a way to secure a balance between economic development and environmental conservation is another major challenge facing Taiwan, Su said, adding that divided opinions on financial reforms and building Taiwan into a regional finance hub in the Asian-Pacific region also need to be smoothed out.

Most of all, Su said, in the face of China's rise, finding ways to retain Taiwan's competitiveness and "economic identity, " and secure a dynamic balance between global markets and the Chinese market, is probably the greatest challenge that Taiwan is facing and needs to tackle immediately.
Su declared that the results achieved in the coming six weeks by the preparatory meeting -- which will be divided into five panels -- will be the key to success of the July 27-28 conference.

Su himself, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Vincent Siew, a former premier who is now chairman of the Chunghua Institution for Economic Research, will serve as co-conveners of the sustainable growth conference.

Meanwhile, a 12-member advisory group has been formed to offer counseling on the agenda and policy options to be addressed during conference. Among the members are former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, former Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker P.K. Chiang and former vice premiers Wu Rong-i and Lin Hsin-i, as well as CommonWealth Magazine publisher Diane Ying.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROUBLE-STRICKEN TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT TO RETURN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat whose skipper was allegedly killed by Chinese crewmen on the high seas near Japan's Iwo Jima island in the Pacific Ocean will be escorted back to Taiwan next week, coast guard officials said Friday.

The officials said that one of two patrol vessels sent to help the boat, the Hsinglung, from the port of Suao in Yilan County, intercepted the vessel early Friday about 95 nautical miles west of Iwo Jima.

After coast guard officers boarded the fishing boat, two Chinese crewmen admitted in an initial investigation that they killed the skipper, Chen Mu-tsai, with a knife, and that his body was put on ice in his cabin.
Chief engineer Huang Chin-hsin and the other crewmen are safe, the coast guard officers said.
The Hsinlung has eight Chinese crew, with only Chen and Huang being Taiwanese.

It is the second time that the boat's two Taiwanese officers have been overpowered by Chinese fishery workers. In August 2004, Chen and Huang were held hostage by nine Chinese crewmen who then took the Hsinglung to Hawaii.

Chen had served as skipper on the ship for more than a decade, and because he had often run into trouble with crewmen hired from Pingtang, Fujian Province, he hired crewmen from Zhangzhou, also in Fujian this year, but had problems with them also.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CUSTOMS OPENS 'ONE-STOP WINDOW' AT FREE-TRADE PORT ZONE

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Customs Office established a "one-stop window" Friday to offer businesses comprehensive information on services offered in Kaohsiung Port's Free Trade Zone as well as the benefits of joining free-trade zone operations.

The multifunctional, professionally staffed window was created by a special task force organized by the customs office and the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau to carry out the free-trade project as part of Taiwan's efforts to develop into a global management center for trade, according to customs officials.

Anyone seeking information about the free-trade zone can find answers at the one-stop window, they noted, expressing hope that businesses will continue building operation centers in the area, which can efficiently package services together -- such as storage, assemblage and procedures to ease customs clearance.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG FILM FESTIVAL TO ATTRACT MOVIE CELEBRITIES FROM ASIA

TEXT.P: The 2006 Kaohsiung Film Festival, which begins Saturday, will be drawing the attendance of many celebrated cinematographic figures including film directors and actors from throughout Asia, the event's organizer said Friday.

At the invitation of the Kaohsiung Municipal Film Archive, several film celebrities -- such as Taiwanese movie director Hou Hsiao-hsien and Philip Lee, the producer of the internationally acclaimed film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," as well new-generation Taiwanese directors and actors -- participated in two seminars held Friday in Kaohsiung as a prelude to the festival.

At the seminar "The Asian movie industry and independent film production vs. movie production with huge capital," director Hou, who won the first Golden Lion awarded to a Chinese-language film at the Venice Film Festival for his 1989 masterpiece "City of Sadness," exchanged views with Pusan International Film Festival Chairman Kim Dong-ho on the movie industry. Both expressed hope that filmmakers will produce works of art to satisfy both the spiritual and cultural needs of moviegoers while pursuing artistic effect and box office success.
The film festival will last until June 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Parties Face Off Over Iraq War in 11-Hour Debate.
Congress plunged into a wide-ranging debate over the origins and conduct of the war in Iraq yesterday, with each party excoriating the other for alleged weakness and complacency about the stakes involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONUMENT DEDICATED TO WORKERS KILLED IN PEIYI FREEWAY CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang dedicated a stone monument in Shihting township Friday to the memory and contribution of 25 workers who were killed during the construction of Hsuehshan Tunnel -- a centerpiece of the newly completed Peiyi Freeway linking Taipei and Yilan County.

Su also formally opened the 55.3-km freeway to traffic Friday after the 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel was completed after 15 years of painstaking construction. The freeway's construction cost more than NT$100 billion (US$3.11 billion).
Of the 25 workers who died during the tunnel's construction, 13 were Taiwanese and 12 were Thai.

The monument was erected in a service area of the freeway in Shihting township, Yilan County. The names of the deceased were carved in granite along with a tribute to their contribution and a chronicling of the construction's progress.

After the master of ceremonies read the text of the monument and introduced relatives of the deceased workers and the Thai representative to Taiwan, the premier and Taipei County Magistrate Chou Shih-wei laid white roses at the monument's base and paid respects to relatives of the deceased.
The Hsuehshan Tunnel is the longest highway tunnel in East Asia and the fifth longest in the world. It has been dubbed the "tunnel beneath troubled waters" because of engineering difficulties.
During the excavation of the tunnel, 48 geological accidents occurred in the main tunnel while the pilot tunnels saw 42 accidents.
The freeway's completion will cut travel time between Taipei and Suao Township in Yilan County from three hours to 45 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Congress Erupts in Partisan Fight Over Iraq War
The U.S. House and the Senate engaged in angry, intensely partisan debate on Thursday over the war in Iraq, as Republicans sought to rally support for the Bush administration's policies and exploit Democratic divisions in an election year shadowed by unease over the war. It was one of the sharpest legislative clashes yet over the three-year-old conflict, and it came after three days in which President Bush and his aides had sought to portray Iraq as moving gradually toward a stable, functioning democracy, and to portray Democrats as lacking the will to see the conflict through to victory.
Wall Street Journal: In Military-Spending Boom, Expensive Pet Projects Prevail
Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks changed American military priorities, the U.S. defense machine is still churning out weapons made for old-style, conventional conflicts, even as it needs new tools to battle terrorists and insurgents. One big reason is the sclerotic nature of the procurement process, in which the military, the White House, the defense industry and Congress fight for pet projects that aren't always in synch with strategic priorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS TO RALLY AGAINST PRESIDENTIAL RECALL DRIVE

TEXT.P: Pro-independence groups will stage a mass rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Saturday to denounce an opposition-initiated campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian over corruption allegations implicating his family and close aides.

"The rally is part of our efforts to stabilize the political turmoil arising from the presidential recall motion launched by the 'pan-blue' alliance of the Kuomintang and People First Party, "said Yang Wen-chia, secretary-general of Taiwan Society North, one of the event's organizers.

The rally will feature themes of "sense and sensibility, " Yang said, adding that pro-independence heavyweights -- including Koo Kuan-min, a former senior presidential adviser -- will deliver speeches at the rally to condemn the pan-blue alliance for mounting the recall campaign for its own political gain at the expense of social stability and harmony.
Yang added he is hopeful that the rally can attract at least 50,000 people to attend.

Over the past two consecutive weekends, pan-blue supporters have rallied at the same location to pressure Chen to step down to assume responsibility for the alleged involvement of his son-in-law and aides in insider trading or illicit business deals.
The opposition hopes to soon gain sufficient support in the legislature to put the recall motion to a vote in a public referendum.
However, Yang said the bid to unseat Chen is unjustified because the president was not personally implicated in any wrongdoing.

Two "pan-green" camp parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union, both known as pro-independence sympathizers -- have encouraged their members to take part in the rally to call for a speedy end to the "recall drama" and an immediate return to political stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU REJECTS DONATION FROM TOBACCO COMPANY

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University has decided not to accept a NT$1 million donation from London-based British American Tobacco Co. to sponsor its annual tree-planting campaign, a spokesman of the university said Friday.

Chen Pao-chi, dean of the university's College of Bio-Resources and Agriculture, said the college had sent a letter to the Taiwan International Medical Alliance a week ago, making it clear it will not accept any more donations from tobacco companies.
British American Tobacco has been donating tree seedlings to NTU's experimental forest since 2001. In return, NTU President Lee Si-chen has presented the company with citations.

Anti-smoking groups in Taiwan, including the Taiwan International Medical Alliance, have strongly criticized NTU's decision to accept the donations as "either corrupt or foolish," and demanded the university make its position on tobacco products known to the public.

British American Tobacco was to donate 10,000 tree seedlings to NTU's tree-planting activity scheduled for June 18, but under mounting pressure from anti-smoking groups, the College of Bio-Resources and Agriculture pledged it will no longer accept the sponsorship of tobacco companies or any other controversial donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL CONTINUE HELPING AFRICAN ALLIES FIGHT DISEASE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday Taiwan will continue helping its African allies combat diseases, such as AIDS, malaria and avian influenza.
Chen made the pledge while attending a reception hosted by the joint trade office of African countries in Taipei to celebrate Africa Day.

Citing statistics compiled by the United Nations and the World Health Organization, Chen said over 60 percent of HIV carriers live in areas south of the Sahara desert, including Taiwan's diplomatic allies of Malawi and Swaziland.

Since 2002, Chen said, Taiwan has posted public health and medical personnel in Malawi to assist in AIDS prevention and control. In July 2004, Taiwan's medical mission at Malawi's Mzuzuin Central Hospital opened an AIDS outpatient department with pharmaceutical support from the United Nations. The department, also known as Rainbow outpatient service, has since offered the AIDS drug ARV to patients free of charge.
The Taiwan medical mission in Malawi has also developed a fingerprint identification system (FPIS) to monitor AIDS patients' use of AIDS drug.

Chen said the Rainbow outpatience service has become one of the best AIDS screening centers in Malawi and has laid a solid basis for Taiwan to set up an AIDS research center in Africa. At present, Chen said Taiwan is preparing to open a similar FPIS center in Swaziland to help with that country's AIDS prevention and control program.

In the past few months, Chen went on, Taiwan has sent medical personnel to Burkina Faso and Chad to assist in fighting avian flu infections, offering epidemic-fighting drugs and medical supplies. Over the years, Chen said, Taiwan has also spared no efforts to help Sao Tome and Principe -- as well as the Gambia -- fight malaria amd other tropical diseases.

"All these efforts signify our determination to assist our African allies fight diseases and promote public health," Chen said, adding that over the past decades, Taiwan has also assisted its African allies in agricultural and fishery development as well as in medical services, education and infrastructural construction.
In addition to chiefs of the African diplomatic missions in Taipei, King Mswati III of Swaziland, who is currently on a six-day state visit in Taiwan, also attended the Africa Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: European Parliament OKs stem cell research programme.
The European Parliament approved Thursday an embryonic stem cell research project for the period between 2007 and 2013 with a total expenditure of 50 billion euros. Many Italian civic and religious groups urged Premier Romano Prodi to vote "No" to the controversial project in the EU Council meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS OFFER TIPS ON PROMOTION OF CHILDBIRTH

TEXT.P: A group of academics in central Taiwan urged the government Friday to adopt incentives to encourage local couples to have children.

The scholars, including professor Tsai Chi-yuan of Tunghai University, made the appeal while attending a seminar sponsored by the Ministry of the Interior on population and national pension issues. The seminar, chaired by Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang, took place in central Taichung City.

The academics suggested that the government offer maternity subsidies for mothers, tax deduction for children's day-care fees, paid holidays for mothers to care for their ailing children and open marriage-related courses at senior high schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturddy, June 17, or the 22nd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1703: British religious leader John Wesley is born. He founded Methodism in 1738, while his brother, Charles, wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing."
1775: The second battle of the American Revolution commences at Bunker Hill and Breed's Hill, just north of Boston, Massachusetts. The Americans lost around 400 men, the British 1,000.
1925: A total of 29 countries sign the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940: Red Army forces occupy Latvia and Estonia and pro-Soviet administrations are installed.
1950: The first kidney transplant is performed by Dr. Richard Lawler in Chicago.
1960: The Chinese communists launch 85,965 shells toward the island of Kinmen on the eve of US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's visit to the Republic of China.
1967: Communist China detonates its first hydrogen bomb.
1971: The United States and Japan sign an agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: Five men are caught snooping around the Washington apartment-hotel complex known as The Watergate, currently being used by the Democratic Party as their headquarters during the US election campaign.
1974: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun leaves for Seoul to attend the 9th Sino-Korean Ministerial Level Economic Cooperation Conference.
1976: Hsu Li-teh is appointed vice minister of finance by the ROC Executive Yuan.
1978: More than 4.5 million eligible ROC voters go to the polls to elect 3,786 representatives of townships and villages as well as 6,417 urban and rural district chiefs.
1979: Charles Cross, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Raymond Perodin, Haiti's new ambassador to the ROC, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1982: Fourteen generals meet at an army base in Buenos Aires and vote unanimously to fire Leopoldo Galtieri, the president who led Argentina into the Falklands War against Britain.
1982: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung, as President Chiang Ching-kuo's special envoy, leaves for Saudi Arabia to offer Taiwan's condolences for the passing of King Fahd ibn Abdul Aziz.
1986: Nineteen mainland Chinese youths defect across the Yellow Sea aboard a small wooden boat to South Korea to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Some 400,000 Parisians and tourists from all over the world celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower.
1990: President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay arrives in Taipei to sign a joint communique calling for closer bilateral relations with the ROC.
1992: Lin Yang-kang, president of the Judicial Yuan of the ROC, leaves for the United States for a three-week visit.
1996: The United States and mainland China reach a deal to stamp out rampant Chinese copyright piracy.
1999: The International Labor Organization adopts a treaty banning the worst forms of child labor, including slavery and forced military recruitment.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweights at an extraordinary session of the party's 15th National Congress call for party unity while protesters outside the session's venue call for the expulsion of former party chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I hate the way scarlet dims the perception of vermilion. I hate the way the modern popular airs are liable to spoil the taste for good music. Finally, I hate the way smartness of speech in men is liable to destroy kingdoms and ruin families."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Congress Wages Partisan Battle Over Iraq War. For the first time since the United States invaded Iraq three years ago, Republican leaders Thursday officially convened a full-scale debate over the war--an effort that they hoped would showcase the increasingly divergent positions of the two parties and that wound up unleashing passions and acrimony on both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times GSDF Iraq pullout may start this month
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is expected to announce as early as next Wednesday a plan to withdraw Ground Self- Defense Fource troops from the southern Iraq city of Samawah, government and ruling bloc sources said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE PILOT KILLED IN TRAINER JET CRASH

TEXT.P: An Air Force trainer jet crashed in southern Chiayi County Saturday morning, killing one pilot and injuring the other, military officials said.

The wreckage of the F5F aircraft was found aflame in a crop field in the county's Taipao city at 7:26 a.m., 26 minutes after taking off from Taitung air base on a routine training flight, the officials said.
While pilot Chou Chieh-wei died before rescue personnel arrived, his partner Hsia Wen-yu sustained severe injuries and was rushed to Chiayi Christian Hospital, they said.
Hsia was in stable condition after emergency treatment, doctors said.
According to witnesses, the plane hit the railing of a road leading to the Taipao station of the high-speed railway before plunging into the field in flames.
Ministry of National Defense officials said the military will set up a special task force to investigate the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES TO TAP MARKETS IN OIL-EXPORTING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is scheduled to lead a trade promotion delegation to several oil-exporting countries including Kazakhstan, Iran and Jordan in September, TAITRA officials said Saturday.

The tour, slated for Sept. 12-23, will target the information technology, electronics, machinery, textile and construction material markets of these countries, with destinations covering Alma-ata, Tehran and Amman, the officials said.

As international oil prices have continued to soar since the 2003 U.S.-Iraq war, major oil exporters that have made huge profits in the past three years have become important markets for businesses around the world, they pointed out.
They said the brilliant economic performance of these countries has significantly boosted their buying power.
