Manila Bulletin: SC issues TRO on Luisita
The Supreme Court (SC) has stopped the government from implementing a resolution that would include the 5,000-hectare Hacienda Luisita of the Cojuangco family in Tarlac under the coverage of the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program (CARP).
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo orders Reds crushed in 2 years
CAUAYAN, Isabela -- In a move tantamount to a declaration of war, President Macapagal-Arroyo yesterday committed billions of pesos in funds to fight the 37-year-old communist insurgency with guns and development projects.
The Philippine Star: AFP gets P1 B to wipe out NPA
CAUAYAN, Isabela -- In fighting one of Asia's longest-running communist insurgencies, the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) will get an extra P1 billion to finance combat operations aimed at wiping out the New People's Army (NPA) within three years.
The Manila Times: High Court stops breakup of Luisita
THE Supreme Court on Friday ordered a temporary stay on the parceling out of the 6,000-hectare Hacienda Luisita in Tarlac under the government's land reform program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL CONTINUE HELPING AFRICAN ALLIES FIGHT DISEASE: PRESIDENT(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday Taiwan will continue helping its African allies combat diseases, such as AIDS, malaria and avian influenza.
Chen made the pledge while attending a reception hosted by the joint trade office of African countries in Taipei to celebrate Africa Day.

Citing statistics compiled by the United Nations and the World Health Organization, Chen said over 60 percent of HIV carriers live in areas south of the Sahara desert, including Taiwan's diplomatic allies of Malawi and Swaziland.

Since 2002, Chen said, Taiwan has posted public health and medical personnel in Malawi to assist in AIDS prevention and control. In July 2004, Taiwan's medical mission at Malawi's Mzuzuin Central Hospital opened an AIDS outpatient department with pharmaceutical support from the United Nations. The department, also known as Rainbow outpatient service, has since offered the AIDS drug ARV to patients free of charge.
The Taiwan medical mission in Malawi has also developed a fingerprint identification system (FPIS) to monitor AIDS patients' use of AIDS drug.

Chen said the Rainbow outpatience service has become one of the best AIDS screening centers in Malawi and has laid a solid basis for Taiwan to set up an AIDS research center in Africa. At present, Chen said Taiwan is preparing to open a similar FPIS center in Swaziland to help with that country's AIDS prevention and control program.

In the past few months, Chen went on, Taiwan has sent medical personnel to Burkina Faso and Chad to assist in fighting avian flu infections, offering epidemic-fighting drugs and medical supplies. Over the years, Chen said, Taiwan has also spared no efforts to help Sao Tome and Principe -- as well as the Gambia -- fight malaria amd other tropical diseases.

"All these efforts signify our determination to assist our African allies fight diseases and promote public health," Chen said, adding that over the past decades, Taiwan has also assisted its African allies in agricultural and fishery development as well as in medical services, education and infrastructural construction.
In addition to chiefs of the African diplomatic missions in Taipei, King Mswati III of Swaziland, who is currently on a six-day state visit in Taiwan, also attended the Africa Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU REJECTS DONATION FROM TOBACCO COMPANY(repeat)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University has decided not to accept a NT$1 million donation from London-based British American Tobacco Co. to sponsor its annual tree-planting campaign, a spokesman of the university said Friday.

Chen Pao-chi, dean of the university's College of Bio-Resources and Agriculture, said the college had sent a letter to the Taiwan International Medical Alliance a week ago, making it clear it will not accept any more donations from tobacco companies.
British American Tobacco has been donating tree seedlings to NTU's experimental forest since 2001. In return, NTU President Lee Si-chen has presented the company with citations.

Anti-smoking groups in Taiwan, including the Taiwan International Medical Alliance, have strongly criticized NTU's decision to accept the donations as "either corrupt or foolish," and demanded the university make its position on tobacco products known to the public.

British American Tobacco was to donate 10,000 tree seedlings to NTU's tree-planting activity scheduled for June 18, but under mounting pressure from anti-smoking groups, the College of Bio-Resources and Agriculture pledged it will no longer accept the sponsorship of tobacco companies or any other controversial donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Singapore shares stage dramatic rebound.
Singapore shares staged a dramatic recovery yesterday with the biggest one-day rise in more than three years after comments in the United States that the risk of inflation had receded.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Phase one of the Common Service Tunnel at Marina Bay is finished.
Singapore's phase one of Common Service Tunnel at Marina Bay is finished.
This S$81 million phase one of the Common Services Tunnel - only the second of its kind in Asia after Japan - as well as a District Cooling Plant which will help businesses cut cost in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL FRUIT CROPS WILL INCREASE IF NO SEVERE DISASTERS OCCUR

TEXT.P: Agricultural officials estimated Saturday that several fruit crops are expected to increase if there are no severe natural disasters this year.

In a fruit crop estimate report, officials of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said even with typhoons and heavy rains hitting Taiwan last year, lemon production was not seriously affected.
The COA forecast that lemon production will reach 17,140 metric tons this year, a slight increase of 3 percent over the previous year as this year's weather has been fine so far.

According to the estimate, production of longan is projected to reach 114,248 metric tons this year, a growth of 11 percent over last year, while lychee production is expected to be 82,829 metric tons this year, an increase of 17 percent over last year.
The production of leaf vegetables is estimated to reach 49,760 metric tons in June, a slight increase of 3 percent over May, according to the officials.

Referring to the June production of cut flowers, that of lilies and roses is expected to increase 23 percent and 6 percent over May, respectively, while chrysanthemum output will decrease 8 percent over May.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TO HOLD NUDE RALLY TO PROTEST 4TH NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: Environmental protection activists are preparing to hold a nude protest rally June 26 at Fulung Beach in Kungliao Township, Taipei County in a bid to save the beach from coastal erosion caused by the construction of a nearby wharf for the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant.

Calling for the public to join the event, Ho Chung-hsun, secretary-general of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, explained at a news conference Saturday that the idea behind holding such an alternative protest is that "it is preferable to be naked rather than having nuclear power."

Ho indicated so far there are 13 male citizens, ages 25 to 45, who have signed up for the protest activity. Coming from various professional backgrounds, they are all joining the planned protest for the same reason -- to oppose the nuclear plant.

The construction of the wharf, designed to import heavy machinery to the power plant, has caused extensive damage to the nearby ecology and marine biology, which was formerly home to over 120 kinds of coral and numerous marine creatures.
Now there is dying coral covered by sand from the construction site of the wharf and increasing coastal erosion, Ho said.

Once the plant begins commercial operations in the near future, oceanic pollution on the northeast coast is expected to turn for the worse as a result of steaming waste water emissions from the nuclear power plant, Ho claimed.
Information about the June 26 rally is available at the Web site of the non-profit union at http://www.tepu.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY, HOSPITAL FORGE NEW INSTITUTE FOR MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: National Chung-hsing University and Taichung Veterans General Hospital have reached an agreement to jointly establish a new graduate institute specializing in medical technology, aiming to combine academic research and clinical experience to offer better medical services in central Taiwan.

A university official said Saturday the new institute will focus on areas such as immunology and molecular medicine, medical imaging and tumor treatment, as well as gene therapy and stem cell therapy.
He also noted the veteran's hospital will not only offer clinical advice to help research focus on practical needs, but will provide students with clinical internships.
The institute has begun offering graduate programs this year, expecting the creation of doctoral programs in two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Foreign Minister D'Alema visits Washington.
Italian Foreign Minister Massimo D'Alema visited Washington D.C. Friday where he had talks with U.S. State Secritary Condoleezza Rice and National Security Adviser Steve Hadley on a wide range of topics, covering Iraq, Afghanistan, Iran, Middle East, Guantanamo and the death of Italian intelligence official Nicola Calpari.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE PLANE CRASH MAY BE RELATED TO BIRD COLLISION

TEXT.P: Collision with birds may be responsible for a fatal Air Force trainer jet crash occurring Saturday in southern Chiayi County, Air Force officials said.
However, they said, until the cause of the crash is determined, other possible causes will not be ruled out, such as human error, engine failure and environmental factors.
The wreckage of the F5F aircraft was found ablaze in a crop field in the county's Taipao city at 7:26 a.m., 26 minutes after taking off from Taitung air base on a routine training flight.
While pilot Chou Chieh-wei was killed in the crash, his trainee Hsia Wen-yu sustained severe injuries but was reportedly in stable condition after emergency treatment.

According to Pan Kung-hsiao, chief inspector of the Ministry of National Defense's Air Force Command Headquarters, the plane was carrying out basic training at Chiayi air base with another trainer jet when the accident took place.
The plane had operated normally and didn't divert from its designated route before the crash, and accounts by witnesses indicate the two pilots did not try to escape by parachute, Pan said.
Pan said the plane had flown for 6,595 hours, adding that Chou had 2,638 hours of flying experience and Hsia had more than 400 hours.

Pan said as bird feathers and bloodstains were found on the landing gear of the other trainer jet that flew behind the crashed plane, the military suspects the crash may have resulted from a bird collision.
The real cause of the crash will only be established after the release of an investigative report on the accident, Pan said.
If engine failure is to blame for the crash, the military will ground all aircraft using the same model of engines for inspection, he said.

Meanwhile, Liu Yu-tien, director of political warfare at the Air Force Command Headquarters, said the Air Force has no plans to replace the F5F jets currently in use since they operate normally, despite the aircraft's age.
Minister of National Defense Lee Jye has instructed the military to conduct a thorough investigation into the accident and offer compensation to the victim's family, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARKANSAS GOVERNOR ARRIVES IN TAIWAN MONDAY FOR FOUR-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Mike Huckabee, governor of the U.S. state of Arkansas, is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Monday for a four-day visit at the head of a seven-member delegation aiming to boost friendly political, economic and cultural ties between his state and Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.

During his stay, Huckabee will call on President Chen Shui-bian and several high-level government officials, including Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco Huang, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang and acting Kaohsiung mayor Yeh Chu-lan.

According to the MOFA, Huckabee is very Taiwan-friendly and paid two visits to the country while serving as deputy Arkansas governor 1993-1996. In 2004, he visited the island in his capacity as Arkansas governor for the first time.

At the 1993 annual meeting of the U.S. Council of State Governments which Huckabee chaired, he proposed supporting Taiwan's access to the World Health Organization (WHO). That year, the council passed two proposals supporting Taiwan's bid for WHO observer status and calling on China to dismantle missiles targeting Taiwan, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CHILDREN GET LEAST SLEEP AMONG FIVE EAST ASIAN CITIES: POLL

TEXT.P: Pre-schoolers in Taipei go to bed the latest and have the shortest sleeping time compared with kids in Tokyo, Beijing, Shanghai and Seoul, according to the results of an international survey released Saturday.

The results were publicized by Tsai Chun-mei, a professor of early childhood education at National Taipei University of Education. The survey was conducted by a Japanese educational research and development institute between March and June 2005 on 6,134 mothers with children ages 3 to 6 from the five East Asian cities.

The results show pre-schoolers in Taipei sleep an average 9 hours and 28 minutes per night, the shortest among the five cities surveyed. Preschoolers in Tokyo have the longest sleeping time -- a nightly average of 10 hours and 6 minutes.
While 75.8 percent of Tokyo children hit the sack before 9 p.m., only 26.4 percent of Taipei kids do so -- the lowest ratio among the five cities surveyed.
On how frequently they watch television, children in Taipei have the third highest frequency after Tokyo and Seoul, the survey shows.
The time spent by Taipei children watching TV is the second highest after Tokyo, with frequency of computer use among Taipei children also second highest after Seoul.
Tsai pointed out that young children need at least 10 hours of sleep every night, and advised parents to ensure children follow good sleeping habits in order to keep them healthy.

Tsai warned that kids' eyesight may be negatively affected if too much time is spent watching television or playing computer games, suggesting children not be allowed to watch television for more than two hours per day.
She urged parents to increase their children's participation in outdoor activities to improve their health and their interpersonal relationships.
Also, parents can enhance interactions with their children by chatting with them while bathing them, preparing breakfast or helping them get dressed, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA RECRUITING VOLUNTEER GUIDES FOR TAIPEI GUEST HOUSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Saturday a plan to recruit volunteer guides to show visitors around the newly renovated Taipei Guest House.
Those aged 18 to 70 who are interested in becoming a guide for the Taipei Guest House may submit an application online: http://tgh.mofa.gov.tw.
The Taipei Guest House, a historical landmark built in 1901 and located in front of the MOFA's building, was formerly the residence of Taiwan's governor under Japanese colonial rule.
After 1945, when the island was handed back to the Republic of China, the mansion was then renamed Taipei Guest House. It has been used for holding state banquets and other activities.
From now on, the MOFA will open the guest house to the public six times a year, on the first Sunday of every even-numbered month, with the first opening on June 4 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR MUST APOLOGIZE FOR SHAM PRODUCTS: CONSUMER GROUP

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) should offer compensation and apologize for the sham health products it produced from hog feed, the Consumers' Foundation said Saturday.

The foundation's officials made the appeal after public prosecutors of the Tainan District Court detained a former Taisugar executive and an importer earlier this week to investigate the procurement of hog feed to produce health food products for human consumption.
Taisugar has used the performance protein powder to manufacture nutritional yeast products including vitamin yeast, flavored vitamin yeast and yeast candy for the past 13 years.

The foundation argues that although no evidence indicates ingesting animal feed causes damage to humans, Taishugar has not acted in good faith with regard to food safety regulations or consumer protection.

Taisugar's "viciousness" has destroyed the faith of consumers, they said. According to food safety regulations, counterfeit food or food additives should not be sold -- they should be seized and destroyed immediately, they said.
They demand that Taisugar propose a means of compensating consumers based on sales of the four products made from hog feed over the past 13 years.
The company should also set up a foundation and put funds toward making amends and compensation, they said.

In addition, they are calling on Taisugar to set up a task force to handle consumer complaints about refunds or compensation. The foundation is also asking to meet Taisugar officials to discuss matters concerning compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Fall Elections Are Rove's Next Test; Reputation as Architect of Victory at Stake.
White House political strategist Karl Rove emerges from the CIA leak case with his reputation scuffed, his power slightly diminished, and Republicans counting on him, once again, to help rescue their House and Senate majorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU'S ANNUAL LYCHEE FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2006 Lychee Festival opened Saturday in the central county of Nantou, where a lychee-tasting event will be held on Sunday and sales of the delicious fruit offered thereafter at the Nantou brewery.
Nantou Mayor Hsu Shu-hua -- accompanied by Chen Chen-sheng, director general of the county's Cultural Bureau -- attended a ceremony to mark the opening of the nine-day festival.
During the ceremony, a charity bazaar was held to auction off "good luck bags" of stationery supplies for senior and junior high school students preparing for basic competency exams.
The lucky bags were made by a group of single mothers from the non-profit Eden Social Welfare Foundation, and embroidered with academic blessings from a local "study god," Wen chang.
Proceeds will be donated to charity as first aid funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVENUES UP IN MAY FOR 56% OF TAIWAN'S COMPANIES

TEXT.P: Business revenues for 56 percent of Taiwan's listed and over-the-counter companies increased 11.3 percent in June over the same month last year, according to statistics released Saturday by Barits Investment Services Corp.
Among them, 128 companies registered record-high turnover in May, compared to just 78 in April.
As a whole, nearly 70 percent of publicly traded companies saw business revenues surging in the first five months over the same period last year.

According to Barits, May's money-making industries included DRAM, motherboards, solar power supply systems, cellphone components, light emitting diode (LED) products, computer and video games, IC packaging and testing, non-iron metals, stainless steel, wire and cable -- registering an average growth of more than 40 percent.

Also in May, 43 percent of listed and over-the-counter companies saw business revenues moving down, with financial holding companies, banks, bicycle and automobile industries dropping by more than 30 percent over the same time last year, while graphic cards, CD players, electrical and electronic engineering sectors moved down by more than 20 percent.

Those with business revenues registering record highs in May were mainly companies devoted to production of electronic products, medicine, medical equipment, plastic raw materials and stainless steel.

However, overall business revenues of Taiwan's listed and over-the-counter companies registered a 4.2 percent decrease in May from April, with financial holding companies dropping most at 90 percent, followed by securities companies, the footwear industry, banks, IC design, bicycle and notebook computer manufacturers, which saw revenue dropping more than 20 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARY CAUCUS LEADER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Graham Watson, head of the Liberal Party caucus in the European Parliament, will arrive in Taiwan Monday for a three-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.
Watson, arriving with his office director Desiree Oen, is friendly toward Taiwan. He has publicly spoken for Taiwan's cause, including its bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).

He also helped arrange for first lady Wu Shu-jen to travel to Strasbourg, France to receive the Freedom Prize on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian in 2001. The prize was presented by the Liberal International in recognition of Chen's contributions toward Taiwan's democratic development.

During his stay, Watson is scheduled to meet with President Chen, former President Lee Teng-hui, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Premier Su Tseng-chang, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chang Siao-yue, Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI REGISTRY TO SET RECORD OF 300,000 POTENTIAL MARROW DONORS

TEXT.P: The number of people taking a blood test in order to donate bone marrow to the Tzu Chi Marrow Donor Registry is expected to reach 300,000 by Sunday, according to the registry's founder, the non-profit Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.
The foundation will hold a celebration marking the record Sunday at Luchiang Elementary School in Taipei County.

The Tzu Chi Marrow Donor Registry was founded in October 1993. By the end of December 2005, the registry had collected data on more than 280,000 people, becoming the world's largest databank of Asian marrow donors.
Over the past years, the center has also made 1,010 successful matches between marrow recipients and donors, according to the Tzu Chi foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTREPRENEUR, PARTY HEAD EXCHANGE VIEWS ON WHAT CONSTITUTES LEADERSHIP

TEXT.P: An entrepreneur and the head of the main opposition party exchanged views on what constitutes a leader in a forum held Saturday in Taipei.

Both Stan Shih, former chairman of the Acer Group, and Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as Taipei mayor, stressed the attributes of vision and integrity during a Harvard Forum on promoting the national interest, sponsored by the Harvard Club of the Republic of China.
Shih cited selflessness, integrity and willingness to take responsibility as the primary characteristics of a leader.
From the perspective of a corporation, he claimed, if a CEO cannot establish or achieve the company's objectives, that individual should resign or be replaced.
Shih said that being a leader is all about taking responsibility, not about fame or privileges. If a leader cannot accept responsibility, Shih said, then the fame and privileges should be stripped.
Ma, the KMT's likely candidate in the 2008 presidential election, said a leader should have the qualities of vision, integrity, commitment and action.
Ma said a leader should be able to effectively communicate a vision to others, and to persevere in reaching goals in a responsible manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF WELCOMES VISIT OF JAPANESE SUMO WRESTLERS

TEXT.P: Cheng Wen-tsang, head of the Government Information Office (GIO), extended his warm welcome to four visiting Japanese sumo wrestlers Saturday at a press conference to promote an upcoming sumo contest slated for Aug. 19-20 in Taipei.
Cheng said he hopes the sumo wrestlers -- regarded as a national treasure in Japan -- will help boost Taiwan-Japan amity during their visit.

The four honored guests form part of a 42-member team of sumo wrestlers invited by a private entertainment company to attend the competition, which will be held at the Taipei Arena stadium in downtown Taipei.
A total of 42 matches will be held during the two-day competition to produce one champion, who will be awarded with 10 million Japanese yen (US$86,8100), according to the organizer.
The history of sumo traces back to 695 A.D., although the sport was not formally accepted by Japanese aristocratic circles until 728 A.D. Since that time, Japan has held regular "sumo festivals."
Japan's schools have offered classes in the sport of Sumo since 1941, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pentagon Study Describes Abuse by Units in Iraq
United States Special Operations troops employed a set of harsh, unauthorized interrogation techniques against detainees in Iraq during a four-month period in early 2004, long after approval for their use was rescinded, according to a Pentagon inquiry released Friday. The investigation is the last of 12 major inquiries to be made public that focus on allegations of detainee abuse by American personnel in Cuba, Afghanistan and Iraq, and the first to focus on Special Operations troops, who operate with more latitude than other military units. It detailed harsh treatment that continued at isolated bases even after the abuses first surfaced at the Abu Ghraib prison.
Wall Street Journal: Profit Goals, A Longtime Loser, Pro Soccer Begins To Score in U.S.
The U.S. men's soccer team plays Italy in the World Cup Saturday, and a loss would all but end U.S. hopes of advancing to the second round of the tournament -- arming critics who say soccer in America is forever stuck in neutral. But a funny thing is happening back home. Five years after nearly going out of business, Major League Soccer, the top U.S. league, is showing signs of growth, stability and even profitability. MLS is attracting well-heeled investors from the major U.S. sports leagues and from traditional soccer countries. The Austrian maker of the energy drink Red Bull is spending more than US$100 million on the league's New York team, and the owner of one of Mexico's most popular soccer clubs has started a team in Los Angeles. MLS teams are enjoying a US$700 million stadium-building spree that will result in seven of the league's 13 teams playing in venues designed for soccer by next year. And the league's exposure on television is increasing.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH COMMISSION HOLDS HK PARTY TO LURE BACKPACKERS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Youth Commission (NYC) sponsored a party in Hong Kong Saturday to inspire more backpackers to choose Taiwan as their top holiday destination.

The Cabinet-level NYC sponsored a party, themed "Let's be Friends," at a bar in Hong Kong's Wanchai District, with the participation of tour operators and foreign students from five Hong Kong universities.
Wu Ching-hui, a NYC official, traveled to Hong Kong to preside over the presentation.

The NYC introduced many of Taiwan's major tourist attractions to the partygoers through film, posters and pamphlets. Young Taiwanese travel professionals were also invited to give speeches at the party.
The NYC has also created a special Web site http: //youtravel.tw offering all kinds of Taiwan-related travel information.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS ON PROTECTION OF 'TAISHANG'

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should put aside their political disputes and negotiate measures to protect the rights and personal safety of Taiwanese businesspeople operating in China, known locally as "Taishang," the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation said Saturday.

In a telephone interview with CNA, a SEF official said that although "Taishang" have tried to keep a low profile and behave prudently in China, many of them have often fallen victim to criminal activities and accidents.

As China's economy is transforming rapidly, the gap between the rich and the poor is also widening quickly, the official said, adding that Taiwanese businesspeople, with their brilliant economic success, have become the envy of the Chinese and thus the target of criminal rings there.
According to statistics, the number of "Taishang" has now surpassed 600,000, with the number of cases involving threats to their personal security increasing from 67 in 2001 to 133 in 2005.

Among various cities in China, Dongkuan, in Guangdong province, saw the largest number of cases involving the personal security of Taiwanese businesspeople in recent years, accounting for 27 percent of cases, followed by Shenzhen, also in Guangdong province, with 13 percent.
According to the official, there are over 80,000 Taiwan businesspeople living in Dongkuan, a rural village turned industrialized city thanks to Taiwanese investment.
However, China-based Taiwanese will never understand that their contribution has at the same time led to murder cases again and again, the official added.
The SEF official urged governments on both sides to engage in talks and to ink an agreement as soon as possible to seek a solution to this problem.

Chang Wu-yueh, an associate professor in China studies at Tamkang University, urged China-based Taiwanese to make a prudent evaluations before investing in China -- and to think how they might save their lives so they can spend the money they've earned.

A China-based Taiwanese businessman recommended that his compatriots abide by China's laws, keep a low profile and avoid talking about politics while investing in China in order to prevent any trouble.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROOM FOR MORE IMPROVEMENT IN LAW AND ORDER: PREMIER SU

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday that there is still much room for improvement in terms of the country's law and order situation, and urged government agencies to work harder toward achieving that goal.
The premier made the remarks while presiding at a meeting on improving social order, the third such meeting since assuming the post in late January.
Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan quoted the premier as saying that various indicators suggest that Taiwan's law and order situation has improved.
Cheng cited a number of examples, such as crackdowns on places selling ecstasy and illicit video game parlors, as well as the confiscation of guns.

A public survey conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission in late May showed nearly 30 percent of people in Taiwan think the law and order situation has improved, compared with 40 percent who said it is "about the same," and slightly more than 10 percent who believe it has deteriorated.

The premier is not yet content with the results, and believes that all government agencies must work harder to deliver on his promise to the people, according to Cheng. The premier recently pledged to either improve law and order within six months or step down.
The premier instructed the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Ministry of Finance to step up monitoring and regulation of dummy banking accounts, as well as pre-paid cellphones.
The Ministry of the Interior, the National Police Agency and the National Communications Commission should work together to strengthen telecommunications regulations to stem fraud, the premier said.

The premier also said that a lot of major economic criminals have fled the country and sought refuge in China, and that he has instructed related government agencies to seek judicial assistance from the other side of the Taiwan Strait to extradite criminals and bring them to justice.

On cracking down on illegal gambling activity and prostitution, the premier has asked the ministry of Economic Affairs and Ministry of Justice to rigorously carry out a policy of cutting off the water and electricity supply to these businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S SUPPORTERS RALLY AGAINST RECALL CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Pro-independence bigwigs and their supporters came out in droves Saturday for a rally in Taipei to denounce an opposition-initiated campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian over corruption allegations implicating his family and close aides.

The demonstrators waved flags and blew air horns at the rally at the wide Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office in a display of support for the embattled president. Braving blistering mid-afternoon heat, some demonstrators held signs saying, "Society Needs Stability, " while others sold T-shirts that bear catch phrase "Protect Taiwan."
The rally was organized by major pro-independence groups, with the support of two "pan-green camp" parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Special booths were step up at the rally site for demonstrators to sign their names against the opposition-initiated presidential recall motion.

Many rally-goers also lined up to sign their name in support of a campaign for a referendum on forcing the main opposition Kuomintang to return to national coffers its ill-gotten party assets allegedly amassed during its 54-year rule of Taiwan.
Pro-independence bigwigs took turn addressing the rally, condemning the KMT-led opposition alliance for stirring up the current political turmoil simply for their own political gain.

Koo Kuan-min, a former senior presidential adviser, said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeo's recent remarks "President Chen would die a miserable death if he fails to resign" prompted him to revisit several bloody incidents during the KMT's authoritarian rule, including the murder in Taipei of Chen Wen-cheng, a pro-independence U.S.-based scholar.

TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming said prosecution authorities should look into whether any irregularities involving in the sale of a Taipei City Government-owned bank to the private Fubon business group several years ago as Ma concurrently serves as Taipei mayor. Lo also questioned the legality of the sales of a large amount of the KMT's ill-gotten or controversial real estate holdings since Ma took the party's helm.
Speaking on the same occasion, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said the recall campaign is mainly a political struggle for the opposition to seize power.

"At this turbulent time, we must stand united to bolster the home-grown DPP administration. We must not give in to opposition threats because the president himself has done nothing wrong, " Yu said, adding that the DPP will not let down its supporters and will conduct soul-searching and self-reflection to live up to public expectations.
Some of the demonstrators said they were tired of watching the opposition demonstrate in the streets the past two weekends and that they wanted their voices to be heard.
The political turmoil was sparked by allegations that Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-min, was involved in insider trading. Chao was arrested on May 24 and the probe continues.

The opposition is hoping to pass a motion on June 27 setting up a public referendum to recall Chen. But many doubt the opposition, which holds a slim majority in the legislature, will be able to muster up the two-thirds majority it needs to approve the measure.
The president and other high-ranking officials didn't appear at the protest. KMT Chairman Ma said Saturday's protest showed that the ruling party was failing to reflect on its leader's shortcomings.

The rally was generally peaceful, but police wrestled a shirtless man with a knife to the ground and grabbed the weapon from him. It was not immediately clear what the man planned to do with the knife.
On Sunday, the opposition plans to continue its protest campaign with a rally in the central city of Changhua.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 18 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, June 18:
09:30, The KMT and the PFP legislative caucuses will call a public hearing on the presidential recall motion.
12:30, Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsan will attend a luncheon in honor of visiting Japanese sumo wrestlers at Grand Hotel.
17:00, The Taiwan Society will hold ceremony to mark its inauguration at Chinese Petroleum Corp. headquarters in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR APOLOGIZES FOR SHAM PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) Chairman Yu Cheng-hsien apologized Saturday for the sham health products the state-owned company produced from animal feed.
"We feel deeply regret for causing public anxiety over our company's negligence and lax internal control with regard to food safety," Yu said in a press statement.

The statement further said the company has retained a lawyer to file a damages suit against the supplier of the "performance protein powder, " which was meant for hog feed rather than for human consumption, and will donate all the sum of money paid by the supplier to consumer protection groups.

Meanwhile, Taisugar said it will complete recall of all its nutritional yeast products containing the "performance protein powder" by the noon of June 22. Consumers are welcome to call toll-free 0800026168 for any question about relevant issues.

For the past 13 years, the company had used the "performance protein powder" for production of at least four popular Taisugar health products, including vitamin yeast, flavored vitamin yeast and yeast candy.

The company began the recall operation Thursday after public prosecutors in the southern city of Tainan detained a former Taisugar executive and an importer who allegedly imported the material from Egypt and Belgium for sale to Taisugar.

To prevent recurrence of similar misdeeds, Taisugar said it will commission a government-sanctioned third party to review all materials or ingredients to be used for foodstuff production when taking delivery of those products from suppliers.

All of Taisugar's material suppliers and contract foodstuff processors must be subject to unannounced spot checks by the third party, in addition to obtaining food safety licenses from health authorities, Taisugar said.
Moreover, the company said it will conduct a comprehensive review of all of its long-term and certain specific suppliers of raw materials to ensure food safety.
The company has also launched an across-the-board investigation to find those responsible for the negligence and mete out disciplinary measures.

Earlier in the day, the Consumers' Foundation pushed Taisugar to apologize and offer compensation for its failure to act in good faith with regard to food safety regulations and consumer protection over the past 13 years.

Arguing that although no evidence indicates ingesting animal feed causes damage to humans, the foundation said Taishugar's negligence has destroyed the faith of consumers and should offer due compensations to consumers. The foundation urged Taisugar to set up a task force to handle consumer complaints about refunds or compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S SUPPORTERS RALLY AGAINST RECALL CAMPAIGN(repeat)

TEXT.P: Pro-independence bigwigs and their supporters came out in droves Saturday for a rally in Taipei to denounce an opposition-initiated campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian over corruption allegations implicating his family and close aides.

The demonstrators waved flags and blew air horns at the rally at the wide Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office in a display of support for the embattled president. Braving blistering mid-afternoon heat, some demonstrators held signs saying, "Society Needs Stability, " while others sold T-shirts that bear catch phrase "Protect Taiwan."
The rally was organized by major pro-independence groups, with the support of two "pan-green camp" parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Special booths were step up at the rally site for demonstrators to sign their names against the opposition-initiated presidential recall motion.

Many rally-goers also lined up to sign their name in support of a campaign for a referendum on forcing the main opposition Kuomintang to return to national coffers its ill-gotten party assets allegedly amassed during its 54-year rule of Taiwan.
Pro-independence bigwigs took turn addressing the rally, condemning the KMT-led opposition alliance for stirring up the current political turmoil simply for their own political gain.

Koo Kuan-min, a former senior presidential adviser, said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeo's recent remarks "President Chen would die a miserable death if he fails to resign" prompted him to revisit several bloody incidents during the KMT's authoritarian rule, including the murder in Taipei of Chen Wen-cheng, a pro-independence U.S.-based scholar.

TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming said prosecution authorities should look into whether any irregularities involving in the sale of a Taipei City Government-owned bank to the private Fubon business group several years ago as Ma concurrently serves as Taipei mayor. Lo also questioned the legality of the sales of a large amount of the KMT's ill-gotten or controversial real estate holdings since Ma took the party's helm.
Speaking on the same occasion, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said the recall campaign is mainly a political struggle for the opposition to seize power.

"At this turbulent time, we must stand united to bolster the home-grown DPP administration. We must not give in to opposition threats because the president himself has done nothing wrong, " Yu said, adding that the DPP will not let down its supporters and will conduct soul-searching and self-reflection to live up to public expectations.
Some of the demonstrators said they were tired of watching the opposition demonstrate in the streets the past two weekends and that they wanted their voices to be heard.
The political turmoil was sparked by allegations that Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-min, was involved in insider trading. Chao was arrested on May 24 and the probe continues.

The opposition is hoping to pass a motion on June 27 setting up a public referendum to recall Chen. But many doubt the opposition, which holds a slim majority in the legislature, will be able to muster up the two-thirds majority it needs to approve the measure.
The president and other high-ranking officials didn't appear at the protest. KMT Chairman Ma said Saturday's protest showed that the ruling party was failing to reflect on its leader's shortcomings.

The rally was generally peaceful, but police wrestled a shirtless man with a knife to the ground and grabbed the weapon from him. It was not immediately clear what the man planned to do with the knife.
On Sunday, the opposition plans to continue its protest campaign with a rally in the central city of Changhua.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROOM FOR MORE IMPROVEMENT IN LAW AND ORDER: PREMIER SU(repeat)

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday that there is still much room for improvement in terms of the country's law and order situation, and urged government agencies to work harder toward achieving that goal.
The premier made the remarks while presiding at a meeting on improving social order, the third such meeting since assuming the post in late January.
Executive Yuan spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan quoted the premier as saying that various indicators suggest that Taiwan's law and order situation has improved.
Cheng cited a number of examples, such as crackdowns on places selling ecstasy and illicit video game parlors, as well as the confiscation of guns.

A public survey conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission in late May showed nearly 30 percent of people in Taiwan think the law and order situation has improved, compared with 40 percent who said it is "about the same," and slightly more than 10 percent who believe it has deteriorated.

The premier is not yet content with the results, and believes that all government agencies must work harder to deliver on his promise to the people, according to Cheng. The premier recently pledged to either improve law and order within six months or step down.
The premier instructed the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Ministry of Finance to step up monitoring and regulation of dummy banking accounts, as well as pre-paid cellphones.
The Ministry of the Interior, the National Police Agency and the National Communications Commission should work together to strengthen telecommunications regulations to stem fraud, the premier said.

The premier also said that a lot of major economic criminals have fled the country and sought refuge in China, and that he has instructed related government agencies to seek judicial assistance from the other side of the Taiwan Strait to extradite criminals and bring them to justice.

On cracking down on illegal gambling activity and prostitution, the premier has asked the ministry of Economic Affairs and Ministry of Justice to rigorously carry out a policy of cutting off the water and electricity supply to these businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS ON PROTECTION OF 'TAISHANG'(repeat)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should put aside their political disputes and negotiate measures to protect the rights and personal safety of Taiwanese businesspeople operating in China, known locally as "Taishang," the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation said Saturday.

In a telephone interview with CNA, a SEF official said that although "Taishang" have tried to keep a low profile and behave prudently in China, many of them have often fallen victim to criminal activities and accidents.

As China's economy is transforming rapidly, the gap between the rich and the poor is also widening quickly, the official said, adding that Taiwanese businesspeople, with their brilliant economic success, have become the envy of the Chinese and thus the target of criminal rings there.
According to statistics, the number of "Taishang" has now surpassed 600,000, with the number of cases involving threats to their personal security increasing from 67 in 2001 to 133 in 2005.

Among various cities in China, Dongkuan, in Guangdong province, saw the largest number of cases involving the personal security of Taiwanese businesspeople in recent years, accounting for 27 percent of cases, followed by Shenzhen, also in Guangdong province, with 13 percent.
According to the official, there are over 80,000 Taiwan businesspeople living in Dongkuan, a rural village turned industrialized city thanks to Taiwanese investment.
However, China-based Taiwanese will never understand that their contribution has at the same time led to murder cases again and again, the official added.
The SEF official urged governments on both sides to engage in talks and to ink an agreement as soon as possible to seek a solution to this problem.

Chang Wu-yueh, an associate professor in China studies at Tamkang University, urged China-based Taiwanese to make a prudent evaluations before investing in China -- and to think how they might save their lives so they can spend the money they've earned.

A China-based Taiwanese businessman recommended that his compatriots abide by China's laws, keep a low profile and avoid talking about politics while investing in China in order to prevent any trouble.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 18, or the 23rd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1812: The U.S. Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners executed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, head of the separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly across the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally begins its Manhattan Project, the manufacturing of the first atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan province, is executed for sedition.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to militarily defeat the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Dr. Robert M. Lumiamsky, president, and Dr. Gordon B. Turner, vice president, of the American Council of Learned Societies.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1980: General Jose Dolores Herrera, El Salvador's ambassador to the ROC, presents his government's Gold Medal of Great Achievements to General Kao Huei-yuan, defense minister, Admiral Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, General Wang Sheng, director of the General Political Warfare Department, and General Wang Yung-shu, director of the National Security Bureau.
1981: The Executive Yuan appoints Dr. Yen Chen-hsing, president of National Taiwan University, as chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as the "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
1999: Florencio Marin, Belize minister of the sugar industry and local government and Latin American affairs, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The opposition Kuomintang passes a party reform package that includes provisions for the popular election of its party chairman following a nationwide party membership verification and registration process.
2001: The ROC breaks off diplomatic relations with Macedonia after the Balkan state made its intention clear that it would establish formal ties with China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAYOR CANDIDATE VOWS TO WIN 2020 OLYMPICS FOR TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for Taipei city mayor, announced a key campaign promise Sunday, claiming that if elected, he will work to win for the city the right to host the 2020 Olympic Games.
Hsieh had secured the right for Kaohisung to host the 2009 World Games when he was mayor of the southern port city.
During a hiking activity in suburban Taipei, Hsieh claimed that Taiwan has "too much politics and too few sports, " which he said are "very apolitical."
By launching an Olympic bid for Taipei, the capital city of Taiwan, he said, the people of Taiwan will have a common goal that will keep them from political bickering and ethnic division.
The host city of the 2020 Olympics will be selected in 2013. Hsieh said Taipei should not be absent from the bidding. The next mayor, to be elected in December, will serve a four-year term.
In reply to media questions as to whether his political rivals will use the Kaohisung rapid transit scandal to attack him during the mayoral election campaign, Hsieh said "it doesn't matter."
A healthy Taipei should have healthy elections, he said, adding that no smearing campaign and no ethnic provocations should be pursued as people are opposed to violence and vote buying in elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAY RESPOND TO RECALL MOTION TO THE PEOPLE: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian may report directly to the people in response to the opposition's motion to recall him, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Sunday.

Ker Chien-ming, the head of the DPP legislative caucus, said Chen may report directly to the people via his online newsletter rather than providing a written statement as requested by the opposition in response to opposition lawmakers' recent initiation of a recall motion against him over the insider trading allegations against his son-in-law.
When and how the president will report to the people in this regard, however, has yet to be decided, Ker said.

The Legislative Yuan is set to review a motion initiated by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party to recall Chen Monday, and the alliance has requested Chen to present a written statement to the legislature to respond to the charges made against him before the review process starts.

Ker rejected the "pan-blue alliance" request that the media be allowed to cover the debates in the review process for live broadcast, saying there is no such precedent in the history of Taiwan's legislature.

Ker also dismissed a "pan-blue alliance" plan to hold a "testimony-style public hearing" at the Legislative Yuan where "legislators from the two rival sides could debate the recall motion," ridiculing the plan as pointless as "none of the legislators is the president."

Meanwhile, Yeh Yi-ching, chief secretary of the DPP legislative caucus, said that the legislature must review the recall motion in accordance with the law and that "no gimmicks should be allowed during the process to turn it into a media event."

Chen Ching-chun, another DPP legislative caucus whip, said that holding a testimony-style public hearing in the Legislative Yuan would be illegal, adding that the DPP caucus will not "dance to the tune of others."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BIGGEST BENEFICIARY OF CROSS-STRAIT AVIATION DEAL: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: China is the biggest beneficiary of the latest aviation deal between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, policy planners and academics said over the weekend.

They were referring to a cross-strait agreement announced Wednesday on a framework for charter flights for holidays and special cases, including emergency medical and humanitarian missions and shipments of machinery and parts for Taiwan-funded companies in China.

The agreement marks rare progress in the often-rocky cross-strait relations, and it surprised many pundits as it came at a time when Taiwan's political situation has been volatile, with an opposition-initiated motion proceeding in the legislature to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Opposition lawmakers invariably scoffed at the surprise agreement, describing it as a "minor event" used by the president in an attempt to draw attention away from corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.

Commenting on the opposition's disparagement, a source familiar with cross-strait policy planning said they were off the mark. As far as cross-strait relations are concerned, the official said, China holds the key in setting the tone for nearly every major issue, with the latest charter flight deal being no exception.

To Beijing, the official said, the just-concluded charter flight deal was easy to achieve, adding that it has generated enormous advantages in China's favor, particularly in courting the hearts and minds of the Taiwan people and projecting a peacemaker image in the international community.

According to the official, the two sides reached consensus on the four-point aviation deal in late May after several rounds of talks in Macau between the Taipei Airlines Association and the Beijing-based Civil Aviation Association (CAA) , both of which were authorized by their respective governments to reach a deal.

At first, Taiwan intended to unveil the deal at a Dragon Boat Festival gathering in Taipei of Taiwan businesspeople operating in China, known locally as "Taishang, " but CAA officials rejected the idea, saying that they had yet to ask the top officials. On June 13, they finally agreed that the deal could be announced.

The "odd" timing made some observers believe that China might have realized that it should keep cross-strait issues separate from Taiwan's political situation if it doesn't want to miss opportunities to improve relations.
But the official said that Beijing should have made a careful political calculation in choosing the timing since "economics serving politics" is the norm in China.
Given the high threshold for a presidential recall motion to be passed under Taiwan's constitutional system, the official said, Beijing might believe that the opposition's campaign is doomed to fail.

"The Chinese leadership probably believes that if they hold out an olive branch at this turbulent moment, they will most likely be able to win the hearts of the Taiwan people, or at least soften pro-independence activists' aversion or hostility to China, " the official said, citing as proof the fact that the legislative caucus of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union reacted relatively mildly to the charter flight deal.

Those in diplomatic circles also lauded China's wisdom for its "extraordinary" timing in announcing the charter flight agreement. While international news media have been giving prominent coverage to Taiwan's political chaos, they have said Beijing could earn credit for its "willingness to contribute to cross-strait peace or concern for the Taiwan people's benefit" by putting aside its traditional distaste for taking any steps that could be seen as helping President Chen because it often reviles him as a radical proponent of Taiwan independence.

Moreover, local academics said the aviation deal serves China's long-term strategic interests of eventually uniting the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Once the door is open, they claimed, it could be an "irreversible trend" toward eventual unification.

On cross-strait charter flight issues, mainland policy planners said Taiwan would best benefit from the opening of regular cargo flight services, given the large number of Taiwan-funded companies in China. However, China would not budge an inch on this regard because it can hardly compete with Taiwan in this market with its far smaller air cargo fleet.

As to the opening of charter passenger flights on a regular basis or on weekends as strongly lobbied by China, policy-making officials said Taiwanese carriers have little interest unless the two sides come to terms on allowing ordinary Chinese residents to sightsee in Taiwan.

For years, Taiwan people have made more than 3 million visits to China annually while the annual number of visits to Taiwan by mainland Chinese have fallen short of 200,000. Until this huge imbalance is addressed, the officials said, Taiwanese carriers will not be able to profit from regular cross-strait charter passenger flight services.
