DOC.HEADLINE: PROFESSORS CALL FOR PRESIDENT TO GRACEFULLY STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: Fourteen university professors launched a signature-collecting campaign Sunday aimed at urging scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian to gracefully step down so as to avoid huge costs to society.
Professors Lee Ming and Kan Yi-hua of National Chengchi University called their signature drive the "Intellectuals' Campaign Urging Chen Shui-bian to Step Down."

As the president is no longer trusted by the people, he should demonstrate grace and step down, they said, adding that the initiators of the campaign will visit presidential advisers and ruling and opposition parties to express academia's views.

"The campaign is not aimed at protesting against the president. Rather, it aims to urge the president to make a wise decision because he should take the moral and political high ground for the first family's suspected involvement in different sorts of irregularities, " Lee said.
He stressed that "Taiwan is facing political deadlock and cannot handle another confrontation resulting from the 'pan-blue' and 'pan-green' standoff."
"President Chen should by no means try to worsen the standoff and cause the country's political and economic engine to rev in neutral," he added.

Lee quoted Lin Tse-hsu, a famous official during the Ching dynasty, to voice his and the other co-sponsors' feelings when they decided to kick off the campaign: "Were it to benefit the country, I would not care even about my life, much less would I try to evade my responsibility for the sake of personal fortune."

Kan said the campaign will try to solicit the support of college and middle and elementary school teachers in a bid to show that the country's intellectuals are expecting the president to "be responsible to the people by setting an example of gracefully stepping down."

To date, the president has not been able to give the people a reasonable explanation of his suspected abuses of constitutional powers, people's anger at high-level corruption scandals, and suspected involvement of his senior aides and son-in-law in insider trading and other criminal charges, Kan said.
Worse still, Kan added, the president has failed to engage in any soul searching over the spate of corruption and abuse-of-power charges.
"Since his integrity is being severely challenged and his political morality strongly suspected, he has confused Taiwan's value system and blocked Taiwan's chances to upgrade itself," he claimed.

Professor Sui Tu-ching of National Chengchi University said he joined the campaign knowing that he could be "given a political tag." Still, he said, "I have to point out that the president's attempts to distance himself and his wife from his senior aides and son-in-law have blurred the subject of the ethics debate."

"No one is demanding that the president take legal responsibility for the suspected involvement of his senior aides and close family members in a string of corruption scandals. But as president, he must take political responsibility," Sui said.
Other professors launching the campaign include Cheng Chung-chien of National Chengchi University, Chih Kai-chung of National Tsinghua University and Chu Ko-yi of National Chung Hsing University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAIRMAN ENDORSES KMT'S AD TO EXPLAIN REASONS BEHIND RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) ran an advertisement endorsed by the party's chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, in print media Sunday, explaining its reasons behind its decision to launch a recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian.

While speaking to reporters after attending a commencement ceremony at Shih Chien University, Ma stressed that the KMT must stand up and speak for the people at this critical time when the nation's leader has drifted away from the core values of "integrity, honesty and clean government."

Ma said that it is extremely important that prosecutors and investigators maintain their independence and neutrality during their investigation into corruption scandals surrounding Chen's close aids and family members.

Ma, who served as minister of justice 10 years ago in the previous KMT government, called on his old colleagues to stick to that stance, "because judicial dignity and fairness must take precedence of private partisan gain."

"The judicial system must firmly resist political pressure, fairly handle every case and get to bottom of every corruption scandal, " he argued, insisting that the KMT must not overlook mistakes made by high-level government officials and the first family and that this is the reason why the party wants to initiate the presidential recall motion at the Legislative Yuan.

"At this historic juncture, the KMT wants to recall Chen to help build a clean, honest, healthy and dignified life for younger generations, " Ma said, adding that "the KMT would let the people down if it failed to do so."

"If the KMT were to hold back from the presidential recall initiative out of fear of mob violence of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , how would we be able to teach our children to be straight, " Ma questioned, pointing out that "the answer is right on the minds of Taiwan parents."
Ma said that he was encouraging and demonstrating his respect to his former co-workers in the judicial sector.

"As long as prosecutors and investigators stand on the right side of justice, the people will throw their support behind them, our children will appreciate them, and they will be remembered in history," he said.
The KMT head also urged conscionable DPP lawmakers to back the presidential recall motion for Taiwan's younger generations, because "it is a major issue in Taiwan's constitutional history."
"The move to recall Chen is not aimed at provoking confrontation between the 'pan-blue alliance' and the 'pan-green camp, and it is by no means a political strife, " he reiterated.
"It is a choice between clean government and corruption, and a choice between the truth and lies," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADS S. KOREA IN GDP BY PURCHASING POWER: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's per capita gross domestic product (GDP) surpassed South Korea's by over US$6,000 in 2003 based on purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments, Taiwan's top economic planner said Sunday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said Taiwan's PPP-adjusted per capita GDP for 2003 was US$24,558, surpassing South Korea's US$17,900, indicating that Taiwanese people enjoyed a higher living standard than South Koreans.

Noting that major international economic institutions use PPP to measure a country's per capita GDP, Hu said the measure, which excludes inflation and currency fluctuation rates, more accurately gauges a country's per capita national income and general living standards.

Quoting statistics compiled by the Swiss International Institute of Management and Development, Hu said Taiwan's PPP-adjusted per capita GDP reached US$24,676 in 2004, ahead of South Korea's US$18,686.
Due to the "time lag" in compiling PPP-adjusted measures, no data is available to make a comparison for the year 2005, he said.

Hu acknowledged that South Korea is a respectable competitor judging from its robust economic development and brilliant trade performance. However, he said he disagrees with those academics who complain that Taiwan has lagged behind South Korea in economic growth in the last two years.

Chu Yun-peng, head of the National Central University's Taiwan Economic Development Research Center, said recently that "South Korea has emerged as the second largest source of Taiwan's trade deficit after Japan. I'm not surprised by its overtaking Taiwan in terms of per capita GDP in 2005. With South Korea's towering ambition, I think that country is likely to surpass Taiwan even in terms of PPP-adjusted per capita GDP in the near future."
Chu also said that Taiwan's government should not become complacent by accepting moderate growth and should map out a forward-looking economic development policy to accelerate growth.

According to recent statistics issued by the Bank of Korea, South Korea's economic growth rate was estimated at 4 percent for 2005, slightly lower than the 4.7 percent registered in 2004. Nevertheless, its per capita GDP reached US$16,291, marking an impressive 14.8 percent year-on-year increase.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's per capita GDP amounted to US$15,271 for 2005, up 7 percent from the previous year's level. By comparison, Taiwan went from leading South Korea by US$100 in per capita GDP in 2004 to trailing it by US$1,020 in 2005.

Hu attributed this mainly to the greater appreciation of the Korean won against the U.S. dollar, which rose 11.8 percent against the greenback while the new Taiwan dollar only rose 3.9 percent during the same period.

Hu said currency exchange rate changes have nothing to do with a country's competitiveness and only reflect international capital movements during a specific period. Therefore, he said, it might be too early to conclude that Taiwan has fallen behind South Korea.

"It is unfair to say that the government has failed in efforts to rev up Taiwan's economy simply because one set of figures show South Korea surpassing Taiwan in per capita GDP for one single year, " Hu argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER ONE THOUSAND PEOPLE PLANT SEEDLINGS IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Over 1,000 people from around the island gathered in Hsitou in the central county of Nantou Sunday to plant seedlings in a bid to "build up Taiwan's lungs."

The seedlings that the people -- many of them families with children -- planted included Formosan Michelia, Machilus thunbergii, Liquidambar formosana and Sapindus mukorossii Gaerm, all of which are endemic to Taiwan.

The seedlings are expected to grow into trees that will in turn help with water and soil conservation and provide the Taiwan people with more oxygen as well, said Wang Ya-nan, director of an experimental forest in Hsitou run by National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT 'LEAST QUALIFIED' TO LAUNCH RECALL MOTION: TSU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) accused the Kuomintang (KMT) Sunday of instigating political strife by launching a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian at the Legislative Yuan, warning the KMT "not to go too far."
TSU legislative caucus whip Ho Min-hao made the comments while answering questions from reporters in Taipei.

Ho termed the KMT "the most corrupt political party" and claimed that KMT Chairman Ma Jing-jeou is the "least qualified" to launch a presidential recall motion on the grounds that "the KMT has yet to return its ill-gotten assets to the people."
"The KMT should not go overboard with the recall motion and instead should shift its attention to issues related to the people's welfare," he suggested.

Pointing out that the TSU will go on promoting an endorsement campaign to force the KMT to return its property to the people, Ho said that his party hopes to collect over 82,000 signatures -- the legal threshold to call a referendum -- before an ongoing extra legislative session ends June 27.
"Even if the TSU is unable to collect the required number of signatures by that date, the party will continue with the campaign to demand that the KMT return its ill-gotten assets," he said.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party have also initiated a national endorsement campaign to display public backing for their presidential recall motion at the Legislative Yuan, which requires the support of two-thirds of all the legislators in a vote in order to be put to a referendum.

The motion has no chance of passing without significant support from "pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the TSU as the "pan-blue alliance" only holds 114 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MUST STEP OUT OF SCANDALS CLOUD TO WIN MUNICIPALITY ELECTIONSBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has nominated two strong candidates for the year-end mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung. But it must be able to portrait itself as a party of clean politics and competent leadership in order to beat opposition party rivals that are ready to focus the campaign debate on a string of corruption scandals in which President Chen Shui-bian's senior aides and close family members are being investigated for suspected involvement.

Analysts said Sunday that Frank Hsieh and Chen Chu, the DPP's mayoral candidates for Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively, have no reason to feel upbeat about their prospects in the December elections as the DPP's popularity has plunged to a new low following the detention of Chao Chien-ming, son-in-law of the president, and Chen Che-nan, his former senior aide at the Presidential Office, on suspicions of insider trading, fraud and other charges.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) have claimed that they will keep hounding former premier and Kaohsiung mayor Frank Hsieh for his suspected role in the Kaohisung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) scandal since three of the city government's department chiefs have been indicted in connection with the scandal.

Chen Chu, former chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs, is also suspected of making policy mistakes leading to the mismanagement of Thai workers whose riot in August last year brought to light a series of irregularities involving KRTC management and city government. Even Hsieh himself has advised Chen Chu not to run in Kaohsiung for that reason.

As Chen Che-nan, who has been in detention for over two months, and Chao Chien-ming and his family members are being investigated on a host of corruption charges, calls for the president to step down have grown louder each day and an opposition initiated motion for his recall is waiting to be handled at the Legislative Yuan, the nation's highest law-making body.

Analysts said that in addition to a joint effort by the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the DPP to clear people's doubts about the high-level corruption scandals, the party needs also to tell the public about the government's achievements over the past six years in order to win back the swing votes -- from voters that do not have a strong attachment to a political party but whose ballots usually decide which side wins in Taiwan elections.

In this regard, Chen Chu can boast of the DPP's achievement made by Hsieh and his successor, Acting Mayor Yeh Chu-lan, and Hsieh can cite the impressive performance of Chen Shui-bian, the first DPP mayor of Taipei.

Another advantage of the two DPP candidates is that their campaign pledges will win the endorsement of the Executive Yuan and the DPP, who have the power and resources to boost their respective campaigns.

For example, the opening of the Hsueshan Tunnel on the Taipei-Ilan freeway in mid-June and the scheduled launch in late October of the high-speed railway linking Taipei and Kaohsiung can be seen as pluses in the DPP government's administrative record.

A third possible advantage for Hsieh would be a decision by PFP Chairman James Soong to run for Taipei mayor while KMT nominee Hau Lung-bin refused to budge, creating a three-way race with the "pan-blue" vote being split and the "pan-green camp's" chances therefore being boosted. A similar situation occurred in the 1994 Taipei mayoral elections, when DPP's Chen Shui-bian beat KMT's Huang Ta-chou and New Party's Jaw Shau-kong.

Analysts said that if Soong, who has yet to announce his bid, were to win 10 percent of the vote, Hsieh's chances of beating Hau would "dramatically increase." However, KMT strategists claimed that "pan-blue supporters" in Taiwan's capital would not be so forgetful as to repeat the 1994 debacle.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' HOLDS RALLY TO CALL FOR PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" organized a demonstration Sunday in Changhua City in central Taiwan, calling for President Chen Shui-bian to step down amid the many corruption scandals in which his family members and close aides are alleged to have been involved.

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, along with Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, led a crowd of about 10,000 people to ask for Chen's resignation in a downtown market.

Ma said that the "pan-blue" efforts to get Chen to step down are aimed at building a dignified life for Taiwan's younger generations, arguing that a head of state that has lost the people's respect and trust should voluntarily resign.

Soong said that the Taiwan people will no longer tolerate the corrupt Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government and that the PFP will seek to topple the Cabinet should the "pan-blue alliance's" recall motion fail to pass during the current extra legislative session which is scheduled to end June 30.
The "pan-blue" demonstration in Changhua City will be followed by two similar rallies -- one in northern Taiwan and one in southern Taiwan -- in the coming weeks.

On the sidelines of the Changhua demonstration, the two parties set up a service center to collect signatures in a nationwide campaign as a means of displaying their support for the "pan-blue" lawmakers' presidential recall motion at the legislature.

Meanwhile, the KMT's Kaohsiung county branch has collected more than 27,000 signatures over the past two days. KMT officials urged the public to join the campaign to demonstrate their anger with the corrupt DPP government.
The KMT's campaign has been endorsed by some 500,000 people across Taiwan so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUNSHINE CAN BE USED TO TREAT ACUTE LIVER FAILURE: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Believe it or not, those suffering from acute liver failure can be treated by simply watching the sun at sunset and sunrise, an expert on Chinese medicine said here Sunday.

Pan Nien-chung, a former professor of naturopathy at the China Medical University in Taichung, told a seminar on Chinese medicine in Taipei that the sun's rays at sunrise and sunset -- with a wave length of between 3,000 Lux and 9,000 Lux--- can stimulate the mitochondrion in the human body to generate an energy which will improve the function of the liver and help it to heal itself.

He suggested that patients suffering from acute liver failure, also known as fulminant liver failure, gaze at the sun's red rays for fifteen to thirty minutes every day. Pan cited the example of a university student who suffered from hepatic encephalopathy because of acute liver failure. Doctors treated him with artificial light over a one-month period and put him on a balanced diet.
One month into the treatment, Pan said, the patient's liver was restored to normal functioning levels.

Dr. Hsu Chin-chuan, executive director of the non-profit Liver Disease Prevention & Treatment Research Foundation was reserved about the theory, saying he couldn't comment on it before reading Pan's report thoroughly.
Acute liver failure is a rare but potentially fatal disease. The mortality rate without supportive management and/or liver transplantation is in excess of 70%.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75-YEAR-OLD GRADUATES FROM SHIH CHIEN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Grey-haired Weng Fu-chu was conspicuous among Shih Chien University's 3,600 graduating students at the school's commencement ceremony Sunday: At 75 years of age, he was the oldest student ever awarded a master's degree by the Ministry of Education.
Weng retired from former Taiwan provincial government more than 20 years ago, but he refused to be a liability of society. Rather, he said senior citizens should be an asset of society.
Starting four years ago, Weng commuted between Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan where he lives to Taipei to attend classes weekly. He has never missed a class.
Now, with a M.A. degree in family study and child development, and as the oldest student ever awarded a master's degree in Taiwan, Weng has proved himself "an old man with dignity."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Former Antiterror Officials Find Industry Pays Better
Dozens of members of the Bush administration's domestic security team, assembled after the 2001 terrorist attacks, are now collecting bigger paychecks in different roles: working on behalf of companies that sell domestic security products, many directly to the federal agencies the officials once helped run. At least 90 officials at the Department of Homeland Security or the White House Office of Homeland Security -- including the department's former secretary, Tom Ridge; the former deputy secretary, Adm. James M. Loy; and the former under secretary, Asa Hutchinson -- are executives, consultants or lobbyists for companies that collectively do billions of dollars' worth of domestic security business. More than two-thirds of the department's most senior executives in its first years have moved through the revolving door. Federal law prohibits senior executive branch officials from lobbying former government colleagues or subordinates for at least a year after leaving public service. But by exploiting loopholes in the law -- including one provision drawn up by department executives to facilitate their entry into the business world -- it is often easy for former officials to do just that.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN SOCIETY' FOUNDED

TEXT.P: Three pro-independence civil groups has incorporated themselves with several like-minded overseas groups into a new umbrella organization called "Taiwan Society" Sunday.

Wu Shu-min, president of the group said former President Lee Teng-hui has agreed to serve as the honorary head of the Taiwan Society which consists of Taiwan Society North, Taiwan Society South, Taiwan Society East and several Taiwanese groups in Japan and the United States.

Wu who used to be the chief of the Taiwan Society North said the members of the new group are mainly academics, physicians and intelligentsia, and they will devote to shaping the public opinion on Taiwan-related issues.

In order to unite all Taiwanese around the world in promoting Taiwan's interest, Wu said his group will keep a distance from local political parties and will have its won opinion about what makes a desirable candidate in 2008 presidential election.
The Taiwan Society will distinguish itself from another pro-independence group, the Defense of Taiwan Union which is headed by Lee Teng-hui too, by promoting Taiwan's culture and identify, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOW PRESIDENT WILL RESPOND TO RECALL MOTION TO BE KNOWN SOON

TEXT.P: How President Chen Shui-bian will respond to the opposition-initiated recall motion at the legislature could be made known soon, Presidential Office sources said Sunday.

The president is likely to "report directly to the people" instead of issuing a statement to the Legislative Yuan in answer to opposition charges as listed in the legislative motion, according to the sources.

The report could be made by means of a televised speech, a news conference, or a recorded speech broadcast by the media, according to the sources, who excluded the option of the president addressing the "pan-green camp" crowd who are scheduled to participate in anti-recall rallies in Taipei on June 24, June 25 and June 27.
The Presidential Office is likely to make known to the media how and when he will respond to the unprecedented legislative motion Monday or Tuesday, according to the sources.
The president has hinted that he will tell the people how difficult it has been for the Democratic Progressive Party government to govern this country over the past six years and its achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: 300,000 PEOPLE IN TAIWAN OFFER TO DONATE SPINAL CORD

TEXT.P: More than 300,000 people have registered with the private charity, Tzu Chi Foundation, to donate their spinal marrow for transplants, an official of the foundation said in Luchou, Taipei County Sunday.

Chen Nai-yu who seeks possible spinal cord donators for the foundation said the 300,000th would-be donator, a female nurse, had signed a statement in Luchou Sunday morning, promising to offer her spinal marrow for transplants when needed.
The nurse is one of 120 people who wrote down their names on a written promise and had their blood drawn for tests for this purpose Sunday morning in that northern Taiwan rural township, Chen said.

Spinal marrow transplant is an effective way to cure certain blood diseases, including leukemia. However, it takes time to seek donors whose spinal marrow will not be rejected by the would-be recipients.
The Tzu Chi Foundation has begun a program in 1997 to collect information of people who are willing to donate their spinal marrow and kept these information at its Stem Cells Center in Hualien.
The center which is touted to be the world's third largest data bank of its kind have successfully matched 1,100 pair of donors and recipients from 23 countries ever since its was founded.

TEXT.P: A fire alarm sounded at the Chunghsiao Fuhsin Station of Taipei's mass rapid transit system Monday, with a preliminary report saying that it was triggered by smoke from an escalator.

All passengers were evacuated when the alarm sounded, and no damage was reported, the TRTC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI BADMINTON OPEN TO KICK OFF TUESDAY

TEXT.P: The Yonex 2006 Chinese Taipei Badminton Open is scheduled to kick off Tuesday in Taipei, with more than 200 ace players from 20 countries and the host Taiwan participating.

The world men's singles champion, Lin Dan, and women's singles champion, Zhang Ning, both from China, are expected to take part in the open slated for June 20-25, according to the Chinese Taipei Badminton Association (CTBA).
Nine of the world's top ten women's singles players and five of the world's top ten men's singles players have registered to compete in the tournament which has prize money totaling US$170,000.
Among the ace women players expected to take part in the open are three Olympic gold medalists, two silver medalists and two bronze medal winners, CTBA officials said.
The winner of the 2006 Chinese Taipei Open men's singles title will receive US$13,600, while the women's singles winner will receive US$11,730, CTBA officials said.
Qualifying and preliminary rounds of the open are scheduled for June 20-22, while the quarterfinal, semifinal and championship matches are slated for June 23-25, the officials said.

The tournament will feature players from Austria, Bulgaria, Canada, China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, the Netherlands, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, the U.K., The Untied States, Vitetnam and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN SOCIETY' FOUNDED(repeat)

TEXT.P: Three pro-independence civil groups have combined themselves with several like-minded overseas groups in forming a new umbrella organization called "Taiwan Society" Sunday.

Wu Shu-min, president of the group said former President Lee Teng-hui has agreed to serve as the honorary head of the Taiwan Society which consists of the Taiwan Society North, Taiwan Society South, Taiwan Society East, and several Taiwanese groups in Japan and the United States.

Wu, who used to be the chief of the Taiwan Society North, said the members of the new group are mainly academics, physicians and members of the intelligentsia, and they will devote themselves to shaping public opinion on Taiwan-related issues.

In order to unite all Taiwanese around the world in promoting Taiwan's interests, Wu said his group will keep its distance from local political parties and will voice its won opinions about what makes a desirable candidate in the 2008 presidential election.
The Taiwan Society will distinguish itself from another pro-independence group, the Defense of Taiwan Union, which is also headed by Lee Teng-hui, by promoting Taiwan's culture and identify, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 300,000 PEOPLE IN TAIWAN OFFER TO DONATE BONE MARROW(repeat)

TEXT.P: More than 300,000 people have registered with the private charity Tzu Chi Foundation to donate bone marrow from their spinal chord for transplants, an official of the foundation said in Luchou, Taipei County Sunday.

Chen Nai-yu, who seeks possible bone marrow donors for the foundation, said the 300,000th would-be donor, a female nurse, signed a statement in Luchou Sunday morning promising to donate bone marrow if needed.
The nurse was one of 120 people who did so and had their blood drawn for tests for this purpose Sunday morning in the northern Taiwan rural township, Chen said.

The Tzu Chi Foundation began a program in 1997 to collect information on people willing to make bone marrow donations. The foundation has kept this information at its Stem Cell Center in Hualien. The center, which is touted as the world's third largest data bank of its kind, has successfully matched 1,100 donors and recipients from 23 countries since the program was founded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA FOUNDATION TO LAUNCH 4TH STUDENT AMBASSADOR PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Thirty students from across America and Taiwan will participate in a two-week intensive congressional program that focuses on deepening each participant's knowledge of international relations with an emphasis on U.S.-Taiwan relations.
The Formosa Foundation announced Sunday that the fourth annual student Ambassador Program will begin June 18 in Los Angeles, Calif., and conclude June 30 in Washinton, D.C.

The Ambassador Program provides a rare opportunity to meet with U.S. congressmen and senators to discuss U.S. policies toward Taiwan, according to Terri Giles, executive director of the Formosa Foundation.

"This is the only program of its kind in the country. Our focus on devising strategies in support of Taiwan and speaking directly to members of Congress gives our students a direct understanding of the challenges that we face," Giles said.

Beginning June 18, the participants will undergo training in Los Angeles with a series of workshops, seminars, and hands-on training in the art of advocacy. Each session is designed to enhance the students' knowledge of current U.S.-Taiwan policy and sharpen their communication and networking skills.

On June 23rd, the participants travel to the U.S. capital to meet directly with members of Congress to discuss several issues of concern to Taiwan, including the island's bid to join the WHO, Washington's one-China policy, high-level diplomatic visits between the two countries, and a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement.

The Formosa Foundation's Ambassador Program was first launched in 2003 with the goal of broadening the involvement of future leaders in understanding and influencing U.S.foreign policy. Over the past three years, 70 students have taken part in the program and have held more than 400 meetings with members of Congress and their staff.

Based in Los Angeles, the Formosa Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting greater understanding of the relationship between Taiwan and the United States and preserving and enhancing democracy, human rights and freedom for the people of Taiwan. By Lu-Sheng Chu

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PUSH FOR NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE AGAINST CABINET IF RECALL FAILS

TEXT.P: If the opposition's move to oust President Chen Shui-bian fails, the Kuomintang (KMT) will unite with other parties to push for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet, a KMT spokeswoman said Monday.

Cheng Li-wen made the remarks as the Legislative Yuan is set to vote June 27 on a recall motion initiated by the opposition. The motion requires the support of two-thirds of all legislators in order to be put to a referendum. As the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) only holds a slim majority in the 221-seat Legislature, the motion has no chance of success unless a significant number of "pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union give their support.
The opposition initiated the recall motion June 12, believing President Chen's leadership is in doubt after his son-in-law and close associates were implicated in a series of corruption allegations.
Cheng said that a KMT think tank, a policy commission and the KMT legislative caucus have formed a task force to study the issue of toppling the Cabinet.
The main opposition party will also work with its allies, the PFP and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, to coordinate the move to topple the Cabinet, she said.

Commenting on reports that the KMT is considering mobilizing 1 million people to take part in a rally in front of the Presidential Office to call for the president to step down, Cheng said that this is unlikely but that the party will not rule out any possibility.
"The KMT is prepared to engaged in long-term efforts to oust the president," Cheng said, adding that "the process will be moderate and rational so as to cut social costs to the minimum."
She cited the example of the Watergate scandal as an example, saying that former U.S. President Richard Nixon only resigned in 1974, or two years after the Watergate scandal first came to light.

The KMT will build up the pressure through a recall vote and a no-confidence vote and throw its weight behind the prosecutors in their probe into the corruption scandals, Cheng said. "We've had no such means to bring down President Chen in one move," she stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO BID TO HOST 2020 OLYMPICS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The government has never ceased trying to win for Taipei the right to host the 2020 Olympic Games and will take gradual steps to reach the goal, National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) Vice Minister Chen Yu-hsin said Monday.

Chen reiterated the government's determination after former Premier Frank Hsieh -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate for Taipei mayor -- announced Sunday that winning for the capital city the right to host the 2020 Olympics is one of his key campaign promises.

Chen said that Hsieh proposed the Olympic bid for Taipei during his service as premier between January 2005 and January 2006. Since then, the NCPFS has been working to map out plans to achieve the "ultimate goal," he noted, adding that at the current stage, efforts are being made to seek for the right to host single-event international sports games, as well as the Asian Games and World Games.

Taipei will host the 21st Deaflympic Games in 2009, the same year that will see Kaohsiung host the World Games, Chen mentioned, suggesting that these are opportunities for Taiwan to show its ability to host major sporting events to make its case for its bid to host the 2020 Olympics.

During a hiking activity in suburban Taipei, Hsieh, who had secured the right for Kaohsiung to host the 2009 World Games when he was the mayor of the southern port city, reiterated his determination to win the right for Taipei to host the Olympics.
With the host city of the 2020 Olympics to be selected in 2013, the candidate to run in the year-end Taipei mayor election said that Taipei should not be absent from the bidding.
