DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MRT STATION ALARM TRIGGERED BY SMOKE FROM DEFECTIVE ESCALATOR

TEXT.P: A fire alarm sounded at the Zhongxiao Fuxing Station of Taipei's mass rapid transit system Monday morning, reportedly due to heavy smoke from a defective escalator.
No injuries were reported in the incident.
According to the Taipei Rapid Transit Corporation (TRTC) , all passengers were evacuated when the alarm, part of the station's smoke-detection system, sounded at 9: 23 a.m.
Service at the station was temporarily halted and was resumed at 10:02 a.m.
According to a preliminary report, the smoke was caused by overheated lubrication oil.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT HEARS EX-NAVY OFFICER'S SLANDER SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The daughter of Lei Hsueh-ming, a retired navy officer, said Monday that Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung was adopting a delaying tactic by requesting the court to summon former Chief of the General Staff Hau Pei-tsun in a case in which Lei has accused Hsu and President Chen Shui-bian of slander.
Lei Chien, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker, is attempting to clear her father's name and claimed that Hsu's request has nothing to do with the case.

Also being sued is William Lai, another DPP legislator, who along with Hsu and the president, claim that Lei and other members of the navy's frigate procurement group took a bribe of US$20 million in connection with the purchase of Lafayette frigates from France.
Hsu said Hau should appear in court to explain why he "suddenly" changed his mind about buying Korean Ulsan-class frigates and decided upon the French frigates instead.
Hau's deputy at the time, Hsia Tien, and Kuo Yun, a former chief of Taiwan's military procurement mission in the United States, should also face the court, he added.

Lei Chien said Hsu had threatened to present a list of "bribe takers" to the court when it holds a hearing on the case, but claimed that what he put forth was a list of "irrelevant names" that he argued should be investigated -- which Lei Chien claimed was a delay tactic.
Lei Hsueh-ming filed the lawsuit in December 2005, accusing the president and the two DPP lawmakers of defaming him and demanding compensation of NT$2.11 billion (US$64.8 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PEOPLE ENVY TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY: JAPANESE DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 19 (CNA) (By Yang Ming-chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The recent detention of President Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law in Taiwan has caused a ripple in mainland Chinese society, with many voices there expressing "envy" of Taiwan's democracy, a Japanese daily reported Monday.

An article carried in Monday's Sankei Shimbun said Beijing's mouthpieces, the People's Daily News and the Xinhua News Agency, had reported the detention of Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, on suspicion of insider stock trading, with the aim of letting the Chinese people know how "corrupt" Taiwan society is.

However, the People's Daily and Xinhua reports had the opposite effect. Many Chinese readers said they were "impressed" with the "true democracy" that they saw in reading about Chao's detention and about the recall motion initiated by opposition legislators to recall President Chen, the Sankei Shimbun reported.
Many messages about Taiwan's "enviable" democracy and China's "true decay" appeared on Chinese chat rooms on the Internet in the days after the reports.
One Chinese citizen wrote that "in China, even the son-in-law of a village leader would not be arrested if he were to commit the same crime as Chao did."
"None of the children of high-ranking officials have been detained for insider trading or other kinds of corruption," he wrote.

The Sankei Shimbun report also said that Beijing University had originally planned to invite Legislator Chiu Yi from Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang, who initially made the allegations about Chao's insider trading, to visit the prestigious university to give a speech to "help ignite an anti-corruption fire in China."
Chinese authorities, however, later decided not to allow Chiu to visit for fear that such a speech would have an "undesirable" impact on Chinese society, the Sankei Shimbun reported.

In response, Chiu, who continues to appear on TV talk shows in Taiwan to make allegations against members of the first family, noted that he doesn't think that President Chen would use his power to deprive him of his freedom of speech.
Chiu's remarks have been spread online by Chinese Internet surfers, the Sankei Shimbun reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 7.27 points to close at 6,583.04.
The bourse opened at 6,576.55 and fluctuated between 6,603.98 and 6,541.33 during trading. A total of 3.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.11 billion (US$2.46 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 5.2 percent, followed by construction issues at 2.5 percent, cement stocks at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.8 percent, textile stocks at 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent.
The one other major stock category lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 469 to 362, with 92 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LEGISLATIVE ELECTION WILL FOLLOW NEW ELECTORAL SYSTEM: CEC

TEXT.P: If the present Legislative Yuan is dissolved, a new legislative election will have to be conducted under the new electoral system, Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Monday.
Chang made the remarks while fielding questions at the Home Affairs Committee in the legislature, which is reviewing a draft re-districting scheme submitted by the CEC.

The opposition has threatened that if an initiative to recall President Chen Shui-bian fails, it will follow with a push for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet in September when the new legislative session opens.

The opposition is seeking a two-pronged approach -- ousting the president and toppling the Cabinet -- in an attempt to build up pressure on Chen, believing his leadership is in doubt in the wake of a series of corruption allegations against his son-in-law and close associates.

Chang said that if Chen dissolves the legislature, then the draft re-districting scheme will no longer be needed to be approved by the legislature and the CEC's draft scheme will then be followed, he said.
The new legislature would be the seventh legislature, he added.
But Legislator Chang Hsien-yao of the opposition People First Party said a re-election should be held after a legislature is dissolved, and the term of the legislators begun from scratch.
The time between the dissolution of a legislature and the forming of a new one should be deemed a legislative recess, according to additional constitutional provisions, he said.

Quoting Constitutional Interpretation No. 31 by the Council of Grand Justices, Chang Hsien-yao also argued that the new legislature would still be counted as the sixth, instead of the seventh legislature.

Under a package of constitutional amendment that was adopted last June, the 7th legislative election to be held in late 2007 will be conducted under the new electoral system of "single constituency, two votes" under a re-districting scheme and the halving of the number of 225-seat legislature to 113.
The newly elected legislators will be sworn in for four-year terms instead of the current three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Scandal of Vittorio Emanuele spreading.
The scandal of Vittorio Emanuele, a former prince and a grandson of late Italian King Vittorio Emanuele III who was arrested last week in Potenza, southern Italy with charges of corruption, prostitution and organization crime, has put the right-wing opposition National Alliance party and the state-run television network RAI in a storm of criticism.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALLING PRESIDENT `NATIONAL CONSENSUS': KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and KMT-affiliated city mayors and county magistrates issued a pledge Monday demanding that President Chen Shui-bian quickly step down so that a "clean Taiwan" can be built.

KMT-affiliated speakers from city and county councils around Taiwan are also slated to issue a statement June 21, supporting the KMT-proposed nationwide endorsement campaign and a recall motion at the Legislative Yuan to boot out Chen from the presidency to take responsibility for a spate of corruption scandals allegedly involving his family members and close aides.

Ma claimed that recalling Chen is "not just the KMT stance but a national activity driven by grassroots members of society" for the sake of Taiwan's younger generation, as over 70 percent of Taiwan's territory and population is governed by KMT mayors and magistrates. Ma said that he fully appreciated the support of KMT local government chiefs for the presidential recall campaign.
The national endorsement campaign to express public anger with a corrupt government has so far collected more than 700,000 signatures, and the number is expected to exceed 1 million, Ma said.

The KMT chairman also accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of "immorally" resorting to what he called "ethnic confrontation" to counter the presidential recall motion, claiming that the DPP lacks the guts to take on responsibility.

Unlike a head of state that can serve as many as eight years in two tenures, a political party must engage in sustainable growth, he said, warning that the DPP should not bet its future on a president he described as "suspiciously unclean."
The KMT's presidential recall motion is "not aimed at instigating political strife" but is a move in line with the principles of accountability in politics, he claimed.

Ma called on the DPP to rethink its core values of "a clean government and loving the motherland and the people" that it broached in the past before the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" partner, the People First Party (PFP) , call a vote on the presidential recall motion June 27 at the Legislative Yuan before the ongoing extra session ends June 30.
Should the DPP fail to honor its promises to the people, its support base will be seriously hindered, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEGISLATORS TO DEMAND PRESIDENT DEFEND HIMSELF

TEXT.P: At least 50 opposition legislators will go to the Presidential Office Tuesday to demand that President Chen Shui-bian defend himself in writing before June 20, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus decided in a caucus meeting Monday.

The legislature referred a motion to recall the president to the Committee of the Whole for review June 13, and the president has the option of defending himself in an official statement within one week prior to the review.

Whether or not the president chooses to exercise this option, the committee is scheduled to meet June 21-23 and June 26 to review the motion before it will be put to a vote during a plenary session June 27.
The KMT has decided to pass a screening agenda in a vote June 21, lest the four-day review turn into a free-for-all.

KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po said the party think tank has prepared relevant information and has invited those related to financial reforms to the review meeting, so as to highlight the legitimacy of the recall motion.
Although financial reforms is one of the goals set by the president, the opposition has criticized them as favoring special conglomerates.

Chen has so far ignored the opposition demands that he defend himself in writing to the opposition-dominated legislature for the spate of corruption allegations involving members of his family and close aides that the opposition thinks puts his leadership in doubt.
The opposition claimed that if the president does not defend himself -- which he is under no obligation to do -- "it is tantamount to admitting his wrongdoing."

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN INVENTOR HIRED BY TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE AS PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: A prize-winning veteran inventor was hired as an untenured professor by the Nan Kai Institute of Technology (NKIT) Monday.

NKIT broke the law to engage Teng Hung-chi -- a five-time gold medalist in the International Exhibition of Inventions and a winner of the highest citation of the Nuremberg International Invention Exhibition, the Genius Achievement Award -- on the grounds that winning gold medals in these two major invention expositions is "tantamount to winning Olympic gold, " said NKIT President Wang Kuo-ming.

Wang said his institute decided to hire Teng after convening a series of meetings and conducting several assessment meetings with former Minister of Education Wu Jing and Hsueh Wen-chen, director of the Creativity Center of the Industrial Technology Research Institute, qualifying Teng to become an untenured professor even though he lacks a doctoral degree, which is required by law.

Speaking upon receiving an employment document from NKIT, Teng said he hopes that his 25 years of experience as an inventor could serve as some kind of inspiration to young people who are also interested in the field.

Teng, a holder of two master's degrees, said he invented his first innovative gear at the age of 17 -- an infrared-controlled toilet faucet -- after deciding that flushing the toilet was "too complicated and effort-consuming."
That inspired him to continue his career as an inventor for 25 years, he noted.
Teng is the holder of patent rights for over 200 high technology products.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND FAVORABLE FOR TAIWANESE INVESTMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Swaziland is a suitable place for Taiwanese investment because it has stable social order and an agreement with the United States allows Swazi manufacturers to ship goods there without quota restrictions and tariffs.

The president made the statement at a presentation on Swaziland's investment climate and trade opportunities designed to attract Taiwan investment in the African country. Visiting Swazi King Mswati III was present at the presentation.
Chen pointed out that most goods produced in Swaziland enjoy zero-tariff privileges when shipped to the United States because both countries signed the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA).
He added that since 2000, 22 Taiwanese companies have invested over US$60 million in setting up factories in Swaziland, providing more than 14,000 jobs.
Chen also described Swaziland as the "African Switzerland" because of its stable social order.
Taiwan and Swaziland have enjoyed diplomatic relations for 38 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER REBUKES KMT HEAD FOR `MISUSING' RIGHT TO RECALL PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chang Chung-hsiung rebuked Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Monday for creating a "bad example" in the implementation of the Constitution by pushing at the legislature for a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
The former premier made the statement at a news conference that he called at the Legislative Yuan, in which he urged the legislature to be "cautious" in using its right to recall the president.

Chang claimed it is hard to find a similar case in other countries to the one in Taiwan and expressed his belief that a misuse of the right to recall the president at the legislature will cost the country in terms of constitutional chaos and political unrest. He also suggested that the legislators take what historic cases exist as references.

Citing a landslide vote in 1954 of the National Assembly to recall then-Vice President Lee Chung-jen, Chang said that Lee was unseated because of his alleged involvement in several unlawful deeds including embezzlement and long stay in the United States.

In the U.S., the impeachments of Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton during their presidential tenures were also formed based on "concrete evidence" that showed their illegal conduct, Chang said, claiming that it is "not possible for Ma" -- who holds a doctorate in law from Harvard and has served as minister of justice -- not to know the conditions for initiating an impeachment of the head of state, which is that the person has to have been proved to have done something illegal.
The opposition initiated the motion to recall Chen in mid-May after the judicial authorities began investigating corruption allegations involving his son-in-law and close aides.
There is no evidence as yet to show Chen is in any way involved in the allegations.
Urging the KMT chairman to think carefully before putting forward the move to unseat Chen, Chang warned that the case will serve as a bad model in the country's constitutional history.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES REPORTS ON DEAL FOR PRESIDENT'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The head of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) denied Monday that his party has proposed a quid pro quo deal for President Chen Shui-bian to step down over the series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who also serves as Taipei mayor, told reporters that there is no truth in reports that the KMT expects Vice President Annette Lu to pledge either in public or in private that if Chen agrees to resign, allowing her to succeed as president, she will grant amnesty to Chen over the scandals that might implicate him.

The KMT and its ally, the People First Party, have launched a campaign to recall the president after he ignored their demand that he resign. Chen's senior aides and family members are engulfed in a series of corruption scandals, with his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, still in custody and likely to face charges over six corruption cases. Chen himself has not been implicated in any wrongdoing.

Ma also categorically denied a rumor that if the plan to recall the president fails he will quit his post as Taipei mayor and lead the people to continue the campaign to depose Chen by taking the issue to the streets.

Asked why he placed an advertisement in newspapers Sunday, urging public prosecutors to be impartial in probing the corruption scandals, Ma explained that he was speaking as a former colleague to the prosecutors, urging them to resist political pressure from high-level officials that might attempt to influence the investigation.
He said he placed the ad because the prosecution's progress on those cases has not met the expectations of the public.
Ma said the public prosecutors and investigators should not be biased for or against those involved in the corruption cases, but should be impartial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TINIEST GOLDEN WIRE ON DISPLAY IN GOLD PARK

TEXT.P: The tiniest gold wire -- about one-fourth the diameter of a human hair -- will be put on display June 23 in the Museum of Gold in Taipei County's Jinguashi, in Ruifang township, when the former gold-mining village begins its annual gold festival.

Chu Hui-liang, director of the Cultural Bureau under the Taipei county government, which sponsors the festival, said the gold wire, on loan from an American scientific research institute, has a diameter of 0.0125 mm, making it the thinnest thread that gold can be made into because of its physical characteristics.
With this diameter, one gram of gold could be made into a thread more than 100 meters in length, Chub said.

Another exhibit in the museum that underlines the metal's amazing malleability is a piece of gold paper, also borrowed from the same American research institute, with a thickness of one-thousandth of a millimeter, or one-hundredth the thickness of a piece of copy paper. In addition to the gold thread and paper, Chu said the museum also boasts the world largest gold ingot, weighing 220 kg.

The museum is the centerpiece of the Gold Ecological Park in Jinguashi, which is built in the compound of a now-defunct mining company that owned several gold mines in the mountain village. The village fell into disrepair when the gold was exhausted, but has enjoyed rejuvenation with the increase in tourism.
The, festival, which will also feature outdoor concerts and a sculpture exhibition, will last until Sept. 10. It is part of the county government's efforts to turn Jinguashi into a resort.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.118 to close at NT$32.598.
A total of US$760 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.580 and fluctuated between NT$32.350 and NT$32.642.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Illegal Hiring Is Rarely Penalized; Politics, 9/11 Cited in Lax Enforcement.
The Bush administration, which is vowing to crack down on U.S. companies that hire illegal workers, virtually abandoned such employer sanctions before it began pushing to overhaul U.S. immigration laws last year, government statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down five points to close at 6,575, with 28,420 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July decreased seven points to finish at 6,523, with 7,982 contracts traded, while September futures gained 11 points to end at 6,421, with 194 contract transactions. December futures decreased two points to close at 6,402, with 14 contracts traded, while March futures moved down 18 points to finish at 6,401, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,580 for June, 6,530 for July, 6,410 for September, 6,404 for December and 6,419 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

June TE futures decreased 1.75 points to close at 271.35, with 4,283 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost three points to finish at 268.8, with 2,342 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 0.9 points to end at 268, with 11 contracts traded, while March TE futures decreased 1.35 points to close at 265, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.

June TF futures increased 3.4 points to close at 982.2, with 3,560 contracts traded, while July TF futures gained 3.6 points to close at 977.6, with 2,290 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up six points to end at 965.6, with two contract transactions and March TF futures increased 13.4 points to close at 969.4, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT RE-DISTRICTING SCHEME PASSES FIRST REVIEW WITH RESERVATIONS

TEXT.P: A legislative committee passed a draft re-districting plan submitted by the Central Election Commission (CEC) Monday, but expressed reservations about the re-drawing of constituencies for Taichung city and six counties.

The Home Affairs Committee started to review the re-districting scheme Monday and legislators from across the party spectrum agreed to the re-districting plan for eight cities and counties -- Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, Nantou County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, Tainan County, Tainan City and Kaohsiung County -- as well as 10 cities and counties that will only have one lawmaker ro represent them.
But they failed to see eye to eye to Taichung city and six counties -- Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Miaoli County, Taichung County, Taichung City, Changhwa County and Pingtung County.

Legislators from across the party spectrum submitted their views on the re-districting of the seven cities and counties and handed them to the legislative caucuses for coordination before the draft re-districting scheme is handed to the plenary session for discussion.
The committee also passed a resolution demanding that the CEC form a task force as soon as possible to deal with the possible dissolution of the present legislature.

The opposition has decided to take a two-pronged approach -- a recall of President Chen Shui-bian and a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet -- to build up pressure on the president, believing that his leadership is in doubt in the wake of a string of corruption allegation against his son-in-law and his close associates.
But if the president dissolves the legislature after a no-confidence vote, then the new legislative election will have to be conducted under the new electoral system, the CEC stated recently.

The CEC also said that if the president dissolves the legislature and the draft re-districting scheme has not been approved by the legislature, the new election still has to follow the new electoral system.
But the legislative committee decided that the matter needs to be further discussed, that the CEC has no right to interpret the Constitution and that the CEC must retract its statement.

According to a package of constitutional amendments passed last June, starting from the seventh legislature to be elected in late 2007, the Legislative Yuan will have only 113 seats and will be elected every four years. While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

The regional seats will be distributed among special municipalities, counties and cities according to their populations, with each locality enjoying at least one seat and one legislator elected from each district. The at-large and overseas expatriate seats will be allocated to political parties that win at least 5 percent of the votes, according to the proportion of votes they garner, with each party required to reserve at least 50 percent of the seats for women.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: North Koreans Are Reported Closer to a Missile Test
North Korea appears to have completed fueling a long-range ballistic missile, American officials said Sunday, a move that greatly increases the probability that it will go ahead with its first important test launching in eight years. A senior American official said that intelligence from satellite photographs suggested that booster rockets had been loaded onto a launching pad, and liquid-fuel tanks fitted to a missile at a site on North Korea's remote east coast.
Wall Street Journal: Identity Crisis, At a U.S. Mosque, Path of Tolerance Leads to Tumult
Souleiman Ghali grew up as a Palestinian refugee in war-torn Lebanon. In 1993, Ghali, who owned a deli at the time, pushed the Islamic Society of San Francisco to have a mosque to shape an "American Muslim identity" of tolerance and respect for other faiths. But the future of his effort is now threatened by a voice from within. His mosque was hauled into court this spring by a fiery imam whom it fired in 2002, claiming he preached extremism. The cleric's wrongful-discharge lawsuit has splintered San Francisco's Muslim community, as rival groups, and ideologies, vie for worshipers' support.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LACKS RESPECT FOR CONSTITUTION: OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: It would be a "lack of respect for the Constitution" on the part of President Chen Shui-bian if he chooses not to file a defense statement at the legislature in response to the opposition's recall motion over a spate of corruption allegations implicating his family members and close aides, the opposition People First Party (PFP) claimed Monday.

PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping made the remarks after a newspaper reported in recent days that Chen may opt to make a report about the allegations on TV instead of filing a statement to defend himself at the Legislative Yuan as the opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers require before they call a vote in the legislature to recall him.
A defense statement from Chen given to the Legislative Yuan would fall in line with the country's constitutional system and help make it become "standard practice," he claimed.

Should Chen exercise his choice to skip a report at the Legislative Yuan, it would "reflect his intention" to shun the legislature's surveillance and highlight his lack of respect for the Constitution, according to Hsieh.

Hsieh accused Chen and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of resorting to ethnic disputes as a means of maintaining power -- something for which he claimed the Taiwan people will have to pay a huge price.

Hsieh expressed disappointment with the DPP for its failure to get rid of Chen's "dragging" and questioned how the DPP government -- which likes to style itself as a "Taiwanese regime" -- could use the "indigenous Taiwanese" ticket as an excuse to pass the buck of "being unclean."
An "indigenous regime" should not equal a corrupt government and the DPP should conduct deep self-examination, he said.

The PFP is poised to seek to topple the Cabinet should an opposition Kuomintang-initiated presidential recall motion fail to clear the Legislative Yuan in a June 27 vote before its current extra session ends June 30, Hsieh said, adding that the party will stand firm on this stance even if a new legislature were to be elected.
Chen is slated to make a report to defend his position regarding the string of high-profile corruption scandals Tuesday evening in a TV broadcast.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 19, or the 24th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
2000: Fifty-eight mainland Chinese were found suffocated in a truck container at an English port. They died during the trip from Belgium to Britain.
2001: Formosa Platics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching says that Taiwan should accept mainland China's "one China" principle out of consideration for its mutual benefits at this critical moment of development for the entire Chinese race.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME ELEMENTARY SCHOOL GRADUATES WILL BE AWASH IN COMMENCEMENT GIFTS

TEXT.P: Four elementary schools in central Nantou County will each graduate only two students this year and every one of the graduates is expected to receive a large number of commencement gifts, Nantou education officials said Monday.
June is Taiwan's graduation season, the officials said, noting the county's 183 elementary and junior high schools will hold commencement ceremonies between June 19 and June 24.

Students at these schools may not have many classmates, but they will surely receive more gifts than their counterparts at larger schools because they are all graduating "at the top of their classes."
The two students at each of the four "mini" elementary schools are bound to be inundated with prizes bestowed by the Nantou county chief, council speaker and the school administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN URGES NOT TO OVERPLAY MA ATTACK REMARKS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun urged the party's supporters Monday to remain calm at this time of political turmoil, which he said was whipped up by an opposition-initiated presidential recall motion.

Yu issued the statement urging DPP members and supporters to "maintain a cool head" and to refrain from sensationalist speculation in order to avoid falling into a trap set by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), which he said has "engaged in political strife" by seeking to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

According to Yu, the remarks about attacking Ma aired by underground radio stations in southern Taiwan were merely an emotionally charged response to pan-blue efforts to recall Chen. Local media must not rehash the issue so as to avoid social confrontation and violence, not to mention bloodshed, he urged.

The kind-hearted Taiwanese would not allow politically motivated assassinations in this democratic era, and DPP backers are only disgruntled over pan-blue attempts to boot out a popularly elected head of state, Yu said.

The opposition's series of demonstrations and activities to that end are viewed by DPP supporters as disparaging of Taiwan's judicial system and its directly elected president, the DPP chairman added.

The pan-blue alliance has initiated a motion in the Legislative Yuan to recall Chen before its current extra legislative session ends June 30 on grounds that Chen should take responsibility for several corruption scandals allegedly involving his family members and close aides, arguing Chen has lost the respect and trust of Taiwan's public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NGOS VOICE SUPPORT FOR MYANMAR FIGHTER FOR DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's non-governmental organizations (NGOs) designated June 19 as "Taiwan NGO's Day of Democracy for Myanmar" on Monday -- the same day as the birthday of renowned Myanmar pro-democracy activist Aung San Suu Kyi as well as the first day of operations of the new UN Human Rights Council.
Taiwan NGOs have also launched a campaign to collectively call on the military junta of Myanmar to release the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and long-time non-violence advocate from house arrest.

A news conference for the campaign was held at Taipei's Youth Hub, with Taiwan Labor Front (TLF) executive board member Sun Yu-lien stressing that Taiwan must not be absent from the "crucial issue of human rights violations in the Asian region" after it succeeded in gaining support for its democratization from many international groups and figures.

The Taiwan NGOs organizing the campaign include the TLF, the Taiwan Association for Human Rights, the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan and the Awakening Foundation. So far, 45 groups have endorsed the move to call for Aung San Suu Kyi's freedom, according to organizers.
The Human Rights Council was established to replace the U.N. Commission on Human Rights and began operations Monday in Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CLAIMS PROGRESS IN SEEKING 'PAN-GREEN' SUPPORT FOR CHEN'S RECALL

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) has achieved some success in persuading legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), to support a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a PFP legislative caucus whip said Monday.

Legislator Lee Hung-chun, general secretary of the PFP's legislative caucus, told reporters that some 10 to 20 legislators from the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and TSU are dissatisfied with the president's performance and may support the motion for Chen's recall, which was initiated by the "pan-blue alliance" of the PFP and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
Lee declined to elaborate on the identities of the PFP and TSU lawmakers or their views toward the president.
Lee disclosed that many TSU and DPP legislators have told him privately that they were sick of the series of corruption scandals embroiling the president's aides and family members.
He said the pan-green legislative caucuses apparently have no intention to protect the president because they offered no resistance when the motion was introduced in the Legislative Yuan.
Lee added that some pan-green legislators even told him privately that they support the PFP and KMT taking the issue to the streets.

A two-thirds majority vote is required in the 221-member legislature to pass the recall motion, after which the issue would be decided in a national referendum. This means the PFP and KMT require the support of 36 legislators from the DPP and TSU to ensure that the motion is carried.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP ECHOES KMT'S PLEDGE TO TOPPLE THE CABINET IF RECALL BID FAILS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) confirmed Monday that if the motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian fails to pass the legislature, the PFP's legislative caucus will push for a motion to topple the Cabinet.

In a move to echo a similar pledge by the PFP's ally, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, said the PFP will do everything it can to push for a no-confidence vote in the legislature and to dismiss the Cabinet if the presidential recall bid fails.

The Legislative Yuan is scheduled to vote on the motion June 27, yet it is expected to fail because the KMT and PFP only control the 221-seat legislature by a slight majority, falling short of the two-thirds majority needed to carry the motion.

Saying the PFP will place the nation's long-term interests above those of the party, Lu vowed that if the motion to recall Chen fails, the PFP will be "dead set" on toppling the Cabinet, although the consequences of such a move may prove unfavorable to the PFP.

Political analysts have warned the PFP that in the event of the Cabinet's collapse, the president may dismiss the legislature and trigger a re-election of all legislators -- a situation that would be unfavorable to the PFP and other small parties under the new "single constituency, two votes" system.

The opposition parties want to recall the president because they claim that he is incompetent in running the nation, as evidenced by a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.
A two-thirds majority vote would be required for the recall motion to pass in the legislature, after which the issue would be put to a national referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO RESPOND TO RECALL MOTION IN TELEVISED SPEECH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a televised speech Tuesday evening in response to an opposition-initiated motion to recall him, Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen said Monday.

The president's speech will come a day before the Legislative Yuan begins debate on the recall motion, instigated by the opposition "pan-blue" alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) on grounds the president has lost the public's trust after a spate of scandals allegedly involving his family and close aides.

Claiming the recall motion lacks legitimacy, Tan Sun Chen said the president decided to forgo his option of issuing a written rebuttal to the opposition-controlled legislature to defend himself against the recall campaign.

Instead, he said, the president will speak to the public on various issues, including his stance on ongoing judicial investigations into his son-in-law's alleged involvement in an insider trading scandal.

"Through his speech, the president hopes his dedication to the country over the past six years and the truth [of the alleged corruption scandals] will be understood by his fellow compatriots, " said Tan Sun Chen.

The Constitution gives the president the option of making a written statement to the legislature, which will hold a vote June 27 on the recall motion whose passage will require a two-thirds majority. If the motion passes -- it is seen unlikely as the opposition only holds a slim majority -- then a nationwide referendum would be held on whether the president should be forced to step down over the corruption allegations.

Since President Chen's son-in-law Chao Chien-ming was detained May 24 on suspicions of insider trading, Tan Sun Chen said the prosecution has been conducting a thorough investigation, although so far there has been no evidence to suggest the president or the first lady was involved in any illegal dealings, he added.

Stressing that the move to unseat the head of state is a very "solemn" event, Tan Sun Chen argued that the opposition's bid to instigate a recall campaign "based on flawed reasoning" cannot be justified, adding that the recall motion "seems nothing more than a facade of ugly political wrangling so the opposition can make a power grab."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO INFORM LEGISLATURE OF 'NO WRITTEN REBUTTAL' DECISION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will inform the Legislative Yuan Tuesday why he has chosen not to issue a written rebuttal against the opposition-initiated motion to unseat him, a ruling party caucus whip said Monday.

Ker Chien-ming, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus, made the remarks after paying a visit to the Presidential Office to discuss how to respond to a letter sent by the legislature last week about the recall motion.
The president is required to inform the opposition-controlled legislature by June 20 whether he would issue a written rebuttal against the recall motion.
According to the Constitution, the president is free to decide whether to make a written rebuttal to the legislature or not.

Although the president will not send a written rebuttal to the legislature, he will instead deliver a televised speech Tuesday evening, explaining his stance and views on the opposition's reasons for the ongoing recall campaign.
The legislature's Committee of the Whole is scheduled to meet June 21-23 and June 26 to review the recall motion before it is put to a vote during a plenary session June 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 20, or the 25th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation links between Vietnam and China.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
1999: Boris Yeltsin presents U.S. President Bill Clinton with recently declassified Russian reports relating to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
2000: Hans Muench, a German doctor in the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp is given immunity from trial at a French court because of his senility.
2001: The 46th World Conference of the International Council for Small Businesses (ICSB) concludes in Taipei after some 500 participants from 55 countries spent three days to discuss how to cope with the challenges posed by the new era.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position, but if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CLAIMS PROGRESS IN SEEKING 'PAN-GREEN' SUPPORT FOR CHEN'S RECALL(repeat)

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) has achieved some success in persuading legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), to support a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a PFP legislative caucus whip said Monday.

Legislator Lee Hung-chun, general secretary of the PFP's legislative caucus, told reporters that some 10 to 20 legislators from the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and TSU are dissatisfied with the president's performance and may support the motion for Chen's recall, which was initiated by the "pan-blue alliance" of the PFP and main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
Lee declined to elaborate on the identities of the PFP and TSU lawmakers or their views toward the president.
Lee disclosed that many TSU and DPP legislators have told him privately that they were sick of the series of corruption scandals embroiling the president's aides and family members.
He said the pan-green legislative caucuses apparently have no intention to protect the president because they offered no resistance when the motion was introduced in the Legislative Yuan.
Lee added that some pan-green legislators even told him privately that they support the PFP and KMT taking the issue to the streets.

A two-thirds majority vote is required in the 221-member legislature to pass the recall motion, after which the issue would be decided in a national referendum. This means the PFP and KMT require the support of 36 legislators from the DPP and TSU to ensure that the motion is carried.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT SYSTEM IN KAOHSIUNG FACING LABOR SHORTAGE PROBLEM

TEXT.P: With Thai laborers working for the mass rapid transit (MRT) system in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan starting to leave this Thursday, the system is facing a labor shortage problem, Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) officials said Tuesday.

The officials said the KRTC currently employs 1,398 Thai laborers for the MRT system, but 171 of them will start to leave Thursday after their two-year contract expires. By the end of this year, a total of 580 of the Thai laborers in four groups will leave Taiwan.

As the construction of the MRT system is now entering into the final track-laying stage, the officials expressed concern that labor shortage could affect the full opening of the system scheduled for October 2007.

Large contractors of the MRT system have complained about the labor crunch, asking the KRTC to provide additional laborers or hire more foreign laborers, but the company is reluctant to do so after a Thai labor riot in August 2005 for alleged harsh treatment by a management company hired by the KRTC.

Affected by the riot, which led to the uncovering of a corruption scandal in which a former close aide of President Chen Shui-bian was implicated, the KRTC has stopped importing foreign labor, and has instead turned to local laborers, which have proved hard to find, and "borrowed" laborers from other sectors.

KRTC officials said that one section of the two lines of the MRT system -- from Kaohsiung International Airport to a downtown department store -- is scheduled to open this October, adding that finding foreign laborers to work on this section will be made a priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE CAA METEOROLOGISTS INDICTED OVER TAA CARGO PLANE CRASH

TEXT.P: Five Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) meteorologists were indicted Tuesday over their alleged failure to issue a bad weather warning that led to a tragic plane crash in December 2002.

The five CAA staff members were charged with dereliction of duty and involuntary manslaughter as their failure to issue SIGMET warnings allegedly led to the crash of a Macau-bound TransAsia Airways (TAA) cargo plane Dec. 21, 2002, which killed two pilots.

Prosecutorial investigations found that the crash was caused by ice accumulation around the plane's major components, resulting in the aircraft's loss of control and plunge into the seas, the indictment said.
According to the investigations, both Hong Kong and Japanese aviation authorities had issued SIGMET warnings to aircraft in the Taiwan Strait both before and after the TAA air tragedy.
The SIGMET (significant meteorology) reports are designed to provide information concerning en-route weather phenomena which may affect an aircraft's safety.

But the CAA failed to issue similar alerts before the ATR-72 TransAsia Airways cargo aircraft plowed into the Taiwan Strait in bad weather, the indictment said, adding that the CAA meteorology center didn't issue the ice accumulation warnings until after the TAA cargo plane crash. Their negligence left pilots unaware of the need to take timely steps.
The indicted CAA staffers are Liu Chao-ming, a chief meteorologist, and four weather analysts -- Wang Tai-yuan, Yu Shou-liang, Tsai Chia-cheng and Hsu Ching-hui, who were on duty at the time.

The ATR-72 aircraft, powered by twin propellers, took off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan at 1:05 a.m. Dec. 21, 2002, but disappeared from radar screens at 1: 56 a.m. that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALL BATTLE SPILLS OVER INTO U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 19 (CNA) (By Wu Jih-chun & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Organizers of a protest rally against President Chen Shui-bian delivered to Taiwan's liaison office in San Francisco Monday a statement signed by the rally participants in which they expressed their discontent with what they called the corruption-ridden administration headed by Chen.

Around 500 Taiwanese expatriates gathered Sunday in San Francisco's Chinatown to voice their protest against Chen, who is faced with a recall motion at the legislature after the judicial authorities began investigating corruption allegations involving his son-in-law and close aides.
Nearly 40 overseas Taiwanese groups organized the protest rally, including an association of members of Taiwan's opposition People First Party in San Francisco.
Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is launching a campaign in the United States to try to win support for President Chen from Taiwanese living in the country.

Lee Han-wun, an executive member of the DPP's U.S. West Coast chapter, said Monday that more and more grassroots DPP members are asking to "fight back" as part of efforts to defend Chen and prevent him from being unseated.

"President Chen should not be the target of a recall motion because he hasn't done anything illegal, " Lee said, adding that the DPP is seeking to collect the signatures of 1 million people in Taiwan and abroad to counter the opposition-initiated recall campaign against the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCA LAUNCHES ENGLISH MAGAZINE 'FOUNTAIN'

TEXT.P: The state-funded National Cultural Association (NCA) launched its English-language magazine -- Fountain -- Monday to help the world better understand Taiwan.

Speaking at a news conference to announce the magazine's launch, NCA Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou said that Fountain is the English version of the NCA's Chinese-language magazine bearing a similar title.
If the English version receives a positive response, Tchen said, then the NCA will launch Japanese and French versions in the future.

Tchen said that Taiwan's representative office in Italy has ordered 200 copies of the first issue to distribute at the Venice Biennial art and architecture exhibition later this year. Many foreign representative offices in Taiwan have also shown interest in subscribing to the new English magazine, she added.

Noting that the magazine is like a "window on Taiwan," Tchen said the inaugural issue features interviews with four renowned Taiwanese movie directors -- Hou Hsiao-hsien, Ang Lee, Yang Teh-chang and Tsai Ming-liang. The second issue is scheduled to hit bookstore shelves in December, with noted Taiwanese designers and their works to be featured.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 60% THINK SUBSTANTIVE CRIMINAL EVIDENCE NEEDED FOR RECALL: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of the people believe that a recall of President Chen Shui-bian is only warranted if there is substantive criminal evidence against him, the results of a new poll conducted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) showed Tuesday.
Chang Yu-feng, director of the DPP's Survey Center, unveiled the results of the poll amid an opposition-initiated recall motion to unseat President Chen.
The opposition initiated the recall motion believing that Chen's leadership is in doubt in the wake of a series of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close associates.
A total of 1,028 valid questionnaires were collected in the June 18 poll which is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

The poll showed that 64 percent of the respondents think that the opposition should submit substantive criminal evidence before initiating a recall motion, while 23 percent said they agree with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's comment that "a recall is a political move and doesn't require substantive (criminal) evidence."
Forty-eight percent of those polled expressed the hope that the opposition will not proceed with its plan to push for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) has insisted that the recall motion be placed at the top of the agenda in the extraordinary legislative session being held June 13-30, but 71 percent of those polled said they are against this and believe that bills related to the people's welfare should be dealt with first.

PFP Chairman James Soong said that if the recall motion fails, his party will push for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet, but the poll showed that 71 percent of the respondents think that there is no need to topple the Cabinet.
Chang said the figures show that Soong's views are "based on his party's own interests and in total disregard of the people's will."

On a series of "sensational revelations" by elected officials in what they called "whistle-blowing" moves for media coverage, 44 percent of the respondents said they trust the media reports, while 36 percent said they do not.
Forty-four percent said the purpose of such revelations has to do with the ongoing political infighting, and not with monitoring the government as claimed by those who have made the revelations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTED TO SIGN FTA WITH EL SALVADOR IN OCTOBER: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with El Salvador in October this year if bilateral negotiations proceed smoothly, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

The signing could take place during Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca's planned visit to Taiwan in October, according to Ko Jai-son, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs.
Taiwan, which has signed FTAs with Panama, Guatemala and Nicaragua, is currently engaged in FTA talks with several other Central American nations, including El Salvador and Honduras.

Although Taiwan and the Dominican Republic have signed a letter of intent for an FTA, neither side is ready to sign the FTA during Dominican President Leonel Fernandez Reyna's scheduled visit to Taiwan later this month, MOFA officials said.

Through the FTA framework, Taiwan aims to build a Taiwan-Central America free trade region to help Taiwanese businesses make further inroads into the U.S. market using the preferential tariff treatment enjoyed by Central American nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 219.49 points to close at 6,363.55.
The bourse opened at 6,536.11 and fluctuated between 6,552.17 and 6,324.69 during trading. A total of 3.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.49 billion (US$2.96 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 4.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 3.7 percent, cement stocks at 3.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.5 percent, textile stocks at 3.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 2.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 808 to 91, with 44 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPING KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY BEST PRESCRIPTION FOR AGING SOCIETY: CEPD

TEXT.P: Building a knowledge-based economy is the best way to deal with a fast-aging society like Taiwan's, a senior official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, CEPD chairman, was commenting on a population estimate that by 2014, people 65 years of age and older will account for 13 percent of Taiwan's total population, an indication that Taiwan society is aging faster than advanced countries in Europe and North America.

The problem will be exacerbated by declining birth rates, as those of the younger generation tend to have few if any children even after marriage, according to a report by the CEPD's department of manpower planning.
Hu said it is time that Taiwan began preparing for an aging population and fewer new births, both of which he said are bound to have an impact on the economy.
One way to cope with the problem is to raise the mandatory retirement age as some Western countries have done, he said, noting that the government is planning to follow suit.

A more pertinent strategy is to focus on developing the knowledge economy, which will better accommodate late retirement, he pointed out, adding that for that purpose, Taiwan's high-tech industry has already begun to invite retired Japanese engineers over to share their experiences.

Moreover, he said, the government is also studying ways to remove barriers for young couples to raise children. For instance, he said, the Ministry of the Interior has mapped out some measures that will be publicized at the planned Taiwan Economic Sustainable Development Conference to be held in late July for feedback.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY PLANS TO PROVIDE FREE LUNCHES TO SCHOOL CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Acting Mayor Yeh Chu-lan asked the city's education and finance officials Tuesday to find money for a "free lunch for all grade school children" program that will be implemented next year as part of her plan to create a "welfare state."

During a budget meeting Monday, the city government approved a budget for a program to provide free lunch to school children of low- and middle-income families. Yeh said the program should be extended to cover all school children to show the government's care for them.

"Many countries have offered free education to their younger generation, " she said, adding that as the government works toward building a "welfare state, " Kaohsiung City should start by offering free lunch to all elementary school students.

City officials estimate that for that purpose, NT$600 million (US$18.4 million) will be required annually. Yeh said it will be money well spent as free meals will make kids happy and help make the country stronger.

The city will have no problem earmarking that amount as its major spending over the past few years on building the city's rapid transit system will finally begin to wind down in October 2007, when the red and orange lines are scheduled for completion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down 216 points to close at 6,359, with 53,447 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July dropped 240 points to finish at 6,283, with 23,379 contracts traded, while September futures lost 251 points to close at 6,170, with 112 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 249 points to close at 6,170, with 35 contracts traded, while March futures dropped 291 points to finish at 6,151, with nine contracts traded.
