Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 8.4 points to close at 262.95, with 7,271 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 11.3 points to finish at 257.5, with 4,564 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 8.65 points to close at 257, with 47 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures dropped 22.2 points to finish at 960, with 3,841 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures lost 37.4 points to close at 940.2, with 3,042 contracts traded.
September TE futures moved down 24.2 points to close at 937.4, with 21 contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 21.4 points to finish at 945, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAYING OF SOCIETY TO ACCELERATE AFTER 2019: CEPD REPORT

TEXT.P: The graying of Taiwan's society is expected to accelerate after 2019 when the country's population is forecast to begin declining, according to the latest population report released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Tuesday.

The report shows that Taiwan's total fertility rate (TFR) declined from 1.68 in 2000 to 1.12 for 2005, marking a 33-percent drop. The TFR refers to the average number of babies born to women during their reproductive years.
As a result, the population growth rate will drop from 0.3 percent in 2006 to 0.03 percent in 2018, the report said.

The working age population, meaning all those between the age of 15 and 64, will account for about 70 percent of the total population over the next 15 years, with the percentage beginning to drop from that time.

The working population is forecast to drop to 55 percent of the total population by 2051, the report said. As a result, the younger generations' burden of supporting retired citizens will increase sharply, from the current figure of 7.2 working age people having to support one senior to 3.3 working age people having to support one senior in 2026, with the figure dropping to 1.5 by 2051.

The percentage of people over the age of 65 will increase from 10 percent in 2006 to 13 percent in 2014 and then rise sharply to 37 percent by 2051. The number of people over 75 years old will rise from 950,000 in 2006 to 1.26 million in 2016 and 3.69 million in 2051, according to the report.
The CEPD report also concluded that Taiwan's population will peak at about 23.2 millions in 2018 and then begin declining from 2019.

A CEPD official noted that it remains to be seen whether Taiwan's fertility rate can be boosted gradually in the future, adding that the government should draw up adequate policies to increase incentives for women to get married and have children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE TO NEW ZEALAND TRANSFERRED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to New Zealand, Victor J. Chin, will be transferred to the post of adviser to the Trade Mission to Fiji after he was indicted in May by the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office on charge of forgery, a ranking foreign affairs official said Tuesday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu explained that there's "no alternative but" to relocate Chin, whom the ministry no longer regards as qualified to serve in his current position due to his suspected involvement in illegal conduct.

The MOFA discovered the diplomat had allegedly forged receipts for publicity spending to the tune of more than NT$200,000 in a scheme aimed at boasting of his capability in terms of management and budget implementation in order to gain promotion.
The case is pending trial in the Taipei District Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CAUCUS POSES TEN QUESTIONS TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of opposition People First Party (PFP) posed 10 questions to President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday as he planned to report directly to the people instead of responding to charges made against him in a presidential recall motion in the legislature.

Caucus convener Lu Hsueh-chang urged the president to answer the 10 questions rather than try to evade reporters' questions during a televised speech scheduled for 8: 00 p.m. Tuesday, titled "Report directly to the people."
First, Lu said, "Did first lady Wu Shu-jen accept any Pacific Sogo Department Store vouchers, or did she not?"
Second, he asked, "Did your son-in-law Chao Chien-ming buy Taiwan Development Corp. shares and peddle his influence to help some people obtain certain posts, or did he not?"
Third, Lu continued, "Did your son-in-law's father Chao Yu-chu embezzle NT$10 million that belonged to the Taiwan Table Tennis Association, or did he not?"
Fourth, Lu said, "Did your former deputy secretaries-general Chen Che-nan and Ma Yung-cheng buy and sell stocks while they were serving at the Presidential Office, or did they not?"
Fifth, he went on, "Was Chen Che-nan involved in the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. scandal, or was he not?"
Sixth, Lu said, "Was Ma Yung-cheng involved in the appointments of senior managers of merged banks and holding companies, or was he not?"

Seventh, he enquired, "Did you and Huang Fang-yen, vice president of Shin Kong Hospital, interfere in selling Taiwan Fertilizer Corp. land, causing NT$2.5 billion in losses to the nation's coffers, or did you not?"

Eighth, Lu said, "Why do you still refuse to step down after former Democratic Progressive Party legislator Shen Fu-hsiung claimed that Wu Shu-jen met former Tuntex Corp. Chairman Chen You-hao and received Chen's political donations?"
Ninth, he asked, "Did your former chief aide-de-camp Yu Lian-fa join others in the Presidential Office in buying and selling stocks, or did he not?"

Tenth, Lu asked, "Since your wife, secretaries, family doctor and lawyer and accountant, in-laws and other relatives are all involved or suspected of involvement in various scandals, can you stay in your job without the slightest compunction? Can the people of Taiwan still call you 'the son of Taiwan'? Or should they call you 'the shame of Taiwan'? Do you love Taiwan, or new Taiwan dollars?"

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.002 to close at NT$32.596.
A total of US$802 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.650 and fluctuated between NT$32.380 and NT$32.655.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL TOURISM GROUPS TO MEET IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: The Asia Pacific Tourism Association (APTA) and the Asia-Pacific chapter of the International Council on Hotel, Restaurant and Institutional Education (APacCHRIE) is scheduled to hold their joint annual conference June 26-29 in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien, organizers said Tuesday.

The conference is being co-organized by the Taiwan Hospitality and Tourism College, the hospitality management and education section of National Taiwan Normal University's Department of Human Development and Family Studies, National Taipei College of Nursing's Graduate Institute of Tourism and Health Science, and Chinese Culture University's Graduate Institute of Tourism Industry.

The event will bring together more than 300 academics and experts in hospitality and tourism from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Taiwan, the United States, Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Ghana, Burkina Faso, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, France, Belgium and China, the organizers said.
The participants will present a total of 224 papers during the conference, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN WOULD QUIT POLITICS FOR CHEN'S OUSTER

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Tuesday that he would quit politics if President Chen Shui-bian steps down.
Soong made the pledge at the PFP's caucus headquarters at the Legislative Yuan.

Soong stressed that the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) will undoubtedly seek to topple the Cabinet should a KMT-initiated recall vote against Chen fail to pass the current extra legislative session.
If the recall bid fails -- and it is likely to be so -- the PFP would ask the Legislative Yuan to open another extra session to deal with a no-confidence vote proposal, he said.

"I would be willing to pull out of the December's election for Taipei mayor, not be premier and even quit politics if Chen steps down, " he claimed, and courted "pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to back the recall vote, which requires two-thirds approval in the legislature.
The pan-blue alliance controls only a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan, and it would be difficult to pass the recall measure in the legislature without joint efforts from its pan-green peers.

According to Soong, the PFP decided to seek a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet -- led by Premier Su Tseng-chang -- only after Su proclaimed that he would back and help solidify Chen's leadership.
The PFP would risk all its legislative seats in exchange for Chen's ouster if a new legislature were to be elected, Soong said.

The PFP was not opposed to Su in the beginning, but his recent attitude toward a "corrupt center" after Chen promised to cede power to him late last month is proof that Su is no longer suitable to serve as premier, he argued.
He urged conscionable DPP lawmakers to join recall efforts in order to build a "clean" and "democratic" Taiwan.

The PFP chairman said that he would "conditionally" support Vice President Annette if she were to replace Chen -- if she abided by the Republic of China Constitution, did not promote de jure Taiwan independence and respected the independence of the judicial system.

Speaking with reporters at the same venue later the same day, Soong said that he "doesn't have the slightest intention" to serve in any Cabinet posts even if Chen opted not to dissolve the Legislative Yuan following a no-confidence vote.

The PFP's purpose to topple the Cabinet is aimed at electing a new Legislative Yuan that would give the pan-blue alliance a two-thirds majority needed to recall Chen, Soong explained, adding that the PFP would not cling to power if a new Cabinet is formed.

He reiterated that the PFP would call for another extra session at the Legislative Yuan to launch a no-confidence vote in case the presidential recall vote fails to gain approval in the present extra session ending June 30.

Meanwhile, Soong is planning to stage a four-day sit-in with PFP lawmakers and supporters at the Legislative Yuan starting Wednesday to "deliver moral encouragement" to Chen and the DPP and TSU lawmakers when the law-making body begins screening the presidential recall vote through June 26, PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang announced later the same day.

According to Lu, the activity is aimed at "looking for Taiwan's conscience" and is directed at the president who "should face up to his mistakes." He also urged "pan-green" lawmakers to heed the public's wishes and bravely cut their connections to a corrupt government.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO RESPOND TO PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will deliver a speech on television Wednesday in response to President Chen Shui-bian's Tuesday's address, a KMT spokeswoman said.
Cheng Li-wen said that Ma will address the nation in a live broadcast at 8 p.m. Ma will not take questions from the media which could interrupt the full expression of his views, she added.

Cheng's words came after President Chen's decision to respond to an opposition-led recall motion in a televised address at 8 p.m. Tuesday in a hall of the Presidential Office. The media is invited to attend, but will not be allowed to pose questions.

Chen's aides said recall the recall motion lacks legitimacy, the president has chosen to give his "first report to the people" in the past six years to respond to 10-point charges raised by the opposition in its recall bid.
Ma, for his part, will also elaborate on reasons for unseating Chen and make a major announcement, Cheng said.

She questioned the president's "refusal to give a written rebuttal to the legislature," arguing it was because Chen is unable to answer all corruption allegations surrounding his son-in-law and close associates.

She said the KMT will harbor no illusions about President Chen's address, expecting him only to describe the recall bid as political infighting and to try to shift focus away from a series of scandals.

Cheng urged members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to seriously consider "drawing a clear line" with the scandal-ridden president, whom Cheng said is "incapable of defending himself" and likely to become a liability to the party.

The Constitution gives the president the option of submitting a written statement to the legislature in advance of a review of the recall motion by the legislature's Committee of the Whole June 21 before a vote held June 27, which requires two-thirds majority to pass.

If the motion succeeds -- viewed as highly unlikely since the opposition holds only a slight majority -- then a nationwide referendum would be held on whether the president should be forced to step down over the corruption allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Chaika Picked to Replace Ustinov President Vladimir Putin picked Justice Minister Yury Chaika as the next prosecutor general on Monday, tapping a career prosecutor who is seen as highly competent, loyal to Putin and independent of the Kremlin clans. ( By Chang Hung-kuang)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA: NO COMMENT ON RESIGNATION OF US OFFICIAL IN CHARGE OF CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu refused to comment Tuesday on the resignation of Robert Zoellick as U.S. Deputy Secretary of State, saying only that such a change would not influence Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Lu told reporters there is a continuity in U.S. diplomacy which does not change with the turnover of its officials.
However, the spokesman said his office will keep a close eye on changes in senior U.S. diplomatic officials.

He made the remarks after Zoellick, who is in charge of Chinese affairs, announced Monday in Washington that he would be leaving his post at the State Department to join Wall Street investment house Goldman Sachs Group Inc. as managing director.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHEN RECALL FEVER' EXTENDS TO OUTLYING ISLAND OF KINMEN

TEXT.P: A passion for recalling President Chen Shui-bian seems to have extended from Taiwan proper to its outlying island, when a Kinmen county councilman tore down the president's photo in the council's building Tuesday.

At a meeting to interrogate Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng regarding county affairs, the Kinmen county councilman Tsai Shui-you strongly criticized members of the first family and Chen's close aides for alleged involvement in a string of corruption scandals, as well as President Chen's "long-term neglect" of Kinmen affairs.

In an expression of fury, the independent councilman Tsai tore Chen's photo down from the wall with the help of councilman Hung Yun-tien, also without political affiliation. They then gave a "thumbs down" gesture to show the public's opinion in Kinmen.

As there were no council members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party present at the Kinmen County Council, the act of tearing down Chen's photo did not provoke confrontation as it did when a similar gesture occurred in the Taipei City Council.

Claiming that Chen failed to honor his promises to Kinmen's people while campaigning in the county in 2000, Tsai said President Chen was now caught up in several corruption scandals implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
"Chen should step down over the current political upheaval and his incompetence," Tsai stressed.

Spurred on by reports of alleged corruption scandals involving the first family and Chen's incompetence, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" has made a motion in the legislature to recall President Chen, and is soliciting public support for the campaign.
Tsai urged the people of Kinmen not to count on Chen's word, and that the island should "go its own way" to boost its own economy.

Magistrate Lee said he respected the "public's opinions" in Kinmen, while the Kinmen County Council noted that tearing down President Chen's photo was only a personal act carried out by two councilmen and not a result of the council's decision, and that the photo will be returned to its proper place within a few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENT WINS COMPENSATION FOR CORPORAL PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: A junior high school in Miaoli, central Taiwan was ordered Tuesday by a court to pay a student NT$660,181 (US$20,253) in compensation for administering corporal punishment that put the student in the hospital for 16 days.

Encouraged by the judgment, the Humanistic Education Foundation, a civic group that advocates development of "human-centered education, " said it was the first time in Taiwan's judicial history that compensation has been awarded to a student who was a victim of corporal punishment.
According to the Humanistic Education Foundation, it took the student's family about 19 months to win the case.
The foundation added, however, that no compensation is enough to heal the psychological wounds that the student suffered in addition to the physical injuries inflicted upon him.

The student was admitted to hospital for 16 days to treat the injuries caused by the brutal violence inflicted by the school, and his learning ability was also hindered, the foundation said, advising all teachers worthy of the title to forsake classroom brutality.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN SHOULD BE HELD ACCOUNTABLE IF RIOTS BREAK OUT: DPP

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou must be held accountable for any mob violence that may break out June 27 when the Legislative Yuan holds a vote to recall President Chen Shui-bian, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday.
DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang made the remarks at a news conference at the party's headquarters.

According to Tsai, the DPP's head office received information suggesting that "some elements" plan to infiltrate the crowd of "pan-blue" supporters gathering outside the Legislative Yuan June 27, and if the opposition-led presidential recall bid fails to pass the legislature that day, these elements intend to incite riots, possibly using molotov cocktails.
While urging Taipei city law enforcement authorities to be fully prepared for any given scenario, Tsai claimed that Ma must be held fully responsible in case of violent contingencies.

Tsai urged the KMT and its "pan-blue" alliance partner, the People First Party (PFP) , to stop making politically motivated attacks and to focus instead on quality of life issues. The pan-blue efforts to recall Chen will turn out to be in vain and its plan to topple the Cabinet can only fail, he predicted.

The "pan-blue" alliance has organized a series of demonstrations and activities in recent weeks to demand Chen's resignation over a spate of corruption allegations involving his family and close aides, fueling tensions between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN CHUNGKANG EPZ POSTS 209% GROWTH

TEXT.P: Investment in the Chungkang Export Processing Zone (EPZ) in central Taiwan's Taichung County posted 209 percent growth in the first five months of the year compared to the same period of the previous year.

A spokesman for the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said in Kaohsiung Tuesday that there were 10 cases of investment in the EPZ during the first five months of this year totaling NT$5.26 billion (US$161.49 million)

He added that the EPZA is improving its management of the country's EPZs by providing professional education to employees of the companies in the Chungkang facility and that investment there is growing rapidly.

According to the spokesman, there are currently 50 companies operating in the EPZ, with a combined investment of NT$27.88 billion. Revenue this year is expected to be between NT$25 billion to NT$30 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR WILLING TO BOOST PINEAPPLE CAKES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Jing-jeou said Tuesday that he would be willing to serve as a spokesman for pineapple cakes produced by bakeries in Taipei, if these cakes are low in fat and high in quality.
Ma made the remarks at a gathering with local business community representatives, including those from the Taipei Bakery Association which asked Ma to promote their pineapple cakes.

Ma said he would be very willing to help promote the speciality snacks made by Taipei-based bakeries and encouraged them to make low-fat and fine-quality products, making the cakes one of Taiwan's top-shelf special delicious desserts.

The cakes with pineapple filling are already very popular around Taiwan and are popular gifts among tourists. The best ones, however, traditionally do not come from Taipei but from the town of Keelung in northern Taiwan.
Bakery industry representatives said that they hope to organize a series of activities around the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Oct. 6 this year -- to promote Taipei-produced pineapple cakes.

Ma's "low fat" requirement is not technically difficult to achieve, business representatives said, adding that they are confident that the mayor will act as their spokesman for the city's pineapple cakes and give them a boost in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIC FARMERS IN YILAN FORM TRADE ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: The Yilan County Farmers' Association (YCFA) set up Tuesday a trade association to promote the county's organic agricultural produce.
The Organic Agriculture Production and Trade Promotion
Association has 30 farmers as its members for the time being but
is sure to increase, a YCFA official said.

Yilan county, located in the Lanyang Plain and surrounded by mountains, has become known as the "garden of Taipei" since a freeway linking it with Taipei opened June 17, the anonymous YCFA official said, adding that trade opportunities are likely to increase for local farmers since the freeway has connected the once-remote county with the Taipei metropolis.

The eastern county's efforts to promote organic food have literally borne fruit in recent years, including organic vegetables grown in Chuangwei township, green tea in Tungshan township, green bamboo in Yuanshan township and lilies grown in Luotung township.
With its clean water and fertile soil, Yilan is the island's most perfect place to develop organic agriculture, the anonymous YCFA official said.

Major tasks of the new association include building "model organic fields" showing how to cultivate organic products, boosting local production, and stepping up efforts to encourage domestic and foreign buyers to purchase Yilan's high-quality agricultural products, the YCFA official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD CONTINUES PRESSING FOR CHEN TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's logic that he should not be implicated by his son-in-law's suspected criminal offenses simply won't wash, said James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), Tuesday.
Soong, who says he is "dead set against" continuing to have a "corruption-tainted" Chen as president of the Republic of China, asked, "Where does Chao Chien-ming's influence come from?"

Chao, Chen's son-in-law, is in detention on suspicions of influence peddling and involvement in a high-profile insider trading case. The prosecution is probing whether he had accepted bribes to secure government jobs for friends.
Had Chao not been "empowered" by the influence of the Chen Shui-bian regime, Chao would not have been suspected of involvement in a complicated string of corruption scandals, Soong said.

Chao's father, mother, brother and brother's wife have all been investigated on suspicion of buying Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) shares based on insider information the corporation would be bailed out by a huge syndicated loan. Chao Yu-chu, Chao's father, is also suspected of embezzling NT$10 million belonging to the Taiwan Table Tennis Association.

Furthermore, Chen's senior aide, former deputy secretary-general Chen Che-nan, has been indicted on charges of fraud and for involvement in the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) scandal. First lady Wu Shu-jen is speculated to have accepted business favors and gift vouchers from a department store.
In spite of all these suspicions, plus the controversy over the March 19, 2004 shooting incident, the president has not shown any remorse, Soong argued.

He claimed that if Taiwan's politicians continue calculating only their personal interests, Taiwan will be hijacked. He is adamant about "bringing down such a corrupt regime, " simply because he wants to be able to "face history," he added.

As to why he is pushing for a no-confidence vote against Premier Su Tseng-chang in case the legislature's presidential recall motion fails, Soong said the move's sole aim is to recall President Chen through a new legislature that would be elected after the Cabinet has been toppled.

With its slim majority in the current legislature, the "pan-blue alliance" of the PFP and Kuomintang (KMT) can easily pass a no-confidence vote against Su and is likely to win more than two-thirds of legislative seats -- sufficient to push for another presidential recall motion.
Soong claimed he wouldn't mind if his PFP wins "not a single seat" in the envisioned new legislature, as long as the legislative election is held according to law.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD CONFIDENT MOTION TO RECALL PRESIDENT WILL FAIL

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday he is confident that a presidential recall motion introduced by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), will not succeed.

Presiding over a changeover ceremony at the DPP's Taipei County office, Yu said his confidence is supported by the results of a DPP poll showing 71 percent of respondents are opposed to recalling President Chen Shui-bian.

The DPP poll's findings are contradicted by other poll results. The China Times released results Monday showing that 53 percent of respondents think Chen is no longer fit to serve as president, with 42 percent supporting the motion for his recall and another 40 percent opposing the move.

Yu also opined that a subsequent motion by the KMT and PFP to topple the Cabinet through a no-confidence vote would fail as well, because the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP remains divided on the issue.
Citing examples, he said KMT lawmakers, including Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Legislator Hsu Shu-po, do not support the motion to topple the Cabinet.
The DPP chairman urged his KMT counterpart Ma Ying-jeou to "halt the horse at the edge of the cliff" for the sake of Taiwan's political stability.
Noting the poll results also show Ma's popularity rating plunged 13 percent after he endorsed the motion for a presidential recall, Yu said this indicates Ma should reconsider his decision.

The legislature is scheduled to vote on the recall motion June 27. The KMT and PFP, which hold a slight majority in the 221-seat legislature, will need the support of 36 legislators from the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, to ensure the motion's passage, after which the issue would be put to a national referendum.

Both the KMT and the PFP have vowed that if the recall motion fails, they will push for a no-confidence vote in the legislature to topple the Cabinet. DPP leaders have warned that if the Cabinet should collapse, they will ask the president to dismiss the legislature, forcing new elections to be held.

DOC.HEADLINE: CTS SAYS IT WILL NOT BE PROPAGANDA MACHINE OF ANY POLITICAL PARTY

TEXT.P: Chinese Television System (CTS) will not be a propaganda machine for any political party, CTS said in a statement Tuesday.

The statement was released apparently in response to news reports quoting former CTS President Chiang Hsia as saying that CTS has been "tinted blue" under the leadership of new CTS President Li Yuan, meaning that the TV company is politically tilted toward the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.
Chiang is a high-profile supporter of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). During her presidency from 2004 to 2006, CTS was widely criticized as a publicity machine of the DPP.
The CTS statement noted that CTS joined the Taiwan Public Television Service in April to become a member of the Taiwan Broadcasting System, which will become operational from July 1.
"CTS will not use its news or entertainment programs as publicity tools for any political party," the statement said.
"Neither the board chairman nor the president of CTS will take part in promotional activities of any political party," it added.
CTS gave its assurance that as a member of the Taiwan Broadcasting System, it will serve the interests of all the people of Taiwan by producing objective, high-quality TV programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC WARNS OF POTENTIAL DENGUE FEVER OUTBREAK IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An outbreak of dengue fever is likely to occur in southern Taiwan, where the dengue-carrying mosquito has multiplied following the recent heavy rain, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) warned Tuesday.

The results of a CDC vector survey show that the larval infestation density of the aedes aegypti mosquito has been rising rapidly in Chiayi County, Tainan County, Tainan City, Kaohsiung County, Kaohsiung City, Pingtung County, Penghu County and Taitung County after days of torrential downpours, with Kaohsiung County, Kaohsiung City, Pingtung County and Penghu County registering the highest levels of increase.

While only 7.2 percent of the villages and boroughs surveyed registered a high risk level of a potential outbreak according to their Breteau indexes -- the total number of water containers having larvae or pupae of aedes aegypti per 100 houses -- in the first week of June, the ratio climbed to 10.4 percent in the second week and further to 25.9 percent in the third week.
The figures compare with 4.8 percent, 5.8 percent and 14.4 percent recorded in the same periods of last year, CDC officials said.
CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi noted that 30 dengue fever cases have been reported in Taiwan this year, two of which were indigenous cases and 28 of which were contracted overseas.

The overseas cases include 11 from Vietnam, nine from Indonesia, four from Thailand, two from Malaysia, one from the Philippines and one from Madagascar, and 17, or 60 percent, of these cases were discovered through quarantine inspection at airports, Shih said.
Shih said half of the overseas cases involved Southeast Asian nationals married to Taiwanese citizens or children of such marriages.
He urged people to wear long-sleeved shirts and pants in light colors and to use anti-mosquito products if they are planning to visit Southeast Asia during the summer vacation.

They should seek medical treatment immediately and disclose their travel history should they develop dengue fever-like symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, severe joint pains, muscle aches, general weakness, nausea, vomiting and rash after returning from their trips, Shih said.
Also, the public should clean water containers inside and outside their homes to prevent infestations of mosquitoes, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraq War May Add Stress for Past Vets; Trauma Disorder Claims at New High.
More than 30 years after their war ended, thousands of Vietnam veterans are seeking help for post-traumatic stress disorder, and experts say one reason appears to be harrowing images of combat in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Reconstruction, Army Cancels Contract for Iraqi Prison
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers said Monday that it had canceled a US$99.1 million contract wi th Parsons, one of the largest companies working in Iraq, to build a prison north of Baghdad after the firm fell more than two years behind schedule, threatened to go millions of dollars over budget and essentially abandoned the construction site. The move is another harsh rebuke for Parsons, only weeks after the corps c anceled more than US$300 million of the company's contracts to build and refurbish hospitals and clinics across Iraq.
Wall Street Journal: Battlefield Conversion, Employees of Contractor Barred From Iraq Resurrect Its Business
The Bush administration's effort to rebuild Iraq has been marred by mismanagement and instances of corruption. U.S. audits have found evidence that hundreds of millions of dollars was spent without proper authorization, given to contractors who performed shoddy work, or paid to firms charging unreasonably high prices. The audits have also found cases where corrupt contractors and U.S. and Iraqi government officials stole money. The U.S. has budgeted US$20.9 billion specifically for Iraq reconstruction, not counting money for smaller projects that comes from the military's budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNG STEM CELLS FOUND BY ACADEMIA SINICA

TEXT.P: The Genomic Research Center of Academic Sinica declared Tuesday that it had found lung stem cells, proving the long-held theory of the existence of adult stem cells in the lungs.

The research team also found the fact that lung stem cells are the primary target of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) viruses and that the infection of stem cells results in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) -- or fatal lung failures that claim the lives of 50 percent of SARS patients who later develop ARDS.

Dr. John Yu, the head of the team, said that due to constant contact with air, lung cells are more fragile than cells in other organs, therefore scientists have long believed there should be stem cells in the lungs to regenerate cells and maintain respiratory function.

Yu added that in their research, they not only found stem cells in the bronchoalveolar junction, but also discovered that lung stem cells renew lung cells at an interval of 25 days, which is also the key period between the peak SARS virus load and the development of ARDS.

During the 2003 SARS epidemic, Yu noticed for the first time the 25-day lag from time of peak virus load to onset of ARDS. Yu at that time hypothesized that the lag time might reflect the duration of the stem cell regenerative cycle, so the team set a goal of spotting stem cells in the lungs.

The team later grew lung cells in vitro and found only one specific group of cells was targeted by the SARS viruses. When verifying the group, they found the cells bear the Oct-4 and SSEA-1 markers -- the same markers for embryonic stem cells, convincing them that they had discovered lung stem cells.
The team has also proved that the high death rate among SARS patients is because the viruses attack stem cells, stopping the cell regeneration process and causing lung failure.

Yu explained that an "experienced" virus will not attack stem cells and cause the death of its host, for viruses seek symbiosis -- to receive benefits from the host as long as possible. Yu added that since SARS viruses are relatively new and "inexperienced, " they will "wrongly" target stem cells.
Yu noted that since the SARS viruses are still young and have shown no signs of evolving, any SARS epidemics that break out will still attack stem cells.
Yu noted that they have now successfully developed lung stem cells in vitro and that they have been working on stem cell therapy for ARDS and other lung failure diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: URBANIZATION INCREASES OVER LAST 15 YEARS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Urbanization is increasing in Taiwan, with nearly 69.4 percent of the country's population living in urban areas by 2005, according to the latest report on urbanization released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The report shows that Taiwan's total population reached 22.77 million at the end of 2005, with 15.8 million people, or 69.4 percent of the population, residing in urban areas, which accounted for only 16.9 percent of Taiwan's territory.

Among Taiwan's cities and counties, the greater Taipei area and Keelung registered the largest extent of urbanization, with its population totaling 6.65 million last year, representing 29.2 percent of the island's population, followed by the Kaohsiung area in the south, with a population of 2.76 million.
According to United Nations statistics, 2 percent of the world's population lived in urban areas in 1800, with the percentage increasing to 30 percent in 1950 and to 48 percent in 2003.

In Taiwan, the population resident in the greater Taipei area and Keelung increased by 540,000 in 2005 in comparison with the figure registered in 1990, while the urban population grew by 530,000 in the central Taichung and Changhua area in the same period of time, with the Chungli and Taoyuan area registering an urban population growth of 520,000 over the past 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOT RESPONDING TO LEGISLATIVE MOTION NOT CONTEMPT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that by choosing not to respond to a legislative motion to recall him, he was acting according to the Constitution and "that absolutely does not mean" he is in contempt of the legislature.

Instead, Chen chose to "report to the people" in a televised speech at the Presidential Office, which he delivered mostly in the Hokkien dialect spoken by a majority of the people in Taiwan. About 30 percent of Taiwan's population, who speak Mandarin, Hakka or aboriginal languages, do not speak Hokkienese.

He refused to allow journalists to ask questions after his speech because he said he did not want the discussion to get "off focus." He noted that he might stage another occasion for journalists to ask him questions.

Under the law, he had until Tuesday to answer charges against him listed in the opposition-initiated recall motion at the legislature. "Very clearly, the Legislative Yuan told me in its official notice that its Committee of the Whole would still go ahead to screen the motion if the intended recallee declines to answer," Chen said.
He said he wrote back to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, telling him that he would not reply to the motion but would instead make a report to the people.
He stressed that he was doing so completely according to constitutional provisions, including constitutional amendments and the law governing the exercise of the legislature's powers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS CAMPAIGN TO RECALL HIM 'CONSTITUTIONALLY DISPUTABLE'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the opposition-backed campaign to recall him is "constitutionally disputable" because he is a popularly elected leader with a fixed term.

Chen made the remarks while receiving Graham Watson, leader of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe in the European Parliament, a day before the Legislative Yuan was set to start reviewing a motion to recall him. The motion was proposed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party in the wake of a recent spate of corruption allegations against Chen's close aides and members of his family.

Chen noted that this is not the first time the opposition has initiated a campaign to recall him and that the previous time they did so was simply over a disagreement with the ruling party on a public policy -- the decision to scrap the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project in 2000.
Chen said that he respects the opposition's moves as long as they are constitutional and that he believes the people of Taiwan have enough wisdom and ability to deal with such a political issue.

On the opposition's plan to launch a no-confidence vote against Premier Su Tseng-chang if the presidential recall motion fails to pass the legislature, Chen said any actions taken by the opposition must follow the Constitution.

Claiming that political stability, Taiwan's democratic foundation and the country's future are what the people are most concerned about, Chen said he will report to the public directly to let them judge for themselves if it is justifiable for the opposition to initiate a motion to recall him.

He pointed out that after the 2004 presidential election, the opposition refused to accept the outcome of the election and occupied the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office for one week until a recount of more than 16 million ballots proved that he won the election.

He stressed that any election disputes should be resolved through judicial means and that the presidential recall motion should also be carried out in accordance with constitutional and legal procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: IF FIRST LADY ACCEPTED SOGO VOUCHERS, I'D STEP DOWN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Tuesday that if his wife Wu Shu-jen is found to have accepted Pacific Sogo Department Store vouchers, he will step down.

The president reiterated the pledge he made in an earlier Presidential Office news release during a televised speech intended to rebut opposition charges against him as listed in a legislative motion to recall him.
In the release, Chen promised that if his wife is found to have ever received Sogo vouchers from Lee Heng-lung, Chang Ming-chiang, Hsu Hsu-tung or Chen Che-nan, he will step down.
"That promise remains effective as of now and will remain effective in the future," he said Tuesday.

He acknowledged that the first lady has shopped at the department store and has used the store's vouchers. "But that does not mean the vouchers she used were given to her as gifts by the four persons," he said.

All of the four except Chen Che-nan are involved in an ownership fight over the department store. Chen Che-nan, now in detention on fraud and other charges, was his deputy secretary-general at the Presidential Office.
Chen claimed that neither he, his wife nor any Presidential Office staff have ever intervened in the ownership fight.
When he heard rumors that some people were using his office's name to gain a business advantage in the matter, he asked his senior aide, Ma Yung-cheng, to find out what was going on, he said.
He claimed that no-one should interfere with the judicial investigation into the ownership fight, and said that whether anyone has broken the law should be determined by the judicial authorities.
"I believe the prosecution and investigation authorities will report all the facts to the public," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN TDC INSIDER TRADING CASE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, have nothing to do with the insider trading case of the Taiwan Land Development Corp., although their son-in-law and his parents are implicated in the scandal.

Appearing on television to defend himself and the first lady against a series of corruption scandals, Chen said that if his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, played a part in the insider trading case, or is involved in other corruption scandals, he deserves to be detained, prosecuted and to receive appropriate sentence.
Chao has been in the custody of the Taipei District Court since late May to answer questions from public prosecutors about his alleged role in the insider trading case.

Initial investigations have found that Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, which is 20 percent state-owned, sold 12.45 million TDC shares it owned to three people, including Chao's mother, Chien Shui-mien, in July 2005 shortly after they obtained information that the financially troubled TDC would be granted a NT$16.5 billion loan from 29 financial institutions.
The president also denied that his family is involved in the electronic toll collection (ETC) scandal.

An administrative court has ruled that the screening process for choosing a private contractor to run the ETC business on the nation's freeways violated the principles of public interest and equality.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPEALS FOR PEOPLE'S SUPPORT IN DISPUTE WITH OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vigorously defended his performance in a nationally televised speech Tuesday in an effort to woo public support for him in his dispute with the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) .

Knowing that the KMT and PFP have little chance of mustering enough votes to pass a recall motion against him in the legislature, the president took to the airwaves to dispute the causes listed by the two opposition parties in their recall motion rather than defend himself at the legislaure.

He defended his wife Wu Shu-jen, who is alleged to have helped a business tycoon take over a loss-making department store in return for huge amounts of gift vouchers in that store, describing the allegations as "groundless" and vowing to step down if the allegations, which are already being investigated by prosecutors, are proved to be true.

Addressing the issue of his son-in-law Chao Chien-ming, who has been detained on suspicion of involvement in the insider trading of stocks in a state-own company, the president said he would give the law enforcement officials a free hand in investigating the case and that Chao should face the legal consequences of his behavior.
Chen said this is also his approach to the case involving his former deputy chief of staff, Chen Che-nan, in detention for taking bribes from businessmen.

As for his political foes' claims that he usurped the constitutional power of the premier by naming his confidants to senior posts in the administration and dictating policy to the Cabinet, Chen claimed he was exercising his power following the Constitution, which was in place long before he was elected.

The Constitution does not oblige the president to name a premier from the majority party in the legislature, Chen argued in response to the "pan blue" charge that he named premiers from his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) "unconstitutionally" because the DPP does not control a majority in the legislature.

Chen said his promise May 31 to stop exercising power beyond those provided for the president in the Constitution should not be considered an acknowledgement that he had wrongfully usurped the powers of the premier.
Instead, Chen argued, it means he will no longer serve as the supreme policy coordinator between the ruling DPP and the Cabinet.

He disputed critics' claims that he practices cronyism by packing the administration with his fund raisers and followers, claiming that those people were appointed because of their knowledge, expertise and experience. "Why brand those able men as my confidants?" he asked.
He said he will not shelter any member of his ruling team and will let justice run its course if they are found to be involved in any wrongdoing.

Chen also defended his decision to cease the function of the National Unification Council in February, a decision branded by the KMT and PFP in their recall motion as a diplomatic bungle that damaged U.S. trust in his administration, saying that the decision, including its wording, was taken only after more than 50 negotiation sessions with the U. S. and only after it was fully understood by Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 21, or the 26th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: The US Constitution comes into effect.
1900: Battles rage in both Beijing and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: Russian composer Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in Scotland's Orkney Islands are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's General Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He had accepted on June 6 General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1976: A 36-member Republic of China delegation to the 22nd Asian Film Festival returns to Taipei from South Korea after winning nine awards.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan calls on free nations to assume moral responsibility for Indo-Chinese and mainland Chinese refugees and to take effective action immediately.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on the nation's agricultural experts to work out concrete measures to expand agricultural development in the country.
1984: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hwa orders an investigation into the cause of the Haishan coal mine disaster.
1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The ROC Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.
1993: An ROC-US agreement for technical cooperation in the field of environmental protection is signed in Washington, D.C.
1996: Leaders of the European Union reach a deal to end the mad cow crisis with Britain.
1997: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, is invited by the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to attend the ceremony marking the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to mainland China at midnight on June 30.
1999: The ROC formally joins the International Council for Small Business (ICSB), becoming the 11th chapter of the world trade body.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui describes US$300 million-worth of aid pledged to Kosovar refugees as "the chance of a thousand years," and urges the public to have empathy as well as a broader mindset.
2000: US Representative Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, submits Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address for insertion in the congressional record.
2001: New Republic of China representatives to Russia and Germany, Charles King and Hu Wei-chen, respectively, are sworn in Taipei and both men promise to further strengthen the nation's ties with the two countries.
2004: SpaceShipOne safely lands in the Mojave Desert in California after completing the first-ever space flight by a privately built spacecraft.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man after 40 is an object of dislike to men, he will continue to be so to the end of his days."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER HOLDS TALKS WITH U.S. SCHOLARS IN N.Y.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 20 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Huang Chih-fang, minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of China, held talks Tuesday with a group of scholars from a New York-based think tank.

Huang told reporters that Taiwan's relations with the United States and China and the situation in Taiwan were the main themes of his dialogue with members of the National Committee of American Foreign Policy.
The U.S. scholars also expressed concerned about the corruption cases involving government officials in Taiwan and the opposition-backed campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian, Huang said.
Huang said these cases have not affected the country's foreign policy or its bid to enter the United Nations.

Also, the minister stressed that his current U.S. visit is not intended for mending fences with Washington after the spat over the arrangements of Chen's planned transit stops in the United States last month.
According to Huang, this matter is over and has not had any negative impact on Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Huang arrived in the United States last week to attend the annual World Forum held by the American Enterprise Institute and the Vail Valley Foundation in Colorado.
Huang is set to depart New York later Tuesday to return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN' LAWMAKERS DECIDE TO BOYCOTT RECALL MOTION REVIEW

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced a recess soon after the extraordinary legislative session began to review an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday as "pan-green camp" lawmakers decided to boycott the process.

Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which together with its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) forms the "pan-green camp, " said the DPP legislative caucus has decided to be absent from all four days of the review process, beginning Wednesday.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has pushed to recall President Chen, believing his leadership is in doubt in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
Huang Shih-cho, a TSU party whip, said TSU legislators will vote against the recall motion during the four days of the extra session set aside exclusively for debates on the motion.

Huang dismissed the "pan-blue alliance's" plan to hold a "testimony-style public hearing" during the extra session, ridiculing the move as "the setting up of a clandestine tribunal to try the president."
He said that if the TSU fails to stop the "recall tribunal, " the TSU legislators may follow the DPP in boycotting the four-day review process.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN TO VISIT U.S., DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang will visit the United States and the Dominican Republic later this month, officials of the pro-independence party said Wednesday.

The officials said that Su will depart Taiwan June 29 for New York, where he is scheduled to call on think tanks and attend the inauguration of the TSU's East Coast chapter and fund-raising dinners before proceeding to the Dominican Republic.
TSU legislators will be unable to accompany Su due to the current extraordinary legislative session which will last until June 30. Su will be accompanied by party officials.
Su is scheduled to return to Taiwan July 10, but he could cut his visit short if there are any unexpected political developments in Taiwan, the officials said.
