DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOLS URGED TO MAKE GOOD USE OF SEX OFFENDER DATA BASE

TEXT.P: Schools and youth social welfare institutions can make good use of a data browsing system the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) recently inaugurated to get information on sex offenders, an MOI official said Wednesday.

Lin Tzu-ling, executive secretary of the ministry's committee in charge of domestic violence and sexual offense prevention, said that the system was inaugurated in April and that the number of sex offenders recorded has reached 131 so far.
LIn estimated that the number will increase, although no schools have applied to look into the information so far.
She said that the number of sexual offenses totaled 3,233 cases in 2005, and the victims in 1,962 cases, or 61 percent of all the cases, were under 18 years old.

To prevent sexual offenders from becoming repeat offenders, the MOI has stipulated that those who are convicted for sex crimes are required to register their home, school and work addresses and other information at police stations every six months for a period of seven years after their release if they were older than 18 when they committed their offense.

Lin urged schools, kindergartens, nurseries and youth social welfare institutions to make use of the system, saying that when they are looking to hire or recruit new staff, they can apply to use the data base to check whether any of the applicants have prior sex-related criminal records.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PROSECUTORS TO SUBPOENA CLOSE FRIEND OF FIRST FAMILY

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Prosecutor's Office said Wednesday that it will subpoena Dr. Huang Fang-yen, a close friend of the first family who was accused by an opposition lawmaker of passing to first lady a huge amount of gift vouchers given by a businessman, for questioning as a witness June 30.

Lin Chin-tsun, a spokesman for the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office, said Huang, a deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Hospital in Taipei who has gone to the United States for health reasons, will be asked to appear at a Taipei court June 30 as a witness in the probe into the alleged scandal surrounding the first lady Wu Shu-jen.

Lin said the prosecutors decided to ask Huang to return to Taipei earlier as they see it as necessary after they gathered further evidence related to the case. Huang has asked for a leave of absence from his job until next month.

If Huang fails to return to Taipei to appear in court June 30, Lin said, the prosecutors will make decisions in accordance with the law after they assess whether Huang has sufficient reasons not to appear in court as requested.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALL CAMPAIGN A BATTLE AGAINST CORRUPTION, INCOMPETENCE: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday defined the KMT-led campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian as a battle against a "corrupt and incompetent" government.
Ma said this is an issue of right and wrong, and he denied that the KMT is initiating a political struggle to try to usurp power.

Ma made the remarks while releasing a joint statement with speakers of 14 county and city councils controlled by the KMT, in which they called on legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union to support the presidential recall motion so as to allow the people to decide whether to unseat Chen.

The Legislative Yuan started reviewing the motion Wednesday and is set to vote on it June 27. If more than two-thirds of the legislators vote in favor of it, the motion will then be put to a national referendum.
As the KMT and its ally, the opposition People First Party, control only a slim majority in the legislature, the odds of the motion passing the legislature are believed to be slim.
Ma claimed that the recall campaign has won the support of a lot of people since it was started two weeks ago, saying that 990,000 people had signed their names to endorse the motion as of Tuesday.

Ma claimed the "corrupt and incompetent" administration led by Chen over the past six years has lost the people's trust and respect, with the president's wife, aides and son-in-law and his son-in-law's family all playing a role in various corruption scandals or the management struggles of financial holding companies.

According to Ma, these people were able to interfere in trading involving millions of New Taiwan dollars because they were Chen's confidants, in-laws or close friends, and the public can no longer tolerate such a situation.
On Chen's claim that he was not aware of the situation and none of these undertakings has anything to do with him, Ma said this shows that Chen has not done a good job as the president.
He stressed that KMT must let Chen hear the voices of the people, who Ma said are expecting the president to give them an answer but are disappointed.
Denying the recall campaign is aimed at usurping power, Ma noted that the DPP will remain in power even if Chen is unseated.
He urged the DPP to stand on the side of justice, integrity and "right" by supporting the recall motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down 43 points to close at 6,316, with 20,587 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July dropped 29 points to finish at 6,254, with 35,676 contracts traded, while September futures lost 28 points to close at 6,142 with 124 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 43 points to close at 6,158, with 19 contracts traded, while March futures rose 49 points to finish at 6,200, with only one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,359 for June, 6,283 for July, 6,170 for September, 6,201 for December and 6,150 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
June TE futures dropped 2.85 points to close at 260.1, with 4,337 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 1.5 points to finish at 256, with 6,598 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 1.8 points to close at 255.2, with 38 contracts traded, while December TE futures dropped 6.2 points to finish at 250.2, with three contracts traded.
March TE futures lost 0.1 points to finish at 257.5, with two contracts traded.

June TF futures moved down 16 points to finish at 944, with 3,071 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures dropped 4.6 points to close at 935.6, with 4,193 contracts traded. September TF futures dropped 16.4 points to close at 921, with eight contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATERMELON FARMERS ELIGIBLE FOR COMPENSATION FOR RAIN-CAUSED DAMAGE

TEXT.P: Watermelon farmers in Taoyuan County who suffered crop losses due to recent torrential rains are eligible for compensation or low-interest loans, Council of Agriculture officials said Wednesday.

The torrential rains this month had caused agricultural losses totalling nearly NT$1.08 billion (US$33.4 million) as of June 20, with persimmon, rice, watermelon, grape and pear fields being hardest hit.
Watermelon fields in Taoyuan County have been listed by the COA as "seriously-hit" farmlands whose owners can apply for compensation or low-interest loans.

According to COA statistics, among the 403 hectares of watermelon fields in Taoyuan County, 314 hectares have been affected by the torrential rains, with crops on 169 hectares being completely destroyed.

According to COA regulations, farmers who suffered complete crop losses on more than 20 percent of their watermelon fields can apply for NT$50,000 in compensation for each hectare, while other watermelon farmers who suffered less damage to their farmland can apply for low-interest loans equivalent to NT$750,000 for each hectare of farmland damaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: President Napolitano calls on citizens to vote in referendum.
President Giorgio Napolitano urged citizens to vote in the upcoming referendum on an amendment to the Constitutional which will be held June 25-26. Napolitano said in a visit to his native city of Napoli that a better turnout of voters will produce a larger consensus of the society, no matter how the result of the referendum on the constitutional reform will be.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: P100 B a year for projects -- GMA President Arroyo yesterday said the government will invest more on infrastructure, education, agriculture and other sectors by as much as P100 billion a year if the government's fiscal reform program proceeds as projected by the country'seconomic managers.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Gov't troops going full blast against NPA rebels
MOVING FULL BLAST against communist rebels, defense officials yesterday announced they would pull out soldiers doubling as bodyguards of politicians and VIPs and send them into battle, as Church leaders appealed to Malacanang to give peace a chance.
The Philippine Star: 'No political will to fight graft' Malacanang's P1-billion allocation for its anti-corruption campaign would get nowhere because the Arroyo administration has no political will to clean up the government, according to opposition senators.
The Manila Times: 3,000 troops sent to 3 NPA hotbeds AT least 3,000 troops are being retrained and redeployed as part of a two-year campaign to crush the communist insurgency in three key areas in Luzon, Defense Secretary Avelino Cruz said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CALLS FOR CALM IF PRESIDENTIAL RECALL VOTE FAILS

TEXT.P: Both the ruling and opposition camps should stay calm if a "pan-blue alliance"-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian fails at the Legislative Yuan next week, Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday.
Lu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after attending the 50th anniversary of the National Institute of Educational Resources and Research.

The previous evening, Chen gave a televised address that Lu described as "a comprehensive report" to defend his position regarding a string of corruption allegations involving his family and aides in response to the recall motion that aims to hold Chen accountable.

The corruption cases should be left for the judicial system to deal with and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" should not make accusations without solid evidence, she said, urging both camps to maintain "cool heads" should the presidential recall vote fail to pass the Legislative Yuan June 27, as "everything should proceed in line with the Constitution."
The vice president also reiterated her oft-stated view that Taiwan must forge its own "blue sea strategy" to create new opportunities to ensure national security and improve the people's livelihoods.
Meanwhile, Yu Shyi-kun, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , described Chen's TV performance as "prudent."

According to Yu, Chen gave a concrete and clear response to the opposition's speculation about his role in the many corruption scandals and displayed his full respect for the judicial system by not mentioning individual cases being investigated by prosecutors.

However, DPP lawmaker Lee Wen-chung said his performance showed that Chen is "an eloquent lawyer rather than a president wishing to apologize, " because he failed to directly answer several questions key to the people, such as whether first lady Wu Shu-jen accepted huge amounts of gift certificates from the Sogo Department Store.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS AUTHORITIES TO CONTROL JUVENILE DELINQUENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang instructed the relevant authorities Wednesday to work out measures to prevent and control juvenile delinquency, which he said is likely to increase during the upcoming summer vacation.

Su said during a weekly Cabinet meeting that summer vacation is the period when teenagers can easily be tempted to engage in activities such as "late-night loitering, " illegal car racing, fighting and drug abuse.

Also, Su said, teenagers might fall victim to scams when they try to find summer jobs and he ordered the Ministry of Education (MOE) , the Council of Labor Affairs, the National Youth Commission and the Government Information Office to step up publicity to remind students to pay attention to this problem.

The authorities should also cooperate with the private sector to arrange for various learning opportunities and recreational activities for teenagers during summer vacation and make available related information on the MOE's official Web site, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD TAIPEI 2006 OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2006 Taipei International Food Show opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Wednesday with exhibitors from 32 countries participating.

Hsu Chih-jen, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , presided over a ceremony at the Taipei International Convention Center to officially open the show, which will run through June 24.

Foodtech Taipei and Taipei Pack, as well as a dozen seminars concerning the food industry are also being held concurrently with Food Taipei 2006 at the same venue, said officials from TAITRA -- the key sponsor of the show.

Also Wednesday, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and Hsu jointly cut the ribbon to open the Taiwan Foods Pavilion -- the largest of all the national pavilions taking part in the show -- where 72 companies put their flagship or latest products on display.
The 1,548 sq. ft. Taiwan Pavilion is divided into eight sections, featuring fruit and vegetables, tea, fish products, rice, husbandry, forestry and processed food products.

Addressing the ceremony, Su said the Taiwan Pavilion serves two purposes -- to allow consumers from around the world to find out more about Taiwan-produced quality foods or signature foods with local features on one hand, while on the other, tipping domestic consumers that they can source "almost all kinds" of high-quality foods from within Taiwan, saving on expensive imports.
Also praising Taiwan-produced foods, Hsu said Taiwan and its farmers are one of the luckiest groups in the world in terms of producing high-quality agricultural products.

Hsu said many Japanese importers have shifted from other Asian countries to Taiwan for their food imports, after realizing that Taiwan foods cannot be replaced by counterparts from other Asian countries, where food may be cheaper in price but can suffer from shabby quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, June 21 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Chinese Buy Udmurtneft for Rosneft
Chinese state oil company Sinopec has agreed to buy TNK-BP's Udmurtneft, giving Beijing its first stake in Russian oil and paving the way for a strategic partnership with Rosneft. [ By ChangHung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG RALLY TO BE HELD AS SCHEDULED: KMT SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: A rally to be oranized by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) June 24 in southern Kaohsiung city to demand President Chen Shui-bian's resignation will be held as planned, despite reported pressure from the central government, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Wednesday.
Cheng made the comments at a news conference at the KMT headquarters.

Saying that the KMT applied to sponsor the rally at the National Science and Technology Museum in Kaohsiung through due process and has already announced it to the public, Cheng stressed that the party will not go back on its decision to stage the protest and she accused the central government of exercising strong pressure on local government officials.

What the central government of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has reportedly done damages Taiwan's democracy because the people are entitled to assemble and protest in a free society, she said.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party has held a series of demonstrations and activities, including initiating a presidential recall vote June 27 at the Legislative Yuan, hoping to force Chen to step down to assume responsibility for the many corruption scandals allegedly involving his family and close aides.
Chen gave a televised speech Tuesday night in an attempt to distance himself from the corruption scandals, stirring up polarized responses from the opposition and ruling camps.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER QUESTIONS 'INTEGRITY' THEME OF OPPOSITION'S RECALL BID

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang questioned Wednesday the "integrity" of the opposition, which has made "integrity" the theme of its recall bid to unseat President Chen Shui-bian over his incompetence and corruption allegations against his family and close associates.

He also urged the opposition to stop political infighting and focus on issues related to public welfare in the hope that a special budget for flood prevention can clear the legislature as soon as possible.
Su was responding to the opposition-initiated recall motion to oust Chen, which began a four-day review at the legislative Committee of the Whole Wednesday before the matter is put to a vote June 27.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party initiated the recall, convinced that Chen has lost the public trust in the wake of a string of corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides.
However, Su questioned the legitimacy of the recall bid, which has "safeguard Taiwan with integrity" as its theme.

He said that a man will be dealt with harshly if he robs others, but pointed out that "a party, " referring to the KMT, has stolen hundreds of billions of dollars from the nation, has refused to return it, and has used it to line its own pockets.

As early as 2001, the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, had requested that the Executive Yuan look into the matter thoroughly, Su said. The results show that land under the KMT name but rightfully belonging to the nation amounted to 145 hectares, with a market value of more than NT$20 billion (US$615.38 million).
But the KMT has only returned two hectares of ill-gotten assets so far, he said.
"Can a party who has robbed from the nation billions of dollars call itself a party of integrity?" he asked.

He said the Executive Yuan has requested the Legislative Yuan to review a draft bill concerning the party's ill-gotten assets since 2002, but has been blocked by the KMT for the 42nd time and has not cleared the legislature.

He also noted that the opposition-dominated legislature has also blocked an arms procurement package from the United States for the 56th time, even though Taiwan is under growing threat from China, and asked how this can be construed as "safeguarding Taiwan."

The Executive Yuan requested an extraordinary legislative session to speed up the passage of a number of priority bills, Su went on, but he lamented that the opposition has made the recall bid a priority even though it is unlikely to pass because it will require the consent of two-thirds of the lawmakers in the 221-seat legislature, where the opposition only maintains a slim majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS NOT OBLIGED TO ATTEND LEGISLATURE'S REVIEW OF RECALL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's resolution to oblige appointed officials at the Executive Yuan to attend its debate over a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian is not binding, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Cheng Wen-tsang, minister of the Government Information Office, said after a weekly Cabinet meeting that Minister without Portfolio Hsu chih-hsiung invited officials from related agencies to study the resolution passed earlier that day by the Committee of Whole at the legislature and determined that it is not legally binding.

The legislature cannot exert its power to investigate executive actions and wrongdoing before a law regulating its exercise is enacted. Until then, the legislature's resolution means nothing more than the lawmakers' desire.

The government spokesman cited an interpretation of the Council of Grand Justices that the legislature cannot compel officials to attend its sessions or administer punishment to those who ignore its requirements unless such moves are provided for under the law.

The spokesman also denied the Committee of Whole's power to order the executive branch to come up with official documents for its examination, saying that the power belongs to individual committees and not the Committee of Whole which is made up of all lawmakers.
The Executive Yuan's decision is in line with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party efforts to boycott the recall motion by walking out of the chamber en masse.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO STEP UP MARKETING OF AGRICULTURE PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will start a new publicity campaign next week to step up domestic marketing of agricultural products, COA Chairman Su Jia-chyuan said Wednesday.
Su said the COA will place advertisements at major crossroads, subway stations, railway stations and airports to introduce Taiwan consumers to domestic agricultural products.
He made the announcement while attending the opening of the 2006 Taipei International Food Show.
Su said it is the COA's dream to bring about new breakthroughs in Taiwan's agricultural sector.

According to Su, local farmers should realize that they must produce the freshest, safest and highest-quality products in order to compete with the rest of the world, while consumers should also change their consumption habits and should not make price the only consideration when selecting agricultural products.
The government, meanwhile, should adopt a new concept and prioritize marketing, Su said.

He noted that in the past, the government thought that it was a matter of course for local consumers to buy domestic agricultural products, but this is not the case now that more and more foreign agricultural products are being imported into the country.

Likening the agricultural sector to the heart of a country, Su said many industrial products will be of no use if there is no agriculture to sustain the lives of the people, and that the government must therefore attach importance to the agricultural sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENT TO COMPETE IN WORLD HAIRSTYLING CONTEST IN MOSCOW

TEXT.P: A student from Kaohsiung County who won a national hairstyling contest sponsored by the Organization Mondiale Coiffure (OMC) in April, is set to head for Moscow to take part in a world hairstyling contest.

Yang You-jen, a student from Shu Te University in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, who is majoring in fashion design, will take part in the OMC-sponsored HairWorld Moscow 2006 slated for July 1-3, school sources said Wednesday.
Yang was awarded a scholarship of NT$100,000 by Shu Te University President Chu Yuan-hsiang Wednesday for winning the championship of the OMC 2006 competition held in the Taiwan area.

Speaking at the award-presentation ceremony, Yang, whose parents are both veteran hairstylists, told of how he used to hate the hairstyling career that his parents chose, how he later became intrigued by the trade and then became of the country's top stylists.

Yang will meet contestants from around the world at OMC's 2006 HairWorld Championship of Beauty in Moscow, hoping to win the competition so he will be entitled to even higher prize money from his school -- ascholarship of NT$450,000 awarded to winners of gold medals in world-class competitions such as the OMC contest.

OMC is a Paris-based organization established to recognize distinguished hairstylists and salon professionals from around the world and to allow them to demonstrate their skills, talent and creativity regularly.
Yang, who won a national hairstyling contest sponsored by the Council of Labor Affairs last year, is also scheduled to take part in a similar competition to be held in Japan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LET PEOPLE DECIDE WHETHER TO RECALL PRESIDENT: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Opposition legislators who initiated a legislative motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian urged their "pan-green camp" rivals Wednesday to help pass the motion so the people will have a chance to vote on it in a national referendum.

Ting Shou-chung of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) challenged ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers to honor the president's wish that it should be the people, not the legislators, who decide whether or not he should serve until his official term expires in May 2008.
"The president said last night that he was willing to allow his fate to be decided by the 23 million people of Taiwan," Ting said.

Ting made his remarks as the Legislative Yuan's Committee of the Whole began to review the recall motion, focusing on the subject of "a declining economy" that the opposition has blamed on Chen's poor leadership.

Ting, Luo Shih-hsiung of the KMT and Lu Hsueh-chang of the People First Party (PFP) said Chen's government does not have a good record in terms of integrity, as can be seen from a string of corruption scandals that are being investigated by judicial authorities.

Moreover, they claimed, the government is almost broke, while unemployment has risen and the suicide rate has soared -- a track record that they claim proves that the president and his government are incompetent and no longer fit to rule the country.

"We are pushing the recall motion to stop high-level corruption and keep the government engine from revving in neutral, " they claimed, adding that the motion is by no means intended to provoke political feuding between the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP and the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the TSU.

Since it is the president's wish to give the population a chance to judge his administrative record, the "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers called on their "pan-green" rivals to help the motion clear the two-thirds majority threshold in the legislature so that the people can pass their judgment in a referendum.

They suggested that the legislature invite Chen, his wife Wu Shu-jen and former DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung to confront each other in the legislature in regard to the controversy over whether Wu accepted political donations from former Tuntex Group Chairman Chen You-hao.

Chen, a criminal on the run in the United States and China, claims that he met Wu in the company of Shen and handed cash to her for political campaign funds, an accusation Wu denies. However, Shen himself has recently confirmed that such a meeting did take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.029 to close at NT$32.625.
A total of US$784 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.596 and fluctuated between NT$32.551 and NT$32.655.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO SUSPEND PLAN TO BUY NEW FLEET DUE TO RISING FUEL PRICES
DOC.DATELINE: Toulouse, France, June 21 (CNA) (By Feng Chao and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Airlines (CLA) will temporarily suspend a plan to purchase a new fleet of planes due to rising fuel prices, CAL Chairman Wei Hsin-hsiung said Wednesday.

Wei made the remarks while presiding over an Airbus A330-300 delivery ceremony in the French city of Toulouse, the 11th of 14 Airbus A330-300s CAL has decided to buy or rent. The three remaining planes are expected to be delivered by the end of 2007.

He said that long-haul flights will be hard to get profits from because of the rising oil prices and that even if the company phases out its aging planes, it will still have large aircraft as the priority and will not consider medium-sized aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slid Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 63.96 points to close at 6,299.59.
The bourse opened at 6,354.43 and fluctuated between 6,399.22 and 6,290.63 during trading. A total of 2.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.33 billion (US$2.49 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 4.5 percent, followed by construction shares at 4.4 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 2.2 percent, machinery and electronics stocks at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 1.1 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent and banking and financial issues at 0.5 percent.
Plastic and chemical shares grew 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 724 to 146, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG CITY TO BAN DISPOSABLE DISHWARE IN JULY

TEXT.P: Disposable tableware will be banned from government establishments in the central city of Taichung starting from July, a spokesman for the city's Bureau of Environmental Protection said Wednesday.

Besides government departments, public and private schools in the city will also have to adhere to the restriction starting from September when the new semester begins. Fines of between NT$600 and NT$1,200 will be handed out to establishments that do not comply with the new rules.
The spokesman said disposable tableware creates too much garbage, while toxic substances released into the atmosphere when it is incinerated makes it harmful to people's health.
The spokesman added that many people now carry their own tableware and that government establishments must take the initiative to ban disposable tableware.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG RING BUSTED IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Police Wednesday cracked a drug ring in the northern city of Taoyuan, seizing more than 50,000 methamphetamine pills smuggled from Thailand.
Three suspects -- a Taiwanese man, a woman and a man of Burmese nationality -- were nabbed in the raid.
The two Taiwanese are suspected of bringing the pills into Taiwan hidden in food cans, police said.

The drugs are mostly sold to Thai workers working in the Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli areas, police said. Preliminary investigations also found that the drugs are sold to the Thai workers through drugstores selling Thai goods and in restaurants catering to Thai workers, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PER CAPITA GDP MIGHT REACH US$30,000 IN 2015: CIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan could enjoy a per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of US$30,000 in 2015 with proper economic policies, Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) Chairman Vincent Siew predicted Wednesday.

Siew's remarks were part of a report on Taiwan's economic prospects in 2015 conducted by five of Taiwan's major economic think tanks -- CIER, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, the Taiwan Thinktank, the Taiwan Research Institute and Academia Sinica.
The report, which was commissioned by Premier Su Tseng-chang, is expected to be published Friday, the 25th anniversary of CIER.
At an interview with CNA, Siew noted that the success of future markets will hinge on who can provide the best value-added services to clients.
With the research of the think tanks, Siew said he believes Taiwan can see its GDP jump significantly by promoting what he described as "3B" (bridge, brain and branding).

"Bridge means Taiwan should open its market further and make more connections with the rest of the world, " Siew said, suggesting that Taiwan open direct links with China and not impose too many limitations on its marine transport to and from China.
"Brain means Taiwan should try its best to attract and cultivate talent, while branding means domestic companies should set up their own brand names," he added.

The report envisions an economic outline for Taiwan in 2015 with the hope that the country's economic growth might top 5 percent, the per capita GDP can reach US$30,000, and the unemployment rate can be reduced to under 4 percent, while the production of specialists such as accountants and lawyers will account for 45 percent of the total service industry.

Noting that the future economic battlefield will be a global competition in value-added services, Siew claimed that Taiwan has a good chance thanks to its advantage in scientific development and talent cultivation.
However, the success will need far-sighted policies and various incentives provided by the government to the service industry.

With Taiwan's unique economic characteristics, in which small- and medium-sized enterprises (SME's) are full of dynamism, Siew suggested that the government incentives should not focus on giant companies, but rather on the SMEs, which Siew said can increase the country's development space and avoid Taiwan companies being marginalized.
With the production of the service industry accounting for more than 70 percent of Taiwan's GDP, Siew urged the service industry to elevate its professionalism and internationalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CENTRAL EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE MIGHT DECIDE NEW LEGISLATIVE HOPEFULS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will change its nomination regulations for the next legislature if the current legislature is dissolved, the DPP Central Standing Committee proposed at its weekly meeting Wednesday.

The participants in the meeting proposed that the DPP Central Executive Committee should nominate the party's candidates if the current legislature is dissolved by the president, forcing a new legislative election to be held within 60 days of the dissolution.
They pointed out that if a regular primary is held, it might not be able to produce candidates in time.
The proposal will be submitted for discussion at a DPP congress to be held next month, they added.

The proposal came in the wake of an opposition People First Party (PFP) threat to topple the Cabinet if its bid to recall President Chen Shui-bian over what the party claims is his incompetence, coupled with corruption allegations against his family and close associates, fails.

DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng said that after Chen delivered a "report to the nation" Tuesday in response to an opposition-initiated recall motion, the DPP legislators were "in high spirits" and "up in arms for a possible fight."
It would rather have the legislature dissolved than give in to the demands of the opposition, Gao said.
DPP Central Standing Committee member Cheng Pao-Ching said the DPP should study other complementary measures to deal with possible situations in hot or controversial constituencies.

The party has initially planned that for constituencies with more than one hopeful, public polls will be conducted as a reference as to who should be picked. For constituencies with no hopefuls, the party chairman will recruit them, drawing from political appointees and respected figures from all walks of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEA PRODUCERS FROM 16 COUNTRIES VIE FOR TAIWAN'S AWARDS

TEXT.P: The first World Tea Awards, sponsored by the Taiwan Commercial Tea Guild Union, began Wednesday in central Taiwan, with some 800 entries submitted by tea producers in 16 countries going through preliminary screening.
Participating countries include Canada, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia and Thailand, as well as the host, Taiwan.

A panel of three judges will spend five days selecting the best entries of Oolong tea, green tea and black tea to qualify for the final round in the competition. All entries are identified by secret codes to ensure impartiality.
The judges will conduct screening based on five criteria: the shape of the tea leaves, the color of the tea's liquid, its smell, taste and leftover tea leaves.

During the final round of the competition in Mingchien township, Nantou County, from June 26 to 28, a judge from Japan and another from South Korea will join their Taiwanese counterparts to select the top 5 percent of entries for gold medals, 10 percent for silver medals and 20 percent for bronze medals.
The first-prize winner in the top 5 percent will receive a cash award of NT$1 million (US$30,650) and gain authorization to market its product under the title, "the best tea in the world."
A ceremony will take place Aug. 12 to present the award and medals, followed by an auction for buyers to bid for the prize-winning entries.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE CONDEMNS PRESIDENT FOR NOT RESPONDING TO RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Deputy Speaker Chung Jung-chi condemned President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday for snubbing the legislature's invitation to respond to a legislative motion aimed at ousting the head of state.

Chung chaired a Committee of the Whole meeting to review the opposition-initiated recall motion, a motion Chen chose to ignore by speaking directly to what he called "the whole population" in his native Hokkien dialect Tuesday night.

The president chose not to respond, not to explain, and not to cooperate with the legislature, Chung said. Rather, the president chose to ignore the legislature's execution of its official duties, he accused.
"The president's behavior is regrettable and incomprehensible, and I must protest and denounce it in my capacity as chairman of the Committee of the Whole meeting," Chung said.

He also upbraided Economic Affairs Minister Hwang Ing-san, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng and Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Su Chia-chuan for failing to appear in the meeting to discuss why the country's economy has been in decline.

While the Cabinet ministers boycotted the first meeting to review the recall motion, other invitees such as National Chengchi University Professor Lin Tzu-chia, former National Science Council Vice Chairman Hsueh Hsiang-chuan and former COA Chairman Lin Hsiang-neng were present.

The legislature will hold three more such meetings before voting on the motion on June 27. If more than two-thirds of legislators approve the motion, it will then have to be endorsed by half of voters in a national referendum to go into effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: GOP Plans Hearings on Issue of Immigrants; Field Sessions May Delay Talks on Hill.
In a move that could bury President Bush's high-profile effort to overhaul immigration law until after the midterm elections, House GOP leaders yesterday announced a series of field hearings during the August recess, pushing off final negotiations on a bill until fall at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: House Plan May Delay Immigration Overhaul
U.S. House Republican leaders said Tuesday that they would hold summer hearings around the nation on immigration before trying to compromise with the Senate. The unusual decision to set a new round of hearings on legislation already passed by the House and the Senate places a serious roadblock in the way of President Bush's drive for major changes in immigration policy.
Wall Street Journal: Twisting Trail, U.S. Falls Behind In Tracking Cattle To Control Disease
When the first U.S. case of mad-cow disease was discovered in December 2003, then-Secretary of Agriculture Ann M. Veneman pledged to hasten creation of a national identification system for tracing livestock quickly during a disease outbreak. Today, more than two years later, the U.S. still has no national ID system for most farm animals, including chickens and beef cattle. An ID system would assign each animal a unique number, and record all its movements as it travels to new ranches, farms or other destinations. This tracking information could prove critical in controlling outbreaks of contagious diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSPORT REGULATIONS TO BE AMENDED TO INCLUDE PENALTIES

TEXT.P: Trade in passports and use of counterfeit will be punishable according to a draft package of amendments to the existing passport statute, a Cabinet spokesman said Wednesday.

The spokesman made the remarks after the Cabinet approved at its weekly meeting a draft package proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) that is in step with the government's decision to crack down on passport-related crime.

Premier Su Tseng-chang was quoted as having said at the Cabinet meeting that the government is determined to meet international standards of safety and convenience now that countries around the world have stepped up travel document security as part of the global war on terrorism in the wake of the "911" terrorist attacks.

This new round of revisions focuses on two points -- the inclusion of regulations providing for the inscription of personal data and photo into the passport's built-in chip and the prevention of passport-related crime, the premier added.

According to the MOFA-drafted amendments, those involved in the trade of passports, those who use their passports as collateral that may lead to damaging the public interest, or anyone who otherwise improperly uses passports may face a maximum five-year prison term plus a fine of up to NT$500,000.

The same penalties apply to those who provide their personal data and identification cards to criminal rings or other individuals to apply for passports, as well as anyone involved in passport forgery or tampering.

The draft package will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval in the near future, the spokesman said, adding that relevant government agencies will strengthen communications with legislative caucuses of various political parties to ensure the smooth passage of the amendment package at an early date.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW INVESTMENT PROJECTS IN FIRST FIVE MONTHS VALUED AT NT$519 BILLION

TEXT.P: The number of new investment projects launched by Taiwan's private sector during the first five months of this year has reached 522, with a value totaling NT$519.1 billion (US$15,792 million), officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Wednesday.
The officials noted that these new investment projects by the nation's private sector in the first five months already account for 57 percent of the goal for this year, or NT$903.2 billion.

Among the various industries, the electronic and information sector launched the bulk of new investment projects during the period, with NT$328.8 billion, followed by the metal, machinery and electrical sectors with NT$112.4 billion, the chemical sector with NT$52.7 billion, the technical service industry with NT$14.5 billion, and electricity supply with NT$1.3 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP URGES PRAYER FOR LESS PRIVILEGED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The World Vision Taiwan (WVT), a Christian group that is committed to helping the world's poor and less privileged, urged Christians in Taiwan Wednesday to choose a day in the coming two months to pray for families in distress and the famine-stricken children around the world.
The event is part of the WVT-sponsored "30-Hour Fast" program which asks participants to fast for 30 hours to experience the pain of famine.

Many Christian celebrities, including actor-turned volunteer Sun Yueh, attended a WVT news conference Wednesday to show their support for the WVT's appeal for local Christians to choose a day between June 22 and Aug. 30 to pray for families in distress and famine-stricken children in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADER CALLS FOR 'INTEGRITY COMPETITION' WITH RULING DPP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou used half an hour of televised remarks Wednesday to respond to President Chen Shui-bian's two-hour speech the previous evening, urging Chen to step down before losing more respect from the people and calling on ruling party members to engage in a "competency and integrity competition" with his party.

The recall motion the KMT and People First Party (PFP) are pushing in the legislature is not aimed at provoking a fight or seizing power, Ma told his "friends" in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Rather, he said, the motion is aimed at creating a clean and competent government that would make Taiwan's democracy a source of pride for its population.

"Let's not engage in a competition of corruption. Let's engage ourselves in a competition of competency and integrity for the dignity of our people, for our democracy and for the future of our children," he urged his DPP rivals.
Ma reminded Chen that in ancient China, even an emperor would confess guilt in the face of social chaos and economic hardship brought about by the ruler's incompetency and negligence of duty.
Ma said when Chen's son-in-law and senior aides were charged with various criminal offenses, the president can no longer claim he should not be implicated.
"You have political responsibility to accept, although no criminal evidence has been found to be not in your favor," he said.

He claimed that throughout the two-hour speech, the president had not squarely faced opposition charges as listed in the recall motion. Instead, the president tried to evade real answers to the opposition's questions and tried to fan ethnic divisions in Taiwan's polarized society.

If Chen insisted on creating even greater division in society just for the sake of saving his own political career, he would only cause ever more serious harm to Taiwan, Ma said, urging "President Chen" to make the best choice both for himself and for Taiwan -- before it is too late.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR FINED NT$200,000 F0R MARKETING SHAM HEALTH FOOD

TEXT.P: The Health Bureau of Chiayi County in southern Taiwan fined state-owned Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) NT$200,000 Wednesday for using animal feed to produce sham health food.

A spokesman said the bureau imposed the heaviest penalty possible under the Food Sanitation and Management Act because Taisugar's nutritional yeast products made of imported hog feed posed a serious hazard to consumers' health.

Taisugar recalled all such products June 15 after public prosecutors in Tainan detained a former Taisugar executive and an importer for supplying hog feed to the company to produce health products for human consumption for the past 13 years.

Lin Ying-hua, a manager in charge of food production at Taisugar's Hsinying plant, and Tseng Teh-fu, former owner of an import firm were taken into custody for supplying "performance protein powder" to Taisugar to manufacture nutritional yeast products, including vitamin yeast, flavored vitamin yeast and yeast candy.

According to prosecutors, the performance protein powder was imported at a low cost from Egypt and Belgium, and the customs declaration forms stated clearly the material was not for human consumption.
Taisugar has admitted there were "some problems" with the company's internal controls and has apologized to consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD'S JAPAN VISIT WOULD BE GOOD: DPP OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 21 (CNA) (By M. C. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: It would be good if Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou could visit Japan in July as planned, and he should use the opportunity to explore Japanese viewpoints, a ranking official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Visiting DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung made the remarks to Taiwanese reporters in Tokyo, where he has attended a U.S.-Japan- Taiwan security forum and met with several influential figures of the Liberal Democratic Party -- Japan's ruling party.

According to Lin, he has been asked repeatedly about "a critical 2008" or "a stormy 2008" during his current visit in Japan, and suggested that Ma clarify his stance toward Taiwan's future ties with China.
The year 2008 is critical because Beijing will host the Olympic Games and China may further fan nationalistic sentiment among its population to underscore its status as a big power, he claimed.
In the same year, the United States will also hold presidential elections, and Washington is likely to tighten its stance toward China in bilateral trade and economic relations, Lin speculated.

As Taiwan will also elect a new president in 2008, the newly elected head of state must be capable of speaking for Taiwan's people and be fully aware of where to lead the nation in a complicated international situation, Lin stressed, adding that Taiwan cannot afford to have a president who is unpredictable.
Lin said the Japan-U.S. security alliance is extremely important to Taiwan, and Taiwan's advantage lies in its democratization and a booming foreign trade despite facing threats from China.

It would be good if Ma visited Japan next month and he should use the occasion to gain an understanding of how the Japanese view him, Lin said, adding that his positions regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations, self-determination and the Japan-U.S. security alliance would be thoroughly examined by 2008 if he wants to take part in the next presidential race.
Ma should make his stance better known to Japan during his coming visit, Lin suggested.
The international community has been closely watching Ma and will continue to do so, especially where he would lead Taiwan and the possible impact of his election in Asia, Lin said.

Ma, chairman of Taiwan's largest opposition party, has widely been viewed as the KMT's best bet for the 2008 presidential election in a polarized society split by ethnic issues and the independence-unification dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU STUDENT CALLS FOR SIT-IN TO URGE PRESIDENT CHEN'S SUSPENSION

TEXT.P: A National Taiwan University (NTU) student is calling on other students at Taiwan's universities and colleges to join him in a sit-in, appealing for President Chen Shui-bian's temporary suspension from office to allow full judicial investigation into corruption allegations involving Chen's senior aides and family members.

Wang Chen-ya, a sophomore at NTU's Department of International Business, has sent out an e-mail calling on other university students to join him in the 80-hour sit-in in front of Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall opposite the Presidential Office from 2 p.m. June 24.
The e-mail says all students who participate in the activity will not issue any statements or accept media interviews.

Queried by the CNA about the reaction of NTU authorities, Feng Yen, the dean of student affairs, said the university will not interfere in the activity because it is being carried out by an individual outside the university's campus.
However, Feng said, the university will urge Wang and any other students who participate to pay attention to their own safety and refrain from doing anything against the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DID WU SHU-JEN TAKE SOGO VOUCHERS OR NOT?' KMT'S MA ASKS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Wednesday that President Chen Shui-bian had not shown any remorse while addressing the nation a day earlier, saying it was another indication the president is no longer fit to rule the country.
For example, Ma said, Chen assured the public that his wife Wu Shu-jen "did not directly accept" the controversial Pacific Sogo Department Store gift vouchers.
"What does that mean, not directly? Did she accept the vouchers, or not? If she took them indirectly, from whom?" Ma asked.

The president used two full hours to address the nation without giving a clear answer to a question that most people are most interested in, Ma said during a half-hour of televised remarks responding to Chen's address.

Titling his speech "Recovering Taiwan's Justice and Conscience," Ma called on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) members to retrieve the party's founding values of "integrity, diligence and love of country" and to be ambitious enough to engage in a "competition of competency and integrity" rather than a "competition of corruption" with the KMT and other opposition parties.

Ma also urged judicial prosecutors and investigators to do their jobs professionally and conscientiously, reminding them that getting at all the facts about high-level corruption would not cost them their career since politicians come and go and since they are paid by the people, not by politicians.

"I know you must be under great pressure when investigating high officials and relatives of a president, as my experience as minister of justice has taught me," Ma said, encouraging the prosecution and investigators to set an example of "what professionals should be doing in a great democracy."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES DPP TO 'CLEAN ITS OWN HOUSE'

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday to "clean its own house" at a time when a legislative motion is at stake to recall President Chen Shui-bian over corruption allegations involving top aides and family members.
In a 30-minute televised rebuttal to Chen's two-hour speech in his defense a day earlier, Ma said the DPP's support for Chen will only "cause him [Chen] more harm."
The KMT would not like to see the DPP sink deeper into a moral quagmire, Ma stressed, adding that the two parties should compete in a constructive manner rather than fighting against each other.
He added that the KMT and DPP should compete by showing to the public which is cleaner and more capable, rather than constantly trying to "fight and kill."

Noting that DPP heavyweights have refrained from criticizing the president's family members who have been implicated in corruption scandals, Ma said, "This is not the Democratic Progressive Party we have come to know."
The KMT chairman added that he is "very disappointed" the DPP has chosen to side with corruption.

He also said the KMT will focus efforts on the recall motion pending in the legislature. As for whether the KMT and its ally, the People First Party, will push for a no-confidence vote in the legislature to topple the Cabinet if the recall bid fails, Ma said he would address the matter after the final results of the recall motion are known.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER SEES DISCREPANCY BETWEEN WORDS, DEEDS OF KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that there is a discrepancy between the words and deeds of main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

Hsieh made the comments after Ma ripped into President Chen Shui-bian in a 30-minute televised speech, in which Ma urged Chen to resign because "his incompetence and corrupt family" were dragging down Taiwan.
If Ma were truly concerned about the country's social stability and economic well-being, Hsieh said, Ma should not have let his party initiate the legislative motion to recall President Chen.

Long before the recall motion -- which has stirred political turmoil and drived down the stock market in recent weeks -- Hsieh lamented that the KMT and its "pan-blue" ally, the People First Party, have spared virtually no efforts to stymie government operations by blocking the passage of many critical bills, including special budget appropriations for flood prevention projects and investment rules governing state-run enterprises.

Deeds speak louder than words, Hsieh said, adding that he cannot but doubt Ma's sincerity when Ma said the president should step down for the sake of people's livelihoods or to save the government from "revving in neutral."
Ma's verbal assault came one day after President Chen gave a two-hour televised address defending himself against the opposition-led campaign for his recall.
Hsieh expressed concern about the ongoing political upheaval, saying it seemed the nation is gradually heading toward an "abyss of mutual destruction."
"I'm hopeful that Ma will take the lead to reverse this ominous trend since the pan-blue alliance holds a slight majority in the legislature," Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 22 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, June 22:
09:15, Vice Interior Minister Yen Wan-chin will attend a seminar in Kaohsiung on response measures for domestic violence and sexual assault cases.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.
17:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with representatives of several of his supporters groups, including the Taiwan Society North and the Taiwan Society South.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS REBUT KMT CHIEF'S CHARGES AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rebutted main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's salvo of accusations against President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday as "flawed reasoning and double standards."

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and the party's legislative caucus whips, including Ker Chien-ming, made the comments after Ma delivered a 30-minute televised speech urging President chen to resign to take political responsibility for corruption allegations against his aides and family.

Yu said Ma used double standards in measuring the DPP administration. He reminded Ma that many fugitive economic criminals are KMT members. "Ma should ask them to return to Taiwan to stand trial before questioning the DPP's integrity," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO PUSH BEIJING TO TALK WITH DPP ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: The United States should continue urging China to hold dialogue with Taiwan's democratically elected government to mend their differences and promote peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, a mainland policy planner said Wednesday.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee who is in Taipei for a visit.

Noting that freedom and democracy are shared values of Taiwan and the United States, Wu said he hopes the U.S. government will adhere to its freedom- and democracy-centered foreign policy and continue pushing Beijing authorities to conduct talks with Taiwan's democratically elected government.

Beijing has consistently rejected Taiwan's olive branch since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in 2000. Wu said Beijing should understand that maintaining cross-strait peace and stability requires dialogue.

"We believe that the two sides should sit down to talk for mutual benefits, " Wu said, adding that the approach of "replacing confrontation with communication is the best guarantee for lasting peace and stability.

Wu also told Huckabee that the ROC government wants to improve cross-strait relations by opening the door to Chinese tourists and direct charter flight services on a regular basis. The two sides have commissioned intermediary bodies to negotiate technical details and concrete results can be achieved in the near future, Wu said.
"We plan to receive 400,000 to 500,000 Chinese tourists a year so that they can experience the liberal and democratic atmosphere here," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 22, or the 27th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as U.S. ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology with Elie Metchnikov, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: Republic of China Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best-loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai islands.
2000: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the U.S. The alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive.
2001: Oscar Alvarez, Costa Rican ambassador to the Republic of China, hosts a "Latin Night" to mark 60 years of diplomatic relations between Taipei and San Jose.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"
