DOC.HEADLINE: TSEC CHAIRMAN TO RESIGN IN LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSEC) Chairman Wu Nai-jen is expected to step down by the end of June.
Wu said Wednesday that he will officially announce his resignation during the upcoming shareholder meeting set for later this month.
Wu said that it is still uncertain who will be his successor and that he has not recommended any candidates to Premier Su Tseng-chang.
However, Wu said the personnel appointment will be finalized before the TSEC's next board meeting slated for July 10.
Wu took over the TSEC chairmanship in June 2004, and his term is supposed to last until June 2007.

TSEC officials said health considerations could be the reason why Wu has decided to resign before his term is due to end and that it is uncertain whether Wu will be appointed another position after his resignation.
Meanwhile, Wu said he will travel around in the second half of this year, adding that he plans to visit China in September or October.
He would not disclose whether the China trip will be a private visit or one with official purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: A RICH CHINA MAY EAT UP TAIWAN: BUDDHIST LEADER
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 21 (CNA) (By Hwang Kwang-chun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Buddhist leader used an analogy of religious equality Wednesday to predict that some day, when China becomes a rich country, it may "eat up Taiwan."

Master Hsing Yun of the Buddha Light Foundation based in southern Taiwan told a gathering of overseas Chinese that Taiwan has cringed at the idea of unifying with China because of its perceived poverty.

"Now China is becoming richer and richer, and some day in the future it would not be incredible that it might eat up Taiwan as the ideas of inequality, such as rich and poor and big and small, are involved here," Hsing Yun said.
He pointed out that any system of belief is aimed at helping believers believe in his or her own mind.
"We say we feel comfortable at home. By the same token, our minds need a home to 'be at home, ' and what religions do is find that home for our minds," he said.

Sharing his experience in resting his mind at ease, Hsing Yun said there are numerous ways of doing that, but such fundamental principles as love, tolerance, cherishing what one has and making friends with all will not change no matter what approach one takes to find a home for one's mind. He noted that a sense of equality is important because only by treating all living beings and all systems of belief equally will peace and harmony prevail in the world.

For that same reason, he said he would advise the people of Taiwan not to look down upon their poorer neighbors in China, who may sometime in the future grow rich enough to bring the Taiwanese into its fold.
The gathering was sponsored by the Republic of China's Embassy in the Vatican, with Ambassador Tu Chu-sheng and Taiwan's top representative in Italy, Cheng Hsin, in attendance.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST MASTER VISITS POPE BENEDICT XVI IN VATICAN
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 21 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Pope Benedict XVI met with visiting Master Hsing Yun, founder of the Buddha's Light International Association in Taiwan, Wednesday in a general audience at St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican.
During the meeting, Benedict XVI expressed his best regards for the Taiwan people and said he will pray for them. The pope also expressed the hope of meeting the Taiwan people if the chance arises.

Hsing Yun arrived in Rome Tuesday. In the company of Ambassador Tou Chou-sheng of the Republic of China, the Buddhist master extended his respects to the pope on behalf of Taiwan Buddhists and invited the leader of the Roman Catholic world to visit Taiwan.
Calling himself a pilgrim during his Rome trip, Hsing Yun said he hopes the journey will act to help boost mutual understanding and cooperation between Buddhists and Catholics.
Hsing Yun founded the Fo Guang Shan Buddhist Monastery in 1967 in southern Taiwan, which has since then evolved to become the largest Buddhist monastery in Taiwan.
Now, Fo Guang Shan has more than 200 branch temples throughout the world with the aim of promoting humanistic Buddhism.
After his meeting with Benedict XVI, Hsing Yun called on Paul Cardinal Poupard, president of the Pontifical Council for Culture of the Holy See, for talks on issues of mutual concern.

Hsing Yun, heading a group of his followers, is currently on a tour to tour Fo Guang Shan branches in Europe. He is scheduled to leave for Geneva Wednesday evening to attend an inauguration ceremony for a new Fo Guang Shan branch temple in the Swiss city.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD GRAB EVERY CHANCE TO JOIN INT'L COMPETITIONS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian suggested Thursday that Taiwan actively fight for opportunities to take part in international competitions, which he called the best occasions to publicize the country on the world stage.

Chen wrote in the latest edition of his online newsletter that he was deeply moved by the sight of soccer players from various countries and their cheering fans wielding national flags at World Cup matches.

Chen noted that the Caribbean nation of Trinidad and Tobago as well as the West African nation of Togo, which originally were not well known in the world, have suddenly become the focus of billions of people because of their presence in this year's World Cup.

While it is the most touching and proudest moment to see the national flag of one's own country flying on the fields of international competitions, Taiwan is the only country in the world that has been forbidden to sing its national anthem and raise its national flag at the Olympic games, Chen said.

He said that although this is the international reality that Taiwan has been forced to accept since the 1980s, Taiwan must not take this suppression as a matter of course and must not give up in fighting for the country's rights.
It is unreasonable and extremely strange that the people of Taiwan are not allowed to bring the national flag to cheer for their country even at international competitions hosted by Taiwan, he said.

The president urged all sectors in Taiwan to actively seek opportunities to participate in international competitions and cherish these opportunities so that Taiwan will get the best publicity every time the country stands on the world stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT ESCORTED HOME AFTER MUTINY

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat whose skipper was allegedly killed by two Chinese crewmembers on the high seas near Japan's island of Iwo Jima in the Pacific Ocean returned to Taiwan Thursday.

The fishing boat "Hsinglung" returned to Suao port in Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan under the escort of a coast guard patrol vessel. The two suspects -- mainland fishermen Yang Jietsong, 22, and Huang Tapao, 23 -- who are suspected of having murdered skipper Chen Mu-tsai, 50, were turned over to the Yilan Prosecutor's Office for questioning.

The "Hsinglung" left Yilan's Nanfanao Harbor in March for fishing operations in waters east of Iwo Jima. On board were the skipper as well as chief engineer Huang Chin-hsin, 49, and eight Chinese fishermen, including Yang and Huang.

Coast guard official Wang Yun-huei said that initial investigations showed that on June 10, the skipper clashed with Yang and Huang in a bitter argument and that the two later allegedly stabbed him to death. His body was put on ice in the cabin of the boat.

The two had attempted to sabotage the satellite telephone and communicates equipment after killing the skipper, according to Wang. They had also wanted to flee to China but then later decided to go back to Taiwan to face justice at the advice of the other crewmembers.
Huang later sent out a distress call for assistance. A coast guard patrol vessel intercepted the fishing boat June 16 and escorted it back to Taiwan.

The case marks the second time in less than two years that the fishing boat's two Taiwanese officers were overpowered by Chinese crew members. In August 2004, Chen and Huang were held hostage by nine Chinese crewmembers who then took the "Hsinglung" to Hawaii.

Chen had served as a skipper on the ship for more than a decade. According to media reports, because he had often run into trouble with crewmembers hired from Pingtan, Fujian Province, he decided to hire crew members from Zhangzhou, also in Fujian Province, this year. However, he also experienced problems with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF UNDECLARED CIGARETTES SEIZED UP SINCE TOBACCO TAX HIKE

TEXT.P: The number of undeclared cigarettes seized by customs authorities has increased significantly following the tobacco tax hike, officials said Thursday.

According to officials at the Ministry of Finance's Taipei Customs Office, a total of 3,635 cartons of undeclared cigarettes have been seized since the tobacco tax was raised from NT$50 (US$1.53) per carton containing 200 cigarettes to NT$100 per carton on Feb. 16.
They pointed out that tax-free items that adult travelers are permitted to bring into Taiwan include up to one liter of liquor and 200 cigarettes or 25 cigars or one pound of tobacco.

Travelers are required to declare any liquor and tobacco products that exceed these limits and pay the taxes due, with the amounts permitted being up to five liters of liquor and 1,000 cigarettes or 125 cigars or five pounds of tobacco, they said.

Any liquor and tobacco products beyond the set limits will only be allowed to clear customs if they are imported by licensed importers or are accompanied by a permit issued by the Ministry of Finance, the officials said.

They said that any travelers who intentionally do not declare their taxable items will have the items confiscated and may face prosecution if they show obvious intent to bring in the products for profit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATE ELECTED VICE PRESIDENT OF OIE'S REGIONAL COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's delegate to the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) has been elected vice president of the organization's commission on Asia, the Far East and Oceania, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Chang Tien-jye, dean of National Chung Hsing University's College of Veterinary Medicine, was elected to the post during the 74th annual conference of the OIE held in May in France, according to John C. Chen, head of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations.

Chen noted the OIE comprises 142 member nations and 40 international groups and non-governmental organizations and that approximately 670 representatives from around the world participated in the May conference, with Hong Kong taking part as an observer.

During the meeting, Taiwan's delegation exchanged views with other participants on the prevention and control of animal diseases, and the U.K. and French delegations also held bilateral talks with the Taiwan delegation on issues concerning the export of pork and poultry to Taiwan, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET SOAR

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange soared Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 185.56 points to close at 6,485.15.
The bourse opened at 6,427.71 and fluctuated between 6,487.91 and 6,397.13 during trading. A total of 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.51 billion (US$2.38 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 3.5 percent, cement stocks at 2.5 percent, textile stocks at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent and foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 825 to 83, with 69 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRCRAFT WITH TAIWAN FRUIT LOGO ARRIVES

TEXT.P: An A330-300 airplane ordered by China Airlines (CAL) from Airbus with the logo of Taiwan-made fruit on its fuselage arrived in Taiwan Thursday.

The aircraft is aimed at promoting sales of the island's agricultural products, and this is the second time the Council of Agriculture (COA) has cooperated with the nation's leading air carrier in doing so.
Last year, a CAL aircraft carried the logo of butterfly orchids -- one of Taiwan's other key agricultural exports -- on its flights to Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and the Middle East.
Afterwards, butterfly orchid exports doubled in 2006 over the previous year.
COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan said the move would help promote Taiwan's fruit sales worldwide and will be favorable to the country's international image when the aircraft begins flying around the world.
The newly ordered A330-300 has the logo of nine of Taiwan's most popular fruits painted on its fuselage -- lychee, pineapple, banana, mango, bell fruit, star fruit, date, papaya and orange.
According to a CAL official, the plane is scheduled to fly first to Japan on June 28, then to Singapore on July 4. It is slated to fly to Vienna, Bangkok, Seoul and Abu Dhabi in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS TO ATTEND KAOHSIUNG RALLY: KMT SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: Leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will attend a rally planned for Saturday in southern Kaohsiung city despite reported pressure from the central government to cancel the activity, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Thursday.

Both KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will take part in the demonstration at the National Science and Technology Museum in the southern port city to ask for President Chen Shui-bian's resignation over a string of corruption allegations regarding his family and close aides, Cheng said at a news conference at KMT headquarters.

Regardless of pressure from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, the activity has gained approval from the museum authorities through a due process and will be held as scheduled, Cheng stressed.

She quoted Ma as saying that if the DPP is the source of the reported pressure, it would be unforgivable for the government to attempt to strip people of the freedom of speech guaranteed in the Constitution.

According to the KMT spokeswoman, the two men will also participate in a similar activity slated for Sunday in Taipei to demand Chen step down -- the latest in a series of protest activities sponsored by the pan-blue alliance to hold Chen accountable for corruption allegations, and in conjunction with a presidential recall vote at the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday.

Commenting on a KMT ad in local print media that calls on the DPP to "give Taiwan a chance," Cheng said that the DPP must not turn into a stumbling block in Taiwan's pursuit of progress and democracy.

She urged DPP lawmakers to vote in favor of the presidential recall motion in the legislature June 27 so as to give the Taiwanese public a chance to have the final say on Chen's fate in a national referendum.

Taiwan should prove to the rest of the world that it is a democratic and progressive country, where its people are entitled to oust a corrupt and incapable president through a set of constitutional mechanisms, she said, noting that it would mark a milestone in Taiwan's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION ACCUSES GOVERNMENT OF DOCTORING FINANCIAL REPORTS

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers and academics accused the government Thursday of doctoring financial reports and embezzling public assets, claiming the country is "almost broke" as a result of rampant corruption and mismanagement.

Legislator Liu Yi-ju of the People First Party (PFP) told a Committee of the Whole meeting at the legislature that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government over the past six years has used six tricks to make false financial statements.

These include exaggerating tax revenues, fabricating income from selling government-owned shares in state enterprises, wasting public money, doctoring accounting items, making complicated reinvestments to evade parliamentary auditing and hiding key information and then endorsing such behavior, according to Liu.

She quoted international ratings as claiming that Taiwan's financial rankings dropped to 79th in the world, with the government debt running at NT$11 trillion (US$337.5 billion) or 110 percent of the gross national product (GDP) , rather than what the government claims to be 39 percent.
President Chen Shui-bian was not telling the truth when he said Taiwan can afford to borrow "twice as much" as it has done, the finance professor-turned lawmaker said.
The meeting was held to review an opposition-initiated legislative motion to recall the president. It was boycotted by DPP lawmakers and most government officials.

Lei Chien of the Kuomintang (KMT) said NT$4.61 trillion (US$141.3 billion) in public assets have been improperly taken away through merging government-owned banks with private holding companies, BOT projects, privatization of state-owned businesses and "sheer waste" by government departments.
"The DPP government should be held 100 percent accountable for the horrible embezzlement," she claimed.

Lee Yun-chieh, a scholar, claimed the Presidential Office has become a "center of corruption" by means of manipulating senior management personnel at major holding companies and interfering in key construction projects.
Chu Yun-peng, another scholar, quoted international studies as claiming that if corruption in Taiwan were at the same level as in Singapore, Taiwan's per capita GDP would increase by US$170.

Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP lawmaker, covered his mouth with a mask during the session, erecting placards that read "Justice can only be realized in the streets" and "Refusing to answer legislative charges amounts to confessing crime," a reference to the president's decision to bypass the legislature to make his rebuttal to opposition charges.

The president delivered a two-hour televised speech Tuesday night, denying all ten charges levied against him after declining to answer to them in the legislature, deciding instead to make a "report to the people."

Thursday's legislative Committee of the Whole meeting focused on the theme "Taiwan is financially broke, " and was second in a series of four before the legislature votes on the recall motion June 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 176 points to close at 6,430, with 43,047 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August rose 205 points to finish at 6,351, with 313 contracts traded, while September futures gained 200 points to close at 6,342, with 76 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 186 points to close at 6,344, with 23 contracts traded, while March futures rose 199 points to close at 6,350, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,254 for July, 6,146 for August, 6,142 for September, 6,158 for December and 6,151 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
July TE futures rose 12.2 points to close at 268.2, with 6,775 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 10.9 points to finish at 266.15, with 26 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved up 9.8 points to close at 265, with 10 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 11.9 points to finish at 262.1, with two contracts traded.
July TF futures moved up 14.4 points to finish at 950, with 3,280 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures gained 18.4 points to close at 940, with 27 contracts traded.
September TF futures rose 14.4 points to close at 939.4, with 17 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures gained 17.6 points to close at 946.8, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.638.
A total of US$699 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.625 and fluctuated between NT$32.595 and NT$32.660.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi calls for support of constitutional reform.
Former premier Silvio Berlusconi called on voters Wednesday to vote "Yes" in the upcoming referendum on an amendment to the Constitution which will be held June 25-26. He said that it is important to Italy the constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR EXPLAINS WHY HE FILED SUIT AGAINST 12 DOCTORS

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday that he filed suit against 12 doctors who released what they claimed were his medical records prior to last year's Taichung mayoral election because he wanted to curb the "malicious practice."
Hu made the remarks when asked about a lawsuit he filed in late May against the doctors -- including Legislator Peter Lin, who is also a practicing physician.

Hu said that some of the doctors had tried to contact him through others, and that they wanted to meet with him to express their apologies, but because they sought a private rather than a public meeting -- which he said was against his principle of a public apology -- he had not accepted the offer.
"After a long period of deliberation, I think doctors should not be allowed to use medical records to sway election results again," Hu said.

The suit was filed on grounds of infringing upon personal privacy and a violation of the election and recall law, he said, adding that even if doctors "happened" to pick up medical records somewhere, they shouldn't publish them.
Hu said that accepting the apology is a personal matter, but he thinks that it is "highly inappropriate for professionals to use professional knowledge to sway an election's outcome."
"This is why I've chosen to do something to redress the practice, instead of acting as a hypocrite," he said.

Legislator Lin was a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). But he was stripped of his membership early this year after the hospital he headed was found to have swindled hundreds of thousands of dollars from the national health insurance project.

The doctors unveiled the medical records of Hu, who once had a minor stroke, at a joint news conference a few days prior to the mayoral election December 3, 2005, in an attempt to thwart the re-election bid of the popular mayor from the opposition Kuomintang by questioning whether he was healthy enough to serve another four-year term.
The doctors claimed the medical records were leaked out of Taichung Veterans Hospital, although none of them work there and it remains unknown how they gained access to Hu's records.
Mayor Hu said that doctors at Taichung Veterans General Hospital are at the top of their field, and that he had no heart to file suit against them.
He also didn't know why the medical records were leaked, saying the question would be left for prosecutors to find out.
Lin, who originally insisted he had done nothing wrong, later openly apologized to Hu in an about-face, saying he had been under tremendous pressure to do so. Hu accepted the apology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS TROOPS ON TATAN ISLET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian traveled to the outlying island of Kinmen Thursday to cheer troops stationed at the Republic of China military stronghold and to demonstrate his determination to boost national security.

Flanked by Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of General Staff Lee Tien-yu and Army Commander-General Hu Chen-pu, Chen took "Air Force One" to Kinmen around 9 a.m. He was then whisked to Kinmen's Shuitou Port, where he boarded an amphibious speedboat to Tatan -- one of 15 islets that form the Kinmen archipelago.

Chen inspected troops posted on Tatan Islet, located southwest of Lieyu Islet (or Little Kinmen) , about 4,400 meters off the White Stone Battery of China's port city of Xiamen. He last visited Tatan on May 9, 2002 during his first term, and made the famous "Tatan declaration" on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, inviting the Beijing leadership to meet him on Tatan for a chat over tea.
After visiting Tatan, Chen turned to Lieyu for a similar inspection tour before returning to Kinmen, where he joined officers and soldiers for a lunch before flying back to Taiwan proper.
This marked the second time in a week Chen has flown to Kinmen to show resolve in reinforcing national security amidst ongoing political turmoil currently embroiling the country.
"Air Force One" was forced to return to Taiwan June 15 because of deteriorating weather conditions prior to touching down on Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST RICE-TRADING CENTER INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first rice-trading center was inaugurated and began its first day of operations Thursday at the Agriculture and Food Agency's (AFA) southern regional office in Tainan City.

Trading at the new facility will emphasize the quality and safety of rice, instead of the weight -- the traditional way of rice-trading on the island, AFA Director-General Huang Yu-tsai said in his address at the inauguration ceremony.

Weight has been key, or sometimes the only reference for traders to buy crops from growers, while the government guarantees the price of NT$21 per kilogram of rice as part of efforts to maintain a stable rice market, Huang explained.
However, at the new rice-trading center, more information including type of rice strain, name of grower and safety guarantees will be available for traders' reference.
Huang said he expects quality-oriented rice trading to replace that of weight-oriented trade.
A rice farmer participating in Thursday's opening expressed support for the rice center's establishment, a venue where he said he had gained a profit twice that of the production area.
The center is the first of four such planned facilities by the Council of Agriculture, with others to be constructed in Taiwan's northern, central and eastern regions, respectively.

Trading at the southern regional rice center will be conducted once every two weeks, with each grower obliged to auction at least 30 tons of rice, while the bidder has to purchase at least five tons of rice per bid, according to the Tainan center.

On the center's first day of operations, a total of 13 trading transactions were completed, with "dream beauty" rice grown in Houpi Township, Tainan County, selling at the day's highest price -- NT$160,000 per ton -- or three times that of other brands of high-quality rice on the market.
According to the AFA, "dream beauty" is a crop of rice bred under a contract of Japanese traders. The rice will be exported to Japan in July and marketed there in small packages.
It is rare to see rice exported to Japan in small packages from other rice-producing countries, AFA officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND WORLD EXPERTS GATHER IN U.S. TO COMBAT AVIAN FLU
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 21 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A total of 24 Taiwanese and world experts are gathering at a laboratory in the United States to receive training in how to prevent a possible outbreak of avian flu.

These experts -- veterinarians and epidemiologists from 19 countries including Taiwan, Argentina, Brasil, Indonesia, Mexico, Uruguay and Pakistan -- are undergoing training at the National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) in Iowa from June 19 to June 23.

Ron DeHaven, an official of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service under the U.S. Department of Agriculture, noted that the program aims to stop the deadly H5N1 strain of bird flu from continuing to spread to other parts of the world.

As there have been sporadic cases of avian flu occurring in Asia and Europe, the U.S. government has begun to strengthen its prevention tactics, with President George W. Bush calling for US$7.1 billion in funds for the prevention of a possible global bird flu outbreak.

The fund is scheduled to cover measures such as the establishment of a global epidemic monitoring system, the storage of medicine and vaccines, enhancing the capability of a U.S. epidemic prevention network against possible emergency situation, and strengthening public education about bird flu.
The training of global veterinarians and epidemiologists at the NVSL in Iowa comprises part of the prevention measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTROMAGNETISM IN SHUEHSHAN TUNNEL AT SAFE LEVEL: EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Thursday that there is nothing to worry about in terms of the level of electromagnetism in the newly opened Shuehshan Tunnel as it is far lower than the recommended maximum level.
EPA officials made the comments to dispel public concern after drivers found they have no difficulty in using cell phones and radios while inside the tunnel.

Addressing speculation that the electromagnetism in the tunnel could be harmful to the humans, the EPA invited officials from the independent National Communications Commission and the Cabinet-level Department of Health to carry out tests in late May.

The results show that the level of electromagnetism released by the electric lines under the tunnel and five cell phone base stations located at the southern and northern ends of the tunnel are far lower than the recommended maximum level for non-ionization radiation.
The 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel, the longest tunnel in Southeast Asia and the fifth-longest in the world, was officially inaugurated July 16.

The tunnel, considered locally as a "construction miracle, " is the centerpiece of the 55.3-km "Chiang Wei-shui Freeway" linking Nankang in the northern city of Taipei to Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan.

The opening of the freeway to traffic -- after 15 years of painstaking construction at a cost of more than NT$100 billion (US$3.11 billion) -- has significantly reduced travel time between Taipei and Yilan, cutting the travel time between Nankang and Suao to 45 minutes from nearly three hours in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MARKET PARTITIONING' KEY TO SURVIVING CHINA'S COMPETITION: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's machinery industrial sector must seek "market partitioning" to make a clear distinction between Taiwan-made and China-made products in order to survive cut-throat Chinese competition, Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san said Thursday.

Seeking to churn out high-quality products is actually the other side of a double-edged strategy to allow Taiwan's machinery industry to survive fierce competition from China, Hwang said during his speech delivered at a forum held in the central city of Taichung.

Faced with China's competition, Taiwan's machinery industry can no longer retain its niche simply by lowering overhead costs and compromising product quality, Hwang said, adding the industry will thrive only by producing innovative, high-quality products while partitioning markets for Taiwan's products from made-in-China counterparts.

Huang suggested that Taiwan's machinery industry follow suit with the country's bicyle industry, which has followed an "A-Team" strategy of using supply-chain competition to improve quality and developing more innovative products to sharpen the industry's competitiveness in the global market.

By forming the "A-Team" with domestic component manufacturers, Taiwan's leading bicycle makers -- such as Giant and Merida -- have put made-in-Taiwan bikes on the world's map of high-quality bicycles.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION URGES GOVERNMENT TO SECURE CONTROL OVER MEGA HOLDINGS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang and Minister of Finance Joseph Lyu should resign if the government loses its majority to private shareholders in the board election of Mega Financial Holding Co., legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday.

Mega Financial will hold its next board election Friday and there is concern that the government, as the single largest shareholder with 22 percent of the shares in the company, might no longer have a majority eight seats representing government shares on the 15-member board.

Legislator Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said at a news conference that if the government fails to secure its board majority, thus losing operational control over Mega Financial's NT$2.13 trillion (US$65.23 billion) in capital, the premier and the finance minister should step down to take responsibility.

Echoing Pan's call, KMT Legislator Alex Fai claimed that if the number of board members representing government shares should fall from eight seats to seven in Friday's election, it would mean that the premier and the finance minister are no longer qualified to remain in their posts.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao claimed that the election is of great concern to all the people in Taiwan because if the government loses its control over Mega Financial, it would represent an average loss of NT$100,000 to each person.

Meanwhile, James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), said if the premier and the finance minister "give up the government's control" over Mega Financial, it will be tantamount to their support for what he described as the "corrupt leadership" of President Chen Shui-bian, who has been accused by the opposition parties for "fleecing the national treasury" under the guise of privatizing state-owned banks.
Soong vowed that the PFP will do everything possible to topple the Cabinet if the government suffers a defeat in Mega Financial's board election.

Mega Financial, Taiwan's second-largest financial service company, was formed by state-owned Chiao Tung Bank and International Securities Co. through exchange of shares in 2002 under the government's financial reform program.

Chiao Tung Bank Chairman Cheng Shen-chih became chairman of Mega Financial, supposedly because of his good relationship with Chen, although he owned fewer than 2 million shares at the time. The privatization process triggered opposition suspicion that it was a scheme by the president and the DPP to "fleece the national treasury."

According to news reports, Cheng has obtained the support of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., which owns 12 percent of the shares in Mega Financial, and that he appears certain to continue serving as chairman, even if control of the board falls into the hands of private shareholders.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC SOUNDS ALARM OVER PROGRESS IN U.S.-CHINA MILITARY EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A recent U.S. invitation for China to observe its military drill in Guam may have an adverse impact on Taiwan-U.S. military exchanges in the long-term, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned Thursday.

The Cabinet-level mainland policy planner was referring to an invitation extended to China by U.S. Pacific Commander Adm. William Fallon to send officers to observe the June 17-19 U.S. military exercise, codenamed "Operation Brave Shield." To the surprise of some pundits, Chinese Defense Minister Cao Gangchuan accepted the invitation.

In its June report on the latest developments in China, the MAC said the engagement has not only ushered in a new round of U.S.-China strategic race in the Asia-Pacific but has also created room for China to impact U.S.-Taiwan military exchanges.

The event was also seen by major international news media as the most positive sign of improvement in U.S.-China military relations since the spy planes standoff over the South China Sea in 2001, the MAC report said.

According to the report, the U.S. invitation had at least three strategic purposes -- expanding bilateral military exchanges, hoping to secure a subsequent invitation from China to observe Chinese military exercises and gauging each other's military strength through the exchanges.

Most China watchers analyzed the U.S. invitation from the perspective of strategic competition between Beijing and Washington. Superficially, they said, the United States looked forward to avoiding conflict with China by enhancing mutual trust through military exchanges.

In reality, they said, the United States intended to get a direct look at China's military prowess and strategic goals, which they said may contribute to the U.S. evaluation of its East Asia military restructuring plan and its global strategic goals.

While the U.S. motives were understandable, the MAC report said, China's acceptance of the U.S. invitation came as a surprise. Beijing was fully aware the United States is unlikely to aid China in its military modernization drive. What the U.S. is concerned about is the "management" rather than "cooperation" of their security relations, the report said.

According to the MAC's analysis, the most important reason behind China's consent to the U.S. invitation lies in its hope that the United States will eventually cease military engagements with Taiwan, including sales of advanced weapons.

In the past, the report said, the United States has adopted a "parallel" strategy in dealing with military exchanges with Taiwan and China. Increased U.S.-China military exchanges might allow China to tilt the balance, enabling China to have a hand in "manipulating" Taiwan-U.S. military relations, the report said.

By all accounts, the report said, the U.S.-China "date" at the Guam exercise marked an important milestone in their bilateral military relations, which is worthy of Taiwan's attention and that of other neighboring countries.

Meanwhile, Yang Chih-heng, a Tamkang University associate professor, said the presence of Chinese military officers aboard a U.S. warship to observe a military drill indeed marked a significant breakthrough in U.S.-China ties.

Noting the main purpose of the U.S. invitation was to forge mutual trust, Yang said he believes that such a move has an even deeper strategic implication by inspiring their respective political leaders to improve bilateral military relations.

With the United States deploying its strategic missiles, submarines and bombers in Guam to reinforce its traditional security cooperation with Japan, with China as their "hypothetical enemy, " Yang said China has gained a rare opportunity to observe the latest U.S. military deployment in Guam by accepting the invitation.

Moreover, Yang said, China can also take advantage of the event as a form of goodwill gesture to East Asian countries in an effort to undermine the legitimacy of including the Taiwan Strait situation into the strategic goals of U.S.-Japan defense cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Rallied by Bush, Skittish G.O.P. Now Embraces War as Issue
Republicans took to the Senate floor Wednesday to offer an unambiguous embrace of the Iraq war and to portray Democrats as advocates of an overly hasty withdrawal that would have grave consequences for the security of the United States. That emerging Republican approach reflects the success of a White House effort to bring a skittish party behind President Bush on the war after months of political ambivalence in some vocal quarters. As President Bush offered another defense of his Iraq policy during a visit to Vienna on Wednesday, Republicans acknowledged that it was a strategy of necessity, an effort to turn what some party leaders had feared could become the party's greatest liability into an advantage in the midterm elections.
Wall Street Journal: Burning Oil, Behind Rise of Iran's President: A Populist Economic Agenda
Iran's new president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, has grabbed the world's attention with his bombast over Tehran's nuclear program and saber rattling against Israel. At home, however, the president's popularity is soaring thanks to another reason: his enthusiastic embrace of economic populism. In recent weeks, he has proposed a US$4 billion national school-renovation program and has raised not only salaries for workers in Iran's vast, government-controlled industrial sector but also the minimum wage for everyone else. He doubled government grants for newlyweds and forced banks to lower interest rates by several percentage points. One key to that plan was diversifying an economy heavily dependent on oil revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Multi-govt effort to fight piracy takes off.
After years of talk, a multi-government plan to combat piracy in Asian waters will finally take off, with Singapore holding fort.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Sentasa will offer 7000 new jobs in next two years.
There will increase 7000 new jobs in Sentosa island next two years, and the number of workers double than before.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FACTION'S '2008 ACTION PLAN' AIMS TO CONTINUE POWER

TEXT.P: The Welfare State faction of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the party Thursday to adopt, when it meets in July, a "2008 action plan" aimed at continuing the party's hold on power as party morale has been undermined by a recent string of corruption scandals.
The plan claims that rallying pro-independence votes and developing the economy will be key to "re-consolidating the party's power base."

The faction, led by former premier Frank Hsieh, called on party members to "believe in the innocence" of President Chen Shui-bian, whom the opposition charged is at the "corrupt center" of an incompetent government, and to support a fair and independent investigation by judicial authorities into opposition and media allegations about Chen and the first family.
The president is facing a recall motion in the legislature, which is scheduled for a vote on June 27.

In addition to lambasting opposition parties for "twisting judicial operations," the faction also accused pro-China media of collaborating with the opposition to create social unrest, leading the country toward a political crisis.

"All DPP members should call on supporters to boycott these scum media and phase them out of the market so a media environment can be created that will be favorable to Taiwan's rule of law and democratic development," said the action plan.

Before the 2008 presidential election, the DPP will be fighting in a legislative election next year, so it's time for the party to create strategies to keep its lead in Taiwan's public opinion, it added.

It said "sovereignty" and "development" should be the main themes of the DPP's 2007 and 2008 campaigns, an appeal that it claimed will "touch the hearts of the electorate" and help the party retain its rein on power.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOBLESS RATE EXPECTED TO FALL BELOW 4 PERCENT FOR 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate is likely to be controlled under 4 percent for this year, with the highest single-month figure, which normally occurs in August, expected to top 4.11 percent, an official of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

Taiwan posted a jobless rate of 3.84 percent in May, marking the lowest of all May figures for the last six years, said Huang Chien-chung, who added that the figure was 0.06 percentage points higher than that posted in April and represented a decline of 0.26 percentage points from the year-earlier level.
The average unemployment rate of the first five months of this year also stood at 3.84 percent, Huang noted.
It is expected that the jobless rate will live up to the government's expectations that it will not exceed 4 percent for 2006, Huang said.

The unemployment rate usually climbs month-on-month from May with the approach of graduation season, reaching its highest point in August before beginning to decline month-on-month in the latter months of the year, Huang noted.

Based on these estimates, the unemployment rate in the months after August is not expected to surpass 4.11 percent per month, making it possible that the whole-year unemployment rate for 2006 will not be higher than 4.11 percent, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION LEAVES FOR IATTC CONFERENCE IN SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation left for Busan, South Korea Thursday to attend the 74th annual conference of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC), a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said.

According to John C. Chen, head of the ministry's Department of International Organizations, Taiwan is participating in the event as an observer and will officially become a member of the IATTC as an fishing entity after the adoption of the Antigua Convention.

During the meeting, the delegation led by Tsai Jih-yao -- a section chief of the Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Agency -- will focus on issues such as whether to extend Taiwan's status as a "cooperating fishing entity" and quotas for long-line fishing of bigeye tuna in 2007 and thereafter, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DISAGREES WITH READER'S DIGEST LIST OF COURTEOUS CITIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed dissatisfaction Thursday with a recent list of courteous cities published by the Reader's Digest magazine, in which Taipei City was ranked 28th out of the 35 cities evaluated.
As Taipei is generally considered a "friendly city, " Ma said he believes that people sometimes have different opinions on "friendly" or "courteous" due to the culture gap.

Ma said a writer in Shanghai told him he thought Taipei is a very friendly city because he was once given directions by a passer-by, while Lo Chih-cheng, director of the Taipei city government's Information Department, talked about the culture difference, claiming that oriental people sometimes pretend that they do not see other people in trouble on the street "mainly to prevent the awkwardness of the victims."
However, he admitted that some people do help those in trouble.
According to Lo, friendliness and courteousness are sometimes classified as different things.
For example, Lo said, offering a seat to an elderly person is polite, but some old people who don't consider themselves old might feel offended when offered a seat.
Lo said he will ask his friends and international civic groups to tell the magazine that Taipei is a friendly city.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAGISTRATE TO PROMOTE LOCAL PRODUCE IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih announced Thursday at a news conference that he plans to promote locally produced high quality fruit and rice later this month in Japan.

Speaking at the Tainan county government headquarters, Su said that he will depart for Japan Sunday and is slated to hold four large-scale promotional activities in Tokyo and Osaka to sell Tainan-grown mangoes and rice.

According to Su, Tainan county is expected to export as much as 1,500 tons of the "ai wen" strain of mangoes to Japan this year, thanks to good growing conditions since the beginning of the year. Southern Tainan county is the largest production center of fine quality mangoes in Taiwan.

In addition, Su said that he will take part in a ceremony June 30 at an Osaka hotel to mark the establishment of a retail distribution network of Tainan rice in small packs, aimed at small Japanese families.
A group of agricultural professionals from local farmers' associations will accompany Su to explore export opportunities for Tainan's flowers, green bamboo, aquatic products and coffee.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MEN ARRESTED AFTER ATTEMPTING TO SMUGGLE HEROIN INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three men were arrested at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after a total of 7,699 grams of heroin was discovered in their luggage, the Aviation Police Office (APO) reported Thursday.
The three suspected smugglers were passengers on a flight from Thailand Wednesday, and claimed they had just concluded a three-day sightseeing trip.
The drug was packed in paper and plastic food containers, APO officers said, noting they had launched the raid based on tips from informants.

Heroin is classified as a "first-class" drug according to the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act, which rules that anyone who manufactures, transports, or sells Class A drugs may face the death penalty or life imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraq Debate Previews Presidential Bids; Votes on Senate Proposals for Withdrawal Set for Today.
Yesterday's lengthy Senate debate over Iraq offered early hints of the 2008 presidential contest, with some potential candidates calling for a rapid drawdown of U.S. troops, some saying that only the president can decide such issues and others urging a middle ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Moscow, June 22 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Kiev Scrambling to Avert Gas Crisis Ukraine is scurrying to form a government coalition and head off a gas crisis that could hit July 1, when its controversial supply deal with Russia expires. [ By ChangHung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE DEPARTS FOR U.S.

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei departed Thursday for a 14-day visit to the United States to promote economic and trade exchanges between the northern county and U.S. cities.
His trip will take him to New York, Houston, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles and he is scheduled to return July 5.
In New York, he will meet representatives of Taiwanese expatriates and is scheduled to hold an exhibition of his paintings.

Chou is also taking with him other ceramics works he has painted. He said some of them will be given to people he meets in the U.S. and some will be auctioned for charity. Chou hopes to raise NT$2 million to build a drug rehabilitation center.

In Washington, Chou is scheduled to attend investment seminars to promote investment in his county, while in Houston, he will visit various high-tech and bio-tech companies. He will also deliver speeches about the Taipei County investment environment.
The last leg of his trip will be Los Angeles, where he will visit the Los Angeles branch of the Chinese Benevolent Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG LOOKING FOR `SECOND ANG LEE': MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu announced Thursday the start of a film-making competition in the hope of exploring young talent that could become "a second Oscar-winning Taiwan-born director Ang Lee."

This is the third year that Taichung City has hosted the "Little Golden Horse Award" competition, which is classified into three categories, focusing on city image, creative filmmaking and sweet family, to present the diversified facets of the city in central Taiwan through different prospective.

Hu and municipal information department director Chen Yung-feng dressed up like the two protagonists in Lee's film "Brokeback Mountain" and each held a model horse while announcing the start of the competition.

By sponsoring the activity, Taichung city hopes to help inject new momentum into the local industry and discover fresh talent that could have the potential to become "a second Ang Lee" -- who won this year's Oscar award for best director with "Brokeback Mountain, " Hu said.
Applications must be submitted before Sept. 15 and the winner of the top prize will be awarded NT$30,000 worth of gifts, said Cheng.

In line with the filmmaking award, a photography competition was also announced to record the beauty and images of the city, Cheng said, adding that prize money for that contest will total NT$300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TALK OF NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE AT PRESENT: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that his party will not consider initiating a no-confidence vote at the Legislative Yuan to topple the Cabinet pending the result of a presidential recall vote next Tuesday at the legislature.

Ma said that the KMT will not talk about a no-confidence vote at the Legislative Yuan as a means of pressuring President Chen Shui-bian to step down before the presidential recall vote has been held June 27.

Stressing that the presidential recall vote is the KMT's focal point now at the Legislative Yuan, Ma said, however, that relevant preparations have been made regarding launching a no-confidence vote, as the KMT has asked its Policy Coordination Committee to form a task force to study the issue.
Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong has repeatedly said that he will seek to initiate a vote to topple the Cabinet if the motion to recall Chen fails.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has launched efforts to oust Chen over a spate of corruption scandals allegedly involving his family and close aides. In line with the presidential recall motion, public hearings at the Legislative Yuan and a series of street protests have also been held.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA 777-300ER TO BE EXHIBITED AT U.K. AIRSHOW

TEXT.P: EVA, one of Taiwan's leading air carriers, took delivery Thursday its third new Boeing B777-300ER in Seattle.
The aircraft was scheduled to land at Chiang Kai Shek International Airport the following day.

An EVA spokesman said the plane will be exhibited at the Farnborough International Airshow in the U.K. slated for July 17-23, adding that it will be the first time an aircraft from a Taiwanese carrier has taken part in the show.
The twin-engined aircraft will be used on the Taipei-Los Angeles route, the spokesman said, adding that it will be the first time a Taiwanese carrier has used a twin-engined aircraft on a U.S. route.
EVA plans to take delivery of another of the aircraft in November, and four others in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDERPRIVILEGED CHILDREN TO BE GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIZED

TEXT.P: Underprivileged children from around the country will be entitled to a monthly subsidy of NT$3,000 each beginning this July to help avoid deaths as a result of child abuse, the head of the Child Welfare Bureau said Thursday.

Huang Pi-hsia, director-general of the Child Welfare Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior, said it is hoped that with the emergency relief subsidy of NT$3,000 each month, the prospective beneficiaries will have access to better care, consequently helping reduce the possibility of deaths caused by child abuse or domestic violence.
The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has agreed to foot the NT$140 million bill for the program, said Huang.
Meanwhile, she said, the Executive Yuan has also decided to allocate some NT$31.5 million to finance local governments in efforts to hire more social workers to facilitate the child subsidy program.

Huang said that before the subsidy program is implemented, a system must be built first -- with the participation of grassroots offices, schools and social workers -- to find and determine the prospective beneficiaries for the subsidy.

Huang said the implementation of the program has become increasingly urgent, with the number of children dying as a result of child abuse or being murdered by their suicidal parents increasing year-on-year.

A total of 24 children died of child abuse or were killed by their suicidal parents in the first six months of this year, slightly higher than the figure posted in the same period of 2005, Huang said, quoting a tally compiled by her bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR TO VISIT EUROPE FOR TRADE PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu will leave Friday for a week-long European tour to promote Taichung City's business relations with the United Kingdom, France and Belgium.
A spokesman for the Taichung city government said Thursday that Hu will first go to London to see the planning of its business districts and urban construction.
He will then go to Paris to see its urban planning, observe the French dining culture and visit famous museums there.
From Paris, he will travel to Belgium to see its urban renovation program and mass rapid transit system.
According to the spokesman, the main purpose of Hu's trip is to invite advanced service industries in the three European countries to invest in Taichung.
Hu will meet with owners of banks, hotels and restaurants there and brief them about the business opportunities Taichung can offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD TO STAY UP ALL NIGHT ON EVE OF LEGISLATURE'S RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said he and PFP legislators will sit up through the night before the Legislative Yuan building on the eve of the legislature's June 27 vote on a motion seeking to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

James Soong told reporters that he and the PFP lawmakers, along with PFP supporters, will use the overnight vigil to call on legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) not to be "hijacked" by the president and become culprits because of their support for him.

The recall motion was introduced by KMT legislators with the support of their PFP allies after the president refused to step down amid a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.

Soong, PFP lawmakers and their supporters have been staging a four-day sit-in during the daytime at the entrance of the legislature that will last until June 24 to coincide with a meeting of the legislature's Committee of the Whole to hear the pros and cons of the proposed recall of the president.

According to PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang, the sit-in is intended to be a moral appeal to the president, the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), "to recover Taiwan's democratic conscience."

The recall motion will need a two-thirds majority vote in the 221-seat legislature before the issue can be put to a national referendum. With the KMT and the PFP holding only a slight majority in the legislature, they will need the support of at least 36 legislators from the DPP and the TSU for the passage of the motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST TAIWAN TRADE POLICY REVIEW AT WTO DRAWS TO 'PERFECT END'
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 22 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan trade policy review (TPR) at the World Trade Organization (WTO) drew to a "perfect end" Thursday amid thunderous applause from representatives of all member states.
Clemens Boonekamp, director of the WTO's TPR department, said marking the conclusion of a member economy's trade policy review with such resounding acclaim was unprecedented and extraordinary.
The acclaim symbolized a mutually beneficial scenario for the WTO and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Boonekamp said.
The WTO is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and China. The first-ever Taiwan trade policy review since its WTO accession in 2002 got under way a day earlier.

Given the often rocky cross-strait relations, the WTO Secretariat had exercised extreme prudence in preparing the two-day session and many other WTO members had also shown keen interest in the interaction between the Taiwanese and Chinese representatives. Over the two days of the review, the two "rivals" had more than 30 minutes of direct dialogue in which the two sides showed self-restraint, allowing the session to proceed smoothly.
Boonekamp credited Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and Li Enheng, China's deputy permanent representative at the WTO, for the successful completion of the review.

The success proves the maturity of the WTO's multilateral mechanism, Boonekamp said, adding that the WTO framework can satisfactorily handle trade and economic affairs between political rivals. Analysts said Boonekamp also played a crucial role in ensuring the smooth proceeding of the review, having twice visited Taiwan in preparation. He has never hesitated to acknowledge that political disputes are the thorniest part of the Taiwan trade policy review.

Knowing the delicacy of cross-strait ties, most WTO members welcome positive and healthy interaction between Taiwan and China under the WTO mechanism. Japan's representative at the session praised the session as a great success.
WTO Director-General Pascal Lamy also attended the session to show his concern.

WTO officials said Li exercised great self-restraint during the session. He asked the Salvadoran ambassador to respect WTO regulations only after the latter repeatedly mentioned Taiwan's official national title "Republic of China" during the session. El Salvador is the ROC's diplomatic ally and Taiwan's official designation in the WTO is the "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."
Asked whether the trade policy review has any positive significance in cross-strait interaction, Li said none of the WTO trade policy review has ever been found to have a negative impact.

As to whether the trade policy review had set a model for future cross-strait interaction in the WTO, no WTO officials would make a forecast. They just said they have noticed that China has no intention to negotiate with Taiwan at the moment over Taiwan's import ban more than 2,200 kinds of Chinese products.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PLANS PERSONNEL CHANGES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved a number of personnel changes at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , with Ambassador to El Salvador Javier Hou being promoted to vice minister, ministry sources said Thursday.
According to the sources, Premier Su Tseng-chang approved the new appointments at the MOFA a day earlier.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, however, declined to confirm the reports, pointing out that the ministry customarily avoids premature comments on personnel changes.
The MOFA sources said Lu will succeed Chen Yeong-cho as MOFA secretary-general. Chen has already assumed the post of representative to South Korea.

Meanwhile, the sources said Victor C.Y. Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's department of West Asian affairs, will be transferred to the post of representative to Malaysia, while Eduando Chen, consulate-general to San Pedro Sula in Honduras, will take over the position of ambassador to the Dominican Republic to be vacated by John Feng, who is retiring.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SETS FIVE STRATEGIES FOR LOCAL PRODUCTION OF POLY-CRYSTAL SILICON

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has mapped out five main strategies to boost the development of the local photovoltaic industry, an MOEA official said Thursday.
The strategies were outlined during a Tuesday meeting of government officials, industry executives and academics, presided over by Economic Affairs Minister Hwang Ing-San.

The MOEA official said Taiwan's solar energy industry has expanded rapidly in recent years -- from a production value of NT$1.2 billion (US$36 million) in 2003 to NT$3.35 billion in 2004 and NT$7 billion in 2005, registering an estimated value of NT$10 billion for this year.

However, he noted that growth has been impeded by a shortage of raw materials -- 98 percent of Taiwan's poly-crystal silicon supply relies on foreign countries. He added that the key to the industry's future development is to raise the percentage of that supply that is produced domestically.

According to the MOEA, the five strategies are: introducing Siemens' conventional production technology, introducing the refining production technology of Siemens, seeking a technology transfer from the Russian Academy of Science, inviting retired German researchers and developing local metallurgy techniques.

The official estimated that local production capacity of poly-crystal silicon should be sufficient for a solar cell production of 100 megawatts in 2010, while the production capacity will expand from this year's 355 megawatts to 745 megawatts in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 23 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, June 23:
09:30, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend a ceremony marking the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research's 25th anniversary.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with Mohammed A.R.Galadari, head of Khaleej Times, a major newspaper in the United Arab Emirates.
16:00, President Chen will meet with labor groups representatives.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: 58 OFFICERS GET PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Fifty-eight officers will be promoted to the ranks of lieutenant general or major general from July 1, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.

The ministry said in a news release that 13 major generals or rear admirals will be promoted to the rank of Lt. general or vice admiral, while 45 colonels or captains will be promoted to the rank of major general or rear admiral.
President Chen Shui-bian has approved the promotion, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 23, or the 28th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoza dies at sea on his way
back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and
religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of
Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent
for the saxophone, a wind instrument in various sizes with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube.
1894: British monarch Edward VIII is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, the American zoologist and sociologist best
known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer
expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chinese Revolutionary
Party in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected
director-general.
1922: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Ting-fang,
who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of illness in Canton at the age of 81.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying
that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan on ROC-controlled Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching as governor of Taiwan.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social
Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait, Australia and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival
returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi
and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes
off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law
during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate
membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk dies in
California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The ROC and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation
agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
2000: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao meets with
Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, agreeing to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries. ROC-Macedonia diplomatic ties ended less than a year later when Macedonian pro-Beijing forces gained the upper hand in the nation's coalition government and transferred diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
2001: The Navy General Headquarters says that it has commissioned
a lawyer to protect its legitimate rights in a kickback scandal involving its purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."
