DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 8 sentenced to death for kidnapping
A Manila Regional Trial Court (RTC) yesterday sentenced eight convicted kidnappers to death a few days before President Arroyo is scheduled to sign into law a bill passed by Congress repealing the death penalty law.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo rushed to hospital
PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo was rushed to St. Luke's Medical Center last night after complaining of abdominal pains while having dinner at a restaurant on Tomas Morato Avenue in Quezon City.
The Philippine Star: 'Run NPAs to the ground'
Security forces have their marching orders: run the New People's Army (NPA) to the ground while protecting the people and business firms forced by the communist rebels into paying "revolutionary" taxes.
The Manila Times: Troops ordered to foil NPA 'taxmen
'Troops will be detailed to guard businesses in areas where communist rebels demand"revolutionary taxes, "President Arroyo said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Ships, planes sent to track ICBM launch
Tokyo has sent ships and planes to monitor North Korea amid regional jitters about a possible ICBM launch, Japanese officials said Thursday, playing dowm Pyongyang's capacity to load a nucleaqr warhead atopthe missile. (by Mike Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: 8 U.S. Troops charged in Iraqi's Death.
Seven Marines and a Navy medical corpsman were charged Wednesday with premeditated murder, kidnapping, conspiracy and other offenses in connection with the April 26 death of an Iraqi civilian in Hamandiya and an alleged cover-up.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA URGES HOG, FOWL FARMS TO SET UP NETS TO PROTECT AGAINST AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) urged operators of hog and fowl farms Friday to set up nets before the end of the year with government subsidies to prevent the outbreak of avian flu.

Officials from COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said that starting from Jan.1, 2007, any hog and fowl farms that have not set up nets will be fined between NT$10,000 and NT$50,000 (US$306-US$1,530).
If the hogs or fowl on those farms have to be culled due to avian flu infection, the government will not compensate the farmers for their losses, the officials added.

They noted that although Taiwan is not an avian flu-affected country, it is on the migratory route of many birds. This, coupled with its geographic proximity to China, where the problem of bird flu is serious, means that Taiwan can't let down its guard.

With the recent reports of avian flu in many countries, Taiwan still has to be on alert against its possible onslaught. All hog and fowl farms should set up the nets as soon as possible, the officials urged.
The bureau provided subsidies to 1,748 hog farms and 1,275 fowl farms to set up nets on a trial basis last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOSE FRIEND OF 1ST FAMILY RETURNS TO ANSWER PROSECUTOR'S QUESTIONS

TEXT.P: Medical professional Huang Fang-yen, a close friend of the first family who has been subpoenaed by the prosecution as a witness in an alleged gift voucher scandal case involving the first lady, returned to Taipei Friday from the United States.

The Taipei District Prosecutor's Office subpoenaed Huang earlier this week for questioning as a witness June 30. Huang, a deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Hospital in Taipei, is alleged to have passed to President Chen Shui-bian's wife, Wu Shu-jen, a huge amount of Sogo Department Store gift vouchers given by a businessman.

Huang was swamped by reporters and cameras upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport as his whereabouts had been unknown since he left a friend's residence near Washington, D.C. several days ago. He had asked for a leave of absence from his job until next month and had departed Taiwan for the United States for health reasons in early June.

Huang was whisked to his office at Shin Kong Hospital, where he appeared briefly for a news conference. He said he will meet judicial authorities soon to give a full account of what he knows about the case.
He also said that he would not hesitate to apologize to the Taiwan public if he were to be implicated in any wrongdoing.

A spokesman for the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office said Wedneday that prosecutors had decided to ask Huang to return to Taipei earlier as they saw it as necessary after gathering further evidence related to the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA HOLD TALKS AT WTO ON TOWEL IMPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 22 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's and China's delegations to the World Trade Organization (WTO) have held their first round of negotiations on Taipei's plan to impose safeguard measures against towel imports from China, sources said Thursday.
The talks mark the first between the two sides under the WTO framework since late 2002.
Chinese officials to the WTO confirmed that the talks were held Wednesday, during which both sides expressed their respective positions on the issue.

During the negotiations, Chinese representatives made clear to Taiwan that China is opposed to Taiwan's plan to impose safeguard measures against towel imports from China because they are "discriminatory" but that it can accept the anti-dumping measures adopted by Taiwan, sources said.

On April 25, Taiwan's WTO delegation officially requested negotiations with the Chinese delegation on the issue and notified the Chinese delegation of Taiwan's plan to impose safeguard import duties based upon the quantity on China-made towels.
According to the plan, the import duties will be NT$42 per kilogram in the first year, NT$32 per kilogram in the second year and NT$20 per kilogram in the third year.
If the measures are adopted, Taiwan will become the seventh WTO member to take safeguard measures against another member state after the United States, Peru, India, Canada, Columbia and Turkey.
From June 1, Taiwan has imposed a provisional anti-dumping tax on towel imports from China, with the tax rates registering up to 237.7 percent.

Also, Taiwan sent a Ministry of Finance official to China last week to investigate whether two Chinese towel makers have sold their products to Taiwan at prices far lower than market value, marking Taiwan's first anti-dumping visit to China under the WTO framework.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO PUSH FOR DOMESTIC CONSULTATIONS, CROSS-STRAIT PEACE TALKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he will push for domestic political consultations as well as for peace talks with the other side of the Taiwan Strait after the legislative vote on the recall motion against him next week.
The president made the remarks while receiving Mohammed A.R. Galadari, head of the Khaleej Times, a major newspaper in the United Arab Emirates.

President Chen, facing a recall motion initiated by the opposition in the wake of a series of corruption allegations against Chen's son-in-law and close associates, said he has been thinking about the issue of "where Taiwan should go" after next Tuesday's vote on the recall motion.

The recall motion is seen as unlikely to gain the required vote of two-thirds of all the legislators as the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party only maintains a slim majority in the 221-seat legislature.
The president said that Taiwan must first ensure domestic stability before a cross-strait peace is possible.

He also said that the world has invested US$560 billion in China and that according to a U.S. estimate, half of that total has come from Taiwan. Even more conservative estimates put the amount of Taiwan investment in China at 30 percent of the total overseas investment there.
Chen reaffirmed that Taiwan must maintain its economic independence, saying that China should not be "the only, the last and the whole market" of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS PUSH FOR ETHICS EDUCATION

TEXT.P: A group of academics condemned the failure of the 10-year-old educational reform as a "wavering monster" that has left Taiwan youths unhappier than before.

Members of the Education Rebuilding Link and the Taiwan Provincial Education Association jointly called a news conference in Taipei Friday to voice their views on what they call the failure of the ongoing educational reform, which they said has not helped the country's youths lead a happier life as originally expected. Instead, they said, the educational reform has only brought a heavier burden to the young.

The academics complained that over the past several years, changes to entrance exam systems have only benefited the rich while vocational and apprentice education have been disregarded. They added that the gaps between the rich and poor and between cities and rural areas have grown even wider and that ethics education has been neglected.

Professor Lin Huo-wang from National Taiwan University said the utilitarianism values that have been prevalent in Taiwan society have not subsided a bit because of the educational reform. On the contrary, he said, today's youths strive to study only for the purpose of seeking better jobs when they finish their education.
Without ethics education, he said, the youths have only become "test machines with animal impulses."

Lin argued that education and training are different. He noted that education allows youths to make preparations for leading a happy life, enables them to perceive the meaning of a happy life, and teaches them that wealth does not necessarily lead to happiness.

On how ethics education should be promoted, Lin said that first, the Taiwan people should know what kind of ethics should be built into Taiwan society. Taiwan is a free society, and in a free society, people should be educated to tolerate different opinions, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved down 53 points to close at 6,377, with 52,097 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August lost 51 points to finish at 6,300, with 451 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 76 points to close at 6,266, with 172 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 57 points to close at 6,280, with 25 contracts traded, while March futures lost 107 points to finish at 6,220, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,430 for July, 6,351 for August, 6,342 for September, 6,337 for December and 6,327 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
July TE futures dropped 2.4 points to close at 265.8, with 6,263 contracts traded, while August TE futures lost 1.25 points to finish at 264.9, with 24 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 0.75 points to close at 265, with 12 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures dropped 10.4 points to finish at 939.6, with 3,329 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures lost 4.6 points to close at 935.4, with seven contracts traded.
September TF futures moved down 14.8 points to finish at 924.8, with six contracts traded, while December TF futures lost 15.4 points to close at 928, with one contract traded.
March TF futures dropped 11.8 points to close at 929.6, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO HOLD TALENT SEARCH ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will hold a talent search activity targeting college students and fresh graduates Saturday, with more than 1,700 summer jobs and full-time jobs on offer, officials said Friday.

The activity will be held at an underground shopping arcade at the Chunghsiao East Road section of the city's mass rapid transit system, according to officials from the city's Employment Service Center.

More than 30 employers will take part in the activity, including Starbucks, Mister Donut, Friday's, Yamazaki Bakery, Mr. Brown Coffee, Wistron Corp., Taiwan Knowledge Book, Asia Pacific Telecom Group, Kingstone Co., Holiday KTV, ET Mall, Costo, Working House and Tsann Kuen Group, the officials said.
They said the positions offered by the employers include storekeepers, salespersons, customer service agents, electronic technicians and marketing personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO MONITOR PARTY LAWMAKERS' VOTE ON RECALL

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will visit the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday to monitor a vote on recalling President Chen Shui-bian, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Friday at the party headquarters.
According to Cheng, more than 5,000 supporters will show up outside the Legislative Yuan that day to display their support for the opposition's demand for Chen's ouster "to rebuild a clean Taiwan."
Ma and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will also hold a news conference to explain the party's stance after the presidential recall vote is held next Tuesday, Cheng said.

In a bid to solicit greater public backing to that end, the KMT will organize two large rallies Saturday and Sunday in Kaohsiung and Taipei, respectively, Cheng said, adding that both Ma and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will also attend the two activities to get together with their "pan-blue alliance" supporters.
On the eve of the June 27 presidential recall vote, Ma and KMT lawmakers will light "sky lanterns" on the square in front of the Legislative Yuan to pray for Taiwan and its people.

Despite the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" efforts to boot out Chen and hold him accountable for a spate of corruption allegations involving his family and close aides, the presidential recall motion stands a little chance of passing the Legislative Yuan as the vote requires a two-thirds majority approval and the "pan-blue alliance" holds only a slim legislative majority.
Soong has repeatedly said that PFP lawmakers will seek to topple the Cabinet if the presidential recall vote fails at the Legislative Yuan in order to further pressure Chen to step down.

In response to the "pan-blue" attempts to oust Chen, the president clarified his position regarding the many corruption scandals in a televised speech Tuesday in which he denied any wrongdoing by himself or by his wife.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT ANNOUNCES CULTURAL AWARD WINNERS

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government announced Friday the winners of the 10th Taipei Cultural Awards, with four figures who have contributed significantly to Taiwan's culture sector receiving the honor.

The four winners are Li Shu-yun, founder of the Chrysanthemum Chaism Studies; Lee Kuo-hsiou, artistic director of the Ping-Fong Acting Troupe; Hsu Chi, martial arts trainer for the Cloud Gate Dance Troupe; and Wu Hsing-kuo, founder of the Contemporary Legend Theater.
The four winners will also each receive a cash prize of NT$200,000.

Liao Hsien-hao, director of the Taipei city government's Department of Cultural Affairs, said his department has been encouraging artists who have traditional arts roots to innovate the traditional arts for the modern age.

Li Shu-yun, an overseas Chinese from Malaysia, founded the Chrysanthemum Chaism Studies ten years ago to promote tea culture and other artistic activities. Her tea house has been frequented by many of Taiwan's artists, designers and scholars. She won the award for "elevating the artistic taste of local people."

Lee Kuo-hsiou, a well-known performing artist in Taiwan, founded the Ping-Fong Acting troupe 20 years ago. His performances combine comedy, tragedy, traditional Chinese opera, magic and dance with profound human care.

Hsu, a world-renowned martial arts master, was invited to serve as trainer for the prominent Cloud Gate Dance Troupe six years ago. His efforts have injected new life into the modern dance of the troupe.

Wu, who created the Contemporary Legend Theater 20 years ago, adapted Shakespearean plays by using actors of traditional Chinese opera. He has attracted global attention for creating a new artistic style.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Ciampi explains why to vote "No" to constitutional reform.
Former president Carlo Ciampi said Thursday that he would go to vote and would vote "No" in the upcoming referendum on an amendment to the Constitution which will be held June 25-26. He said that he would do so because he opposes irregular reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN ACCLAIMED IN SEARCH AND RESCUE TRAINING

TEXT.P: Three female trainees in a just-concluded training program held in Taipei were praised Friday for their search and rescue skills by experts from the Taipei City Fire Department's search and rescue team at the commencement ceremony for the program.

The women were some of 28 Red Cross Society volunteers from South Asian countries and areas including Macau and Hong Kong who attended the three-week training program, co-sponsored by Taiwan's Red Cross Society and the Taipei City team, which began June 5.
The trainees took part in intensive training courses and practiced for nine hours a day, five days a week, to improve and sharpen their rescue skills.

Tsai Chia-lung, a deputy lieutenant of the Taipei search and rescue team, said the only three female trainees in the program performed well and said there are no differences between women and men in rescue operations.
The training program was formed with the goal of helping upgrade the disaster response mechanisms of South Asian countries prone to tsunami, including Indonesia and Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Thaksin's party broke law, panel finds.
Thailand's Election Commission (EC) has found that the ruling Thai Rak Thai (TRT) party violated polling laws by paying smaller political parties to contest the discredited April 2 elections - a move that could lead to the party's dissolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, June 23 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Tymoshenko Seeks Gas Deal Review While she is not yet Ukraine's prime minister.
Yulia Tymoshenko on Thursday began outlining what she wanted to do once in office, beginning with revisiting a Russian gas deal forged after supplies were halted in January. [ By ChangHung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 32.84 points to close at 6,452.31.
The bourse opened at 6,432.46 and fluctuated between 6,462.91 and 6,362.23 during trading. A total of 2.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.54 billion (US$2.37 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 3.2 percent and construction issues gaining 1.9 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 526 to 349, with 108 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA REITERATES LIMITS ON PBDE USE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has reiterated its limitations on the use of polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) in anything other than flame retardants, due to the hazardous effects of PBDEs on humans, an EPA spokesman said Friday.

PDBEs are widely use in making fire-resistant plastics and fabrics. When exposed to flames or high heat, PDBEs release bromines that absorb oxygen in the air to slow or stop the fire. During the process, however, endocrine-disrupting chemicals such as brominated dioxin and benzofuran are produced, which pose a health threat to humans.

The official noted that the EPA registered Octa-brominated diphenyl ether and Penta-BDE as class I hazardous chemicals last December, while Deca-BDE was categorized as a class IV hazardous chemical in 1999. He added that the EPA still allows the use of PBDEs in flame retardants, but said local makers should start using non-brominated substitutes as soon as possible.
According to the EPA, brominated flame retardants comprise 36 percent of global flame retardant products and 450 tons of PBDEs are used annually in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS TO FOCUS ON PEOPLE'S WELFARE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged opposition legislators Friday to concentrate their efforts on bills related to the people's welfare during the ongoing extra legislative session, instead of engaging in a political struggle against the ruling party.

Su pointed out that the budget proposals for several major development projects worth more than NT$100 billion, including a flood-control project, have been stuck in the legislature for a long time and require the support of lawmakers regardless of their political affiliation.
Su made the remarks while inspecting a highway project in Taipei County.

While the project has been planned for more than 10 years and the Executive Yuan has already earmarked the required funds for the project, opposition legislators are dragging their feet in passing the budget for the project, which has seriously delayed the progress of the construction work, Su noted.
Su said he hopes Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will help lobby KMT and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers to pass the budget as soon as possible.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP, which together hold a slim majority in the legislature, is aiming to push through a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian during the extra legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAGISTRATE ARRIVES IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By S.S. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei arrived in New York Friday at the beginning of a 14-day visit to the United States.
Chou, accompanied by nine Taipei county councilors and several county government officials, was warmly greeted by local Chinese community representatives at Kennedy Airport.

Saying that Taiwan should reach out more to cement its foreign relations, Chou said he will visit some U.S. local government and federal officials in search of bilateral trade and investment opportunities and cultural exchanges.

Chou will proceed from New York to Washington, D.C., where he will auction some of his paintings for charity to build a half-way home for drug addicts -- the first of its kind in Taipei County. Chou expressed hope that Taiwanese people living in the United States will also extend their love and care for Taiwan's drug users.
Chou will also visit Houston and nearby Harris County, where he will ink a twin-city accord with the Harris county chief, before returning to Taiwan from Los Angeles.
Chou is slated to give two speeches about Taiwan's law and order and the economic outlook for Taipei County in Los Angeles and visits various hi-tech companies there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DISPLAYS RECEIPTS AMID VOUCHER CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office produced Friday receipts of gift vouchers it purchased between 2003 and 2006 in an attempt to dispel doubts about the source of the vouchers.
Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, displayed the receipts after an opposition legislator questioned their source the previous day.

Kuomintang Legislator Sun Ta-chien said President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu-jen started to offer Sogo gift vouchers as draw prizes at the year-end gatherings of the Presidential Office in 2003 -- the year the ownership of the department store changed -- and demanded clarification from the Presidential Office on the source of the vouchers. Wu is embroiled in the "Sogo voucher" controversy.

Cho claimed that Sun's accusation was groundless and not worthy of response, but "because the public wants answers, " he located the invoices of the Presidential Office' s purchase of gift vouchers from various department stores between 2003 and 2006.

Cho said this is the first time the Presidential Office has publicly displayed receipts, although it is only required to produce them when the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, asks for an audit.

He said that in the past, rumors were always rampant in the last days prior to major elections, and now that an opposition-initiated recall motion will be put to a vote in the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday, "the same thing has happened."
He said he expected "more sensational revelations will come out in the next few days."

Noting that Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez Reyna will visit Taiwan at the end of this month, he said the Presidential Office staff were forced to put their preparations on hold to look for the invoices, which he claimed was a "terrible waste of time and personnel."

President Chen Sui-bian, in a televised report June 20, said that the first lady had not "directly" received gift vouchers from the department store and that the first family had not interfered in an ownership battle of the department store.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI PROVIDES DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CHECKLIST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) released Friday a checklist to help the public evaluate on their own the possibility of domestic violence.
Ministry statistics show that 68 percent of domestic violence cases reported in Taiwan occur in relationships between married couples, cohabiting couples or girlfriends and boyfriends.
The checklist uses a scale of 1 to 12 for the evaluation, with 0-1 indicating a green light, 2-5 indicating a yellow light and 6-12 indicating a red light.

The questions on the checklist include: "Are you required to inform your partners of all your expenses, your activities with friends and your whereabouts? " "Are you tired of communication failure with your partner? " and "Have you had enough of certain behavior from your partner?"
According to Lin Tzu-ling, executive secretary of the MOI's Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault Prevention Committee, if "yes" is the answer for all three questions, it could point to trouble.
If the result of the evaluation is a green light, it will mean that the respondent's relationship with his or her partner is not in trouble, according to Lin.
She claimed that a yellow light means there is tension or conflict in the relationship and that problems are likely to worsen if they are not dealt with properly.

A red light means the relationship is tense, with violence and conflict likely to have existed for a period of time, she went on, urging respondents with this problem to seek professional support or ring the 113 hotline for assistance.

Interior Minister Lee Yi-yang said that although the Domestic Violence Prevention Act has been enacted for eight years, it remains a common mentality among people in Taiwan that "domestic violence is a family affair. "
If the public can detect the crisis of domestic violence in their relationships early and seek professional assistance, they will be able to prevent the occurrence of serious conflict, Lee said.
The checklist is available on the MOI's official Web site and from domestic violence prevention centers around the country, MOI officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CONFIRMED JAPANESE ENCEPHALITIS CASE IN YILAN

TEXT.P: The first confirmed Japanese encephalitis case in Yilan County has been reported, health officials of the northeastern county said Friday.
A 45-year-old man was admitted to a hospital in mid-June after developing high fever. His other symptoms included lack of consciousness and breathing failures, the officials said.
The man remains unconscious and requires continued treatment, the officials said.
Although the members of the man's family and his neighbors have not shown any symptoms so far, health officials are continuing to monitor the situation, they added.
Japanese encephalitis is a viral disease that mostly occurs in the summer. The virus develops in pigs and is transmitted to individuals through mosquito bites.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' SAID INSTIGATING STUDENT MOVEMENT TO PUSH RECALL

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has been instigating a student movement to facilitate the party's scheme to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a legislative party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Friday.
According to Yeh Yi-chin, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party has pulled out all the stops to incite a student movement "without the students' knowledge."
The "pan-blue alliance" is pushing to recall Chen, believing his leadership ability is in doubt in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations implicating members of his family and close aides.
Yeh accused the "pan-blue" camp of instigating students from National Taiwan University (NUT) to first stage an 80-hour sit-in, beginning Saturday, even though the NUT final term exams are on.

DPP Legislator Kao Chih-pen said an NUT professor, who is one of the researchers of a KMT think-tank, has mobilized NUT students to take part in the planned sit-in, while Lin Yi-shish, head of the KMT Youth League, is championing an island wide petition to push for Chen's recall.
Kao described the KMT Youth League as "a wolf in sheep's clothing, " claiming that the KMT group is maneuvering a political struggle in the guise of a student movement.
DPP Legislator Kuan Pi-ling claimed that a student movement, which according to her "serves as a social trailblazer, " should be "pure, spontaneous and able to create core values of society."
Unfortunately, she claimed, NTU student Wang Chen-ya, who the "pan blue alliance says is organizing the sit-in has denied his involvement "on the Internet."
"Shameful" is not a word strong enough to condemn the "pan-blue" people, who have "impersonated" Wang for their scheme, Kuan claimed.
Kuan said NTU President Lee Si-chen should, on behalf of the institute and its students, speak out to condemn the shameful politicians for scheming the sit-in in Wang's name.
Meanwhile, NTU Secretary-General Fu Li-cheng said that NTU students have long played a key role in student movements in Taiwan's contemporary history.

Fu claimed that Saturday's sit-in -- titled "Calling for political conscience, president leaving office temporarily" -- is a "spontaneous activity, " adding that the NTU authorities choose to remain "neutral" on the matter, pointing out that the Constitution also empowers students with freedom of speech and the right to assembly and association.

Also Friday, KMT Youth League Director Lin Yi-shih, an incumbent KMT legislator, claimed that no movements conducted by university students can be "maneuvered" by any individual or political party. "The movement will not be recognized unless it is staged by the students spontaneously," he claimed.
Lin told the ruling DPP legislative caucus not to "intimidate" the students and not to label the "pan-blue alliance" for no reason.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.078 to close at NT$32.716.
A total of US$924 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.740 and fluctuated between NT$32.656 and NT$32.768.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE TAIPEI HOUSE PRICE WORTH 9.5 YEAR'S INCOME: SURVEY

TEXT.P: It will cost the average person 9.5 year's income to buy a house in Taipei, according the results of a survey released Friday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The survey, undertaken by a private firm for the council, found that for the whole country, the average house price is 6.8 times the national average income compared with 6.9 times for the final quarter of last year, although in Taipei the ratio has risen from 8.9 to 9.5.
The confidence index for house prices rose by 7.97 points to 107.12 in the first quarter of this year, indicating a prevailing optimism among potential buyers about rising house prices.
The survey also found that mortgage payments account for 41 percent of a person's income in Taipei City--- which is a four-year peak -- and 24.7 percent in Kaohsiung.
The survey was conducted between April 15 and May 15 among banks, house-selling firms and real estate brokers across Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SPREAD OF TUBERCULOSIS IN HUALIEN: COUNTY OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Eastern Hualien County health bureau officials urged the public Friday not to be panic over a rumor of a possible spread of tuberculosis in the county.

Bureau officials dismissed the danger of the disease spreading, as two policemen at a local police station found to have been infected with tuberculosis are now in stable condition following treatment.

Other policemen and the people who had contact with them were traced and X-rayed, and were all found to be uninfected, an indication that the disease has not spread among the public, the officials said.
The two policemen who developed sweating and coughing in May and were discovered later to have tuberculosis, are now convalescing at home, they noted.
The officials said that they will continue to monitor the situation, although they admitted that sometimes it can take as long as 10 years to detect the source of contagion.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 0.54 KG HEROIN

TEXT.P: Police in central Nantou County announced Friday that they had seized 540 grams of high-grade heroin and 161 grams of methamphetamine during a raid the previous night.

Police raided the home of drug dealer Lin Chin-lung in Changhua City, whereupon Lin tried to throw the drugs out of his house to avoid detection, while at the same time trying to contact his accomplices to collect the drugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICIANS SHOULD STEP DOWN FOR UNFOUNDED ACCUSATIONS: DPP

TEXT.P: Leaders of the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that politicians who make unfounded accusations against other political figures should step down.

They were referring to accusations made by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi that President Chen Shui-bian's wife Wu Shu-jen received gift vouchers from Pacific Sogo Department Store worth millions of dollars as a gift for her settlement in an ownership battle over the store.

KMT Legislator Sun Ta-chien claimed further that the president and the first lady used the Sogo gift vouchers as lucky draw gifts for employees of the Presidential Office at festivals. Chiu also demanded an explanation from the Presidential Office of the source of the Sogo vouchers.
In response, Chou Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, showed receipts for the vouchers Friday as evidence to rebut Sun's accusations.
Chen Chin-chun, a DPP legislative caucus whip, noted that the legislature is full of slander and unfounded accusations that will only disturb political circles.
Now that such accusations have "proved unfounded, " Sun should step down, Chen Chin-chun said.

DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said people have heard enough of the "unfounded accusations, " while Presidential Office staff have to spend time finding evidence to prove their innocence, disturbing their regular work.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Kuan Pi-ling speculated that ruling and opposition camp supporters might fight outside the legislature June 27, when an opposition-proposed motion to recall President Chen over corruption allegations will be put to a vote in the legislature.
Kuan said the motion proposal needs to be settled inside the legislature and not in the street.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS WANT TO REVIEW PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE'S EXPENDITURE RECORDS

TEXT.P: Another political storm seems to be brewing over the Presidential Office and first family after an Australian resident of Taiwanese origin said Thursday that her cousin had taken all her receipts from a Taipei hotel from 2000 to 2005 and given them to first lady Wu Shu-jen.
Ligi Lee, a resident of Australia, is the owner of Taipei-based Taiwan Ang Co., which markets a series of products featuring the peachy pink color -- a symbol of festivity to the people of Taiwan.

She told TV reporters that her cousin Lee Bi-chun, chairwoman of Shinlin Sinseng Pharmaceutical Co., had taken all her purchase receipts from Grand Hyatt Taipei Hotel over the past five years, with an aggregate total of some NT$10 million.
She said that when asked about the purpose of asking for the receipts, her cousin replied that they would be given to the first lady.
Legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) now want to find out whether the Presidential Office used any of those receipts to embezzle public funds meant for state affairs.
The KMT's legislative caucus has formally requested the Ministry of Audit under the Control Yuan to supply the Presidential Office's expenditure records from the past five years.

In its letter to the Ministry of Audit, the KMT caucus says opposition legislators are exercising their right to review files and documents according to law in order to clarify whether the Presidential Office engaged in forgery or embezzlement of public funds.

President Chen has been under mounting pressure to step down over a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and members of his family. His son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, is implicated in at least six alleged corruption cases.

The Legislative Yuan will vote on a motion June 27 seeking to recall the president, although the motion's passage appears unlikely because the KMT and its ally the People First Party only hold a slight majority in the legislature -- short of the two-thirds majority required to pass the motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOVE TO ADJUST ARMS PROCUREMENT PLANS NOT DELAYED: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has not delayed the procedure of adjusting its long-stalled arms procurement package based on the Legislative Yuan's opinions, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Friday in response to an accusation by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

During a meeting with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou expressed doubt over the Executive Yuan's June 14 approval of a defense ministry-proposed draft provisional act governing crucial national defense investment, claiming that the consent came too late for the legislature to place the draft bill on the agenda for its June 13-30 extra session.
The Legislative Yuan decided the agenda June 12 and the arms procurement bill was not listed.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" headed by the KMT, which strongly opposed the government's original NT$610.8 billion arms procurement package, has been accused of "not caring" about national security after failing to have the legislature place the new draft bill on the agenda for its ongoing extra session.
The draft bill will allow for appropriation of a budget of NT$6.3 billion for four projects aimed at enhancing military power.

The budget was proposed to finance the following projects: constructing a runway for cargo aircraft on the remote, Taiwan-controlled Taiping Island in an effort to safeguard the lives and property of Taiwanese operating in the South China Sea; engaging in a review of a project to buy diesel-electric submarines; replacing outdated anti-submarine equipment; and upgrading the capability of the Patriot missile systems.
Ma asked Su to offer the public an explanation for the "delay" in submitting the new draft bill for legislative review.

Cheng said that the arms procurement bill has been put off at the legislature for a long time, blaming the "pan blue alliance" for continually blocking the bill from being placed on the legislature agenda.
Calling for a "rational dialogue" between the ruling and opposition parties, Cheng expressed the hope that the two sides will cooperate with each other in the pursuit of national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION INDEX UP 8.47%: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing production index (MPI) stood at 145.38 in May, a growth of 8.47 percent over the same month last year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Friday.
MOEA officials said the growth was due to an increasing global demand for consumer electronic products, panels, communication, petrochemicals and steel products.

Among the different industries, the production index of the information and electronic sectors grew the most -- by 15.52 percent over the same month last year -- followed by growth in the chemical sector by 6.3 percent, the consumer product industry by 2.28 percent and the metal and machinery industries by 0.59 percent.
Cumulatively, the MPI in the first five month of the year registered 138.19, an increase of 7.9 percent over the same period last year.

Meanwhile, the statistics also show the industrial production index (IPI) stood at 142.44 in May, a year-on-year growth of 8.6 percent, and the IPI for the first five months registered 134.76, a growth of 7.88 percent over the same period last year.

Noting that Taiwan's short-term exports will continue growing due to the strong global demand for information and electronic products, the officials said this will boost the manufacturing production index in the next few months.
They predicted moderate growth for the manufacturing production index in June, and an 8 percent growth for the MPI in the first half of this year over the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bank Records Secretly Tapped; Administration Began Using Global Database Shortly After 2001 Attacks.
The Bush administration, relying on a presidential declaration of emergency, has secretly been tapping into a vast global database of confidential financial transactions for nearly five years, according to U.S. government and industry officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bank Data Sifted in Secret by U.S. to Block Terror
Under a secret Bush administration program initiated weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, counterterrorism officials have gained access to financial records from a vast international database and examined banking transactions involving thousands of Americans and others in the United States, according to government and industry officials. The program is limited to tracing transactions of people suspected of having ties to Al Qaeda by reviewing records from the nerve center of the global banking industry, a Belgian cooperative that routes about US$6 trillion daily between banks, brokerages, stock exchanges and other institutions. The records mostly involve wire transfers and other methods of moving money overseas and into and out of the United States. Most routine financial transactions confined to this country are not in the database.
Wall Street Journal: Hidden Burden, As Workers' Pensions Wither, Those for Executives Flourish There's a twist to some big companies' pension situation -- while reducing, freezing or eliminating pensions for workers, the executives are building up ever-bigger pensions, causing the companies' financial obligations for them to balloon. Companies disclose little about any of this. But a Wall Street Journal analysis of corporate filings reveals that executive benefits are playing a large and hidden role in the declining health of America's pensions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY EXPORT ORDERS UP 26.01%: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export orders for May totaled US$24.6 billion in terms of value, recording a year-on-year growth of 26.01 percent thanks to global economic growth, which contributed to a vivid demand for consumer electronic products in the international market, according to statistics released Friday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Most orders were placed for electronic products and reached US$5.48 billion in value, posing a growth of 24.89 percent compared to the same month last year.

Export orders for information and telecommunication products grew 25.63 percent in May to US$4.45 billion, while those for transportation equipment -- including new ships -- recorded a year-on-year boost of 198 percent to US$1.4 billion, the tallies showed.

In some areas, orders from Hong Kong (including China) reached US$6.39 billion in May, registering a year-on-year growth of 35.9 percent and making that region Taiwan's largest source of export orders for the month, following the United States.
Cumulative export orders during the Jan.-May period amounted to US$116.59 billion, growing 21.64 percent from the same period last year.
MOEA officials expect export orders in 2006 to post an annual growth of more than 15 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 105 UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS PLACE AD CALLING FOR PRESIDENT TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: More than 100 professors from Taiwan's universities placed an advertisement in two major newspapers Friday, urging President Chen Shui-bian to step down because they claimed he no longer has the people's trust and is incapable of carrying out his constitutional duties.
The 105 professors, whose names appeared at the end of the joint statement, urged the president to "be responsible to the people" and step down gracefully in order to "set a good political example."
They said in the statement that as intellectuals, they firmly believe the moral integrity of a chief of state must be beyond question.

However, they continued, President Chen is not only unable to offer a reasonable explanation for why some senior aides and family members have been involved in a series of corruption scandals, but also lacks the ability to reflect upon himself and his administration.
The professors added that Chen's "unfit" conduct has "violated the basic moral conscience" of Taiwan's people and has "confused Taiwan society's system of simple values."
Therefore, they concluded, Chen should resign his post as chief of state as soon as possible and set a good example for the benefit of solidifying Taiwan's democracy.

In reaction to the joint statement, legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) dismissed it as an appeal by professors who are supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party.
As a rebuttal, several of the professors told reporters the 105 endorsements in the joint statement comprise professors of all political persuasions, including DPP supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT RETAINS CONTROL OVER MEGA HOLDINGS

TEXT.P: The partially state-owned Mega Financial Holding Co. remained under government control Friday after an apparent maneuver by the Cabinet turned unfavorable results in a board of directors election to its advantage.

Holding 22.78 percent of Mega Financial's shares, the government managed to capture only seven seats and lost its majority on the 15-member board, including seven representing private shareholders and one independent member.

However, at a meeting held after the election, the new board re-elected Cheng Shen-chih as chairman, which was followed by resignations of the independent board member and another member representing private shareholders, leaving the government's seven seats in control of the 13-member board.
A by-election to fill the two vacancies is impossible without approval by two-thirds of board members.
Commenting on the new development, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said the Cabinet is "not entirely satisfied" with the results, although it had achieved its goal.
She added that the Cabinet will closely supervise future developments involving Mega Financial Holding Co. and safeguard the public's interest in the financial institution.
Tsai stressed that the government will be in full control of Mega Financial for at least the next three years.

The dramatic turn of events dissolved a crisis for Premier Su Tseng-chang and Minister of Finance Joseph Lyu, who had faced pressure from opposition legislators to step down if the government should lose its operational control over Mega Financial's NT$2.13 trillion (US$65.23 billion) in capital.

Mega Financial, Taiwan's second largest financial service company, was formed by state-owned Chiao Tung Bank and International Securities Co. through an exchange of shares in 2002 under the government's financial reform program.

Cheng, who serves concurrently as chairman of Chiao Tung Bank, announced after the board meeting that when Chiao Tung Bank is merged with the Internal Commercial Bank of China Aug. 21, he will no longer be the chairman of the expanded entity.
Cheng also assured that he will not allow Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. to buy Mega Financial in the next three years.
Chinatrust has increased its shares in Mega Financial from 12 percent to 15 percent in recent months and is reportedly aiming to eventually take it over.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR MORE CROSS-STRAIT RELIGIOUS EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan should expand religious exchanges with China as part of efforts to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait, a group of advisers to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

Speaking at the council's monthly consultation meeting, the MAC advisers said the government should adopt an "open-door" policy toward cross-strait religious exchanges because such engagements would foster friendship among people on both sides and contribute toward maintaining cross-strait peace.
With robust religious freedom and diverse religions, the advisers said, Taiwan has many advantages in promoting the bilateral religious exchanges.
The advisers said the exchanges should not be confined to organizing pilgrimage tours of historic Buddhist and Taoist temples in China.

In future, the advisers said, the two sides should strengthen exchanges and cooperation in theological studies and promote core values and scriptures of many religions. By doing so, they said, the two sides will not only learn from each other's strengths, but China will be less likely to use traditional religious activities -- such as Buddhist and Taoist programs -- to boost its "unification" drive.

As a countermeasure, the advisers suggested that Taiwan's flourishing Christian and Catholic groups play a more active role in promoting the exchanges, including inviting more Chinese Christians and Catholics to visit Taiwan to boost mutual understanding and trust.

On promoting China's religious freedom, the advisers said Taiwan can play diverse roles. For instance, they said, local universities can invite Chinese professors in various religious fields to visit Taiwan, or co-sponsor seminars on religious themes with foreign groups and invite Chinese scholars to attend.

Such exchanges are expected to help enhance Taiwan's influence on China's religious organizations, they said. Given China's strict control of religious activities, the advisers said cross-strait religious exchanges should focus more on humanitarianism themes and avoid controversial issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS IMPROVEMENT IN JOB MARKET

TEXT.P: President Chen shui-bian said Friday he is confident that Taiwan will be able to keep its unemployment rate below 4 percent this year.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of representatives of major labor organizations.

Thanks to concerted efforts of the government and the private sector, Chen said the nation's jobless rate dropped to 3.84 percent in May, marking the seventh consecutive month that saw the unemployment rate fall below 4 percent.
Barring unexpected developments, Chen said he is convinced that the country will be able to realize its goal of having the unemployment rate routinely below 4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 24 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, June 24:
10:00, The results of a public opinion poll on perception of domestic law and order will be unveiled at a seminar to be held at Howard International House.
10:40, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a prayer service for fishery workers in Wanli, Taipei County.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will visit Lungshan Temple in Taipei City's Wanhua district.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 24, or the 29th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1314: Led by Robert the Bruce, the Scots defeat the English army at the Battle of Bannockburn.
1340: The British fleet destroys the French at Sluys in the Hundred Years' War.
1497: John Cabot, originally Giovanni Caboto, an Italian-born navigator and explorer in the service of the English crown, discovers the North American mainland just 35 days after leaving Bristol in his ship, the Matthew.
1812: Napoleon Bonaparte, leading his Grand Armee, begins his invasion of Russia.
1821: Simon Bolivar, known as "the Liberator," leads 8,000 South American patriots to victory against 4,000 Spanish Royalists at the Battle of Carabobo in Venezuela, virtually freeing Venezuela from Spanish control.
1940: Japan formally asks Britain to close the Burma Road.
1948: The Berlin airlift begins as the Allies delivery food and essential supplies by air to Berliners after the Soviets blockade the city.
1953: Jacqueline Bouvier announces her engagement to Senator John F. Kennedy.
1964: Fu Jen Catholic University, founded in Beijing in 1926 and taken over by the Chinese communists in 1950 after the ROC government moved to Taiwan, is reopened in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
1973: Eamon de Valera resigns as president of Ireland at the age of 90.
1974: Robert E. Page, and Frank W. Beatty, vice presidents of United Press International, arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the banking law.
1975: The China External Trade Development Council and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, sign an agreement to promote trade and other economic relations.
1976: A 1,000,000-ton dry dock at Kaohsiung shipyard is christened.
1976: The Executive Yuan appoints Fan Kwei-shu as political vice minister of the Ministry of Justice and Chen Min-ching as commissioner of the Department of Reconstruction, Taiwan Province.
1978: Lieutenant-Colonel Ahmed Hussein al-Ghashni, president of the Yemen Arab Republic, is killed by a bomb carried by a South Yemen special envoy, who also dies in the explosion.
1981: The opening ceremony of the 30th Council Meeting of the Asian Pacific Parliamentarians' Union is held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
1983: President Assad of Syria orders Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to leave Damascus.
1983: Sally Ride becomes the first American woman in space when she blasts off in Challenger with four male astronauts.
1987: Kim Dae-jung and 300 other dissidents are released after two weeks of unrest in South Korea.
1989: Zhao Ziyang, who expressed sympathy with pro-democracy students in mainland China, is replaced by Jiang Zemin as general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party.
1993: A Xiamen Airlines passenger plane is hijacked and diverted to Taiwan by Chang Wenlung, a mainland Chinese youth.
1994: Russia and the European Union sign a friendship accord in Corfu, Greece, designed to help stabilize Russia and bring it closer to its former rivals.
1998: The UNSC agrees to maintain sanctions against Iraq for 60 more days.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government there are five good principles to be kept in mind and respected. First, to benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country; secondly, to encourage labor without giving cause for complaint; thirdly, to desire for the enjoyments of life without being covetous; fourthly, to be dignified without being supercilious; fifthly, to inspire awe without being severe."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: U.S. Secretly Tracks Global Bank Data. The U.S. government, without the knowledge of many banks and their customers, has engaged for years in a secret effort to track terrorist financing by accessing a vast database of confidential information on transfers of money between banks worldwide.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Brazil just too much for Japan
Brazil shattered Japan's World Cup dreams and ended coach Zico's reign in the most humiliating of fashions Thursday night as the five-time champion handed out a 4-1 thrashing in their final Group F match.

BAGUIO CITY: The Communist Party of the Philippines, undeterred by the all-out offensive declared by the military, has ordered its armed wing, the New People's Army, to strike back with guerrilla attacks.
