DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-DPP U.S. GROUPS CALL FOR END TO POLITICAL STRUGGLE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Thirteen pro-Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Taiwanese groups in the United States called on the opposition Friday to stop their political struggle against the ruling party "to sustain Taiwan's development."

In a joint statement, the groups, led by the U.S. east coast branches of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, expressed concern over the political turmoil marked by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -led campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

The groups said they are deeply saddened by the scandals allegedly involving Chen's son-in-law and understand the doubts and criticism that Taiwan society has against the government following this and a spate of other corruption scandals involving other members of Chen's family and his close aides.

They said that while they support the investigation by the judicial authorities into the scandals, the "arbitrary revelations" by the Taiwan media of "unverified" information concerning the cases and the opposition's taking advantage of the situation to create political struggle are worrying.

Claiming that the revelations have violated the principle of secret investigation and have seriously undermined the public's trust in the judiciary, they urged those who have engaged in such activities to stop interfering in the judiciary.
They said the media should play the role of the fourth estate impartially to uphold justice, instead of creating social unrest and disturbance.
Meanwhile, they called on the ruling party to show the public its courage and sincerity in self-examination and urged the opposition to stop their struggle against the ruling party.

Also Friday, officials at the KMT's New York Youth League claimed that integrity is a basic requirement for politicians and that the people should judge politicians with the highest of moral standards.
They urged Chen to resign to "save social costs" and called on civil servants in Taiwan to remain neutral and responsible in performing their duties.
A petition launched by the youth league calling for Chen's ouster has won the support of 742 Taiwanese expatriates in the United States, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Plot to attack US buildings thwarted.
Seven people arrested in Miami planned attacks on US Federal Bureau of Investigation ( FBI) buildings and the landmark Sears Tower in Chicago.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA APPROVES R&D ALLIANCE ON GENE VECTORS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has approved an application from three local pharmaceutical companies to form a research and development alliance on gene vectors, an MOEA official said Saturday.

He described gene therapy as a new hope for people with cancer or genetic diseases, but noted that Taiwan still lacks key knowledge in producing genetic medicines, so the alliance should be helpful to Taiwan's biomedical industry.

The alliance -- formed by ADImmune, Myceanx and CESCO -- will not only develop its own technologies in gene vectors but will also seek technology transfers from other countries to assist local genetic medicine production.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez Reyna will arrive in Taiwan Monday for a four-day visit at the invitation of the government, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Saturday.
He will be welcomed with full military honors at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office, the officials said.

Fernandez will sign a joint communique with President Chen Shui-bian and is also scheduled to visit Foreign Affairs Minister Huang Chih-fang, as well as host a ceremony to kick off a trade fair of Dominican goods, attend a presentation of trade and investment in Dominican Republic, and visit the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center in the southern county of Tainan.
Fernandez will also receive an honorary doctoral degree from Chinese Culture University in suburban Taipei, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN HOPING TO VISIT OPPOSITION LEADERS AFTER RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun is planning to visit the leaders of the two main opposition parties after a June 27 legislative vote on a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a DPP official said Saturday.

According to DPP spokesman Tsai Huang-liang, the DPP will try to stabilize the situation after the political turmoil and hopes that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will take part in inter-party dialogue to be promoted by Chen.

On Friday, Chen said he will push for political consultations with the opposition and peace talks with China after the June 27 vote, which was initiated by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP in the wake of a spate of corruption allegations involving the first family and Chen's close aides.
If more than two-thirds of the legislators vote in favor of it, the motion will then be put to a national referendum.
However, with the "pan-blue alliance" controlling only a slim majority in the legislature, the odds of the motion passing the legislature are believed to be slim.
Local media reports have said the "pan-blue alliance" might initiate a second campaign to recall Chen if it fails to push through the motion next week.

Responding to the reports, Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, refused to confirm if there is a plan for a second recall campaign and stressed that the KMT's priority at present is to make sure the motion passes the legislature next week so that the people can decide on whether the president should be unseated.
Pan said the KMT, in addition to holding public briefings to explain to the people the reasons for recalling Chen, is also trying to lobby DPP legislators to support the motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80 PERCENT OF PEOPLE FEEL NO IMPROVEMENT IN SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: Up to 80.5 percent of the respondents to a recent poll said law and order have not improved at all over the past three months, according to the results of a poll released by the non-profit Institute for National Policy Research (INPR) Saturday.

The INRR published the poll results on public feelings on law and order for the third time since Premier Su Tseng-chang vowed in March to step down if the public do not perceive a marked improvement in law and order within six months.
Overall, however, public satisfaction with law and order has risen dramatically, climbing to 29.9 percent compared to 15.89 percent in the first survey.

On the other hand, the public faith in the Executive Yuan's declaration to improve law and order has declined. In the first survey, those who said social order has improved totaled 27.16 percent. The figure dropped to 16.9 percent in the latest survey, even lower than 22.53 percent in the second survey.

INPR officials said the conflicting figures seem to reflect the fact that the public do not harbor high expectations for the current social order and are worried about the government's determination to improve the situation.

The officials said that on law and order issues that have surfaced over the past month, attempted fraud is considered the most serious problem in all three surveys, with more than 80 percent of the respondents having been targeted by scammers.
The respondents are also more concerned about problems with substandard food products than about collection of debts through violent methods.
The INPR commissioned Master Survey & Research Co. to conduct the survey by telephone June 16-17. A total of 1,078 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of around 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU COUNTY APPROVES BLUEPRINT FOR BIOMEDICAL SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu County's urban design committee has approved a construction blueprint for a biomedical science park in the northern county.

Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-Chin said Saturday that the approved designs cover a hospital and accessory facilities in the East I area, as well as a restaurant and a parking lot with space for 850 cars in the East IV area.
Cheng said that after receiving the permit, construction of several new buildings can get under way right away and the county government will provide necessary assistance to the park administration.

The National Science Council has done an evaluation on the science park recently, and the results show that over a 20-year period, the park can expand the production value of Taiwan's biomedical industry by NT$500 billion (US$15.5 billion) , as well as creating tax revenue of an estimated NT$71.3 billion.
The park, with six major research and development centers, is expected to be fully operational by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO HOLD POLITICAL CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed to hold political consultations at home and engage in peaceful talks with the other side of Taiwan Strait, while "confessing" to a Buddhist master Saturday for his lack of wisdom in governing the country.

According to Chou Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, Chen visited Buddhist Master Sheng Yen, founder of Dharma Drum Mountain, earlier in the day to confess that due to his lack of wisdom and mercy, society has been full of confrontations during his mandate of the last six years.

Expressing hope that Master Sheng Yen can use his religious wisdom to help lead the country toward happiness, Chen vowed to engage in domestic political consultations and cross-strait talks for the welfare of the country and cross-strait peace.

Chen said that although he cannot meet with Master Sheng Yen every day, he has the master's calligraphy hanging in his office. The calligraphy reads: "Mercy will have no enemy, wisdom will cause no trouble."

Chen is embroiled in several corruption allegations implicating his son-in-law and close aides and is facing an opposition-proposed motion for a referendum to recall him over the corruption allegations and his incompetence.

With the approach of June 27, when the recall motion will be put to a vote in the legislature, and amid speculation that ruling and opposition camp supporters might fight outside the legislature that day, Chen also visited other temples near Taipei Saturday to pray for the stability of the country.
On Sunday he will visit several temples in his hometown in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. FTA FAVORABLE TO U.S.: TAIWAN OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 23 (CNA) (By Wu Jih-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official urged the United States Friday to prioritize the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) with Taiwan, which she described as the most valuable gateway for U.S. small- and medium-sized businesses to make inroads into the Asian market.

Addressing the annual conference of the Taiwan Chambers of Commerce of North America, ROC Minister without Portfolio Ho Mei-yueh said the establishment of a Taiwan-U.S. FTA would be advantageous to the United States because it would create a lot of business opportunities for U.S. businesses.
While it would not be a problem for large U.S. businesses to enter the Chinese market, small- and medium-sized businesses need a reliable partner like Taiwan to enter the Asian market, Ho claimed.

Ho said Taiwan is the United States' best trading partner and its best friend in Asia, with Taiwan being a major destination of U.S. exports including corn, soybeans, wheat, beef, chemicals, plastics, textiles, steel and machinery.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT LAW ON INDOOR AIR QUALITY CONTROL UNVEILED

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration unveiled Saturday a draft law aiming at controlling the indoor air quality of public establishments and office buildings.

The draft law stipulates that the concentrations of pollutants such as carbon dioxide, suspended particulates, volatile organics and bacteria in indoor environments must not exceed the EPA-recommended levels for indoor air.

According to Yeh Fang-lu, a section chief from the EPA's Department of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control, as people spend 80 percent to 90 percent of their time indoors every day, the quality of indoor air directly affects the quality and efficiency of their work, as well as their health.
Research indicates that people can display symptoms such as drowsiness, itchy eyes and dry throat after staying for long periods in an indoor environment where the air quality is bad, Yeh noted.
Yeh said that after the law is enacted, it will apply to public establishments first before expanding to other facilities.

Violators will be subject to fines of up to NT$25,000 (US$765) and will be required to make improvements. Until the situation is improved, prominent signs should be set up at the entrance of the buildings to warn the public of the air quality inside, Yeh said.
She said the draft law will be submitted to the Cabinet for review soon and is likely to be included in the Legislative Yuan's agenda for the next session set to start in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP MIFFED ABOUT PLANNED POLICE CRACKDOWN ON NUDE ACTIVITY

TEXT.P: An environmental protection group expressed anger Saturday after police said they would crack down on a nude event planned for next Monday to highlight opposition to the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant in northern Taiwan.

The group was responding to an earlier warning by the police, who said that according to regulations on assembly, the group should have applied to Juifang police station one week prior to the activity. Since the group has not done so, police will act accordingly, Juifang police officials added.

Ho Tsung-Hsun, secretary general of the Taiwan Environmental Protecting Union (TEPU), said the group has solicited the public to pose nude and display the words "No Nuke" on Fulung Beach near the plant site next Monday.

The event is aimed at conveying the ideals of opposing the nuclear power plant and saving Fulung beach, which is eroding due to a nearby wharf that has been constructed to take delivery of heavy equipment destined for the nuclear power plant.

The event is described as an artistic performance aimed at environmental protection, he said, adding that the group has acted according to law, which stipulates that all outdoor assemblies and protest marches require permission from the related authorities, while academic, literary, travel, sports competitions or similar activities are exceptions.
He stressed that a hotel has been commissioned to manage Fulung beach, that the beach is privately owned and that the TEPU has already paid for its use.
In addition, the event is in line with the government's policy of a "nuke-free homeland, " he said, questioning why the police have arbitrarily decided that it is a protest activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY CHIEF VISITS NEW YORK TO SEEK TRADE OPPORTUNITIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, heading a trade-promotion delegation, hosted a trade and investment conference in New York Friday as part of efforts to attract traders and investors to his county in northern Taiwan.

During the conference, which was attended by Taiwanese living in the region, Chou introduced Taipei County's investment environment. However most of the participants appeared more interested in Taiwan's current political situation, and pointed out that a stable political environment is the key factor for businessmen seeking to invest.

Asked about the opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, the county chief, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang, admitted that it might be difficult for the motion to be adopted in the legislature, but said it is possible for a no-confidence vote on the Cabinet to be successful.
The topic was also brought up in the delegation's following visit to the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association.
The association, founded in 1883, is one of the oldest Chinese community organizations at New York's Chinatown, which is one of the most significant Chinatowns in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY TRADE-PROMOTING DELEGATION VISITS N.Y. CITY COUNCIL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taipei County official trade-promotion delegation, headed by County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, visited the New York City Council Friday.

The delegation met with council member John Liu, who guided the group on a tour of the city council founded in 1625 and the historic City Hall, site of the office of George Washington, the first president of the United States.
Nine members of the Taipei delegation are county councilors.

Introducing the election system in New York City, Liu said there are currently 8.2 million people residing in the "Big Apple." Since there are 51 seats in the city council, on average every 160,000 New York voters are obliged to elect one member of the council, Liu said.
New York is the delegation's first stop of its two-week visit to the U.S., aimed at seeking trade opportunities and boosting foreign investment in the northern Taiwan county.
Chou said he hopes the trip will help boost Taipei County's image and attract U.S. enterprises, as well as U.S.-based Taiwanese businesses, to invest in his county.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PROSPECTS TO BE HELD JULY 4

TEXT.P: A conference on Taiwan's economic prospects in the coming 10 years will be held July 4, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the organizer of the conference, said Saturday.

Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) , will present proposals to the government on behalf of Taiwan's major economic think tanks -- CIER, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, the Taiwan Thinktank, the Taiwan Research Institute and Academia Sinica.
The meeting will be considered a prelude to the much-anticipated Cabinet-organized conference on Taiwan's sustainable economic growth scheduled for late July.
Commissioned by Premier Su Tseng-chang, Siew is expected present a research report conducted jointly by the five think tanks at the July 4 conference.

Part of the content of the report was revealed in advance Friday, the 25th anniversary of CIER, in which Siew suggested that the government develop Taiwan into a "global center of value-added services."

With Taiwan's unique economic characteristics, in which small- and medium-sized enterprises (SME's) are full of dynamism, Siew suggested that government incentives should not focus on giant companies, but rather on the SMEs, which Siew said can increase the country's development space and avoid Taiwan companies being marginalized.

Noting that the success of future markets will hinge on who can provide the best value-added services to clients, Siew said Taiwan companies need not waste too much time enlarging the scale of their enterprises but should focus on the speed of their services, the number of patents they obtain and their participation rate in the market.

As Taiwan does not boast the huge capital needed to support the giant companies that are a feature of Japan, South Korea and China, Siew said, Taiwan should emulate countries such as Finland, the Netherlands and Ireland by focusing on its own economic characteristics amid the pressure from the neighboring big countries.

At a CIER celebration cocktail party Friday, Siew also envisioned an economic outline for Taiwan in 2015 with the hope that Taiwan might enter the list of advanced countries at that time, when the per capita gross domestic product is expected to have reached US$30,000.

Siew stressed that if the government follows its proposed policies of cultivating talent, making more connections with the rest of the world and setting up brand names, Taiwan might see its average economic growth rate in the coming 10 years topping 5 percent, and the average unemployment rate being reduced to under 4 percent with the creation of some 1.26 million jobs in the next 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Voters urged to vote in referendum on constitutional reform.
Both the ruling and opposition camps urged voters to vote in the upcoming referendum on an amendment to the Constitution which will be held June 25-26. The proposed reforms are to radically alter government institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO PUSH FOR 'AMITY MEETING' AMONG RIVAL GROUPS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that she will organize an informal gathering of opinion leaders of different political stripes for "amity talks" after the June 27 vote in the legislature on a referendum to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Lu made the remarks while attending a religious ritual in Taipei County's Wanli coastal township to pray for social stability and national wellbeing amid the current political turmoil stirred up by the corruption allegations involving members of Chen's family and his close aides and an opposition-initiated campaign to unseat him over the allegations.
Saying she dislikes seeing society divided by political disputes, Lu said she has long planned to invite politicians from the nation's two rival political camps to meet for reconciliation talks.

Before the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) launched the recall motion last week, Lu had proposed a meeting of officials from the ruling and opposition camps for exchanges of views on major policy and political issues, to be co-chaired by herself and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT veteran.

The plan was aborted because the timing was not right, Lu said, adding that she was not daunted by the setback and will continue her efforts to help mend differences between the "pan-blue alliance" and the DPP-led "pan-green camp" for the sake of seeking a breakthrough to the protracted domestic political stalemate.

As an initial step, Lu said she will invite leaders of private social groups, regardless of their party affiliation or preference, to an informal "brainstorming session" on major national issues and feasible measures to halt partisan infighting.

Lu said the planned meeting will take place after next Tuesday's legislative vote on the presidential recall motion, which is widely seen as unlikely to succeed. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" holds a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan but needs to muster two-thirds of the votes in the 221-seat legislature to clear the way for voters to decide Chen's fate in a national referendum.
According to Lu, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, a key figure in the campaign to oust Chen, once promised her to help push for realization of her "amity" meeting.
In related developments, Lu said Friday evening that those in power should never be arrogant nor break the law, as their power comes from public mandate.

Speaking at a training program for nurturing a new generation of leaders for the 21st Century, Lu said both she and Chen will pull out all the stops to fulfill their official duties for the remainder of their term in office. "Both of us have come to power with integrity and will leave office in style," she added.
Noting that the 21st Century is an era of globalization and digitization, Lu encouraged those attending the class to make good use of knowledge and to cultivate international perspective and vision.

She also told her audience that the 21st Century is an era of gender equality. "We should come to understand that no single thing can be monopolized by a single gender and that cooperation and division of labor between the two genders is required," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPTIMISM SEEN IN EFFORT TO SEEK GERMAN INVESTMENT: COUNTY CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing expressed Saturday in Geneva his optimism in persuading German makers of medical equipment to invest in his southern Taiwan county.

Yang, heading a county government delegation, is on a European visit aimed at persuading some of the world's leading producers of devices and equipment for medical treatment to set up manufacturing operations at the Kaohsiung Science Park.

The delegation arrived in Geneva a day earlier after concluding a visit to Germany. In an interview with CNA in Geneva, Yang explained the prospects for the development of Kaohsiung's medical equipment manufacturing sector.

Yang said the industry needs a workforce with expertise in making high-grade metal and steel products and that Taiwan is a better place than China to house factories making medical equipment and tools.
Yang also said German businesses appear more confident in Taiwan's ability to protect intellectual property rights than that of China.

The delegation also attended a religious ceremony Friday in Geneva to mark the inauguration of an international Buddhist convention center established by the Kaohsiung-headquartered Fo Kuang Shan Buddhist organization.
Master Hsing Yung, founder of the Fo Kuang Shan monastery, presided over the ceremony, which included a Buddhist ritual to pray for world peace and happiness of all people around the globe.

The new Buddhist center was built on land donated by the Geneva state government. Over 500 people, including Geneva state officials, diplomats from Taiwan and China and religious leaders in the region participated in the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH EX-AIT OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 23 (CNA) (By Wu Jih-chun and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung met Darryl Johnson, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT's) Taipei office, in Seattle Friday to exchange views on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.
According to You, Johnson showed great concern on the recent developments in cross-strait ties and asked You to pass his greetings to President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

You told Johnson, who has long supported Taiwan, that China's enactment of its "Anti-Secession Law" and its deployment of hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan have unilaterally changed the relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

You mentioned that an agreement reached between Taiwan and China in mid-June for the opening of four kinds of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services represented Taiwan's efforts in improving cross-strait ties.
During his U.S. visit, You has met several Chinese academics working in the U.S. and is planning to meet other American academics in the next few days.
In addition, he will also visit overseas Taiwanese leaders residing in the United States.

In a speech to be delivered at the annual meeting of the Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce of North America, You will talk about cross-strait ties and will suggest that the governments of both sides engage in talks on issues such as the rights of Taiwan businessmen in China, the prevention of double taxation, and the protection of intellectual property rights.

The most urgent topics will be the details of the opening of cross-strait charter flights on a regular basis, the entry of Taiwan agricultural products into China, and the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, You added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF BASEBALL STADIUM IN TAICHUNG AHEAD OF SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: The construction of a baseball stadium in Taichung, central Taiwan is expected to be completed in October on schedule, a Taichung city government official said Saturday.

Lin Huei-tang was reporting on the construction of the baseball stadium, the venue of an international baseball competition slated for November, to officials led by Wu Tze-cheng, director of Executive Yuan's Public Construction Committee.
Lin said all construction work and quality control, as well as material and facility reviews, have been carried out strictly according to the regulations.
The stadium is expected to be completed Oct. 15, with the construction of a connecting traffic network around the stadium scheduled for completion in late September.
Wu said the central government has provided subsides of more than NT$100 million (US$3.05 million) for the construction project.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR SUPPORT FOR RECALL MOTION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged the people of southern Taiwan Saturday to throw their support behind the campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian, claiming that "only his recall will bring Taiwan hope."

Ma made the remarks in a major rally in Kaohsiung -- traditionally a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- with the aim of drumming up support for the opposition-initiated recall motion, which will be put to a vote in the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday.
He claimed that Chen's administration has lost the trust of the people due to its incompetence and a spate of corruption allegations involving members of his family and close aides.
The president has reneged on his inauguration vow, and the people have to take back through the recall the mandate they gave him, Ma said.
He claimed that the recall motion has nothing to do with partisan or ethnic struggle, but is for the future of the Taiwan people.
He also called for the DPP to draw a clear line with the president instead of rallying behind him.
If the president clings to power and refuses to step down, more and more scandals will be exposed, Ma speculated.

Braving sweltering heat of 37 degrees, nearly 10,000 supporters attended the rally, which had "safeguarding Taiwan with integrity" as its theme, in the square in front of the National Science and Technology Museum.

KMT Legislators Wu Yu-sheng and Kuo Shu-chun presided over the rally, with Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, KMT Kaohsiung mayoral hopefuls Huang Chun-ying and Huang Chao-shun, as well as legislators Wu Den-yih, Chiu Yi and People First Party Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng all speaking out against Chen and his government.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTSTANDING CULTURE VOLUNTEERS AWARDED

TEXT.P: Seventy-five outstanding culture volunteers from around Taiwan were honored Saturday for their devoted service in helping promoting grassroots arts and cultural development.

Hung Ching-feng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Culture Affairs, presided over the annual service recognition award ceremony at Hushan Culture Park in downtown Taipei in honor of the 75 individual arts and culture volunteers and five volunteer teams.
Addressing the citation ceremony, Hung said the council deeply appreciates all those who have volunteered for museums and culture centers in cities and counties around Taiwan.
"Your volunteer work has contributed much to helping the public better understand our cultural heritage, historic relics and latest artistic and cultural developments," Hung said.
The award winners have volunteered at municipal or county arts museums, libraries, cultural affairs departments or culture centers in grassroots communities around the country.

Li Chiu-chen, one of the 10 Gold Medal winners who has volunteered at the Hsinchu city government's archives office, visual arts gallery and glass art museum for many years, said volunteer work in arts and culture has enriched her life.
"I have gained valuable life experience through volunteer work for arts and culture organizations," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER LAUNCHES 'PRO-STABILITY' CAMPAIGN AMID TURMOIL

TEXT.P: A ruling party lawmaker launched a petition campaign in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Saturday calling for "rationality" amid the current political turmoil triggered by an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the "Believe in Judiciary and Maintain Social Staibility" campaign is mainly aimed at galvanizing rationality and self-restraint at this crucial moment of political upheaval.

Supporters of rival political camps should exercise restraint and refrain from radical moves to exacerbate the feuding and confrontation, which will only add up to social unrest at the expense of overall national wellbeing, Kuan said.

More than 30 grassroots social groups, including Lions clubs, have thrown support behind the petition campaign, Kuan said, adding that the passionate response indicates that grassroots groups are concerned about the escalating confrontation between the country's two rivaling political camps -- the DPP-led "pan-green" camp and the Kuomintang (KMT)-led "pan-blue" alliance.

Over the past two months, Kuan lamented that a suspected illegal case that can be clarified and resolved through judicial procedures has been overblown into a political storm, with the opposition striving to unseat the president and threatening to topple the Cabinet provided that the recall motion in the legislature fails.

Kuan was referring to a stock insider trading case allegedly involving Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, who has been detained since May 24 for questioning about his role in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock trading scandal.

Since taking office, President Chen has shown invariable respect for the judiciary, Kuan said, citing as proofs his attendance as a witness at a court hearing on an election bribery charge and the proceedings of the two lawsuits concerning the 2004 presidential election.
For the TDC insider trading case, Kuan said, Chen has pledged on many occasions that his son-in-law wouldn't receive preferential treatment as "everyone is equal before the law."

Kuan said opposition politicians and news media should refrain from overblowing the case in terms of unfounded speculation to interfere with judicial investigations, which would only lead to more clashes and chaos in local society.
"Let the judicial case run its course and none of us should 'incriminate' anyone before judicial authorities conclude investigations and mete final verdicts," Kuan said.
Kuan's office set up booths at Sanming Park in downtown Kaohsiung for city dwellers to sign their names in support of the "Believe in Judiciary" petition campaign.

She took the opportunity to slam the National Communications Commission (NCC) for what she called "discrepancies" in its treatment of of a Taipei-based cable TV station and radio stations in southern Taiwan.

According to Kuan, the NCC, while turning a blind eye to the TVBS talk show fans' oft-threatening rhetoric against Chen, launched a raid at an underground radio station in southern Taiwan earlier this week simply because one of its listeners gave a call-in phone call suggesting "assassinating" KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
"The NCC's biased treatment of the southern Taiwan radio station is unacceptable," Kuan said.

Nevertheless, she urged supporters of both camps to refrain from emotionally-charged rhetoric and irrational actions before and after the June 27 legislative vote on whether to hold referendum to sack Chen over corruption allegations.

The "pan-blue" alliance staged a final weekend demonstration in Kaohsiung Saturday against Chen and his administration to drump up support for the recall motion. Many doubt the opposition "pan-blue" alliance, which has a slim majority in the legislautre, will be able to muster the two-thirds majority needed to pass the motion next Tuesday to authorize a recall referendum.

Chen himself visited two temples in Taipei Saturday to pray for peace, harmony and national wellbeing, officials said, adding that the president will visit his hometown in southern Tainan county to see his mother and grassroots supporters.

Chen on Tuesday offered a point-by-point rebuttal of the opposition's recall case during a two-hour televised address. His DPP has been boycotting legislative hearings on the topic. DPP bigwigs have said the bid to oust Chen is unjustified because he is not personally implicated in any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Cheney Calls Tapping of Bank Records 'Essential';Critics Assert Secret Program Invades Privacy.
Vice president, other officials insist that U.S. examination of private financial records has been vital to preventing terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Court Says S.E.C. Lacks Authority on Hedge Funds
A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission lacks the authority to regulate hedge funds, dealing a possibly fatal blow to the commission's efforts to oversee a rapidly growing industry that now has US$1.1 trillion in assets. As hedge funds have grown, and as some have collapsed amid fraud or because they took excessive risks, pressures to regulate them have grown. But fund managers have protested that the vast majority have acted responsibly and should not be subjected to "regulatory overlays and burdens"
Wall Street Journal: Stop Order, SEC Dealt Setback As Court Rejects Hedge-Fund Rule
The U.S. government's long-running battle to regulate hedge funds was thrown into doubt as a federal appeals court tossed out a controversial rule requiring hedge-fund advisers to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The court decision abruptly halts, for now, the SEC's attempt to regulate the murky world of hedge funds, the private and sometimes volatile investment pools that have surged in popularity in recent years and now oversee more than US$1 trillion in assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 ABSCONDED VIETNAMESE WORKERS SEIZED

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City police seized 18 absconded Vietnamese workers in southern Pingtung County Saturday.

The Vietnamese were caught illegally working at a farm produce refrigerating company in Pingtung county's Kaoshu village. The company's owner confessed that he had employed the Vietnamese to do packaging work on a daily wage of NT$600 each.

Police authorities have transferred the case to the Pingtung county government to mete out penalties on the employer and the absconded Vietnamese workers in accordance with the Employment Service Law. Police said they will continue tracking down on the illegal manpower brokerage ring behind the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 25 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, June 25:
09:55, President Chen Shui-bian will pay a visit to the Taoist Taitien Temple in Nankunshen, Tainan County.
10:00, The TaiwanThinktank will hold a seminar on Taiwan's present political infighting and constitutional plight.
10:40, President Chen will visit Huian Temple in Kuantien, Tainan County.
15:15, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a seminar on Taiwan's industrial development to be held at the Nantou county's cultural affairs bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 25, or the 30th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th U.S. state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Co. turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was the supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia during World War II, the last viceroy of India, then the commander in chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration, and other elements.
1942: Maj. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of U.S. forces in Europe and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the U.N. Charter. The ROC, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain are made members of the U.N. Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second-place finish.
1975: Mozambique gains independence, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as U.S. secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news-gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua-lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
2000: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh is elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
2001: The Council for Economic Planning and Development announces that the government will encourage the formation of 50 private venture capital funds, totaling NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), to boost the development of the local bio-tech industry.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: 18 ABSCONDED VIETNAMESE WORKERS SEIZED(repeat)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City police seized 18 absconded Vietnamese workers in southern Pingtung County Saturday.

The Vietnamese were caught illegally working at a farm produce refrigerating company in Pingtung county's Kaoshu village. The company's owner confessed that he had employed the Vietnamese to do packaging work on a daily wage of NT$600 each.

Police authorities have transferred the case to the Pingtung county government to mete out penalties on the employer and the absconded Vietnamese workers in accordance with the Employment Service Law. Police said they will continue tracking down on the illegal manpower brokerage ring behind the case.

TEXT.P: A ruling party lawmaker launched a petition campaign in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Saturday calling for "rationality" amid the current political turmoil triggered by an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the "Believe in Judiciary and Maintain Social Staibility" campaign is mainly aimed at galvanizing rationality and self-restraint at this crucial moment of political upheaval.

Supporters of rival political camps should exercise restraint and refrain from radical moves to exacerbate the feuding and confrontation, which will only add up to social unrest at the expense of overall national wellbeing, Kuan said.

More than 30 grassroots social groups, including Lions clubs, have thrown support behind the petition campaign, Kuan said, adding that the passionate response indicates that grassroots groups are concerned about the escalating confrontation between the country's two rivaling political camps -- the DPP-led "pan-green" camp and the Kuomintang (KMT)-led "pan-blue" alliance.

Over the past two months, Kuan lamented that a suspected illegal case that can be clarified and resolved through judicial procedures has been overblown into a political storm, with the opposition striving to unseat the president and threatening to topple the Cabinet provided that the recall motion in the legislature fails.

Kuan was referring to a stock insider trading case allegedly involving Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, who has been detained since May 24 for questioning about his role in the Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stock trading scandal.

Since taking office, President Chen has shown invariable respect for the judiciary, Kuan said, citing as proofs his attendance as a witness at a court hearing on an election bribery charge and the proceedings of the two lawsuits concerning the 2004 presidential election.
For the TDC insider trading case, Kuan said, Chen has pledged on many occasions that his son-in-law wouldn't receive preferential treatment as "everyone is equal before the law."

Kuan said opposition politicians and news media should refrain from overblowing the case in terms of unfounded speculation to interfere with judicial investigations, which would only lead to more clashes and chaos in local society.
"Let the judicial case run its course and none of us should 'incriminate' anyone before judicial authorities conclude investigations and mete final verdicts," Kuan said.
Kuan's office set up booths at Sanming Park in downtown Kaohsiung for city dwellers to sign their names in support of the "Believe in Judiciary" petition campaign.

She took the opportunity to slam the National Communications Commission (NCC) for what she called "discrepancies" in its treatment of of a Taipei-based cable TV station and radio stations in southern Taiwan.

According to Kuan, the NCC, while turning a blind eye to the TVBS talk show fans' oft-threatening rhetoric against Chen, launched a raid at an underground radio station in southern Taiwan earlier this week simply because one of its listeners gave a call-in phone call suggesting "assassinating" KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.
"The NCC's biased treatment of the southern Taiwan radio station is unacceptable," Kuan said.

Nevertheless, she urged supporters of both camps to refrain from emotionally-charged rhetoric and irrational actions before and after the June 27 legislative vote on whether to hold referendum to sack Chen over corruption allegations.

The "pan-blue" alliance staged a final weekend demonstration in Kaohsiung Saturday against Chen and his administration to drump up support for the recall motion. Many doubt the opposition "pan-blue" alliance, which has a slim majority in the legislautre, will be able to muster the two-thirds majority needed to pass the motion next Tuesday to authorize a recall referendum.

Chen himself visited two temples in Taipei Saturday to pray for peace, harmony and national wellbeing, officials said, adding that the president will visit his hometown in southern Tainan county to see his mother and grassroots supporters.

Chen on Tuesday offered a point-by-point rebuttal of the opposition's recall case during a two-hour televised address. His DPP has been boycotting legislative hearings on the topic. DPP bigwigs have said the bid to oust Chen is unjustified because he is not personally implicated in any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTSTANDING CULTURE VOLUNTEERS AWARDED(repeat)

TEXT.P: Seventy-five outstanding culture volunteers from around Taiwan were honored Saturday for their devoted service in helping promoting grassroots arts and cultural development.

Hung Ching-feng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Culture Affairs, presided over the annual service recognition award ceremony at Hushan Culture Park in downtown Taipei in honor of the 75 individual arts and culture volunteers and five volunteer teams.
Addressing the citation ceremony, Hung said the council deeply appreciates all those who have volunteered for museums and culture centers in cities and counties around Taiwan.
"Your volunteer work has contributed much to helping the public better understand our cultural heritage, historic relics and latest artistic and cultural developments," Hung said.
The award winners have volunteered at municipal or county arts museums, libraries, cultural affairs departments or culture centers in grassroots communities around the country.

Li Chiu-chen, one of the 10 Gold Medal winners who has volunteered at the Hsinchu city government's archives office, visual arts gallery and glass art museum for many years, said volunteer work in arts and culture has enriched her life.
"I have gained valuable life experience through volunteer work for arts and culture organizations," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR SUPPORT FOR RECALL MOTION(repeat)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urged the people of southern Taiwan Saturday to throw their support behind the campaign to oust President Chen Shui-bian, claiming that "only his recall will bring Taiwan hope."

Ma made the remarks in a major rally in Kaohsiung -- traditionally a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- with the aim of drumming up support for the opposition-initiated recall motion, which will be put to a vote in the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday.
He claimed that Chen's administration has lost the trust of the people due to its incompetence and a spate of corruption allegations involving members of his family and close aides.
The president has reneged on his inauguration vow, and the people have to take back through the recall the mandate they gave him, Ma said.
He claimed that the recall motion has nothing to do with partisan or ethnic struggle, but is for the future of the Taiwan people.
He also called for the DPP to draw a clear line with the president instead of rallying behind him.
If the president clings to power and refuses to step down, more and more scandals will be exposed, Ma speculated.

Braving sweltering heat of 37 degrees, nearly 10,000 supporters attended the rally, which had "safeguarding Taiwan with integrity" as its theme, in the square in front of the National Science and Technology Museum.

KMT Legislators Wu Yu-sheng and Kuo Shu-chun presided over the rally, with Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, KMT Kaohsiung mayoral hopefuls Huang Chun-ying and Huang Chao-shun, as well as legislators Wu Den-yih, Chiu Yi and People First Party Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng all speaking out against Chen and his government.

Mateo M. Mayuga, and supportive active-duty officers and enlisted men.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PLAYS 'RECONCILIATION CARD' AMID RECALL JITTERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is now opting for a "reconciliation card" in an attempt to cool the current political turmoil triggered by an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

The "pan-blue" alliance of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) has pushed for a recall motion to unseat Chen in the wake of a string of corruption scandals in which Chen's senior aides and close family members are being investigated for suspected involvement.

Chen vowed Saturday to hold political consultations at home and to engage in peaceful talks with the other side of Taiwan Strait, providing a shot in the arm to the ruling DPP, which has been cloaked in a shroud of depression since the pan-blue opposition launched the recall motion two weeks ago.

Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that she will organize an informal gathering of opinion leaders across the political spectrum for "amity talks" after the June 27 vote on a legislative referendum to recall the president.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun will also soon pay visits to the opposition KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong to help eliminate misunderstandings between the DPP-led "pan-green" camp and its rival pan-blue alliance.

The DPP, which in the meantime has grappled with a sense of crisis over the recall motion, has sorted out a "diverging and converging" strategy aimed at creating a reconciliation atmosphere and "throwing the issue back to the opposition."

In fact, the DPP has become more complacent as the recall motion proceedings drag on, believing the longer the issue plays out the more likely the situation will turn in favor of the president and ruling party.

Many doubt the opposition pan-blue alliance, which has a slim majority in the legislature, will be able to muster the approval of two-thirds of the 221-seat legislature next Tuesday in order to clear the way for voters to decide on Chen's fate in a national referendum.

Most DPP legislators believe the recall motion would have no chance to succeed and some DPP officials even speculate that Tuesday -- when the recall motion may be aborted -- is the day President Chen may be freed from the current domestic political turmoil.

Meanwhile, the opposition pan-blue alliance is viewed as full of controversies from within the alliance, with PFP Chairman James Soong insisting if the recall motion fails, moves to topple the Cabinet should proceed, while the KMT leader said no further moves to oust Premier Su Tseng-chang and the Cabinet are considered even if the recall motion fails to pass in the legislature.
Chen's son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, has been detained since May 24 for questioning about his role in an insider trading scandal involving Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks.
DPP bigwigs have said the bid to oust Chen is unjustified because he is not personally implicated in any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FULLY BACKS PRESIDENTIAL RECALL VOTE: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The main Kuomintang (KMT) will focus efforts on pushing a recall vote against President Chen Shui-bian through the legislature but will not consider toppling the Cabinet as a means of ousting Chen, KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said Sunday.
Pan made the remarks while fielding questions from reporters at the Legislative Yuan.

Stressing that the KMT would do its best to pass the presidential recall vote in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, Pan said it would be untimely to call for a no-confidence vote in the legislature to topple the Cabinet before redistricting of electoral constituencies has been completed for the next legislative election.

As the current legislative session ends June 30, it is beneficial for KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to make use of the ensuing two-month summer recess to decide whether to launch a no-confidence vote when the next session begins in September, KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng suggested.

Wu claimed that he was sure new evidence regarding corruption allegedly committed by Chen's family would surface in coming months, adding the KMT would gauge public response before deciding whether to call the no-confidence vote, and only after the June 27 presidential recall vote has been held.
Meanwhile, Soong vowed to continue pushing for a no-confidence vote in the Legislative Yuan and to pressure Chen to step down even if the presidential recall vote fails in the legislature Tuesday.

Soong, who has been staging a sit-in in front of the Legislative Yuan since late last week to solicit wider support for the presidential recall vote, said that "the PFP will undoubtedly propose a no-confidence vote in the Legislative Yuan, " as "The Taiwanese are looking forward to having politicians with a strong will to wipe out corruption."

"Pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (PFP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union must not veto the presidential recall motion Tuesday so as to provide the public with a chance to decide Chen's fate in a national referendum, Soong said.

"If 'pan-green' lawmakers really respect what they called 'the public mandate,' they are supposed to vote in favor of the presidential recall motion and leave people with the chance to determine Chen's fate," Soong urged.

If the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP are still unable to oust Chen from the presidency through their combined efforts, it means that Taiwan's democratic mechanisms to check and balance the government have become paralyzed, PFP Policy Center Director Chang Hsien-yao stressed, expressing concern about Taiwan's democratic future.

Commenting on reports that the KMT has held back from its decision to call for a no-confidence vote in the legislature as a follow-up to the presidential recall motion to unseat Chen, Chang said that it may indicate that differing opinions within the KMT need to be consolidated, adding that "it is wrong to say the KMT has softened its position."
According to Chang, it is the common desire of all of Taiwan's people to denounce corruption, regardless of political affiliation.

Faced with the "pan-blue alliance's" move to oust Chen, DPP legislative caucus whip Yeh Yi-jin urged the KMT and PFP to refrain from political wrangling and to address the quality of life issues and public welfare.
"Otherwise, it would backfire among the public," she warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG POLICE DETAIN 27 ILLEGAL FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung county police arrested 27 illegal foreign workers as of Sunday, in the first two days of a six-day raid that wil last until June 29, according to a spokesman for the Kaohsiung County Police Headquarters.

Police authorities in Linyuan, Jenwu and Kangshan townships detained the largest number of illegal foreign workers, each nabbing six individuals who had run away from their workplaces, the spokesman said.

In coming days, local police will continue tracking foreign laborers who have unlawfully stayed in Kaohsiung county to better preserve social order and protect the due rights of Taiwan's employers and local workers, the spokesman said.

The Kaohsiung County Police Headquarters also encouraged alien laborers who have absconded from work to turn themselves in to local police authorities, the spokesman said, urging local business owners not to hire illegal foreign workers or they may face stiff fines of up to NT$700,000 (US$21,900).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italians begin to vote today on constitutional reforms.
More than 47 million voters begin to go to the polls Sunday to decide whether to ratify a draft amendment to the Constitution approved by the former center-right Silvio Berlusconi's government. The proposed constitutional reforms are to radically alter government institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, U.K. RESEARCH INSTITUTES FORM ALLIANCE ON GENETIC ENGINEERING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and Britain's Sanger Institute have formed an alliance to carry out joint research in genetic engineering, an ITRI official said Saturday.
A memorandum of understanding was also signed on Friday by ITRI President Johnsee Lee and Sanger's senior researcher Panos Deloukas.

Lee said this alliance -- combining ITRI's forte of biochip technology and Sanger's capacity for genetic analysis -- will not only accelerate the process of decoding human genes, but may also help establish the use of Taiwan-made genechips within global academic research.

According to the MOU, the two-stage cooperation will first apply cell strains of lymphoblastoids to different platforms of biochips to analyze gene expressions and compare the efficacy of the biochips.

In the second stage, the two institutes will use biochips to compare human lung cancer cell strains before and after treatment with the medication "Warfarin, " in order to understand the metabolic aspects of this medicine.
The Sanger Institute -- set up 1992 in Cambridge, England -- is a genome research center specialized in the sequencing and interpretation of human genomes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS TO LAUNCH SIT-INS CALLING FOR PRESIDENT'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Another group of some 100 academics called on President Chen Shui-bian Sunday to resign in order to "set a good example in Taiwan's democratization."

This marks the second time in three days that professors and academics in Taiwan have run ads in major dailies demanding that Chen step down, about one month after the detention of his son-in-law, Chao Chien-ming, following allegations of insider trading by an opposition legislator.
In a front-page statement published in Sunday's newspapers, 106 intellectuals said the moral integrity of a head of state must be beyond question.

However, they said, Chen is not only unable to offer a reasonable explanation for why some senior aides and family members have been involved in a series of corruption scandals, but also lacks the ability for self-reflection by using provocative rhetoric to distort the solemn procedure of democratic politics into a political struggle between the Democratic Progressive Party-led ruling "pan-green" camp and the rival "pan-blue" alliance of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party.

The intellectuals continued to say that DPP officials and lawmakers -- who have supported the president's decision not to respond to the allegations in the legislature and have defended the first family in cases of alleged wrongdoing -- should also bear all consequences for their "total disregard for truth and fact."

Huang Kuang-kuo, a psychology professor at National Taiwan University and convener of the Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) which sponsored the newspaper ads, said the DAA is sponsoring a candlelight vigil at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Sunday night as a reflection of Taiwan public determination to seek truth and justice, and is expected to transcend confrontations between the pan-green camp and pan-blue alliance.

Meanwhile, Huang said, this group of intellectuals will join the public in DAA-sponsored sit-ins at the same venue Monday and Tuesday in order to call for Chen's resignation because the president no longer has the public's trust and is incapable of carrying out his constitutional duties as a leader, Huang argued.

The group of 105 professors published front-page ads in two major newspapers Friday petitioning Chen to "be responsible to the people" and to step down gracefully in order to "set a good political example."
They said in the statement that as intellectuals, they firmly believe the moral integrity of a chief of state must be unquestionable.
The professors added that Chen's "unfit" conduct has "violated the basic moral conscience" of Taiwan's population and has "confused Taiwan society's system of simple values."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STANDS BY DENIAL OF BUSINESS TYCOON'S DONATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stood by his denial that his wife had never met with a controversial business tycoon at his Taipei home or received political donations from him, a presidential aide said Sunday.

In response to remarks made by the founder of the now-defunct Tuntex Group Chen You-hao at 12: 00 a.m. Taipei time Sunday in Los Angeles that he had personally presented NT$3 million (US$91,600) to Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen in 1994 and 1998, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said the president "has made it very clear" on June 20 that "no is no" and any attempts to contradict the president's statement are "politically motivated."

Chen You-hao, a fugitive wanted in Taiwan for illegally transferring his company's assets overseas, accused the president of lying when he denied in a nationally televised speech June 20 that Wu had never met with Chen You-hao, much less received his political donations.

The Presidential Office spokesman said they do not wish anyone with political motivations to unveil "behind-the-scenes" information at a time when lawmakers are about to vote on a motion in the Legislative Yuan to recall the president.
The spokesman also urged Chen You-hao to return to Taiwan, provide an explanation for the issue and to assist investigators in other ongoing cases.

During Chen You-hao's news conference, he said he gave money to President Chen on two occasions in the 1990s, claiming each time he gave President Chen Shui-bian -- then a candidate in the race for Taipei mayor -- NT$3 million in cash.
The first time was in 1994, he said, when he visited Chen Shui-bian's residence on Minsheng East Road with Shen Fu-hsiung, a former lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

He claimed the second visit took place in 1998 when Chen Shui-bian was running for re-election as mayor of Taipei. Chen You-hao said he went to Chen Shui-bian's residence accompanied by Shen, and that they were received by Wu again.
Shortly after they left, Chen Shui-bian called to thank him. The call was made to a phone in his car and his conversation with Chen Shui-bian was clearly heard by his driver.
Shen recently confirmed he had accompanied Chen You-hao to visit Chen Shui-bian at his Taipei house in 1994 and handed over NT$3 million to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION EFFORTS IN RECALL BID 'INADEQUATE': ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: The opposition has shown itself incapable of succeeding in its bid to recall President Chen Shui-bian over the past two weeks, an academic said Sunday.

Legislative caucus members of the "pan-blue" alliance of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party have fallen short in maneuvering and executive abilities in the legislature when they pushed for a presidential recall, said Chou Yang-shan, director of Chinese Culture University's Chungshan Academic Research Institute.
The pan-blue legislators also have serious coordination problems concerning morale, party discipline and the "combative capability" of the opposition, Chou claimed.

Nevertheless, Chou said, Taiwan's opposition is not the only group in the world that is insufficient or incapable of recalling the head of state. In fact, he said, most countries, regardless of whether they are newly democratic countries or veteran democracies, have constitutional problems in recalling the executive.
Taiwan has a seasoned democracy and electoral system, but lacks a well-designed process to recall or impeach the president or topple the Cabinet, Chou argued.

Chou claimed that in Taiwan, the threshold is too high for a presidential recall -- proponents must gain the support of two-thirds of the legislature before voters decide on the issue in a national referendum.

The fact that one-third of legislators can veto a decision made by the other two-thirds reflects a "minority ruling" phenomenon, he said, adding that "this shows the inadequacy of Taiwan's constitutional mechanism."

Meanwhile, Hsu Yung-ming, an assistant researcher at Academia Sinica, said the ongoing recall drive is teaching Taiwan's opposition that the too-high threshold for a recall referendum means risking the spirit of democracy.

The KMT has said it has already collected enough signatures for a recall petition, Hsu said, adding that the public's endorsement actually has no say in a recall motion since the measure is passed or rejected only by legislators, not by the people.
The pan-blues should seek more support for the recall drive from the "pan-green" camp consisiting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, Hsu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION, PAN-GREENS PREPARE STRATEGIES TO FOLLOW A FAILED RECALL

TEXT.P: Both the ruling and opposition camps are preparing for a new phase in Taiwan's politics after a vote is held on a presidential recall motion in the legislature June 27, academics said Sunday.

Scholars and political analysts made the comments at a seminar sponsored by Taiwan Thinktank on "Crisis and turning point: Taiwan's political strife and reform predicament," and comes at a time when lawmakers are set to vote on an opposition "pan-blue alliance"-led motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Hsu Yung-ming, an assistant researcher at Academia Sinica who chaired the seminar, said that visionary political figures from both camps have begun preparing for the "post-627 era" because the results of the presidential recall vote -- the first in Taiwan's history -- are predictable.

Hsu based his claims on a media report that main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will return to his "middle-of-the-road" stance following the June 27 vote -- a development that coincided with remarks made recently by Chen in an interview with foreign media that he will pursue political dialogue at home while engaging in cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations after the vote takes place.
Hsu urged politicians to reflect deeply on whether Taiwan's constitutional system should be reformed in light of a vicious cycle of political wrangling since Chen came to power in 2000.

Tseng Chien-yuan, a professor at Chung Hua University, said it would be a good strategy if the KMT returned to its moderate stance by not seeking to topple the Cabinet after the presidential recall vote, and he contended that the main opposition party should respond to Chen's call for negotiation.
The ruling and opposition parties should also cooperate to iron out an adequate constitutional system that would help foster Taiwan's democratic development, he said.

National Chengchi University Professor Lee Si-tang opined that the KMT hopes to take a centrist policy after being driven by its pan-blue partner -- the People First Party (PFP) -- to join recall efforts.
Chou Yang-shan, a professor at Chinese Culture University, said the opposition's recall bid underscored the fact that "Taiwan's electoral democracy" lacks a balancing mechanism.

Although the Constitution stipulates the people are entitled to recall or impeach the president or topple the Cabinet, Chou said these practices are hard to carry out in actuality due to a lack of supporting measures.
Taipei University professor Chen Yao-hsiang attributed Taiwan's political crisis to an unclear system of central government.
He called for a new Constitution or an overhaul of the existing one to better implement checks and balances for a normal democratic nation.

According to a media report, the KMT has decided to adjust its stance by not seeking to topple the Cabinet following next Tuesday's recall vote, which is expected to fail in the Legislative Yuan for lack of a two-thirds majority. Ma was also reportedly planning to meet with Chen.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen responded that the KMT has been moderate and there is no need for the party to adjust its strategy. She denied the report by saying the KMT has never ruled out the possibility of toppling the Cabinet and that Ma has no plans to meet with Chen in the near future.
The KMT is focusing efforts on recalling Chen and has been calling for him to step down.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN THANKS HOMETOWN SUPPORTERS FOR MORAL SUPPORT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian thanked supporters in his hometown in southern Taiwan for their moral support at a time when he was facing the hardest period in his life.

On a visit to a temple in Guantien Township, Tainan County, the president -- who is facing a recall motion in the legislature over scandals allegedly involving family members and close aides --- said he is willing to sacrifice everything for the country but will never yield in the face of hardship.
Chen said he is going to visit different temples around the island and to pray not for himself but for the country and people, and to wish them good luck.

He said that Taiwan is not a normal country, and that it is encountering the same difficulties as any other country transforming from an authoritarian regime into a democratic country. Difficulties include abnormal media, parliament and intelligence agencies.
However, the president said he will never concede to difficulties, but will instead lead the country and its people bravely toward a better future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF CALLS FOR CALM IN RECALL DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yueh-tseh called on opposition and ruling parties Sunday to take a step backwards from a fierce dispute over whether President Chen Shui-bian should be recalled in the wake of scandals allegedly involving his family and administration.

He said in a written statement that opposition legislators who initiated the recall motion should fully understand why the Constitution outlines stringent requirements for a presidential recall -- to ensure domestic stability and to make it difficult for a recall bid to pass without a clear legislative majority.

The recall motion is expected to fail because opposition parties leading the recall are highly unlikely to obtain the two-thirds majority as required by the Constitution when the motion is put to a vote in the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday.

On the other hand, the Nobel laureate said, as the target of the motion the president should understand the best way to ward off future accusations is to "mend his ways and conduct himself accordingly."

Lee -- whose support is viewed as having contributed to Chen's presidential election victories -- was claimed by Chen's political rivals to be "morally responsible for Chen's failure" to rein in his aides and family members.

As a response to their claims, Lee said he felt deeply sorry that the DPP, instead of adhering to its political objectives and pursuing them, has been dogged by scandals and performed far below public expectations ever since it took power in 2000.
He urged the DPP to reflect carefully on its internal governance and to make up for its faults by mending its ways.

He called for reconciliation among different parties, noting that partisan bickering would only hinder the country's development and jeopardize the welfare of 23 million people while other countries are making rapid advancements.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SELECTS CANDIDATE FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL RACE

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung chapter of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has selected a candidate to run in the year-end mayoral races in this southern port city after a second round of primaries were held Sunday.

Huang Chun-ying emerged as the clear winner after receiving 65.505 percent -- a figure calculated according to the party's formula of combining results of primary polls and opinion surveys for a final outcome -- and will be named as the KMT candidate pending approval of party authorities.
His only rival in the second primary, KMT lawmaker Huang Chao-shun, garnered 34.497 percent.
The electoral turnout for Kaohsiung KMT members in the party's second primary was 37.56 percent.
During the second primary, Huang received 8,769 votes while the other candidate received 5,318 votes from KMT members.

Casey Jr., the number of American combat brigades in Iraq is projected to decrease to 5 or 6 from the current level of 14 by December 2007.
