DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF CALLS FOR CALM IN RECALL DISPUTES(repeat)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yueh-tseh called on opposition and ruling parties Sunday to take a step backwards from a fierce dispute over whether President Chen Shui-bian should be recalled in the wake of scandals allegedly involving his family and administration.

He said in a written statement that opposition legislators who initiated the recall motion should fully understand why the Constitution outlines stringent requirements for a presidential recall -- to ensure domestic stability and to make it difficult for a recall bid to pass without a clear legislative majority.

The recall motion is expected to fail because opposition parties leading the recall are highly unlikely to obtain the two-thirds majority as required by the Constitution when the motion is put to a vote in the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday.

On the other hand, the Nobel laureate said, as the target of the motion the president should understand the best way to ward off future accusations is to "mend his ways and conduct himself accordingly."

Lee -- whose support is viewed as having contributed to Chen's presidential election victories -- was claimed by Chen's political rivals to be "morally responsible for Chen's failure" to rein in his aides and family members.

As a response to their claims, Lee said he felt deeply sorry that the DPP, instead of adhering to its political objectives and pursuing them, has been dogged by scandals and performed far below public expectations ever since it took power in 2000.
He urged the DPP to reflect carefully on its internal governance and to make up for its faults by mending its ways.

He called for reconciliation among different parties, noting that partisan bickering would only hinder the country's development and jeopardize the welfare of 23 million people while other countries are making rapid advancements.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SELECTS CANDIDATE FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL RACE(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung chapter of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has selected a candidate to run in the year-end mayoral races in this southern port city after a second round of primaries were held Sunday.

Huang Chun-ying emerged as the clear winner after receiving 65.505 percent -- a figure calculated according to the party's formula of combining results of primary polls and opinion surveys for a final outcome -- and will be named as the KMT candidate pending approval of party authorities.
His only rival in the second primary, KMT lawmaker Huang Chao-shun, garnered 34.497 percent.
The electoral turnout for Kaohsiung KMT members in the party's second primary was 37.56 percent.
During the second primary, Huang received 8,769 votes while the other candidate received 5,318 votes from KMT members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 26, or the first day of the sixth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The U.S. Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the U.N. founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter would become effective Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to U.S. President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Student leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the Republic of China.
1992: A peoples' court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: U.S. forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former U.S. President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton begins a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
2001: ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi signs an agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart, Marco A. Ventura, to help train youth from the Central American nation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

At least 50,000 Iraqis have died violently since the 2003 U.S.-led invasion, according to statistics from the Baghdad morgue, the Iraqi Health Ministry and other agencies--a toll 20,000 higher than previously acknowledged by the Bush administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REBUTS ALLEGATIONS OF BRIBERY IN MILITARY PROMOTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian rebutted Monday "officer-for-sale" allegations that have been heard in the military, saying the armed forces have been following an open, fair and transparent system in handling personnel affairs.

Chen, in his capacity as the commander-in-chief of the Republic of China's armed forces, said "honor is the second life of servicemen and servicewomen, and this sense of honor should not be impaired by anybody for any reason."
Noting that the armed forces are part of the country and people, Chen appealed to the public to continue to support the military.
Chen made the remarks during a ceremony held at the Armed Forces Officers' Club in Taipei where he witnessed the promotion of scores of officers.
A total of 13 officers were promoted to the rank of lieutenant-general and 45 officers to the rank of major-general, with their promotions to take effect July 1.

Also denying allegations that bribery was involved in some military personnel promotions, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said lobbying or "hand-greasing" are absolutely taboo in the military in terms of personnel promotions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Special zones for Riau to draw more investors.
Singapore and Indonesia yesterday inked a new economic agreement designed to revitalise the islands of Batam, Bintan and Karimun, and which also promises to bring the two countries closer together.
The Lianhe Zaobao: S'pore, Indonesia ink pact to set up three economic zones.
Singapore and Indonesia yesterday inked a new Special Economic Zone agreement that will oversee the development of Batam, Bintan and Karimun in Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTENDS GROUNDBREAKING FOR RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM TO AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang presided over the ground-breaking ceremony Monday for the construction of a rapid transit system linking Chiang Kei-shek Airport to Taipei City.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Kuo Yao-chi, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun and other officials also attended the ceremony held in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

The section between Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan and Sanchung, Taipei, will be completed by the end of 2010, officials from the Bureau of High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said.

Taipei City Government's Department of Rapid Transit System will be responsible for the design and construction of the system's underground section between Sanchung and Taipei Railway Station. The full line is expected to be completed in June 2012.

After the line is fully open, it will take 35 minutes to travel from Taipei Railway Station to CKS International Airport. People in southern Taiwan will be able to use the Taiwan High-Speed Rail, which is expected to be launched in October, to get to Taoyuan Station, and then transfer to the rapid transit system for a 10-minute ride to the airport.

The rapid transit line will begin from the second terminal of CKS Airport and lead in a northeastern direction through Linkuo, Hsinchuang, Sanchung and Taipei Railway Station, and in a southeastern direction to the Taoyuan Station of the Taiwan High-Speed Rail, with a total of 22 stations along the way through Taoyuan County, Taipei County and Taipei City.
The rapid transit system for the CKS Airport has been included in the government's "new 10 top construction projects" with a total budget of around NT$93.6 billion (US$2.86 billion), officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTIAN FUND SEEKING 300 NEW FOSTER FAMILIES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Fund for Children and Families is seeking 300 new foster families to provide foster care for orphaned, abused or neglected children, a spokesman for the Christian charity said Monday.

The foundation is cooperating with Family Mart in soliciting decent families to join its foster care program, the spokesman said, adding that those who are willing to offer family foster care for children in need are welcome to register at any of the 1,900 Family Mart convenience stores around Taiwan by Sept. 25.

Quoting the results of a recent Taiwan Fund survey, the spokesman said an average of 3.1 children or adolescents have to leave their birth families per day around Taiwan, but only 0.7 new foster families are available each day.

The substantial gap between the demand and supply of foster families can be attributed to a combination of factors, the spokesman said. On the one hand, the number of abused children has been on a steady rise, while on the other hand, local people have become less interested in becoming foster parents for various reasons, including foster children's disappointing behavior, birth parents' reluctance to cooperate or foster families encountering unexpected misfortunes that force them to stop providing foster care, he said.

In 2005 alone, the Taiwan Fund had to find foster parents for 1,143 new children in need, 52.6 percent of whom were abused or maltreated by their birth parents. For abused children, the spokesman said, foster parents not only play the role of "substitute parents" but also have to serve as professional counselors.

Through cooperation with Family Mart, the foundation managed to recruit in 2005 far more new foster families than in the previous year. Nevertheless, the number of new families recruited still fell short of the number needed. Each foster family under the Taiwan Fund program now has to care for an average of two children.
"We hope the new foster family recruit program can help bring the ratio down to below 1-1.5," the spokesman said.
Those who intend to join the foster care program are welcome to contact the Taiwan Fund by phone at (04)-2206-1234 or visit the fund's Web site at www.ccf.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE EMPLOYEES MAY BE ALLOWED TO SEEK EXTENDED EDUCATION IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: The government may consider allowing Chinese employees of Taiwan companies operating in China's Fujian Province to seek extended education in Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.
By doing so, the government can help strengthen business operations of the Fujian-based Taiwan companies, MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said.
Liu made the remarks in response to a recent announcement made by Fujian's Xiamen City that the Chinese province will soon activate nine incentive measures to boost educational exchanges with Taiwan.
Responding to the measures, Liu said, the government should further encourage China-based Taiwan businesspeople to send their children to the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu for education.

Liu related that China has been systematically increasing work on Taiwan's youths in recent years in an attempt to have the new generation Taiwanese turn to the fold of the Chinese communists in the long run.

For Taiwan's part, Liu suggested that Taiwan open its doors wider to mainland Chinese students so as to allow young Chinese men and women to have a better chance to learn about Taiwan's freedom and democracy.

HEAVY RAINS spawned by tropical storm "Domeng" dislodged rocks and boulders, some as big as tricycles, from the slopes of restive Mount Bulusan over the weekend, threatening three villages in Sorsogon.

Workers in Metro Manila will get an additional P25 in their basic pay starting middle of next month, P50 less than the amount being asked by labor groups in their petition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 71.37 points to close at 6,523.68.
The bourse opened at 6,464.4 and fluctuated between 6,448.51 and 6,548.94 during trading. A total of 2.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.845 billion (US$2.11 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by foodstuff, machinery and electronic shares at 1.5 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, plastic and chemical shares at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent, and banking and financial stocks at 0.3 percent.
Only construction issues lost ground, moving down 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 661 to 212, with 119 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 104 points to close at 6,481, with 36,611 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August gained 109 points to finish at 6,409, with 530 contracts traded, while September futures rose 120 points to close at 6,386, with 109 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 116 points to close at 6,385, with 31 contracts traded, while March futures gained 118 points to finish at 6,392, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,377 for July, 6,300 for August, 6,266 for September, 6,296 for December and 6,274 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
July TE futures moved up 4.7 points to close at 270.5, with 3,960 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 3.5 points to finish at 268.4, with 13 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures rose 3.0 points to finish at 942.6, with 2,647 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures gained 1.8 points to close at 932, with 31 contracts traded.
September TF futures moved down 3.2 points to finish at 930.2, with 33 contracts traded, while December TF futures lost 7.8 points to close at 922, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL CONSIDER NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE `CAUTIOUSLY': SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will exercise extra caution if it launches a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet at the Legislative Yuan as a means of pressuring President Chen Shui-bian to step down, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Monday.

Speaking at a news conference at KMT headquarters, Cheng said the party has not ruled out the possibility of calling a no-confidence vote to serve that end, but will do so in an "extremely cautious" way.

However, the KMT will not stop its bid to demand Chen's resignation, such as through a recall motion at the Legislative Yuan, because "more than half" of the Taiwan people feel that he is no longer capable of serving as head of state because of a string of corruption allegations involving members of his family and close aides, Cheng claimed.

The Constitution provides the people with the right to recall or impeach the president or topple the Cabinet and it is lawful for the people to exercise such rights, in addition to staging sit-ins or street protests, she said.
The KMT has always been a moderate political party and there is no need for it to adjust its line, she claimed.

Cheng's remarks came in the wake of a media report that the KMT will drop a plan to join the People First Party's (PFP) efforts to topple the Cabinet as a follow-up move to oust Chen if the presidential recall vote -- the first of its kind in Taiwan's history -- fails at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday.

The presidential recall vote stands no chance of passing the Legislative Yuan without the backing of the "pan-green" lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, as the vote requires a two-thirds majority approval.

Meanwhile, it is feared that confrontation over the presidential recall motion showdown might be brought to a boil as the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP and the "pan-green camp" will mobilize supporters at the Legislative Yuan to display their stances.
About 2,000 "pan-blue" supporters will show up on one side of the Legislative Yuan, while some 10,000 "pan-greens" will appear on the other side, according to local media reports.

DPP lawmakers Lin Kuo-ching and Hsieh Hsin-ni told a news conference earlier the same day that according to information they had received, some gangsters dressed in black or in the colors of the national flag are likely to infiltrate the crowd of "pan-blue" supporters Tuesday with the intention of creating chaos between the two camps.
Hsieh said that the presidential recall vote is doomed to fail at the Legislative Yuan and called on "pan-blue" supporters not to be fooled by their leaders or cause bloodshed in the streets.
DPP social development department head Lin You-chang confirmed that around 10,000 "pan-green" supporters were expected to show up near the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to show their support for Chen.

Lin promised that the DPP will do its best to prevent conflict by sending task force members to maintain traffic order at street intersections, and urged the Taipei city police authorities to maintain high alert to head off any contacts between supporters of the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEST POINT VALEDICTORIAN HONORED BY TAIWAN GROUP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 26 (CNA) (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The head of the class of 2006 of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, whose parents are from Taiwan, was awarded a "Pride of Chinese Descendants" medal by a Taiwan group in Washington, D.C. Sunday.

Jessamyn Liu, who graduated as valedictorian of West Point's Class of 2006 and received her diploma from the graduation speaker, President George W. Bush, May 27, was awarded by Tsai Chi-tsun, president of the Taiwan Clan Association in Washington, D.C. at a dinner to welcome a visiting Taipei County economic and trade promotion delegation led by Magistrate Chou Shi-wei.

Liu, 21, who was named on USA Today's All-USA College Academic Team for 2006 for her achievements in academics and leadership, was accompanied by her parents, Liu Wei-chao and Reiko Liu, at the dinner. Jessamyn is a great granddaughter of Liu Shi, a celebrated general of the 1940s when the Republic of China government still ruled China.
Reiko Liu said her daughter's interest in the military started at a very young age. "Jessamyn's never been the girlie type. Growing up, she wanted weapons, not Barbies," she said.
"I wanted to be in the military since I was pretty little. I got serious about going to West Point when I was a sophomore in high school," Jessamyn Liu said.
Liu earned a Gates Cambridge Scholarship, which she will use to attend the University of Cambridge this fall for one year to study political thought and intellectual history.
She will then return to military duty. She is required to serve for five years of active duty and three years as a reservist.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.013 to close at NT$32.729.
A total of US$588 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.795 and hit a low of NT$32.710.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK UGRES CEPD TO STEP UP ROLE IN PROMOTING SERVICE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The development of the domestic service sector is slow, and the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the nation's top economic planner, needs to strengthen its role in promoting its development, a think tank said Monday.
The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) made the call when it unveiled a report on the situation of Taiwan's service sector.

TIER officials lamented that the development of Taiwan's service sector remains weak two years after a national conference on the development of the service sector in which participants called for an annual service sector growth of 6.1 percent.

Saying that a weak service sector will drag down the economy, they blamed the lack of development on various government agencies and the fact that the CEPD is incapable of reining in them and coordinating between them.

The officials noted that the ratio of Taiwan's service sector accounts for 73 percent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP), although the number of those employed in the sector accounts for only 58.27 percent of the total employment.

Compared with the figures in industrialized countries, such as the 2004 service sector employment in Hong Kong accounting for 81.4 percent of the total employment, with 75.6 percent in the United States, 74.6 percent in Britain and 67.1 percent in Japan, the creation of service sector jobs in Taiwan is low.
In addition, although Taiwan's service sector accounts for over 70 percent of the nation's GDP, its contribution to economic growth is comparatively low.

In terms of the contributions of various sectors to economic growth, the contributions of the service sector (0.88 percent) lagged behind those of the manufacturing sector (1.64 percent) and the industrial sector (1.5 percent) in 2005.
In terms of the real growth of various sectors, the service sector also lagged at 3.8 percent behind the 5.76 percent of the manufacturing sector and the 5.24 percent of the industrial sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF CALLS FOR PARTY RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: Instead of engaging in partisan struggles, political parties should work together for the benefit of the country, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Monday.

Lee reiterated the remarks he made in a four-point written statement the previous day, adding that his statement was made in response to the many e-mails he has received asking about his views on the political situation.
He emphasized that the purpose of his statement was to urge political parties to end their vicious disputes and pay more attention to the country's development.
He said the most important part of his statement is his call for parties to start negotiations and that the ruling and opposition parties should strive for the country's development.

Lee's statement also urged the opposition and ruling parties to step back from the fierce dispute over whether President Chen Shui-bian should be recalled in the wake of scandals allegedly involving members of his family and close aides.

His statement said that opposition lawmakers who initiated the recall motion should fully understand why the Constitution outlines stringent requirements to recall the president, which is to ensure domestic stability and to make it difficult for a recall bid to pass without a clear legislative majority.

The recall motion will be put to a vote Tuesday at the Legislative Yuan, where it is expected to fail because the opposition parties leading it are unlikely to obtain the two-thirds majority required by the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEW DEPUTY REP TO U.S. TO ASSUME POST JULY 3
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 26 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new deputy representative to the United States, Deng Chen-chung, is expected to assume his post in Washington, D. C. July 3.
Having been Taiwan's deputy representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) for more than four years, Deng departed from Geneva Monday for Taipei.

Deng, a shrewd economic affairs official who has performed well in multilateral trade talks since he was assigned to the WTO headquarters in April 2002, was seen off at the airport by Representative Lin Yi-fu and other officials from the Taiwan mission.

Deng is expected to stay in Taiwan for four days before heading to Washington, D.C. July 3, making him the first Taiwan deputy representative to the United States who has expertise in economic and trade affairs.

Striving to enhance bilateral business and trade exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and the United States in general and pushing for the signing of a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement (FTA) in particular will be Deng's major task after he assumes his duties in Washington.

Deng, 53, from Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan, is a graduate of Soochow University in Taipei, majoring in law. He obtained a master's degree in law from George Washington University and has acquired a lawyer's license to practice in the Washington, D.C. area.

Other posts he has held include section chief of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, section chief of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States and vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER TO PROPOSE SECOND EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that he would propose a second extraordinary session of the legislature after a showdown between the ruling and the opposition parties on an opposition-initiated recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday.

DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said the second extraordinary session should focus on the discussion of a major arms procurement bill and on bills related to public welfare such as special budgets for flood-control as well as a draft bill on the establishment of a group to supervise a labor retirement fund, which he said is crucial to the rights of 6 million wage earners.
Ker made the remarks after a regular meeting with Premier Su Tseng-chang and DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun at the premier's office. Su approved of his suggestion, according to Ker.
Ker said they also discussed the party's strategy on the recall motion vote and how to deal with the aftermath of the vote, expected before noon Tuesday.

As the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) only maintains a slim majority in the 221-seat legislature, Ker said the recall motion is "bound to fail, " as a recall motion requires the endorsement of two-thirds of the legislators before it can be put to a national referendum.

Ker said the DPP, defined the recall motion as "political strife, " will not take part in the vote, but said the DPP lawmakers will unfurl a banner prior to the vote to express their opposition to the recall and the political struggle, and to put forward the party's pro-public welfare stance.

On an opposition announcement that it will encourage DPP lawmakers to side with them, Ker claimed that "they are lying and that it is also impossible, " warning them that some KMT and PFP legislators might "act in line with the public will and stay away from the vote."

Amid tension between the ruling and the opposition parties after days of campaigning by the rival parties, Ker, Su and Yu also decided that after the vote, police will step up checks at major traffic points, including mass rapid transit stations and railway stations, to avoid possible clashes between "pan blue alliance" supporters and their "pan green camp" rivals, Ker added.

The legislators agreed to an extraordinary session June 13-30 after the legislature went into recess in late May. The DPP has listed several priority bills for discussion in the special session, but the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) put the recall motion at the top of the agenda.

With reports saying that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is most likely to represent the party in the 2008 presidential election, intends to return to a middle-of-the-road path after the vote, Ker said he hopes Ma will support the idea of the second extraordinary session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIALS ATTEND IATTC CONFERENCE IN SOUTH KOREA
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, June 26 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The 74th meeting of the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) opened Sunday in Busan, South Korea, with two officials from Taiwan taking part.

Tsai Je-yao, a section chief of the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture, and Huang Lee-fang, a division head of the International Organization Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, are representing Taiwan in the six-day conference. Taiwan has observer status at the IATTC.

Taiwan is expected to join the IATTC as a full member through due protocol process after the IATTC approves its Antigua Convention, Chen Chung, director-general of the MOFA's International Organization Department, said recently in Taipei.

In the ongoing IATTC annual conference in Busan, Tsai and Huang will express Taiwan's concern over the IATTC's quota allocation for bigeye tuna catches for 2007 and the years to come, according to Chen.

South Korean officials in charge of the issue revealed that they will ask the IATTC to take countermeasures to deal with overfishing by other countries in the eastern Pacific Ocean like China and Taiwan and will ask for a larger quota for tuna catches in the meeting.
The IATTC comprises 15 member states that include Japan, Mexico, Panama, Peru, Spain, South Korea and the United States.

More than 150 representatives from these member states and some non-member nations, such as Taiwan, Colombia and Belize, as well as those from global fishery organizations and the international deep-sea fishing industry, are attending the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIRING OF FOREIGN WORKERS DEPENDS ON DEMAND: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will review the overall needs of industry and the actual labor shortage situation before deciding whether to allow the hiring of more foreign laborers, a senior official said Monday.
The official was responding to a recent call by Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Ing-san to allow for more foreign workers to be brought in to meet the demands of certain "hardship" industries.

In a speech delivered at a ceremony to mark the formation of a 150-member workplace hygiene and safety inspection corps last Friday, Hwang said he hopes the CLA can set up additional foreign laborer import quotas because certain "special manufacturing industries" have 60,000 jobs left unfilled.
The CLA's 20,000 foreign laborer quota for this year is not enough to meet the demand of these labor-intensive industries, particularly those with dirty and dangerous work conditions.

However, CLA Chairman Lee Ying-yuan said that more than 7,000 vacancies remain for this year. "The CLA will discuss with the Industrial Development Bureau how to allocate the remaining quota for special manufacturing businesses," he added.
As to whether to allow more foreign laborer quotas, Lee said the CLA has to evaluate overall industry demand and the actual labor market situation before reaching a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-GANGSTER RELEASED BY PROSECUTOR TO OUTCRY OF POLICE

TEXT.P: A former gangster who was arrested the previous day in a high-profile police operation was released on bail by prosecutors early Monday to the outrage of the police authorities.

Yang Shung-wu, who is accused of extorting money from local businessmen, was questioned by prosecutors overnight and released on NT$300,000 bail, on the grounds that there is little ironclad evidence to substantiate the police charges against him.
Also released were eight alleged members of Yang's crime ring who were arrested along with him.
It was a hard blow to police because they had monitored Yang for more than three days without sleep and had mounted a large-scale operation to arrest him and crack down on his crime ring.

Chung Chung-hsiao, assistant director of Kaohsiung District Prosecutor's Office, said the police failed to substantiate their charges against Yang with evidence and added that if new evidence is been presented by the police, Yang may be detained later.
Yang who lives in Kushan, Kaohsiung City, ignored media requests for interviews.

Police claim that Yang extorted NT$20 million from a businessman selling grit and sand in July 2005 and ordered one of his underlings to smash the windows and furniture of a night club after its owner rejected his demands for NT$5 million early this year.

They claim that Yang, who was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1990 for killing two other gangsters in a turf war but was released on probation in 2003 after serving 13 years, bullies businessmen and extorts cash in return for his "protection."

Yang was once listed as one of the nation's top-10 wanted fugitives and went into hiding in Japan and China until 1990, when he visited Thailand and was arrested by Thai police at the request of their Taipei counterparts.
Yang has avoided publicity ever since his 2003 release.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: A 35 percent turnout for the first day of referendum on constitutional reform.
Some 35 percent of the 47 million Italian voters cast their ballots Sunday, the first of the two-day referendum on a constitutional reform that will radically alter the government institutions. The polling booths around the nation will reopen Monday from 7 a.m. through 3 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20% YET TO LAND JOBS FIVE YEARS AFTER LEAVING COLLEGE

TEXT.P: Nearly 20 percent of college graduates have yet to land jobs five years after leaving college or university, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey was conducted by www.1111.com.tw, an on-line manpower firm, between March 8 and May 10 with the aim of learning about the employment situation among college graduates five years after leaving school. A total of 1,297 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of 2.7 percent.

The survey results show that 69.93 percent of college graduates are hired as full-time workers within five years of their graduation, 19.12 percent have yet to land jobs, while 9.79 percent are in non-typical jobs such as short-term jobs, temp work or case-by-case projects.
That means that around 30 percent have yet to enter the traditional work force after receiving their diplomas, the survey shows.

Asked if they have ever been jobless, 44.64 percent of those polled said "yes, " compared with 55.36 percent who did not. On average, college graduates experience a five-month waiting period before landing jobs.
During the unemployment period, 87.22 percent said they live with their parents, compared with 12.78 percent who said they do not.
Questioned on how they manage for money, 60.62 percent said they have to depend on their parents, while 55.79 percent said they rely on their savings and 12.6 percent get help from their siblings.
A spokesman for the job bank urged college graduates in non-typical jobs to be active, build up their connections and nurture and sharpen their skills to help them land full time jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TAIPEI CITY COUNCILOR QUESTIONED ON EXTORTION

TEXT.P: Public prosecutors took a Taipei city councilor of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and two of his aides into custody Monday for questioning on charges of extorting money from a number of construction companies in the 2002-2004 period.
Before interrogating Lo Tsung-sheng, the public prosecutors searched six locations, including his office and home, and the homes of the two aides.
Owners of construction companies have alleged that they were forced to pay some NT$20 million to Lo in order to make him keep his mouth shut about their unlawful dumping of construction debris.

They claim that Lo and his aides used their access to files at the Maintenance Office of the city government's Public Works Department to obtain information about construction companies that had been found to have been dumping construction waste illegally.
Lo and his aides would then allegedly demand money from the companies and threaten to blow the whistle on them if they did not cooperate.
According to the construction companies, Lo would "borrow" the money from them by writing a check to each of them, but the checks would always bounce.
The owners of the construction companies said they decided to tell the prosecutors everything because they had had enough of him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVELERS WARNED TO DECLARE TOBACCO, CHINESE CURRENCY

TEXT.P: Travelers should declare any Chinese currency, alcohol and tobacco in their possession when they enter or leave Taiwan or risk having undeclared excess amounts of those articles confiscated, a spokesman for the Taipei Customs Office warned Monday.
According to existing regulations, each passenger is allowed to carry no more than 20,000 Chinese yuan into or out of Taiwan, one carton of cigarettes and one liter of alcohol.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Afghan Leader Losing Support; Foreign, Local Allies Cite Weak Karzai Leadership.
Many Afghans and some foreign supporters say they are losing faith in President Hamid Karzai's government, which is besieged by an escalating insurgency and endemic corruption and is unable to protect or administer large areas of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: `PAN-BLUES' MIGHT SPLIT OVER PRESIDENTIAL RECALL VOTE: EX-PREMIER

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh forecast Monday that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" might split following a Tuesday vote on a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian at the Legislative Yuan.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh claimed that the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Part (PFP) is set to split should some lawmakers be disciplined for having failed to cast a "yes" vote to oust Chen.

If this happens, it is very possible that some lawmakers will quit the two parties, Hsieh forecast, pointing out that in that case, it will be also impossible to launch a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet as a means of maintaining pressure on Chen to force him to step down.

Hsieh blamed the "pan-blue alliance" for calling the presidential recall vote, because doing so is against the present world trend that suggests co-existence backed up by dialogue, negotiations and conciliation to replace confrontation.
Taiwan will lose its advantages on the world stage because of the fierce infighting at a time when the rest of the world is engaged in cooperation, he contended.

It is regrettable that the "pan-blue alliance" has failed to notice this point and does not sense that the presidential recall vote will further fan ethnic confrontation in Taiwan, he said, warning that this will be a huge crisis for the country.

The former premier made the remarks on the eve of a presidential recall vote at the Legislative Yuan -- the first of its kind in Taiwan's history -- aimed at booting out Chen from the presidency over a string of corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Militants' Raid on Israel Raises Gaza Tension
In an ominous development, Israel threatened strong military action on Sunday after eight Palestinian militants in Gaza, including members of the governing faction Hamas, emerged from a secret tunnel dug 300 yards into Israel, killed two soldiers, wounded three and kidnapped another. Israeli tanks moved a short distance into Gaza on Sunday, the first tank raid since Israel withdrew from the territory last summer.
Wall Street Journal: Dry Hole, Great Expectations For Private Water Fail to Pan Out
To RWE AG, Germany's biggest electric company, the water business a few years ago seemed to promise a gusher of profits. Governments in the U.S. and around the globe were eager to privatize their water systems. RWE was already experienced in delivering electricity and gas to millions of homes. But dreams of heady profits evaporated amid heated opposition in U.S. townships. RWE found itself fighting in town referendums and state legislatures across the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG, JAPAN'S IBARAKI PREFECTURE TO FORGE CLOSER TIES

TEXT.P: A delegation of 51 councilors from Japan's Ibaraki prefecture council made a courtesy visit Monday to the Kaohsiung City Council in southern Taiwan to promote bilateral economic, trade, tourism and cultural exchanges.

The delegation was received by Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Tsai Chien-hsing, who noted that Kaohsiung is closely tied to Japan because the city councils of Yokohama and Osaka are sister councils with the Kaohsiung city council.
Besides that, there are around 2,000 Japanese living in Kaohsiung City, and there is a school for the children of Japanese expatriates in Kaohsiung, Tsai added.

The leader of the Japanese delegation said he hopes to promote economic, trade and cultural exchanges between Kaohsiung and Ibaraki to consolidate friendship, and he noted that Ibaraki is very advanced in robotics and aeronautical engineering.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN TO TELL INT'L PRESS WHY PRESIDENT SHOULD BE RECALLED

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will tell the world community through an international press conference Tuesday why his party has been pushing for a legislative motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a PFP spokesman said Monday.

According to Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, Soong will hold the news conference at 9:30 a.m. prior to the legislature voting on the recall motion. He will answer questions from international media about why Chen should be recalled.

The recall motion was introduced by legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang with the support of their PFP allies after the president refused to step down amid a series of corruption scandals allegedly involving his senior aides and family members.
The motion will need a two-thirds majority approval in the 221-seat legislature before the issue can be put to a national referendum.

The motion's passage appears unlikely because the KMT and PFP only hold a slight majority in the legislature. The two parties would need the support of at least 36 legislators from the ruling Democratic Party DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to carry the motion.
Soong, PFP legislators and party supporters, have staged a four-day sit-in in front of the Legislative Yuan, appealing to the president, the DPP and TSU to "recover Taiwan's democratic conscience."
He and his supporters will hold an overnight vigil on the eve of the vote on the recall motion in an attempt to call on DPP legislators not to be "hijacked" by the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER CALLS FOR RESPECTING OUTCOME OF RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged supporters of the country's two rival political camps Monday to respect the outcome of the upcoming legislative vote on a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

"No matter what the result turns out to be, supporters of the 'pan-green' and 'pan-blue' camps should respect the parliamentary resolution, " Wang appealed on the eve of a closely watched vote on the opposition-led recall motion.

Noting the legislature's Committee of the Whole finalized screening of the recall motion earlier in the day, Wang said he is hopeful all lawmakers will cast their ballot in a responsible way and based on prudent judgment.
"During the voting procedures, proponents and opponents of the motion should remain calm, rational and peaceful," Wang added.

As both the opposition "pan-blue" alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) -- which initiated the recall motion -- and the "pan-green" camp led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will mobilize their loyalists to rally on the issue outside the legislature Tuesday, Wang said all demonstrators should respect and accept the vote's outcome and refrain from any drastic actions.

"Taiwan is now a liberal democracy that values the rule of law and denounces violence," Wang said, adding he keenly hopes locals and politicians of all political stripes will work together after the recall vote to create a stable, harmonious environment that is favorable to economic development.

The recall campaign was triggered by allegations of corruption in President Chen's family. His son-in-law, Chao Chien-min, was arrested May 24 and is being held under detention while being investigated on suspicions of insider trading.

Thousands of pan-blue loyalists are expected to gather outside the legislature for Tuesday's vote, which is unlikely to succeed as the pan-blue alliance lacks the two-thirds majority needed to put the recall motion to a national referendum.

The ruling party is also planning to send supporters to rally outside the legislature, but DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun warned that any party member who starts trouble would be punished, adding that party officials would be on hand at the site to help maintain order.
"It's not in our best interest to stir up things. We're trying to stabilize the political situation," Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER TO SEEK GRAND JUSTICES' CLARIFICATION ON RECALL CLAUSE

TEXT.P: A main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator is drafting a motion asking the panel of grand justices to explain whether the second clause in the Constitution has deprived people of the right to recall the president and vice president.

John Wu told reporters that with the support of the KMT's legislative caucus, he will introduce such a motion after the legislature votes Tuesday on the proposed recall of President Chen Shui-bian on grounds he can no longer lead the country effectively after some senior aides and family members were investigated in a series of corruption allegations.

The recall motion appears unlikely to pass the legislature because, according to the Constitution's second clause, a two-thirds majority vote is required before the issue can be put to a national referendum.

Wu said he intends to ask the grand justices to explain whether the second clause has "violated the spirit of the Constitution," because voters who can select the president and vice president through direct elections cannot institute a motion to recall them and have to wait for the legislature to adopt such a motion before they can vote on the issue in a national referendum.
He said the threshold to pass a recall motion in the legislature is currently too high, making it impossible for Taiwan's voters to exercise their constitutional right.

Wu added that if the grand justices' interpretation says the "indirect democracy" prescribed by the second clause of the Constitution is unconstitutional, the KMT will propose a motion to amend the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, granting voters the right to directly introduce a motion to recall the president and vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Visiting Dominican Republic President Leonel Antonio Fernandez Reyna reaffirmed Monday that his country will continue supporting Taiwan's bid to upgrade its international profile, including joining major world organizations.
Fernandez made the reaffirmation during a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.

As Taiwan's faithful ally, Fernandez said, the Dominican Republic firmly supports Taiwan's efforts to expand its international space and its bid to join the World Health Organization and the United Nations.
During the talks, President Chen said he hopes the two countries will sign a mutually beneficial free trade agreement as early as possible.
Chen presided over a welcoming ceremony earlier the same day for Fernandez, who was accorded with full military honors complete with a 21-gun salute.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APPEALS FOR RATIONALITY AHEAD OF RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged political parties Monday to refrain frim stirring up violent protest Tuesday when the Legislative Yuan votes on an opposition-initieated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian over alleged corruption and incompetence.

Both the opposition "pan-blue" alliance of the Kuomintang and the People First Party and the "pan-green" camp led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are expected to mobilize their supporters to rally outside the legislature Tuesday to express their stances.

"Some people want to mobilize supporters tomorrow. I urge them to be rational, cool and keep order. Don't be too emotionally charged, " Su said. Su was quoted as having all reminded DPP lawmakers during a dinner with DPP members in the legislature's transportation and communications committee that they should be on hand to help keep order outside the legislature and avoid instigating any conflict.

Earlier in the day, 20-plus DPP lawmakers met with President Chen at the Presidential Office to boost his morale. Chen was quoted as having told them that he would respect the outcome of the parliamentary vote and that whether the DPP has the opportunity to stand up again is entirely up to the Taiwan people to decide.
The embattled Chen burnt incense and prayed at temples in Taipei and his hometown, Tainan, in the south over the weekend.

Barbed-wire barricades were set up outside the legislature ahead of Tuesday's vote to prevent any clashes between Chen supporters and opposition protesters. More than 4,000 police officers will be mobilized to maintain law and order and major streets surrounding the legislature will be subject to traffic control from midnight through Tuesday evening.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel chemistry prize winner who backed Chen in the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections, issued a statement Sunday saying his "heart ached" that the DPP has achieved little and was embroiled in scandal.
The recall motion is not expected to succeed as the "pan-blue" alliance lacks a two-thirds majority needed to clear the legislature to pave the way for a public referendum.

Three Taiwan-friendly U.S. congressmen issued a joint statement expressing their concern about Taiwan's political situation amid the turmoil triggered by the recall motion. The U.S. House members, including Steve Chabot and Sherrod Brown, said they hope the recall motion will not affect preservation of Taiwan's constitutional system and democratic ideals.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 27 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 27:
09:00, A Dominican Republic trade fair will open at Taipei World Trade Center.
18:30, President Chen Shui-bian will host a state dinner in honor of visiting Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez in Tainan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 27, or the second day of the sixth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads had gone out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
2000: The Legislative Yuan adopts a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.
2001: A total of 175 illegal mainland Chinese immigrats are repatrated from Fu Su Port on the frontline island of Matsu through arrangement by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Buffett Pledges Billions to Gates. Business titan Warren E. Buffett, the world's second-richest person, has pledged to begin giving away 85% of his $40-billion-plus fortune in July--most of it to the Billand Melinda Gates Foundation. Some experts are calling it the biggest philanthropic gift ever.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times E. Timor's Alkatiri resigns from post
East Timor's embattled Prime Minister Mari Alkatiri resigned Monday, triggering celebrations in the violence-scarred capital and raising hopes for an end to weeks of politcical turmoil and unrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SUPPORTERS RALLY TO CALL FOR STOP TO POLITICAL FIGHTING

TEXT.P: Thousands of supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gathered outside the Legislative Yuan Tuesday morning to urge opposition lawmakers to "end the political infighting" as the legislature prepared to vote on the motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
The recall vote was slated to be held at 9:30 a.m. and take about one-and-a-half hours to complete.

Police were out in full force in anticipation of possible clushes between supporters of the two rival camps -- the DPP-led "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party.

Earlier in the day, the KMT legislative caucus decided that all KMT lawmakers would be obliged to attend the vote and cast ballots in favor of the recall and that any lawmakers who did not follow orders would face party discipline.
The vote on the recall motion against the president marks the first of its kind in the constitutional history of the Republic of China.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN BEGINS RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan began an unprecedented vote Tuesday on an opposition-initiated recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian for incompetence and corruption allegations against his family and close associates.

The vote was being held amid tight security as 5,000 police officers were deployed to prevent possible clashes between supporters from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party who had converged outside the Legislative Yuan.
Around 60 KMT lawmakers shouted slogans such as "clean politics to save Taiwan, " "against corruption" and "President Chen Shui-bian must step down," prior to the vote in the legislature.
They also unveiled white banners emblazoned with the words "supporting President Chen Shui-bian is supporting corruption" and "supporting the president is a real disgrace."
The vote began at 9: 10 a.m. and was expected to last 90 minutes. Legislators received ballots printed with a serial number, their names and two options -- "yes" or "no" to the recall motion.

In inter-party consultations, it was agreed that one legislator from each party would be sent to monitor the vote. The representatives selected were Kuo Su-chun from the KMT, Ko Shu-ming from the PFP, Kuo Lin-yung from the TSU. The DPP and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union decided not to send representatives.
Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a former KMT vice chairman, was cheered by KMT legislators as he stepped down from the podium at 9:37 a.m. to cast his vote.
Ker Chien-ming, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, reiterated that the recall motion is a "political struggle with the aim of creating national turmoil."
The DPP legislative caucus decided not to enter the legislative hall to cast their ballots in boycott of the recall motion, Ker said.
He also expressed the hope of rational and peaceful dialogue with opposition parties after the political turmoil triggered by the recall vote ends.
KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jou, in greeting "pan-blue" supporters outside the Legislative Yuan, said the recall motion has made a mark on history.

Ma lashed out at President Chen for refusing to give a written reply prior to a debate on the recall motion held June 21-23 and June 26 and instead resorting to a televised address in order to, in the president's words, "report to the people, " while denying the public the right to express their views through a national referendum on the recall motion.

The recall motion is unlikely to pass as the "pan-blue alliance" only holds a slim majority in the 221-seat legislature, far short of the two-thirds required for the motion to pass and be put to a national referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALL MOTION FAILS IN LEGISLATIVE VOTE

TEXT.P: The opposition-initiated recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian failed to gain the required support of two-thirds of all lawmakers in an unprecedented vote in the legislature Tuesday morning, with only 119 legislators casting their ballots in favor of the motion.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced shortly after 11 a.m. that 133 lawmakers were present for the vote, with 119 casting ballots in support of the motion and zero against. There were 14 invalid ballots. A total of 88 lawmakers were not present as the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative decided earlier in the day to boycott the vote.
As the recall motion failed to gain the required support of 148 lawmakers in the 221-seat legislature, it will not be put to a national referendum.

Legislators of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) toed the party line, with all 89 KMT lawmakers and 23 PFP lawmakers casting ballots in support of the motion. Independent Legislator Lee Ao and six legislators from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) also voted in favor of the motion.

The 14 invalid ballots included 12 votes cast by Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers and one each by Legislator Lin Wei-chou, who quit the DPP earlier this year, and Legislator Peter Lin, who was stripped of his DPP membership for alleged involvement in a national health insurance fraud scam earlier this year.

In the current legislature, the "pan-blue alliance" holds a slim majority, with 89 KMT lawmakers and 23 PFP lawmakers. The ruling DPP holds 86 seats, while its "pan-green" ally, the TSU, holds 12 seats, and the NPSU eight seats. There are three independent legislators -- Lee Ao, Lin Wei-chou an Peter Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECALL VOTE GRABS ATTENTION OF FOREIGN COUNTRIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: Most countries have shown interest in Tuesday's legislative vote on the opposition-initiated recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian but have underlined their position of non-interference in Taiwan's domestic affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that as the vote has grabbed global attention, the ministry will inform foreign governments as well as overseas Taiwanese of the results of the vote through all of its overseas offices.

The recall motion failed to gain the required support of two-thirds of all legislators in Tuesday morning's vote, with only 119 lawmakers in the 221-seat legislature casting ballots in favor of the motion. As a result, the motion will not be put to a national referendum.
A total of 88 lawmakers were absent from the vote as the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party decided earlier in the day to boycott the proceedings.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU CITY, COUNTY TO SET UP DRUG PREVENTION AND CONTROL CENTERS

TEXT.P: Both the Hsinchu county government and city government have decided to set up drug prevention and control centers to facilitate their campaign against drug abuse and trafficking.
Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin and Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Cheng-tzer unveiled their plans during a meeting with Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin Monday.
Both Cheng and Lin invited Shih to preside over the inauguration ceremonies for their respective drug prevention and control centers next month.

Shih praised the two local government chiefs for their innovative efforts in the battle against drugs, adding that he believes that the establishment of the centers will upgrade efficiency in helping drug addicts quit their vice and in facilitating one-on-one counseling service.

The war against drugs has become more urgent as many new types of drugs have appeared on the streets, drug users and drug traffickers are starting at a younger age, and the ratio of repeat and serial offenders is on the rise in Taiwan, Shih said. He added that the sharing of needles among drug users has accelerated the spread of HIV/AIDS.

Worse still, Shih noted, many robberies and violent crimes are related to drugs, adding that drugs thus pose a grave threat to public order. Against this backdrop, he said, the Executive Yuan has made anti-drug operations a major part of its ongoing campaign to improve law and order in the country.
Shih encouraged the Hsinchu city and county governments to promote community "living camps" to help young student drug abusers and school dropouts to get back on track.
Other city and county governments are also expected to follow suit to boost the national campaign against drug abuse and trafficking, Shih added.

DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Australia and Indonesia ties back on track.
Relations between Indonesia and Australia are on the mend.
Talks between the leaders of the two countries in Batam yesterday defied initial expectations of tension and proceeded smoothly.

Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong said yesterday he already instructed Matthias Yao Chih, the mayor of South East Community Development Council (CDC) , to run programs to support young parents in raising their children, such as offering a range of services from accredited providers which can be purchased with their baby bonuses.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEROIN MOST COMMONLY ABUSED DRUG IN TAIWAN: CDC

TEXT.P: Heroin is the most commonly abused drug in Taiwan, followed by amphetamine, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Center for Disease Control (CDC).
Of the 4,740 drug users registered at treatment centers in Taiwan from January to April this year, 94.9 percent were heroin addicts and 30.3 percent were amphetamine addicts, CDC officials said.
Other commonly abused drugs include nimetazepam, inhalants, ketamine, ecstasy pills, morphine, marijuana and pethidine, the officials said.
Although only 0.1 percent of the drug users were codeine addicts, the ratio marked a 300 percent increase over the same period last year.

Meanwhile, statistics from the Ministry of Justice show that the amount of drugs seized by Taiwan authorities rose from 2,000 kilograms in 2001 to more than 12,500 kilograms in 2005, while local research indicates that 10 percent to 15 percent of drug users in Taiwan are HIV carriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN HOPES TO MEET WITH OPPOSITION LEADERS AFTER RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun expressed the hope Tuesday that he can meet with opposition leaders to discuss major bills related to the people's welfare now that the political turmoil triggered by an opposition-initiated recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian has come to an end.

Yu made the remarks after an unprecedented vote on whether to put a recall motion to a national referendum failed to pass the legislature with only 119 lawmakers voting in favor of the motion, far short of the required two-thirds of all legislators in the 221-seat legislature.

With the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) only maintaining a slim majority in the legislature, the result of the recall vote was "predictable, " Yu said, although he added that he felt "no joy at heart, as there is no winner in this vote."
Saying that political turmoil has a huge social cost, he said that "the end of the recall motion in the legislature should also be the end of inter-party strife and the start of getting things done."
Yu said he hopes he can meet with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PPF Chairman James Soong to exchange views so as to "do something useful for the people."
He lamented that since the extraordinary session of the legislature convened June 13, it has achieved nothing.
"If the KMT and the PFP really have the interests of the people at heart, they should start inter-party consultations to promote bills related to the public's welfare and the bills' budgets."
The opposition should at least pass the special budget for a flood-fighting bill before the extraordinary session ends June 30, Yu added.
Ker Chien-ming, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that none of the priority bills the party listed have passed since the extraordinary session began.

Ker said that Ma should take the biggest responsibility. Since Ma assumed the party chairmanship last year, the rivalry between the ruling and the opposition parties has been the most serious, he added.

In addition to the long-stalled arms procurement bill in the opposition-controlled legislature, Ker also called for the speedy passage of the budget for flood-fighting and the restoration of budgets for some government agencies that have been frozen due to the opposition of the KMT and the PFP.
Ker reaffirmed that the nation should return to the normal after the recall vote and that inter-party dialogue should begin for a rational discussion on bills related to the people's welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L COOPERATION & DEVELOPMENT FUND TO CELEBRATE 1OTH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will hold a series of activities from July 1 to celebrate the 10th founding anniversary of the MOFA-operated International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF), a ranking official said Tuesday.

Cho Shih-chao, MOFA chief of economic and trade affairs, indicated that President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang have been invited to take part in a planned celebration, while former World Bank Vice President Motoo Kusakabe has been invited to host a conference slated for July 1 at Taipei's Grand Hotel.

Many local and foreign scholars and experts, including Craig Hawke, deputy executive director of New Zealand's International Aid and Development Agency, and Burkina Faso Ambassador to Taiwan Jacques Sawadogo, will attend the one-day event to explore global trends in international development and examine Taiwan's experiences with international cooperation, Cho noted.

On the same day, the MOFA will also host an evening party, called the Night of International Cooperation, with around 1,000 officials, scholars, foreign diplomats stationed in Taiwan, as well as members of the ICDF's board and supervisory committees and overseas technical missions expected to attend the party.

In addition, leaders of all ICDF technical missions stationed in countries around the globe have been instructed to gather in Taipei July 3 as they are entitled to a training program aimed at providing the professionals with state-of-the-art techniques and know-how, Cho said.

The ICDF was established in 1996 with the aim of strengthening international cooperation and enhancing foreign relations by promoting economic development, social progress and the welfare of the people in partnership with nations around the world. It primarily assists Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central and South America, the East Caribbean, Africa and the Asia Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 48.71 points to close at 6,572.39.
The bourse opened at 6,520.77 and fluctuated between 6,622.81 and 6,513.03 during trading. A total of 3.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.48 billion (US$2.74 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.2 percent, cement stocks, plastics and chemicals shares and machinery and electronic shares all at 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent.
Only paper and pulp issues lost ground, dropping at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 566 to 297, with 138 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED FOR PARTY LEADERS' MEETING: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou turned down an offer from his ruling party counterpart, Yu Shyi-kun, Tuesday for the heads of the various parties to meet, saying there is no need for such a meeting since "ruling-opposition cooperation on legislation has been going on."

Yu called for a meeting of political party leaders after an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian failed to pass in a legislative vote Tuesday morning. Yu said since "the bruising incident is over, it's time to move on."

In response, Ma said the Legislative Yuan passed 75 bills during its previous session, an indication that ruling-opposition cooperation on legislating relevant laws has been in progress and so there is no need for party chairmen to meet at this moment.

What is urgent for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is for it to "clean its own house" by examining why it has become a party marred by a string of corruption charges so quickly, Ma said.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party filed the recall motion charging that the president has allowed his senior aides and son-in-law to engage in various sorts of irregularities such as insider trading and influence peddling.
There is no need for the DPP to hurry into meetings with the opposition parties, which have not contributed in any way to its loss of integrity, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN FAMILY FINANCIAL STATUS HITS NEW LOW: POLL

TEXT.P: The public's confidence in the financial status of families has dropped to a record low in June as possible inflation is expected to increase expenses, according to survey results released Tuesday by National Central University's Taiwan Economic Development Research Center.
The consumer confidence index fell 0.48 point from the previous month to stand at 68.53 in June, with five of the six indicators used in the survey declining.
The "timing for investing in the stock market in the next six months" saw the greatest decrease, losing 2.3 points from the previous month to 70.50.
The "domestic consumer price level in the next six months" fell 0.5 point to 40.95. The "domestic economic outlook in the next six months hit 53.30, down 0.25 point from May.
The "family financial status in the next six months" slid 0.25 point to hit a record low of 55.65, while "employment opportunities in the next six months" dropped 0.1 point to stand at 74.80.
Meanwhile, the "timing for buying durable goods in the next six months" rose 0.45 point to 116.00.
The survey was conducted June 18-20 among 2,637 adults around Taiwan via telephone. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 1.9 percentage points.

Wall Street Journal: Rules Limit Entry, Prospects of Foreign-Born Scientists Despite Demand for Them

As other countries, such as the United Kingdom and Canada, loosen their rules on immigration to attract these same highly skilled workers, the U.S.'s long-term competitiveness could be hampered.
