DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN HAILS 'PEOPLE POWER' IN THWARTED RECALL EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun hailed "people power" as the major force behind a thwarted attempt by the opposition to pass a legislative motion for the recall of President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday.

Yu made the comments while publicly announcing the failed passage of a presidential recall motion initiated by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the legislature.

A total of 119 lawmakers -- including 89 KMT lawmakers and 23 PFP lawmakers as well as one independent lawmaker and six from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) -- cast a "yes" vote to recall Chen at the 211-member Legislative Yuan. But it still fell short of a two-thirds majority of lawmakers, or 148, for the presidential recall motion to be put to a national referendum.

According to Yu, the drop in public approval ratings for KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and his party indicate the average voter is fed up with political infighting. Yu promised the DPP would cooperate with its "pan-green" partner, the TSU, to work in the public interest and on improving Taiwan's economy and democracy.

Pointing out that the outcome of the presidential recall vote, which was aimed at ousting Chen over a string of corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides, was foreseen, Yu said that the DPP was not content with the results because "no one is the winner -- the ruling party, the opposition, the people nor the country."

Now that the presidential recall vote has failed in the legislature, it is time to end politicking and social upheaval and to begin doing something in the public interest, Yu said, voicing hope of meeting with Ma and PFP Chairman James Soong to discuss such quality of life issues.

"If the people of Taiwan are really important to the KMT and PFP, they should agree to resume inter-party negotiations to pass more budgets and bills related to people's welfare during the Legislative Yuan's current extra session -- such as a budget bill pertaining to a flood control project," Yu proposed.
The DPP chairman also called for swift passage of a major military procurement bill and three sunshine laws if the pan-blue alliance really wants to build a clean Taiwan.
"Don't let the extra legislative session come up empty-handed before it ends June 30, " he urged, calling on the pan-blue camp to assume responsibility for the nation's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CAREFULLY MULLING NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION AGAINST GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday his party has not ruled out the possibility of proposing a no-confidence motion against the government of President Chen Shui-bian, but said the strategy must be "carefully studied."

The issue needs careful evaluation because it might bring about an "idling period" of the government, as rules on the election of a new legislature -- which would likely follow the toppling of the premier in the wake of a no-confidence vote -- have not been set, Ma said.

He made the remarks after the legislature failed to pass an opposition-led motion to recall the president. He urged the president to "know the right thing to do" and not to "become a liability to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party," or DPP.

According to Ma, more than 1.7 million Taiwanese adults have signed a petition calling on Chen to step down to take moral and political responsibility over his senior aides and son-in-law's suspected involvement in various corruption scandals currently under investigation by judicial authorities.

He said his party's 89 legislators will call town hall meetings in their constituencies to explain to voters the need to "protect Taiwan with politics based on integrity" and urging them to "resuscitate Taiwan's core values."
In the meantime, Ma said the KMT encourages officials involved in the investigation to do their jobs professionally and conscientiously.
"We're not trying to interfere in their judicial work. We're just encouraging them to do their jobs properly," he added.
On the other hand, he said if President Chen became a burden to the DPP, he would be "contributing to the continuation of the party's decline and holding it hostage," Ma said.
As for the KMT, he said although the recall motion had failed, it set a democratic example of "a direct exercise of people power."
"It may not have been a successful exercise. But the KMT has played its role as an opposition party," he said.
Its next step? He said he will not exclude the possibility of proposing a no-confidence vote against the premier, another recall motion or impeachment proceedings against the president.

A no-confidence vote, which requires only half of the legislature's 221 votes, may result in a change of premier or trigger an election of a new legislature if the president decided to dissolve it, Ma said.

But redistricting and election rules for the new "two votes, single constituency" system have yet to be finalized, he said, adding that without establishing these "matching measures" to election law, Taiwan may face a period of "no government."

DOC.HEADLINE: UB, STAPLES FORM PARTNERSHIP TO CONQUER ASIA'S OFFICE SUPPLY MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main supplier of office furniture, UB Express, and Staples, a leading office supply superstore in the U.S., announced plans Monday to jointly establish a new company, UB Staples, to conquer the office furniture market in Taiwan and enter the Southeast Asian market.

The US$6 million contract was signed by UB Group President Lin Wei-hsiu and Jack Van Woerkom, the Staples representative in Asia. Lin has been designated head of UB Staples, where UB Express and Staples each own 50 percent of the company's stakes.
A spokesman for UB Express said the Taiwanese office furniture market has a potential revenue of around US$2.5 billion per year.

UB was established in Taiwan in 1973. The spokesman said that UB's annual proceeds altogether reach NT$3 billion (US$93,75 million) in the Taiwanese and Chinese market, adding the Taiwan market's revenue is around NT$2 billion (US$62.5 million) per year. UB Group has established furniture factories in Thailand, Taiwan and China.
UB Express, under the UB Group, was established in 1998. It primarily sells stationery in Taiwan, China and Southeast Asia.
Staples was established in 1986 and operates 1,786 stationery supermarkets worldwide.

The spokesman said that Staples, which sells stationery in 21 countries in the Americas and Europe, is aggressively expanding its market in Asia. He added that Staples registered a 12-fold increase in revenue in the Chinese market within 18 months.

In the coming month after UB Staples is established, the new company's management will work on integrating a "Staples style" of administration in terms of purchasing, services, management and logistics, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES SPEEDY PASSAGE OF PENDING LEGISLATION AFTER RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for a "return to normal" and for ruling and opposition parties to engage in rational discussion on major bills related to the public's welfare after opposition attempts to recall him through a presidential recall motion failed on Tuesday.

The president made the appeal after the opposition-led motion failed to pass the legislature, with only 119 votes in favor of the recall, far short of the required two-thirds majority approval in the 221-seat legislature.

The embattled president said that because the opposition put the recall motion at the top of the agenda, major bills related to the public's welfare have yet to be reviewed since the extraordinary legislative session convened on June 13.
He urged all political parties to "return to rationality" after the recall vote and to speedily pass the pending legislation.

President Chen also said that whether he personally stays or leaves is unimportant, and that he respects the process and results of the recall motion as long as it adheres to the Constitution. He apologized to the public for the hefty social costs of the recall bid, which the opposition launched in response to a series of corruption allegations against Chen's family and close associates.
The president urged all parties to respect the results of the recall vote and to placate the most fervent supporters so that Taiwan can return to a "normal and tranquil state" soon.

As for ongoing judicial investigations into a series of corruption scandals -- which have implicated Chen's former deputy secretary-general and son-in-law -- the president urged faith in the nation's judicial system.
Let the judicial authorities uphold justice without interference, he urged.
He expressed concern that a social divide has deepened due to the recent political turmoil, which has seriously undermined internal unity and solidarity.
Expressing his desire to mend his ways, he also reaffirmed that he would contribute to Taiwan's solidarity by promoting inter-party consultation and cross-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FOLK FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF IN YILAN

TEXT.P: The 2006 Yilan International Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival is scheduled to kick off Saturday in Yilan county, with children's folkdance groups from over 20 countries showcasing their countries' folk dances.
A spokesman for the event said that two of the dance groups -- from Jordan and the Republic of Tuva -- are coming to Taiwan for the first time.
The festival is slated for July 1-Aug. 20 and will be held in two parks -- the Dongshan River Water Park, where has been held in past years, and the Wulao Scenic Area.

Organizers have included the Wulao Scenic Area in order to welcome a possible sudden increase in the number of visitors from northern Taiwan during weekends this year caused by the opening of the Peiyi Freeway linking the eastern Taiwan county with Taipei.
Admission during weekdays costs NT$350, rising to NT$450 during weekends. Visitors will be allowed entry to both parks with one ticket.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CITY COUNCILOR RELEASED ON BAIL BUT BARRED FROM LEAVING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court allowed a Taipei city councilor of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who has been implicated in several extortion cases to be released on NT$800,000 bail Tuesday, but barred him from leaving the country.

Public prosecutors interrogated Lo Tsung-sheng and two of his aides for 13 hours Monday after searching their residences and offices in response to complaints they had extorted money from a number of construction companies between the years 2002 and 2004.
The prosecution filed a request in court for Lo's detention on grounds the crime involved is a felony and that he should be prevented from colluding with witnesses.
However, the court ruled the witnesses in the cases are all "hostile witnesses," and that there should be no apprehension about Lo colluding with them.
The court allowed Lo to be released on NT$800,000 bail but prohibited him from leaving Taiwan.
Four construction companies have alleged they were forced to pay Lo millions of new Taiwan dollars so he would keep mum about their unlawful dumping of construction debris.

They claim that Lo and his aides used their access to files at the Maintenance Office of the city government's Department of Public Works to obtain information about which construction companies were found to have illegally dumped construction waste.
Lo and his aides would then allegedly demand money from the companies and threaten to blow the whistle on them if they did not cooperate.
According to the construction companies, Lo would accept the cash and pretend that he "borrowed" the money from them by writing a check to each of them, but the checks would always bounce.
The owners of the construction companies said they decided to tell prosecutors everything because they had had enough of Lo.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE REMAINS OPTION FOR KMT: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Calling a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet remains one of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) options to pressure President Chen Shui-bian to step down, but the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) need to further negotiate over when and under what conditions to do so, KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said Tuesday.

Pan made the remarks in response to PFP Chairman James Soong's urging that the two parties should launch a no-confidence vote at the Legislative Yuan as a follow-up move to keep the pressure on Chen after a "pan-blue alliance"-led motion to recall Chen failed to pass the Legislative Yuan.
Although a no-confidence vote requires the endorsement of only half of the 211 lawmakers, Pan said that "the possible consequences must be fully gauged in advance."
Stressing that the KMT and the PFP share the same stance -- that Chen must step down -- she said, however, that "a no-confidence vote is not being considered for the time being" by the KMT.

The KMT has no fear of facing a new legislature election which might be called by the president in the wake of a no-confidence vote, but the party must carefully weigh how to respond to Chen's naming of a new premier if he chooses not to dissolve the Legislative Yuan, Pan pointed out.
In addition, she said, accompanying measures have yet to be put in place for a new legislative election, which could also be a point of contention.

Responding to Pan's comments, PFP legislative caucus whip Lee Hung-jun said his party will continue to seek KMT lawmakers' cooperation in proposing a no-confidence vote at the Legislative Yuan so that a new legislative election can be held.

Believing the "pan-blue alliance" is sure to won a two-thirds majority in the new election, Lee said "A new legislature backed up by new public mandante can recall Chen successfully, " adding that "the PFP stands firm on its position of calling a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet, so as to push Chen to dissolve the Legislative Yuan and allow the various political parties to be examined by the public again."

Judging from Chen's statement issued following the recall vote result at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said that "Chen apparently fails to realize that the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers' decision to cast invalid votes is an indication that former President Lee Teng-hui -- the TSU's spiritual leader -- is no longer willing to back the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)."
The abstention of all 86 DPP lawmakers from the vote further underlines the fact that "the 119 votes cast were all in favor of Chen's recall," Lee claimed.
It is unnecessary for Chen to apologize to the people, and he should step down voluntarily to stabilize public order, Lee argued.

Although 89 KMT lawmakers and 23 PFP lawmakers, as well as one independent lawmaker and six from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union cast "yes" votes to demand Chen's ouster, the 119 votes still fell short of the legal threshold of 148 votes, or a two-thirds majority at the 211-member Legislative Yuan, denying the people the chance to decide the president's fate in a national referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR END TO POLITICAL FEUDING

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called for national reconciliation Tuesday after an opposition-led motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian failed to muster the two-thirds majority approval required for the measure to be put to a national referendum.
Lu issued a statement calling on ruling and opposition parties to stop political feuding, "inside and outside" the legislature.

She also called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to speed up "house-cleaning efforts" and ethical reform. The party's image has been tarnished by a spate of corruption scandals in which President Chen Shui-bian's senior aides and son-in-law are being investigated for suspected involvement.

The vice president then called on the public to engage in a national campaign for "blue sky, green grass, good Taiwan," referring to the DPP's green logo and main opposition Kuomintang's blue-based party flag.
She asked the opposition parties to "understand the ordinary person's true feelings" and to quickly pass law bills aimed at improving people's livelihoods.
She said she had intended to comfort the crowd gathering around the legislature as it voted on the historic recall motion but could not show up in person as she was not feeling well.

"My caring for people has not been affected in any way by my physical condition, " she said after her eye disease flared up again and she was further stricken by a sudden inflammation of disc nerves in her back.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG'S ENGLISH SIGNAGE TO BE REVISED IN ADVANCE OF WORLD GAMES

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Government has decided to correct and update all English translations of signage at 132 scenic spots in the southern port city as part of preparations for hosting the World Games in 2009.

Deputy Mayor Cheng Wen-lung, who is convener of a city committee formed to develop Kaohsiung's English living environment, said Tuesday that in addition to the changes, the committee is also considering standardizing the English translations of food names in the area as a way to help foreign athletes -- as well as the large number of foreign visitors who are expected at the upcoming World Games -- recognize Chinese and local cuisines.

A group of specialists from Taipei-based Studio Classroom, the second most popular English-teaching magazine in Taiwan, is serving the city government as a chief advisor in the English language in plans to update English translations on all of the city's key signage within one month.

In the "English translation/integration" program, Cheng said the city will be described as "Taiwan's Maritime Capital" instead of "Ocean Capital, " while the park called "Urban Spotlight" will be renamed "The Urban Spotlight Arcade," and "Birthday Park" will become "Zodiac Park."
Other new translations for scenic spots include "Lianchihtan" for a popular lotus pond and the "Spring & Autumn Pagodas" in the Tzuoyi district.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, decreasing NT$0.065 to close at NT$32.664.
A total of US$725 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.729 and hit a low of NT$32.635.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOWS TO SLASH PREFERENTIAL TREATMENT FOR RETIRED PRESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vowed Tuesday that they will introduce legislation to slash the allowance for retired presidents and vice presidents by about 50 percent.

Legislator Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT's legislative caucus, said that before the 18-day extra legislative session ends June 30, the KMT will try to pass an amendment to the current Statute Governing Preferential Treatment for Retired Presidents and Vice Presidents.
According to her, the amendment would reduce the annual allowance for a retired president -- paid in 12 monthly installments -- by half to about NT$230,000 (US$7,043) per month.

The measure is apparently intended as retaliation to the collective abstention from voting by the 86 legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

The recall motion was defeated, although 119 Legislative Yuan members voted "yes, " including the 89 KMT legislators and 23 People First Party legislators -- well short of the two-thirds majority required to pass the motion and refer the issue to a national referendum.
The KMT and the PFP want to recall Chen because they claim that with his senior aides and family members involved in a series of corruption scandals, he is no longer fit to govern the nation.

Chen is to retire in 2008 after serving the remaining two years of his second four-year term. Opposition legislators have complained that with his abysmal performance as president, Chen does not deserve a pension three times that of a retired U.S president for the rest of his life.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 34 points to close at 6,515, with 53,268 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August gained 25 points to finish at 6,434, with 526 contracts traded, while September futures rose 34 points to close at 6,420, with 82 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 28 points to close at 6,413, with 67 contracts traded, while March futures lost 23 points to finish at 6,355, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,481 for July, 6,409 for August, 6,386 for September, 6,385 for December and 6,378 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

July TE futures moved up 1.6 points to close at 272.1, with 6,070 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 1.25 points to finish at 269.8, with 34 contract transactions. September TE futures decreased 1.45 points to end at 268.7, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.
July TF futures rose 4.4 points to finish at 947, with 3,226 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures gained 1.2 points to close at 933.2, with 20 contracts traded.
September TF futures moved up four points to finish at 934.8, with 17 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA KICKS OFF 'TAIWAN BIOBANK'

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica will begin the second stage of an operation to construct a "Taiwan Biobank" next year, collecting biological samples and health information from 15,000 residents in Miaoli, Chiayi and Hualien counties, an Academia Sinica senior researcher said Tuesday.

According to Academia Sinica, the first stage -- scheduled from August 2005 to July 2006 -- should collect samples from 1,000 people to evaluate the feasibility of the whole project. However, due to some delays in the review process, the 1,000 samples have yet to be gathered.

The biobank -- constructed and operated by the Biomedical Science Institute of Academia Sinica -- starts with 15,000 initial volunteers, with the hope that a maximum of 200,000 entries will eventually be gathered.

The official said the biobank, based on a pool of native genes, aims to run mass-scale, cross-generation studies to understand the interconnections between Taiwanese and the local environment, enhancing the efficacy of disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment.

He said that although a dozen countries -- such as Japan, the United States, Canada, Sweden, the United Kingdom and Singapore -- have already established similar biobanks, the study results are confined to specific groups of people and are not necessarily applicable to Taiwanese, hence the need for the local operation.

In response to several ethical issues raised by local non-governmental organizations, the official claimed that Academia Sinica values the protection of privacy and human rights before all else, adding that the biobank will not be initialed if there are any doubts among the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ENCOURAGES INVESTMENT IN THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is encouraging Taiwanese businesspeople to take part in a presentation on the Dominican Republic's investment environment, to be moderated by its president Leonel Fernandez at the Grand Hotel in Taipei Wednesday.
The head of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, Cho Shih-chao, said bilateral trade between Taiwan and the Dominican Republic totaled US$95 million last year.

Cho added that the Dominican Republic enjoys trade privileges with the United States and customs privileges with the European Union, which may be helpful to Taiwanese investors who manufacture and export from that country.
Officials of the Collins Group of Companies, a Taiwanese group that already invests in the Dominican Republic, will share their experience with participants at the event.
Taiwan primarily imports metal scrap from the Dominican Republic, and exports automobile accessories and fabrics to the island nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUST STORMS INCREASE AMOUNT OF AIRBORNE BACTERIA: EPA

TEXT.P: The amount of bacteria and fungal spores in the atmosphere tend to increase by at least six times whenever a dust storm hits Taiwan, according to the results of a study released Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).

Every year during the period between January and May, Taiwan is susceptible to dust storms originating in the desert region of northern China, which worsens the air quality and becomes a major source of allergies.

In March and April, the EPA sampled and tested dust in the air of Wanli, Taipei County -- the first place that the dust storms normally affect -- and found that the amount of bacteria and fungal spores was five to six times higher compared with when there are no dust storms and that the amount of spores was 20 times that of bacteria, EPA officials said.

According to Yen Jung-hua, an associate research fellow at the EPA's Environmental Analysis Laboratory, six to 12 additional kinds of bacteria and fungal spores were discovered during the dust storm period, they said.
The EPA said these microorganisms are able to survive because the coverage by thick dust clouds significantly reduces their exposure to ultraviolet rays.

Hung Wen-tzung, a section chief at the Environmental Analysis Laboratory, said it requires further observation to see if the increase in the amount of bacteria and fungal spores in the atmosphere has any direct impact on human health.
Hung said the EPA is also planning to study the possibility of viruses being transmitted via dust storms.

However, unlike fungal spores, viruses die in a short period of time after leaving their hosts, which leaves little chance of viruses such as the bird flu virus to invade Taiwan via dust storms, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS TO VISIT U.S. TO INSPECT BEEF CATTLE PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: A legislative committee reviewing the government's policy on U.S. beef imports decided Tuesday to send a delegation to the United States in late July to inspect the raising, slaughtering and exporting processes of beef cattle.

The committee will request that the Department of Health provide the committee with written materials related to the creation of the policy and has invited Hsieh Hsien-tang, a research fellow from the National Health Research Institutes, to brief the committee on mad cow disease.
In addition, the committee will hire experts to serve as consultants to assist with the review.
The discovery of bone fragments in a shipment to Taiwan in April has raised doubts over the government's decision to reopen its market to U.S. beef.
Taiwan banned beef imports from the United States in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single case of mad cow disease.

In April 2005, Taiwan lifted the import ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, but again suspended American beef imports June 25 that same year after a second case of mad cow disease was confirmed in the U.S. earlier that month.
The second ban was lifted on Jan. 25, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITAL CITIES CONVENTION SET FOR JUNE 28-30 IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Digital Cities Convention Taipei will be held June 28-30 in the capital city, officials said Tuesday.
The event is being co-organized by the Taipei city government and the Wireless Internet Institute (W2i) , an organization promoting global digitization.

Participants in the convention will include top executives of Taiwan and foreign technological firms, chiefs of local governments and mayors of digital cities from other countries, as well as experts and academics on related issues, according to city government officials.

Themes to be explored during the conference will include broadband policies and regulatory reform, public application services with the ultimate goal of bridging the digital divide, wireless infrastructure and e-government efficiency, they said
At the close of the convention, representatives from various cities in Taiwan and other countries will sign a digital cities declaration, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST INTERNATIONAL STREET DANCE COMPETITION

TEXT.P: An international street dance competition will be held next month in Taiwan, with amateur dance lovers from across the world vying for a cash prize of U$$10,000 -- the highest of its kind to be offered in Taiwan, organizers announced Tuesday.

The first-round qualifiers will be selected at a Kending wharf in southern Pingtung County from July 8, while the final qualifier is set to be held at Fishermen's Wharf in Tamshui in northern Taipei County from June 14, with the champion to be decided June 15, according to the organizers.
The competition will be divided into two categories -- Hip Hop and B-Boy -- and dancers from Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan have applied to compete.

Street dance has gained increasing popularity in Taiwan since 1994, in particular on campuses and among youths, with many students in local high schools and universities setting up clubs dedicated to street dance.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL PARTY CREATES BIG WAVE IN TAIWAN POLITICSBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: James Soong, leader of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , hurled himself into another political battle Tuesday by calling for a no-confidence motion against the government after the opposition "pan-blue alliance" failed to muster two-thirds of the legislative votes needed to call a referendum to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

The PFP's 23 lawmakers joined 89 Kuomintang (KMT) colleagues in the "pan-blue alliance" in the historic vote. Even though the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union and independents stood on their side, the resulting 119 ballots fell far short of the 148 threshold in the 221-seat Legislative Yuan needed to put the motion to a national referendum.

Soong appears to be betting his political future on continuing to creating waves in Taiwan politics, calculating that a toppled Cabinet would trigger a re-election of the legislature in which the opposition could win more than two-thirds of the 113 seats up for grabs, with which it could launch another motion to recall Chen.

The KMT has been forced to follow his lead in the just-ended "first phase" recall campaign because that was what the people wanted -- a chance for the ruling DPP to separate itself from the president, whose credibility is very much in doubt after his senior aides and son-in-law have been investigated on corruption charges, Soong claims.

Soong claims that he did not "kidnap" the KMT into voting for the recall motion. Now that it has failed in the legislature because of the ruling DPP's boycott, the DPP government should be toppled for endorsing a scandal-ridden president, he said.

On the other hand, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was downplaying the urgency of filing a no-confidence vote against Premier Su Tseng-chang, although he did not rule out the possibility altogether, choosing instead to return to his "modest and rational" middle-of-the-road policy line.

For this flip-flop, Ma has been criticized for "being not bold enough and lacking in action ability, " as new polls indicate a drop of 19 percentage points in his support rating. But he knows the recall campaign missed support from the DPP legislators because Chen, seeing not enough evidence to implicate him and his wife, was able to portray it as an opposition attempt to "seize power" from his "pro-Taiwan regime."

Ma called for a "truce" in political feuding, in tune, ironically, with the president's overture to his political rivals. After months of political shouting and street rallies, people do need a good rest now, both sides claim.

But KMT insiders claim this would be a chance to "wait for the DPP rebels who want to save the party to demand Chen's head" -- when the opposition will be given more room for maneuvering against the president.

A seemingly unperturbed Chen was already waiting for the "reconciliation" game to start, throwing out olive branches for "political consultation" at home and even "peace talks" with China, Taiwan's arch-rival. Ma has turned down an invitation from DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun for the party leaders to meet.

Ma could ignore the DPP's "peace" offer, but he will run into trouble if he ignores the PFP's insistence on launching a no-confidence motion on a government that "cannot tell the difference between a questionable leader and its need to govern."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG LITTLE LEAGUERS TO PLAY IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: A baseball team of the Feng Nien Primary School in Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, will go to Hong Kong in the second half of July to compete for the right to represent the Asia-Pacific region in the 2006 Little League Baseball World Series at Williamsport in Pennsylvania.
The team will play against other Little League teams from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Guam and the Philippines.
The Little Leaguers of the Feng Nien Primary School will be led by Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-cheng on their Hong Kong trip.

The team lost 5-14 to Kaohsiung County in a double-elimination tournament that began June 22 among 11 cities and counties, but staged a comeback from the losers bracket to grab the Taiwan Little League championship by defeating Kaohsiung County 9-4. Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: SHORTAGE OF FUNDS FOR HEALTH INSURANCE MUST BE SOLVED BY OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The shortage of funds for the National Health Insurance program must be solved by October when the government's last subsidies to the program run out, Vice Health Minister Chen Shih-chung warned Tuesday.

Chen said the program's safe reserve fund will be used up by the end of June, although the program can keep operating for another three months by a government grant expected to be available by the end of July.
He estimated that the reserve fund for the program will plunge to minus NT$1.5 billion by the end of this year.

As for a NT$20 billion-odd premium owed by the two municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung to the program, Chen said the National Health Insurance Bureau, which runs the program, can circumvent it by borrowing money from banks on mortgage of its credit to the two cities.
Citing a report presented by the bureau to the Legislative Yuan, Chen said the outstanding loan of the bureau stands at between NT$70 billion and NT$90 billion every month.

The key to replenishing the program's funds lies in raising the premiums or the insured person's share of payment for medical treatment, or hiking the ceiling premium for government employers, Chen said.

He refused to speculate on which of the three ways the Department of Health and the National Health Insurance Bureau might choose, saying only that any decision will have to be taken before the end of October.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 28, or the third day of the sixth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1776: British forces are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: A peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the victorious allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Treat of Versailles because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against the Chinese communists.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from Cominform at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the U.S. government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the ROC Navy and Air Force.
1950: Gen. Douglas McArthur, commander of the Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of the 17-year-old soccer player Pele, whose real name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.
1970: U.S. troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1976: Fifty-one American scholars, researchers, teachers and students arrive in Taipei for a five-week Seminar on China Studies.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives H.A.E. Scheels, permanent honorary vice president of the International Badminton Federation.
1977: Ma Chi-chuang, board chairman of the China Steel Corp., puts a torch to the blast furnace of the company's new Kaohsiung steel plant to signify the start of steel making at the plant.
1979: The ROC government approves two new appointments proposed by the Kuomintang's Central Committee, naming H.K. Yang, political vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Africa, and Ding Mou-shih, administrative vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Korea.
1981: To promote cultural communication and economic relations, the Sino-Nigerian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus becomes the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
1999: The 1999 International Seminar on the Protection of Clean Coasts opens in Kaohsiung with more than 100 experts from home and abroad attending.
2000: Just as scientists from around the world have finished the first big step toward mapping the human genome, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces that Taiwan will establish its own genetic research center within one year.
2001: The National Policy Foundation, an opposition Kuomintang think tank, unveils new policy guidelines featuring a "confederation" with Beijing and a "double economic triangle" covering Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention -- that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious."
