DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES PASSAGE OF NT$3.8 TRILLION WORTH OF BUDGET BILLS SOON

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang on Wednesday urged the Legislative Yuan to pass major budgets worth a total of NT$3.8 trillion (US$116.56 billion) before the current extraordinary session ends June 30.

Su was referring to the NT$3.7 trillion budget for state-owned enterprises, NT$100.7 billion for major infrastructure projects, and NT$44.9 billion for flood-prevention works, including the dredging of Shihmen Reservoir and its water collection areas in northern Taiwan.

He said the budgets should have been passed in the last legislative session which ended in late May, pointing out that this is the reason why the Executive Yuan had requested the holding of an extraordinary legislative session, which began June 13.

Noting that the month-long political turmoil triggered by the opposition-initiated recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian came to an end Tuesday, with the motion failing to gain the required support of two-thirds of all lawmakers in a legislative vote, Su said the nation must "return to the normal."
With the recall vote over, the premier said, the public expects the government to "get down to the real work at hand."

Su said he hopes the legislature will pass the budgets as failure to do so would mean the gross domestic product would be cut by NT$20 billion, economic growth would be cut by 0.15 percent and the unemployment rate would rise by 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BALTIMORE COUNTIES ESTABLISH SISTERHOOD TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Baltimore, Maryland, June 27 (CNA) (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's northern county of Taipei established sisterhood ties with Baltimore County in the U.S. state of Maryland Tuesday to foster closer trade, economic and cultural exchanges between the two counties.
Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and Baltimore County Executive Jim Smith jointly inked the sisterhood agreement at a ceremony held at the Baltimore county office.

Chou is leading a 13-member Taipei County official trade promotion delegation to the United States. The delegation, comprised of nine Taipei County councilors and several county government officials, arrived in New York June 22 for the first leg of its U.S. visit.

Earlier in the day, Chris Foster, deputy secretary of the state of Maryland, met with Chou and his group. Foster said the delegation's visit to the United States will definitely boost Taipei County's image and exchanges with the rest of the world.
Foster said that he and Maryland Governor Robert Ehrlich will pay a visit to Taiwan in September and that their itinerary will include a stop at the Academia Sinica.
Before arriving at the Baltimore County office, Chou and his group visited Baltimore City where municipal authorities presented honorary citizenship certificates to all the members of the delegation.
Later in the day, Chou and his party met with members of the Taiwanese expatriate community as well as Chinese language media outlets operating in the Washington, D.C. area at a dinner gathering.
During the dinner, Chou remarked that he remains committed to his campaign promise to seek the merger of Taipei County and Taipei City.

Chou said the main aims of the delegation's current visit in the United States are boosting Taipei County's image, attracting U.S. enterprises and U.S.-based Taiwanese businesses to invest in his county, and meeting with and offering greetings to Taiwan expatriates in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL TURMOIL WON'T IMPACT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY: VICE MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 27 (CNA) (By J.J. Hwang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long expressed confidence Tuesday in the outlook for Taiwan's economy despite the recent political turmoil marked by the opposition-backed campaign to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Speaking during a luncheon with a group of Taiwanese businesspeople in the United Kingdom, the vice minister said that the chaotic situation in Taiwan's politics is an inevitable phenomenon in the process of democratization and that Taiwan's democratic development has been smooth compared with that of other countries.
Although the turmoil has caused fluctuations in the financial market, the fundamentals of Taiwan's economy remain sound, Chen said.

Chen noted that private sector investment, which is a major force in Taiwan's economic development, was valued at NT$510 billion (US$15.64 billion) between January and May, accounting for 57 percent of the target amount set for this year.
He said that Taiwan's exports and imports have risen 12.2 percent and 12.9 percent, respectively, while the unemployment rate for the first four months of this year dropped to 3.8 percent.
Chen said Taiwan's economic growth rate is expected to reach at least 4 percent, which he said is better than that of Europe and Japan.

To prevent the hollowing out of Taiwan's economy following the exodus of local industries, the government has continued to introduce new industries into Taiwan, including the energy conservation and renewable energy industries, he said.

Chen said the government welcomes the return of Taiwanese businesspeople and has made available a NT$200 billion financing program to serve their needs, with the interest rate registering below 3.6 percent for medium-term and long-term loans.
Also, investors will enjoy preferential tax rates, while the import of production facilities by investors will also enjoy preferential tariff treatment, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGREEMENTS REACHED AT ANNUAL TAIWAN BRITAIN BUSINESS COUNCIL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 27, (CNA) (By J.J. Hwang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Britain Business Council (TBBC) held its eighth annual meeting in Cambridge, England Tuesday, with a 44-member Taiwan business delegation headed by Taiwan Cement Corp. Chairman Leslie Koo attending the gathering.

Taiwanese and British entrepreneurs reached many agreements aimed at enhancing cooperation and exchanges during the one-day meeting, including working to set up a Web site to boost mutual exchanges, assisting British pharmaceutical companies to promote their new drugs in Taiwan, and launching a cooperative effort to bid for construction projects in the Middle East, according to the council.
In an interview with CNA, Koo indicated that biotechnology, telecommunications technology, and infrastructure projects were three major topics of discussion during the meeting.

Koo said many British businesses have shown great interest in cooperating with their Taiwanese counterparts in investing in China, the largest market in Asia, because Taiwanese businesses know the Chinese market well and have a lot of experience investing there.

British businesses are also interested in investing in projects to develop the areas surrounding Taiwan's high speed railway stations in Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi and Tainan, according to John Yu, chairman and CEO of Taiwan-based CTCI Corp.
Yu praised British businesses' capability in transportation construction, citing as an example the successful transformation of Canary Wharf in London into a modern financial center.

Taiwan's Representative to Britain Edgar Lin, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and Michael Reilly, director general of the British Trade and Cultural Office, also attended the meeting.
The annual TBBC meeting is considered the most important event for those interested in forming business alliances between Taiwan and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO STEP UP CRACKDOWN ON CRIME: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that under a revised criminal code that will take effect July 1, the government will step up its crackdown on repeat offenders of serious crimes.

The premier made the remarks while presiding over a weekly meeting of the Executive Yuan, noting that several new measures will take effect July 1 and that related government agencies should step up the publicity campaign.

He said that from July 1, a "three strikes" law patterned on that adopted by many U.S. states will take effect. Anyone convicted of manslaughter, robbery, kidnapping or other felonies on three or more separate occasions will not be eligible for parole, which he said should help deter crime and improve law and order.
He instructed the Ministry of Justice to publicize the message, lest people commit crimes without knowing of the consequences.
The maximum prison sentence will also be raised to 30 years from the current 20 years, the premier said.

The stated rationale for the "three strikes" law is that the automatic and lengthy imprisonment of individuals who commit more than two felonies is justified on the basis that repeat offenders pose a threat to public safety.
On electricity rate hikes scheduled for July 1, Su said the new measure will not affect families, small shops, elementary schools or junior high schools that use less than 330 kw/h per month.

Other new measures will also be put into practice out of concern for energy conservation or cost efficiency, Su said, urging related government agencies to step up their publicity drives for the various measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PREFERENCES AFFECT STOCK INVESTORS' DECISIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: The trading decisions of Taiwan's stock investors are related to their political preferences, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

While 60 percent of respondents supporting the "pan-green camp" said they would reduce the number of shares they own if the Legislative Yuan adopted a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, more than 50 percent of respondents supporting the "pan-blue alliance" said they would do the opposite if the motion were adopted.

The bimonthly "Taiwan investor sentiment index" survey was conducted by Shih Hsin University in cooperation with the magazine Business Today on 1,074 stock investors from June 20-22. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

The survey shows that the investor sentiment index plunged to -72.2, down 69.9 points from the previous survey, with the individual index falling 36.5 points to -16.9 and the economic index declining 33.4 points to -55.3.
The fall in investor sentiment is the second largest since an October 2005 survey conducted ahead of the "three-in-one" local elections, when the index plummeted 70.5 points.

The survey indicates that "pan-blue" investors were even more pessimistic about the presidential recall motion than when the "pan-blue" candidates were defeated in the 2004 presidential election, with their sentiment index being 77 points lower.

If the recall motion were adopted, "pan-green" investors think that it would facilitate the passage of the long-stalled arms procurement package from the United States and a relaxation of the country's policy toward China, while "pan-blue" investors think that it would help achieve clean politics, social justice and judicial impartiality.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Ronaldo's 15-goal record.
Brazilian striker Ronaldo wrote himself into the history books yesterday when he became the World Cup's all-time top scorer with his 15th goal.
The Lianhe Zaobao: One smart card for all e-payments will be realized in two or three years.
Singapore's InfoComm Development Authority is working on a project together with industry players like the Land Transport Authority, NETs and EZ Link to produce a card for all e-payments, and the authority hope that can be realized in two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Northern League angry with results of referendum.
The Northern League, which is seeking the federalism, was angry with the results of the June 25-26 referendum, in which Italians rejected overwhelmingly a controversial constitutional reform drawn up by former premier Silvio Berlusconi's government. The Northern formed part of Berlusconi's government and supported staunchly the reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS YET TO DETERMINE WHETHER TO SUBPOENA FIRST LADY

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Prosecutor's Office has yet to decide whether to subpoena first lady Wu Shu-jen in the on-going investigation into an alleged gift voucher scandal, a prosecutor said Wednesday.

Prosecutor Lin Pang-liang of the Taipei District Court denied categorically a media report that the Taipei prosecutors are subpoenaing medical professional Huang Fang-yen, a close friend of the first family, Wednesday as a witness in the alleged Sogo Department Store gift voucher scandal case involving the first lady, and that the prosecutors will summon Wu "secretly" June 30 for questioning as another witness.

Lin said that Huang, a deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Hospital in Taipei, will be subpoenaed June 30 as originally scheduled and that the prosecutors will decide in later days whether to subpoena Wu depending on how the case unfolds.

Lin noted that the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office has no plan at present to summon the first lady, adding that even if it is determined that Wu should be subpoenaed to help in the probe, her health condition will be an important factor in considerations by the prosecutors.

Meanwhile, according to Lin, the prosecutors have accelerated collection of information and evidence to pave the way for questioning of Huang, who is alleged to have passed Wu a huge amount of Sogo Department Store gift vouchers given by a businessman to facilitate his efforts to gain ownership of the department store.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO OFFER EDUCATION SUBSIDY TO TRY TO BOOST BIRTH RATES

TEXT.P: Taipei City will begin from the second academic semester in 2006 to offer an education subsidy of NT$500 (US$15) per semester to each public elementary school student in the city who is the third child or upward in a family, a municipal official said Wednesday.

The measure was adopted by the city government Tuesday as part of efforts to encourage citizens to have children as the birth rate has been dropping in the capital city over the last several years, Director of Education Wu Ching-ji said, noting that his department has planned a budget worth NT$12 million for the upcoming subsidization next year.

To boost the birth rate, initiatives have also been proposed by the city's social affairs bureau and labor department, including a plan to allow the third child or upward in a family to be given priority to attend public pre-schools, as well as a proposal to provide such children aged under six with medical subsidies in a form of reduced registration fees at hospitals and local clinics.

Health officials indicated that a budget totalling more than NT$9 million has been planned for the proposed medical subsidies in 2007 and that the proposal will be carried out Jan. 1, 2007, if the city council approves the budget in the upcoming six months.

A survey conducted by the city government showed that "tax cut" is the most attractive initiative to encourage most citizens to bear more than one child, with 37.7 percent of those surveyed expressing their willingness to have more than one child if they are entitled to such preferential tax treatment.

The education subsidies raises the interest of 5.8 percent of the polled citizens to bear a third child, while the priority right to enter public pre-schools and kindergartens raises the interest of 12.1 percent of the surveyed to have more children.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHECKING REPORT ON VATICAN-CHINA TALKS ON FORGING DIPLOMATIC TIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is checking a report that the Vatican is engaging in secret talks with China on the establishment of diplomatic relations, a MOFA official said Wednesday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu noted that it is a well-known fact that Beijing and the Holy See have been maintaining interaction for years.

Lu was responding to a report published Tuesday by the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post that a high-level Vatican delegation is currently on a visit in Beijing and is likely to discuss issues concerning the establishment of diplomatic relations.
The paper said this is the first high-level Vatican delegation to visit China since 2000.

China has put forth several conditions on the establishment of diplomatic ties with the Vatican, including that it must not interfere with China's internal affairs and must sever diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The matter is at a standstill because the Vatican has refused to compromise on some of these conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI SEEKING SUPPORT TO TURN OLD PRISON INTO MUSEUM

TEXT.P: Chiayi Mayor Huang Ming-hui will solicit central government support for a plan to turn an old prison in the southern city into a prison museum when she attends a meeting of city and county chiefs in southern Taiwan later this week.
The central government is expected to send officials to attend the meeting of eight chiefs, to be held in Luokuei, Tainan County.

Huang, a legislator-turned-mayor who is the only local chief among the eight from the opposition Kuomintang, noted that the Ministry of the Interior designated the old prison as a national historical relic in 2005, making it Chiayi's only national historical relic. The other seven chiefs are from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
She said the prison, completed in 1922 when Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule, has a distinctive architectural style.

The Chiayi city government has applied to the Ministry of Justice for a subsidy of NT$310 million (US$9.48 million) to turn the old prison into a museum by 2009 to keep historial documents concerning Taiwan's prison development, as well as house exhibits of prison life in several Asian countries.

In Friday's meeting, Huang said she will also propose that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications provide NT$200 million as an initial sum "to make Chiayi a transshipment center, " so that passengers traveling to and from Chiayi can have easy access to buses and railways, including the high-speed railway and the tourist railway to Alishan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LENOVO COMPUTER MOVES INTO TAIPEI 101

TEXT.P: Lenovo Group Ltd., which acquired IBM's personal computer business last year, set up a new office and flagship store Wednesday in Taipei 101, the world's tallest office building.

Lenovo Taiwan General Manager Huang Wei-teh said the opening of its largest flagship store in Asia outside of China symbolizes its brand value as the company tries to give consumers a new impression of Lenovo products.
Ravi Marwaha, Lenovo vice president for global operations and chief executive officer for Asia, cut the ribbon for the Taipei store.
He said opening a store in the world's tallest office tower will help the company's efforts to boost the image of its products as well as staff morale.
"This is also an indication that Lenovo is determined to increase its presence in Taiwan and work harder to expand its market here, " Marwaha said.
Lenovo Taiwan was established in August last year, three months after the Chinese computer giant took over IBM's personal computer arm.
Huang said Lenovo products did not sell well in the Taiwan market in the first two quarters of this year but he predicted that sales will pick up in the third quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Moscow, June 28 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Treaty to Replace START Sought President Vladimir Putin called on Russia and the United States on Tuesday to negotiate a new nuclear-arms treaty and urged the Russian diplomatic corps to bolster the nation's global prominence while avoiding confrontation. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 31.46 points to close at 6,540.93.
The bourse opened at 6,500.38 and fluctuated between 6,540.93 and 6,481.65 during trading. A total of 2.82 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.78 billion (US$2.38 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by cement stocks and foodstuff issues both at 0.2 percent, and construction issues at 0.1 percent.

The four other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 580 to 315, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD BLAMED FOR NO PASSAGE OF KEY BILLS AT LEGISLATURE: DPP

TEXT.P: A legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blamed main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday for failing to push key bills to pass an extra legislative session that will end June 30.

Ker Chien-ming claimed that Ma must be held accountable for the situation and ascribed the political upheaval to Ma's efforts to recall President Chen Shui-bian -- the only thing that the extra legislative session has dealt with up to now since it opened June 20.
According to Ker, the launch of the recall motion to unseat Chen was the product of an alignment between what he called an "incapable" Ma and a "tricky" People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

Commenting on a Soong's insistence that the PFP will continue to collaborate with the KMT to call a no-confidence vote at the Legislative Yuan to topple the Cabinet as a follow-up to pressure Chen to step down, Ker said that it was only "empty talk," given that the PFP only holds 21 seats at the legislature.

Ker claimed that Ma has been caught in a dilemma after being "driven by Soong" to make public a three-point set of conditions for initiating a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet, and cited KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan as saying that "there has been enough of this farce" -- referring to the two parties' thwarted efforts to boot out Chen in the Tuesday legislative recall vote.
"Now that polarized confrontation brought up by the recall motion has come to an end, it is time for all the political party leaders to hold dialogue and reconcile," he urged.

Regarding a news report that Ma met Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Lai Hsing-yuan in secret last week prior to the failed presidential recall vote, Ker said that he has confidence in the TSU and added that there is "no need to overreact to an groundless report."

Former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader," was reported to have lost faith in the DPP government, which has always labeled itself as a "clean and indigenous regime" dedicated to promoting a distinctive identity for Taiwan and the people's welfare.

Ker said that he respected the 12 TSU lawmakers' decision to cast invalid votes in Tuesday's vote because each political party has to weigh its future development. "But the TSU was firmly against launching the presidential recall vote," he argued.
The DPP and the TSU form the "pan-green camp" as rivals to the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP.

The vote to recall Chen initiated by the "pan-blue alliance" over a spate of corruption allegations implicating his family members and close aides failed at the 221-member Legislative Yuan when only 119 votes were cast in favor of Chen's recall, which would have required a two-thirds majority approval in order to have the recall motion put to a national referendum.
All 86 DPP lawmakers boycotted the vote.
The different moves by the TSU and the DPP is seen by some as a sign that the "pan-green camp" has split out of competition to vie for the support of pro-independence activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR-RAID DRILL PARALLELS HAN KUANG EXERCISE: MND

TEXT.P: The No. 29 Wan An air-raid drill for northern Taiwan is scheduled to be held early July 6, breaking the norm of holding the drills in the afternoon, a Ministry of National Defense spokesman said Wednesday.
Wu Chi-fang said the 30-minute drill is scheduled to begin at 5 a.m., when air-raid sirens will sound in cities and counties north of Hsinchu.
Wu explained that the Defense Ministry decided to hold the drill in the early morning to parallel the ongoing Han Kuang Exercise, some of which involves live-ammunition firing.

The moving forward of the Wan An air-raid drill schedule is also based on a scenario that the Chinese People's Liberation Army launches a surprise attack on Taiwan in the early morning rather than later in the day, Wu said.

Wu appealed to the public not to be angry about the possible inconveniences that the early morning air-raid drill might cause, pointing out that the enemy will not invade Taiwan suddenly at a time that would be "convenient" for anybody.
The spokesman appealed to the public to take complementary measures on the early morning air-raid drill July 6, saying that people "should be prepared for danger in times of peace."

Wu said the Defense Ministry has communicated with local governments in advance over the rescheduling of the drill. For example, he said, the celebrated fish market auction in Keelung will be closed that morning.

Traffic restrictions will be imposed in all areas of northern Taiwan during the drill, with pedestrians and drivers told to clear the streets and cars ordered to stop. Stores and shops will be told to close their doors, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISPOSABLE TABLEWARE BANNED IN GOVERNMENT RESTAURANTS

TEXT.P: From July 1, disposable tableware will be banned from restaurants at government offices as part of the government's policy to discourage the use of plastics, with school restaurants expected to also follow the program when the new semester begins in September.

The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday that cups, bowls, dishes, forks, lunch boxes, knives, chopsticks and spoons will not be permitted if they are made for "one time use only."
The EPA has estimated that the new policy will reduce 2,600 metric tons of disposal tableware waste per year.

First-time violators of the policy will be warned and repeat offenders will be fined between NT$1,200 and NT$6,000. Those who ignore orders to adhere to the policy will be fined every time they are found to be in violation, according to the EPA.
Also from July 1, gift sets of cakes, cosmetics, liquor and computer software will have to follow government-set standards in the use of plastics that set a limit on the amount of packaging allowed.
The restrictions will be expanded to cover processed food gift sets July 1 next year. Violators will be fined between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000, according to the EPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGHUA AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS TO BE SOLD IN BRUNEI

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government signed a letter of intent of cooperation with Brunei's First Emporium and Supermarket Group whereby agricultural products from the county will be sold in stores run by the group.
The group, which is one of the largest chains in Brunei, owns nine supermarkets.

Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said that through the agreement the county hopes to market products such as rice, pineapples and cabbages to Brunei, which will establish a channel of cooperation between Taiwan and the private sector of the Southeast Asian nation.
Cho noted that the Brunei retailer already imports fruit from Taichung County for sale in its supermarkets.

Lim Toh Yung, manager of First Emporium and Supermarket Group, said agricultural products from Changhua County have good market potential because of their high quality, and he predicted that the products will be popular among Brunei consumers.

According to Chiu Shih-ping, head of the county's agricultural bureau, representatives from the supermarket group have visited Changhua flower, dragon fruit, paddy and cabbage farms and will discuss export details with county government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Israeli Troops Enter Gaza; Bridges Are Hit
Israel sent troops into southern Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday, in an effort to prevent militants from moving a wounded Israeli soldier they abducted Sunday, Israeli Army officials said. Witnesses said Israeli troops had taken over the old Gaza airport and were heading toward Rafah on the road that marks the border between Gaza and Egypt, as Egyptian troops watched. The Israeli Army said the operation was limited to an effort to rescue the corporal and was not an attempt to reoccupy Gaza.
Wall Street Journal: Core Value, At Apple, Secrecy Complicates Life But Maintains Buzz
Apple Computer Inc. generates buzz for its new products by obsessively enforcing a strict secrecy policy. But the policy can sometimes leave partners, big customers and even employees in the dark. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., mostly keeps its plans for new products to itself. It rigidly compartmentalizes itself so that even its own employees don't find out about coming products. It has fired and later sued workers who leaked information about unannounced products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PREPARING ARTS FESTIVAL FOR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government is scheduled to kick off a one-month arts festival for children July 15, offering kids an opportunity to see all sorts of culture and art styles from different countries, as well as from all over Taiwan.

Liao Hsien-hao, chief of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, announced at a news conference Wednesday that "the world is by your side" is the theme of the seventh Children's Arts Festival, which will run through Aug. 12.

A "kid's passport" will be offered, Liao said, that will entitled the holder to a wide range of different benefits including discount admission to the special exhibitions, such as "Toys from Spain" at the National Museum of History, the Taipei Water Festival at Taipei Water Park, and "Round the World with Paper"at Suho Memorial Paper Museum.
This year, 35 popular museums and scenic spots in Taipei City, Taipei County and Yilan County are taking part in the festival.
On July 29, the "Taipei Children's Arts Day, " art and cultural facilities around the city and counties will open until 9 p.m., Liao said.

In addition, from July 15 there will be many popular domestic musical and children theater troupes, including the Ju Percussion Group, the Song Song Song Children's Puppet Theater and the Eyuan Puppet Theater, performing every evening at Taipei's Da-an Park and at the Songshan Tobacco Factory.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES 'LEGISLATIVE LETHARGY'

TEXT.P: A legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) denied Wednesday a claim by a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator that the legislature has become "lethargic."
Pan Wei-kang, secretary-general of the KMT's legislative caucus, told DPP lawmaker Ko Chien-ming to stop making false accusations against the opposition.

"If the DPP is sincere in reaching a consensus on major budget bills, then on Friday it should not try to boycott all other major bills being debated at the legislature and help pass them together, " she said.

Pan was responding to Ko's earlier accusation that the legislature's extra session has achieved nothing except a vote on the opposition-initiated motion to recall the president. If the session ends up without passing any bills, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should be held responsible, he charged.

Pan pointed out that all parties have agreed to pass two budget bills for flood-control projects, a government proposal to spend NT$500 billion over five years on various national development projects and a budget for state-owned enterprises by June 30.
She emphasized that negotiations over the bill on the budget for state-owned businesses were still going on that day, and questioned how this could be perceived as "legislative lethargy."

Pan said Ko had pledged to deal with all of the 14 bills put forward by the KMT during the extra session of the Legislative Yuan. The DPP should not boycott talks over these bills -- including an amendment for setting up direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait and another amendment on the statute governing the treatment and privileges of retired presidents and vice presidents.
She added that whichever party attempts to boycott the normal legislative process should be held accountable.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIALS SUPPORT CAUTIOUS ATTITUDE TOWARD NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION

TEXT.P: Two central standing committee members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday that they support KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's desire to maintain a cautious attitude toward proposing a no-confidence motion against Premier Su Tseng-chang and his Cabinet.
Lee Chi-chu and Wu Yu-sheng, who are also KMT legislators, made the remarks on the sidelines of a regular weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee.

Ma reaffirmed his cautious attitude toward a no-confidence motion, in contrast with the keen stance of James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, an ally of the KMT in the opposition "pan-blue alliance." Soong vowed to pursue the no-confidence motion after a recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian failed to pass a day earlier because only 119 legislators were in favor of the motion, far short of the required two-thirds in the 221-seat legislature.

Lee noted that if the no-confidence motion succeeds after getting the endorsement of half of the legislators, the president could either name a new premier to replace Su -- which would anger the ruling Democratic Progressive Party because Su represents the best hope of the party in the 2008 presidential election -- or dissolve the legislature to force a new election within three months.
In the latter case, she said the administration would be left in a vacuum, which would not be good for the nation.

The next legislature will face a new electoral system, which is said to be unfavorable to minority parties such as the PFP, as the number of seats will be halved to 113 and a "single constituency, and two votes" system will be adopted.

On Ma's approval rating slipped to less than 50 percent after the recall vote -- down from more than 60 percent in late March -- Lee said that any reforms will invoke different reactions, which she said is "nothing to worry about."
Wu said the recall motion has drawn criticism, has polarized the rivalry between the ruling and opposition parties, and needs to be reviewed to avoid similar faults at the next stage.

Wu also said the best timing to topple the Cabinet hinges not on the will of Ma or the determination of Soong, but on public opinion and the results of a probe into the series of corruption allegations that triggered the recall motion in the first place.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRIKES CONSIDERED TO DEMAND PRESIDENT'S OUSTER: PFP

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will continue holding activities and might consider calling on the public to stage strikes in markets, workplaces and on campuses to force President Chen Shui-bian to step down, PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang said Wednesday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, Lu said that the PFP agrees with the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) call for a return to a centrist party line after a presidential recall vote failed to clear the Legislative Yuan a day earlier. He argued, however, that this does not mean everything should be put on hold.

From now on, the PFP will join efforts with social activists to forge national consensus and promote a movement calling for Chen's ouster, in addition to moves made through debate in the legislature, Lu said, reiterating the PFP's stance that Chen should "behave himself" by voluntarily stepping down from the presidency.
He also claimed that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers' boycott of the Tuesday presidential recall vote "proves" that they acknowledge that Chen is corrupt.

The vote initiated by the KMT and the PFP to remove Chen over a string of corruption allegations involving his family members and close aides failed at the Legislative Yuan due to the lack of support from the "pan-green" lawmakers of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

A total of 119 votes were cast in favor of Chen's recall, but the number fell short of a two-thirds majority approval to put the vote to a national referendum to allow the people to decide Chen's fate.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, TSU DENY THEY HAD SECRET CONTACT BEFORE RECALL VOTE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's ally in the "pan-green camp" -- and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) both denied Wednesday that the two parties had a secret contact before Tuesday's vote in the legislature on a motion to recall president Chen Shui-bian.

The two parties issued the denials in separate news conferences in reaction to reports that TSU Legislator Lai Hsing-yuan and Chang Jung-feng, vice president of Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research, met with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou secretly for one hour last week and relayed a message from former President Lee Teng-hui, the "spiritual leader" of the TSU.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said she did not know why there was rumor of a secret TSU-KMT meeting and stressed that the KMT had made no contact with the TSU prior to the recall vote.
TSU Secretary-General Lo Chih-ming said he suspected it was probably started by DPP members who were unhappy about the 12 TSU legislators who cast invalid ballots in the recall vote.
Lo declined to say whether the TSU would work with the KMT to topple the Cabinet on the condition that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng be named the next premier.
Asked to comment, Wang said the reports were mere conjecture and refused to comment on hypothetical questions.
Wang said he will instead focus his attention on issues on the legislative agenda.

The recall motion, prompted by a series of corruption scandals implicating the president's senior officials and family members, was defeated because the vote fell short of the two-thirds majority required for its passage.

Although the victory could provide the president with temporary relief from pressure to step down, political analysts claimed that the vote result was a "disgrace" for him because none of the 221 Legislative Yuan members voted against the motion, while 119 legislators -- more than half -- voted "yes," with 14 invalid votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT IN TUNE WITH PFP OVER NO-CONFIDENCE DRIVE: KMT WHIP

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is in tune with its ally, the People First Party (PFP), in its determination to unseat President Chen Shui-bian "in order to save the country from meeting its doomsday because of a corrupt leadership, " a KMT party whip said Wednesday.

KMT legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang denied that the KMT is out of tune with the PFP over the plan to recall Chen and an ensuing no-confidence motion against his administration after the recall motion failed the previous day.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has been pushing for Chen's recall, believing that the president's credibility is in tatters as a result of his senior aides and son-in-law being investigated on corruption charges.

Pan reiterated that the KMT is maintaining close communications with the PFP decision makers and will jointly decide "in the shortest possible period" on when to launch a no-confidence motion in the "most workable fashion" to topple the Cabinet now that the "pan-blues" have failed to muster the two-thirds of the legislative votes needed to call a referendum to recall the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BALLROOM DANCE CHAMPIONSHIP TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: More than 500 professional and amateur dancers from 13 countries will take part in an international ballroom dance competition in Taipei next month, vying for cash prizes totaling NT$600,000 (US$18,400).

Chou Shou-hsun, a lawmaker and honorary chairman of the ROC International Dance Sport Association, expressed hope that Taiwan dance aficionados will gain more technical skills in ballroom dancing from this competition that kicks off July 1 at the Taipei municipal stadium.
According to Chou, dancers from Taiwan, Russia, Britain, Slovenia, Italy, Japan and Latvia will compete in 32 categories, including top professionals in Latin dance.
Liu Chia-cheng, head of the Taipei City Government's sports department, said that the city sponsors more than 1,200 sporting events each year, attracting some 1.7 million local and foreign athletes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' ASSOCIATION HELPING GROWERS EXPORT BANANAS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association said Wednesday it was helping farmers export 200 metric tons of bananas to China as its price was hitting a new low in the local market.
Association officials said they had reached an agreement with a Chinese business group to buy Taiwan bananas at NT$11.1 per kilogram as exports to Japan dropped to NT$10 per kilogram.

The Taiwan Provincial Fruit Marketing Cooperative was purchasing bananas from growers at that price, but only about one-third of the output qualified for the Japanese market, with the rest crowding into the local market at NT$2.5 per kilogram, a price farmers said was insufficient even to cover their costs.
The officials said they would like to help sell more surplus bananas to China, after the 200 metric tons have been loaded for shipment.
Last year, typhoons and heavy rains hit Kaohsiung County -- where banana farming was concentrated -- and its price soared at one point to N$50/kilogram.
That attractive price lured many farmers to grow bananas this year, resulting in the current surplus.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Evacuation Ordered in Montgomery County; Dam Threatens to Fail, Forcing More Than 2,000 From Their Homes.
More than 2,200 people were evacuated from their homes and apartments in central Montgomery County overnight, as a dam holding back the waters of Lake Needwood near Rockville leaked and threatened to fail, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC'S FIRST LADY VISITS TAIPEI PRIMARY SCHOOL

TEXT.P: The Dominican Republic's first lady, Margarita Cedeno de Fernandes, paid a visit to Taipei's Sanyu Elementary School Wednesday to observe its computerized teaching program.

Fernandes received a warm welcome from faculty members and schoolchildren upon her arrival. The school's string band performed Taiwanese folk songs and the theme song of the famous stage and film musical "Fiddler on the Roof" to welcome the Dominican Republic's first lady.

Sanyu is one of the Taipei elementary schools selected for an experimental "mobile" teaching program that integrates information technology into natural sciences education as part of the municipal government's ambitious "digital city, mobile Taipei" development project.

The school has 36 tablet PCs, also known as slate-shaped mobile computers whose "touchscreen," or digitizing tablet technology, allows the computer to be operated with a stylus or digital pen rather than a keyboard or mouse.

Fernandes was impressed by the school's use of tablet PCs in natural science instruction, which is convenient for interactive and outdoor education programs. The Dominican Republic's first lady said she will raise funds to procure tablet PCs for educational purposes upon returning to her country.
Dominican Republic President Leonel Antonio Fernandes Reyna, accompanied by his wife and senior officials, arrived in Taipei Monday for a four-day state visit

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, decreasing NT$0.009 to close at NT$32.655.
A total of US$721 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.684 and fluctuated between NT$32.630 and NT$32.704.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved down 60 points to close at 6,455, with 36,982 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August lost 47 points to finish at 6,387, with 230 contracts traded, while September futures decreased 51 points to close at 6,369, with 37 contract transactions.
December futures moved down 53 points to close at 6,360, with seven contracts traded, while March futures lost 41 points to finish at 6,349, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,515 for July, 6,434 for August, 6,420 for September, 6,413 for December and 6,390 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

July TE futures moved down 3.1 points to close at 269, with 3,489 contracts traded, while August TE futures lost 2.35 points to finish at 267.45, with 12 contract transactions. September TE futures decreased 6.15 points to end at 263.35, with one contract traded, while March TE futures lost 10.35 points to close at 263.25, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.
July TF futures lost 10 points to finish at 937, with 2,234 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures lost 8.4 points to close at 927.2, with 14 contracts traded.
September TF futures moved down 7.6 points to finish at 921.8, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU DENIES FORMER PRESIDENT WANTS FINANCE MINISTER REPLACED

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) denied Wednesday that its spiritual leader, former President Lee Teng-hui, will pressure the ruling Democratic Party (DPP) government to replace two key Cabinet officials in the next legislative session.

In response to a report by Chinese-language daily the China Times that Lee is disgruntled with the DPP government's financial reform and wants Minister of Finance Joseph Lyu and the Financial Supervisory Commission's acting Chairman Lu Daung-yen to be replaced, TSU Secretary-General Lo Chih-ming said he had never heard of such remarks nor received such instructions from Lee.

Lo acknowledged that Lee is displeased that the DPP government seems bent on pushing toward the second stage of its financial reform program, which has allowed chunks of public wealth to fall into the hands of private financial groups.
However, Lo added, he has not heard Lee saying that he would put pressure on Premier Su Tseng-chang to replace the finance minister and the acting chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANANAS WITHIN JAPAN'S SAFETY LIMITS: COA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) affirmed Wednesday that Taiwan bananas are firmly in keeping with international safety standards, denying rumors that a shipment of Taiwan bananas bound for Japan was returned for having contained residual pesticides.

COA officials were responding to a rumor that a batch of bananas had arrived in Japan and was found to contain high levels of residual pesticide, and that the whole shipment had been returned to Taiwan in April.
They pointed out that in order to meet Japan's new regulations that took effect May 29, the COA early this year started educating local farmers about the use of pesticides.
Moreover, all Japan-bound bananas must pass the COA's lab tests before being issued export permits, according to the officials.
COA statistics show that in the first five months of this year, Taiwan exported 10,324 metric tons of bananas to Japan, down 3.91 percent from the same period last year.
The banana exports were valued at US$10.9 million, up 48.22 percent from the same period in 2005, the COA said, noting that the price per ton went up 54 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING, COLLECTING CORAL BANNED IN KENTING NATIONAL PARK
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, June 28 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Catching fish and shellfishing in the coral reef area of Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan will be banned from July 1, the park's administration office announced Wednesday.
A spokesman for the administration said the ban is to prevent the national park's marine resources from being depleted.
He added that holidaymakers are also prohibited from poaching live coral from Kenting's coral reef.

The spokesman warned that first offenses of the National Park Law will be subject to a NT$3,000 fine, and that second- and third-time offenders will face NT$9,000 and NT$15,000 penalties, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE VOWS TO FIND TAIPEI'S 'DEFINITIVE ROLE'

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh, who has been drafted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run for Taipei mayor, said Wednesday he will find a new definitive role for Taipei if elected.
In an interview with CNA, Hsieh also presented his vision for Taipei's development, promising to "revitalize old communities while fostering amity in new communities."
Hsieh, who stepped down from the premiership in late January, said he doesn't feel frustrated or "wronged" by the party's decision on his joining the year-end Taipei mayoral race.
Defying comments that his Taipei mayoral bid would be an uphill battle, Hsieh said he has full confidence in the success of his pursuit.
"When I first ran for Kaohsiung mayor eight years ago, few thought I could beat the incumbent Kuomintang mayor. I was undaunted by all those pessimistic forecasts and I finally made it," Hsieh said.

During his six years as Kaohsiung mayor until assuming the premiership in February 2005, Hsieh said he consistently ranked among the top three best-performing or most popular local government chiefs in various public opinion polls. Sometimes, Hsieh said, his ratings even surpassed that of charismatic Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

With experience in presiding over many successful projects in Kaohsiung, including the arduous cleanup of Love River and the improvement of drinking water, Hsieh said he is confident he will bring new hope to Taipei.
As the country's capital, Hsieh said Taipei is the envy of other cities and counties in Taiwan.
"Taipei is our political and economic nerve center. It has all sorts of developmental advantages."
However, Hsieh lamented that Taipei now faces some "crises," including a population exodus and a graying population, as well as a decline in the city's international competitive edge.
Claiming Taipei's relatively lackluster development in recent years could be attributed to Ma's failure to carve out a definitive role for the city.

"During my tenure as Kaohsiung mayor, I defined the port city as Taiwan's maritime capital. With this definitive goal in mind, all infrastructural construction projects, urban landscaping, harbor development plans and water sports facilities are designed in clear tandem with this goal," Hsieh said.

Although Ma once announced his plan to build Taipei into a "healthy city," Hsieh said, although the city's current mayor has failed to flesh out a clear definition for that plan. Consequently, Hsieh argued, Taipei lacks its own "distinctive identity and style."

Worse still, Hsien said, Ma -- who concurrently serves as chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang -- has turned Taipei into a "battlefield of political dogfighting" by taking part in unlawful assemblies and demonstrations.

In the past, Hsieh said, the mayor of Taipei never personally took part in any political strife. Regrettably, Hsieh said, Ma has broken this "time-honored tradition" by playing a key role in the recent political turmoil whipped up by the KMT-led motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian over corruption allegations against members of his family and staff.

"As the chief of a local government, the mayor should play the role of arbitrator, mediator or conciliator. With Ma assuming a dual role, Taipei has become a battlefield for political strife. This is a setback in Taipei's development," Hsieh said, adding that Taipei should not be a hub of political wrangling and should instead focus on cultural and economic development.

"Let's ward off politics while ushering in more economic and cultural activities," Hsieh said, adding that his mayoral campaign platform will focus on offering his visions and strategies for helping Taipei regain its glamour as an "economic capital with trust, love, culture and style."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 29, or the fourth day of the sixth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thais revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai-shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by the Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1974: The ROC government announces the suspension of diplomatic relations with Venezuela, which recognized the Chinese communist regime.
1974: The 6th National Little League Baseball Tournament ends with the Li Teh team from Kaohsiung City designated to represent the ROC in the Asian playoffs.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship-carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates the new Commissioned and Noncommissioned Statute of the Armed Forces and the new Entertainment Tax Law.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1982: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives Richard Allen, senior counselor for foreign policy to the Republican National Committee of the United States.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law, or Eugenics Bill, after a third reading.
1986: Argentina wins the World Cup soccer title again in Mexico, thanks to Diego Maradona, 25, who was directly or indirectly responsible for all the goals in the championship game.
1992: Mohamed Boudiaf, president of Algeria, is assassinated as he opens a cultural center in Annaba.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
1999: The ROC wins the right to host the annual global Information Technology conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000.
2000: Taiwan-based China Airlines signs an agreement with eight other regional airlines to establish a Pan-Asia Travel Portal website by the end of this year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: 40 ILLEGAL FOREIGN WORKERS SEIZED IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: A total of 40 illegal foreign workers have been seized in the southern county of Pingtung in the past few days, police said Thursday.

As part of a new round of nationwide crackdown on illegal foreign workers initiated by the National Police Agency (NPA) , Pingtung county police launched an all-out search for illegal foreign laborers in the county last weekend.

In addition to interviewing owners of factories, small cafeterias and construction companies, police officers have also combed farms, orchards, hog ranches and major infrastructure construction sites to look for absconded foreign workers.
As of Wednesday, 40 illegal foreign workers, including those who have overstayed their visas or absconded from their original jobs, had been uncovered.
According to NPA tallies, more than 21,000 absconded foreign laborers remained at large.

NPA officials reminded prospective employers that they have to apply for labor authority approval before hiring foreign workers or caregivers. Those who are caught to have illegally employed foreign workers could face a fine of up to NT$750,000 under current regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC TO SIGN FREE TRADE PACT IN 2007

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is scheduled to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the Dominican Republic in 2007, government officials said Thursday.

According to a joint communique signed Wednesday by President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Dominican Republic President Leonel Antonio Fernandes Reyna, the two countries will immediately start FTA negotiations, with an aim of signing such an accord next year.

It was also agreed in the communique that Taiwan will help with the Dominican Republic's plan to build a science-based industrial park in the Caribbean nation's capital and that the two countries will continue strengthening cooperation in trade, investment and technological development for mutual benefits.

Fernandes reaffirmed in the communique his country's staunch support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international organizations as well as peaceful solution to cross-Taiwan Strait issues.
Fernandes, accompanied by his wife and senior officials of the Dominican Republic, arrived in Taipei Monday for a four-day state visit.
