DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON-IN-LAW MAY BE INDICTED SOON FOR INSIDER TRADING

TEXT.P: Chao Chien-ming, son-in-law of President Chen Shui-bian, may soon be indicted on charges of insider trading and misappropriation of funds as investigators wind up their probes into a high-profile corruption scandal revolving around the trading of Taiwan Development Corp. (TDC) stocks.

Investigation results were handed in Thursday morning to prosecutors at the Taipei District Court, who said Chao and six others will likely be indicted on charges of violating the securities exchange law, breach of trust and misappropriation of funds.

The other six are Chao's father, Chao Yu-chu, who will probably be charged with insider trading and misappropriation of funds; Waterland Securities Co. board member Tsai Ching-weng, TDC Chairman Su Teh-chien and businessman You Shih-yi, who will each likely be charged with insider trading; and two private companies' top managers, Chen Ching-yao and Hung Min-sen, both likely to be charged with breach of trust.

After more than a month of investigations, investigators have gained a clear picture of the case and how Chao senior and junior have been involved in misappropriating funds and their complicated dealings with the political and business sectors involving huge amounts of money.

Judicial sources said Chaos' money dealings with politicians and businesspeople may lead to charges for other irregularities, such as influence peddling in connection with the appointments of senior managers in bank mergers and the awarding of public construction contracts, suspicions that will be the target of investigators' "second-phase" probes.

Prosecutor Hsu Yung-chin, who is in charge of investigating the TDC insider trading case, said he has mapped out a chart indicating the flows of funds used in the buying and selling of TDC shares based on the bank accounts of Chao family members and their "business partners."
He said the "first-phase" investigations are coming to an end and that the prosecution may officially lay charges against all the suspects by the end of this month or early next month at the latest.

Investigators have found that Chao Chien-ming, Su and Tsai are the main suspects in the case. As Tsai had confessed almost everything to the investigative officials, his sentence will likely be reduced.

On the other hand, prosecutors will likely request a heavier sentence for the president's son-in-law who has all along denied any wrongdoing. The prosecution will also demand that all suspects pay back all of the illicit gains from their illegal dealings.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE PASSES AMENDMENT TO LIFT DIPLOMATIC RESTRICTIONS ON TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 28 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives passed Wednesday an amendment that would lift various restrictions on the United States' relations with Taiwan, including a ban forbidding Taiwan officials from visiting the White House.

The amendment to the Science, State, Justice, Commerce Appropriations Bill was jointly proposed by four pro-Taiwan representatives, namely Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.) , Robert Andrews (D-N.J.), Steve Chahot (R-Ohio) and Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio).
If the amendment is approved by the Senate, several restrictions set forth in the U.S. State Department's Guidelines on Relations with Taiwan will be removed.

These restrictions include that meetings between U.S. and Taiwan officials may not occur in the State Department buildings, the White House or the Old Executive Office Building; that officials from U.S. foreign affairs agencies and those above the rank of GS-14 may not attend the annual Republic of China National Day reception hosted by Taiwan's representative office in Washington; and that executive branch personnel are not permitted to attend functions held at the Washington residence of Taiwan's representative to the United States.

The guidelines also stipulate that officials from the Department of Defense and State Department above the rank of office director or the rank of colonel or Navy captain may not travel to Taiwan on "official business," executive branch officials at or above the level of assistant secretary of state or three star flag military officers may not travel to Taiwan for personal travel without advance clearance from the State Department, and all travel must be on "tourist" rather than "official" passports.

In addition, executive branch personnel may not officially correspond by mail directly with Taiwan officials unless their correspondence is first sent to the American Institute in Taiwan. While any such correspondence may not be on letterhead, nor may it contain the official title of the author, personal correspondence between executive branch personnel and Taiwan officials are subject to the same restrictions.

Further restrictions include that executive branch officials are not permitted to refer to Taiwan by its official name "Republic of China, " nor can they refer to Taiwan's government as a "government." Instead, the term "Taiwan authorities" must be used. The guidelines also prevent executive branch personnel from referring to the people who live in Taiwan as "Taiwanese" but require them to refer to these people as "people on Taiwan."
Tancredo said getting rid of such "humiliating restrictions" will force the State Department to treat Taiwan as an "equal partner in freedom and democracy."
"China shouldn't control our foreign policy, Americans should, " Tancredo added.
Meanwhile, Andrews called the guidelines "an unnecessary roadblock" to clear communication between U.S. and Taiwan officials.
"In approving this amendment, the House voted for respecting democracy and human rights abroad," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU MAYOR CANDIDATE CHALLENGES DPP NOMINEE OVER CHINA TRADE POLICY

TEXT.P: Lo Chih-ming, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidate for Kaohsiung City mayor, challenged his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) counterpart, Chen Chu, Thursday to make clear her party's China trade policy which he claimed could affect the well-being of large numbers of workers in the southern port city.

Lo said that if Chen withdraws from the DPP's New Tide faction, which he noted supports a "boldly go west" policy, and explains to former President Chen Shui-bian her proposed cross-Taiwan Strait policy, then there will be room for the two parties to talk about fielding a single candidate in the mayoral election.

In that case, Lo said he would be willing to quit the race -- a remark he soon clarified by pointing out that he did not mean "withdraw from the race" and instead meant he would be willing "to negotiate" with the DPP over a unified strategy to win the race.
What is hampering the two parties from engaging in negotiations is the DPP's New Tide faction, to which Chen belongs, Lo said.
Lo stressed that he is not targeting Chen Chu as an individual, but rather "trying to discuss the issue from the policy perspective."
He claimed that if the city government adopts the "boldly go west" policy toward China, it will cause serious unemployment in Kaohsiung which has a large blue-collar population.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TIME'S NOT RIPE' FOR TALKS BETWEEN RULING, OPPOSITION: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: In response to Vice President Annette Lu's proposal for ruling and opposition party leaders to gather and talk, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday "the time is not ripe" for organizing such a meeting.

Ma expressed thanks for Lu's invitation, but said that as the opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian has just failed to obtain legislative support, he thinks "everyone now needs time to think it over."

Ma, who also doubles as Taipei mayor, made the remarks on the sidelines of the 2006 International Digital City Forum, which kicked off Thursday at the Taipei International Convention Center. Both Lu and Ma were invited to deliver speeches at the opening ceremony.

Before leaving the event, Lu expressed hope that everyone in the country would one day have the chance to see the existence of a "mature democracy" on the island, and suggested leaders across the political spectrum get together to exchange opinions and ideas.
A "positive political atmosphere" would help resolve differences, Lu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: 46% OF PARENTS FEEL 'HIGHER THAN NORMAL' PRESSURE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (CCF/ Taiwan) released results of a survey Thursday indicating that 46 percent of parents of elementary school pupils experience "greater than normal" pressure due to multiple pressures of being a parent, income earner, spouse and a member of society, with five percent saying they suffer "extreme" pressure.

A lack of knowledge about parental responsibilities has for five consecutive years been the No. 1 reason cited for child abuse, according to the authors of the survey, which was released as child abuse enters its "peak season" of July to September.

Chou Hui-hsiang, director of CCF/Taiwan's department of social work, said female parents, single parents, grandparents looking after grandchildren, parents with little education or greater economic burdens and families with a large number of children tend to face greater pressures.

CCF/Taiwan suggested that parents learn stress management and relaxation techniques, find more time to unwind and make good use of social support networks. At home, household duties should be shared by all members of the household and parents and children should find "quality time" to share daily experiences and communicate with each other.

The organization will distribute 150,000 booklets across Taiwan teaching parents how to improve parent-child relations. For further information, call 04-2206-1234 or visit the fund's Web site at http://cp.ccf.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 80 points to close at 6,535, with 42,461 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August rose 59 points to finish at 6,446, with 495 contracts traded, while September futures gained 67 points to close at 6,436, with 88 contract transactions.
December futures moved up 73 points to close at 6,433, with nine contracts traded, while March futures gained 35 points to finish at 6,420, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,455 for July, 6,387 for August, 6,369 for September, 6,360 for December and 6,385 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
July TE futures moved up 2.25 points to close at 271.25, with 4,308 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 2.05 points to finish at 269.5, with 22 contract transactions.
March TE futures rose 6.55 points to finish at 269.8, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved up 16.8 points to finish at 953.8, with 3,001 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures gained 15.8 points to close at 943, with 12 contracts traded.
September TF futures rose 14.4 points to finish at 940, with eight contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA, YONHAP SIGN COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Central News Agency (CNA) signed a cooperative agreement with South Korea's Yonhap News Agency Thursday that provides a framework for future bilateral exchanges and cooperation in news, photo, video and audio services.

The agreement between the two leading news agencies was signed by Jeremy Tzong-jer Yuan, director-general of CNA's Business Department, and his Yonhap counterpart, Kim Chang-Hoe, at CNA's Taipei headquarters.

Addressing the ceremony, Yuan welcomed Kim, who had arrived in Taipei a day earlier to sign the cooperative agreement and to attend celebrations for CNA's 10th anniversary as Taiwan's national news agency.

With the signing of the agreement, Yuan said, the two news agencies will begin cooperating in various news service fields. And through a platform provided by the CNA, he added, Yonhap's information services will now gain access to local media outlets, thus helping to enhance local people's understanding of South Korea while working toward developing cultural exchanges beween the two countries.
For his part, Kim said that although CNA and Yonhap first signed a cooperative accord in 1981, the new agreement marked the beginning of substantive cooperation between the two.

With comprehensive news-gathering networks at home and abroad, Kim said, Yonhap has won public acclaim for its updated and precise news services. Kim added he believes CNA - Yonhap cooperative ties will contribute toward promoting mutual understanding and friendship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 66.46 points to close at 6,607.39.
The bourse opened at 6,578.58 and fluctuated between 6,623.39 and 6,574.4 during trading. A total of 3.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.55 billion (US$2.81 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 4.4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.9 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.1 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 685 to 204, with 118 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SPEND NT$300 BILLION ON WIRELESS INTERNET

TEXT.P: The government will spend NT$300 billion (US$9.24 billion) from next fiscal year to provide wireless broadband to 6 million Internet users, Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday.

Addressing the participants in the 2006 Digital Cities Convention Taipei being held June 28-30 at the Taipei International Convention Center, Lu said that as one of the nation's major development plans, the Cabinet will build 3,000 access points in 25 cities and counties to achieve its goal.

She also said the central government's operations will be completely computerized now that Taipei City was ranked first in the Intelligent Community Forum's list of the world's top seven intelligent communities earlier this month.

Also speaking at the convention, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that gaining recognition as the world's No. 1 intelligent city does not give the people of Taipei the right to feel complacent, because other cities might soon catch up.
Ma said the Taipei city government will launch a publicity campaign over the next six months to encourage city residents to use wireless Internet.

At present, Taipei has more than 2,000 access points for wireless Internet users in an area of 28 square kilometers, covering some 50 percent of the city's population -- ahead of any other city in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA, BUSINESS WIRE INK NEW PACT FOR COMMERCIAL NEWS DISTRIBUTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central News Agency (CNA) inked an agreement with U.S.-based Business Wire Thursday to boost bilateral cooperation in news distribution and commercial representation.

CNA's President Liu Chih-tsung and Hector Botero, president of Business Wire's Latin America and China operations, signed the agreement on behalf of the two leading news agencies at aceremony held at CNA's Taipei headquarters, marking a milestone in bilateral cooperation between the two.

Addressing the ceremony, Botero quoted a recent New York Times report as saying that efforts by Taiwan's government to foster Internet-related industries and an information infrastructure have yielded "substantial rewards."

Botero said Taipei's WiFly network may be the most visible evidence of Taiwan's technological aspirations, but besides the technology, the government has been working on a "far-reaching" plan since the 1990s to use the Internet as an efficient and inexpensive way for government functionaries to communicate among themselves and with citizens.

He quoted the New York Times as reporting that in 2005, 92 percent of Taiwan's businesses and 35 percent of individuals filed taxes electronically, Taiwan's government distributes about 100,000 documents online every working day, thousands of Taiwanese students pay school tuition through the Internet and one million citizens now have identification cards with chips inside.

The efforts of Taiwan's government have attracted great attention, the report said, adding that the Brown University Taubman Center for Public Policy put Taiwan at the top of its list of the world's most Internet-savvy governments, according to Botero.

"The Internet is not just to get rid of regulations, but also to establish a mature democracy," said Yeh Jiunn-rong, the former chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.
"While we were doing government reform, it was a golden opportunity to do it right with e-government," Yeh was quoted as saying in the New York Times report.

"These excerpts from the New York Times article reflect Business Wire's interests in participating with the Central News Agency to provide the Taiwan capital markets, the Taiwan Stock Exchange and the companies listed on the exchange with the latest state-of-the-art technology for corporate news distribution," Botero said.

Business Wire was established over 50 years ago and is the world's leading service for corporate news distribution. It has over 15,000 corporate subscribers and offices and bureaus in the United States, Europe, Latin America and the Asia Pacific region, he said.

Botero said that Business Wire was acquired by legendary investor Warren Buffet earlier this year. Buffet is considered the second wealthiest man in the world, he said, adding that Buffet announced plans this week to donate more than US$40 billion in Berkshire Hathaway stock to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation for children's education and medical research.
"We are very proud that someone as influential and respected as Mr. Buffet recognized our leadership, integrity and values," Botero continued.
"We at Business Wire have recognized the qualities of CNA including its outstanding leadership, its management, its worldwide reputation, integrity and values," he added.
For his part, Liu said Business Wire has long been one of CNA's key partners and this new agreement will surely bring the two even closer.

Liu said Business Wire, now a wholly owned subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway, is the global market leader in commercial news distribution. Thousands of member companies and organizations depend on Business Wire to transmit their full-text news releases, regulatory filings, photos and other multimedia content to journalists, financial professionals, investor services, regulatory authorities and the general public worldwide, he said.

"Through the coopertion of Business Wire and CNA, we could help the Taiwan Stock Exchange establish a platform to help transmit information of local enterprises to international stock exchanges, monetary markets and Internet portals," Liu said.

"This ground-breaking collaboration is expected to greatly increase the popularity of local listed and OTC companies in the world arena, while ensuring the transparency of related information," he said.

CNA and Business Wire signed their first cooperation agreement on news distribution and commercial representation in February 2005 with efforts focusing on Business Wire transmitting global corporate news to Taiwan's clients via the CNA news vehicle.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR END TO POLITICAL STRIFE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that political parties in Taiwan must put aside their differences and work together toward the promotion of constitutional reforms that will sustain the country's democratic development.

Addressing the opening ceremony for two study programs offered by the Executive Yuan for government employees, Chen said the country's two major directions of development should be toward a "democratic Taiwan, sustainable development" and "pursuing peace, seeking dialogue."

To ensure the nation's sustainable development, the government needs to beef up national security, deepen the country's democratization, continue its economic development, uphold social justice and build a civil society, Chen said.

Chen said that national security is vital to Taiwan's survival, and that faced with China's military intimidation the country must establish sufficient self-defense capabilities and unite its people against that threat.

On the deepening of Taiwan's democratization, Chen said the transition of power in 2000 marked a major step toward deepening the country's democratic development, and he pledged that the government would continue to work to create an "open political environment" with transparent decision-making processes.

On continuing down the path of economic development, Chen said that while the economy is essential to the country's survival, Taiwan should attach equal importance to environmental protection and development in order to enhance its overall competitiveness.

On upholding social justice, the president said it is the government's responsibility to create a social environment that is fair and just, and to achieve that goal the government is promoting taxation reform, planning a national pension program, improving the National Health Insurance program, establishing a social security network and enhancing the welfare of the disadvantaged.

On the establishment of a civil society, Chen said the government hopes to joint forces with the private sector and non-governmental organizations to build a society in which people identify, respect, care, trust and help one another.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROMOTE FTA WITH U.S. THROUGH AMERICAN ENTERPRISES
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 28 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Steve Chen said Wednesday that promoting the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States is the most important task for the Taiwan government and that the government plans to promote the signing of an FTA with the U.S. through the influence of American enterprises.

Chen, who is heading a trade promotion delegation visiting Britain, noted that the United States is the most important trade partner for Taiwan, and said the coutnry's FTA negotiations with the United States are urgent, as Wahsington has already completed FTA talks with several Asian countries such as South Korea, Malaysia, and Thailand.

He noted that Taiwan and the United States maintain close economic and trade relations and said both sides can create more trade opportunities in information technology, the service industry, financial and transport sectors with the signing of an FTA.
With FTAs Taiwan has already signed with Panama, Guatemala and Nicaragua, Taiwan can connect to the whole American market if it can sign an FTA with the United States, Chen added.

With the huge American market in mind, the government will help Taiwan enterprises diversify their investments in the market, while American companies can enter the Asian market via Taiwan, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA MINISTER OUTLINES 'NEW AGRICULTURAL MOVEMENT'

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Su Jia-chyuan outlined a "new agricultural movement" Thursday with the hope that Taiwan's agricultural exports will increase by 20 percent within three years.

With the new project, the COA plans to redouble within three years the area in which farmers dedicate to the cultivation of organic farm products; attracting 1,000 additional young farmers to the agricultural industry: increasing revenue for technical transfer
In addition, the COA will implement a system by 2015 in which the agricultural products will have their thorough records from cultivation to marketing.

Noting that Taiwan's agricultural industry is facing fierce competition from liberalization and internationalization since its entry into World Trade Organization, Su said the country's agriculture should not only focus on production and technology, but should also strengthen the renovation and international marketing.

Under the "new agricultural movement, " the COA will promote the development of biomass energy in fallow lands, implement insurance for the agricultural industry, as well as strengthen global marketing for Taiwan's agricultural products.

In addition to arousing the public concern over the agriculture, the COA will also invite celebrities to promote its cause, that will include Acer Group founder Stan Shih and Taipei 101 Chairwoman Diana Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'YOUTH PROGRAM' TO KICK OFF IN KEELUNG

TEXT.P: Keelung city police authorities, in cooperation with the private sector, will launch a two-month "youth program" for students at all levels from July 1 through Aug. 31 to coincide with the summer vacation.

According to a spokesman for the Keelung municipal police, policemen and officials from the city's education, public health, public works, commerce and economy and fire-fighting bureaus will form a task force to carry out late-night raids on the MTVs and KTV parlors, Internet coffee shops, video game shops and billiard halls that teenage students tend to frequent during their vacations.

In a bid to prevent teenagers from becoming involved in the sex trade or commiting crimes such as illegal car racing and robbery, the task force will also strengthen inspections at street intersections, the spokesman said, adding that special summer camps dedicated to young men and women will also be organized to help teenaged students spend their summer vacation in what the authorities believe is a "healthy and peaceful way."

The spokesman also urged parents to pay special attention to the behavior of their children and called on them to remain on high alert should their children seem to be spending extra money or behaving strangely.

Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li told a seminar sponsored by the Keelung city police bureau that all relevant municipal agencies must swing into full gear to help protect the safety of teenagers in the coming two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BOYCOTT BEHIND PRESIDENT'S DIPLOMATIC EFFORTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his efforts to expand Taiwan's international presence is due to China's relentless attempts to isolate Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks in an online weekly newsletter issued by the Presidential Office in an attempt to detail his diplomtic efforts since coming to power in 2000.

Stating that he is sure that Taiwan's 23 million people are aware of the country's difficult situation in the international community, Chen said that as head of state, he must not hold back and must tackle all difficulties to "reach out" for Taiwan.

For instance, recent visits to Taiwan by Dominican Republic President Leonel Antonio Fernandez Reyna and King Mswati III of Swaziland and a visit next week by Honduran President Manuel Zelaya are proof of his efforts, Chen said, noting that since 2000, he has visited some of Taiwan's diplomatic allies each year, with nearly half of them visited by Taiwan's president for the first time.

According to Chen, his visit to the Vatican in April last year to attend the funeral of Pope John Paul II carried great significance because it was the first-ever visit to Taiwan's only European diplomatic partner by a Taiwan president. Over the past few years, he has also received several international human rights awards in the United States on behalf of the Taiwan people, he said.

Last year, he also made transit visits in Fiji, the United Arabian Emirates and Indonesia, which maintain no formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, in addition to a stopover in Libya this year, Chen added, claiming that his "diplomatic offensive" was made to counter China's suppression of Taiwan.

Chen said that China makes "no difference" between the "pan-blue" and the "pan-green" camps when it seeks to block Taiwan in international activities, citing as evidence that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a heavyweight in the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was unable to take part in last year's summit meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum on his behalf as a result of pressure from China.

Under such circumstances, unity is important among the Taiwan people to deal with China's strenuous diplomatic suppression, Chen said, adding that the public should lend their support to the government's diplomatic officials and encourage them to help Taiwan play a bigger role on the world stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RENEWS CALL FOR LEGISLATURE TO PASS MAJOR BUDGET BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang renewed a call Thursday for the legislature to address crucial budget bills concerning people's livelihood, such as major projects in public construction and flood control, before the current extra legislative session expires in two days.

Su warned that if the legislature fails to pass the bills, the country's gross domestic product would see a decline of over NT$20 billion this year, the economic growth rate would drop 0.15 percent and the unemployment rate might grow 0.1 percent.
Su made the call while addressing a ceremony marking the beginning of two Executive Yuan-organized training programs on public service and women's leadership development.

Citing a construction project for a mass rapid transit railway line between Taipei and Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Su said if the concerned budget fails to pass the legislature, current construction will have to be suspended due to financial difficulties.
Furthermore, the government will have to make additional compensation to contractors for losses due to construction delays, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRITER TO RUN IN 2008 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Huang Yue-sui, a writer and former national policy adviser to the president, announced Thursday that she will run in the 2008 presidential election.

If no political parties can run the country well, it is better for them to "take a break" and "make way for a woman to reign, " said Huang, a feminist, claiming that if she were to serve as president, "the people in Taiwan would be happier than they are now."

Huang made the announcement at a launch ceremony for a book of her poetry that was attended by Vice Minister of Cultural Affairs Wu Chin-fa, as well as Huang's best friend and poet Lee Min-yung, and writer Lin Wen-yi.

Huang claimed that 40 percent of people in the country are supporters of neither the "pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party nor the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party.
Work can be done to get these people's support, she said as she expressed confidence in her ability to win the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH ENTERPRISE LSE FOR TALENT TRAINING
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 28 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) signed an agreement Wednesday with Enterprise LSE Ltd., a subsidiary of the London School of Economics And Political Science (LSE), for training programs for Taiwan officials.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Steven Chen and Enterprise LSE Chairman Roger Mountfort signed the agreement on behalf of the two sides.
Chen, who is leading a trade promotion delegation that is visiting Britain, noted that many Taiwan officials, such as Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, have studied at LSE.

With the fierce competition from globalization, the European Union has become a very important trade partner for Taiwan, and the Enterprise LSE training programs will help Taiwan government officials better understand the E.U.'s structure, operations, trade policies and policy-making process.
The 8-week programs, which will begin Aug. 21, will cover 40 of the MOEA's middle-level executives, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENSIONS FOR RETIRED PRESIDENTS TO BE SLASHED

TEXT.P: The allowance for retired presidents and vice presidents will be cut by almost 50 percent, according to consensus reached Thursday among legislators of the ruling and opposition parties.

The legislators completed a draft amendment to the Statute Governing Preferential Treatment for Presidents and Vice Presidents, but the document was not signed by the legislative caucus whips of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the main opposition Kuomintang and two smaller opposition parties -- the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
According to the amendment, a retired president will be entitled to NT$250,000 (US$7,670) per month for a period as long as the number of years he or she had served in the post.
Other preferential treatment will include NT$8 million in office expenses in the first year, NT$6.5 million in the second year, and NT$5 million from the third year of retirement.
A retired president will have eight to 12 security personnel to protect his safety, plus the service of chauffeurs.

For a retired vice president, the monthly allowance will be NT$180,000, with the office expenses set at NT$4 million in the first year, NT$3.25 million in the second year, and NT$2.5 million in the third year, plus the protection of four to eight security personnel.
All retired presidents and vice presidents will enjoy health care provided by the state and will have the privilege of attending important national ceremonies.
According to the amendment, such preferential treatment will be suspended if a retired president or vice president becomes gainfully employed again as a public office holder.

A retired president or vice president who has emigrated to another country, lost Republic of China nationality, or been convicted of rebellion or treason will automatically lose the preferential treatment.
An incumbent president or vice president who has been relieved of his or her post because of a recall, impeachment or a criminal sentence will also forfeit the right to such preferential treatment.

The amendment was prompted by opposition legislators' complaints that President Chen Shui-bian, who is to retire in 2008 after serving the remaining two years of his second four-year term, does not deserve a pension three times that of a retired U.S. president for the rest of his life, because he has plunged the nation into turmoil with a series of corruption scandals involving his senior aides and family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.035 to close at NT$32.620.
A total of US$680 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.705 and fluctuated between NT$32.600 and NT$32.710.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS TAIWAN'S PRESS FREEDOM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian touted Taiwan's press freedom Thursday, saying Taiwan now ties with Japan at the top of the Asian rating in terms of press freedom.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of senior executives of major international news media who have come to Taipei to attend the June 30 celebration of the Central News Agency's 10th anniversary as Taiwan's national news agency.

Since taking office in 2000, Chen said, he has committed himself to defending freedom of the press and freedom of speech. "Thanks to our continued efforts, we have made enormous progress in the press freedom world rating," he said.

In the annual rating of press freedom in more than 190 countries compiled by the U.S.-based Freedom House, Taiwan advanced to 35th place this year from 44th last year and 49th in 2004, Chen said, adding that among Asian countries, Taiwan ties with Japan at the top of the press freedom rating this year.

In contrast, Chen said, China is notorious for its human rights violations, including suppression of press freedom. Ranking nearly at the bottom -- 177th for 2006 -- China has been blamed for censorship against such world famous Internet portals as Microsoft and Yahoo. China has also kept more journalists in detention than any other country in the Freedom House 2006 survey, Chen added.

Recalling that he himself was once jailed for eight months for what he described as "his dissenting views" during Taiwan's martial law era, Chen said he takes pleasure and pride in seeing Taiwan's evolution from an authoritarian country with no press preedom into a liberal democracy.
The foreign media executives were accompanied by CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping during the meeting with the president.
Chen praised CNA for its always updated and precise news reporting and information services.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET NAMES NEW FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Ho Chih-chin, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, will replace Joseph Lyu as new minister of finance, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Thursday.
Lyu will become a minister without portfolio, Cheng said.

He also said Premier Su Tseng-chang has named three academics to serve as commissioners of the Financial Supervisory Commission -- Shih Chun-chi, chief executive of Academia Sinica's system and behavior research center; Lin Kuo-chuan, a National Chengchi University (NCU) law professor; and Chang Shih-chieh, a professor at NCU's risk management and insurance department.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 30

TEXT.P: The following are major events to take place Friday, June 30:
09:10, Premier Su Tseng-chang will preside over a ground-breaking ceremony for a biotechnology industrial park in Talin, Chiayi County.
10:00, Vice President Annette Lu will host an informal gathering of opinion leaders aimed at promoting political reconciliation to be held at Taipei Guest House.
14;10, Vice President Lu will attend a celebration ceremony for CNA's 10th anniversary as Taiwan's national news agency to be held at Grand Formosa Regent Taipei hotel.
15:00, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen and GIO Minister Cheng Wen-tsang will attend a celebration ceremony marking CNA's 10th anniversary as Taiwan's national news agency.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA TO INAUGURATE NEW WEB SITE ON GRASSROOTS NEWS

TEXT.P: The Central News Agency will inaugurate a new Web site focusing on grassroots news Friday as part of celebrations of its 10th anniversary as Taiwan's national news agency and its 82nd founding anniversary.

With a comprehensive round-the-island news-gathering network, the new CNA Web site will specialize in grassroots news reports, particularly those related with social customs, cultural heritage, historical relics, tourist attractions, lifestyles as well as major development projects, sports and artistic activities in various cities and counties.

The new Web site is aimed at helping people at home and abroad better understand true Taiwan as well as its charms and characteristics. Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen will preside over the new Web site's inauguration at the CNA's anniversary celebration ceremony to be held at Grand Formosa Regent hotel in Taipei.

Many honorable guests, including Vice President Annette Lu, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, senior executives of major international news organizations as well as government officials, party bigwigs and business executives, have been invited to attend the celebration ceremony.
As part of its efforts to promote international information exchanges and cooperation, CNA signed cooperative agreements with U.S.-based Business Wire and South Korea's Yonhap News Agency Thursday.
Meanwhile, CNA will sponsor a Taiwan images exhibition in India in the near future to introduce Taiwan's various aspects to Indians via a collection of vivid news photos.
Accompanied by CNA chairman Su Tzen-ping, the 10-plus foreign media executives paid visits to President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang Thursday.

Both Chen and Su briefed representatives of major foreign news organizations, including Associated Press, Reuters, AFP, Yonhap, Kyodo, JiJi Press, Thailand News Agency, Bloomberg News and the United News of India News Agency, on Taiwan's journalistic development and press freedom.
According to the Freedom House 2006 global press freedom rating, Taiwan ties with Japan at the top of press freedom in Asia and ranks 35th in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Israelis Batter Gaza and Seize Hamas Officials
Israel stepped up its confrontation on Wednesday with Palestinian militants over the capture of an Israeli soldier, battering northern Gazan towns with artillery and sending warplanes over the house of the Syrian president, who is influential with the Palestinian leader believed to have ordered the kidnapping. Israeli Prime Mminister Ehud Olmert demanded the soldier's unconditional release or an escalation that could widen the conflict regionally: Haim Ramon, Israel's justice minister, raised the possibility of a strike in Syria to kill Khaled Meshal, the exiled political leader of Hamas; the men who hold the Israeli soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, 19, are believed to be following his orders.
Wall Street Journal: Energy Stalks, Big Players Join Race to Put Farm Waste Into Your Gas Tank
The U.S. Energy Department is staging a competition backing the private sector to build the nation's first three commercials plant capable of producing cellulosic ethanol. The department, which has US$160 million to spend on the contest, is requiring each candidate to have a pilot plant showing a process that can be successful once it is scaled up. At least 30 companies are in the running for the aid, industry officials say. One player with big backers is Iogen Corp., a privately held Ottawa-based biotech company that has patented enzymes that can extract the sugars from wheat and barley straw. It has proposed building a commercial plant in southeastern Idaho, where it already has contracts with farmers to deliver the raw materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 30, or the fifth day of the sixth month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of the Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: U.S. President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian cosmonauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record-breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.
1983: Hsu Shih-hsien, mayor of Chiayi and Taiwan's first female mayor, dies of liver cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Sten A. Akestam, president of the International Association of Lions Clubs, and six other top-ranking Lions officials.
1987: The construction of Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County, with a price-tag of NT$14 billion, is completed.
1989: ROC Interior Minister Hsu Shui-teh and Vice Defense Minister Kuo Tsung-chin jointly preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a national boundary stone tablet inscribed with the words "Shield of the South China Sea" on Tungsha Chuntao (the Pratas Islands) in the South China Sea.
1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The U.S. government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1997: Britain hands Hong Kong back to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
1999: The U.S. ratings agency Standard and Poor's gives the ROC's long-term foreign currency credit a rating of AA+, indicating its belief that the country has a high level of capability in fulfilling its financial commitments.
2000: A total of 251 sinologists from around the world meet at Taiwan's Academia Sinica to discuss the digital preservation of traditional Chinese literature and language archives.
2001: Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, accompanied by a high-profile delegation, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit to the ROC at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO EXPAND 'CLEAN SYRINGE PROGRAM' FOR DRUG USERS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will from July 1 expand its "clean syringe program" for intravenous drug users to cover the entire country to reduce HIV transmission, officials said Friday.

According to tallies from the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , 11,486 AIDS/HIV cases have been reported in Taiwan as of the end of May, with 4,064, or 35 percent, being drug addicts who contracted the virus via sharing needles with other HIV-carrying addicts. Needle sharing has replaced homosexual intercourse as the main form of HIV transmission in Taiwan.
The CDC has since last year provided drug addiction counseling and clean syringes free of charge to drug addicts in Taipei County, Taipei City, Taoyuan County and Tainan County.
While 40,546 syringes have been handed out, 9,153 drug addicts have sought counseling, CDC statistics show.
CDC officials said the "clean syringe program" has been effective in reducing HIV transmission.

For example, Tainan County, where more than 30,000 syringes have been handed out, has reported only 26 new AIDS/HIV cases so far this year, compared with 136 new cases reported during the same period last year, the officials said.
They estimated that the decrease will help the government save NT$1 billion (US$30.67 million) in health spending on AIDS patients.

From July 1, the CDC will provide an extra 5 million clean syringes at 427 designated locations in 23 counties and cities around Taiwan, the officials said, adding that the CDC is also planning to set up 100 syringe vending machines around the country by the end of this year.

Meanwhile, the CDC will expand its methadone treatment program starting August to help drug addicts quit their vice and will purchase enough of the medication for one day's use by 1.13 million people, they said.
While the methadone will be provided free of charge to HIV-carrying drug addicts, others can join the program voluntarily by paying their own medical bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FINANCE MINISTER SEEN AS 'HIGHLY COMPETENT'

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) economics professor Ho Chih-chin, who was appointed as the finance minister by the Cabinet Thursday, will be "highly competent" to carry out his new governmental duties, according to his colleague Chen Tien-chih.

Ho, who returned to Taiwan only three years ago after serving as a senior official at the U.S. Treasury Department and at the Justice Department for 15 years, is known for his expertise in the fields of tax laws and financial policy, said Chen, a professor with NTU's Department of Economics.

A former first economist with the United States' Internal Revenue Service (IRS), Ho is currently head of NTU's Department of Economics. He has been instrumental in formulating the country's taxation reforms, particularly in redefining minimum taxation criteria, over the last two years, Chen said.
Ho, with a strong academic background and work experience, will be a competent finance minister, Chen said.

Ho received his bachelor's degree from NTU's Department of Economics and his doctoral degree in economics from Michigan University. He comes from a family of judges -- both his father and grandfather were grand justices of the Republic of China.

Ho was appointed the new finance minister after incumbent Joseph Lyu has offered to resign recently. Lyu, whose resignation was accepted by Premier Su Tseng-chang Thursday, will become a minister-without-portfolio.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREATMENT FOR RETIRED NATIONAL LEADERS SHOULD BE FAIR: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the Legislative Yuan Friday to craft bills based on the principle of fairness and not just to accommodate certain people.

Lu's remarks came in the wake of the legislature's passage earlier in the day of a draft amendment to the Statute Governing Preferential Treatment for Presidents and Vice Presidents which will cancel lifelong payments to retired presidents and vice presidents and dramatically curtail other preferential treatment. Former President Lee Teng-hui and former Vice President Lien Chan, who stepped down in 2000, will not be affected by the change.

Lu said that she has no specific view on the legislature's move, because "as a civil servant, I have not thought about the money." However, she urged the legislature "to be reasonable and fair in their move, " adding that the treatment for retired presidents and vice presidents should be reasonable.
According to the amendment, a retired president is entitled to NT$250,000 (US$7,670) per month for a period as long as the number of years he or she had served in the post.

Other preferential treatment include NT$8 million in office expenses in the first year of retirement, NT$7 million in the second year, and NT$6 million for the third year and NT$5 million from the fourth year. Furthermore, a retired president will be provided with eight to 12 security personnel to protect his or her safety.

For a retired vice president, the monthly allowance is NT$180,000, with office expenses set at NT$4 million for the first year, NT$3.5 million for the second year, and NT$3 million for the third year and NT$2.5 million from the fourth year, plus the protection of four to eight security personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEEP OCEAN WATER R&D CENTER PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO LOCAL COMPANIES

TEXT.P: The Research and Development Center on Deep Ocean Water has helped several local companies break through operational bottlenecks, and one of the facilities in the eastern county of Hualien is expected to become fully operational by August, a spokesman of the Water Resources Agency (WRA) said Friday.

The R&D center -- co-sponsored by the WRA under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Industrial Technology Research Institute -- began operations on June 1, with the aim of offering consultancy in technology and facility establishment.

The official said that the facility -- set up by Taiwan Fertilizer Co. -- will pump up 2,400 tons to 2,600 tons of ocean water per day from 710 meters below the surface to produce bottled drinking water.

He added that the center will assist in the construction of at least six more facilities located along the eastern Taiwan coastline in the coming years -- one in Yilan County, two in Hualien, and three in Taitung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT INVITES POLITICAL LEADERS TO COFFEE MEETING

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that she has rung leaders of the ruling and opposition parties to invite them to meet with her over a cup of coffee.
Lu said that she was able to reach all of the political leaders Thursday with the exception of one and that some of them accepted her invitation immediately.

As some of her guests, such as Solidarity Taiwan Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, are either on a foreign visit or will soon go on such a trip, the meeting will probably be held after they return home, Lu said.
Lu predicted that the atmosphere will be better then as these leaders will discover on their overseas visits that "the political strife is a very trivial matter compared with the size of the world."

Citing a survey on 34 democratic countries, Lu said the Taiwan people rank only 29th in terms of their pride in their own country despite Taiwan's achievements on human rights protection and democratic and technological development. She reasoned that the results are related to the political instability and strife going on in the country.
The vice president again called on the political leaders to give up their "zero-sum struggle" and put their heads together to find ways to make Taiwan better.

Lu had put forth a similar proposal early this month before the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party initiated a motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, but the plan was later canceled.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM MAY FORM INTO TYPHOON

TEXT.P: A new low pressure system lurking in an area east of the Philippines may increase in intensity and form into a tropical storm over the next two days, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Friday.
There is a possibility that the tropical depression could develop into a typhoon and affect Taiwan directly, said Daniel Wu, director of CWB's Weather Forecast Center.
Should the system develop into a typhoon, it will be the second in the Pacific region this year and will be named Ewiniar, which means the God of Storm in Micronesian.

Meanwhile, Wu quoted the CWB Weather Forecast Center as predicting that 24 to 26 typhoons will form in the Western North Pacific and the South China Sea areas this year, with four or five of them expected to affect Taiwan directly.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN NUCLEAR SOCIETY AWARDS TAIWAN SCIENTIST

TEXT.P: The American Nuclear Society (ANS) has presented the 2006 Special Award to Dr. Lin Chien-chang of National Tsing-hua University -- the first Taiwanese recipient since 1962, a university official said Friday.

According to the ANS, the award is to recognize an individual or individuals for outstanding contributions to peaceful applications of nuclear technology. The topic for this year's Special Award is "Radiochemistry in Nuclear Technology."

The official said Lin has devoted himself to research in nuclear technology for nearly 50 years, as well as leading the research and development department at General Electric for over 20 years. He added that Lin has greatly contributed in the field of radiochemistry to research and development related to boiling water reactors.
The official explained that research advances in radiochemistry have been vital to the safety of nuclear power plants in terms of radiation control and detection.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CERTIFIED AS WORLD'S LARGEST WI-FI NETWORK CITY

TEXT.P: Taipei City has been certified by the San Francisco-based JiWire Inc., a leading provider of wireless broadband services, as the "world's largest Wi-Fi network city."
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou accepted the certification from JiWire Chief Executive Kevin McKenzie Thursday at the Taipei International Convention Center.
Ma explained that the efforts to build the capital city into a digitized modern metropolis began in 1999 with the construction of wireless broadband infrastructure.
The project is scheduled to be fully completed by July, when the wireless network coverage will have reached around 90 percent of the city, providing service to 2.3 million people, Ma said.
According to official statistics released in March, Taipei has a population of over 2.6 million people.

McKenzie said the certification was conducted by their technicians who visited the city to sum up the number of "hotspots" -- wireless Internet accesses points -- public space and population in Taipei, and to double-check that Taipei's public wireless network coverage is the largest in the world.
The experts also proved the steadiness of the city's wireless network operation, as well as the high online speed, he noted.
Ma said Taipei is willing to share its fruit with all the people of the country by assisting other cities and counties to "become digitalized."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 97.02 points to close at 6,704.41.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,731.07 and hit a low of 6,682.38 during trading. A total of 3.86 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.8 billion (US$3.57) billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 2.2 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent, construction issues at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks dropping 0.9 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 616 to 293, with 110 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 95% OF ENTERPRISES OPERATING IN LINE WITH NEW PENSION SYSTEM: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More than 95 percent of Taiwan enterprises are operating in line with the new pension system implemented last July 1, according to the results of a recent survey released Friday.

The survey, which was conducted by 1111 Manpower Bank, an online job search firm, from June 20-28, found that 95.07 percent of the enterprises are operating completely in line with the new pension system, while 4.35 percent of the companies are partially in tune with the new system.

Under the new pension system, employers must deposit at least 6 percent of an employee's salary into their pension account each month, which the employees can carry with them whenever they change jobs. Under the old system, an employee would get his or her pension after working for 25 consecutive years for the same enterprise or when they reached the age of 55 years and had worked for the same company for 15 consecutive years.
Also under the old system, employees would receive their pension in one lump sum, while under the new system, retired workers are eligible to receive a monthly pension for the rest of their life.
The survey results show that 13 percent of Taiwan employers have changed their employee salary structure due to the new pension system, while 86 percent have not done so.

According to survey, 47.25 percent of the enterprises said they hope their employees choose the new pension system, while only 3.19 percent said they hope their employees choose to stick with the old system, while a total of 43.77 percent of the companies said they will make the judgment on a case-by-case basis.

Wu Ruey-ying, spokesman of 1111 Manpower Bank, said employers could violate the Labor Standard Law if they try to offset the increased labor costs resulting from the new pension system by reducing employees' salaries or signing new labor contracts with their employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRMAN CONCERNED ABOUT POLITICAL STRIFE IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 29 (CNA) (By Lin Chieh-you and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Richard Bush, former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), expressed concern Thursday that political confrontation in Taiwan will only be exacerbated and that the Taiwan people might suffer for a long time.
The AIT is a quasi-official organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan.
Bush, currently director of the Center for Northeast Asian Policy Studies at the Brookings Institution, a U.S. think tank, made the remarks when he was interviewed by Taiwan media.
He predicted that Taiwan's politics will continue to be polarized, adding that political strife has been going on for some time and that he is sure it will continue for the next few years.
The Taiwan people will be the ones who suffer if the inter-party strife continues, he added.

Bush stressed that U.S. government policy is to not interfere with Taiwan's internal affairs, but said Washington will continue to keep a close watch over whether the political crisis will affect regional stability.

Noting that a recall motion against President Chen Shui-bian initiated by Taiwan's opposition over the president's alleged incompetence and corruption in his family and among his close associates failed to pass in the legislature Tuesday, he expressed concern about a possible opposition follow-up motion to propose a no-confidence motion against Premier Su Tseng-chang.
He urged political figures across the party spectrum to avoid polarization, find a way of reconciliation and focus on matters related to the people's welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES 3 MAJOR BUDGETS TOTALLING NT$141.9 BILLION

TEXT.P: The legislature approved three budgets totalling NT$141.94 billion (US$4.39 billion) Friday for flood control and national development projects.
A total of NT$30.97 billion will go to controlling floods in low-lying areas across Taiwan in the government's "first-phase flood fighting program."
For that budget, the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution prohibiting the government from collecting the money by selling its shares in publicly owned banks and the tobacco and wine monopoly.
As a result, all the funds will come from the issue of government bonds, with the principle and interest burdens to be shared by the taxpayers.

Another NT$13.97 billion was approved for dredging and improving the Shihmen Dam in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, a project that is expected to stabilize water supply and control flooding for area residents.
For this special budget, the government was permitted to borrow NT$10.36 billion. The other NT$3.61 comes from the previous fiscal year's budget surplus.

A third budget of NT$97 billion was also approved for the government's "expanded national development program" as part of its third-year spending. The program calls for NT$500 billion over five years.

The legislature suddenly became efficient in screening the major budget proposals because both the ruling and opposition parties were under pressure from the public to "do something right" rather than engaging in their never-ending political feuding.

The extra session was called after both sides agreed to deal with an opposition-led motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian, a motion that failed to garner a two-thirds legislative majority vote to clear the legislative floor.
Premier Su Tseng-chang thanked the legislature for respecting public opinion by passing the major budget proposals on the final day of the special session.

DOC.HEADLINE: CADMIUM-CONTAMINATED RICE IN CHANGHUA DESTROYED: COA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has had all cadmium-contaminated rice in central Changhua County destroyed, officials claimed Friday.
A latest inspection conducted by the COA shows that rice produced from 12 paddy fields with a total area of 3.67 hectares in the county was contaminated with cadmium.
COA officials said the council will assist the affected farmers and will trace the source of the contamination.
If the contaminants exceed the permitted levels, the land will be forbidden from being used for planting food crops, they said.
Also Friday, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan confirmed that 22,000 kg of contaminated rice was incinerated two days ago under strict supervision.
Cho pledged that the county government will investigate the causes of the contamination and step up its crackdown on the polluters.

County government officials noted that the government has recovered 820 pieces of cropland with a total area of 184 hectares with techniques such as dilution and acid washing after they were discovered to have been contaminated with cadmium in 2003.
In some cases, the content of cadmium in rice is not necessarily related to the cadmium content in the soil but could be related to the pH levels of the soil and the strain of the rice, they claimed.
