DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER SEES NEWLY PASSED TREATMENT BILL 'NOT REFORMATORY ENOUGH'

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator said Friday that a newly passed amendment to the Statute Governing Preferential Treatment for Presidents and Vice Presidents is not "reformatory" enough to be fair to the people.
Legislator Lin Cho-shui said the amendment is not reform-minded enough and is far from "reasonable, " making it necessary for all the legislators to apologize to the Taiwan people.

The legislature passed the amendment on the last day of an extraordinary legislative session June 13-30 to handle 14 bills, including an opposition-initiated motion to recall President Chen Shui-bian. That motion failed.

Lin said that although the amended law cancels lifelong payments to retired presidents and vice presidents and dramatically curtails other preferential treatment, the treatment accorded to Taiwan's retired leaders is still too extravagant compared to that accorded to their counterparts in the United States, which has much higher per capita income than Taiwan's.

Lin said it is particularly unacceptable that the amendment still maintains preferential treatment in addition to monthly allowances for Taiwan's retired vice presidents. Retired U.S. vice presidents are given no preferential treatment besides a monthly allowance, he noted.

According to the amendment, a retired president is entitled to NT$250,000 (US$7,670) per month for a period as long as the number of years he or she served in the post. Other preferential treatment includes NT$8 million in office expenses in the first year of retirement, NT$7 million in the second year, NT$6 million for the third year and NT$5 million from the fourth year. Furthermore, a retired president will be provided with eight to 12 security personnel to protect his or her safety.

For a retired vice president, the monthly allowance is NT$180,000, with office expenses set at NT$4 million for the first year, NT$3.5 million for the second year, and NT$3 million for the third year and NT$2.5 million from the fourth year, plus the protection of four to eight security personnel.
Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus whip Pan Wei-kang said the amendment is helping institutionalize relevant government policy on treatment for retired national leaders.

Pan claimed that the amendment was not designed "to accommodate certain people" as implied by Vice President Annette Lu earlier in the day. Lu was referring to allegations that the move is designed as "punishment" for what the opposition sees as the ineptitude of Chen and his administration.

Lu Hsueh-chang, a legislative caucus party whip of the opposition People First Party, also expressed welcome to the passage of the amendment, saying that the law will help save money for the country to the tune of NT$68 million a year.
Former President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan are not subject to that amendment as the law will not be applied retroactively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYCOON CALLS ON GRADUATES TO TOPPLE 'MR. CHA BU DUO'
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 30 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: "Mr. Cha Bu Duo" or "Mr. Almost Good Enough" is a Chinese icon created by former Academia Sinica President Hu Shih, but for Hong Kong business tycoon Li Ka-shing, Mr. Almost Good Enough apparently is definitely not good enough, as he called on young people to topple the concept of Mr. Almost Good Enough.

During a speech to graduating students at Shantou University in China's Guangdong Province Thursday, according to the Friday edition of The Sun newspaper of Hong Kong, Li advised students not to be like Mr. Almost Good Enough, who "has eyes but does not see clearly; who has ears but does not hear clearly; who has a brain but does not think logically as he lacks insight."
Li deplored that Mr. Almost Good Enough remains alive and kicking, particularly in Chinese societies, where generations of people have come and gone since Hu Shih created him.

"Whenever I reread this great article by Hu Shih, I am shocked not only by Mr. Cha Bu Duo's pitiable ignorance but even more by how people around him have accepted his way of life -- people who feel complacent at being like him. I really want to cry over such a twisted way of wasting one's life that could have been spent much more wisely," Li said.

"If you want to shake off the shackles of destiny, " he suggested to the students, "be brave in thinking, respect science, honor principles, be able to feel and sense, dare to pursue, dare to care and act aggressively."
He encouraged the students to stand the tests of life but remain "people of integrity in the face of adversity, keeping love and kindness in your hearts."
Li, the wealthiest Chinese person in the world, recalled his early years when he was fleeing from war in China, not knowing what the future had in store for him.
"But even at that time, I was determined not to become another Mr. Cha Bu Duo, another Mr. Almost Good Enough. How about you? " he said in conclusion.

Hu Shih, a scholar who introduced the vernacular literary style to China in the early 20th Century, had considerable influence on modern China's cultural development. He also served as the Republic of China's ambassador to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WANTS TO CANCEL BUDGET FOR LATE PRESIDENTS' MAUSOLEUMS

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislators proposed Friday that the government cancel an annual budget for the maintenance of the mausoleums of late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo.

The lawmakers noted that the NT$70 million earmarked annually for the maintenance of the mausoleums is "obviously excessive" compared with the NT$15.2 million budgeted for the security of former presidents and vice presidents, which they claim gives the public the impression that "dead people enjoy better treatment than those who are still alive."

They put forth the proposal after the Legislative Yuan passed an amendment earlier in the day to cancel lifelong payments for former presidents and vice presidents and curtail the benefits accorded to retired leaders.
However, former President Lee Teng-hui and former Vice President Lien Chan, who stepped down in 2000, will not be affected by the change as it is not retroactive.

Ho Min-hao, head of the TSU's policy committee, said the amendment is inconsistent with the principle of "fairness and justice" because former presidents and vice presidents will only have eight to 12 security guards after the amendment, while a total of 129 workers, military policemen and honor guards are assigned for the maintenance of the two late presidents' mausoleums.
In addition, Ho said, while Lien is now receiving NT$470,000 per month, presidents and vice presidents who step down in the future will only get NT$250,000 per month.

TSU legislative caucus convener David Huang said there is no legal basis for the Ministry of National Defense to earmark an annual budget to maintain the mausoleums and assign soldiers to protect them and suggested that the remains of the two late presidents should be buried to save money.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% OPPOSITION SUPPORTERS OPPOSED TO TOPPLING CABINET: DPP POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of the supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" are opposed to a no-confidence motion to topple the Cabinet headed by Premier Su Tseng-chang, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The DPP released the result of its survey on the party's inaugural online newsletter in which it also gave a special report on the party's nominees for the year-end Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.

The survey was conducted June 21, one day after President Chen Shui-bian gave a televised address to respond to allegations of incompetence and corruption cited by the opposition for initiating the recall motion, which failed to pass the legislature Tuesday because it failed to get a two-thirds endorsement from the 221-seat legislature. But the opposition People First Party has vowed to continue to propose a no-confidence motion to build up the pressure on Chen and the DPP.

Asked about a no-confidence motion, 65.7 percent of those polled said Su is not involved in any alleged scandals and there is no need to topple his Cabinet, compared with 20.8 percent who said the Cabinet should be toppled.

Among those polled, 57.8 percent of those who claimed to be "pan-blue alliance" voters said there is no need to topple the Cabinet. If the Legislative Yuan proposes a non-confidence motion, 48 percent said Chen should dissolve the legislature and allow new legislative elections. Only 28.4 percent said Chen should replace Su.

The online newsletter will be published every Friday, and it will also appear irregularly to target specific issues, in the hope of increasing exchanges with grassroots members and providing them with the latest information from the party.
Tsai Huang-liang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said it is significant to launch the online newsletter on the 20th anniversary of the party's founding.
The newsletter will be mainly sent to party members in the initial stage, with a subscription system implemented in later stages.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN TURNS DOWN TALKS WITH DPP

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Friday that he has rejected invitations from Vice President Annette Lu and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun to have coffee with them and other political party leaders.
Soong made the remarks while expressing his views on the current political situation at home during a lunch gathering with PFP lawmakers.

According to Soong, Lu and Yu phoned his secretary and PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng, respectively, to relay the message. But Soong said that he turned down their invitations because "now is not the right time for such political meetings or talks."

The PFP chairman said he also asked Chin to tell Yu that he will not meet with ranking DPP officials unless Yu apologizes to the public on behalf of the DPP and draw a clear line with President Chen Shui-bian over a string of corruption allegations involving members of his family and close aides.
Soong said he will not let the people down by making them "misunderstand" that all politicians are keen on games of "power exchanges."

However, he then went on to comment on the PFP's plan to continue initiating a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet at the Legislative Yuan following a failed passage of a presidential recall motion Tuesday, saying that he was really disappointed with the matter and ascribed what he called a slow handling at the legislature to the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) changing attitude and what he claimed is "the DPP's cover up."
Soong said that he cannot understand why the KMT is hesitant about calling a no-confidence vote now that it only requires approval of 112 lawmakers, or half of the 221-member Legislative Yuan.

It was the second time that Lu made the offer to opposition political leaders to negotiate to stabilize Taiwan's politics. She first raised the idea last month but had to drop the plan due to cool response from Soong and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EVIDENCE TO SHOW GENETICALLY-MODIFIED FOOD UNSAFE: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: There is no evidence to show that genetically modified food is bad for people, an Academia Sinica researcher said Friday.

He Ruey-hua, director of Academia Sinica's Institute of Plant and Microbial Biology, noted that almost everyone in Taiwan might eat genetically-modified food every day in items such as bean curd or soybean milk.
He said the Taiwanese consume large amounts of genetically modified food, which is mainly imported from abroad.
According to He, Taiwan does not produce soybeans and mainly imports from the United States, where as much as 94 percent of soybeans are genetically modified.
Noting that Taiwan people began to eat genetically modified soybeans in 1996, he said there have been no recorded cases of health problems related to this kind of food.
There is groundswell of demand for genetically-modified food to be clearly labeled and much of it is.
However, He reminded farmers to pay heed to the safety of their products while cultivating genetically-modified crops.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 47% OF ENTERPRISES HAVE CHANGED SALARY STRUCTURE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The results of a survey released Friday show that nearly 47 percent of Taiwan enterprises have changed their salary structure in order to cope with the new pension system implemented last July.

A Taipei-headquartered online job search company, 1111 Manpower Bank, conducted the survey June 13-28 among local wage earners to find out whether they are beneficiaries or victims of the new system that took effect a year ago.

The results show that 66.45 percent of the enterprises that the respondent employees worked for are operating completely in line with the new pension system, while 18.27 percent have partially adopted the system and 10.63 percent have made no changes.

As to changes made in terms of salary structure, 41.84 percent of the respondents said their paychecks were cut, while 29.08 percent said their insurance coverage has been changed and 25.53 percent said their companies have submitted false salary figures to labor affairs authorities in order to cut their spending.
Under the new pension system, employers must deposit 6 percent of an employee's salary into their pension account each month, which the employees take with them whenever they change jobs.

According to Bureau of Labor Insurance statistics, 74.06 percent of employees around the country adopted the new pension system, while 25.94 percent chose to stay in the old one, under which an employee gets his or her pension after working for 25 consecutive years for the same enterprise or when they reach the age of 55 years and have worked for the same company for 15 consecutive years.
Under the old system, employees receive their pension in one lump sum, while under the new one, retired workers are eligible to receive a monthly pension for the rest of their life.

Asked whether the new system offers more secure pension guarantees, 43.52 percent of the respondents said they did not know, while 38.87 percent said they believe it offers a better guarantee and 17.61 percent said it does not.
The survey shows that most employees are still bewildered by the new system, 1111 Manpower Bank spokesman Wu Ruei-ying said.

Wu noted that no major flaws in the new pension system have been seen since it was put into effect a year ago. However, employees should still be aware of the system, particularly when they are transferred to a different post, as employers might try to offset their increased labor costs resulting from the new pension system by signing new labor contracts with employees, he warned.
A total of 1,204 effective samples were collected for the online survey, with a margin of error of 2.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS SEIZE SMUGGLED HEROIN IN YUNLIN COUNTY

TEXT.P: Officers of the Coast Guards Administration (CGA), assisted by local police and military police, arrested a drug trafficker Thursday and confiscated 2.5 kg of high-quality heroin with a street value of nearly NT$30 million.
Chang Chun-cheng, a resident of Yunlin County, was referred to the local public prosecutors office Friday.
A CGA spokesman said the CGA's detachment in Yunlin County received tip-offs three months ago about drug pushing in Taihsi township.

After three months of surveillance, the CGA officers learned that Chang was going with his wife to peddle heroin in Linnei township Thursday. A task force of CGA officers, local police and military police caught him red-handed and seized five heroin bricks weighing 2.5 kg along with more than one kg of amphetamine.
The task force found that Chang has asked acquaintances with no criminal records to smuggle heroin into Taiwan from China. Investigations are continuing to trace his buyers. (|By Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ADMITS FAULTS IN PERSONNEL CHANGE PROCEEDING

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Friday that the proceeding of naming a new finance minister was not "thoughtful" enough and that he will improve.

The premier made the remarks after some legislators expressed discontent about being kept in the dark about the abrupt replacement of Finance Minister Joseph Lyu with National Taiwan University Professor Ho Chih-chin, which was announced a day earlier.

Su said that Lyu, who assumed the post Jan. 25 and is the shortest-serving finance minister, had expressed his desire to leave his post several times. Lyu, who was criticized in several controversial financial cases, including the government's battle to keep control of Mega Financial Holding Co., has accepted an invitation to serve as a minister without portfolio.

Ho only returned to Taiwan three years ago after serving as a senior official at the U.S. Treasury Department and at the Justice Department for 15 years. A Ph.D holder in economics from Michigan University, Ho is known for his expertise in the fields of tax law and financial policy.

DPP Legislator Lin Chung-mo said that he has been on the legislature's Financial Committee for the past six years and yet even he did not know that Lyu was to be replaced. He also said he had no knowledge of the new finance minister.
Lin criticized the premier for displaying the "arrogance of power," saying that he should at least have given some notice.

If the Executive Yuan will not respect the DPP caucus, then the Executive Yuan and the DPP legislators should "go their separate ways" and the Ministry of Finance should solve its own problems without bothering to ask for assistance from the legislative committee.
President Chen Shui-bian, in a major announcement May 31, said that the will give a free hand to the premier on personnel appointments in the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLDIER OF ARMY HONOR GUARD INVESTIGATED FOR THREAT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A soldier of the Army Honor Guard was referred to investigators after calling for the assassination of the president on a Web site, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense said Friday.

Maj. Gen. Wu Chih-fang said the soldier, identified as Chiu Chao-kang, has been removed from the Army Honor Guard after army authorities received complaints that he called for the assassination of President Chen Shui-bian in a chat room.

The spokesman said the Defense Ministry regrets that a soldier would make a threat against the president, although it is sure that Chiu has not formed a "gangster organization" in the army and that his statement on the Web site did not reflect on other members of the armed forces.
A preliminary investigation by the army has determined that Chiu's remarks were simply rhetoric, the spokesman added.

According to local news reports, the army took Chiu's threat seriously because as a member of the honor guard, which often attends national events presided over by the president, he would have had the chance to follow through with his threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS ON CHINA VISITS BY CIVIL SERVANTS RELAXED

TEXT.P: The legislature passed an amendment Friday to allow lower-ranking civil servants and policemen to travel to China without applying for permission in advance.
The legislature passed the amendment on the last day of an extraordinary legislative session that began June 13 to handle 14 bills.

According to the amendment, lower-ranking public functionaries and policemen whose work does not involve national security or intelligence, do not need to apply for prior permission before visiting China for tourism or to visit relatives.
The opposition-dominated legislature also demands that the Ministry of the Interior draft enforcement rules within three months for the implementation of the new amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES CNA TO CONTRIBUTE MORE TO TAIWAN'S GLOBALIZATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the Central News Agency Friday to contribute more to Taiwan's globalization in the coming decades.
Lu expressed her hope in a speech delivered at a ceremony to mark CNA's 10th anniversary as Taiwan's national news agency and its 82nd founding anniversary.

Acknowledging CNA's consistent leading role in Taiwan's news services, Lu said CNA should take the lead in upgrading the quality of news reports. Noting that Taiwan's news media has an obsession with sensationalism, Lu said she hopes local media outlets can respect "people's rights to know, not to know and not to be known, " referring to respect for other people's privacy.
She also suggested that the domestic news media give more coverage to international news events to enhance local people's global perspective and vision.
Noting that CNA has contributed a great deal to disseminating information about Taiwan's development, Lu said CNA should play an even more active role in promoting Taiwan's globalization.

In addition to Lu, many other guests attended the celebration ceremony at a Taipei hotel, including Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen, party brass, government officials, academics and business executives.

Representatives from major international news organizations, including Business Wire, Associated Press, Reuters, AFP, Yonhap, Kyodo, JiJi Press, Thailand News Agency, Bloomberg News and the United News of India News Agency, also traveled to Taipei for the celebration ceremony.

Addressing the ceremony, CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping said CNA has pulled out all the stops over the years to be a credible news provider, offering updated, precise, objective and non-biased news services.

With a comprehensive round-the-island news-gathering network, Su said CNA has decided to open a new "Taiwan roundup" Web site to help people at home and abroad better understand true Taiwan as well as its charms and characteristics.

Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen pushed the button to inaugurate the new Web site at the anniversary celebration ceremony. The new Wed site will specialize in grassroots news reports, particularly those related to social customs, cultural heritage, historical relics, tourist attractions and lifestyles, as well as major development projects, sports and artistic activities in various cities and counties.

A day earlier, as part of its efforts to promote international information exchanges and cooperation, CNA signed cooperative agreements with U.S.-based Business Wire and South Korea's Yonhap News Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN AIMS TO CUT DRUNK DRIVING ACCIDENTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Beverage Alcohol Forum launched a campaign Friday in an attempt to prevent people in Taiwan from driving while intoxicated.

Chang Chin-kai, chairman of the charitable organization, told a news conference that the campaign, similar to the "Bob campaign" in Europe, aims to raise awareness of the dangers of drunk driving by asking each group of friends or colleagues to designate a driver, a "Bob," who does not drink and has the responsibility of driving home the others at the end of the event.
Chang added that his organization launched the campaign because drinking-related road accidents in Taiwan have been on the rise.
The campaign is supported by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Department of Transportation under the Taipei city government and tourism circles.
Lin Chih-yin, Taipei's top official in charge of transportation affairs, cited figures showing that traffic police handled 19,000 drunk driving cases in the city last year.
Lin added that according to poll results, more than 80 percent of Taipei's residents support strict enforcement of the law against drunk driving.
The Bob campaign originated in Belgium in 1995 when government departments, police and the Belgian beer brewing industry worked out the concept of "designated drivers" to curb drunk driving.
The government of Belgium claims the campaign has triggered a change in mentality, with 80 percent of its population considering drinking and driving to be unacceptable.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT STILL MULLING NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) remains likely to call for a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet as a means of pressuring President Chen Shui-bian to step down if the party's legislative caucus approves of the measure, KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po quoted Chairman Ma Ying-jeou as saying Friday.
According to Chan, Ma made the remarks during a meeting with the KMT's legislative caucus earlier the same day.

Chan revealed that Ma also hailed the performance of the 89 KMT lawmakers who all cast a "yes" vote to recall Chen June 27 at the Legislative Yuan, leaving a good historical example of the Republic of China's constitutional practices.
The KMT will also continue a nationwide campaign to solicit public endorsement for Chen's ouster, hoping to collect at least 3 million signatures in the short-term, Chan said.

Later the same day, legislative caucus whips of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) announced that they have forged a consensus on launching a no-confidence vote at the legislature to topple the Cabinet and to pressure President Chen to step down.
The two parties found common ground on the issue after PFP legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang visited his Kuomintang (KMT) counterpart Pan Wei-kang earlier the same day.
Pan said that the KMT and PFP stand firm on their stances that Chen must step down to take responsibility for a spate of corruption allegations involving members of his family and close aides.
The two parties share the same desire for Chen's ouster, evident by the fact that all KMT and PFP lawmakers cast a "yes" vote to recall Chen in a legislative motion Tuesday, Pan said.
Pan stressed that "calling a no-confidence vote has always been one of our options," but pointed out that when such a proposal should be made at the Legislative Yuan has yet to be decided.

She said the KMT has set up a task force to continue demanding Chen's ouster and has asked each lawmaker to hold at least 10 seminars in July to explain the party's cause to voters in their constituencies.

The KMT decided at a June 3 plenary meeting that its legislative caucus and Policy Coordination Committee will be in charge of assessing the no-confidence vote issue and that "toppling the Cabinet has always been one possible option for the KMT, " she said, adding that the timing of a no-confidence vote in the legislature remains undecided.
Lu said that it is understandable if it takes more time for the KMT to consolidate opinions over the issue, given that it is the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.

PFP lawmaker Lee Hung-jun said that the PFP hopes to continue cooperating with the KMT in calling the no-confidence vote "in order to allow the public to examine the ruling Democratic Progressive Party again."
PFP lawmaker Chao Liang-yen said she believes that as long as a new legislature can be elected, a new public mandate will undoubtedly demand Chen's ouster.
KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po quoted party Chairman Ma Ying-jeou as saying earlier the same day that the KMT is not opposed to proposing a no-confidence vote at the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITAL CITIES CONVENTION TAIPEI TO PROMOTE WI-FI SERVICES

TEXT.P: Delegates at the 2006 Digital Cities Convention Taipei adopted a joint communique Friday calling on governments to work together to build an infrastructure facilitating the use of wireless communications technology.

The joint statement, approved by foreign delegates and local government representatives from Taipei and Miaoli counties and Hsinchu and Tainan cities, pledged to build a policy discussion mechanism and to promote industrial standards for wireless Internet services.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wi-Fi services are expected to cover 90 percent of the city by next month, where 23 million people will be able to get Wi-Fi services from 4,000 access points.
The city's wireless network was named by JiWire, which maintains the world's most complete directory of verified public Wi-Fi hotspots, the largest and densest Wi-Fi network in the world.

Ma said the ultimate purpose of the city's wireless Internet connection program is to boost the city's competitiveness. Ever since he became mayor in 1998, he noted, he has been pushing for the project so the city has become the first in Taiwan to offer free e-mail services to its citizens.
The city government has also been promoting the use of computers at schools, data-searching skills and e-learning for students and ordinary citizens, he added.
Now the city's Wi-Fi coverage, data transmission speed and relevant technologies have all been recognized and certified by international organizations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP FORMS AN ALLIANCE TO WORK TOWARD TAIWAN'S PUBLIC WELFARE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Friday that she has forged an alliance comprised of several civil groups that are working on promoting public's welfare in Taiwan.

At a press conference held at the Presidential Office, Lu said although the crisis of recalling President Chen Shui-bian has temporarily abated, the society remains rancorously divided over political stances and ethnicity, which she said has seriously damaged Taiwan's image and spurred her to promote the alliance.

An opposition-proposed motion to recall Chen over a string of corruption allegations implicating members of the first family and Chen's close aides failed to gain the two-thirds approval required by the Constitution in the 221-seat legislature June 27.

To stress her determination to promote harmonious relations in the country, Lu had invited the country's main political leaders to a summit in early June to discuss ways of stabilizing the volatile domestic political situation; however, the summit failed to go forward due to cool response from political figures.
Lu said Friday she still hopes to hold the summit and that her alliance calls for rational consultation and competition amongst different political parties and integrity of the administration.
The alliance will also push the legislature to approve nominations for the posts of president, vice president and members of the Control Yuan, as well as the "Sunshine Law" to prevent corruption.

The alliance also urges the Legislative Yuan to speedily pass major bills related to the country's defense and people's welfare, and called for an independent judicial system to ensure justice, and an effective media that can help "purify" society.

According to Lu, the alliance will hold different panels from July to December to discuss topics such as anti-corruption efforts, social order, moral reconstruction, education, industrial development, the economic environment for investors and Taiwan's globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY RATES TO GO UP JULY 1

TEXT.P: Domestic electricity rates will increase starting Saturday, with an average 5.8 percent hike depending on the type of electricity consumption.

However, households or small shops that use less than 330 kw/hours per month will not see a rate increase, while prices in terms of electricity consumption for industries will see an average hike of 7.63 percent, according to Taiwan Power Company's (Taipower's) new electricity rates.
The last time Taipower raised electricity rates was in 1981. The upcoming hike is to release the company from suffering serious losses caused by rising fuel costs in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT FINANCIER GETS 8-YEAR JAIL TERM IN ZANADU DEVELOPMENT CASE

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang (KMT) Business Management Committee Chairman Liu Tai-ying was found guilty Friday of misappropriation of funds and several other charges and sentenced to a combined eight years in jail in the much reported Zanadu Development Corp. case.
The Taipei District Court meanwhile acquitted Liu of charges that he took commissions from Zanadu, Taiwan Fertilizer, Taiwan Pineapple and other companies.

The scandal erupted in September 2002 when Su Hui-chen, Zanadu's vice president and principle shareholder, accused Liu of taking more than NT$1 billion from her in exchange for helping secure a syndicated bank loan for her company.

As a host of irregularities and illegal practices have been suspected, involving quite a number of business and political heavyweights, former president Lee Teng-hui and vice president Lien Chan had appeared in court to provide testimony in the case.

In June 2005, former Taiwan Fertilizer Chairman Hsieh Sheng-fu was convicted and sentenced to 14 years in jail, Su to eight years behind bars, and Yu Chen Yueh-ying -- a former Kaohsiung County magistrate and Democratic Progressive Party politician -- to one year and six months.

On Friday, Liu was found guilty of six counts of violating the tax code, business accounting law and corporate law. He was given sentences ranging from three months to two years and 10 months for a combined eight-year sentence.
Liu's lawyer Chen Sung-tung said Liu might appeal because prosecutors had "mistakenly believed in" Su's accusations against the defendant.
Chen said he made his statement on the basis that of the 12 "facts" prosecutors had charged Liu with, eight were found to be in Liu's favor.

In connection with the case, former legislator Lin Ming-yi was sentenced to eight months in jail for breaking business accounting law; businessman Hsieh Wen-chin was given a term of one year and six months for embezzlement; and three China Development Financial Holding Co. officials -- Chen Kun-yung, Chen Jui-hsun and Yang Ching-lan -- were given probation on terms ranging from eight months to one year and two months.

Shih Che-hsiung, China Development's vice president, was sentenced to three terms -- four months, one year and four months, and one year -- for a combined two-year-six-month sentence after being convicted of several charges of embezzlement and breaking the tax code and business accounting law.

Su Chih-jen, brother of former president Lee's secretary Su Chih-cheng, was charged with breach of trust and the prosecution in this case requested a three-year-nine-month sentence for him. Su fled the country in October 2002, becoming a fugitive suspect.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONDEMNED FOR BLUNDER CAUSING ELECTRICITY PRICE HIKE

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan adopted a resolution Friday condemning President Chen Shui-bian for halting construction on the fourth nuclear power plant in 2000, making electricity price hikes inevitable for Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) to make up for huge losses.

A total of 110 legislators -- mostly opposition legislators -- in the 210-seat legislature voted for the resolution, which also condemns former Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and former Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's decision to cancel the fourth nuclear power plant project in October 2000 on grounds it wanted to create a nuclear-free homeland.

Although the government changed its mind in February 2001 and allowed construction on the project to resume, state-owned Taipower suffered such huge losses that the national treasury had to spend NT$216.5 billion to cover extra budgets, interests and increased costs for generating electricity.
Taipower has announced that it will hike electricity rates July 1 for an extra revenue of NT$30 billion to maintain a financial balance.

The legislators of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party claimed the price hike is a consequence of the DPP government trying to govern the nation by placing ideology ahead of the well-being of its people.
They said they passed the resolution in hopes that similar blunders will not occur again to harm the interests of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA UNHAPPY WITH JAPAN'S CHASE OF TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT

TEXT.P: The government has expressed "grave concern" over Japan's treatment of a Taiwanese fishing boat allegedly intruding into Japan's exclusive economic zone, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.

Lu was referring to the Fuhsiang No. 16, a fishing boat from Taipei county's Chinshan township which was chased by Japanese coast guard patrols while operating in waters some 292 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan Thursday.

The Coast Guard Administration immediately sent a patrol to the disputed area, but Japanese authorities insisted on slapping the Taiwanese fishing boat with a fine of 4 million yen on the ground that the Fuhsiang had transcended the "temporary demarcation line" and intruded into its exclusive economic zone.

According to reports from Okinawa, coast guard patrols and fishing boats from the two countries have continued a standoff in the open seas. The eigh crew members aboard the Fuhsiang vessel are all safe and healthy, the reports said.

Lu said Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chang Hsiao-yueh met with Tadashi Ikeda, Japan's representative in Taiwan, Friday afternoon to express the government's "grave concern" over Japan's handling of the incident.

Chang was quoted as having told Ikeda that bilateral fishing disputes should be resolved through consultations and negotiations. According to the ship's owner, the Fuhsiang consistently operated within the "temporary demarcation line" Thursday and didn't intruded into the Japanese economic zone.

Because of their conflicting claim over the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea, Taiwan and Japan have often been embroiled in fishing disputes. The waters surrounding the Tiaoyutais have been Taiwan's traditional fishing grounds, but Japan has claimed rights over the areas since the United States handed over control of the island group along with Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
Japan has since often detained or fined Taiwan fishing boats operated in the disputed waters. The two countries had held 15 rounds of talks since 1996, but failed to come to terms.

To better protect Taiwanese fishing boats, the government has designated the center line in the two countries' overlapping economic zones as the "temporary demarcation line" and vowed to protect the safety and fishing rights of Taiwanese fishing boats operating within that line.
During Friday's talks, Chang urged Ikeda to push Japan to hold a new round of fishery talks with Taiwan as soon as possible to settle the longrunning disputes.

The 16th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks was originally scheduled for June, but was canceled due to great differences between the two sides on certain fundamental issues, mainly their conflicting sovereignty claim over the Tiaoyutais.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU FIELDS CANDIDATE FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislator Lo Chih-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) announced Friday that he will represent the party in December's mayoral election in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city after Taipei.

Lo hailed Kaohsiung's progress over the past eight years under the leadership of former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and incumbent acting mayor Yeh Chu-lan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, but claimed the city needs a better economic policies and sound management in order to attract more investment.

Lo promised to build Kaohsiung into a modern city where citizens can enjoy a healthy environment, vibrant economy and good way of life, and expressed confidence that as mayor he would demonstrate "clean, " visionary, creative and active qualities.
Lo faces competition by DPP candidate Chen Chu and Kuomintang (KMT) rival Huang Chun-ying in the year-end election.

Although many consider Lo to have no chance of winning the election due to the DPP's impressive support in Kaohsiung, Lo has repeatedly vowed he will not pull out of the race, claiming that he could save the "pan-green" camp at a time when his rival Chen was suspected of playing a role in corruption scandals related to the construction of the city's mass rapid transit system.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: After Ruling, Uncertainty Hovers at Cuba Prison
As the U.S. Supreme Court prepared to rule on the Bush administration's plan to try terror suspects before special military tribunals here, the commander of Guantanamo's military detention center was asked what impact the court's decision might have on its operations. The Defense Department repeated that the court's sweeping ruling against the tribunals did not undermine the government's argument that it can hold foreign suspects indefinitely and without charge, as "enemy combatants" in its declared war on terror. Privately, though, some administration officials involved in detention policy -- along with many critics of that policy -- were skeptical that Guantanamo could or would go about its business as before.
Wall Street Journal: Trial and Error, Justices Bar Guantanamo Tribunals
In a withering opinion handed down on the last day of its term, the U.S. Supreme Court declared unlawful the Bush administration's military tribunals, an alternative legal system established to prosecute enemy prisoners without granting them traditional rights found in courts-martial. The tribunals were among the first and most far-reaching of White House responses to the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER REMAINS TAIWAN'S NO.1 KILLER

TEXT.P: Cancer remained Taiwan's No. 1 killer in 2005 for the 24th year in a row, accounting for more than 26 percent of fatalities, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.
On average, cancer claimed a life in Taiwan about every 14 minutes and seven seconds, DOH officials said.
Thanks to the DOH's active promotion of early screening, the cancer mortality has declined in recent years, the officials said.

Nevertheless, the officials added that the incidence of colon & rectal cancer, female breast cancer and oral cancer has increased probably because of Westernized diet, higher fat intake, insufficient exercise, smoking and men's habit of chewing betel nuts.

The ranking of top 10 causes of death in 2005 remained almost same as in 2004, with cancer followed in order by stroke, heart disease, diabetes, accidents, pneumonia, chronic liver disease, kidney disease, suicide and hypertension-related diseases.
